sentence: It needs diverse use so we’re capturing all the risks

sentence: Industry is IT?

sentence: Absolutely

sentence: You're not separating?  You see it quite organically as an interactive thing?

author: A
sentence: We’re very separate structurally, absolutely

author: A
sentence: But the decisions that we make, probably have the biggest impact on the employees

author: A
sentence: The culture, even the budget that we’ve agreed, we chose and I pushed for a very aggressive budget target

author: A
sentence: If we didn’t - and that’s had a massive impact on the organisation, both in terms of stretching it

author: A
sentence: That decision alone has changed everything about that business

author: A
sentence: It’s changed the structure, the conflict, the people they need in certain positions

author: A
sentence: The flow on impacts of that, were probably the biggest that they've had, the biggest change that’s happened to that business

author: A
sentence: That’s an example of how one decision, relating to one number that was a board decision, has flowed through and affected all employees, culture, HR, everything

author: Q
sentence: You knew that because of the diversity on the board?

sentence: Yes, because particularly because of like Chris had had a similar circumstance before, and so had I, we were able to triangulate and say, if we run the same play here, and stretch, go for a stretch, we’re going to have an outcome, a better outcome, so we pushed for it

author: Q
sentence: Is Chris the investor?

author: A
sentence: Chris is the investor, so it’s Chris and myself, pushing for a higher budget than the founders

author: Q
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q
sentence: So, you right, okay

sentence: This is so different to other much literature that really doesn’t give voice to this kind of thing, so it’s fabulous

sentence: I just want you to understand, i want more of it

author: Q
sentence: Now I'd like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards?  You've talked about it a bit

author: Q
sentence: How such conflict is managed

author: Q
sentence: I want you, because you’ve made it central, conflict is central to the process

author: Q
sentence: Can you explain the process of how you as chair, manage conflict constructively, to problem solve and strategies?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so before each board meeting, we get the board papers, and each person individually will review them and have their own comments and points to make

author: A
sentence: Then we come in to the board meeting, and then we quickly - things where there is agreement, we just don’t really spend much time on, and we’re really fishing for the areas of conflict, to bottom them out

author: A
sentence: Then it’s really just a - it’s a discussion that’s moderated by me as the chair, and it’s timebound and we try and distil what’s really the difference of perspective and difference of view

author: A
sentence: Then we just try and get as crisp as we can to enunciate, like what are the people’s different views?  Then set out a process for resolving them

author: A
sentence: So, it’s a smoke detector, it’s a compliance business, they do smoke detector inspections and gas inspections and stuff like that

author: A
sentence: It’s actually a sort of technology and compliance business

author: A
sentence: When it came to the budget, it was, well why don’t you model out three different scenarios, and then we’ll have an interim meeting between now and the next board meeting, to work out what each of those scenarios would mean and where we’d land

author: A
sentence: It’s more of a process for resolution, that’s pretty specific to the subject matter usually

author: A
sentence: Another one was, so I felt that as a board member, as a non-executive director, I hadn’t invested in the business, like I was just paid, I'm just paid

author: A
sentence: I felt that the other three directors have invested, like significantly

author: A
sentence: I thought that in order for me to really make sure that I'm highly better aligned to the business and the board, I should invest myself as well

author: A
sentence: So,I asked to invest, and that was a controversial decision, because they don’t like other people investing in the business, a tightly held company

author: A
sentence: There was effectively conflict around that, it wasn't like ding dong conflict, but the founders weren't interested, the other investor was, I was

author: A
sentence: So again, we went through a process of where they got together between the board meetings, discussed it, positives and negatives

author: A
sentence: Then we tabled it at the next board meeting, we discussed it and then they made a decision at the following board meeting

author: A
sentence: So, there’s common that we don’t all agree, but then between one board meeting and another, we’ll get to agreement

author: A
sentence: Because the whole thing, business moves pretty quickly so there's not many things that we can really afford to now sort of chew over for too long

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you have - what about if there’s a values conflict?  You've described it like what I see as a problem-solving process

author: Q
sentence: What about if there’s a values conflict?

author: A
sentence: So, have we had an example of a values conflict yet?  I think we’re pretty aligned on values

author: A
sentence: I think it’s not so much about the values of the board members, but the values of the company, which is set by the founders

author: A
sentence: In some ways the values of the company need to be owned and ingested by the board members

author: A
sentence: So, if the board members don’t adopt those values, then they either need to try and change them, or probably get off the board I'd suggest

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so they're a given, they're like a framework for the board?

author: A
sentence: Well they're a given for the board, and then if the board, yeah again, so if I've joined a company and they're all about, like I'm a vegetarian for example

author: A
sentence: If they were all about eating meat, I'd be either say well I don’t want to be on that board, or I propose that we change

author: A
sentence: It’s a constraint on the board

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and you wouldn't be on the board of an abattoir then?

author: A
sentence: No, so that's right

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting when you say they, because I think there’s personal values of directors, which could be very difficult between directors

author: A
sentence: But I think that the values of the company should trump the values of the actual board members, when it comes to making decisions

author: A
sentence: Because the board is there to represent the board and the shareholders, which are encapsulated in the values of that, the shareholders and the board

author: A
sentence: Not the personal values of the director

author: Q
sentence: That’s the only board you've sat on so far?

author: Q
sentence: When you talked about the impacts on employees and things, where does that value, that concern for employees?  Where does that come from?  Is that part of the investors?  Or is that part of stakeholders?  Or is that the founders?

author: A
sentence: So, in this circumstance, I think that it comes equally from each of the directors

author: A
sentence: The voice of employees at the board level, is one of the voices that we consider

author: A
sentence: It’s like shareholders, employees, and I'm not sure what other stakeholders we’re really focused on, and investors

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the shareholders, employees, investors

author: A
sentence: Interestingly, the shareholders and the investors are represented at the table, but the employees aren’t specifically represented at the table

author: A
sentence: I think that there’s just a shared acknowledgment, that without employees, without them on board and looking after them, we don’t really have a business

author: A
sentence: There's never really - there hasn’t yet been an issue where the interests of employees has been subservient

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting -

author: Q
sentence: There hasn’t been a conflict over how to manage that?

author: A
sentence: There hasn’t been, but it’s interesting, because if there was a conflict at the moment, I fear that because there’s no specific employee representation, that would be a problem

author: A
sentence: I wonder whether there should be more employee representation on boards?  AN IT COMPANY, because I used to report to that board, as an executive, there wasn’t employee representation either, shareholders yeah

author: Q
sentence: But you reported to the board?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, Ireported to the board as a manager there

author: A
sentence: But when I look at the board structure -

author: Q
sentence: That's how they got the voice?

author: A
sentence: - I'm like yeah, but yeah, they got a voice because management advocated for employees

author: A
sentence: I think that you're probably just, I think in this day and age, it just goes without saying, if you're not looking after employees, you're kind of not going to have a business for very long

author: A
sentence: It probably doesn’t need specific representation on the board level

author: Q
sentence: Unless you had some really narrow minded, narrow focused person who just look, all that matters is shareholder wealth at the moment, and be damned, you know?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so there are circumstances like that right

author: A
sentence: I sat on the board of my own start-up, as a director of that as well, for a few years

author: A
sentence: That's probably the only other one, we had actually board meetings and everything else

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you can be bought out or something

author: A
sentence: That’s right, so some private equity company’s come in and buy the business and just carve it up, and whatever happens to the employees happens, we’ll try and make some money on the way through

author: A
sentence: I think that’s a certain motive operating that exists, and in which case they wouldn’t want the voice of employees on the board, in any event

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and would they want diversity?

author: A
sentence: No, they just need to get a job done

author: Q
sentence: So that’s probably one situation, with these acquisitions sort of thing?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so like carve ups, yeah, that would be one scenario

author: A
sentence: They don’t really need diversity, but they're not - I would suggest they're not really acting as a board, like in that sense, because they're really just, they're just carrying out a certain mission, on behalf

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so a lack of diversity would actually be a benefit in that circumstance, where you just want to get something done quickly, and single-mindedly, and yeah

author: Q
sentence: But that’s a very isolated situation?

author: A
sentence: It is an isolated situation

author: Q
sentence: And short-term?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and probably not sustainable as well

author: A
sentence: Like I'm thinking about other projects that are short-term and very focused, like let’s say you're doing the cross-city tunnel or something

author: A
sentence: You go we just need to get a tunnel across the city

author: A
sentence: But even then, you can’t just say, just dig and dig and dig, and just keep digging, and make sure you get your 50 metres of tunnel a day

author: A
sentence: Because you've got environmental constraints and all sorts of crazy stuff, so you need to oversee for that too

author: Q
sentence: You can draw from either one?

author: Q
sentence: Because I was wondering also, another value that might not be shared, which hasn’t come up, is the environment, and some board members mightn’t really care, and others might, in your board

author: Q
sentence: Have you made decisions that might bring that to the fore?  Conflict over that?

author: A
sentence: Not related to the environment, no

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so -

author: A
sentence: We've made a lot that relate to customers and the health and wellbeing of customers and the safety, because it’s a compliance business

author: A
sentence: I think that there’s just a shared view that the business is - the success of the business is underwritten on making sure that at the end of the day, tenants are safe in their houses

author: A
sentence: It’s kind of unwritten that that is something that we need to do

author: Q
sentence: Now I'd like to explore how diversity might contribute, oh we’ve done that, we’ve done that, I love the way you talk about conflict

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity, so by this we mean different approaches to problem solving, different perspectives

author: Q
sentence: You opened on this

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that it influenced your board’s functioning?  You made it central

author: Q
sentence: Oh right, how might cognitive diversity, because you opened with that, how it influences problem solving, to manage risk and complexity

author: Q
sentence: How might cognitive diversity be identified, for example if selecting new board members?

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, that’s an interesting one

author: A
sentence: I guess you just need to test how people would think through certain problems in a case study environment, would probably be the easiest

author: Q
sentence: Hop ons?  What did you say?

author: A
sentence: Problems

author: Q
sentence: Oh problems, you can obviously see I have a technology background

author: A
sentence: No, so exploring, tell me about how you thought through a certain issue, that would expose someone's way of thinking

author: A
sentence: Yeah, cognitive diversity is important, like I think it’s almost like the, I don’t know how you describe it?  The personality is an important one, when I think of the board that we have at the moment

author: A
sentence: We have not much diversity in terms of personality

author: A
sentence: If we did a Meyers Briggs, I reckon we’d all land pretty similar

author: A
sentence: Something that we find valuable here, is that everybody has a very different personality profile, and it’s actually pretty challenging working with people with a different personality profile

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you mean here?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, in my workplace

author: Q
sentence: In your business?  Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so at the board level, we can actually move faster, because we’re all pretty much the same types of personalities

author: A
sentence: We sort of just dispassionately break down issues, work out what the right answer is, move on, be quite transactional

author: A
sentence: Whereas, others that might need to settle in to the idea a bit more, think about it more, whatever might feel more discomfort in that environment

author: A
sentence: Interestingly Margo, before you came, a couple of hours ago I was having a chat with one of our employees, where I came out of a meeting, and I was completely excited and jazzed, like a client meeting

author: A
sentence: They were just nonplussed, and I was probably at a 10 out of 10, and they were one out of 10

author: A
sentence: I knew based on their profile that they would probably be a two or a three out of 10, but I was surprised that they were one out of 10, in terms of emotional excitement

author: A
sentence: I had to sit down and say what’s going on?  I kind of expected you to be pretty low energy, but not this low

author: A
sentence: It was a pretty brutal meeting actually, because they felt offended that I was even calling it out

author: A
sentence: I was like this is so obvious that I have to call it out

author: A
sentence: They were like but you’re making judgments about my emotional response to something and I can’t affect that

author: A
sentence: I was just trying to say, but I need to understand what it is, so I can actually understand

author: A
sentence: We don’t have any of that stuff on the current board that I'm in, because we have probably not much cognitive diversity because we all approach problems cognitively, we process them in the same way

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well you're the chair, would you want to expand the board to increase cognitive diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Given the importance you place on it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Is that something you plan to do?

author: Q
sentence: With the start-up of course, that was another?

author: A
sentence: I hadn’t thought of it until now

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting, because at what point do you reach a tipping point of more, like the board is highly effective at the moment, and efficient

author: A
sentence: Adding in another voice might - we will become less efficient, but we would cover off more - we’d be more thorough and possibly cover off more risks

author: A
sentence: So, we’ll try probably balancing efficiency with risk, with our current composition

author: A
sentence: There is a question about whether there are risks that we’re missing, because we’re probably over indexing on efficiency at the moment

author: A
sentence: But the type of people we are, and the type of business it is, I think we prefer to over index on efficiency, particularly at the stage of business, because it’s small and fast moving and technology and we can - if we see a risk, even if we see it a bit later than we otherwise would

author: A
sentence: We can actually react to it faster and solve it anyway

author: A
sentence: So, we’re probably making the right balance

author: Q
sentence: Do you think, that’s interesting, first of all, do you think risk and efficiency are always intention?  Like two ends of a spectrum?

author: A
sentence: I'd like to think not, but I reckon -

author: Q
sentence: You've got risk and complexity, you sort of had combined, is that like intention with efficiency?

author: A
sentence: So probably not, I think that you could have a scenario where you're highly efficient and still able to get a lot of like diversity and manage complexity and manage a lot of risk

author: A
sentence: It’s probably not - it’s probably a short, you're right, there’s a short-term trade off

author: A
sentence: Because if we brought someone else in like next month, it would take four, five months before we’d get the level of efficiency that we have today

author: A
sentence: That’s probably just intertemporarally you'd take the hit

author: Q
sentence: It would be an investment?

author: A
sentence: It's an investment

author: Q
sentence: Do you think sometimes risk and opportunity are seen as similar?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, there could be some opportunity costs as well, if you don’t have - I mean you haven’t -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yeah totally, so you're right, you're totally right

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a board, you’re probably more focused on risk than opportunity, like I am

author: Q
sentence: And you're an entrepreneur?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Because I think because the business itself and the strategy -

author: Q
sentence: Is up there?

author: A
sentence: Is up, there’s such a big opportunity and they're running at it anyway

author: A
sentence: I've got to keep the risks in check

author: Q
sentence: Okay, gotcha, but this is not, the business that you're on the board of, it’s not entrepreneurial?

author: A
sentence: Yeah it is

author: Q
sentence: It is?

author: A
sentence: They're really entrepreneurial?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, I thought when you talk compliance, I think it’s something?

author: Q
sentence: That’s good, you can compare the two positions, it might be relevant, might not

author: Q
sentence: First, how does the composition on boards that you're familiar with, how have they changed over time, in terms of diversity do you think?

author: A
sentence: Oh no, it’s really entrepreneurial

author: A
sentence: These guys basically have these technology platform, they’ve got 60 - you've probably seen them on the road, well you will now Detector Inspector

author: A
sentence: They go around doing smoke detector inspections for rental properties, for landlords, and so they’ve got a technology platform, that basically arranges for all of theseengineers to go around and check smoke detectors, and make sure they're compliant and they're working and blah blah blah

author: A
sentence: They’ve got aspirations in terms of opportunity, to enter in to different states and do different services, not just smoke detectors, but gas and all sorts of other services

author: Q
sentence: Yeah water?

author: A
sentence: Water and all sorts of other checks, and even just landlord checks

author: A
sentence: If you've got a rental property then your landlord can come in a couple of times a year and just check that everything’s okay, like property inspection checks

author: A
sentence: That’s another thing they can branch out in to

author: A
sentence: There’s a lot of opportunity for them, each month we’re talking about buying different businesses and investing in different stuff

author: A
sentence: I sort of don’t need to worry about that, because the DNA of the business is high opportunity focus

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so that's a bias in our discussion, that because you are focused on highly innovative businesses?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, only fast-moving innovative businesses

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so risk is predominant, however you’ve said that opportunity would be there if it was, you know -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, opportunity’s baked in to the business already, so I need to worry about risk

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but if it was Epworth Hospital or something like that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, if it was Epworth, where it wasn’t about opportunity, and risk was sorted out because everything about the hospitals all about risk, and I'd be like where are the opportunities?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly, you’d be [unclear] 00:46:18?

author: A
sentence: And commerce

author: A
sentence: The board that I joined eight months ago, so that was deliberately with a view to gain diversity, because the business had just gained investment, and the private equity, sorry the venture capital fund that invested in it, wanted more diverse views on the board, so that’s why they brought myself in

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think what happened was, we actually dealt with a lot of the opportunity of the business by canonising a strategy that’s like a three-year strategy, early in my - so we did that in the first quarter of me joining the board

author: A
sentence: I was like we don’t have a good strategy, let’s get that sorted

author: A
sentence: The opportunities kind of taken care of by the strategy and then the budget, which I explained to you before

author: A
sentence: Which is like pretty stretched

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and you've only been there eight months?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s been a pretty crazy transformation, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Anyway, that’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so selecting new board members, you’ve said right, you use like a case study

author: Q
sentence: We’re on the last page

author: Q
sentence: Now managing diversity

author: Q
sentence: When identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity, and how is it done?

author: A
sentence: No, it was done pretty ad hoc

author: A
sentence: They were basically charged with just get another director, and get that done

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and law’s good?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I don’t even think they looked at it in that detail

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think the guys probably knew that I was a lawyer until a few months ago

author: Q
sentence: That’s really funny

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence this selection process do you think?

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: What importance do you think diverse boards have, 10 extremely, one, none?

author: A
sentence: No, not for that

author: Q
sentence: Your financial fellow did?  Oh, but he’s on the board now?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, he’s on the board

author: Q
sentence: The investor?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Because his is often like superannuation funds and that are big investors in the companies?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: But this is not like that?

author: A
sentence: No, that’s right, so there’s nothing like that, it’s pretty small stakes

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and he’s on the board?

author: A
sentence: Oh 10, yeah 10, it’s all about the diversity of the view, yeah

author: A
sentence: He’s already on the board that investor

author: A
sentence: But yeah, I mean investors absolutely influence in, but just not in this case

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process, example, between on the one hand trying to attain collegiate fit, and on the other trying to avoid group think

author: Q
sentence: You actually articulated that one when we were first speaking?

author: A
sentence: Yeah absolutely, I reckon there’s absolutely attention there, and the board just needs to be mature to strike that balance, to say what’s the right level of, it’s not what’s the right level of diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s like just getting the right person for the right time for the business, that’s where they're at

author: Q
sentence: I'm thinking also from what you've said, being able to be confident that you can manage it?  You’ve described how you build trust on the board, and you have a process of problem-solving that might go over a couple of meetings

author: Q
sentence: You must meet fairly regularly?

author: A
sentence: We meet in person every month, and then we have a call midmonth

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so that’s every fortnight you're in touch?

author: A
sentence: Every fortnight, yeah, we touch every fortnight

author: Q
sentence: So, your problem solving is really a continuous process then?

author: A
sentence: That’s right, yeah

author: Q
sentence: You're going to give me an example of your constitution, which might be part of the process, shape it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so when you're selecting, so you're going to just be - I like this, it links with what you said about managing the tension between those two, depending on what situation the board’s in

author: Q
sentence: Diversity of views, okay, we will -

author: A
sentence: I think it takes courage for the board to appoint a new director, that has a significant amount of diversity

author: A
sentence: Because they're effectively encouraging new perspectives, that may be uncomfortable in to the room

author: Q
sentence: But you seem to be comfortable with that discomfort, you actually want it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it is important

author: A
sentence: What we’ve done in the business here, the same philosophy around teams, is we try and get as maximum diversity in a team

author: A
sentence: When we don’t, we start - we just find that we don’t have high performance

author: Q
sentence: You will be cultivating the board, to be equally uncomfortable with lack of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: That’ll be your strategy is it, as a chair?

author: A
sentence: It is, but I haven’t done it -

author: Q
sentence: That will be one way -

author: A
sentence: - but I have not done that with this board

author: A
sentence: I mean I've only been there for eight months, but I also don’t think I've got the control to do that

author: A
sentence: Because the people that are on it, the two founders and they're not going anywhere, and then the investor, and myself

author: A
sentence: The big question is whether I'd invite someone else on to the board, and it just doesn’t seem to be a business need to do that

author: Q
sentence: It’s interesting, because you're so committed to it

author: A
sentence: Sorry not a view, not just a view, but diversity, like just generally different perspectives coming together

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: The barriers, can you explain your barrier?

author: A
sentence: What?  Barrier to what?

author: Q
sentence: To inviting another - some other person on?

author: A
sentence: Another person on the board?

author: Q
sentence: Spell out these barriers, because it’ll be useful

author: A
sentence: The first would be that socialisation of the person, so I'd have to get - I'd have to build a case to my other board members, that we need to get another person on the board, for some reason or another

author: A
sentence: Either we’re missing something already, in terms of the decisions or the way we operate, or the skillset, and I can't really make that case

author: A
sentence: I'd also have pushback from the directors, the founders in particular, because they'd say that’s an unnecessary expense, to have another board member that we need to pay

author: A
sentence: They’d just say I don’t see it being broken

author: A
sentence: I think that for them, they are not as - they would prefer - they're not as in tune with what diversity brings, so I'd have to take them on the journey of this is what you get from a more diverse board, and getting someone else on

author: A
sentence: They'd be like oh it’s probably just going to be a bit of a pain in the arse, so we’re good as we are

author: Q
sentence: Where did you learn your appreciation of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think from the teams that I’ve been involved in, not the board, but the actual working teams to deliver product

author: A
sentence: We build these teams here, and we really socially engineer them pretty thoughtfully, and have found that’s what’s helping us

author: Q
sentence: Right, now so that’s an IT background?

author: Q
sentence: Different perspectives, okay

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it's always - so how long were your start-up?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, they're basically small technology teams, each one has got about six or seven people

author: Q
sentence: Small technology teams

author: A
sentence: They build a product as an independent team

author: Q
sentence: Is this?

author: A
sentence: Propel

author: Q
sentence: Oh, is Propel the work, it’s not Agile?

author: A
sentence: Oh, it’s Agile, yeah okay, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: Okay, got you

author: A
sentence: It's a small Agile team, an Agile team is sort of a certain way of working as a team

author: Q
sentence: Yes, I understand okay

author: Q
sentence: So that experience has really shown you, right

author: A
sentence: So that was about 18 months

author: A
sentence: Yeah that’s influenced me a lot

author: Q
sentence: Now these people, what age are they?

author: A
sentence: They're all between about 25 and 35

author: Q
sentence: On the board?

author: A
sentence: Oh no sorry

author: Q
sentence: On the board, sorry your board, back to your board?

author: A
sentence: On the board, the two founders are about 35, they're both about 35 and the investor is about 45, and I'm 43

author: Q
sentence: Have they worked?

author: A
sentence: They’ve never worked anywhere else, they started this business when they were about 22

author: Q
sentence: So, they haven't had the experience of small teams, let alone Agile?

author: Q
sentence: 18 months and now eight?

author: A
sentence: No, they haven’t had any of that, they just run this one business for the last 13 years

author: Q
sentence: Wow, well we can’t rely on every board member having Agile experience to value diversity?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: So, your perception of the barriers, can I have a quick understanding of that before we move to the last?

author: A
sentence: The barriers to diversity?

author: Q
sentence: From these guys?  The ones that don’t have the experience of Agile, I get yours, I understand you

author: A
sentence: Right, so why would they be against it?  They wouldn’t have seen the benefit of it, they would just see it as slowing us down

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, the inefficiencies and stuff?

author: A
sentence: The inefficiency, the cost and yeah, they wouldn’t see the benefit

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting because they actually told me one day, who - when they were choosing between me and someone else, for the board role

author: A
sentence: They told me who the other person was, and I know her quite well, very well

author: A
sentence: She would have been fantastic and more diverse than me, and interestingly I'm probably a better board member for the first year, to put all this stuff in place

author: A
sentence: She wouldn’t have been as good at that, but then going forward, she actually would be better for them than me, after that stuffs in place

author: A
sentence: Because they need - and they probably chose me because I was less diverse, I was more like them

author: Q
sentence: Their selection criteria?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Selection bias to me

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you're amazing that you can just stand out and see yourself this way

author: A
sentence: [Unclear] 00:55:59 that's a nice thing to say

author: Q
sentence: From a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about the way diversity of Australian boards is currently being promoted?  I don’t know if you were, like gender targets?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I reckon it’s just pretty narrow and not - it’s not informing the world about what we’re really trying to achieve

author: A
sentence: It’s made it in to - it’s made a more complex nuanced topic in to a sound bite, of we need more women in the board

author: A
sentence: Then when there are women on the board, then people are throwing stones at it saying, yeah but they're all the same sort of women

author: A
sentence: They're white 50-year-old women, and then they're actually - there’s a cadre of them or something

author: A
sentence: The whole discussion is becoming - what’s the word?  It's like at a low level and it’s ignoring the high-level objective that we’re trying - that could be achieved

author: Q
sentence: Tokens, stereotypical?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s becoming too token, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it's not really meaningful?

author: A
sentence: Like focusing it on gender has missed the point, so if - and I don’t know how we got to that point to be honest

author: A
sentence: Because when you look, yeah, it’s a shame, because I think that anyway, but there’s a lot of really - I think being on boards, is such a fantastic way, particularly for really talented women, to contribute at a high level, without - and also be able to do whatever they want too else in their career

author: A
sentence: It’s a really flexible thing to be able to do

author: A
sentence: Yet it seems like not that open to females, yet at the same time we’re saying oh we need more females, but actually it's not so much about females and males, it's just about diversity more generally

author: A
sentence: There should be more Aborigines and more like less well-off people and more Chinese people and whatever, it’s just different, different, different

author: Q
sentence: Do you think though, that the barriers to gender, to females, might, if they're managed it might open the way to other types of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that it’s always been important, diversity, like this important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: Q
sentence: We can measure female, male fairly easily, reported

author: A
sentence: That’s a good point, it’s definitely a step towards diversity

author: A
sentence: Yes, so probably the bluntest

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely, but you can count it

author: A
sentence: But it’s fine, you can count it

author: Q
sentence: Do graphs and report it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, but that doesn’t help you, because you could get a female on the board that’s got the same sort of everything as me, cognitively, religiously, philosophically

author: Q
sentence: And be a lawyer?

author: A
sentence: And be a lawyer, and you get the same as me, so it doesn’t really help

author: A
sentence: How do you - how would you then measure the level of diversity or divergence?  You might have to cover - it’s kind of interesting, people wouldn’t like it

author: A
sentence: But if not personality profile, but something deeper than that, where you actually came up with all these different axis and said, in terms of libertarianism and like ethnicity and socioeconomic and religion

author: A
sentence: You kind of just list out 15 different vectors of diversity and then map the board, and say here’s where we are

author: A
sentence: You kind of say like a good board is a spread across these as possible

author: A
sentence: That would be a - it would be pretty controversial, because particularly if a public company, you get these directors that then have to say, well I'm like a liberal voter or a labour voter, or I'm a vegetarian, or I'm pro this

author: A
sentence: It would be kind of invasive

author: A
sentence: But that’s probably the ultimate way of doing it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you're going real deep, like you're looking fundamentally at meta differences, values differences?

author: Q
sentence: Commerce, I thought it was commerce yeah, okay great

author: Q
sentence: That sort of can influence, you know we look at how that might influence

author: A
sentence: It’s difficult for me to comment

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s got to be bigger than just gender

author: Q
sentence: I mean we could easily count religion though, we could have Muslim and Christian

author: A
sentence: Yeah, you could totally do that

author: A
sentence: It would be interesting though, if you did that and you put the board of a publicly listed company up, and you chartered it

author: A
sentence: It would be really controversial, because what you might find, is that on one axis, let’s say it’s like political persuasion, everyone's the same, and you're like ah

author: A
sentence: Okay do we need to engineer this whole thing, so we actually have someone?  You’d be like okay, so I need to find a conservative female that’s also a lateral thinker, it would be interesting

author: A
sentence: It would be - you'd end up, I don’t know if your hiring would be easier or harder?  It would be easier in some ways, because you just go, I just need someone who ticks all these boxes

author: A
sentence: If you can prove to me that you're that profile, you've got a role on this board

author: Q
sentence: Who does this?  Is it head hunters?  How do you find this out?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s done at different levels, depending on the board

author: A
sentence: So, for the start up type board that I'm on, it was the founders and the investor that did all of that

author: A
sentence: I think it was the HR person in the company

author: A
sentence: But for a publicly listed company, they’ve got the resources to just get a head hunter, and they'd say we need X, Y, Z

author: Q
sentence: Now 10 years in to the future, I had this line, creating tomorrows business, you've got up here, tomorrow’s boards, what are they going to look like do you think, in 10 years’ time?

author: A
sentence: If I think of the board of a publicly listed business, like AN IT COMPANY, I think that there’ll be more - I think the word is like accessible and egalitarian

author: A
sentence: At the moment, when you look at, and AN IT COMPANYs not like this, they're actually more accessible and egalitarian than others

author: A
sentence: But if you look at boards of other ASX listed companies, they're with sort of insiders

author: A
sentence: I think that ideally the boards would be with higher performing people, that aren’t necessarily insiders

author: A
sentence: The challenge with this, I had this when I was reporting to the AN IT COMPANY board, that the directors that were insiders, that understood the industry, were a lot easier to deal with then the directors that weren’t

author: A
sentence: You kind of knew what you were getting, and there was more predictability, quicker ability to make decisions, understanding

author: A
sentence: It was kind of easier with a board of what you would expect

author: A
sentence: It’s pretty difficult to mount a case, or to get it over the line to say we need to have this board with much more different people

author: A
sentence: Not industry insiders, much different perspectives, et cetera

author: A
sentence: I wonder where it’ll settle?  The way that I've seen it work pretty well, is this coexistence where there’s a part of the board that represents diversity really well, and a part of the board that’s not that diverse, and able to run fast

author: A
sentence: It’s kind of pragmatic

author: Q
sentence: The sprinter?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, when your board is a certain person, you can kind of do that, you can have three or four that are pretty similar, and then three or four that bring in the outside views

author: A
sentence: I'm not sure in the future, whether the best boards will be ones that are all diverse or just have a diversity component

author: A
sentence: But I do think that having outsiders, sends a strong signal, because it tells people that you don’t necessarily have to be someone that’s white with a law degree and in a certain socioeconomic bracket to be a board member

author: A
sentence: Which I fear is the message right now

author: A
sentence: We have to be a woman who’s 50 with a pearl necklace and earrings and coiffed hair

author: A
sentence: There’s this image of the female board director

author: Q
sentence: Stereotype

author: Q
sentence: Because it’s pretty short?

author: A
sentence: Stereotype, and it’s not right, that for me, it seems wrong

author: A
sentence: Particularly for some of these businesses, the super funds and stuff like that

author: A
sentence: I haven’t seen many of those boards, but the ones that I have seen, I just think why are you on that board?  What value are you bringing?

author: Q
sentence: Who do you know?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s who do you know

author: Q
sentence: Possibly, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: There’s that concern

author: Q
sentence: This is so interesting, thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: I've gone over the hour, sorry

author: A
sentence: [Unclear] 01:06:10

author: Q
sentence: You're wonderful, it was really good Ben, really good

author: A
sentence: You're welcome, I'm glad it was useful

author: A
sentence: [END PART A] [START PART B]

author: A
sentence: It’s pretty short, but just generally speaking, I think that it hasn’t been as important, and now it’s becoming much more important

author: A
sentence: There’s a recognition now

author: Q
sentence: I don’t want to lose any of your thoughts

author: A
sentence: It gave me a lot to think about, and one of the things that I think I'll struggle with, coming out of this discussion, is that balance between speed and like efficiency and diversity

author: Q
sentence: Well I'll share this with you, yeah

author: A
sentence: I reckon that in the short-term there’s absolutely a trade off, and that’s difficult to work out, when to make that trade off

author: Q
sentence: And long term its investment?

author: A
sentence: Long term it’s an investment and you're going to get better outcomes

author: A
sentence: You never know what you're missing out on

author: A
sentence: You're like we’re okay aren’t we?  But there’s no parallel board that comes up with something

author: A
sentence: I guess there is a parallel board and that’s your competitors

author: A
sentence: If your competitors are making better decisions than you, that would evidence that your board’s not as high functioning as you think it is

author: Q
sentence: Or the start up is a bit difficult isn't it?  Do you need help because you're?

author: A
sentence: Well the nice thing, with our start up, we’re way ahead of the competitors in terms of how organised we are

author: A
sentence: The others are just not that organised, so there’s nothing to compete against

author: A
sentence: But if you're ASX listed, you’ve always got a couple of competitors, and it would be interesting to know

author: A
sentence: It’s difficult then to work out though, is it - like if you're comparing one logistics company with another, is it the management that’s letting it down and the operational execution?  Or is it the board strategy?  Each one will just point fingers at each other, I guess

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: What I came away with in terms of modelling, from what you've said, what’s coming to my head, is that let’s say complexity and opportunity or strategy, let’s say complexity and strategy, you’ve got up here

author: Q
sentence: Then you've got your board parts you spoke of, and you've got this sprinter part, which has got your insiders with insider knowledge

author: Q
sentence: But I remember, I just looked at something out there, and it’s about you always validate don’t you, was the term?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, why do you think the investors felt that it was so important to get more diversity on the board?

author: Q
sentence: There’s validation, ongoing validation in that

author: Q
sentence: Then you’ve got your diversity path, which is outsiders and that’s a real problem, that’s problem solving, big picture stuff, isn't it?  This is problem solving, more focus perhaps with validation?  I don’t know, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: This is more execution focused, and then that’s more managing with it, and like risk

author: Q
sentence: I constructed that and that’s wrong

author: Q
sentence: Because you were thinking something else

author: Q
sentence: Your sprinter thinkers, are thinking quick, certain and go this far, then you check, go that far, then you check

author: Q
sentence: It’s short-term thinking, but cyclical?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Whereas this is outside the square, seeing opportunities and risk, contributing to problem solving, and the trouble is they're two very different ways of problem solving

author: Q
sentence: How do they come together?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so you put them in a board scenario and you're like you might have paralysis

author: Q
sentence: You might

author: A
sentence: Because these people are going to slow them down, and I found that at AN IT COMPANY, that basically there was the board, and there’d be three board directors that totally get what you say, and you’d be like I've already made a decision

author: A
sentence: Then the discussion would go for another 40 minutes while you're catching the others up

author: A
sentence: They were very good about it, because they'd just be like okay, this is just the way it is

author: A
sentence: But it was a two-speed board, you could see it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well maybe there’s two different types of problems

author: A
sentence: I think that as a board member you've got to suck it up and sometimes it’s going to be a bit boring at that level, because it’s a two speed board, and some things you’ll be like, I sort of know this is the right decision, and this executive knows what they're doing

author: A
sentence: Let’s just get it done

author: A
sentence: I've got to wait for everyone else to just get on to the same page

author: A
sentence: I think it was particularly, in my situation, was because there’s two founders of the business, they invested in, so they had board seats, plus then the VC got a board seat, and then they agreed that they needed to just balance it out

author: A
sentence: Just in terms of raw numbers and voting, was I think the primary - their primary concern actually

author: A
sentence: It was more just mathematically making things less slanted towards the owners, like balancing things up

author: A
sentence: It wasn't so much about diversity of opinion, and perspective, but then what’s happened subsequently, is that the founders have realised how valuable having a different perspective is

author: A
sentence: There’s been a much greater value given to voicing differences - voicing different perspectives

author: Q
sentence: Yes, not every board member will be across every problem?

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: But they will trust the sprint part of the board, recognising this is a sprinter question, and trust that they -

author: A
sentence: No, it wasn't like that, no, because the board members at that level, they're signing off on every

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so they won't do that, they won't trust parts of the board?

author: A
sentence: No, there’s no sprinter thing, it’s more like everyone needs to get - you need to invest the amount of time, to make sure that all board members are all aligned, and it just takes time

author: A
sentence: Essentially you actually are sacrificing the efficiency of the board, for the quality of the board

author: Q
sentence: The outcome?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and so that’s why I think sometimes at different phases of a business’s life cycle

author: A
sentence: When AN IT COMPANY was private, its board was able to be insular type, not diverse of it

author: A
sentence: Now it’s public and it’s taking public money, so they need to be more diverse and they get independence in, and it’s much slower, and that’s the price they pay

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I haven’t got a model, I don’t know yet

author: A
sentence: Different strokes for different times, different folks is the answer

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: That’s great, I'll be fascinated to see the outcome of the research that you're doing Margo

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so operationally the guys running the business, frequently have questions about how to run things, so recently one of them was even a small thing about car insurance

author: A
sentence: At the moment, they're a relatively small business, and they said listen, we’re just thinking about continuing our car insurance with the current vendor

author: A
sentence: But it’s actually what’s happening, is that all of the car insurances in one of the founder’s names, and not in the company name

author: A
sentence: They said we just get a cheaper rate, rather than putting it in the company

author: A
sentence: They knew that by coming up to the board, they'll get my view from legally, I was like legally that’s probably fine

author: A
sentence: But philosophically where the business is going, so you can’t do that, because like you're obeying the letter of the law but not the spirit

author: A
sentence: They were able to see what a legalistic answer was and what a financial answer was, and what a pragmatic answer was

author: A
sentence: They really valued coming at it from different perspectives

author: A
sentence: So, Chris, one of the other independent director, he said listen, from a business perspective that's fine, you're saving money

author: A
sentence: Then I was able to come at it from a legal perspective

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good, so it helps problem solving?

author: A
sentence: It helps problem solving, yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that actually is influence I'd say

author: Q
sentence: What about strategy, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so I wear a couple of different hats, because I've previously worked at Boston Consulting Group, where I learned a lot about strategy

author: A
sentence: Percentually this business is very operationally intense, so they need help with operations, finance, strategy and culture, they're probably the main pieces

author: A
sentence: We have questions around those areas, at most board meetings

author: A
sentence: The founders don’t have much experience with any of the others, except for operational

author: A
sentence: So, they lean on the board for like my view around strategy, Chris’s view around finance, my view around culture

author: A
sentence: We all come at it with a different angle

author: Q
sentence: Great, okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there’s any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating?  For example, high uncertainty or risk?  I was noticing this is your area of working, you love this climate?  As an entrepreneur, so you're the perfect person

author: Q
sentence: Does diversity help or hinder, and can you give me an example?

author: A
sentence: I can't see a circumstance by which you would want less diversity on a board, or even in a workplace

author: A
sentence: I think you're just exposing yourself to more risk, when you've got less diversity

author: A
sentence: If that’s the case, if you've got a particularly low risk environment, you could afford to have a lower, a less diverse board, that probably makes sense?  If the stakes are low, then you probably don’t really need it so much

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it really comes in to its own, when there’s risk and uncertainty?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example?  Of how diversity helps there?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so in a high stake’s environment, where there’s lots of money or lots of employees at risk, or yeah, then you just need to be able to, as a director, understand as many of the different angles as possible, so you can make the best decision

author: A
sentence: With less diversity, you're going to hear less angles, to think about

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so really the diverse board, can better manage the complexity or the many facets, that contribute to this -

author: A
sentence: To the risk

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, great

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so how many years have you been a Board Director?

author: Q
sentence: to this risk?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And to its management?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, beautiful, so now we’ve got risk and complexity is better with this diversity

author: Q
sentence: That hasn’t come up before, it’s neat

author: Q
sentence: Gender diversity has been debated for a while, how do you feel about the recent inclusion of other sorts of ethnicity, such as sexual orientation?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think gender diversity is only one angle of diversity, and actually sometimes by focusing on gender diversity, you might achieve gender diversity, but actually not actually achieve diversity across a whole lot of other vectors

author: A
sentence: We actually just had this, like a couple of hours ago, where we’re choosing an employee to hire

author: A
sentence: We have like a female of Russian descent, a female of Indian descent, and a male of - like a New Zealander

author: A
sentence: We were like okay, so how is having a female actually different, like if we choose between the females, what sort of different diversity are we going to get between them?

author: A
sentence: We’re able to identify well, one of them who’s Indian is actually not diverse compared to the rest of the team

author: A
sentence: Because most of the rest of the team are Indian actually, but the Russian lady actually, you get both cultural and gender with her

author: A
sentence: We were discussing how many different vectors of difference diversity can you get outside of just culture and discipline and gender

author: A
sentence: Gender really just counts for one of many characteristics

author: A
sentence: You might get off gender, so you have a female, but if the female’s actually an Indian and everyone else is Indian, or they have the same sort of political persuasion as everyone else, you're kind of not getting much benefit for the diversity

author: Q
sentence: This is great, okay, so do you think there’s a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others?  Or does it depend?

author: A
sentence: I think I'm not mature enough to see different angles of diversity count for more than others

author: A
sentence: I think that what happens is in certain circumstances, a type of diversity becomes more important

author: A
sentence: I've been in situations where just having one female in the room, really has a big impact

author: A
sentence: In other circumstances, it might be not gender diversity that we need, it’s probably socioeconomic diversity that’s more impactful

author: A
sentence: I think that it depends, is the answer for that one

author: Q
sentence: You have so many different understandings of diversity, it’s so good, you have mentioned, I don't know they'll be counted up when we do your transcript

author: Q
sentence: It’s great

author: Q
sentence: Really good

author: Q
sentence: I won't challenge you to list them, don’t worry

author: A
sentence: So, I've been a Non-Exec Director of this, a company that’s not my own, for only eight months

author: A
sentence: Yeah sure

author: Q
sentence: We want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that diversity can really help with, and can you give me an example?  Now you've given me one around problem solving, is there another one you can give me, perhaps from your business that you were in for about 18 months?  That you were the director of for about 18 months?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so how does diversity influence decisions, is it influence with -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, board functioning and you can talk about the other one too, because it’s not just problem solving

author: A
sentence: So, there's a couple of things

author: A
sentence: I think it can - when there’s more views expressed, it forces people to address those views, so that there’s less comfort

author: A
sentence: What happens is that in a healthy environment, you're trying to actually surface up the conflicts, because the conflict is already there

author: A
sentence: But unless it’s stirred, you're not going to see it

author: A
sentence: I think that diversity helps you to actually surface things that would otherwise go unspoken or unsaid, and then unaddressed and then missed, and then you get risk

author: A
sentence: I think that’s the main thing that the board functioning that you see it

author: A
sentence: It’s just, it probably feels less comfortable, which is the answer actually

author: Q
sentence: You have to feel uncomfortable?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, when you're feeling uncomfortable, because someone’s said something that you think oh,I haven’t thought of that, or I don’t agree with that, then you're probably on to something

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example, do you reckon?  It just really helps?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so I'm not - this isn't in a board context, but in another group that I'm involved with

author: A
sentence: I'm frequently finding that there’s a female in that group, and when she expresses her view, I'm constantly like I hadn’t even - that wasn’t even a thing that I was thinking about in that scenario

author: A
sentence: She’s able to like - so she’s raising things that I would have otherwise missed, I think that’s the first bit

author: A
sentence: Then sometimes she’ll also say things that I completely disagree with, but a day later I'm like, you know it’s grown on me, and now I think you might be right

author: A
sentence: What’s an example of when Anna’s done that?  Oh I can't remember a specific example at the moment, it’s been a couple of months since she’s been in those meetings

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I'll have to come back to that

author: Q
sentence: Has she left those meetings because of this conflict?

author: Q
sentence: Right, so eight months, so you're an independent?

author: A
sentence: No, no, and we actively like I'm now wondering whether it’s because she’s a female and the rest of us are male, or whether it's just a personality thing that could be replaced with another person

author: A
sentence: I also personally think that when you get too many guys in a room, it just becomes a bit macho, and it’s like kind of unavoidable

author: A
sentence: A female actually holds them to account, so that’s like only one type of diversity naturally

author: A
sentence: But it probably happens, again talking about different vectors, socioeconomically, there’s just a whole lot of people of the same socioeconomic, they all start talking about you know, their Ferraris or something

author: A
sentence: It’s just so it holds you to account, where there’s someone that’s different

author: A
sentence: You’ll be more careful, probably more thoughtful about what you would say

author: A
sentence: Which actually, now that I say it, could have a detrimental impact on a board environment

author: A
sentence: Because if you're scared about offending other board members, then you may clam up a bit

author: A
sentence: That probably suggests that diversity on its own, it’s a precondition for success

author: A
sentence: It’s necessary but it’s not sufficient, because if you haven’t got the environment by which all views are then respected and able to be voiced, then you can be as diverse as you want, but you're not going to achieve the positive outcome you're looking for

author: Q
sentence: Not voicing is a barrier, and voicing is a lever

author: Q
sentence: This is probably, what makes the difference?

author: A
sentence: Yeah you need the diversity, but if they don’t have the ability to voice their true self in that environment, you might as well not have the diversity in the first place

author: Q
sentence: How do you get that ability?  How do you build that ability for everyone to voice?

author: A
sentence: Well so the way we’ve done it in our board meetings, for Detector Inspector, is we shared our - we tried to create a deep sense of trust between us as board members

author: A
sentence: One of the ways, like there's a whole lot of ways of doing that

author: A
sentence: One of the ways we’ve done it, is to share one thing we call our journey line, which is sort of our past history since a kid

author: A
sentence: This is who I am and this is where I've come from, and this is why I've made decisions like I do

author: A
sentence: We did this and I lived there and I'm a middle child and blah blah blah

author: A
sentence: We do that there as well actually

author: A
sentence: But I think in arenas where you’re not fostering a deep level of trust, people aren’t going to actually be open and bring their perspective

author: Q
sentence: Wow, no one has talked about that

author: Q
sentence: Has this come from your culture?  You mentioned that you were brought on to the board because of your strength in culture as well, in culture management?

author: A
sentence: So, I think that they got lucky

author: A
sentence: In terms of choosing me for that board

author: A
sentence: I think they looked at me and thought, like the decision makers weren’t necessarily looking for diversity

author: A
sentence: They were looking for diversity in terms of numbers and votes, as I was saying

author: A
sentence: So there’ll be another person, and they looked at me and I thought, I think that the two founders of that business looked at me and thought I can kind of relate to this person

author: A
sentence: Again, they're probably not looking for diversity, here's another guy -

author: Q
sentence: You're not female?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s like another guy, I sort of understand him, he kind of looks kind of normal, there’s people like that in my neighbourhood, you know

author: A
sentence: If I had purple hair and different socioeconomic and like different gender and different political, they probably would be like nah

author: A
sentence: So, they would have been nah

author: A
sentence: In fact, I think I was actually chosen based on my lack of diversity, when I come to think of it

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I'm an independent director on that board

author: Q
sentence: Isn't that funny, that’ll come up in board selection, but you can think about othersituations, so that’s funny

author: Q
sentence: They got lucky from your point of view, but they were probably challenged when your comfort with conflict, and this trust building exercise -

author: A
sentence: Oh, we’re on a journey with those folks, the first argument we had, it was challenging for them, they weren’t used to having anyone else in their business actually

author: A
sentence: So, they were really threatened

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s you and someone else?

author: A
sentence: Me and a big investor and then the two founders

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you and the investor sort of got together, well when I say you sort of worked together to challenge there?

author: A
sentence: Yes, that’s exactly the dynamic

author: Q
sentence: That’s a bit of a social rift in the board?

author: A
sentence: There absolutely is, because there’s like the founders, the founder owners and then the outsiders, and so there’s definitely a rift, not a rift, we’re pretty high functioning

author: A
sentence: But there’s definitely a line drawn down the table

author: Q
sentence: Yes, but you've got the power of the investor that investor is -

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily, I'm independent, so I don’t have, but I'm chair as well, so if there is a two two split, then my vote carries

author: Q
sentence: Okay good

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got this one, is it for profit?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, I was thinking, so it’s great you're a chair, thanks for letting me know that, because a lot of people talk about, oh the chair is central and it’s hard to get chairs

author: Q
sentence: So how you manage it

author: Q
sentence: But I was just thinking, I suppose the clout of the investor means they have to hang in there and stick with this idea of a board?

author: A
sentence: Well they can't get rid of the board, once I'm appointed now, I can't remember how it is that they can - I think that all three of them actually need to vote to get me off

author: Q
sentence: Right, there’s a constitution?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, there’s a constitution and as part of that, it's quite difficult to remove me as a director

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I don’t mean you personally

author: A
sentence: Yeah well anyone, whoever was in that non-executive director role, once it’s been filled, I think you need 75 per cent of the votes or something to remove it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, brilliant

author: A
sentence: That’s correct actually, so the two founders, if they really didn’t want me on the board, they can’t themselves vote me off

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so there's -

author: A
sentence: There’s protection

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Are you the only young one? Are they all sort of my age or your parents’ age?

author: Q
sentence: This is a really wonderful story

author: Q
sentence: And I mean you probably think of it just as a personal story, but I can see some strategies that could help other people to follow in your amazing trajectory

author: Q
sentence: So you know it's really good

author: Q
sentence: Now I'm conscious of the time, and I want us to get some of these questions that I ask other people

author: A
sentence: Yeah of course

sentence: Sorry, I'm rambling a bit

author: Q
sentence: No, no, no, that was brilliant by the way

author: Q
sentence: That was brilliant

author: Q
sentence: This sort of information you gave there will work beautifully with some theory that will help us a lot, so don't think you rambled

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:36:22

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly

author: Q
sentence: So how important do you think it is to have a diverse board? Let's say I give you a scale one to 10, 10 is extremely important and one is not at all important, what would you say?

author: A
sentence: Well surely it's got to be a nine or 10

author: A
sentence: Should I qualify that?

author: Q
sentence: You tell me which one

author: Q
sentence: And then yes, then I will ask you to qualify it

author: A
sentence: I'm going to say nine

author: A
sentence: The reason being that, and this is perhaps the somewhat controversial opinion, diversity is important in that it needs at the very least it should reflect the community which you're serving regardless of whether it's corporate or not for profits

author: A
sentence: If you don't have the points of view purely from a business perspective, if you don't have the points of the view of people that you're serving then it's surely not going to deliver the best outcomes

author: A
sentence: Further to that, where people make the argument that the board – you know potentially if an argument is that the demographic for our product or service is not particularly diverse, we don't really need a diverse board for that reason, then my argument would always be well this is what your business does now and this is who your business serves now, but you always need to be evolving as an organisation and perhaps having a different point of view around the table will help you see where that next opportunity is or the risk to your business that you can't comprehend

author: A
sentence: So it is incredibly important, but I don't know that in my own personal life, I don't know that I would want to be – no one wants to be the token

author: A
sentence: So, if I felt like I'd been appointed or there was a chance of being appointed purely for being a token, then it does a lot of discredit both to that individual and to the organisation I think

author: Q
sentence: Can you explain that a little more?

author: A
sentence: And this is not in the context of my board experience but in the context of work, I felt like at times maybe I was put in certain positions because I was young, of migrant backgrounds and female

author: A
sentence: And I had to work that much harder to prove myself, which absolutely – and people talk about this all the time, that much harder to prove myself but which I could do to the immediate team with which I worked

author: A
sentence: But beyond that there's very little opportunity to demonstrate your value

author: A
sentence: And people – at the end of the day when you move on to another role, it's not going to be the six people you directly work with and it might be their connections that help you in

author: A
sentence: But if the wider team of 50 all has a perspective and view that it's very difficult to shift without having an opportunity to interact with them, then it just makes future opportunities that much more difficult as well

author: A
sentence: I think many of them either have children, have daughters at the school or recent leavers

author: A
sentence: So most of them are still working, we've got a few who are now partially retired, who are  doing a lot of governance work involved

author: A
sentence: So I'd certainly say that I'm younger than – well I am younger than all of the other board members

author: A
sentence: My experience coming into the role was that –and I'm not sure if this unnecessary background but hopefully it helps

author: A
sentence: I had decided that I wanted to be involved with boards quite early on in my own personal professional life

author: A
sentence: So when I was at university the idea of a board level or a directorship career was sort of brought to my attention for the first time, and I didn't think too much of it but I had met particularly some board members involved with THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  at that time who were very inspirational women mostly

author: A
sentence: Who I then, in a roundabout way, I then went to work in banking and in working with some of my clients which were all sort of institutional and clients

author: A
sentence: Some of these names were quite familiar because they had been board members at THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  and now were on various Australian corporate boards

author: A
sentence: So it was inspirational to see these women who very loosely had a personal connection through, to see them really at the top of their industries, sitting in various corporate board roles

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So you lose a strategic opportunity for yourself, opportunity for yourself if you're token and it doesn't feel very nice either

author: Q
sentence: And you work really hard for very little gain

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Like if there's an option between going to go into a board that said, “We'd love to have you involved because of x y z reasons” and they can clearly articulate them, and I feel like I can deliver into that, versus a board that can't do that and, for whatever reason, makes me feel like they might be just checking a box, then of course I'll choose the one that can articulate their values

author: Q
sentence: What percentage of women are on your board, the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD?

author: A
sentence: I should know off the top of my head but I don't

author: A
sentence: But it's certainly the majority

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: It is a females [unclear] 00:40:37 – just to test your theory earlier

author: Q
sentence: That’s great, okay, good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there's any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating of to diversity

author: Q
sentence: High uncertainty, high risk situations, something like that maybe?

author: A
sentence: That's an interesting question

author: A
sentence: No, because I think the high risk question is really interesting because well anecdotally and from what I've read, men tend to be more risk taking, so I'm sure there's hypothesis there about a board with a higher risk appetite doing things differently

author: A
sentence: But if it's diverse then there should be a balance between those who are willing to take risks and those who are a little less likely to

author: A
sentence: So hopefully not, no

author: Q
sentence: Yeah okay, that's good

author: Q
sentence: And what now does diversity – you mentioned earlier, but what does it mean to you, what does board diversity mean to you?

author: A
sentence: It means having people around the table that bring different perspectives

author: A
sentence: And there is no way you can cover all of them, but you can certainly try

author: Q
sentence: Some people talk about gender, so demographic diversity, gender, age, ethnicity those things you can measure and see

author: Q
sentence: Functional, like your experience, your experience in the bank, your experience at THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL , your experience as a young woman who has gone through THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  and is engaging in the workforce

author: Q
sentence: So you talked about those experiences and how that was really important

author: Q
sentence: So –

author: A
sentence: Well I think it just the way the boards are structured now, at the bare minimum, the board needs to be diverse enough to cover off and discharge its duties as a board

author: A
sentence: So you need to have the technical and requisite skill sets around that board table

author: A
sentence: That's the baseline

author: A
sentence: And then further to that, the ability to bring different perspectives

author: A
sentence: And this is the thing, it doesn't necessarily need to be – lived experience is one way to get it but it doesn't need to be someone who is – like a perfect example is, I speak often about elements of Chinese culture

author: A
sentence: I'm not Chinese, I've never grown up there, and yet I can speak to – in that setting, I have the most relevant experience to be able to speak to it

author: A
sentence: And so it's not necessarily about being fully representative of that community, which I acknowledge and own that I'm not

author: A
sentence: But just to have a different perspective to the other board members is a place to start

author: A
sentence: So that was a back of my mind inspiration, but on a practical sense I had always been really interested in volunteering but had found over the years that I really wanted to be doing more skilled volunteering

author: A
sentence: So, I'd sort of graduated from doorknocking, which is hugely important, to helping with providing analysis or strategic advice or different pieces of, as they say, skilled volunteering

author: A
sentence: A few years into my corporate career an opportunity came up through just some informal networks, a girl that I had mentored in a way during my university years had been a very active volunteer with A YOUTH ORGANISATION Victoria and she'd found out that they were looking for young advisers to their board and put my name forward and I had a few conversations with them, went through an interview process and eventually joined their board in an advisory capacity

author: A
sentence: So not as a director

author: A
sentence: Because you know you've got a board with 10 seats around the table, there's no way you can capture every perspective of whether it's a young woman or young man or someone who's gone through school and had to deal with the challenges of figuring out their sexuality or whatever it is, you know well-being in schools is a huge issue now

author: A
sentence: So pastoral care experience, with I think the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD board is fantastic in that we've got adolescent psychologists on the board, we've got educators, we've got accountants and lawyers

author: A
sentence: So it’s, from a skills perspective, very diverse

author: A
sentence: From a representation a representation of our community it's also very diverse in that we've got parents, ex-students and we’ve had benefactors in the past so most of the community is represented on the board as well

author: A
sentence: But as to whether it's ticking off a certain demographic or not, whether it's, “Okay we need one person between the age of 18 and 26, and one person between the age of 26 and 35” that seems a bit arbitrary to me

author: A
sentence: But perhaps it's the only way to achieve it because how else would you – I think that setting benchmarks has to be quantifiable, so perhaps that's a way to do it

author: Q
sentence: We'll get on to regulation towards the end, so that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that there's a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others or does it depend always, like you’ve mentioned?

author: A
sentence: Do I think that different types of diversity matter –

author: Q
sentence: More than others

author: A
sentence: -@more than others?

author: Q
sentence: And then would you vary your ranking depending on the situation or context?

author: A
sentence: I think sometimes it's very helpful

author: A
sentence: And I don't know if the board room as appropriate for it but maybe that's the only place for this conversation to happen

author: A
sentence: But I think that it's really useful to have someone in the room that can almost play the devil's advocate

author: A
sentence: Because that's the ultimate demonstration of not having groupthink

author: A
sentence: As to whether it's diversity, I don't know

author: A
sentence: But having someone in the room who says, “But what about this” or considering something on the flip side, at the very least encourages quite a robust debate

author: A
sentence: But it's not the same thing as diversity, where I think diversity is almost instead of flipping something on its head, diversity is adding to the conversation by pulling in different points of view

author: A
