sentence: I think maybe I haven't had enough practical experience, but maybe on boards there have been people who've played that role who are quite contrarian, and so they can have these robust discussions

author: A
sentence: But they might not be bringing in different points of view

author: A
sentence: I'm not sure if that makes sense

author: Q
sentence: The devil's advocate role is not necessarily –

author: A
sentence: It’s not the same –

author: Q
sentence: Which board was that, YM –

author: Q
sentence: - the same as diversity

author: Q
sentence: Well this is a good time to ask about, to think about – there's been a lot of talk about cognitive diversity, and what I'm thinking about here is different approaches to problem solving and different perspectives or different information processing styles

author: Q
sentence: So this is sort of as close as I can think of to your devil's advocate role

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel that cognitive diversity influences your board's functioning, and is this a positive or negative influence, or does it depend?

author: A
sentence: So I should say that my line of work is in developing experiences that test the teams and individuals based on different cognitive styles

author: A
sentence: So this is my –

author: Q
sentence: Oh fantastic

author: A
sentence: Yes, this is my bread and butter

author: Q
sentence: So do you use that term, cognitive diversity?

author: A
sentence: I don’t, but I will from now on

author: A
sentence: No, we speak to a very – I guess we use very layman terms and we deal actually with corporates in a quite relaxed setting

author: A
sentence: So it's just about talking about different thinking styles

author: A
sentence: I have not thought about it strictly within – like when I'm sitting in the boardroom, I don't know that I think about it very consciously

author: A
sentence: I know that there are other – so there's quite a difference in experience in the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD boardroom in terms of governance

author: A
sentence: So there are some, and I mean you spoke to a director who's incredibly experienced and an amazing individual

author: A
sentence: He will make references in the boardroom to specific theories around cognitive style

author: A
sentence: So he might say, “Okay, to put on the black hat for a moment” and pose a question

author: A
sentence: So I would think that there are members in that room who are certainly more conscious of it than others in the role that they're playing in the boardroom

author: A
sentence: I think that we've sort of spoken about it that there’s certainly particularly the black hats, I guess

author: A
sentence: I can't remember all of them, but blue ocean thinking as well, having that person who throws out the more faraway concepts

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I certainly think that there’s incredible value to having different cognitive styles in the room, and that goes for any team, not just the boardroom

author: A
sentence: As to how well every board manages to assess that, harder to tell

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: To assess it as “this individual will contribute x, this one y” or “how do we assess its functioning on our board” –

author: A
sentence: ,Yes it's probably two parts

author: A
sentence: I don't think it's particularly well assessed

author: A
sentence: I think technical skill sets are very well assessed, as is experience

author: A
sentence: I don't think that different cognitive styles are considered as much but it might just be because the board, this is my experience, the board functions in quite a structured way and there's not actually a lot of – there isn't necessarily, I can't think of a way, there isn't necessarily a lot of flexibility to accommodate for maximising the benefits of different cognitive styles

author: A
sentence: So everybody brings what they can to the table but you've got two hours of a board meeting, six to eight times a year

author: A
sentence: There isn't a huge amount of time to say, “Okay well, this is your style and this is the way it will work best with the other board members and management

author: A
sentence: And this is the way we're going to structure our meetings so that we can make the most of each of these things”, especially when each meeting deals with such different content

author: A
sentence: It might be difficult to capitalise on that, but it's certainly important to have just in terms of having a discussion, that there are different thinking styles around the table so that someone can play devil's advocate or someone can throughout be, “Have we considered this?”

author: Q
sentence: Okay so it contributes to functioning and so it's really important, but it seems to be hard to assess and measure, so to control or manage?

author: A
sentence: Yeah difficult to assess measure, and also capitalise on to its maximum benefit

author: A
sentence: Which makes measuring it less important

author: A
sentence: Which is if we can't –

author: A
sentence: A YOUTH ORGANISATION Victoria

author: Q
sentence: Capitalise on it –

author: A
sentence: - do a lot with it, it's like, “Okay we know this about our members but we don't have a lot of flexibility to be able to make much of it

author: Q
sentence: So the inflexibility comes from people not being able to – or you haven't got the time?

author: A
sentence: I think it's a question of time

author: A
sentence: Because you don't want to limit people in the context of a discussion to say, “Well this is your thinking style and this is how you're going to contribute to the boardroom

author: A
sentence: ” I mean we could go through the exercise and be conscious of how each person thinks, but you also wouldn't want people to fall into specific roles, “Okay it's my responsibility to say only these things

author: A
sentence: ” So I don't know if making every board member – there’d have to be a fine management of making board members aware and then also making use of it in some productive way, which I feel like there isn't a lot of time to do well and that there may be more inherent risks

author: A
sentence: So well, that person's always going to play this role or –

author: Q
sentence: Pigeon holding people

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting, I'll look into that through some more interviews

author: Q
sentence: It's an interesting idea

author: Q
sentence: So, now I'd like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards, and if so, how such a conflict can be managed

author: Q
sentence: Can you remember a decision, can you recall a decision that the board needed to make which involved conflict, and you think diversity of some kind had a role in this?

author: A
sentence: I'm sure there is some

author: A
sentence: Well I think it's natural that conflicts will arise when two people have different points of view

author: A
sentence: As to whether that needs to be a bad thing or not, or if I can even recall a time where it's had any – I feel like it just results in a robust discussion, and typically it gets voted on if there is a lack of consensus, obviously it will get voted on

author: A
sentence: If it's very split still, typically it goes to further investigation and that will come back to the next board meeting

author: A
sentence: So I think –

author: Q
sentence: Can you remember one where it went to, “Okay more research is needed and then we will come back”, do you remember one of those?

author: A
sentence: Hard to say whether this research was going to happen already or not, but we discussed basically demographics in Melbourne and where young people, so graduates from the school who are about my age, their late 20s early 30s, where would they typically moving to? And there was a hypothesis, and then I just sort of looked at my peers and said, “Okay well this is where they all live

author: A
sentence: ” Yeah absolutely, they may have grown up in these suburbs but they now all moved here and there was some disagreement about whether that was true

author: A
sentence: That was absolutely fair enough because it was very anecdotal evidence so further research was undertaken to decide what accurately reflected the demographics we were looking at

author: A
sentence: So, I think when it's anecdotal evidence, then I feel like it's perfectly justified to disagree with it

author: Q
sentence: What does it stand for?

author: Q
sentence: So that's a question of fact

author: Q
sentence: What about values, have there ever been any conflict over perhaps something with a value base? I mean I'm also conscious that you've been on the board for 16 months, you know, I've been asking this question of people who've been on for 10 years and could be the reasons [unclear] 00:56:42

author: Q
sentence: So it doesn't matter if you can't think of one

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so values

author: A
sentence: I don't think I've ever, and this is where I've been involved in a conflict, I don't think I've ever raised anything that didn't have practical implications

author: A
sentence: So I don't think I've ever raised some kind of value judgment or perspective that didn't have practical implications on what the board was discussing

author: A
sentence: So, then it becomes very much discussion about the practicalities of action or inaction, as opposed to necessarily a question –

author: Q
sentence: Whether you should do it or not –

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: morally

author: A
sentence: Yeah morally as a question

author: Q
sentence: Is that because of the culture, the strong cultural norm of the board do you think?

author: A
sentence: As my only experience, it’s hard to compare to anything

author: Q
sentence: But you seem to all agree fundamentally about this –

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well I don't think that it's particularly – tolerant is not the right word, but I don't think it's the norm for any board member to put forward a comment which doesn't have some basis or support which we can then unpack

author: A
sentence: So, you can't just voice an opinion and have nothing to –

author: A
sentence: Young Men's Christian Association, but I don't think they particularly affiliate with anything like that anymore

author: A
sentence: But they run a huge portfolio of community and social services

author: A
sentence: So that was a really interesting organisation to be involved with for a while, just to see the breadth of their operations and to get an understanding of – I mean that was the first exposure I had to a board

author: A
sentence: So I sat in on some of the subcommittee meetings

author: A
sentence: I wasn't a board member so I wasn't in board meetings but the relevant subcommittee meetings I would attend

author: A
sentence: And just the process of how boards are run and the distinction between management and the board et cetera, et cetera, was a really interesting experience further to being able to feel like I was contributing to their organisation

author: Q
sentence: Substantiate it

author: A
sentence: - substantiate it or qualify it, which can then be discussed and unpacked

author: A
sentence: So maybe it's just a matter of – and I also think when there's only two hours you don't have time to entertain those types of opinions and thoughts, so I don't think people raise concerns that they aren't able to substantiate

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I guess it might be something about whether THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  should target some high achieving people from a low socio economic background and give them scholarships or something, and so that's a really a values question, it’s not a question of fact

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that maybe it’s a question of – maybe the answer is just that the board is quite agreed on values

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, that’s what I'm thinking

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve not been there for that long, like in the future there might be some strategic decision where this kind of – not that particular situation but something else

author: Q
sentence: But that's good

author: Q
sentence: And a final question, now you've talked about that and I really like the way you talked about that, this is about identifying new members

author: Q
sentence: They did consider ways to increase diversity

author: Q
sentence: They had as a matrix, but it came up as the measurable ones, demographics, we have no one who matches our student clientele or the –

author: A
sentence: I think in the past, and I was not privy to those conversations having taken place before I joined

author: A
sentence: But in the past a lot of those concerns had been there was a demographer on the board

author: A
sentence: So I think some of those concerns had been alleviated by having someone who was able to comment from a technical point of view on that demographic

author: A
sentence: And then I think there was some discussion – so he left, and I think there was some discussion about how they then fill that knowledge gap, and the obvious thing was to simply go for someone who had been a student at the school, best case scenario, who had been to the school and was a young person who had some kind of skills to bring the board

author: A
sentence: And so I think it was just right place right time for me, and something that they were looking for

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So it was because so a particular person on the board had a particular skill, it wasn't because of a generic tool they used that they realised, “oh gee we need someone, representative” –

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well, I think they’d gone through their [unclear] 01:01:07 exercise, and I don't know if it was – it's hard to quantify that

author: A
sentence: But I know through informal discussions that that had been a concern

author: A
sentence: And they'd relied on his input for certain conversations and not having him around, they definitely – probably from a cultural point of view they just felt like they needed someone who could contribute in that way

author: Q
sentence: Have they put on anyone – are you seeking someone else for your board, so you're seeing this process unfold or?

author: A
sentence: So he left before I joined

author: A
sentence: I kind of stepped into –

author: Q
sentence: And who chaired that subcommittee?

author: Q
sentence: His shoes

author: A
sentence: his shoes, I guess, in some ways

author: A
sentence: Couldn't make up for it in many other ways

author: A
sentence: The process hasn't changed in that we – a new director has just been appointed and he again fills a very specific skills gap that the board believed would be necessary in the medium term

author: Q
sentence: Did someone, like a recruitment organisation or someone help them analyse and identify the gap or do they do it themselves?

author: A
sentence: I believe it's internally complete, so there's a self-valuation of the board and I'm sure it gets benchmarked

author: Q
sentence: Like a subcommittee

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So do you think your board has any barriers to managing or building its diversity? And if so, what would that be?

author: A
sentence: The obvious thing is if they want more young board members, it's simply not that many young people that put their names forward

author: Q
sentence: And why is that?

author: A
sentence: I don't think it’s specific to THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD, that's the first thing

author: A
sentence: I think it's quite representative of all boards

author: A
sentence: I think that is probably because a board has been seen as a place where you go when you've reached the pinnacle of your career and you can then contribute substantially in a much more condensed period of time to an organisation

author: A
sentence: Perhaps it comes to an understanding of what the board's role is in an organisation

author: A
sentence: And so, many boards that will probably still be the case, that we need people who are not just at the peak of their own careers but leading the industries to be involved with our organisations at the board level

author: A
sentence: Insofar as that continues to be the case, it's very unlikely that young people will be able to take a seat at the table because there’s no substitution for 40 years of experience if that's what the board wants

author: A
sentence: For other boards where they see a value in the board room for strategic conversation – and I think boards have dealt with this in different ways in that they get management to complete or get consultants to complete piece of research, would then get circulated to the board for decision

author: A
sentence: But yeah, as to whether the lived experience is helpful in the context of the board discussion, who knows

author: A
sentence: I think the jury's kind of out, like it could be you know often you have guests, they come in and speak on certain items, so do they need to be directors?

author: A
sentence: An experienced director

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, like you were on an advisory for a board for example

author: Q
sentence: But I guess I'm interested the barriers for you

author: Q
sentence: You talked about the image of the board

author: Q
sentence: What it’s seen to be, it's for people at the end of their career as when they can bring it all together and whatever

author: Q
sentence: If that's the image of what it is to be a board member that young people have, what happens when they see you and they hear someone like you? Do you think that will challenge that understanding?

author: A
sentence: Completely different reference, have you ever heard of Malcolm Gladwell’s, what does he call that, Pioneers and Pariahs or something, great read, you should read it

author: Q
sentence: I’ll write it down

author: A
sentence: It’s really relevant to this discussion because he talks about different examples where sometimes one person can open the door and lots of people follow them because they’ve now seen the example

author: A
sentence: There's often times where one person gets appointed into a role and then no one again for a really long time

author: A
sentence: And so, it's not necessarily about the first person, it's really about reading reaching some kind of tipping point around representation

author: A
sentence: So, absolutely for a few people maybe it will resonate, my story will resonate with them and they'll think that this is a possible option for me

author: A
sentence: But for a lot of people it won't still think that that experience is purely my own and that there's no way to replicate it

author: A
sentence: It's not a situation that they perceive as accessible to themselves until a point in time when there's lots of us

author: A
sentence: I don't think that that will change

author: A
sentence: And that's my reflection built upon conversations that I've had

author: A
sentence: So I don't think people here, “Oh you're a board member with this school” I think a lot of people are aware of it, more people than I would expect to be aware of it, but I don't think that they think that that means something for them

author: A
sentence: And you know it is probably still an element of tall poppy where they look at me and say, “Oh well she thinks that she can do these things” and whether they – and lots of people supportive but not everybody is

author: A
sentence: So I hope that it inspires people to try but it doesn't seem like that's what the impact is most of the time

author: Q
sentence: So would you be invited to talk at THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  to students so they can see, “Oh look there's a young board member”?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, on occasion

author: A
sentence: I think that's really important

author: A
sentence: So it's really important for our community, as to how much that resonates across a wider, across the education system or the not for profit sector or even in general

author: Q
sentence: Fashion for example

author: A
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: And I think as well the fact that it makes so much sense from our board's perspective that I am a past student of this school

author: A
sentence: Makes it seem a lot less relevant to every other organisation, because like well okay she's on that board because she had the lived experience of going to that school and now she participates in the board

author: A
sentence: Where it would be different I think if it was a position with a comparable institution that I had no affiliation with

author: Q
sentence: So would you, with this experience under your belt, put your hand up for another board in another industry?

author: A
sentence: I would love to one day and it’s certainly in the plans

author: A
sentence: I think that for now my focus is on getting really good grounding, so I go through my [SED] 01:08:44 and probably finish this term at THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD first before I consider anything

author: A
sentence: I would love to

author: A
sentence: I think for me it's a matter of finding an organisation with similar values to what THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL  is espousing in that they see the value of having – whether it's me or someone like me, in the boardroom

author: A
sentence: Which having done a little bit of research don't think that that's most organisations

author: A
sentence: So, it's probably a matter of finding the right fit both from their values perspective and ultimately I want to do something meaningful

author: A
sentence: So finding an organisation that both wants someone like me in the room and with whom I want to work, which is a very small pool I think

author: Q
sentence: And what was her role on the board?

author: Q
sentence: You're in the network now though, you can keep your ear to the ground with your fellow board members

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about the use of the government, like ASX does, gender targets, but let's imagine age targets because we're looking to have some people under 40 on boards, let's say, increase that segment? What do you think that might look like? Do you think it might be effective, doable, of any use?

author: A
sentence: People ask me about targets a lot, and I never really have a good answer

author: A
sentence: I'm very much on the fence about them

author: Q
sentence: Why?

author: A
sentence: In that I can certainly see why they're beneficial, that's an easy argument to me

author: A
sentence: I think it's about the unintended consequences, like when you appoint people who – so you give an organisation – so this is worst-case scenario

author: A
sentence: You give an organisation a target, they don't espouse the values that their target is trying to identify and address

author: A
sentence: They appoint a person who may or may not have the requisite skillset

author: A
sentence: Maybe they just needed that opportunity but they aren't given the proper encouragement and welcome within the boardroom anyway, so they have a terrible experience or they don't contribute in a meaningful way

author: A
sentence: That board also gets to kind of wash their hands of the issue because they've dealt with it but not in any meaningful way

author: A
sentence: So that person is allowed to sit at the table but as to whether their opinion is welcomed or listened to, that's a cultural and values decision

author: A
sentence: So yes, you could do it but it won't necessarily have the impacts required

author: A
sentence: And at the same time, it could be really harmful for that individual for their own personal career, and frankly, their wellbeing

author: Q
sentence: I can see, and that goes back to your earlier conversation about the imposter syndrome and –

author: A
sentence: Even if they feel like they are worthy of being in that room but they're surrounded by 10 people who say to their face or behind their backs you're only here because of X

author: Q
sentence: Particular box, yeah, and they’ll be quiet

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly, fabulous

author: Q
sentence: Now this is the last question

author: Q
sentence: Looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards? And what do you think needs to happen for that to occur?

author: A
sentence: I mean best case scenario would be that we're not talking about it anymore because everything is wonderful

author: Q
sentence: Love it

author: A
sentence: That seems unlikely

author: A
sentence: Look I think, now being realistic, I hope that there's more and more people making a lot of noise about it and whether it's – because I think ultimately it needs to be a cultural and social change

author: A
sentence: So you can put in targets in the short term and because you've got a few powerful people who have made this decision, but until society changes and business culture changes, then diversity won't be properly embraced

author: A
sentence: So the more people who subscribe to this thinking and who are quite vocal about it, that's probably the best that I can hope for

author: A
sentence: And whether that's the boardroom or it's just diversity in general

author: A
sentence: And being accepting of other points of view in your own team more

author: A
sentence: And I think a lot of that I'm hopeful will happen because people of my generation typically tend to be quite – there are lots of – they certainly have lots of flaws, but they tend to think about things in quite flat structures and organisations have started reflecting that, so age and experience is not as relevant sometimes in certain business cultures, because there are so many new industries and so many new roles that everybody comes in knowing nothing anyway

author: A
sentence: So I'm hopeful that as this kind of generation moves up, not only will they now be in those positions in boardrooms, but because they have had this different experience and different point of view around what hierarchies look like, and boards are definitely seen as a top hierarchy, that they'll open the door and welcome people who have less experience or different experience, because that's how they experience their working life

author: Q
sentence: You sent it to me didn’t you?

author: A
sentence: Initially she was just a director and then during my tenure she became the chair

author: A
sentence: Whereas, I feel like board members today in their working life experience quite hierarchical structures

author: A
sentence: You do your time, you get promoted, you do your time, you get promoted

author: A
sentence: So if the natural progression is probably that people my generation will get to the top of their careers, sit on the boards but then hopefully open the door

author: Q
sentence: Open the door for others without going up the hierarchy?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So the hierarchy is not the essential feeder to board positions in the future, that will be your hope? That in 10 years’ time, that management, that ladder with all its broken runs and people pushing you down, that ladder up is not the only way to the board and for governing organisations?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think that will sort of be disrupted

author: A
sentence: I think it will certainly still be the way for my generation that it is still seen as the top, but hopefully once we get there because we had a different experience, that they will think about things differently

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: And do you think there's something that needs to happen to like, you know, legislation, you're familiar now with boards, any legislative changes or is it more just cultural? Industry bodies, director programs perhaps?

author: A
sentence: Now look I’d selfishly say it would be fantastic if there was more support for young people

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, no that’s good

author: A
sentence: I think I've been really lucky in having the support of some quite experienced directors who have been able to kind of guide me through the process

author: A
sentence: And even conversations that I had with AICD quite early on of other people who wanted to undertake the program

author: A
sentence: The question of, so you get the accreditation and then find a role or do you find a role and then get the accreditation? How important is it? Which parts are important? What type of experience is important? Having mentors to guide you through that processes

author: A
sentence: And I think I've spoken to THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD a few times, I think they're quite open and transparent about what they believe the best process is as well

author: A
sentence: So those conversations are very helpful

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so that's a useful organisation to help people for your future board as well, the way it looks

author: Q
sentence: Well thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: Have you any last comments you'd like to make? The aim of the research is to enable board diversity and we're looking beyond gender

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Was she a mentor for you do you think, did she encourage you?

author: A
sentence: I think it's a fantastic piece of work

author: A
sentence: And I certainly hope that it results to see diversity on our boards

author: Q
sentence: Oh

author: Q
sentence: I think we'll have to be humble – let’s hope it is a push in the right direction

author: A
sentence: I'm sure it will be

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, with people like you maybe we'll get there

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: A
sentence: She did

author: A
sentence: There was certainly huge support from all of the board members at that time

author: A
sentence: There was some that I was close to and they had a quite a formal introduction in that you were paired up with a buddy director etc

author: A
sentence: , to introduce you to the program

author: A
sentence: It was, again much like my experience with THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD, I think I've been very fortunate in that they were also operate at a very high level

author: A
sentence: And so that was fantastic grounding and I still keep in contact with a number of the board members

author: A
sentence: I'm just so personally – it's a small – Melbourne certainly it's a small community so you see people in all different types of forums again

author: A
sentence: And from that experience – and I can't be absolutely sure, but at the time when I joined as an advisor they brought on two other young people at the same time

author: Q
sentence: As advisors?

author: A
sentence: As advisors

author: A
sentence: And the three of us sat in different subcommittees

author: A
sentence: So I think for them it was an opportunity, and I don't know completely, but I think for them it was an opportunity to get insight from people that they believed were important part of their community into the various elements of governance

author: A
sentence: And whilst two of us didn't stay on in the long term, one of them is – I believe she was still with the board last time I checked

author: A
sentence: So she became a director

author: Q
sentence: She’s now on the board? Great

author: Q
sentence: And how old would she be? Like your age, bit older, maybe younger?

author: A
sentence: Maybe a few years older but I wouldn't say too much

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but young

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you were on like training wheels there?

author: A
sentence: Yeah a little bit

author: Q
sentence: They provided a buddy to help you learn about the board without taking on all the responsibilities?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I've sent you one but there’s a hard copy

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Did they put you through a course like with the Australian Institute?

author: A
sentence: It was floated and discussed with them and the secretary at the time

author: A
sentence: I felt like it might be more useful when I had more practical experience

author: A
sentence: I felt like maybe – and whilst I thought that was a fantastic experience, it was also in some ways quite difficult because I was privy only to a portion of what the board was doing

author: A
sentence: So being involved with one subcommittee did make it – I felt incredibly useful and like I was contributing, but I didn't feel like I had good oversight over everything the organisation was doing

author: A
sentence: So I personally didn't feel like it was the right time for the company director’s course with the AICD

author: A
sentence: Now that I'm with THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD and have had – so I've been on the board now for 16 months or so, I'll probably look to undertake that this year, because I feel like I've sat in the role for the while, I understood how it works, have a level of oversight that I feel comfortable with, and can now feel like I would take a lot more out of that course

author: A
sentence: Where I felt like I'd looked at some materials that I received through online and various other resources, and I just felt like maybe it wouldn't resonate as highly until I'd had some experience

author: Q
sentence: That makes sense, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Now Will THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD pay for you to do this cause or you pay for yourself?

author: A
sentence: I haven't asked the question yet

author: A
sentence: Regardless of whether – I haven't asked a question yet, it's a voluntary position with THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD

author: A
sentence: And I feel regardless of whether they would be willing to support that or not, I think for my own benefits and also for my own peace of mind, I would be prepared to make that investment either way

author: A
sentence: And I think maybe this unique experience, I don't know if it, I shouldn't say that, I don't know if it's a unique experience, but certainly as a young person it's a big expense to consider a two week course

author: Q
sentence: How much is it now?

author: A
sentence: The last time I checked it was something like 11,000

author: Q
sentence: Yeah this is a big chunk out of your –

author: A
sentence: Because you went to uni, you may well even have a HECS debt, or someone your age often does

author: A
sentence: Because I'm just thinking these are barriers to come up with ten thousand plus for a course for an unpaid role, it's a lot to ask if someone's you know put a HECS debt and you know often other expenses like mortgages might be coming on the horizon

author: A
sentence: I mean I appreciate that and why I hesitated once I said maybe this is a young person's issue

author: A
sentence: Everybody has different expenses and we can never really know, so I think it could be prohibitively high for many people regardless of their age

author: Q
sentence: Oh perfect, thank you, thank you

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Now you’re particularly interesting to me because you are so young compared to the other people I've interviewed, you're 28

author: Q
sentence: In fact you told me you're a female and your parents are from Malaysia, although you were born here in Australia

author: Q
sentence: But you went to a private school you said

author: Q
sentence: And so you think that helped you get on the board?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, good point

author: Q
sentence: But for someone young it's probably across the board

author: Q
sentence: I don't know even if your parents are particularly well-off, they might balk at forking out that sort of money

author: Q
sentence: I don't know, you know, for something that's not going to return any investment or whatever, however they might calculate

author: Q
sentence: But anyway, these are barriers, potential barriers

author: Q
sentence: You mentioned your skilled volunteering, now your bank, the one you worked with, do they have a volunteer program?

author: A
sentence: They do

author: A
sentence: It's primarily used – broad generalisations, in the areas that I worked it’s broadly used as a team bonding activity that the teams would go out and perform some kind of volunteering, whether it was skilled or otherwise

author: A
sentence: And it was definitely encouraged

author: A
sentence: Most of my volunteering I did outside of work

author: A
sentence: So in some cases I actually felt that I needed to inform my workplace so that they wouldn't be concerned with conflicts or – conflicts of interest or also just conflicts in time and commitment

author: A
sentence: I had those conversations when I first stepped into the advisory role with A YOUTH ORGANISATION

author: A
sentence: And they were supportive but there was certainly an expectation that your role is what comes first and we expect you to perform that well

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So were these meetings that you attended, were they during office hours or after office hours?

author: A
sentence: Typically before work

author: A
sentence: And my experience has been that's typically before work and maybe a few – maybe till 9 o'clock, so depending on what time you normally start work it may interfere or not

author: A
sentence: But that's been the same experience with THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD and I think that's reflective of the fact that many board members have day jobs that they are meant to get to as well

author: A
sentence: So I guess that's a consideration for everybody

author: Q
sentence: So that's good

author: Q
sentence: So your role at the bank, like your background from uni, what did you do?

author: A
sentence: So I studied bachelor of commerce at Melbourne Uni

author: A
sentence: I majored in finance and management

author: A
sentence: Wasn't quite sure what I wanted to do, went into one of the banking grad programs

author: A
sentence: I was really fortunate to have some fantastic experiences there across strategy, another team that was very technical, I wasn’t there for very long but where developed some really valuable technical skills

author: A
sentence: And then I moved into a permanent role in the institutional banking division working with industrial clients

author: A
sentence: So I was there for about three years, perhaps a little more

author: A
sentence: And concurrently I was volunteering and a few years into my role I also started a business

author: A
sentence: So I was busy at that time

author: Q
sentence: Yeah you were

author: Q
sentence: So with the potential for conflicts of interest with the bank, so you're an employee in the management stream, and let's say clients, for their or something, they might appear in the context of your board making decisions

author: Q
sentence: How do you manage that potential for conflict?

author: A
sentence: I was fortunate that it never did arise for me

author: A
sentence: But I think in my own reflections, it wasn't very likely that any of the clients with which I had a relationship would appear in a board room setting for decisions

author: A
sentence: So it would have probably been procurements and would probably have been left with management in most cases

author: A
sentence: And if it had arisen to the board then I would have to notify the chair and –

author: Q
sentence: So you’d manage it – yeah

author: Q
sentence: So your bank, when you talked to the bank, your manager there, were they concerned about – did they raise any concerns about this and instruct you about how you might manage it or they just left it to you?

author: A
sentence: No concerns from the bank's point of view

author: A
sentence: I also didn't think that they – you know they are quite conscious of conflicts of interest, and I don't think that they perceived that there was a high risk –

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: So I think I'm aware that my position on the board is quite unique given my particular background and experience

author: Q
sentence: Because of the nature of the board

author: A
sentence: Because of the nature of the board

author: A
sentence: Particularly when I was with the bank then, it was an advisory role, it wasn't strictly a board directorship

author: A
sentence: So there are a few other nuances to the relationship

author: A
sentence: So, they were probably more conscious of conflicts in commitment

author: Q
sentence: Yes exactly

author: Q
sentence: Your resources and commitment

author: Q
sentence: So you're still with the bank?

author: A
sentence: No I'm not, I should have mentioned that earlier

author: Q
sentence: You're not with the bank now –

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: So are you in your own business now?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Full time?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Which is –

author: Q
sentence: So you can manage your own conflicts of interests?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: It's much easier for you

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Perfect

author: Q
sentence: And you just have to manage it through the chair as you describe, okay

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel – let's say can you imagine, if you had the board position at THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD and you spoke to your manager at the bank, might they be concerned because you're now a director and do you think they might have raised some concerns about conflict of interest?

author: A
sentence: I wouldn't think so

author: A
sentence: I think that there are certain roles outside of work that institutions like that, so the bank that I was working for was one of the major banks, and I think they would have on a day to day basis been fairly agnostic about my involvements

author: A
sentence: And I think in other certain settings they'd see it as great opportunity

author: Q
sentence: So it wouldn't have been a barrier, it would have been easy to negotiate that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And I don't think that they – I can't imagine any circumstance where they would have said that they had an issue with it, particularly given it's a not-for-profit cause, it was working in a sector that I don't have any direct involvement with

author: A
sentence: So it would be hard to see where they would have had an issue

author: A
sentence: Had I been working – I did work briefly in the school sector within the bank

author: A
sentence: I think then they may have been some issues but that would have been a very clear conflict of interest

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I don't know what I would have done if I'd still be working in the school sector, that would be a different – lots of moving pieces there to imagine

author: A
sentence: At least within the Australian context

author: A
sentence: As you've already mentioned, I'm quite young compared to many average board members, I think

author: A
sentence: And in my own limited understanding, perhaps it's slightly more common in a not for profit board setting that you'll have a slightly younger demographic

author: A
sentence: But certainly working with the a private school board, which is a very highly qualified and well-trained board, it's a great privilege to be able to be involved, and I think that my involvement speaks to the commitment of the board itself in wanting to have diversity

author: A
sentence: And that's diversity across a number of metrics, which includes obviously it's girls school, there’s commitment to having women on the board and also having representatives who are a bit younger because they want to understand how things have changed in schooling and also in work after school

author: A
sentence: So I think that's where I sit, in addition to sort of the technical skill set that they look for in terms of the board

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: So because at the management level, so if you're the CE, then you can sort of sit on boards in your own industry and just declare a conflict of interest whatever, but you have the authority within your own organisation to do that

author: Q
sentence: I'm just thinking if you're lower down in the management pipeline, then there's probably less flexibility about that

author: Q
sentence: But that, as you point out, you work out what industry is this board in and you target that industry, or you avoid an industry that you might have conflict of interests with

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think, just now reflecting on it, the bigger issue as a young person, so I would have been 22 when I had that first conversation with the bank around this advisory role

author: A
sentence: And I didn't think of it as an issue as at the time because it was something that I want to do, so I was very prepared to have whatever conversations I needed to

author: A
sentence: But subsequent to that time, I spoke to a lot of my peers, and we were all entry level roles, so you're at the very bottom and you're there with usually the point of view that you're trying to build towards the next role, the next promotion

author: A
sentence: And I know that it was a big concern for people to raise, whether it had been volunteering with the board or volunteering with any organisation, there's a lot of concern about raising any kind of conflict in commitment and time with work

author: A
sentence: So I imagine that to be very barrier for people whether or not they actually perceive that they have the time to make it to the commitment of a board, I'm not sure

author: A
sentence: But certainly being able to have that conversation with a workplace

author: A
sentence: Because I think the feeling is generally, yes they'll support you unless there's an obvious conflict of interest, but in a softer way you don't know what impact that might have on your future prospects

author: A
sentence: So a lot of people might be – lot of my peers who were sometimes very interested in governance didn't really consider it as an option because their main role in work, which is what pays for their lifestyles, needed to come first

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there is a tall poppy thing that might get in the way, being so young? Just out of uni, advisor on a board, your manager has probably never been an advisor on a board or that close to a board? Do you think there could be a tall poppy barrier within management/ Did you feel that or you may not have?

author: A
sentence: Yeah I'm thinking about it now

author: A
sentence: Maybe behind closed doors

author: A
sentence: I don't think anybody ever said something to my face

author: A
sentence: There were probably definitely a few people that were a bit sceptical

author: A
sentence: And you have to have a certain resolution about what you believe you can contribute

author: A
sentence: And everybody, not everybody, many people suffer from imposter syndrome from time to time

author: A
sentence: And I certainly, when I began conversations with the field, the directors in considering an application for the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD,– the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD had been in the press significantly in the past, and it was a high profile board with high profile members so I had a lot of reservations about getting involved

author: A
sentence: And there's only so many seats on the table and you want everybody to be able to contribute in a meaningful way

author: A
sentence: So I had that conversation with at least two directors ahead of even applying for –

author: Q
sentence: Of the board?

author: A
sentence: Of the board, yeah

author: A
sentence: I'm not sure how much – tall poppy definitely plays into that because if you feel like people around you also are a bit sceptical about your involvement, compounded with the effects of an imposter syndrome, then it could be quite prohibitive, it would stop you ever applying for anything in the first place

author: Q
sentence: Can you explain to me your imposter syndrome? I’d like to understand that a little more

author: A
sentence: Just feeling like you are in a room and not qualified to be there, or that other people believe of you something that you don't believe in yourself

author: A
sentence: I think that – I'm not sure what the definition of imposter syndrome is, but that's how I understand it

author: A
sentence: So the feeling that – and it was a great privilege to be appointed to the THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD, and to walk in and be very – I to do quite a bit of reflection to say, Okay, well this is what I know and I acknowledge that there are many things that I don't know about, technically when it comes to the operations of the school and even various aspects of governance

author: A
sentence: So I don't have any practical experience and considering the rem committee or just different aspects and I've been appointed to the board and the farm subcommittee

author: A
sentence: ” And I had some experience in finance given my professional work, but certainly not at the depth of what some of the other candidates had even had

author: A
sentence: So some of the other candidates were, and other directors, were partners in leading accountancy firms

author: A
sentence: So, sitting at the table to go, “Okay, well I've got four years of banking experience

author: A
sentence: ” But being supported by the rest of the board members to say, “Okay well this is how you add value” and they've been so supportive and been very clear that I'm contributing to the board and the organisation more broadly, so that's comforting

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So tell me, what age spread would you – like are there any others perhaps in their thirties on the board?

author: Q
sentence: That's really good

author: Q
sentence: So the imposter syndrome is a self-perception, is it? So it affects your confidence and then you feel like you’re an outsider

author: Q
sentence: So then it's the others have to build that bridge to you

author: A
sentence: Yeah definitely

author: A
sentence: I think it's less of an issue now that I'm on the board, but it was certainly an issue in considering applying

author: Q
sentence: It was a barrier?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So you needed to be wooed by these couple of board members, actually helping you to see you would be adding value?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And I think that comes from as well – again this is not to my credit at all, but the board had gone through a very rigorous process to evaluate where their skills and expertise lay and they had identified that this is something that they wanted

author: A
sentence: So they've made a commitment to – and they certainly weren't going to appoint anybody

author: A
sentence: So they needed someone with the requisite skill set, but they were conscious of the fact that they wanted someone who could speak a little bit more to the experience of a few things which I can speak to

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, like students’ experience?

author: A
sentence: Yeah or even –

author: Q
sentence: Career trajectories?

author: A
sentence: Career trajectory

author: A
sentence: So I have a very, and I think the schooling system is very different now to when I was at school 10 years ago

author: A
sentence: But it's probably more relevant than the other board members, and I also since then have had a very – I've had a career that does not resemble what the other board members have had, irrespective of the board role itself

author: A
sentence: I've worked for a big firm and then started my own businesses, which I now run alongside various volunteering roles

author: A
sentence: And it's that idea of a lot more fluidity in my professional life that is quite valuable

author: A
sentence: Further to that, I think having the perspective of someone with – and there are a lot of different perspectives in that room, but a migrant background, particularly with some Asian heritage, Chinese influences, given the way that demographics are changing in Melbourne particularly, is just a different point of view that colours some of the conversations that we have in the boardroom

author: A
sentence: Oh, now you’re [pressing] 00:02:28 me

author: A
sentence: No I don’t think –

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that your conversations are heard, that your voice is heard, your particular voice?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Give me an example of how that's managed?

author: A
sentence: So I see my role in that boardroom specifically as asking questions that other people might not think to ask

author: A
sentence: So typically how it would go is, I would reflect on my own experiences or the experiences of my peers and pose a question in whatever context that discussion is happening, and it'll either be built upon by other directors or management will take it away to investigate

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's just a matter of being able to ask a question that can then get addressed

author: A
sentence: And it doesn't always mean that it immediately gets actioned in any way but at least then we can have a discussion about where that point of view comes from and whether we can confidently say that we know enough about that or do we need to do more investigative work

author: A
sentence: I feel sometimes that there's a lot of responsibility in expressing some of these views, because I'm conscious that at the end of the day I am speaking only from my experience and some anecdotal evidence of people around me

author: A
sentence: So a lot of it has to be supported by further research from management or whoever else they get involved

author: A
sentence: But it's just a starting point for a question to be asked

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, the research then starts

author: Q
sentence: Whereas, before it would be just left, there's no hypotheses, no question, so the research doesn't happen

author: Q
sentence: That's really good

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so everyone on the board plays a role in that, it's not like the chair is integral in this process

author: Q
sentence: All of the members on the board interact with you?

author: A
sentence: The THIS PRIVATE SCHOOL BOARD board is fantastic in that I think it's very open, I think everybody feels quite comfortable to express their opinions

author: A
sentence: I was certainly more reserved when I first joined the board, but I think that was natural in wanting to get an understanding of the culture and how things ran as opposed to feeling uncomfortable

author: A
sentence: It was just more about familiarity

author: A
sentence: Now I almost need to be careful not to take up too much time

author: Q
sentence: That's lovely

author: Q
sentence: Tell me because you went to the school itself, do you feel that – is the board a mirror of that culture? Do you feel it's a familiar culture for you?

author: A
sentence: This is pushing me to think back to that school

author: A
sentence: Look I think certainly the board espouses the values of the school, so as to whether it’s a direct reflection of the culture? Harder to say, but I think it's definitely built upon the same values

author: A
sentence: Which makes complete sense

author: A
sentence: I think if the board was being guided by values other than what the organisation stood for, the incongruity would be very obvious somewhere

author: A
sentence: So yeah, I think it’s been – it was obvious from even before I joined the board in that the directors that I did speak to were so willing

author: A
sentence: And these weren't directors that I had any relationship with

author: A
sentence: I think I'd met one of them at an event, at a school related event in passing

author: A
sentence: And I saw her name so I thought I'd reach out, and it was complete cold

author: A
sentence: I reached out on LinkedIn, “So I'm thinking about this, I think we've met before but I'm not sure

author: A
sentence: ” And she took time out of her weekend to have a coffee with me and talk about what it was like to be on the board and her experience and why she was involved

author: A
sentence: And then after that conversation when I decided that I would think about it more seriously I reached out to the chair, who again I hadn't met before and we didn't have a chance to meet up in person but we spoke over the phone and through those conversations I felt like I should put my name in the ring

author: Q
sentence: So you reached out to have those conversations, they didn't come to you?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Although I have to say I reached out on LinkedIn and that first conversation – so Annie, who's one of the other directors, we went out for coffee locally and I think one of her comments to me was like – well actually it probably wasn't at this first meeting, it was probably once I'd already joined the board

author: A
sentence: She’s like, “Let's be honest, you've been around

author: A
sentence: ” So I think they didn't reach out to me but by the time they'd received my application they were all familiar at least with my name because of other work that I'd done with the school since I'd left

author: A
sentence: So I'm quite actively involved in some other aspects of the school

author: A
sentence: And I think that as well was reflected well in their consideration to appoint me to the board

author: A
sentence: It’s, I have demonstrated my commitment and I'm familiar with these aspects of the school community

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: And so we talk about the role we play in directly attracting, having conversations with potential female board members, or those from different age demographics, so millennials, for example, as well

author: A
sentence: We actively play a role in sourcing and having conversations and bringing those people into the mix

author: Q
sentence: And gender diversity, what is that?  Is that just something you can measure that is a rough indicator of that?  Or it’s something different to cognitive diversity?  I’m just trying to think how these concepts work together

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure I understand

author: Q
sentence: If I’m getting an understanding of what you mean, cognitive diversity is like the root

author: Q
sentence: It’s through being able to manage complex decision-making in a dynamic and uncertain environment

author: Q
sentence: That’s important, that’s performance

author: Q
sentence: So that capacity that cognitive diversity gives you - now, we’re talking about people

author: Q
sentence: We’re trying to find the right people to give cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: Gender’s one that we can measure, and it’s important

author: Q
sentence: But gender, you did say that you feel there tends to be a difference in thinking with different genders, but it wasn’t the only thing

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive diversity, if I’m getting you right, is something much more fundamental, and there’s other factors

author: Q
sentence: Gender diversity won’t get it for you;  it’s insufficient

author: Q
sentence: So what else - I’m trying to get a schema in my head, if I’m getting this right

author: Q
sentence: Let’s think of an inverted triangle, performance is down the bottom

author: Q
sentence: That’s what the ultimate goal

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive diversity is the means to that end, but cognitive diversity, how do we find that?  Well, we can measure by gender and graph it

author: Q
sentence: There’s other kinds of diversity you said, diversity of background

author: Q
sentence: Are these just different kinds of diversity that you hope will deliver cognitive diversity?  Is it that, is that the logic?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Is it?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: From where you’re coming from, I think I understand what you’re saying

author: A
sentence: If where I’m hearing you, to get to the nirvana?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: If that’s the sort of goal, I believe it’s a little bit like - there’s a number of layers, I think, is where -

author: Q
sentence: How do you do that?

author: Q
sentence: I’m trying to understand -

author: A
sentence: Because there’s gender - I mean, there’s obviously skills, and age

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, skills matrix

author: A
sentence: There’s a whole range of other components that create the formula, potentially, for those - that level of decision-making

author: A
sentence: But, again, overarching all of those things is good leadership, and the bringing of it together, common goals alignment, constant review

author: A
sentence: There’s a lot in it

author: A
sentence: Diversity’s all one thing, but it’s about how it’s brought together and how it’s managed effectively to get the best outcomes

author: Q
sentence: So now that comes to good functioning

author: Q
sentence: So how might this diversity be facilitated or whatever so as it leads to optimal board functioning?

author: A
sentence: Let’s go back to the top:  ‘What’s our vision, and what’s the one and three-year goal, and what do the headwinds look like;  as an organisation what are our values, and do we have the right leader in place to guide us and share that vision’

author: A
sentence: That’s the role of the chair, and to an extent, the CEO

author: A
sentence: So if we’ve got that really clear, and we’ve and understood the matrix, and that’s aligned to that strategy, and we are aware that diversity has economic impacts - and then we’ve got the right level of behaviours and board performance review, KPIs, and coaching and mentorship and feedback - if all of that comes together, then the formula is there for you to be in a much better place than if it’s not

author: Q
sentence: And do your services help with these different - what different parts of this process do you -

author: A
sentence: The core part of the services we provide is around the sourcing and introduction of executives and non-executives

author: A
sentence: And that’s our core service

author: A
sentence: The how that we do that - which we talked about at the start - is through networking and head-hunting and all those components

author: A
sentence: But the service really is around the understanding

author: Q
sentence: Of what they need

author: A
sentence: As an executive search firm, we do that through networking, through head-hunting, through more traditional methods which might be advertising, but it’s less so

author: A
sentence: It’s more about proactively identifying

author: A
sentence: Of what they need

author: A
sentence: And then it’s around the coaching, and it’s around the influencing to get the right people into those organisations or onto those boards

author: A
sentence: There is an element post-that that we provide as well, which is assessment, and so the assessment is around looking at the performance of the executive team or looking at the performance of the board

author: A
sentence: That can be done through understanding what the KPIs are, individually assessing an individual through interviewing, and through - whether it’s some sort of 360 feedback

author: A
sentence: The board might review each other and we can align that together and we can feed back that to a chair

author: A
sentence: And then we can look to get process improvement

author: Q
sentence: But by understanding the full picture, you might ask questions about, ‘How does the chair manage, perhaps, conflict and difference on the board’?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: ‘And maybe we need some strategies around that’, and then someone else does that?

author: A
sentence: Good question

author: A
sentence: Our core business is around executive sourcing and selection

author: A
sentence: In terms of the coaching and ongoing mentoring of a chair, and the facilitation of improvement of board performance, that’s not our core business

author: Q
sentence: Who does that sort of stuff?

author: A
sentence: There are people within the - [Maryanne] 00:36:44, for example

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that’s what I’m thinking, so the leadership coaching

author: A
sentence: The leadership coaching would be really - experienced at all sites and have got board experience

author: A
sentence: The area we would be effective in would be around - because our core business is around assessment, so assessment of an individual’s capability for a potential role, and then it’s around assessment of an individual in their existing role

author: A
sentence: That would be based on a framework and a number of competencies that align to their role, and there’s a number of qualitative and quantitative tools that we’d use to formulate that assessment, some sort of testing, or interviewing, or interviewing others

author: A
sentence: But, again, if it’s aligned to a framework, we can come up with an assessment, a review, some recommendations

author: A
sentence: And then there are others who would work with the board to get them to the next level on an ongoing basis

author: A
sentence: We’d probablyhandle itat that stage

author: A
sentence: Part of the how is around working through industries, working through organisations, working through people and talent within those businesses or on different boards, and approaching them and having direct conversations about where they are at on their professional journey, whether that’s in that executive pathway or that non-executive pathway

author: A
sentence: That’s the how

author: A
sentence: It’s around a direct approach in working, head-hunting conversations

author: Q
sentence: It’s a complex field

author: Q
sentence: It must cost quite a bit

author: Q
sentence: I didn’t think about the costs of actually developing and maintaining a well-functioning board

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I didn’t even think of it as a cost, to be hones so there you go

author: Q
sentence: Now, we’ve talked about cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: How might you identify that when selecting board members?

author: A
sentence: So like in any process, there’s a methodology of behavioural-based interviewing, which we use as a  way of understanding someone’s ability around strategy, leadership, corporate governance

author: A
sentence: And so we can look at the past behaviours to predict the future

author: A
sentence: That’s one way

author: A
sentence: We would reference with other individuals their experiences, so a reference-checking process as well

author: A
sentence: We can test for commercial, financial acumen, leadership capability, work preferences

author: A
sentence: There’s a number of tools we can use again

author: A
sentence: Similar that we would use to assess the existing performance, we’d use to assess their potential

author: Q
sentence: If I was applying for a board, and you were involved in that selection process, I would be filling out questionnaires?

author: A
sentence: Probably not

author: A
sentence: It would probably be more done on an interview basis

author: A
sentence: But there could be some testing as well that’s done on top of that

author: A
sentence: Psychometric or analytical, numerical, or deductive

author: Q
sentence: I mean, we’ve all done Myers-Briggs, anyone who’s worked in an organisation

author: Q
sentence: They’re from around the world, you source them, and you apply them, so they’re those sorts of tools we’re talking about?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: That’s correct

author: Q
sentence: Are you a psychologist?

author: Q
sentence: Now, do you do anything or facilitate mentorship of people who might not be quite ready but they want to move into board positions in the future?

author: A
sentence: No, but we work with psychologists

author: A
sentence: And those sorts of Myers-Briggs or personality testing are not necessarily the tools to make the decisions

author: A
sentence: They’re more so around - and if you were the chair, that could be really useful in terms of, ‘Well, what’s this individual’s work preferences?  How do I understand this individual?’, more so to get the best out of them and to use techniques to draw the best out of them

author: Q
sentence: It’s to cultivate board candidates, and I was thinking there are people from social-economic disadvantaged backgrounds, for example

author: Q
sentence: They might struggle to pay to do a course, management and whatever, a director’s course, and they might have gone to the wrong university or they went to the wrong school

author: Q
sentence: So you’ve got someone from that background

author: Q
sentence: But they’ve come onto your radar through your networking or something

author: Q
sentence: They might have done law at Victoria Uni, but someone told me that they know a legal firm that deliberately sources graduates from Victoria University law because they are determined to succeed

author: Q
sentence: But that person may come with very little of the social-economic resources

author: Q
sentence: Is there anything you might do to help someone like that?  They can’t afford to pay for the course, they probably haven’t had some of the opportunities that others might have had

author: Q
sentence: Can you do anything?  Is it in your brief capacity?

author: A
sentence: There’s lots of examples where we identify special people, special talent, and invest time and energyand adviceand coaching and counselling around how best they manage their own career

author: A
sentence: That might be not necessarily paying for the AICD, but it might be around getting them access to people and leaders and individuals who might be able to get them onto a board, whether it’s a not-for-profit - or to facilitate that effectively for them

author: A
sentence: And there’s a recent example of a board we recently worked with who are in this space, so a not-for-profit, a non-paying board and more of a working board

author: A
sentence: And through referrals and speaking to a well-known director, we were given access to an individual who’s an exec

author: A
sentence: And this would be their first board role

author: A
sentence: An individual who - the brief we talked about, a refugee here in Australia, came out here, put himself through accounting, and he’s now working for a bank

author: A
sentence: And this was their first board role

author: A
sentence: And they’re probably a 34-year old individual

author: A
sentence: It’s the joining of the dots through the networking and the identification of good people, and then the introduction

author: A
sentence: And if you get a skills matrix of that particular board, it’s a really nice fit

author: Q
sentence: And that board paid for the person to do the board course?  The - whatever you called it, management -

author: A
sentence: Maybe

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if that particular organisation will, but there’d be no reason why, if the funds were there, for every board to want every one of their members to have done the GAICD

author: Q
sentence: It’s a capacity building strategy

author: Q
sentence: What do you see as the main barriers to building diversity boards in Australia?

author: A
sentence: Old-school views

author: A
sentence: Old-school boards

author: A
sentence: Boys’ clubs

author: A
sentence: Yes, to an extent

author: A
sentence: Part of our role in the executive search space is to guide, coach not in a structured way - i

author: A
sentence: e

author: A
sentence: structured mentorship program - but really just through advice and consultation

author: A
sentence: We will do that naturally as part of the conversation we have with individuals

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to ask you to explain what these mean

author: Q
sentence: Give me examples

author: A
sentence: Well, old-school views are - and, again, it comes back to this whole notion of unconscious bias

author: A
sentence: And so that’s the biggest [inaudible] 00:45:09

author: A
sentence: Looking for people like me, wanting to feel comfortable around individuals, and a misconception that finding people like you is a good thing

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s a bit of a demographic around this?  I’m thinking baby boomer, are they more prone to liking people to be more like them than, say, the millennials?  Or are the younger ones more open and comfortable with diversity, do you think, than, perhaps, the 60-plus?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I don’t have the answer

author: A
sentence: I’d love to see if there’s any research on that

author: Q
sentence: I haven’t seen any

author: A
sentence: It’s a really interesting point

author: A
sentence: Because I don’t know if necessarily all millennials are as diverse as we think in their thinking

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I don’t know the answer to that question

author: A
sentence: There’s a lot of data to suggest what millennials - I mean, we know the kind of history around millennials being - and having a draw towards being more purpose-driven and cause-related

author: A
sentence: So you could argue that there potentially could be that link to being a bit more open to more diversity, but I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I’d be interested if there’s any data on this

author: Q
sentence: It’d have to be in Australia, too, rather than -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I don’t know the answer to that question

author: A
sentence: My gut would say they probably are

author: A
sentence: But I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: Because I’m just thinking, the high school kids, 40 years ago high school kids looked much more homogenous than now because we’re a much more diverse -

author: A
sentence: Yes, so my gut would say they probably are

author: A
sentence: But I haven’t seen the data on that

author: A
sentence: And that might be around the how, how they might build up their skills to become more attractive to a board

author: A
sentence: That might be through finding ways to introduce them to the right people - be it shares or selection committees - to be on the radar, if you like, to have more access to those sorts of opportunities

author: Q
sentence: I’ll see if there’s some research on that at some stage, I think

author: Q
sentence: So barriers, what do these barriers - situation five years ago, you’ve said that

author: Q
sentence: You said five years ago it was less diverse, perhaps?  Five years, anyway

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about the lack of change?  Or do you feel it’s changed much in five years?  Diversity, the appetite for it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I’m going to have a punt at this one

author: A
sentence: And the gender conversation’s probably the one that’s got the most noise

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about that?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s great

author: A
sentence: I think what I said before was - I’ll use an example of PwC

author: A
sentence: PwC have doubled their workforce in the last five years;  as in, their numbers of staff

author: A
sentence: They actually made the decision as a leadership group that the notion of diversity was a really hard one to address, every bucket, so the one they chose was gender

author: A
sentence: And they actually have quotas - with a very old-school partner group, very male-dominated - around the numbers of female partners that are promoted

author: A
sentence: And what that’s actually forced in their organisation has actually meant that they’ve become more diverse in education

author: A
sentence: Because it actually - they can’t rely on accountants and lawyers just - a lot of males, so they’ve gone out to other - engineers and a number of other faculties

author: A
sentence: They’ve gone into a broader ethnicity base to get more female talent into the organisation

author: A
sentence: And as a result of having a focus on the quota of females and, ‘We need to promote more female partners’, it’s actually broadened the diversity of other groups as a result because of the lack of talent that they’ve had

author: A
sentence: They’ve had to be wider in their recruitment

author: A
sentence: I think gender’s probably the one that’s driven the most noise, but I think that that’s had an impact on other diversity buckets, if you like

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: That relates back to an earlier question

author: Q
sentence: That’s a really interesting idea

author: Q
sentence: And so, in a way, it’s served us well that in the university sector, which I obviously look at as a feeder

author: Q
sentence: There’s some gender bias

author: Q
sentence: There’s not as many female engineers, for example

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to be interviewing this woman who is an advocate for female engineers in a couple of days

author: Q
sentence: But that lack of females in that area - then in the mining, if they’re asking for a quota of females, it might pull in people from philosophy, other backgrounds, because there’s a lack of female engineers

author: Q
sentence: I like that

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: A
sentence: So the correlation between - whilst I don’t agree with quotas, they went down the quota pathway

author: A
sentence: But it got them to a stage where they as an organisation - so the economics were that they’ve doubled their business somewhat in the last five years, revenue-wise

author: A
sentence: They’ve doubled their staff

author: A
sentence: But they’ve been a much more diverse group of individuals as a result of that

author: A
sentence: And they’ve had to because the talent pools are quite tight in certain areas

author: Q
sentence: Are there areas that are perhaps female-dominated?

author: A
sentence: Marketing, functionally

author: A
sentence: Digital

author: A
sentence: Again, we’re looking at nursing, and the health sector, and education tend to be - I mean, we all know this stuff

author: Q
sentence: Would you suggest they do some courses?  Board director courses or things like that as well?

author: Q
sentence: Let’s imagine, let’s take one of those, marketing

author: Q
sentence: If it is female-dominated, if the quota was 50% females, 50% males, do you think that might have a benefit because it brings in more men?

author: A
sentence: I’m not really in agreeance with quotas

author: Q
sentence: Because you did say that initially

author: A
sentence: And, again, it comes back to the strategy of, ‘What are we trying to achieve’

author: A
sentence: And I come at this from a recruiter’s perspective, which is around solving the problem around, ‘Where are we going as an organisation’

author: A
sentence: And taking out anything to do with any group necessarily and bring it back to, ‘What’s going to give us the best result’

author: A
sentence: I think overlaying that with having less bias, so if they’d been more self-aware

author: A
sentence: A combination of the two is what gives us the best result

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about these agenda targets, you’ve said that

author: Q
sentence: Is there any other kind of diversity that you think matters?  Yes, you’ve said that

author: Q
sentence: What was the situation five years ago, you’ve said that

author: Q
sentence: So I’m - finally now, looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?  And why do you think it would be good?

author: A
sentence: I think that the diversity of Australian boards needs to be at the absolute forefront of the conversation to begin with

author: A
sentence: There needs to be much deeper and better training and education around the commercial and economic impact that a more diverse board adds

author: A
sentence: And then as a result of that, in terms of what the makeup of boards looks like in 10 years compared to today, I would like to see more female participation, I would like to see greater ethnicity, more millennials

author: A
