sentence: So the traditional makeup of the board as it stands today, to look different in 10 years

author: A
sentence: And I think that that really comes with - less about quotas, and less about, ‘We feel this is what the market’s telling us’, but much deeper appreciation for the commercial benefit and impact it has

author: A
sentence: And therefore, as a result, we just have naturally a much more diverse group of individuals running organisations

author: Q
sentence: So are you doing something to provide that evidence base?  Are you involved in research?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, we are

author: A
sentence: One of our pillars as an organisation, last year was around leadership;  this year it’s around diversity and inclusion

author: A
sentence: We did a big piece of research last year on leadership, which actually had a really interesting link around what our leaders are looking foris a much more inclusive, vulnerable, open leadership style

author: A
sentence: And the days of hard versus soft leadership are very different

author: A
sentence: We are looking for soft leadership

author: A
sentence: That’s what people want

author: A
sentence: That’swhat they’re not getting

author: A
sentence: And so we think there’s a really strong correlation, if we talk about the gender conversation, that - not stereotyping female leaders, but there’s a suggestion to say that females can dial up that ability to be more vulnerable or empathetic, use the softer side of leadership

author: A
sentence: Because there’s arguments to say that they’ve got more of that in-built in them than males

author: A
sentence: And so - and that’s what we think the future of leadership looks like

author: A
sentence: And males and females need to demonstrate that

author: A
sentence: But we think there’s an opportunity for females to really dial that up

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think becoming a graduate of the Australian Institute of Company Directors is an important part of the process in terms of understanding all of the elements of what it is to be a board member, from the governance, et cetera, perspective

author: A
sentence: There’s a theory-based component that just gives people - and funnily enough, though, a lot of board directors I meet, they haven’t done the GAICD

author: A
sentence: And so I don’t think that necessarily means that they’re not as capable or experienced or knowledgeable, but I think it is an important start for someone who’s looking to go on that journey

author: A
sentence: Because it just gives a very good foundation about the role of a board member

author: A
sentence: And then going forward - so that was last year

author: A
sentence: We will be focusing this year on more research around diversity and inclusion, the kind of impacts that that might have on businesses for the future

author: A
sentence: I can share with you when we get to that

author: Q
sentence: I’ll shoot you a review article, if you’d like - it’s international - on diversity and performance

author: Q
sentence: It’s a review from last year

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well, that might be an opportunity for us to get involved together, is some of the research

author: Q
sentence: That’s what I was thinking

author: Q
sentence: I mean, this research is being led by the professor of governance at La Trobe

author: Q
sentence: She’s amazing

author: Q
sentence: She’s overseas at the moment

author: A
sentence: There could be a real link

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, we’ll stay connected

author: A
sentence: I’ll send you the report that we did for the research we did last year on leadership

author: Q
sentence: Be brilliant

author: A
sentence: But this is our topic for this year

author: Q
sentence: It’s great because it’s ours

author: Q
sentence: And you mentioned selection committees

author: Q
sentence: How do you link your potential board candidate to a selection committee?  How would you do that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so there’s opportunity for us to get involved in that together

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: It’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Back to the final question

author: Q
sentence: What do you think needs to happento make it look like what you want it to look like in 10 years’ time?  What needs to happen at a government level, governing institutions, industry bodies, director programs?  Individuals such as leadership coaches and head-hunters?  What needs to happen?  “No, let’s start again”

author: Q
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Look, I think that this needs to continue to be a topic that we talk about

author: A
sentence: And with that, education and evidence-based impact that more diverse boards and organisations have

author: A
sentence: I think that that’s where it starts

author: A
sentence: And as leaders, we need to have advocates at the chair level and at the CEO level, who are filtering that conversation down through organisations

author: A
sentence: That’s got to be where it starts

author: A
sentence: It’s got to be the leaders that are open and prepared to talk about it, and to back a more diverse board or a more diverse organisation

author: A
sentence: That’s that filtering down, and then within that there’s storytelling around the organisations that have had economic impact or have made significant change or transformation through having more diversity

author: A
sentence: I think that’s where it looks

author: A
sentence: In terms of funding and the like, potentially there could be more programs out there to get more flexibility

author: A
sentence: From a gender point of view, there’s that whole argument that we get more females through

author: Q
sentence: I’m thinking universities, in every subject we teach, we probably should include leadership, and then whoever’s doing the subject, whether they’re male or female or whatever, leadership is part of it

author: Q
sentence: Because I’m thinking, even if your career is research into black holes, it has an influence

author: Q
sentence: We’ve just hadthe first photograph of a black hole

author: Q
sentence: This is amazing, so leadership helps you understand how you might work as a team, how you might collaborate effectively across countries and stuff like that

author: Q
sentence: Maybe that would help us achieve more diversity on boards

author: Q
sentence: Because we’re thinking in terms of, ‘We can contribute through leadership, whatever our background is’

author: Q
sentence: Say if I’m a philosopher, if I’m a mathematician, I can get on a board and contribute as a leader

author: Q
sentence: Or get on a professional board

author: Q
sentence: You know what I mean?  So everyone’s thinking in terms of how they can contribute through the boards

author: Q
sentence: And so that’s, I’m thinking, a push from below

author: Q
sentence: A consumer demand sort of thing

author: A
sentence: Yes, yeah

author: A
sentence: And, again, that comes back to the notion of storytelling as well

author: A
sentence: We’re able to tell their stories around the philosopher that joined the BHP board and has had huge impact on sustainability and just ways of thinking

author: Q
sentence: The ways of thinking

author: A
sentence: And that’s a great outcome for everyone

author: A
sentence: Society, economics, and shareholder

author: Q
sentence: Another participant put me in contact with you because in our conversation, the issue of people who influence boards by providing services to them, helping them search, is a key factor in board diversity, and you happen to be in that space

author: Q
sentence: This is what I want to focus on with you so that’s great

author: Q
sentence: First of all, how do you build your network of potential directors that you put forward to boards?

author: A
sentence: A lot of what we would do would really come back to the brief, and the brief has a lot of layers to it

author: A
sentence: The best practice elements around that might be around, really, from a matrix point of view, what’s the current makeup of the board in terms of skills and gender and experience, be it functional

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Are there any final comments you’d like to make before we close?

author: A
sentence: I think that covers it

author: A
sentence: It’s been really good insight for me too

author: Q
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: I’d love to see a transcript

author: A
sentence: And I think there would be a great opportunity at some point for us to talk again about what you’re doing around diversity, and how we might be able to work together to use research and our network or something to help unpack this issue

author: A
sentence: Because we’re really passionate about it

author: Q
sentence: Well, I’ll put you in touch

author: A
sentence: Underlying that is where the organisation is at in terms of its strategy and what do they see coming up in terms of the next 12 months to three years, and so that could be digital disruption, for example, and what’s the capability of the organisation from a board perspective in areas of that type of functional or technical type of skill

author: A
sentence: But I think having an understanding of the current board matrix, having an understanding of the strategy, and the potential headwinds or challenges that the organisation’s facing can then help to identify what type of board members we might need to enable that organisation to move forward in the future

author: Q
sentence: Is that one of the services - on your website you have board services

author: Q
sentence: Is analysing the board - that’s one of the things you do?

author: A
sentence: Yes, yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: And good practice around sourcing and selecting is around understanding and having a really clear understanding of what that board matrix looks like

author: A
sentence: I mean, that’s quite a simple process to do

author: A
sentence: Not that complex

author: A
sentence: But once it’s identified and you look at the board matrix structure, and you start to see the makeup of males and we’re 60 years-plus, and we’re CFOs - and we’re looking at a business that’s going through some significant transformation and change, and has been disrupted through technology or an ageing target market that might look very different - we probably need to start thinking, ‘Do we have the right board structure in place to enable the business to prosper in the future’

author: Q
sentence: Do you work with the Chair primarily in these discussions?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sothat would be a natural - or the relevant selection committee member

author: A
sentence: So a combination of the two would be where it comes from

author: A
sentence: But I also think good practice is to have as many conversations with as many of the board as possible to be aligned and understand, ‘Are we aligned on what the organisation’s goals are, challenges, and what their future would look like in terms of new board members’

author: Q
sentence: There’s questions that are coming to my mind that are not on this sheet, and so I wantto pursue that because you’ve got a unique angle that we need, so I’m flying by the seat of my pants

author: Q
sentence: What about, if, when you’re talking to the different board members, you can see there’s a lack of diversity, and this is a potential issue, given the goals and their situation, their strategy and their situation?  How might you work that potential inertia within the board and homogeneity in the board?  And perhaps resistance to diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yes, indeed

author: A
sentence: The network has been built up over many years of performing executive search assignments

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s agreat question, and there’s no easy answer

author: A
sentence: Particularly when there are - what we have is unconscious bias in many situations, and breaking down unconscious bias is one of our biggest challenges as an executive search firm

author: A
sentence: And it’s actually one of the challenges we face as an organisation in selecting people as well

author: A
sentence: We have to, as search professionals, be trained in how to overcome unconscious bias

author: A
sentence: I think that it starts with the individuals

author: A
sentence: That’s number 1

author: Q
sentence: And can you unpack unconscious bias?

author: A
sentence: So unconscious bias, in essence, is around the unconscious ways we naturally make decisions on people

author: A
sentence: And we have unconscious bias towards age, towards religion, towards gender

author: A
sentence: And so having an awareness - and there are tools and techniques to be tested on that, to understand what your potential blockers are, and then have self-awareness around that

author: A
sentence: And then there are potential ways, techniques that we can use, to remove some of those:  removing names off resume, removing age off resumes, particularly universities that someone went to;  interests and memberships

author: A
sentence: All those sorts of things that we naturally may have informed views on, so there’s some techniques we can use for our own individual ways to minimise that

author: A
sentence: But then, coming back to your point around how we might educate or share with a decision-maker, it’s not easy

author: A
sentence: There’s case studies, there’s prior history in terms of board makeup, and examples of organisations that have been able to lead the way and transform and change

author: A
sentence: And by providing those sorts of examples and case studies to help an individual understand why a more diverse board can have economic impact

author: Q
sentence: Because my reading of the literature - international literature - is that it’s inconclusive, the actual impacts

author: Q
sentence: And a lot of that is quantitative research

author: Q
sentence: The link between diversity and performance is inconclusive

author: Q
sentence: But then there’s critiques of that, which says, “That’s because the methodologies are different”

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got bodies of case studies that you use, this is interesting

author: A
sentence: Yes, and there are two sides to the coin

author: A
sentence: I’m of the view that a more diverse board - and I’m not always talking about gender

author: A
sentence: I’m talking about just how we create different levels of thinking

author: A
sentence: And depending on what an organisation’s strategy and needs are and what the headwinds look like, it can play an important role

author: A
sentence: It is a case-by-case example

author: A
sentence: Quotas I don’t agree with

author: Q
sentence: Great, there was a question on that

author: A
sentence: But I think that having an appreciation for what the business’ challenges and needs and what the strategy is and aligning that to the right mix of individuals - their skills, experience, backgrounds - is the best approach

author: Q
sentence: It’s getting the right fit for the right time, first time

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: How many years are we talking?

author: Q
sentence: That aligns with a director I interviewed last week who was very entrepreneurial, and that was his idea

author: Q
sentence: Similar age, actually, probably, to you

author: Q
sentence: It’s interesting, I’m seeing the patterns

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to move to this so as we can start linking your data with other people

author: Q
sentence: How do you think - because you’ve been right in this space for 15 years, you can look at it for 15 years quite easily

author: Q
sentence: How has the composition of boards that you’re familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think we’ve seen a big shift towards more females

author: Q
sentence: And why do you think that?

author: A
sentence: No question there’s a view that a more diverse female - from the gender perspective - has just a different level of outcome and output and ways of thinking that create economic value to an organisation

author: A
sentence: There’s just cases and cases where that is very clear, and so that’s probably the biggest shift that I’ve seen

author: A
sentence: More recently we’re starting to see more - and I’m not talking ASX necessarily, top 100, but probably more mid-sized organisations, an appreciation for age

author: A
sentence: Millennials and Gen Y being - there is a different way of thinking, I think, that the demographics have

author: A
sentence: And there is more of an appetite to have more millennials on boards

author: A
sentence: It’s hard because there’s a gap in skill

author: Q
sentence: What skill is missing?

author: A
sentence: Well, experience

author: A
sentence: I’ll put experience

author: A
sentence: And there’s a perception that someone may not have - there’s a link, a perception - whether you call it an unconscious bias, again - about experience and capability, which is where I think there’s been a gap, and why there’s probably not as many millennials going onto boards

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed a couple of people who would be entrepreneurs and start-ups, and there seems to be a view that maybe that capability might be a bounded way of thinking and being, and limiting

author: Q
sentence: That’s really challenged my preconceived ideas of diversity

author: Q
sentence: Even as a researcher, you think, ‘Right, these are the ideas garnered from the literature’ and whatever, and it was like I was being completely refreshed and reframed in these interviews

author: Q
sentence: How might you respond?  I don’t know, do you ever work with start-ups?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: Your Organisation has been in existence for 15 years, and so the network has been built up through many years of performing executive search assignments

author: A
sentence: That gives the access to a pool of talent who are actively pursuing opportunities, board appointments or executive roles, because there are executives that perform executive roles as well as non-executive roles

author: A
sentence: The pool of talent is made up of both non-exec and execs that can perform both roles

author: Q
sentence: How do they feel about this capability idea and experience?  I don’t want to put words in your mouth, but do they have a different view, perhaps, to your bigger organisation, more established organisation?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, start-ups are probably a unique example in some way because their needs might be more around investors and equity and funding, and so having big-name, experienced board members is actually more appealing

author: Q
sentence: You would be [inaudible] 00:19:05 that's experience?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so probably getting back to the notion of the organisational goals

author: A
sentence: And also having more experience - grey hair, if you like - on the board in terms of guiding businesses going through this sort of growth

author: A
sentence: High growth is where it’s about bringing governance and structure and process, and having more experience can sometimes be a good thing

author: A
sentence: And I think there’s an appetite that more start-up businesses might have to have more of that type of experience

author: A
sentence: On the reverse, though, businesses that are larger and corporates that are going through really changing dynamics from a new market or they’ve been disrupted because of technology, it probably goes in reverse, and having less - the experienced, old ways of thinking is probably an inhibitor, and hence the reason why having a more diverse millennial-style individual in a business like that could be a good thing

author: Q
sentence: How would you explain that?  Say I’m the chair of a board who’s in that situation

author: Q
sentence: How would you explain to me that this 30-year-old person would be really good for us to have on the board?

author: A
sentence: Well, again, coming back to the skills matrix, and coming back to the strategy, and coming back to the headwinds and what it looks like in 12 months or three years, if there’s argument to say that - if there’s a gap in that level of experience or thinking, then presenting that as an option, to review candidates that have that type of profile

author: A
sentence: Assuming that they’ve got the commercial acumen and the financial acumen and they understand governance, et cetera

author: A
sentence: But I think presenting - I mean, our role is not to make the decision for organisations, but our role is to guide and coach and suggest

author: A
sentence: And through analysis, we’re able to then provide options, and counsel an organisation as to, ‘Have you considered this type of individual’

author: A
sentence: And then, ‘This might be an example of an organisation that’s done that and has had great benefit’

author: Q
sentence: Are these the case studies?  They’re from your business experience, is this the case studies that you were talking about?

author: A
sentence: That’s right, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Some board members have exec experience and some don’t?

author: Q
sentence: So they’re Australian?  Because you’re an Australian business

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: They’re Australian, they’re situated in this culture, in this institutional environment, so they’re appropriate?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Let’s say the board saw the logic of what you’re saying, the chair and the board, but they were concerned about lack of experience

author: Q
sentence: Would you facilitate or enable them by perhaps linking them with a coaching service?  Would you do something like that?  Is that the sort of - a way you would facilitate diversity of boards?  Do you know what I mean?

author: A
sentence: I do, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So the 30-year-old might get the job, but they’re on trainer wheels, they’ve got a mentor

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a role, yes, and there’s a role the chair plays

author: Q
sentence: The chair would do that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: And some go through an evolution of taking on non-executive roles - whilst in an executive role - as a pathway to becoming a professional non-exec director, once they get to that stage of their career where they no longer will be an exec

author: A
sentence: I think the pool is joined

author: Q
sentence: It’s not your organisation?

author: A
sentence: It wouldn’t be our organisation

author: A
sentence: You might suggest pairing them up with someone from the AICD, or having an external coach, or the role the chair or the rest of the board plays

author: A
sentence: And I’m not suggesting that there’s a lack of millennials on boards here

author: A
sentence: That’s not my point here

author: A
sentence: I mean, it would be just one of the areas that perhaps there’s a lack of understanding

author: Q
sentence: The kind of boards that are perhaps most diverse, we’ve got not-for-profits, for-profits

author: Q
sentence: By industry, you’ve said that the ASX 100 tend to be less diverse, is that right?

author: A
sentence: I mean, there’s probably anecdotal evidence to suggest that

author: A
sentence: We do know just under 30% of the top 100 ASX are female

author: Q
sentence: From a gender point of view, definitely

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and from an age and so forth

author: Q
sentence: But probably the other things too

author: Q
sentence: Do you think gender diversity is a bit like - one person did say that they saw gender diversity as a signal of other kinds of diversity

author: Q
sentence: It’s measurable, so you can measure gender diversity and you can put it into graphs and disclose it, report on it

author: Q
sentence: But if a board lacks gender diversity, they’re probably likely to lack the other kinds of diversity

author: Q
sentence: Do you agree with that?

author: A
sentence: It’s a good question, and I don’t have the data to make that total assumption on that

author: A
sentence: But I would suggest that’s a pretty reasonable assumption

author: Q
sentence: A rule of thumb?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: A
sentence: And the notion of gender diversity is one that is - diversity’s an interesting whole conversation

author: A
sentence: And organisations, whether at the exec level or the board level - because I do think it feeds down into an organisation if a board has the view that we’d be - we’ll become more diverse

author: A
sentence: And it’s hard to tackle everything in one go, and organisations, at all levels, have probably found tackling gender is just the starting point

author: A
sentence: And then it feeds down into some of the other areas

author: Q
sentence: And how do you develop diversity in this pool?  Or the diversity of this pool?  Or do you?

author: A
sentence: Because it’s just hard overnight to address every group from a diversity perspective and make change across the board

author: A
sentence: And I think organisations that I’ve seen perhaps tackle gender as the first one, and then will start to let that flow down

author: Q
sentence: Why is it easier, the gender one, do you think?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if it’s easier, actually

author: A
sentence: Because if I actually think about it, there’s this issueof - in certain industries - a lack of great female executives

author: A
sentence: Just they’ve chosen for being a mother, or career as not being their priority for a period of time

author: A
sentence: It’s harder and there’s just less of them

author: A
sentence: I don’t think there’s an easy on that one either

author: Q
sentence: But it’s clearer, you can measure it, is that the point?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: Q
sentence: And manage it, therefore

author: Q
sentence: Now, how important - I’ve got - 10 is extremely important

author: Q
sentence: Board diversity’s extremely important, 10, or not important at all, 1

author: Q
sentence: Where would you rate it?

author: A
sentence: Ten

author: Q
sentence: And do you think it’s always been important?  Has it always been important to Australian boards?  And perhaps if I move to the next point which is, if you feel it hasn’t, what has led to the change?  The change of view that diversity is really important, extremely important to boards?  What’s led to that change?

author: A
sentence: I think that organisations have become - they’re waking up to the fact that a more diverse board has economic impact

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of how they - what’s woken people up?

author: A
sentence: That’s a really interesting question

author: A
sentence: And in terms of developing diversity, if we just go back a step and we define it by other things than just gender - when we talk about age and demographics, and we talk about ethnicity, religious beliefs and a whole range of other factors - I think naturally there is just this - a great pool of individuals that have been built up that sit within a number of those different buckets

author: A
sentence: Though, through our beliefs that a more diverse board has a greater economic impact, we actively play a role in sourcing and attracting individuals that may come from more diverse backgrounds

author: A
sentence: I just think that organisations have realised that with changing economies, and with changing technology, and with changing societal views, with the internationalisation, globalisation, organisations are waking up that if you don’t have a diverse board, you don’t have diverse thinking,  you don’t have diverse perspectives, you don’t have diverse views, and you become very single-minded

author: A
sentence: And things change very quickly, so having that level of thinking and diversity in different views from different individuals - be it ethnicity, or whether it be gender, or whether it be age - allows for much better decision-making, for much better agility, for much greater way of - for just different thinking

author: Q
sentence: And that’s cognitive diversity, that’s what people mean?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: What you’re looking for is really that improved problem-solving?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: And so cognitive diversity is really about enabling that

author: A
sentence: Yes, correct

author: Q
sentence: So this is the basis that you’re moving on?

author: A
sentence: The outcome is the economics, but the basis is the diversity of thinkingand the notion of cognitive decision-making

author: Q
sentence: Good, so yes, you’re an engineer and you’re being influential or seeking to encourage women into engineering, is that correct; this is what I’ve heard, in order to get them through, or why are you doing this?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that might have been it because I couldn’t find you as an author so I’m sorry I tried to-

author: A
sentence: Yeah, look I think you’re not going to get the change you want without some targets there

author: Q
sentence: Because of this private at the second -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, you won’t

author: A
sentence: And I was having a conversation with someone last night and this is about trying to get more pilots to be women and there was a positive description towards women

author: A
sentence: And he said, “Well think about that, someone with the lowest score got in

author: A
sentence: ” And I said, “Well 50 years ago, it was the opposite that women who could have done it, didn’t get in even though they had better scores and now it’s the opposite

author: A
sentence: ” It’s going to bounce out and when we get there, there’s going to have to be a correction

author: A
sentence: So,unfortunately, they go, “Yeah right, just okay

author: A
sentence: “You think about the long-term, it’s a long-term, we’re not talking about today and tomorrow, we’re talking about trying to make a correction and once people are in there, more people will want to be in; but you’ve got to get them in there in the first place and we’re going to need that positive thing to get -

author: Q
sentence: So, how do you think the culture, this dare I say, the token, the risk of tokenism, how might that then affect the culture of oh well this could be the cockpit fit and we’re really looking at boards

author: Q
sentence: If that is the perception, you’re here because you’ve ticked a box

author: A
sentence: Just have to get over it

author: Q
sentence: [inaudible] 00:37:55 have to get over it, the board or both

author: A
sentence: Both I think

author: A
sentence: We’re just going to say, there’s going to be some backflak from it

author: A
sentence: We’re looking at the longer-term benefit

author: A
sentence: People always have that for you

author: A
sentence: They could be right or could be wrong and there’ll be some good highs and some bad highs but that’s what we have now, isn’t it really

author: A
sentence: I think that’s an excuse not to take some action

author: A
sentence: I hear that argument, that’s fine you can have that argument, but I don’t think that’s a reason not to go ahead

author: A
sentence: Maybe, some of the targets to me seemed a little bit too big

author: A
sentence: I think just moderate, maybe go 50% but maybe you’ve got 10, 20 or 30 is not a bad target

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But with targets, do you think there’s some things that can’t be measured that matter? Because targets imply you can measure them, you can say 30% or 40%

author: A
sentence: Oh, well that’s always the case, isn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but there are things that you’ve been talking about that are really hard to measure

author: A
sentence: It’s all right, it’s fine

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, a lot

author: A
sentence: Well I mean there’s a lot of – look the biggest issue with 50% on boards is that there are not 50% of executives who are women, so it’s just a very difficult pull to select from

author: A
sentence: If you’ve only got 10% of executives are women, and you want 50% on the boards -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, do the maths

author: Q
sentence: I’m really going back to this what you’ve said about your experience which is just because we’ve had the technological revolution, we don’t have secretaries except for maybe the CE

author: Q
sentence: We all run from our mobiles, from our laptops, and whatever and so you miss the support

author: A
sentence: There’s no support in business now

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so this could be an invisible glass ceiling

author: A
sentence: I think it is

author: A
sentence: I think you’ll hang around but you won’t be able to go to the next level because the way you succeed more in the mantra is you go out for dinner; you’re catching up in the corridor; you’re making those other connections; you might be at some business dinner and you can’t, it’s just very hard to do that when you’ve got kids

author: A
sentence: And also, if I think on it being one of the reasons I finally resigned from Exxon is I coined the term I was diarising toilet breaks and it was so busy; and even then, and I’m busier now I’d say but I thought I was busy then

author: A
sentence: And I remember, it was one weekend anyway, I was so busy, someone left the front door open, one of the children wandered down the street; I justwasn’t there, and I go, Joan try to do all this and it’s my safety with the kids and they keep talking about that you’re not talking to your kids

author: A
sentence: We can have some social mess up

author: A
sentence: It’s really interesting to know and that’s why I just think, gosh I don’t know how to advise women going through it right now, if they have kids and stuff

author: A
sentence: I go, I did it and I think I did it pretty well but -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, there was a bit of luck maybe

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: My kids are pretty good

author: A
sentence: I was lucky they’re pretty healthy and the kids were okay, but I hear some terrible stories of really difficult children who just need a more present parent all the time and that’s not that it worked every time

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: And the extended family thing, because of our -

author: A
sentence: It’s so limited, yeah, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: - where it’s a global community, you spend a lot of your time overseas

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re not where your parent – you know, there’s not the parents to call on or siblings that might have come in 50 years agoif and when we’re trying to do it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so,that’s reallygood to bring that into my head but I think the technological part of it and no secretaries, that is across the board, across all industries and that is the factornow, who does that impact more?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, well that’s what she was meaning

author: Q
sentence: And so, she said that you would be really useful to our project because you could shed some light on how you’ve been trying to increase the number of women in engineering getting through to senior management experience in order that they can have a go of boards in this industry

author: A
sentence: I think its women, I think it is because often, and especially single women, even worse so because -

author: Q
sentence: It’s impossible

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so maybe and I’m single now, I’ve been ten years but guys, maybe they know so much because they’ve got someone sometimes at home keeping an eye on them and checking on this, you’ve just got nothing

author: A
sentence: You’re just going, no one is thinking about you in any capacity

author: A
sentence: Sometimes I go, really

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it’s really hard

author: Q
sentence: I see it’s a hard call, like you can’t advise, but anyway, you’ve been a role model and you can share your experience

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Look I think the workplace is much better for women and people behave better, they talk to each other with more respect

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve heard over a meeting with all guys in there and they’re shouting at each other

author: A
sentence: And then I open the door, going, “Is there a problem here?”“Oh, no this is how we talk

author: A
sentence: ” I said, “Well do you mind not

author: A
sentence: This is not very good to me

author: A
sentence: Only just quieten down and just have a bit,” so, I think people do behave better and that’s a good thing

author: Q
sentence: That’s funny

author: Q
sentence: So, what do you see the main barriers to building diverse boards?

author: A
sentence: Well it is a pipeline and I think it’s the experience

author: A
sentence: If you’ve never worked with another woman on the board or had – half these guys probably haven’t worked for a male boss or a female boss or something like that, it’s just a change and it’s how prepared they are

author: A
sentence: Women are very busy to take that on

author: A
sentence: I remember onetimeI was trying to employ a new scheduler or something and there were two applied and it was within the company and it was a guy and a girl

author: A
sentence: I remember thinking at the time, both of them were quite capable; the girl probably would actually be more capable but she needed a bit more training and I had no time to train; and I go, “I’ve got no time, I’m going to have to select him because he’s done half the job anyway,” and you can hit the ground running, even though I knew it would be great but I’ve got no spare capacity

author: A
sentence: And I do think again the way the workplace is, there’s this thing, well we’ll train them up, it doesn’t happen

author: A
sentence: So, if people aren’t already got experience, even though we talk about you can cross into it, because people can adjust, but the pace just I think it takes time

author: Q
sentence: That’s come out in other interviews, the pace has but not the implications for the pipeline

author: Q
sentence: So, that’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: It sounds awful

author: A
sentence: I know and yes it does, it’s just seems it’s going to be hard work

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I don’t want to get you into a stress

author: Q
sentence: So, has this pace increased say over the last five years; is there a turn?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And look, it’s complex at every level but one example I did, for a while there I actually worked in Melbourne University and so what I decided to do was trying to get more post graduate women back into university sector and lecture positions

author: A
sentence: Andwhat I do is try and create a scholarship because you know most graduates are always desperate for money and then they want to keep doing study or do a scholarship

author: A
sentence: But I said, “Well I’m not going to do a single scholarship

author: A
sentence: ” I’m not having some poor woman there just by herself

author: A
sentence: I’m only going to put the scholarship up if I can get three women; that they can actually, once you’re there, you can actually then learn from each other and have a voice

author: A
sentence: And so, I think that’s very important in women

author: A
sentence: If you just put a token of women in there, theydon’t have a voice and you only then attracting women who want to act and behave like everyone else, so what’s the point

author: A
sentence: And I think one of the books that really informed me was of that Amanda Sinclair’s one: Doing Leadership Differently

author: A
sentence: And I thought about that quite heavily when I was at Melbourne University

author: A
sentence: And she said there’s four stages of getting women into leadership

author: A
sentence: And the first stage is where people are; it depends where people are at as to how you take them to the next stage

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I’d say, definitely from the last ten years and up to now, it’s still just getting faster

author: A
sentence: And look I think I’ve changed from I’ve always been on the client- and I’m on the services-side now; it’s the first time, which is almost never heard of

author: A
sentence: You normally don’t go from one, you’re always on the client-side of the services

author: A
sentence: But the wayengineering has changed is all the work I’m doing now, would have be done on the client-side when I first started work

author: A
sentence: So, you’d have all your engineers in with Exxon or even with BP

author: A
sentence: What they’ve decided is well, they want to cut costs, so they move it out to a lower-cost provider, and we provide internal services into these companies

author: A
sentence: So, it’s a change of the model but it means there is no downtime really; whereas I suppose in a client-side you produce something over a year, and you might stop, and you celebrate and you make money for the goods

author: A
sentence: We’re a labour hire company so you only make money when the people are working

author: A
sentence: So, you don’t stop for an hour for lunch

author: A
sentence: You make 10% on the whole time

author: A
sentence: So, if you stop working, your business goes down

author: A
sentence: It’s a very different model

author: A
sentence: I think the site’s pretty busy

author: Q
sentence: When did that happen?

author: A
sentence: Look I think it’s been over the last say 15, 20 years

author: A
sentence: It started mainly in engineering when they couldn’t handle the unions, the companies and so they said, “Oh, we’re outsource another company, we’d have a new set of union agreements and that’s the only way we’re going to get those rates down by stopping and hiring them and getting this other company,” so that’s where it started from

author: A
sentence: Anyway so, I’m digressing again

author: Q
sentence: No, but this is giving me a sense of the pace, and over ten years

author: Q
sentence: So, the model has to be sensitive to context and not everyone’s been around in one industry from this long and actually like to the level that you understand it

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s wonderful even though,this is that part of industry, but there will be similar things happening in others; like the like financial industry to keep the global financial crisis

author: Q
sentence: I mean, we’ve got these moments that are challenged and watershed moments that have changed things

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that you put on there – yes you did but you talked about that so we can move on; do you feel that diversity not really seem to be important? That’s all right

author: Q
sentence: From a regular true perspective, we’ve talked about gender targets, and quotas and we’ve talked about what was the situation five years ago, you’ve told me about that

author: Q
sentence: So, finally, because I’m aware we’ve got - looking ten years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards? And then I’m going to ask why you think it will be good and what do you think needs to happen for that to occur?

author: A
sentence: Look I’d like to see that unit - every board is at least 30%

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if it needs to be 50, but I think -

author: Q
sentence: Of female?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: But it’s also, there’s more diversity than just gender

author: A
sentence: I think racial diversity and cultural diversity is important

author: Q
sentence: So, are you measuring those as well

author: A
sentence: Look essentially, I thought on here I’d have a - I seeif we talk about gender diversity, I go, I’ve never had such a racially or culturally diverse group and I want to just find out which countries are represented

author: A
sentence: I think it’s fascinating

author: A
sentence: And I don’t know whether to measure it as a target, but I think it’s interesting

author: A
sentence: I love what it means

author: A
sentence: I love having conversations with people about how you’d go about doing it in different cultures and so it just brings ideas into it

author: A
sentence: Is there another way of handling it and I think people are not very good at doing that; so, for example, we talk in a big company typically when someone leaves, you might do an exit interview and I said, “Why the hell don’t people do entry interviews?” I’m fascinated

author: A
sentence: You start at a new company and you start

author: A
sentence: They don’t go, “Can we just download everything that you’ve done and understood so we can learn from that?” They don’t

author: A
sentence: And I go, “Why wouldn’t you?” So, I remember I was doing some work with Exxon and we had to do a transfer with Shell, and I said, “Has someone in this business worked in Shell before?” And they go and found this guy and I said, “Hey, come here

author: A
sentence: I need to do this can you tell me what goes on down there, so I know what to?”“Yeah we did,” and he said, “Oh you shouldn’t do that

author: A
sentence: ” And I said, “What do you mean,” you know, got all the information but it just meant I’ve got this resource that you should use

author: A
sentence: And one other example, and actually I was trying to get more diversity at Melbourne University Engineering Faculty

author: A
sentence: And I also was trying to engage students to enjoy the cultural diversity in their teams because they’re always doing teamwork

author: A
sentence: Now typically you think back your hand because if they were from Asia, you couldn’t understand, their English wasn’t very good, and I don’t want to have them in the group

author: A
sentence: And I said to the lecturers, I said to one, “Look you need to design your projects thatencourages diversity in the teams because they can’t get the answers unless they’ve got some from Malaysia

author: A
sentence: Don’t just do it about building the equipment, ask about the labour relations and how we going to source the team of people

author: A
sentence: So, if you’ve got to build a windfarm in Malaysia, and say well how we going to then run your labour rules and stuff and then the guys in the team who are from Australia, are going to want the Malaysian guy in because they can’t answer the question

author: A
sentence: ” And the answer I got from the lecturers, “I can’t do that, because I don’t know the answer

author: A
sentence: And so, I used that for what I did at university sector, I said, “Okay, if you’re at the first phase, there’s no point of me engaging with you with my ideas of someone who’s maybe at the fourth stage, because (one) you lose them; and (two), it’s a bit disrespectful;” because not everyone is informed about a particular topic of someone else

author: A
sentence: So, if I’m talking to a medical guy, he’s not going to talk to me about high order stuff and it’s not that I’m not capable of understanding it’s just I’m not informed

author: A
sentence: So, I think there’s a respect about the diversity agenda

author: A
sentence: So, the first phase they say is about that there isn’t a problem

author: A
sentence: So, some people go, well it’s not a problem

author: A
sentence: Why are we even working through that? So, with that, I would present data and start to show data

author: A
sentence: So, if they’re at that phase then let’s just move them onto the next stage and present the data

author: A
sentence: The next phase is well, oh okay, all right, I believe the data, could you just get some women who act and think like men and just put them in there? And then I tick my boxes and that’s great and then we’ll get that number in

author: A
sentence: So, they go, okay, I have a problem but gee, can I just get some like-minded men that look and aren’t like women and get them and that’s fun

author: Q
sentence: I’m sorry that’s a scream they’re teaching

author: Q
sentence: So, let’s try and what would the analogous situation on a board, does that transfer to a board?

author: A
sentence: I think the analogous thing is if you just had the quota and you’ve put them in there and you don’t, you’re not interested in that perspective that they bring, you’re wasting your time

author: A
sentence: It is disrespectful

author: A
sentence: Like I had a meeting, I was here, and I was the only woman in there and they started talking about how to get more women in? And they all talked; not one of them paused to say, “[Participant] what’s your view?”

author: Q
sentence: And here you are

author: A
sentence: And after a while I’d like to say something, I go, they all had a view, “Why would you have a view before you’ve asked me,” like really,I was fascinated

author: A
sentence: And then one of them, the other one said, “Oh I had two who are pregnant and I couldn’t keep them because they haven’tgot car parks at work and so they couldn’t, you know, if they wanted to leave quickly and it was too hard to get to work

author: A
sentence: ”I said, “Bloody get a car par

author: A
sentence: Why can’t you provide those services? If I had someone who was pregnant here, we’ve got three parks, can’t we just release a car park for her so that whilst she’s coming in here, she’s or when she comes back?” Because they don’t, they won’t differentiate because then it’s not fair anyway

author: Q
sentence: Oh yeah, I’ve had that thinking

author: A
sentence: Sorry, so coming back to boards, I think it comes back to leadership and it’s just different ways of thinking, isn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, can I justask you something; I haven’t thought it through, it’s not coming from the literature, but it’s coming from bits and pieces that I’ve picked up from people

author: Q
sentence: The pipeline implies a mechanical line

author: Q
sentence: Now what if, getting onto boards is not so hierarchical in ten years’ time; what if its more organic? Is it possible; is that something advantageous? Potentially, can you get there?

author: A
sentence: Look when I did the AICD course I thought, why does the course not then put you as a ghost person on every board? To me it seemed obvious

author: A
sentence: So, you need experience

author: A
sentence: Why don’t all the big boards have two people, you don’t get paid, you sit there

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you’re observers, and you learn, and you can ask questions

author: A
sentence: Yeah and maybe later on they can source that person and they’re a while so, how many positions would that be? So, I don’t know why they just don’t; those positions aren’t available, and it should be part of doing the AICD course; it should be to get people then have you shadow a board for six months or something

author: A
sentence: So, you start to get more women I suppose at that point and then as the next group, they go okay, and then the women start getting together and they’re going, yeah, but you’re not actually supporting us

author: A
sentence: Then they might go to their CEO and say, “Well that’s fine but we’ve actually other needs

author: A
sentence: ” And they go, okay, I acknowledge that

author: A
sentence: Can you goform a woman’s group over there and can you go and just decide what you want, and we’ll give you some money and just do whatever makes you happy there

author: A
sentence: So, (one) we now know it’s there, we know women need a bit extra but please don’t bother me with it, just sort it out amongst yourselves

author: A
sentence: And then the fourth maybe, hopefully it’s more, is the culture is such that women just want to be in there

author: A
sentence: You don’t actually have to have scholarships to get them in there; you don’t have to have a diversity agenda to get them in there, it just happens

author: A
sentence: It’s just natural

author: A
sentence: It just feels like they’re naturally meant to be there and that’s obviously where you want to get to

author: A
sentence: I guess in my study and thinking about it, I go, it just doesn’t happen by itself

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that is really good and manage conflict of interest

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the legality or whatever the job

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly and if you’re on a board that’s a competitor with you, obviously just don’t shadow on their board

author: A
sentence: That’s right exactly or greater, you know, they have, what do they call alter directors and have all these rules and stuff and just call it a substitute director; or you could have a role for six months or something because you’re meant to audit the board every so often and all these things; they can get you to do a project or something

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and it will be useful

author: Q
sentence: So, I guess, because if the pipeline is so much part of your thinking, the way you frame it, is it necessary for people to have all this experience before they go; is it just because of the tall poppy syndrome; or do you think it’s something deeper, it is really necessary that people have quite a lot more experience to be on a board?

author: A
sentence: Look, I think experience, but I could be, because I’ve now got experienceand I just know that I can see issues quite differently

author: A
sentence: Maybe when you’re younger and got less experience, you see issues differently again, which is still valid

author: A
sentence: And I think it’sagain about leadership and saying, “I want to have young and more experienced

author: A
sentence: ” Because young people aren’t hampered by things they’ve tried before, and it didn’t work

author: A
sentence: And so that is a valid way of energizing groups

author: A
sentence: And so, I think it’s about again, good leadership to explain the benefits and all of those things

author: A
sentence: So, I think that is the combination of it

author: A
sentence: But it’s again, what is the role of the board?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, well that’s it, that sort of comes back then and it’s functioning, how much mentoring can go on; how much support? Like you’re legally liable for, responsible for things that you’re accountable

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I mean, if you have to be responsible or signing off on all the balance sheets and things, well it’s not very respectful to give it to someone who’s not seen that; but they can’t, they haven’t seen lots of numbers through, they haven’t seen the meaning of numbers so it’s hard

author: A
sentence: I think, its interesting when I the AICD course, there was a lot of, there’s a bias towards accountants and lawyersand so that’s fine

author: A
sentence: I think therefore a lot of women who get into boards who’ve got those two qualifications

author: A
sentence: I’ve got strategy and stuff, but we’ve sat in, we had to do this role play and there was an accountant there and lawyer and we had to say what were the first three issues that were important, or this particular one had a safety issue which I’m across

author: A
sentence: And so, I said, “Look I think weshould look at safety issues

author: A
sentence: ” They said, “Oh no, but we’re insolvent and the accountants can only think this

author: A
sentence: ” And I said, “Okay, but you need to include that in there

author: A
sentence: ” And we had to nominate someone who would be the fill-in chair and someone or someone else

author: A
sentence: Anyway, this woman they nominated, I don’t know her from Adam anyway, “The law taught in it that it’s all about your fiduciary duty and the fact that you’re meant to include everyone’s ideas

author: A
sentence: ” So, I’m trying to say a couple of things, but anyway this woman spoke 00:57:55 but anyway and everyone deferred

author: A
sentence: And I said, “Here we are, we’ve just done four weekdays training and we’re sitting in here and you’re not listening to everyone

author: A
sentence: ” I thought it was interesting but anyway I came back and was talking to a girlfriend, and I said, “It’s fascinating, just in the course, trying to give a view in, they defer it to us; you know it’s almost as if she was famous

author: A
sentence: Okay, maybe she is

author: A
sentence: ” I look her up and she’s a sport star on TV

author: A
sentence: And I go, isn’t that funny

author: A
sentence: Oh my God, this human nature, we’re just at the training, so anyway

author: Q
sentence: That’s funny

author: Q
sentence: I mean it could be a famous footballer and I wouldn't recognise

author: A
sentence: People might argue about, oh that’s unnatural forcing numbers

author: A
sentence: Yeah, okay, but you never going to – I don’t believe you get to that final stage unless you make those things happen

author: A
sentence: So, I guess your question was, how have I informed that in some other places and in the university thing I informed that

author: A
sentence: I said I’m going to get three people in if I’m going to do a scholarship

author: A
sentence: I want to give them the strength in numbers

author: A
sentence: Where I worked typically, there have been very few men and I haven’t actually been bothered by that, I enjoy -

author: A
sentence: No, well I didn’t know anyway, I didn’t know so she’s some, on TV and stuff like I didn’t recognise her

author: A
sentence: But I just go, it’s just that people behave like all the guys are like this you know, and I go, really, so anyway, there you go

author: A
sentence: But I think we can do a lot more about getting people on boards just to shadow them around and give people confidence and others; and it should be so hard but there’s so many different types of boards

author: A
sentence: The other thing I’ve seen for women is the way you get onto boards is you dovolunteer fornot-for-profit or something; and I go, “Then none of my skills are there though; All my skills are in the paid job

author: A
sentence: ” I don’t know about marketing and all that sort of thing so why would I want to do that? And I am annoyed at that, and I’m going, “Guys don’t have to do that path, why do I have to go for a not-for-profit when not with other skills, all my skills are there

author: Q
sentence: So, your skills are, but I thought you said strategy but only with industry

author: A
sentence: Yeah, okay just strategy in that or strategy anyway

author: A
sentence: But most of them when they’re looking for that, they’re looking for people for fundraising in not-for-profit, they just need to bring money in

author: A
sentence: I mean, that’s what they want to bring in money and look I don’t mind doing that, but I’m actually much better in my experience

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and in a field

author: A
sentence: In a paid board yes

author: A
sentence: But they just want their guiding women that how you get in, they don’t guide men that way, but anyway

author: Q
sentence: How do they guide men?

author: A
sentence: Well you just go through mates and just get onto a board; it’s through the network

author: Q
sentence: And there’s not enough women in these boards

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: When you look at it, it really doesn’t matter I suppose, it’s just a different pathway

author: Q
sentence: Oh it does matter, because there’s someone like you with - what I really like because I thought this young women really articulated it so beautifully, she wants to be fulfilled and she wants to do, it has to work for her as well

author: Q
sentence: And I thought, she’s right and basically, you’re sort of, you want experience -

author: Q
sentence: Very few men?

author: A
sentence: Yeah and I’m glad we’ve had this conversation because I just started this job six months ago and okay, I thought I’ll give myself a year and then I’m going to start looking for board positions again when I feel I’ve got this one in control again

author: A
sentence: Oh, few women, sorry

author: A
sentence: No, very sorry, thank you

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s all right

author: A
sentence: Well I think it’s a fabulous career to start with, but equally, having a diverse workforce, especially in gender, to say it’s essential, a better dimension and just a nicer place to work; it works better

author: A
sentence: And a lot of women can do it

author: A
sentence: It gives people a permission to be themselves a lot more

author: A
sentence: I think when they see there’s different types of people

author: A
sentence: A lot of guys have a lot of characteristics that they could exhibit if they knew others were understanding of it

author: A
sentence: So, I think once you get more women sometimes, they go, oh, yeah, well I can act like that too or argue or have different views

author: A
sentence: And so, I think it’s very healthy around here

author: A
sentence: So, very few women and so I’m used to working with men, I can’t see the difference; because I’m looking out to the world and no one looks that different to me, it’s only if I was sitting in their shoes, so that’s fine

author: A
sentence: It was only when I was working at Sugar later on, there was bit of a more marketing and the more women there

author: A
sentence: Sometimes a group of us will go out for dinner and I’ll have so much fun and I go, oh my goodness, there’s another conversation that I was never having when I was just with guys

author: A
sentence: And not that I didn’t enjoy that conversation, but there’s another one to be had

author: A
sentence: And that’s really good too

author: A
sentence: So, I think sometimes you just don’t realise and you go, oh, I can talk about different things and I can see the world a bit differently; and I can see some subtleties that I can’t have if I don’t have that conversation as well

author: A
sentence: So, I think part of women supporting other women is then to understand a bit about themselves and how they relate to the workplace, I think is important

author: Q
sentence: Oh, it’s so interesting so the bounded experience can mean you’re blind until you -

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah

author: A
sentence: You think I got through and what’s the issue but there was no problem

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, or you just not aware as you said

author: Q
sentence: You happen to be in an industry that’s mainly men and so that part of you that wasn’t been exercised, you just weren’t aware of until you worked somewhere else

author: Q
sentence: So, the men then, would be equally unaware, it’s not malicious or intended

author: Q
sentence: It’s just as it is, so it’s that institutionalisation of this, it’s entrenched

author: Q
sentence: So, if I understand these shifts, so you’ve got like the band-aid support for that and then it’s like a cultural transformation that’s the final one

author: Q
sentence: But there’s mutual awareness and respect, engagement with different points of view; so that’s sort of your -

author: A
sentence: Yeah it is, and it takes a very experienced leader to pull out those different thoughts

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and possibly a trajectory of change

author: Q
sentence: So, now we’re going to focus on boards, but this is to understand

author: Q
sentence: You’ve explained how you see diversity in the different stages so that underpins, which is really great

author: Q
sentence: So, your role, what you do here in your job now, and when you were talking in that book, when you were being recorded in that book or whether you wrote a chapter or whatever, how are you trying to influence, apart from the university sector, now back in industry, how were you trying to influence or how do you try and influence women here so as they in the organisation?

author: A
sentence: Look it’s always probably been about being the role model, so, to be much more comfortable in being a woman

author: A
sentence: Because I understood that I would subjugate really your femininity when you’re younger, and not that there was a problem with it, but I just felt that’s what you did

author: A
sentence: And I’m appointed because I’m the best at the job, not because I’m a female; and we all had that rhetoric

author: A
sentence: And it only changed one time when it was sort of a social gathering and there was a glass ceiling and everything and I remember this guy, he comes in and he’s a marking person and we’re talking about this and he goes, “[Participant], I am so pissed

author: A
sentence: ” And I go, “What are you on about?” He said, “Marketing is about apoint differentiation

author: A
sentence: You spend millions of dollars to get a quantitative differentiation and you have it and you’re not capitalising on it

author: A
sentence: You, how lucky are you because there’s so few women just,” I go, well of course

author: A
sentence: It’s about changing that lens going, people spend millions to be differentiated

author: A
sentence: Here you are trying not to be

author: A
sentence: It’s the most stupid thing I’ve ever heard

author: A
sentence: And so, it’s about sort of celebrating it I suppose and thinking how lucky I am

author: A
sentence: And so, I think it’s that sort of lens

author: A
sentence: So, then to create it in a culture around you, that is more lively and fun to be in because women will always vote with their feet typically, quicker than guys

author: A
sentence: So, whenever you’re in a workforce, it’s always the women who are leaving more often because if they’re not happy, there’s personal circumstances, there might be two workers, and they go, I don’t have to put up with this

author: A
sentence: And they will leave

author: A
sentence: And they’re also much more sensitive to poor leadership, I think

author: A
sentence: A lot of colleagues of mine doing brilliant in a company, change of boss and are very sensitive to poor leadership

author: A
sentence: They do not, won’t accept being treated badly and they’ll leave

author: A
sentence: So, what is my mantra? It’s about I guess being authentic yourself and then giving permission for others to be like that

author: A
sentence: But I probably do; I focus particularly on women or men; I try to treat them all the same I guess, in a sense that I think guys could perform better by being a bit more authentic and open and try to get information from them

author: A
sentence: I think I’m sort of quite good at letting everyone have a voice and so, therefore I find my victims come, so I usually have a good source of information

author: A
sentence: So, if I have good information, I can make good decisions and I’ve got to have a group of how many who trust me enough to let me know what’s going on

author: A
sentence: So, now, I’ve mentored women in mining and others; I talk to them about more issues and just about finance issues and then try to ask other questions about how they’re going to do with the families and kids and part-time work and all these things

author: A
sentence: So, I’m very happy to have conversations with them, more than just their work situation too

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Have any of these women that you’ve mentored, have they positions on boards at the moment?

author: Q
sentence: So, good problem-solving skills then too

author: A
sentence: Look, you come and go, you don’t know what happens

author: A
sentence: But there’s a lady I was mentoring and she’s now GM in mining or EMG

author: A
sentence: There’s another girl we catch up with and she’s on a board, I think

author: A
sentence: So, different people are at different times, yeah

author: A
sentence: Look and I thinkI’m still not clear about the pathway and the right time that someone should get on a board

author: A
sentence: So, times when I’ve been not working, I’ve looked, oh maybe it’s a good time to get on a board but I think that timing is quite difficult to know when it is

author: A
sentence: Because sometimes when you’re full on, it’s like a 12-hour day job, it’s very hard to know when you can get enough time to work on a board so I’m still struggling with those sorts of issues

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Well I just interviewed a 28 year old girl who’s on a board and she said that her proprietary step was to be an advisor in an advisory capacity to a board and not-for-profit and her employer, like her manager, she had to negotiate a conflict of resources, time and whatever

author: Q
sentence: Although the meetings were held before work, they could go a bit late and all that sort of stuff

author: Q
sentence: So, that was a problem for her

author: Q
sentence: So, I hear what you’re saying

author: Q
sentence: Do you think women or a particular demographic, younger people, women, any of these demographics, different industries, do you think it’s harder in terms of this perceived conflict between commitment and resources? If you go and work on a board, attend six meetings a year or eight meetings a year, and that might be seen as in conflict with your work commitment?

author: A
sentence: Look it could be

author: A
sentence: I mean, I think good employers now should support that because I think at the end of the day, the more connected you are in with the new business and the networks and more externally I think you add more value

author: A
sentence: I think some people have - some CEOs and GMs might have their mind made up in that space and you probably can’t change it

author: A
sentence: I think some younger ones who are a bit more forward-thinking, fit, encourage that

author: A
sentence: I know a CEO and he wanted me on the boards, but his next CEO level just had that view that he couldn’t be whereas he would have supported me because he felt it was the right thing to do

author: A
sentence: So, I think it depends on different people at the end of the day, than just principles

author: A
sentence: And I had another CEO work for mining and he always made sure in any contracts he wrote for people, that they were never excluded from working on a board because he felt - and he was specifically trying to support women in that way and said that they should try and get on boards here

author: A
sentence: He’s very good

author: Q
sentence: And he was on boards?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, he’s a CEO of a company

author: Q
sentence: And so, did he mentor people onto boards?

author: A
sentence: Yes, a lot

author: A
sentence: He’s brought his company secretary; he’s brought a woman on there

author: A
sentence: No, he’s been very influential and proactively getting people, which is great

author: Q
sentence: So, that was through writing contracts

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, he made sure on the contracts that they weren’t ever prescriptive, that they couldn’t – so make sure that you have the groundwork

author: A
sentence: So, makes me that whenever I sign the contract for a job, I look at it and make sure that it is open; and I’ll always have a conversation with them saying,“Look I am looking at boards and how is that thought through? And I think if someone said no, I would be maybe inclined not to take a job

author: Q
sentence: Why, what does that say to you?

author: A
sentence: A whole lot of things

author: A
sentence: It’s just, I think good decision-making needs lots of different ways to look at a problem but also, having good empathy helps you come to better decisions

author: A
sentence: And often that empathy is limited to your experience

author: A
sentence: So, if you have more people with lots more experience, you naturally create to that group empathy and it’s much greater

author: A
sentence: Well it says to me that they’re just not very visionary really

author: A
sentence: And where I’m in my career, I’m looking at that service not supporting where I want to go

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so it’s a good test

author: Q
sentence: What about someone who’s young, what do you think about them being on boards?And you know, their contracts and whether we can apply the same kind of organisational procedures to someone at the lower levels of management, you know, entry level to your speaking about senior levels and executive

author: A
sentence: Yeah, look I think it’s all possible

author: A
sentence: I think what might stop you is having a boss who’d be jealous

author: A
sentence: Because at the moment they may perceive that there’s more opportunity for women to get onboards because of this

author: A
sentence: But I want to get on boards and I’m not getting selected and you are; it will be a problem

author: Q
sentence: Oh, so you think this might be a barrier for women

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, younger; if someone’s 28 going, well she was on a board at 28, why do you think - I think it would be - most people who are supportive of othershave often done that themselves, unfortunately, it just comes with nature

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And that’s whether it’s a male, or a female that, will I call it a tall poppy?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: Q
sentence: You haven’t done the work

author: A
sentence: And I think you exactly need more and therefore what are you trying to do here

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but it’s a bit of indignation perhaps, who are you; who do you think you are?

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of where that happened well and perhaps not well?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well that’s interesting

author: A
sentence: And this maybe also in the workplace; why you need to inform them but most contracts you do have to inform them; but you could be doing it on your weekends or out of hours

author: A
sentence: But I think the workplace contracts are such that you’re required to inform an employer

author: A
sentence: So, if you didn’t have to inform them, and they’ll see the conflict of interest, but if it didn’t and he independent advice, why would you need to inform them

author: A
sentence: And look maybe you don’t but most people do, I think

author: A
sentence: And often there is, some of them do want to one day have strategies sessions or something like that

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, true, they want to do the course

author: Q
sentence: The board might pay for them to do the course so it’s a really good opportunity

author: A
sentence: The other observation I had is -boards are a very strategic tool for the CEO and the Chair, and they’ve got certain things that they need the board to support

author: A
sentence: And I guess, I spent a bit of time, I wrote a paper on looking at the effectiveness of boards and stuff when I was doing my NBA

author: A
sentence: And I always struggle with the role of the board actually; what are they going to do;what’s their effectiveness? And now if I’m the CEO and I’m a small business, I’d want a board that diversifies some of the skills I need

author: A
sentence: So, I might need someone who’s - maybe I haven’t got enough legal, so I’ll be like a legal advisor and a few things like that

author: A
sentence: So, it’s sort of a way to branch out and extend some of your capability or I might be thinking about mergers and so, who’s connected

author: A
sentence: So, I think there’s a lot of strategic intent behind the type of experience people have more so than just the diversity piece

author: A
sentence: I think that comes first typically people are strategic-driven

author: A
sentence: I think until you get real diversity in the management ranks, the boards are different; it’s just sort of an add-on really

author: A
sentence: It’s sort of like it should reflect what’s in the management really

author: A
sentence: I mean if the management don’t reflect enough women, it’s very hard to get the board there because experience comes from often

author: Q
sentence: Because then there’s a tension between the way the board is strategizing, and they do decisions and the management

author: A
sentence: Yean, I just think it’s very hard

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting because there’s like, I mean the culture, a similar culture between the two seem to be important

author: Q
sentence: But this is really, well I suppose it is culture because you can think of demographic diversity as being the artefacts of your -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, anyway it’s just another thing to think about is sort of I mean, I’m just so surprised there’s so little diversity in the management ranks

author: A
sentence: To me, there appears to be more diversity in the board ranks than I’m seeing in the executive management ranks, but anyway

author: Q
sentence: And why do you think that?

author: A
sentence: So, for example, I had three children [two work] 00:01:45 and when I was at Exxon, I was only the second woman to be in a senior management role, but I was the first one to be married and have kids in that role

author: A
sentence: So, I wasn’t too sure what to do; do I go for part-time work, I’ve never seen anyone else do that and how would they respond to it? And I was very fortunate that I had a boss who, and I was in the US when I had my first child and over there everyone just went back to work after six weeks

author: A
sentence: But I didn’t want to do that so I came back and he said, “Look, how about I find you a job that’s just three days a week, that’s it not mission critical, so if the kids are sick, you could actually come and go

author: A
sentence: ” And I said, “Oh that will be brilliant

author: A
sentence: ” But I couldn’t have thought to ask for that because I just had never seen it happen

author: A
sentence: So, he was very thoughtful and that helped me get my sort of feet back on the floor after that

author: A
sentence: And subsequent to that, every other woman who had a child that came back, and they retained them and stayed and went part-time, for that period; so that was that example

author: A
sentence: I just think this year nowI’ve got less women around me than I did 32 years ago

author: Q
sentence: Are they more senior positions?

author: A
sentence: No, they’ve dropped

author: A
sentence: When I started with Exxon, 50% engineers were recruited that were women, yeah 50% 32 years ago

author: A
sentence: And everyone’s talking about the pipeline, so they were doing that years ago

author: A
sentence: And then they sort of go off to other jobs, they haven’t stayed the distance and I probably stuck it longer than most

author: A
sentence: And look this is a services industry and when I had children, I had a secretary and now you don’t

author: A
sentence: And I could not do my job now with three young children

author: A
sentence: So, I could back then at the workplace

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: They supported you, of course

author: A
sentence: It’s changed underneath me

author: A
sentence: I just am so busy that I couldn’t have done, I couldn’t have had three kids

author: A
sentence: I couldn’t do my job now

author: A
sentence: It’s getting less to me, friendly, yes you can do - people work from home more often but it’s not the job

author: Q
sentence: You keep your mobile with you all the time

author: A
sentence: And the whole thing of work, is you’re engaging with people and you actually face-to-face

author: A
sentence: You can talk about flexibility but it’s not, you’re not very good when you’re not at work

author: A
sentence: You’re okay, you can do it occasionally, but you’re not going to change the world doing that

author: Q
sentence: No, it’s not the people stuff

author: Q
sentence: Oh, very interesting

author: Q
sentence: Because I was going to say, this only came out on Wednesday, did you see the Australian Institute of Company Directors Report on broad gender diversity and they were expecting it to reach the 30% target and it hasn’t

author: Q
sentence: And so, it’s been a surprise, a bit of a shock and I was wondering why? Because these targets have been around for a long time and these boards don’t even have anyone on them

author: Q
