sentence: Now, if your observation that the number of women have declined, that’s the pipeline, has declined, then is this - I’m going to interview them and see if they -

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think that’s partly

author: A
sentence: So, I was made redundant about a year ago before I started this job

author: A
sentence: And I thought okay, engineer, lots of skills, done everything

author: A
sentence: The recruiters were excruciatingly brutal and just – every time I left, they interviewed me as if they just want you to be like a man

author: A
sentence: And they are the ones that select you, get you infront of the companies

author: A
sentence: And I thought, okay, I’m redundant now but I’m glad I’m a woman, because they need lots

author: A
sentence: But no one was asking

author: A
sentence: I’m so surprised there was so little interest

author: A
sentence: If people are really out there trying to do it, they - and I went to a few companies directly, and they just, I don’t know, they just not interested or not taking the time to think it through

author: A
sentence: So, I think people are just paying lipservice they’re not seriously seeking people

author: A
sentence: Because I’m just thinking if you’ve go on to LinkedIn and say right, I want a senior engineer, we need to get more women, why wouldn't you just get contacted all the time

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly with your experience

author: Q
sentence: It’s not like you were an entry level

author: A
sentence: But then fast forward, five or so years, I’ve got one of the guys that work for me and he was trying to start up another sort of side business and I said, “Oh so do you want to work part-time for a while?You know, you’ve got other interests, just some people do it for kids

author: A
sentence: ”And he goes, “Gee, that would be awesome

author: A
sentence: ” I said, “Well I don’t want to lose you and we can work that through, so just work part-time, I’m okay with that

author: A
sentence: ” So, there’s a whole lot of things that you’re just accommodating for

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and look maybe I’m not the right mould, but look I think extensively I tick most boxes

author: A
sentence: So why is that, I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, the recruitment agency might have a -

author: A
sentence: Filter out

author: A
sentence: They filter that

author: A
sentence: It’s a brutal experience

author: A
sentence: I guess their reputation is on the line and would they be prepared to take the risk

author: Q
sentence: So, you think they think there is a risk in that a female eventually versus a male

author: A
sentence: Yeah, because if you’re given a brief, you’re only going to give a brief for someone you’ve had before

author: A
sentence: You see you can’t brief for a skillset that you have never used in your business

author: A
sentence: So, the brief is I want someone who I’ve seen before which is a man

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it’s because there’s not enough of you

author: Q
sentence: So, now you’re a rarity and therefore you’re a risk, an uncertainty, to the agency not to the industry

author: A
sentence: Yeah that’s right

author: A
sentence: Well, because they say I want someone who’s had all this experience in the same industry and a lot of women will have a much more tessellated career, so it doesn’t, it’s just not easy to slot into that same pro forma

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, I should try and get a copy of a pro forma that they might use or where we can refer to it

author: A
sentence: So, I’m jumping around

author: Q
sentence: No that’s good

author: Q
sentence: What I’ll do is I’ll tie you down, I’ll say, how important do you think it is to have a diverse board, if you were given a scale of ten to one; ten’s extremely important, one, not at all, what would you say?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Now how does this - because we’re looking at broad diversity

author: Q
sentence: So, the person who suggested I speak to you, she raised it

author: Q
sentence: She’s a director of a number of boards and chair of some and she mentioned you in the context of management is a barrier to diversity, or let’s say a strong determinant of the diversity onboards

author: Q
sentence: So, if women don’t have the kind of management experience that is required for boards, chief executive experience or chief finance officer or something like that, then they can find it very difficult

author: Q
sentence: So, she mentioned you because she said - I think I couldn’t find that there’s a book you’ve written is that right? No, anyway she mentioned -

author: A
sentence: Well I’ll say ten with the qualification

author: A
sentence: It depends what’s the board’s doing

author: A
sentence: If it’s an area that’s more male focused, it’s that the knowledge and the skills that our board bring is more beneficial, then I think there could be reason to be one way or the other, an allmen’sclub for example and why we’re giving women on the board and if you want to have an all men’s club, then go for it but I’d say ten

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And because we’re not speaking just about gender diversity either

author: A
sentence: No, true

author: Q
sentence: So, do you feel this will always be important, a diversity board, has it always been important? And what do you feel has led to the change if you think, oh no, it’s become more important?

author: A
sentence: Look I think diversity only works effectively if you have really good leaders and a poor leader can’t manage diversity

author: A
sentence: So, if you haven’t got a good leader, I’ll say, you don’t want a diversity because they can’t manage it

author: Q
sentence: Nice, okay

author: Q
sentence: So, leadership is the key and leadership is not the Chair

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Well I think it’s partly the Chair, CEOs, but it needs to be; you’ve got to have a good leader who can utilise the diversity

author: A
sentence: But if you don’t, if you really looking for group thing, well don’t have a diverse board

author: A
sentence: I mean, if that leader can’t lead, accept it then you might as well notbecause they’ll be more effective and they go, I want this; we’ll all say yes and then go on

author: A
sentence: Or else you have a disaffected board group and that’s not very helpful either

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: There’s a question made about conflict

author: Q
sentence: So, your reason for thinking diversity is important, you termed it in terms of decision-making; is there anything else?

author: A
sentence: I think role model reflects people who visually can look at it

author: A
sentence: So, people have said to me, it’s nice to see a woman in charge because they haven’t ever had that before

author: A
sentence: So, there’s a visuality of it

author: A
sentence: Decision-making, experiences, empathy, I think it just brings other views on it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, more to the tables

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there is some situations where diversity might be less important; perhaps situations of higher uncertainty and risk; and can you help me to understand why you might change that priority from a ten say to a -

author: A
sentence: Look I think I might have been showcasing a book, talking about different [leads inaudible] 00:04:20 something like that -

author: A
sentence: Well it just depends

author: A
sentence: So, you might have a medical board; so, they make decisions on - so you could have gender and racial diversity, but you want more to be doctors

author: A
sentence: So, you’re already - what does diversity mean; is it by profession? So, I think it’s still filtering, and you say, and they need to have this base layer of knowledge

author: A
sentence: So, look I think, there’s so many women are as good at making hard-arse decisions as others and some guys fall over

author: A
sentence: So, I think you can’t tighten them much

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly so, it would be

author: Q
sentence: So, because of your broader understanding of diversity, the way you understand diversity, which by the way is consistent with almost everyone I’ve interviewed, which is nice, then it’s not an issue

author: Q
sentence: Could you explain to me how you seek to influence the priority that Australian boards give to diversity and the capacity of boards to build diversity?

author: A
sentence: It only would be more at a personal level that if I know someone like I know this guy who’s on a mining board and I said, “Look if I come across people, some women who I think are really good,” and said, “If you ever need to get some women on the boards, I know who I would recommend

author: A
sentence: ” So, I think it’s about saying to people and giving ideas to people who can move around and offer that role

author: A
sentence: But also done – I think it’s supporting leaders I supposeor look I haven’t done a lot specifically in that space

author: Q
sentence: Were the women in the workforce that you’ve been working with

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and look I’ve got friends who are on boards and stuff like that

author: A
sentence: So, you talk about the issues and you support people

author: A
sentence: So, I’ve encouraged a couple of my girlfriends to do the AICD course and I’ve done that, and they’ve enjoyed it

author: A
sentence: So, a girlfriend, [Jo Mercer] 00:35:04 and she should get onto boards, so we’ll get her onto boards at some point, but she needs the AICD course I think before then

author: A
sentence: So, I guess what I’m trying to do is make sure they’ve got those qualifications so probably half a dozen I’ve encouraged to do that course

author: A
sentence: Because I think it’s saying that you’ve got the qualifications, don’t let that discount you and then think about the network from there

author: Q
sentence: So, gender diversity has been [Participant]ated for a while, how do you feel about the recent inclusion of ethnicities, sexual orientation, things like that?

author: A
sentence: I have no problems with ethnicity and gender, I’m struggling on the sexual orientation because some people don’t even know

author: A
sentence: My sister was, so she’s at the university, she’s a PHD and she’s applying for a job and they said, “Are you gay?” And she goes,“No

author: A
sentence: ”“Oh it would be easier if you are

author: A
sentence: ” And she’s going, “But I’m not

author: A
sentence: ”“No, because we need that in our, or it would be better

author: A
sentence: ” So, I’m going, “Really

author: Q
sentence: That was for a position

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting

author: A
sentence: Yeah, Head of school

author: A
sentence: So, really,it’s just – so, yes, I mean, people like the diversity but really

author: Q
sentence: It’s just creating a box and now we’re talking about, they wanted to tick a box, so your view then about targets

author: Q
sentence: I’ve just turned my recorder on so, yeah, we’re on

author: Q
sentence: Thanks so much for this interview

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: It was around our capital management policies and around the way in which we return capital to shareholders

author: A
sentence: There was one board member who felt quite strongly around the fact that we should do a special dividend which required us to take on debt to be able to make that and most of the board I think naturally were pretty averse to taking on debt to pay money to shareholders

author: A
sentence: But he, through his understanding of financial markets, genuine understanding of the financial strength of our business, managed to convince everyone that that was the right course of action and so that’s what the board took

author: A
sentence: It’s just never struck as being relevant and I don’t even know if it’s legal for us to ask people, “Before you join you have to tell us your religion

author: A
sentence: ” That feels a bit weird

author: A
sentence: Why does it even bother you? Why would it matter? It’s very difficult to actually try and change something if you don’t measure it

author: A
sentence: Margo, I’m going to have to go

author: A
sentence: I apologise

author: A
sentence: There’s someone here who needs this room

author: Q
sentence: I can see

author: Q
sentence: I have spent your [Participant]e

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: That was really, really helpful

author: Q
sentence: I wish I could shake your hand

author: A
sentence: Have a great day

author: Q
sentence: Same to you

author: Q
sentence: Bye, [Participant]

author: A
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: In hindsight, was that a good decision?

author: A
sentence: In hindsight, I don’t think it had the impact that he expected

author: A
sentence: It wasn’t a bad decision per se but I don’t think it had the impact that he was hoping for in the share price

author: Q
sentence: The diversity of the board really allowed the board to manage risk in another way I guess, a way that it wouldn’t have done if he wasn’t on the board

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: I get that

author: Q
sentence: How does your organisation, this is the Male Champions of Change, how does that seek to influence Australian boards? I’ve got this download from the web

author: A
sentence: Male Champions of Change isn’t predominantly focused on boards

author: A
sentence: Male Champions of Change is focused on roles within the business so operating leadership roles, representation of women in the workforce, the roles that they play, gender pay equity, et cetera

author: A
sentence: Therefore, it’s an organisation of CEOs, not of directors

author: A
sentence: Through that however, what it is seeking to do is to have men who are in leadership positions so male CEOs take accountability for gender equity in their organisation

author: A
sentence: I think it’s almost impossible to do that in sort of down without thinking about how does that impact upwards as well

author: A
sentence: I think it’d be hard to be a Male Champion of Change and be on say, 100% male board and not be staring into the fact that what you’re trying to live down here is not reflected up here

author: Q
sentence: This has come up in other interviews

author: Q
sentence: The cultural connection between the board and the organisation the board serves, it needs to be congruent

author: Q
sentence: It just came up

author: Q
sentence: That’s how they described it and I wonder, is this necessary?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, yes

author: A
sentence: Because I think the days that an organisation is a walled entity are over

author: A
sentence: As a CEO you can’t say one thing internally and act one way and then in a different context act in a way that’s inconsistent because that’s just seen as inauthentic

author: A
sentence: You can’t for example, say one thing to team members and then have a marketing message to customers that is different than that

author: A
sentence: My team are all active on social media

author: A
sentence: They comment on what happens at work so it’s a very porous – the concept of a company is now an organisation with very porous edges and the same happens for the board

author: A
sentence: If the board is seen to be living by a different set of standards, a different operating cadence, to different values than the organisation then the organisation sees that

author: A
sentence: Now it doesn’t see it – it can depend how prominent the chair and the directors choose to be in the business but for example, in our business if our board was all male, with the effort and the accountability that we hold managers to, to getting gender diversity into their teams, they would just look at it and say, “Why me? Why are you telling me to do that when that’s not what happens at the top of the organisation?” You can no longer live sort of in parallel universes or dual existence

author: A
sentence: There has to be a lot of congruence between those different ways

author: A
sentence: No problem, my pleasure

author: Q
sentence: Something is just coming to me about, as a CEO let’s say there was incongruence, how would you manage that? You’re the link between the two

author: A
sentence: I had a chat to one of our directors about the language that they used because it was out of sync with the language we use at AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY

author: A
sentence: He’s older

author: A
sentence: He’s from a different generation and I think his thinking was very good and very high quality but the examples that he used, some of the words that he used to me were frankly, just no longer what you would call contemporary or acceptable in some cases

author: A
sentence: I just had to sit down and let him know that A, that wasn’t what he could do with AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY but B, I don’t think he should have done it anywhere and I liked this person

author: A
sentence: I considered him a friend and so I sort of thought of myself as really doing him a favour

author: A
sentence: He said, “It’s funny I was wondering if that sort of persona was wearing a bit thin now and it’s been on my mind a bit” et cetera and I said, “Stop wondering

author: Q
sentence: It is

author: A
sentence: I think as a CEO, you have to have the courage to do that because that’s obviously a risky situation because the board employs you

author: A
sentence: My view in general is you can have any conversation with anyone

author: A
sentence: You just have to think carefully about what the best way to have that conversation is and you have to accept that some messages are very difficult to receive and therefore might not be well received

author: A
sentence: But I think in the long run you can’t allow things that you think are wrong, harmful for the business, undermining the other work that’s been done to continue

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: That’s really helpful because that was an un-fleshed out area that just arisen

author: Q
sentence: That was the other point, pipeline

author: Q
sentence: What you described, Male Champions of Change are focused on the management level so under the CEO and up to the CEO

author: Q
sentence: I’ve had some interviews

author: Q
sentence: In some interviews it’s come that the pipeline is the problem so women and people from other diverse backgrounds are not getting on boards because they’re not enabled in the pipeline

author: Q
sentence: They’re not getting the management experience that’s necessary or perceived to be necessary for a board position

author: Q
sentence: What do you think about that?

author: A
sentence: I think that’s true and I think that exists across lots of roles and so then it really just comes down to acknowledging that and owning the problem, because the easiest thing to do is to acknowledge it and say, “And therefore it’s too hard,” right?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: But that doesn’t solve anything

author: A
sentence: So that’s the big thing as a Male Champion of Change

author: A
sentence: I think I always would have been someone who people would have said, created environments where both men and women can succeed

author: A
sentence: I think that people would have said and in fact, all about data says that AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY was a place where people believe, embrace diversity that had a strong sense of belonging for both men and women, people of different religions, different races

author: A
sentence: We’ve always been I think an environment that allows people to succeed being who they are rather than having to become an [IBMer] 00:14:16 to succeed

author: A
sentence: We’ve always had that perspective

author: A
sentence: But the difference with the Male Champion of Change is you actually have to own the outcomes

author: A
sentence: You can’t just say, “I’ve got lots of examples of where women have succeeded in my organisation and therefore, I’ve proven women can succeed in my organisation and surely that’s what my job is, to make sure it’s an environment where both men and women can succeed

author: A
sentence: ” Male champions pushes a step past that and says, “Actually that’s not enough

author: A
sentence: What you’ve got to do is actually get to the point where there is gender equity

author: Q
sentence: [Participant], you’re comfortable with the research

author: Q
sentence: I got your form

author: Q
sentence: You understand I’m taping it

author: Q
sentence: We do transcripts

author: Q
sentence: We de-identify

author: Q
sentence: We’re looking at diversity of boards in the broad sense, not just gender

author: Q
sentence: I see that you’re a member of the Male Champions of Change so I thought I’d focus on how you influence boards, how you seek to influence boards but also your board experience would be great as well if you use both those backgrounds

author: A
sentence: The pipeline for us, the most challenging one is in computer science graduates

author: A
sentence: Software programming is a very, very male-dominated field

author: A
sentence: About 17% of computer science graduates in Australia are women and that’s a quarter of our workforce and they’re the highest-paying jobs

author: A
sentence: If you can’t get 50/50 in that you’re not going to get gender pay equity across our business

author: A
sentence: It just won’t happen and you’re starting with an 83/17 input

author: A
sentence: Then of course women who start tend to find that the environment often isn’t an environment they really want to stick in

author: A
sentence: That they’re in a team of eight people, they’re the only woman

author: A
sentence: They spend years being the only woman and so they end up changing careers

author: A
sentence: The 17% gets worse as you get to senior and they’re looking for software engineers with 20 years’ experience to become a senior architect or whatever it might be

author: A
sentence: There is a real pipeline problem

author: A
sentence: But what Male Champions of Change says that’s no excuse

author: A
sentence: That’s just no excuse so you’ve got to think about how do you change the pipeline

author: A
sentence: We’re now getting to the point where we’re getting 40% intake of our software engineers are women

author: A
sentence: Now it’s going to be a long [Participant]e to build the skills to get to the point where we can get that at senior levels in the software engineering team

author: A
sentence: But it’s a bit like the Peter Drucker quote, “The best day to plant a tree was 20 years ago but the second best day is today” because if you don’t start then you won’t have a tree in 20 years’ [Participant]e either

author: Q
sentence: I’m intrigued so 40%

author: Q
sentence: Is this affirmative action? Are you employing women who are less skilled than men in the early stages? How is it then? Was it 17% at the university are graduates are women and then you’re selecting 40% women? Did I get that right?

author: A
sentence: You did

author: A
sentence: No, it’s not

author: A
sentence: All of the women that we bring in have that position through their credentials

author: A
sentence: I think there’s two things

author: A
sentence: One, we’ve proven that we have a genuine commitment to gender equity so although 17% of women we become a very attractive employer, they understand that they’re not going to be the only women who’s starting with us that year et cetera, so it just becomes a natural gravity to where we’re able to draw more of that pool

author: A
sentence: But secondly, we thought more broadly about, how can we bring more women into the software engineering profession? So we run a specific program called Developer where we employ women on an internship

author: A
sentence: It’s about a nine-month program and by the end of that we get their skill capability up to the same as a three-year undergraduate computer science degree holder

author: A
sentence: These are women who have other roles in our business

author: A
sentence: They’re women who maybe have had children and are returning to the workforce and don’t want to go back to their former career or they’re just women who want to a change in career

author: A
sentence: So we made a firm commitment that we will be 50/50 at the graduate level and so if we can’t recruit enough on campus we supplement that with the Developer program to make sure we’re 50/50 at the graduate level

author: A
sentence: Now then as you go more through the organisation, it’s more challenging

author: A
sentence: I won’t say can’t but it’s very difficult to get 50/50 in the senior roles which is why the overall average is down to the 40%

author: Q
sentence: Will these people, the women who do your in-house course will they have equal opportunity to those who have graduated from uni in other organisations? Is it respect –

author: A
sentence: The first cohort that we put into this is now about three years ago and there were three women

author: A
sentence: One didn’t work out and the other two both left the organisation and taken on successful software development roles somewhere else

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: That’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Are you also working with the university sector, perhaps scholarships for women or something like that so that the can get through them?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: We’re really trying to focus on the Developer program and putting our effort there because that is far faster for us to get results

author: Q
sentence: That makes sense

author: Q
sentence: Would other people in the Male Champions of Change be doing similar things to manage the pipeline?

author: Q
sentence: We might as well get right into it

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of talk about board diversity but we’re interested to hear in this research from people who are working in the field on boards or influencing boards

author: Q
sentence: As I said, I’m seeing you as someone who influences boards, as well as, someone who’s on a board so we’ll have both perspectives

author: Q
sentence: Anyway, first how have the composition of boards that you’re familiar with changed over [Participant]e in terms of diversity? Has it increased, decreased, not changed?

author: A
sentence: I think they’re all doing different things and I think it does come down to each organisation

author: A
sentence: I know REA have openly said in public forums, “We saw what AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY was doing

author: A
sentence: We thought it was great and copied it” which is fantastic

author: A
sentence: We tell the story as widely as we can just to try and s[Participant]ulate other people learning from what we do

author: Q
sentence: That’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: I really like that

author: Q
sentence: Thank you, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: Let’s think about why it might be important

author: Q
sentence: How important do you think diverse boards are? Say 10 is extremely important and 1 is not important at all, where would you put it?

author: A
sentence: It’s high

author: A
sentence: It’s probably an 8 or a 9

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that it’s always been this important and if this has always been the case or not always been the case, what do you feel has changed the importance rating that you would give it?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s always been important

author: A
sentence: Perhaps not quite as important as it is now but I think it’s always been important just probably less appreciated

author: A
sentence: Let me say why I think it’s important and then come back to why it’s becoming more important

author: A
sentence: I think there are three things

author: A
sentence: Number one, just from a corporate risk perspective, I think that consumers increasingly care about the business that they engage with and that they increasingly want to see businesses that represent the community that they’re a part of

author: A
sentence: For me just from a, will we be able to get employees in the future, the best employees? Will customers want to engage with AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY? How will our supply chain look at us?

author: A
sentence: I think that if you didn’t have a diverse board that would be one of the signals that people would look at and say, “I really don’t want to go and work there

author: A
sentence: ” I think just from a, setting yourself up for success in the future and I’ll call it corporate risk because I think there’s just a risk that you’ll be left out of opportunities if you don’t do that

author: A
sentence: Number two, I think that diverse teams make better decisions and that gets back to the point that we were talking about 10 or 15 minutes ago in the example that I gave of once you’ve got diversity of viewpoints through diversity of experience you’re more likely to make a well-balanced, well-rounded decision as a team

author: A
sentence: Then number three, for me it just comes back to the individuals

author: A
sentence: If you believe that talent enters the workplace roughly 50/50 distributed across men and women that are entering the workplace and every piece of evidence says if it’s not exactly 50/50, it’s within 49/51 depending on what tests you look at and whatever but you just take it there

author: A
sentence: If you look at a system where today, I think it’s 6% of ASX200 businesses have female CEOs then you’ve got stand back and say, the system is doing something to materially skew the opportunities that happen to those two groups of people who enter with sort of talent distributed evenly across them

author: A
sentence: So for me, I stand back and say, “As a CEO I own that system

author: A
sentence: I have the power

author: A
sentence: I have the authority to change the way things are done

author: A
sentence: So how do I feel about standing in front of a group of graduates who started AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY and simply by, not even looking at them, just by knowing their gender on a list, saying that one has 20 [Participant]es the likelihood of taking my role at some point in the future than another?”

author: A
sentence: I don’t have to have a single conversation

author: A
sentence: I don’t have to look at them

author: A
sentence: I don’t have to have any EQ reading

author: A
sentence: There’s nothing

author: A
sentence: If I know their gender, I can just know that the evidence says that that’s the reality of the system as it’s operated over the last couple of decades for me to get to this position

author: A
sentence: The truth is I feel awful about that

author: A
sentence: That’s a terrible system and to own a system that biases so heavily more one group and against another group isn’t representative of the country that I believed I was born into

author: A
sentence: It isn’t representative of what I believe was a meritocracy

author: A
sentence: I grew up in a middle-income family at a country high school

author: A
sentence: I didn’t have the private school connections or anything else but I believed if I worked hard I could do whatever and I’ve been able to

author: A
sentence: Now it was years and years later, in fact in the last few years that I realised that I’m a white man and actually the system wasn’t ever a meritocracy

author: A
sentence: It may have been a meritocracy amongst white men but there was significant skews and biases all working in my favour compared to say, my sister who left high school with similar talents and capabilities to me

author: A
sentence: For me it comes to those three levels as to why do we need to do this from a corporate risk perspective, from making better decisions and frankly, from just doing what I think is the right thing

author: A
sentence: Again, having been on the AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY board for 12 years, that’s the main reference point that I have, there is no doubt that diversity is a much higher topic I think the in the conversations of all boards

author: A
sentence: If I think about the AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY board, there is no doubt that it had become significantly more diverse over the last decade

author: A
sentence: That diversity has come both through diversity of experience, being the primary one but also from gender and race, if I reflect on it

author: A
sentence: Why has it become more important of recent [Participant]e? To answer your question, I think on the first of those the community expectations have changed and I think 15 years ago people may have been happy to buy products from a company that didn’t represent the community

author: A
sentence: In fact that just wasn’t seen as important

author: A
sentence: I think it’s lifted in the communities’ views and therefore companies need to respond to that

author: A
sentence: On the middle one of making better decisions, I don’t think that that was appreciated and understood as much in the past as it is today

author: A
sentence: Now I will say the importance hasn’t changed there but the understanding of the importance has changed

author: A
sentence: On the third one, again just simply doing the right thing

author: A
sentence: I think that the conversation wasn’t there and so it was just a lens but lots of people who were in positions of authority never looked through

author: A
sentence: I think things like Male Champions of Change, I think that’s the real power that Liz Broderick has had, is to challenge people like me to look through that lens and to then trust that frankly, when we do look through it, we’re likely to see things in a different light because she’s an incredibly persuasive person who never tells you what to do

author: A
sentence: She has a real power of helping you see things for what they are but not blaming and therefore, not making a negative engagement

author: A
sentence: It’s not just her obviously

author: A
sentence: There’s tons of people who have been involved in that shift to help people like me see the reality of the systems that have been built over [Participant]e and that we oversee

author: A
sentence: I’m prattling on so tell me Margo, if you want me to stop

author: A
sentence: What amazes our team and I’ve had these conversations about what it means to be a Male Champion of Change, about six months ago I did town halls in all of our offices talking about sexual harassment and everyday sexism and raising this

author: A
sentence: One of our team members in Brisbane, a woman, told a story to the team there which I then repeated around all the other offices

author: A
sentence: When she worked at the AMP when she was married, just before she left for the wedding, she got called into her manager’s office

author: A
sentence: She went in and she was handed her letter of resignation

author: Q
sentence: When was this?

author: A
sentence: Because married women weren’t allowed to work at AMP

author: A
sentence: She’s still a team member today

author: A
sentence: She’s a great grandmother today but she’s still a team member here

author: A
sentence: She works three days a week and people couldn’t believe that

author: A
sentence: That it was that recent

author: A
sentence: If you think about that system, that wasn’t viewed as being bad

author: A
sentence: That was actually viewed by society as being quite reasonable and probably the right thing to do

author: A
sentence: If you think about the thousands of years that we as a species have that are being baked into these systems and in this case the system of business where in such a recent [Participant]e that was considered normal and good by lots of people, then there’s a lot of change that has happened

author: A
sentence: But you also got to recognise that we didn’t reset

author: A
sentence: What we’ve been doing is morphing and adapting and trying to change from that starting point which is a really dramatic starting point to trying to get the whole way to say, we don’t believe there are gender biases in our system of work anymore

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: So you want to reset? No adapt?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: I can’t reset because I can’t change everyone’s experiences

author: A
sentence: I can’t overnight just say, “That system is done

author: A
sentence: Here’s a new system

author: A
sentence: ” It’s not a computer program where I can say, “The old one is now dead

author: A
sentence: We built a new computer program” because these are people

author: A
sentence: You’re trying to change people and so people turn up to work today expecting that work will be done the way it was done yesterday

author: A
sentence: So to bring people on a journey of change, to bring systems on a journey of change, et cetera, we’re trying to put effort and energy into compressing the [Participant]e as much as possible but when you’re dealing with humans a reset is just impossible

author: Q
sentence: Your employing strategy is supporting people to see themselves differently and see their team differently, your employment strategies here at AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY

author: Q
sentence: That’s potentially quite a quick change in a social organisation, isn’t it?

author: A
sentence: I mean in three years we’ve moved from being a 38% women to 44% women so that’s a material change in three years and our goal is to be greater than 40% men and greater than 40% women in all our communities

author: A
sentence: So hierarchically, vertically, wherever you’re looking to teams, you will find that any team has quite naturally got a good gender balance and it’s not 50/50 because I think by the [Participant]e you’re 50/50 you aren’t prescribing quotas and that gets back to the, are you lowering standards and so on?

author: Q
sentence: Why do you think that’s happened?

author: A
sentence: Some[Participant]es there is just an abundance of talent for whatever reason at one point in [Participant]e from women or men who apply and we’re a commercial entity

author: A
sentence: But I think if you get to at least 40% no one really feels like they’re in the minority

author: A
sentence: People don’t feel like they’re the only one, like they’ve got to constantly represent one viewpoint but I always find that naturally they’re in a team where there’s multiple viewpoints

author: Q
sentence: I was also wondering if you were accommodating – because with students some people don’t identify with either male or female and we tend to divide gender as male or female

author: A
sentence: If you look on our website at our employment page, one of our transgender team members is one of the team members that we highlight on that page

author: Q
sentence: So you accommodate also different identities

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: That’s good, without labelling, great

author: Q
sentence: I wonder if I’ll just ask a couple of questions but I really want to turn it over to you because I love the way you’re talking about the system and I’d like you to talk about how we might – you’ve described the elements of the system like measure elements, norms, understandings, and you’ve described in the org, you’re using AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY as an example of organisations, businesses

author: Q
sentence: You might want to talk a little more about your understanding of the system, how it’s currently, let’s say holding patterns that are not ideal and then what can be done? You’ve given us an example of what you’re doing at AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY but what can be done more broadly here in Australia do you think? Then we’ll use the last to patch up questions that might not be answered

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: I think the first thing to realise is the system inside AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY doesn’t exist in isolation

author: A
sentence: We’re obviously part of a broader community as well

author: A
sentence: One of the things for example we’re trying to do is look at where does talent leave the system and particularly where does it leave the system biased to gender? One of the areas is parental responsibilities

author: A
sentence: We will see that when team members have a family that disproportionately, it is a female team member who takes parental leave as the primary caregiver and then disproportionately therefore, that’s a moment in [Participant]e that can cause people to leave the system

author: A
sentence: So we’ve been very focused on two things

author: A
sentence: One, talking to the men in our organisation about what that actually means, to becoming a father and the support that that means you might need to think about and how we can support you in supporting your family

author: A
sentence: Secondly, through the period that women do choose to take parental leave really keeping connections with them

author: A
sentence: One of the things at the end of that period is that there’s a feeling like, I’m not sure if I still have the skills

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure if I still have the social connections

author: A
sentence: There’s a barrier to overcome, to choosing at that moment to re-enter an organisation

author: A
sentence: Whereas if you’re invited to team events along the way, if you are continuing to keep in touch with what’s happening in the organisation then that feels like a less – that barrier is lower for you to say, “Actually, I’d like to come back

author: A
sentence: Secondly, we’re doing a lot around flexibility

author: A
sentence: I’d like to come back but would it be possible for me to come back three days a week or four days a week? Can I change my hours of work so that I start earlier and leave earlier because my partner can drop the kids at school but I really want to be there to pick them up? How can I increase flexibility? We have a policy that all roles flex and the manager has to say why it’s not possible to do a job through a requested flexibility or flexible conditions rather than the employee having to build a case as to why that should be okay so trying to change the dial on all of those things

author: A
sentence: But the one for example that I talked about, we would love to see parental leave be taken equally by men and women but that’s just societal change

author: A
sentence: So getting to your question, what can be done more broadly in Australia, that’s a conversation we can have with men at AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY but that’s 1% of the conversation that they’re going to have

author: A
sentence: It’s going to be a conversation they have with their friends, with their dad, with their brothers, with their partner

author: A
sentence: All of those conversations are going to have more influence than the conversation that we have at work

author: A
sentence: But what we do try and do is promote and highlight the cases where we see things happening that we think if more people knew that, they would feel like they had permission to do that

author: A
sentence: We try and put in place specific policies where we can see systematic points of linkage

author: A
sentence: We try and highlight conversations around what Liz Broderick describes as the gender asbestos

author: A
sentence: It’s invisible

author: A
sentence: You can’t see it

author: A
sentence: You can’t smell it but it’s in the air

author: A
sentence: It’s in the walls

author: A
sentence: It’s in the ceiling and it’s deadly and that sort of comes down to the everyday sexism type things

author: A
sentence: We absolutely had open conversations about sexual harassment but there are laws around that and there are procedures and it doesn’t always get reported

author: A
sentence: But what we’ve tried to is make it okay to have the conversations and make it okay to have, that’s a not okay conversation without it being a legal proceeding because lots of people don’t want to pursue it to that extent

author: A
sentence: But also just try to make sure that men and women are equally aware of the signs of everyday sexism and the impact that that has on people over a long period of [Participant]e

author: A
sentence: This is the roles that people are expected to play, the language that is used

author: A
sentence: When talking about this, I had a female developer who highlighted the fact that software developers have code reviews so if you’ve written some code I might review it

author: A
sentence: I’ve written some code

author: A
sentence: You might review it before we can commit to actually going into the formal testing and production systems

author: A
sentence: She’s just said, “It’s all the [Participant]e that I get told to have one of the guys check my code

author: A
sentence: It continually reinforces the fact that in this company, as a woman, my code isn’t seen as being the same quality as a guy’s because I have to have a man check my code first

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a growing appreciation of the fact that boards are a team endeavour and that the team is stronger, often more difficult to manage but stronger if they bring different experiences to the table

author: A
sentence: Therefore, if you’ve got a board member who is continually thinking about how the public markets will respond to something and you’ve got another board member whose natural bias is towards thinking about what will be the impact on the team and how will the team respond if this is the decision, and you’ve got another board member who is thinking very much as to are we going to be able to successfully sell that and how will our clients react?

author: A
sentence: Now the reality is I think the term ‘guys’ was not perceived by the people who use it to be a gender exclusive term

author: A
sentence: The fact is the two senior developers in the crew that she’s a part of are both men and so it was being suggested that one of those two men should review it, the same as they do the junior men in that group

author: A
sentence: But the fact that she had never had her code reviewed by another woman, only ever by men, had an absolute impact on her seeing ceilings where the organisation wasn’t trying to put them

author: A
sentence: So to all of those everyday things that we need to tackle, from the community perspective I think we just need more leaders that have conversations the way we’re trying to have leaders inside the organisation having those conversations because the more education we can have the more awareness that we can have

author: A
sentence: It’s why I talk on – I’m doing panels and conferences and so on about this because I think it’s a conversation that men have felt excluded from

author: A
sentence: I’ve actually been warned by women before

author: A
sentence: “Listen this might be a hostile environment for you to go and have this conversation because there are women who really feel like they own the women agenda and by you being a man and participating in that they actually don’t want you

author: A
sentence: They’re happier with the way it was

author: A
sentence: This is the feminist movement” and so on

author: A
sentence: Everyone’s welcome to their perspective but I think electively we’ll be more successful in tackling the problem if A, we all are focused on tackling the problem and B, if people who are in positions of authority and power are tackling the problem

author: A
sentence: The message is if people in positions of authority and power are not welcome in the conversation then that’s a very easy copout for people, very easy

author: A
sentence: I think right around having more community leaders who are diverse, talking about diversity

author: A
sentence: So if men are talking about gender diversity, different people are talking about diversity but it’s not if you like, those that are seen as being excluded or in the minority who have to [unclear] 00:43:06

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: It would be nice if we had more politicians speaking positively about diversity instead of – we’re back in, to me I feel a sense of the 60s, 70s in what I’m seeing on the media about the current political status and they’re important leaders

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: That is so good because it’s very different

author: Q
sentence: Your pitch is very different to other interviews I’ve had

author: Q
sentence: That’s why I wanted to give you a free wheel because that social, political way you see things is really useful

author: Q
sentence: Now, back to the board, you described mechanisms for AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY as an organisation

author: Q
sentence: Now with the board, what kinds of mechanisms might help to shape that leadership level for the same effect?

author: A
sentence: To get gender equity?

author: Q
sentence: Correct, to do what you’re trying to do here

author: A
sentence: So one of the things that we did was as a board agree to diversity targets which we have to

author: A
sentence: We have to report them in our annual report but there’s nothing that says that they have to be about board representation or there’s no prescribed set of metrics

author: A
sentence: You just have to have a set of targets and track against those targets

author: A
sentence: That was a really useful mechanism for us to say, “All right, should board gender mix be an item” and I said to the board, “I think it should, how are we going to get there?” There’s a big push at the moment to be 30% of directors being female

author: A
sentence: When we started out at that point we’re a six-member board with one female so we became a seven-member board with two females which meant we were sitting at 29% or something

author: A
sentence: Now we determined we did not want to be an eight-person board and we didn’t have an underperforming director that we wanted to move on

author: A
sentence: What we said was, “Listen, in the next 12 months we’re comfortable with where we are but we put long-term objectives out there where we said like the rest of AN AUSTRALIAN IT COMPANY a long term objective is to be 40%

author: A
sentence: ” Had we had the one male standing down and the female then we would have got there

author: A
sentence: So we could see a very direct line of sight

author: A
sentence: Justin, our chair, and I focused in our pipelines on continuing to meet female directors, people who we thought had good backgrounds when that moment came and this is one of the things you learn

author: A
sentence: If you leave it until the last minute you will find that there are multiple qualified men for every one qualified woman and that gets back to the pipeline issue

author: A
sentence: How do you get around that? You don’t leave it until the last minute

author: A
sentence: You plan and prepare and you spend [Participant]e

author: A
sentence: Of course the very good women are highly sought after and so they’re actually far more difficult to recruit

author: A
sentence: So you’ve got to make sure therefore that you’re on their list well in advance of needing them and they’re on your list because at that point in [Participant]e when the opportunity comes up they say, “I’ve been tracking you for a couple of years and I really like some of the things you’re doing

author: A
sentence: I do have this board over here which I’m not enjoying and actually, I wouldn’t mind stepping down somewhere in the next 12 months

author: A
sentence: ” So that will happen but if you leave it until the last minute when you’ve got six weeks and you want to make an appointment and they don’t know who you are, then the high-quality candidates won’t be interested in joining

author: A
sentence: You just won’t get that done at that point in [Participant]e

author: A
sentence: But you may well get a qualified man because the demand and supply equations are different

author: Q
sentence: How do you find these people, your recruits?

author: A
sentence: The experience that the board members have naturally leads them to have a bias in viewpoints and we all do

author: A
sentence: There’s no one who doesn’t bring biases because of what we call experience, right? Experience builds preconceived ideas and et cetera

author: A
sentence: Then as a team, they’re more likely to have a richer conversation

author: A
sentence: I’ve seen circumstances where one board member has moved the entire board and had that board member not been there and brought that one lens that they were very, very strong on, then the board would have taken a different position

author: A
sentence: I think that’s now sort of widely appreciated

author: A
sentence: It’s just constant working

author: Q
sentence: Is it networking, digital?

author: A
sentence: Constant networking from the existing board members, from talking to other CEOs who are listing their company and looking at setting up boards, from being a part of the Business Council of Australia through Male Champions of Change, all of those things

author: A
sentence: It’s a relatively small business community in Sydney and you’re constantly –

author: Q
sentence: Bumping into each other

author: Q
sentence: Given it’s an informal network, are there structures that shape that like men’s club or cultural differences like football? No?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: I think there were

author: A
sentence: I think that’s likely

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: A
sentence: There are business groups

author: A
sentence: There’s the BCA

author: A
sentence: There’s the CEW, the women’s CEO group, Male Champions of Change

author: A
sentence: There’s the Institute of Company Directors

author: A
sentence: There’s a few business orientations but they happen very much for business now

author: A
sentence: They don’t happen at a football club membership

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if there – are there still men’s clubs?

author: Q
sentence: There’s one in Melbourne still

author: A
sentence: I wouldn’t have a clue whether there’s one in Sydney or not

author: A
sentence: It wouldn’t be appealing to me and therefore I’d never go looking for it so I’ll probably never be invited

author: Q
sentence: Not that you worry

author: Q
sentence: [Participant], what struck me, it’s so good that we’re tapping into the current situation because the literature, it is or by definition 10 years plus out of date

author: Q
sentence: I’m aware of how rapidly changing our world is, socially, culturally as well as business

author: Q
sentence: Can you think now about how in 10 years’ [Participant]e in the future, how would you like to see diversity in Australian boards? Please feel free to broaden your consideration of diversity, from gender to other things, different ethnicities and ages and things like that

author: Q
sentence: That sounds like a really interesting example

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me about that? How that came about, that one tangential perspective that influenced the decision by the board?

author: A
sentence: I think the diversity of boards will likely lag the diversity of, I’ll call them business roles and there’s a broad interpretation of that but if you don’t understand business – I sit on a public company board

author: A
sentence: There might be circumstances where you’ll have one director who has a political background because there’s a government relations component and so it’s not exclusively – business is the wrong word

author: A
sentence: Are there commercially-relevant experiences? It might be a broader set of terms

author: A
sentence: But if you don’t get 50% of women in parliament then you won’t have 50% of politicians retiring who are women which means when those roles open up the pipeline will be heavily skewed towards men and so on

author: A
sentence: I think boards in some senses because of the requirement for experience will lag other areas and I think we’ve got to accept that

author: A
sentence: I think given the number of board seats there’s plenty of talent available

author: A
sentence: I think that it has to be a priority of agenda while the pipeline is not 50/50 but I think there is sufficient pipeline to at least get to the 40/40 where you say at any point in [Participant]e at least 40% of directors are women, at least 40% are men and we accept if we want someone with specifics then there’s going to be 20% which is just based on the talent pool available

author: A
sentence: Frankly, when you’re looking at six or seven people it literally comes to one individual that can then move sort of from the 40%

author: A
sentence: The thing that I think is going to be more challenging and the thing that I think is the step further on is then within the talent diversity, so the experience diversity I said we had the person who really understood financial engineering inside our balance sheet and P&L was one of our directives

author: A
sentence: We had somebody else who was a lawyer and really looked at the governance side

author: A
sentence: I think that you find and we find this in our company today that there are gender skews in both areas of the business that are predominantly women and areas that are predominantly men

author: A
sentence: What’s actually difficult is to balance, to say we want both of those areas to be gender-diverse

author: A
sentence: I think what you’ll find is there’ll be women who run [unclear] 00:53:13 far more prominently or added to the board for commercial experience and so on and that’s okay because it’s a first step

author: A
sentence: But what you [unclear] 00:53:25 is to have, if you’ve got two or three people with commercial experience, a couple with legal experience and maybe one with government, you’d really rather not have three men with commercial experience, two women who are lawyers because you’d get a stronger conversation if you actually had diversity within those functional expertise, which is another layer beyond just having the optics of gender diversity on the board overall

author: Q
sentence: You see a difference, quite important

author: Q
sentence: Can you flesh this out a little between men and women in terms of what they might bring to a function, a skill they have? Can you talk about that a little?

author: A
sentence: I think that brings different experiences as people

author: A
sentence: I think what you see is let’s just say that we had two people who had run those organisations all their career and maybe they were CEO or maybe they left as a senior executive in a sales [unclear] 00:54:37 function

author: A
sentence: I think the man and the woman there would see things through different lenses

author: A
sentence: They would have faced quite possibly some of the things we were talking about earlier of moments of dislocation differently through their career

author: A
sentence: They would have, in all likelihood, had to be in a minority or being part of a majority as they build their career to different extents and in different circumstances and so on

author: A
sentence: I think for another least 10 and probably 20 years, if you have those two people, while they had similar functional experience they would have had different life experiences, just because one was a man and one was a woman in the workplace over the last 30 years

author: A
sentence: I think that’s an important difference

author: A
sentence: I hope in the future it won’t be

author: A
sentence: I hope in the future parenting responsibilities would more likely been equally born by those two people and so on

author: A
sentence: I’d love to get to a point where I could say honestly, we can just drop that and move past it but I don’t think we’re there realistically today

author: A
sentence: If you don’t acknowledge it then what you do is have two people who don’t bring to this perspective of what it’s like to build a career and be a senior sales leader as a man versus as a woman

author: Q
sentence: I can see why it’s so important that you hang a lot of gender diversity

author: Q
sentence: I can see that

author: Q
sentence: It makes sense

author: Q
sentence: You’ve spoken in the beginning about how experience shapes decision making in teams and that improves decision making and manages corporate risk because of perceptions

author: Q
sentence: I get that

author: Q
sentence: I can see this is a really nice coherent story for me

author: A
sentence: Margo, just to fill one thing actually

author: A
sentence: The good thing for me is actually the diversity of thought and diversity of experience

author: A
sentence: We then have gender

author: A
sentence: Partly the reason that I don’t talk about race and other forms of diversity nearly as much is in our organisation we are actually quite diverse and so across our organisation you’ll see that there are people of different religions, people of different races, et cetera, right through the organisation

author: A
sentence: We don’t measure it so we don’t ask people to identify a religion

author: A
sentence: I can’t actually tell you what the diversity is and it’s very difficult to manage something that you don’t measure

author: A
sentence: We don’t ask people their ethnic background

author: Q
sentence: Is that by choice? Obviously by choice but why don’t you?

author: Q
sentence: Good, Okay [Participant], thank you for agreeing to be interviewed -

author: A
sentence: Education

author: A
sentence: It's hard because I think there's - if you're moving outside of gender, I'd say you'd still find men that think differently as well, have a real issue

author: A
sentence: People that are from different cultural backgrounds

author: A
sentence: I'd say women that get to the C-suite are similar - it's really at the moment, still similar people getting to that stage where they're outcomes focussed

author: A
sentence: They're really driven to make decisions so they're usually the people that are getting to those positions, more so than the process driven people, or the people-people

author: A
sentence: A lot of it is personality and interpersonal skills rather than all technical competencies

author: A
sentence: And we see that time and time again

author: A
sentence: People succeeding because of their interpersonal skills, which is great, but big personalities aren't always the best CEOs! I think we've got a long way to go in terms of really understanding where the people's different thinking styles and how to use that effectively, and how to develop people that may not have those interpersonal styles, but would make great leaders

author: A
sentence: How do you develop that into - it's like how do you get an introvert to be at times extroverted? It's a bit difficult! That's a real challenge, I think

author: Q
sentence: Okay, yeah

author: Q
sentence: With selection, board selection, director selection, there's the skills matrix that people tend to use and whatever and they map it to their - this is what the board needs, given its purpose and blah, blah and so this is what we need, these are the skills; but this is a different way

author: Q
sentence: It's like well yes, we need an accountant, someone with financial skills, but from this lens of cognitive diversity we need someone who's got strong people skills or is an empathetic person -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - or they think in terms of process and depth of understanding, rather than outcomes focussed and short-term financial and whatever

author: Q
sentence: I don't know how you cast it at the board level, but is that the sort of thing - how would you be able to select for this?And how does it compete with the other tool that's pretty standard -

author: A
sentence: Well, I suppose -

author: Q
sentence: -@ tools matrix?

author: A
sentence: - a lot of boards wouldn't do an assessment via someone's cognitive diversity as such, but in saying that, it depends on - a lot of recruits now, like the big four, have very useful leadership competencies and styles assessments tools

author: A
sentence: They will have a candidate complete that and so they will be able to talk to a board about an individual's leadership style and their competencies, and assess them more than just their technical skills

author: A
sentence: I'd say listed boards now, are very focussed on not just having someone technically competent

author: A
sentence: When they interview a director, they will want to know what their leadership style was, they will want to have an understanding of where that person will sit in different issues, how they will navigate a crisis situation

author: A
sentence: Whether they'll stay calm or get panicked, that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: They'll want to see they interact with other members of the board and their executive team, so other members of the board will interview a new candidate, usually the whole board meets them, members of the executive team will meet them

author: A
sentence: We released a 30% Club report on Wednesday on the next - actually I've got a copy here if you like - this was from the 'Pathways to ASX 200 Boards'from the 2018 appointees, so not - just last year for men and women

author: A
sentence: What was really, I suppose heartening, was that the journey in terms of the recruitment process in getting on to the boards was really similar for males and females

author: A
sentence: But what they were saying is that directors are - boards are looking for more than just people that are technically qualified

author: A
sentence: They're looking for people that have moral integrity, that do have compassion, ability to learn and develop as people

author: A
sentence: So, I'd say chairs are becoming better at trying to understand that

author: A
sentence: Because they know that they've got a small group of people and so yes, they want someone to challenge, but they need to also have people that work well in a team environment; because the board dynamics are really important

author: A
sentence: They can't afford to have a director that's just disruptive for the sake of being disruptive, that causes conflict

author: A
sentence: So, there's a difference between challenging effectively and having a different point of view to someone that's just causing conflict

author: A
sentence: It's a hard skill to learn as a director, like when to ask to questions? what are the right questions? when to stay silent? Because they're all skills too, that you don't really learn until you're on the board or on a board

author: A
sentence: That's tough and so a good chair would also be a mentor

author: A
sentence: Mentor a new director as to how the board operates, that sort of - some of those mechanics, talking to them off side about questions, that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: So, do most chairs - are they like a mentor for the directors?

author: Q
sentence: Education?

author: A
sentence: Not for established directors because - more for newer directors to the board

author: A
sentence: So, if they're a newish director they should be doing a mentor role

author: A
sentence: If they're new to the board, they'll just try and help them, induct them into the board and help them get up to scratch with the way that the board operates

author: A
sentence: But really, a good chair should also be questioning, ensuring that the directors are engaging in some sort of professional development, learning, engaging with the outside world

author: A
sentence: Because it's a hard role being the chair

author: A
sentence: It's a tough role

author: A
sentence: You can't say one way works better, because they're all so different

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it depends on the board!

author: A
sentence: It depends on the chair, as well -

author: Q
sentence: On the chair!

author: A
sentence: On the style and the way they like to run things

author: Q
sentence: Does it depend on the industry, do you think?

author: A
sentence: A bit, but I don't know

author: A
sentence: From the chairs I've talked to, I think it more depends on personal style and their executive experience and how they've run things in the past

author: A
sentence: Some will more sit back and want the directors to talk and then give their point of view at the end

author: A
sentence: Others will kind of challenge whilst they're going, it's really preference

author: A
sentence: Some are more of the quiet ones; some are more bombastic

author: A
sentence: So, I see it as more of a personal style approach

author: Q
sentence: So, they're really cultivating a team? It's like a team, the directors?

author: A
sentence: Oh, yeah

author: A
sentence: That's why not all ex CEOs will make good directors because they're used to commanding and control, some of them, and you've got to work as a team as a board

author: A
sentence: You've got to support your fellow directors and you've got to build up trust and mutual respect

author: A
sentence: That's really important

author: Q
sentence: How might they do that for someone say who's quite visibly different? It might be someone who's black skinned in a predominantly white board? Or in the old days it was gender, but hopefully we've got at least - if it's 30% we should have at least three, is that right?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: It's hard, because I think of course the board and the chair can make people feel included

author: A
sentence: It's reallyimportant that they make new directors feel welcome and that they can have a pointof view, and they encourage them to speak andto have a point of view

author: A
sentence: And, they ensure that they feel included in the culture

author: A
sentence: But it is really tough though if you're the one different director in a group of maybe seven

author: A
sentence: Because I suppose it's like all environments, you do develop ways of doing things, don't you? If the board has a certain way of doing things and certain discussions, and you feel that you're not in this inner circle because they've been all directors onthe board for years, it is really tough! And it's intimidating and you've got to be a strong person and incredibly resilient to go into a boardroom and not care that you're the one person

author: A
sentence: So, yeah that's a bit of a responsibility for that one person as well

author: A
sentence: So, we say it's not ideal, because you also don't want to look to that person to be the view of their gender or their race or the culture -

author: Q
sentence: Or their age group

author: A
sentence: - or their age, exactly! It's not fair on them and of course they don't represent everyone in their whatever demographic

author: A
sentence: I think that's very tough but then you'll talk to some women as the only woman on the board and they’re fine, and that's because the board has a really good culture

author: A
sentence: But I say most would prefer that there would be more than them, you talk to them and they're like, well would like a few more!

author: Q
sentence: Because otherwise it could be a bit token

author: A
sentence: Well it's hard for them

author: A
sentence: It's hard to feel that you can sometimes have your point of view and say stuff, so yeah

author: Q
sentence: Without any backing! That's great

author: Q
sentence: Okay so how does your organisation seek to influence boards?

author: A
sentence: Well it depends on which elements you're looking at

author: A
sentence: We do a lot of education because we're - of course we're strong supporters of good governance, so we try to educate as much as possible through courses, through events, through our magazine and different resources

author: A
sentence: We also try to do - like we've got a Governance Leadership Centre so we try to promote new thinking or different thinking, so that people can engage and go 'oh well maybe I haven't thought of that way'

author: A
sentence: We try to look more than - to talk more like the Royal Commission that when we did the roadshows, that culture is really important and how do you influence that as a director? So, we also try to look at some of the forward agenda stuff, like what's coming up for directors? Being a director is more than the technical skills

author: A
sentence: How do we help directors and provide resources that support them?

author: A
sentence: But in my role, a lot of it is advocacy, it's campaigning so it's developing resources to change people's point of view or to help them with something

author: A
sentence: It's the getting chairs to support diversity through becoming a chair member of the 30% Club, it's talking to them, getting them involved in different diversity initiatives

author: A
sentence: It's me trying to influence the way that they're thinking, or just to understand what's going on, I think it's really important to understand

author: A
sentence: I'm quite happy to hear divergent view points and negative view points if it helps us in developing the right resources

author: A
sentence: So, we try to be very welcoming and inclusive and we are a member-based organisation, so our members are very diverse as well

author: A
sentence: But yeah, it's really about advocacy and the campaigning and putting messages out in the media, because at the end of the day I can't recruit a board member

author: A
sentence: I have no influence on who gets appointed! We can only do what we can do, and hope that chairs go 'well yeah actually I do need someone with a diverse point of view on board'

author: A
sentence: And we work with recruiters too, to ensure that they believe in it

author: A
sentence: Although a lot do and the search process is becoming more rigorous

author: A
sentence: There're some amazing search consultants out there really looking further afield

author: A
sentence: Looking outside of the current director network, looking overseas, trying to find different individuals

author: A
sentence: So, I 'd say a lot of search consultants are doing a really good job, some aren't but that’s like anything isn't it?

author: Q
sentence: Should I - I mean I've talked to one, I'm just wondering if I should talk to another search consultant? And if so, who would you recommend?

author: Q
sentence: You mentioned, so it's chairs because I looked on your website so you've got a specific Chair's -

author: A
sentence: Well that depends, you've got the big ones, like the SHREKs but then you've got some really good boutique consultancies as well, which do an excellent job

author: Q
sentence: In terms of diversity, who would you recommend?

author: A
sentence: Oh, it depends, I'd still talk to some of the big ones

author: A
sentence: I think, Heidi Mason, who's now at Korn Ferry, she was at Egon Zehnder

author: A
sentence: She's got a wealth of experience in this space

author: A
sentence: But the Chair of our Executive Search Group, Jane Neale from Hattonneale, she's really excellent

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well that's two

author: A
sentence: In the - Nick Fletcher from Russell Reynolds here, because he's Melbourne based

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that's easier for me because I find Zoom is terrible

author: A
sentence: It's hard, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Nick Fletcher, from?

author: A
sentence: Fletcher, Russell Reynolds yeah, he's here

author: Q
sentence: That's a good start -

author: A
sentence: Mentoring Programme, yep

author: A
sentence: They'll tell you about some of the practical realities as well with this, as well, that it can be hard

author: Q
sentence: [Unclear]00:38:30 I probably need at little more on that -

author: A
sentence: And it depends what the sector you're looking at too

author: Q
sentence: - particularly in terms of leadership

author: Q
sentence: I loved what you said about leadership, how the -

author: A
sentence: Oh, they all have their tools and measurement that they're very protective of!

author: Q
sentence: [Unclear] 00:38:47

author: A
sentence: Their IP!

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly! They might tell me enough that we can -

author: A
sentence: They'll show them to me but they won't - that's it! That's fine, I like - it's great to see that they're doing that sort of stuff

author: Q
sentence: I think competition is good

author: Q
sentence: -@ mentoring Programme as Well as -@ when did you introduce that?

author: A
sentence: We're using Heidrick & Struggles for our assessment of our Chairs Mentoring Programme applicants

author: A
sentence: This is the first time we've used a consultant and they're doing the leadership matrix and interviewing them

author: A
sentence: Which is excellent because it removes me from the process! Which I think is very important and yeah, I'm fascinated to see their assessments of individuals

author: A
sentence: I think it's great

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: How important - I'm moving all around the place - how important do you think it is to have a diverse board?

author: A
sentence: Like huge!

author: Q
sentence: One is nothing, not at all, 10 is extremely, so one to 10?

author: A
sentence: Well I'd say 10

author: A
sentence: It's extremely important

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: As long as you harness it in the right way! That would be the caveat

author: Q
sentence: As long as it's well harnessed

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I like that! Do you think it's always been important?

author: A
sentence: I think it's more the people didn't really think about it

author: A
sentence: They felt if they had people from different - that had done really well in their executive careers - that they would be able to cover everything

author: A
sentence: And that's fair enough

author: A
sentence: It's like everything, we're learning and developing

author: A
sentence: So, yeah, I just don't think people thought about it, really

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: What do you think has caused that change in thinking, that people now think about it?

author: A
sentence: The Chair's Mentoring Programme, our first one launched in 2010 so we really started - AICD started focussing on this in about 2009 and that's when the percentage of women on ASX 200 Boards was 8

author: A
sentence: 3%, so really low

author: A
sentence: Internally there was a bit of conversation - I wasn't in the diversity role then and internally there was a conversation, what we can do? So, with the Mentoring Programme we matched ASX 200 chairs with - I wouldn't say even emerging female directors - they were really amazing executives that you see on all the 200 now

author: A
sentence: They were really just - it was really more of a networking exposure visibility kind of piece

author: A
sentence: And I'd say the Mentoring Programme is still like that

author: A
sentence: The people on the Programme are all technically capable, they're all qualified, it's really about creating that support network for them

author: A
sentence: Ensuring their visibility to chairs to other NEDs to recruiters and then creating that network for them ongoing

author: A
sentence: This is our sixth one and we'll be launching - yeah, applications have just closed and we're launching in August

author: A
sentence: So, we run them probably every 18 months because it is a 12 month relationship, so we give the chairs a bit of a rest in between

author: A
sentence: So, it actually amounts to two years

author: A
sentence: I think a lot has been started by more women coming onto boards and wanting to be on boards

author: A
sentence: I think we've started at the base

author: Q
sentence: The gender push?

author: A
sentence: The gender push has been huge and then it moved to 'well hang on it shouldn't just be gender, what about people from different cultural backgrounds?' Particularly in Australia, that's huge! Then we've gone to the LGBTIQ - I think I got it right!

author: Q
sentence: Well done!

author: A
