sentence: I felt like there were more letters! And now that's important too

author: A
sentence: So, then we've gone 'well hang on, we can't just then focus on separate groups all the time, how do we move beyond that?' Then we went to diversity, now we've gone to inclusion and now people are talking about belonging

author: A
sentence: So, I feel like it's just one of those spaces that just keeps evolving

author: A
sentence: We're still trying to do it properly

author: Q
sentence: Can you explain to me the transition from diversity to inclusion?

author: A
sentence: Well I suppose it used to be - well you just need to have more diversity and whatever executive leadership teams in organisations, and then people realised that that's great, but you can't just put diverse people into a group and expect them to feel comfortable and to be able to perform

author: A
sentence: And, the people - the group also needs to accept them and to celebrate their diversity

author: A
sentence: So then, we moved into the inclusion which is ensuring that people felt that they knew you were including them

author: A
sentence: And now, people are talking about belonging, saying well people need to feel like they belong in that group; that if you are different you can belong in a group that maybe a lot aren't different

author: A
sentence: I think that's - we're really trying to evolve in terms of ensuring that people are accepted for who they are, into teams

author: A
sentence: It's tough and I think a lot of organisations are struggling with it

author: A
sentence: It's definitely not an easy process

author: Q
sentence: Do you think - given your - you think right only if diversity, you'd give it a 10 only if people can perhaps include - they could be included in the board - do you think if there is not that capacity, then diversity is not as important?

author: A
sentence: I think that it's more that it's detrimental to the individuals

author: A
sentence: I think it's detrimental to their confidence, to their ability to perform

author: A
sentence: So, if you're - you can't just throw people in - it can be harmful if they feel that they're not included and it's a negative experience

author: A
sentence: But also, you can't expect - and Juliet talks well about this in her book - that you can't just throw diverse people together and expect them to perform, because they don't

author: A
sentence: You can't go 'well I've got a person from this background, this background, this background all thinking styles', they won't necessarily make the best decision

author: A
sentence: You've got have a person that can get them to make the best decisions, hence why the role of the chair is vital on a board

author: A
sentence: Because they're the ones harnessing it

author: A
sentence: They're the ones ensuring that people can perform and bring their best selves to the boardroom

author: A
sentence: Also, if you've got people that are diverse and not being harnessed, not being - I suppose, challenged appropriately - then you've got everyone just throwing out different things

author: A
sentence: Then the board won't make good decisions

author: A
sentence: The board won't get anything done so then you're better having people that can work together, that may not be as diverse, but can still make good decisions

author: A
sentence: Whether they'll make the best decisions, but better to make good decisions than have a board that's dysfunctional

author: A
sentence: That was our flagship diversity initiative and then the AICDs done a number of scholarships with the federal government for women going through our educational programmes

author: A
sentence: We continue to do different types of scholarships, federal and state which has been excellent

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the risk of a board falling into dysfunction because of diversity is real -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - can't be ignored, so that's important because some people use that as reason for against diversity

author: A
sentence: Well, I'd say for that to happen though, the board needs to be incredibly diverse like everyone different

author: A
sentence: It's not going to happen if you've only got two people from a different point of view, or three, it's more that they're not going to be able to perform the best that they can

author: A
sentence: Because they may not feel that they can speak up as much

author: A
sentence: So then, you've got people that aren't being utilised effectively

author: A
sentence: So, the dysfunction I'd say, would only come if the whole board was really different and you didn't have a chair that -

author: Q
sentence: Could pull it together

author: A
sentence: - could pull it together properly

author: A
sentence: But it's still dysfunctional if you've got a homogenous board because you're not making the best decisions

author: A
sentence: That's where groupthink comes in because that's also really dangerous, because people are all agreeing with each other!And we've seen that happen on boards where they've said the issues were groupthink

author: Q
sentence: That's right and there's lack of ethics then

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that's another conversation! The ethical piece

author: A
sentence: I suppose, you've got to find that nice point in the middle; which some boards have done really well

author: Q
sentence: I'm just wondering - I'm thinking about - because you're using - like targets are really important - you call them targets?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do they move beyond gender to say low socio-economic backgrounds, cultural differences?

author: Q
sentence: Targets are really important, a strategy that you use, if that's - if a board says 'I've just all my team, I don't have a coherent base, a cohesive base, I can't just pull everyone from diverse backgrounds, I need some homogenous group, and then later on in two years time or something, I'll be able to get people from different gender backgrounds and different ways of thinking and things like that, increase my diversity', would you accept that? Do your targets allow you to - is it like a 'please explain' rather than a?

author: A
sentence: Well we don't have - you can't - unless you've got government quotas where there's actual regulation and there's consequences, targets - I think for us, we've seen the targets as important

author: A
sentence: Because we actually have seen chairs call us around the table and when they've achieved it, say that, and we've seen chairs speak in public about the importance of the targets

author: A
sentence: So, targets are incredibly important and you just hope that there's always a flow-on effect that once you've achieved this in diversity, some are doing it hand-in-hand, you see some boards, they've got great international directors as well that are culturally diverse

author: A
sentence: But it's yeah, I suppose, with all things we can question chairs, we can say, "Why haven't you achieved the target you said you would?Talk to us about some of the reasons

author: A
sentence: " But we can't force anyone to do anything unless there are quotas or some sort of regulation in place

author: Q
sentence: Would you support that? Would you think that would be a good idea?

author: A
sentence: Organisationally? The AICD doesn't support targets - quotas, neither does the 30% Club because we've seen that we can get there with voluntary efforts

author: A
sentence: Personally, I've got a different point of view but that's my personal opinion and I can't talk about that because I represent organisations

author: A
sentence: Because I suppose, I see that - like all things, you put in a quota and you just have to make it work

author: A
sentence: The arguments against it, which is a concern, is that there are not enough women in senior leadership roles and executive teams at the moment

author: A
sentence: Which is a huge concern in Australia

author: A
sentence: We're still not getting women in the P&L roles

author: A
sentence: Women are still experiencing so many barriers in the workplace and so if just say quotas came in, yeah, the pipeline could be an issue

author: A
sentence: So, it's - that's a struggle, that space, at the moment

author: Q
sentence: Do you think this is the main limitation on diversity? Achieving diversity, pipeline issues?

author: A
sentence: I still think we've got enough women for the listed space at the moment to have 50:50 really

author: A
sentence: Because there's only - well if you take out the executive directors, there's only about 1100 board roles on the ASX 200

author: A
sentence: That's nothing without - so clearly there are enough women for that! In terms of our long-term - the longevity of this and women expanding into other boards, other areas, yeah, it's a huge problem

author: A
sentence: The pipeline is huge problem

author: Q
sentence: Not just women now, let's think more broadly

author: A
sentence: Oh, cultural diversity

author: A
sentence: No, they're not getting up to - people with culturally diverse backgrounds -

author: Q
sentence: Is it a pipeline issue again?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: There're too many barriers within - and it's not that there's not people, they're skilled

author: A
sentence: I suppose people celebrate then women or people from culturally diverse backgrounds starting their own businesses and going with start-up spaces and that is excellent

author: A
sentence: That is a really exciting space

author: A
sentence: But it's also a concern

author: A
sentence: If you feel that in your organisation, your talents aren't recognised and you're not going to achieve your ambitions so you go and start your own business, I think that's pretty crap

author: A
sentence: So, I'm like that's not great! And women will do that sometimes, not for the best reasons in terms of leaving to be a director, and we're like 'don't do that' because you won't achieve your ambitions if you leave now

author: A
sentence: You're better to stay longer and then you will get some excellent board roles, but it's because again, they don't feel that they're going to achieve what they want to achieve and so we're trying to say, "Go get another role

author: A
sentence: Try to find an organisation that will support you and go somewhere else

author: A
sentence: We do different ones

author: A
sentence: In the gender space because I'm really - my role is primarily women - we've done cultural diversity scholarships; we've done rural and remote scholarships so we do try to ensure that we cover some of those as well

author: A
sentence: We've done a disability sector scholarship programme and then we do other ones

author: A
sentence: So, outside my portfolio I suppose - in the political term - we've got like a not-for-profit sector leader so we do not-for-profit scholarships and different ones

author: A
sentence: So, they're not all in the diversity space

author: A
sentence: It merely depends on the different governments and ministers and what they want to work on

author: A
sentence: That's some of the stuff that we've done and it was in 2015 though that we said, oh the progress in the ASX 200 we're not moving fast enough, it was about 19

author: A
sentence: 3% and so that's when we called for a target for ASX 200 Boards to achieve 30% women by the end of 2018

author: Q
sentence: Do you help people?

author: A
sentence: That's not our role

author: A
sentence: Why we don't, is because the 30% Club overseas does, is because we've got chief executive women who do a really great job in this space

author: A
sentence: We're really supportive of them and we work with them

author: A
sentence: You've got the Male Champions of Change, you've got the Workplace Gender Equality Agency going off and trying to do their best, you've got some different organisations in different sectors and so we didn't want to crowd out the executive space,because there's enough work going on there

author: Q
sentence: But you might refer them to those?

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, but it's hard

author: A
sentence: You've got some great recruiters now that are coming up, that you see that are operating just in the diversity space, which is good

author: Q
sentence: Oh! Maybe I should interview one of them?

author: A
sentence: Yes, so you've got - I've got to think, somebody like Diversity Careers I think they've changed their name though -

author: Q
sentence: If I Google Diversity Careers -

author: A
sentence: DiverCity Careers I think it is, DiverCity Careers, yep

author: Q
sentence: @ it might come up with an old one or something

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: There's someone that's excellent who's launching her own business called [Rejig, Shavon Savage] 00:51:09 who's - basically it's a software programme that she's going to sell to organisations to map - it's mainly for diversity for women, but it can also help you map your future workforce and the skills that you'll need

author: A
sentence: You can actually map your whole network because a common thing is that, I suppose managers will say, "But I don't know anyone in my network with those skills

author: A
sentence: " That sort of system will allow them to map their network and go 'well actually I know more people than I thought I did'

author: A
sentence: So that'll be excellent, very exciting for her, she's fantastic

author: A
sentence: Oh, that's all right

author: A
sentence: At that same time, the 30% Club launched in Australia by Patricia Cross who's based here

author: A
sentence: She said to our then CEO, John Brogden, "I see the natural home for the 30% Club being the AICD because I can't manage a movement myself

author: A
sentence: " She's a busy non-executive director and so we agreed to manage it

author: A
sentence: But in saying that, the 30% Club is a separate entity to the AICD

author: A
sentence: So, I'm the Executive of it, I manage it, I resource it but the AICD doesn't own it, it's separate

author: A
sentence: We do our own initiatives, it's very flexible

author: A
sentence: It's people by working group, like we've got working group members that are volunteers, so it's a very fluid kind of entity which is great

author: A
sentence: Because we get to do some really amazing stuff with the 30% Club and now, we've got a slightly different target

author: A
sentence: Although we nearly reached the 30%at the end of last year, we still haven't reached it but we will, we will

author: A
sentence: The 30% Club is now looking at the ASX 300 and having a target for them by the end of 2021

author: Q
sentence: Interesting

author: A
sentence: We support it, but we're just mindful to stay in the board space and although it's all connected, we've just - we can't do everything! Otherwise we'd spread ourselves too thin

author: Q
sentence: Now look I want to ask you a cool question which is, what does board diversity mean to you? Just so I've got it here

author: A
sentence: I still think - I do understand that board diversity is about different individuals with different perspectives, and some of that's demographic diversity from the socialisation process

author: A
sentence: Some of it is your thinking styles and the way that you come at decisions either as your executive career and what you've - so that to me is the ultimate board diversity

author: A
sentence: But for me right now, I still think of board diversity in terms of gender and getting more women on boards because we're still at a space where we don't have enough, for me to say comfortably, that we can move on

author: Q
sentence: You know, I've interviewed people who have said that they wouldn't go and apply to be a director on a board if there wasn't gender equity

author: A
sentence: I think that's great

author: Q
sentence: And they weren't women

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: They said, "They see it as a flag for diversity and they're not interested in being on a board that is antidiversity

author: A
sentence: Gosh! We need more men to say that!

author: A
sentence: The AICD is still supporting the reporting, we're still advocating for more women on boards but we've adopted a stance of 40:40:20 that we think that's best practice; 40% male, 40% female and 20% [unclear] 00:05:08

author: A
sentence: So that's kind of the AICDs now policy but we support all the activities of the 30% Club

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly! I thought we had a little pocket of -

author: A
sentence: We need more men to put their hand up to say, "I won't go on a board without women!"

author: Q
sentence: Yeah!

author: A
sentence: Because there's still plenty that do! So that is encouraging

author: A
sentence: We just need more people to think like that really

author: Q
sentence: We've had a little pocket, I think, of amazing men

author: A
sentence: Oh, there are plenty out there and sometimes they're not getting the opportunities too, because they're thinking differently as well

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, possibly

author: A
sentence: This is for the benefit of everyone, we like to say!

author: Q
sentence: Yes, exactly

author: Q
sentence: So, what do you see as the main barriers to building diverse boards in Australia and how do these work? You've mentioned pipeline

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the pipeline is definitely an issue, particularly in some sectors

author: A
sentence: It's an issue - where it comes an issue is if a chair - and this is fair enough in some cases - if they need someone with particular skills and that's because of their skills matrix

author: A
sentence: They've got a board where they cover off the other skills and so they're saying 'well I need - I have to - because of the business we're in, we have to get someone that's been a senior mining executive' and that's when they go, "We really struggled

author: A
sentence: We did a search and we couldn't find any women

author: A
sentence: " I do sympathise and say, "Yep, I understand

author: A
sentence: " But I think that's a part of it, but I think a big bit is attitudinal

author: A
sentence: It's not understanding what diversity is, the importance of it

author: A
sentence: It's looking at the board and having this narrow view of what a director is and that you need someone that's an ex CEO or an ex C-suite without looking at the rest of the board and saying, "Well, do we actually need someone like that?  Could we get someone that's been in a functional role that provides a different point of view?"

author: Q
sentence: Why have you shifted to 40?

author: A
sentence: That is them having a limited view as to what makes an effective director and you'll see great cases where they have recruited women

author: A
sentence: They've gone 'oh we need this director' but then they've gone 'oh, hang on a sec, that person's going to step off the board in a year, although she doesn't fit the person we're looking for here, she actually fits that person

author: A
sentence: Because she's so good, let's put her on now and then we can recruit for those skills later'

author: A
sentence: That's someone being future-focussed and really wanting diversity

author: A
sentence: A lot are not like that, so I'd say the biggest barriers are still attitudinal

author: Q
sentence: Does your organisation, Australian Institute of Company Directors, does it work on the area of recruitment? Because it seems to be key

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: And why we haven't, is because it's a tricky space, recruitment

author: A
sentence: It's very resource intensive and so we don't really have the resources plus we're mindful that we want to work well with other recruiters

author: A
sentence: We try not to favour recruiters over others

author: A
sentence: But in saying that we're asked all the time, why don't we provide lists of directors? Why don't we do this? Again, that goes into the tricky space of endorsing people and vetting them and we don't want - I don't think we're going to move into the vetting and endorsing ever

author: A
sentence: But we do have Directorship Opportunities portal where we advertise board roles

author: A
sentence: We are looking at redeveloping that where I think we will be able to do more searchable skills, so it'll be more effective in terms of matching individuals and their capabilities to boards

author: A
sentence: So, that will be, I think, in the future

author: A
sentence: I do recommend people that have gone through the mentoring programme

author: A
sentence: I do get chairs come to me and ask for recommendations

author: A
sentence: But the caveat of that is, that I say, "These are people that have gone through the mentoring programme

author: A
sentence: This isn't my membership base

author: A
sentence: This isn't a full list of AICD members

author: A
sentence: " We're always asked to provide a list of women for things

author: A
sentence: It's something we grapple with; we just haven't landed on what's best

author: A
sentence: We kind of do a bit of this and that and we're still a bit mindful of the risks involved

author: Q
sentence: What about in your training - in your educational programmes, do you talk about this as being a key area and how one might approach recruitment?

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, definitely

author: A
sentence: We do sessions with recruiters

author: Q
sentence: Strategic, long-term, not just now?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: The future-focussed that you were talking about?

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah and that report too, it talks about building your - I suppose developing your director brand and reputation early

author: A
sentence: Networking with recruiters early, developing your value proposition, not just leaving an executive career and suddenly going 'oh suddenly, hang on I might be a director'

author: A
sentence: You start to really develop this, 10 to 20 years, even now, starting to think about it

author: A
sentence: We do stress the importance of networking with recruiters, but I also say don't go to a recruiter and not have an idea of what you want, because it's a small market

author: A
sentence: You've basically got one shot with a recruiter, if you don't make a good first impression then they don't really help you out

author: A
sentence: 40:40:20? Because I suppose that we saw that as - really that is best practice

author: A
sentence: We've never said that 30% is the ceiling

author: A
sentence: We've always said it's the floor, it's the minimum, you should move beyond 30%

author: A
sentence: Why we supported the 30% was because of research, it said that was when minority voices are heard in a group

author: A
sentence: But really, we do think that it should be 40:40:20 that's fair, that's proper diversity around the table

author: A
sentence: So that's why we've moved into a general position because we think that's important

author: A
sentence: All our reporting is still looking at the ASX 200, 300 still monitoring against that 30% target

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay!

author: A
sentence: So, you need to go to them really demonstrating your skills

author: A
sentence: because some - they're all different, like humans

author: A
sentence: Some will coach people more and they will be more understanding

author: A
sentence: Others won't, they'll be that was a bad impression, no

author: A
sentence: you've just got to be careful, that when you go into this space,you're prepared

author: A
sentence: Because it can be a bit gruelling as well doing the recruit arounds, it's not fun

author: Q
sentence: Okay great, we've done that one

author: Q
sentence: We're on the final question! Looking now 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Oh, I would like to see them truly diverse, not just in terms of women and people with culturally diverse backgrounds, I would like to see people that have - I would like to see more academics on board

author: A
sentence: I would like to see people more that have developed amazing, their own businesses on listed boards

author: A
sentence: I'd really like to see more Indigenous people on our listed boards and private boards

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I'd really like to just look at a board profile and go, wow! Aren't these people amazing? They're all incredibly skilled and they've all come from such a diverse background

author: A
sentence: That's what we're aiming for

author: A
sentence: I don't want to continue looking at board profiles and seeing a whole bunch similar aged white men

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: So yeah, that's the goal, but 10 years is quite soon! I don't know

author: Q
sentence: What do you think needs to happen [inaudible] 00:59:40

author: A
sentence: It's hard! I think a lot of different things

author: A
sentence: You need more women in C-suite roles and P& L roles

author: A
sentence: You need more guys really understanding the value of diversity

author: A
sentence: You need more people that are culturally diverse in C-suite roles too

author: A
sentence: We need good examples of different leads that aren't the all the big personalities

author: A
sentence: You need to show there are different leadership styles, so there needs to be more workaround what different leadership styles there are, and how that can work in harnessing diversity

author: A
sentence: There's a whole bunch of issues

author: A
sentence: You need more men taking up flexible work, parenting duties, you need equal numbers of men working -

author: Q
sentence: Social change!

author: A
sentence: Yeah, total social change! Because you need more men working flexibly to understand the issues and to take on some of the mental load, because women take on most of the mental load when it comes to the family

author: A
sentence: So, we need to free up space for that and we need to fundamentally change day-care structures, the money

author: A
sentence: It costs to put kids in day-care because all that has a flow-on effect to women being able to work

author: A
sentence: So, I feel unless we have strong government policies and interventions, I don't know if I'm going to see that much change in 10 years, to be honest

author: Q
sentence: You said best practice?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the government policies and interventions are not targeting necessarily the regulations of boards?

author: A
sentence: No! It's a bigger [unclear] 01:01:20

author: Q
sentence: It's social reform! Wow I like that!

author: A
sentence: It's like Scandinavia

author: A
sentence: Well, why can't we do a similar structure that you do get extra parental leave, but you don't get it if the man doesn't take it

author: A
sentence: So, why can't we basically force more men to take parental leave? Because no matter what organisations say about flexible working, if that's done by 10% of their male employees and 90% women or 60% women or whatever it is, then really that just shows men are still going to keep going up because they're the ones that are there all the time, working fulltime

author: A
sentence: That shows to them that's what leadership is

author: A
sentence: Unless that changes, I just - it's too hard for women to then break through, to compete with that

author: A
sentence: How do we compete with that?

author: Q
sentence: The other kinds of diversity? Like cultural?

author: A
sentence: I think cultural, it's still going to be really hard until we change the model of leadership and what leadership looks like

author: A
sentence: Look at government

author: A
sentence: We've got a whole bunch of older white men now, again, what does that signal to the rest of society? Is it that you're being run by old white men?So, I'm really scathing of the fact that there are no women in the coalition

author: A
sentence: I think it's despicable

author: A
sentence: Like, who's going to be Minster for Women? Who are they going to throw in that portfolio? Like Marise Payne is excellent and she's been an excellent Foreign Minister, but surely they're not going to take that portfolio from her? Kelly Dwyer's not there, who else are they going to grab? So, for me, I just think well, unless our government actually reflects society, how do we change society? Because a government like that has no inclination to change society and to change the structures

author: A
sentence: So how can - as organisations, we can do as much as we can, but we can't really change society to the point that it needs to be at, to get where we want to go

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: So, yeah

author: Q
sentence: They need to role model -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Mm-hm

author: Q
sentence: - diversity!

author: A
sentence: Oh, but yeah, another devastating result!

author: Q
sentence: Lovely to finish in a - with a political tone!

author: Q
sentence: Is there an international standard or something?

author: A
sentence: No, there's different views

author: A
sentence: But I'd say governments have set 40:40:20, there's a lot of different organisations that support that as achievable

author: A
sentence: And why is because 50:50 is great but due to numbers it often doesn't work 50:50 as well

author: A
sentence: So, it's important to say, well actually 40% of each is really important and then whatever the 20%

author: Q
sentence: Okay and 30% you said was essential for minority voices to be heard?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - for our research on board diversity

author: Q
sentence: So initially, I'd just like to get a feel for the discipline background you're from

author: Q
sentence: What did you - are an accounting?

author: Q
sentence: Is there research to support that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah there is some research that does support that view

author: A
sentence: Different groups have done research on that and we stress that that doesn't mean that they're a minority in general, just that within a group if they're the minority voices - they don't - if there's one female director it's very difficult for them to prosecute their arguments

author: A
sentence: That's when people tend to start to feel more comfortable, when they reach that kind of threshold

author: Q
sentence: Is there a particular research that has been influential in supporting this 30% target in Australia?

author: A
sentence: There's been different research

author: A
sentence: I can dig up the kind of stuff that we've looked at because we've looked at lots of different research

author: A
sentence: For some, it's about the economic argument as well, the financial metric, there's a lot like McKinsey research pieces that have been really important

author: A
sentence: Deloitte have done some really good ones too

author: A
sentence: So, I can dig some out and send them to you because there's a lot of different research that we've used in the past

author: Q
sentence: Right, okay

author: Q
sentence: That'd be great

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: If you can, I know you're really, really busy

author: A
sentence: No, I can do that

author: Q
sentence: That would be fantastic

author: A
sentence: Because there's some really good ones

author: A
sentence: But in saying that, the economic argument one is an interesting one in that - I suppose some people still really like to see the evidence, they want you to demonstrate that having more women on boards increases financial performance and stuff

author: A
sentence: But I personally, I find those a bit - it doesn't sit well with me

author: A
sentence: I feel that women are justifying their positions and men don't have to do that

author: A
sentence: So, I'm more go the social equity the facts that women go through university at higher rates, perform better at university

author: A
sentence: So, I find it insulting that women, that we still have to prove that we have to be there

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: It's a power issue not a performance issue

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: And really, diversity - there's a lot of research also that shows that diverse teams make better decisions because they cover the breadth of issues, that they have people thinking about issues differently

author: A
sentence: So, I think people understand that diversity is important

author: A
sentence: I think where we come unstuck is that diversity can be uncomfortable

author: A
sentence: Some people still don't want to put themselves in a position where it's uncomfortable, when it's more effort to manage a diverse group of people

author: A
sentence: A lot of people still naturally tend to, I suppose, select people that are like them, in groups

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a little bit more about that discomfort?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Because it's a barrier that you're putting up

author: A
sentence: Well it is

author: A
sentence: I've said that we've talked about this; that diversity can be really uncomfortable

author: A
sentence: So as a leader, you have to be quite insightful and understand that you're going to be in situations where you're going to be with people that don't agree with the way that you present things, or your points of view

author: A
sentence: So, you've got to be a leader that develops those sorts of skills to manage that, to take on different points of view, but also to accept it and to look for that diversity

author: A
sentence: And to want people to question what you're doing because you see that as important

author: A
sentence: I think not everyone's that insightful! Not everyone can - it's a difficult skill to learn as well; to accept questioning and difference, so it's tough

author: Q
sentence: Do you focus on that skill in your education - the education offered here?

author: A
sentence: No, although - it's hard

author: A
sentence: Because the Company Directors Course, which is our well-known course -

author: Q
sentence: Core business

author: A
sentence: - is really about developing those technical skills

author: A
sentence: Although we talk about decision making and the importance of group dynamics, there's a lot to get through in terms of governance,what strategy and risk is, the financial understanding you need to have as a director

author: A
sentence: So, there's already so much to cover in terms of your technical skills that it's - we can't then focus a huge amount on some of those interpersonal aspects

author: A
sentence: Like I said, we talk about group dynamics

author: A
sentence: It's really about what is a director and what's a boardroom

author: A
sentence: We are relaunching our what used to be Mastering the Boardroom now called Boardroom Mastery programme and I think we're starting to run those in the second half of this year

author: A
sentence: That will more look at the - you'll be doing the psychological testing, that more looks at your interpersonal skills and who you are as a director

author: Q
sentence: Humanities?

author: A
sentence: That will go into depth but you have to be quite an experienced director to be accepted onto that

author: A
sentence: It's not like a public programme where you can just sign up

author: A
sentence: You need to have developed quite a significant amount of director experience, because they're looking for people that can bring that to this programme as well, and that have a real understanding of what it is to be a director

author: A
sentence: And are ready to say 'okay I want to develop some new skills, I need to think about who I am'

author: A
sentence: With the mentoring programme, we're also more focussed now on developing people as directors I suppose as individuals

author: A
sentence: So, it's about them - some of the workshops we do are around the interpersonal, the active listening, navigating boardroom conflict, communicating effectively, what is power in the boardroom; that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, we’re looking at that because for us, we say it's really important to develop yourself as an individual, not just as a director

author: A
sentence: We're trying to do those with the mentoring programme

author: A
sentence: I think more and more will be doing more in this space in terms of the EQ side of it

author: A
sentence: I think gradually we'll be doing more in that space, because we know that it's really important to be an emotionally intelligent human being

author: Q
sentence: Oh brilliant, excellent

author: Q
sentence: That's good, we've navigated through the whole form now, so that's great

author: Q
sentence: I love it

author: Q
sentence: Let's go now, we'll start - the first question is, how have the composition of boards that you're familiar with, changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I'd say a lot of boards have become more diverse in terms of gender and I would say that's - some are starting to be more diverse in terms of backgrounds, like executive experience and that's due to the current environment

author: A
sentence: You see more directors with more understanding of digitisation, cyber security, marketing that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, I've seen that change in terms of where they're getting people

author: A
sentence: But in terms of - if I talk about the listed space, there's still - because of the nature of listed boards they're still looking for people that have had serious executive experience, meaning like line roles, P&L, ex CEOs, running significant parts of the business

author: A
sentence: So, I don't see that changing in the listed space and considering what listed boards have to do and the public oversight, I don't think that's a bad thing that they want people that have had line roles and P&L experience, that's fine

author: A
sentence: I think we're still at the starting point because we're stilling trying to get more women onto boards

author: A
sentence: To then move to other elements of diversity, people that think very differently, come at decisions with a very different lens, I don't think we'll see that happening for a few years yet

author: A
sentence: I think it's at the starting point

author: Q
sentence: So, the cognitive diversity aspect that is at the beginning?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: We're trying to do some work on cognitive diversity, some research which would be excellent

author: A
sentence: Some people understand that cognitive diversity is about your thinking styles and are quite across it

author: A
sentence: Some chairs are really insightful as to what that means and for them it's more about how can they measure it

author: A
sentence: So, I'd like to do some resources in terms of how do you understand that? how it plays out in the boardroom? But some do confuse cognitive diversity with your executive background, so you'll talk to them about it and they'll say, "Oh, yeah, well he's from the mining industry, and he's from financial services

author: A
sentence: " We'll say, "Yes, that does influence who you are, but that's not technically cognitive diversity

author: A
sentence: " I think in terms of boards but a lot of executive leadership teams, they are comprised of outcomes outputs focussed people

author: A
sentence: I think if we can start to talk about it more and educate boards more on that, I think it will change as well

author: A
sentence: They'll start to see that 'hang on, is it an issue that we've got seven people that are primarily outcomes focused? We probably need some different points of view here'

author: A
sentence: But again, that goes to the managing diversity and different points of view

author: Q
sentence: Exactly which is what we started off with!

author: A
sentence: Being frustrated with the process driven person or the person that's all about the evidence

author: A
sentence: So yes, then you have to do a piece on how do you manage that? How do you leverage that and take that on board? I think there's probably a number of directors are still concerned that having that will slow decisions down, slow the conversations down, and there's a lot of work for some boards to get through

author: A
sentence: It's a balance, it's a bit of a challenge

author: A
sentence: I suppose humanities because my Masters was in Museum Studies -

author: Q
sentence: These courses, the Boardroom Mastery and the Mentoring Programme, you'll be looking at cognitive managing, cognitive diversity and what that means [unclear] 00:16:31?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: They're more about looking - I suppose -

author: Q
sentence: EQ?

author: A
sentence: - yeah, that sort of aspect

author: A
sentence: The cognitive diversity, we've just had a lot of conversations and I'm hoping to do a bit of a literature review as to what's out there, understanding what directors understand of cognitive diversity, and then figuring out 'okay, we've done that literature review, we've got an understanding, what are the next steps?' Do we produce resources on boards? Do we do a diagnostic tool that boards can use to assess themselves? So, we're kind of at that starting point

author: A
sentence: There's been a lot of talk about it and we published a book by Juliet Bourke, 'Which Two Heads?' a couple of years ago which is an excellent book on this

author: Q
sentence: Juliet?

author: A
sentence: Juliet Bourke

author: A
sentence: So, she's -

author: Q
sentence: B-U-R-K-E?

author: A
sentence: B-O - yep, like Bourke Street

author: A
sentence: She is a partner at Deloitte so she wrote a book that we published and that's an excellent book

author: Q
sentence: And that's available?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, we sell that

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that's fantastic!

author: Q
sentence: Oh, perfect!

author: A
sentence: I'd think we'd sell it here but we sell it on our website

author: A
sentence: But she talks a lot about the thinking styles, decision making

author: A
sentence: Lots about the decision-making process and when we make best decisions, mental fatigue, that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: So, we'd like to do more work around that because that was a really excellent book

author: Q
sentence: I'll have a look at that, I haven't looked at that

author: Q
sentence: Do you promote that book - obviously through your organisation because you said it's on your website? Do you tag how many have been sold, what the uptake would have been?

author: A
sentence: I haven't looked at that recently, I can actually

author: A
sentence: I can talk to our Publisher - because that's been out for a couple of years now, so I can't remember when we launched it, it might have been 2016 even

author: A
sentence: But yeah, I could look into that

author: A
sentence: We've got really great feedback around it

author: Q
sentence: So, people are reading it?

author: A
sentence: Oh, yeah

author: A
sentence: Like I said, there's an understanding

author: A
sentence: Sometimes it's just how you engage with these sorts of things; that's hard

author: Q
sentence: Because I've been interviewing - obviously I've been interviewing a number of directors and younger directors - meaning in their 40s - I have noticed really a passion for working with difference and it's completed accepted as the norm

author: Q
sentence: It's not seen as a steep curve; it's seen as the norm and of course and why not! Even the way they perform an interview with me, the willingness to challenge and to whatever -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - rather than to be passive respondents, do you know what I mean?

author: A
sentence: Yeah!

author: A
sentence: - So yeah, a bit of change and shift getting to where I am now

author: A
sentence: but yeah, I more came from Communication Arts sort of background

author: Q
sentence: It just shows me a little bit of how they would be in the boardroom

author: A
sentence: I think it's exciting!

author: Q
sentence: It is exciting!

author: A
sentence: We’re getting there!

author: Q
sentence: I came out of those interviews on a high! It was so - it's interesting, qualitatively different

author: Q
sentence: They obviously really are quite passionate about working with difference

author: Q
sentence: You have it with what they would say, "To get good problem-solving

author: Q
sentence: " So that’s how they saw it

author: Q
sentence: So, they're not the typical though, I gather?

author: A
sentence: Well, not necessarily

author: A
sentence: It depends on the sectors

author: Q
sentence: Yes, these are start-ups

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Oh! start-ups? Amazing! They're coming from a very different point of view and business challenges and creativity

author: A
sentence: The start-ups space is very exciting

author: A
sentence: And it's hard too, because it's like a lot of things

author: A
sentence: You can't say it is generational change because I'd say, yeah like my generation, yes, we've grown up in quite a culturally diverse society, we understand the importance of difference

author: A
sentence: There's a lot of diversity and inclusion talk and leadership programmes and development

author: A
sentence: So, it'd be easy to say 'well once the older generation are not on these boards, things will change'

author: A
sentence: But I've actually met a lot - because we're really primarily on the listed space and I've met a lot of older directors who are really insightful, that are really humble, that are excited to learn, that are constantly trying to learn and engage

author: A
sentence: Which is really important I think as a director, because it's harder to see what's going on if you're out of your executive career for a long time

author: A
sentence: I wouldn't say that age is a barrier because some are very open

author: A
sentence: It's a personality thing and I suppose I see this in just the gender space in general

author: A
sentence: I meet some young guys that have got appalling views on gender and where women's role is, and the fact that they're missing out because of women now and their entitlement

author: A
sentence: So, I see it as attitudinal and it's not generational

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so do you think this could be measured and [screened?] 00:21:37

author: Q
sentence: That's great

author: Q
sentence: The organisation that you work - the Australian Institute of [inaudible] 00:00:52 Management, what does it primarily do?

author: A
sentence: Maybe! Maybe, yes

author: A
sentence: I suppose you could

author: A
sentence: So yeah, it’s hard because I think a lot of people have gone 'there used to be a thing of when all the dinosaurs die out' type thing and people would say that about climate change as well

author: A
sentence: It'll be all okay when this generation gives up power, but it won't be

author: A
sentence: Unless you're actively pushing it, working out different resources and arguments, prosecuting those arguments, a lot of influencing, we won't get there

author: Q
sentence: Oh nice

author: A
sentence: Because there's just too many young people that have got obnoxious views and they're in their 30s and 40s on this

author: A
sentence: I think a lot of it's an education point of view too

author: A
sentence: I think schooling - the way that schooling is structured in Australia has a lot to answer for

author: A
sentence: In terms of our single sex schools! That's all problematic

author: A
sentence: So yes, some really get it and unfortunately a lot still don't

author: A
sentence: Hence why you know if we did, we'd have equal numbers of young men doing flexible working as women, but they're not are they? So, they're not staying home to look after their kids

author: A
sentence: They're saying 'well if I do, I'll be punished workwise' and their bosses might only be in the 40s, they're not in their 60

author: A
sentence: So, there's - yeah, we've got a long way to go in Australia

author: Q
sentence: Are you familiar with other countries?

author: A
sentence: Yeah and in our work, we do we work with executive organisations and I'd say Australia is very patriarchal

author: Q
sentence: Oh! This is so interesting to hear that

author: A
sentence: I find it a bit depressing and I talk to people that have come to director recruiting in Asia and they'll say there's far more women in executive leadership roles than here

author: A
sentence: Yeah and of course that's nuance too in places like Japan, that's different

author: A
sentence: Europe is a bit different in the executive leadership, different in the UK, they really argue for executives to be on boards as well

author: A
sentence: Whereas here, it's not encouraged as much

author: A
sentence: There're all different nuances but I think we've got significant issues with the way that we see women in the workplace that we have to overcome

author: Q
sentence: I think I'm hearing a link between women in the workplace and then cognitive diversities, so the capacity to - because we want to be broader than gender diversity in this -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: -@ we want to consider -@ how do you see that connection between gender diversity and Say cognitive diversity and other kinds of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Good morning [participant]

author: Q
sentence: It’s very kind of you to participate in our research

author: Q
sentence: Thank you very much

author: Q
sentence: Can you first of all tell me, what sort of boards do you sit on, and for how many years have you been a board member?

author: A
sentence: Not greatly, to be honest

author: A
sentence: I mean, the boards I am on haven’t changed in terms of personnel in my experience actually, if I think about

author: A
sentence: DIG – there was a board in place at the time, then I was added to it in 2015

author: Q
sentence: It’s lovely

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular Board functions that diversity can really help with, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the obvious one is framing the service to meet the needs of that community

author: A
sentence: I don’t there’s any specific legal, accounting, IT or functional difference that I can think of, but at the coal face, when the service is designed and delivered, that’s where the rubber hits the road, I think, in terms of making sure that’s appropriate

author: A
sentence: And that’s – I think that’s fundamentally why we need to know what the needs of all of our segments of the community require

author: A
sentence: To design a service around them, for them

author: Q
sentence: What about, then, the cognitive diversity of the Board?  How might that help Board functioning?

author: A
sentence: I can’t think of an immediate example or a benefit

author: A
sentence: But I’m going back to thinking about projects – the way – my inclination is to think that the way we design and deliver a program, which is a project – that’s a project – might be influence by people who have modern approaches to delivering projects

author: A
sentence: A cognitive skill

author: A
sentence: But I can’t think of an example where I’ve seen that in action, and a direct link between the success of design and delivery of the program and the cognitive skills that were brought to the table to influence the design and delivery

author: A
sentence: I can’t think of one

author: Q
sentence: Some people think visually, other people – some people think process, some people think outcomes

author: Q
sentence: Some people think visually, and others think more –

author: A
sentence: Analytically

author: Q
sentence: - analytically

author: Q
sentence: and So, do you think that that kind of diversity can help board functioning or influence?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Of course

author: A
sentence: I think that if – we have to think about the way the service would be received by the community that’s it’s intended to serve

author: A
sentence: And if we do that without recognition of the community’s capacity to utilise the service, and make good of the service, then we would be deficient

author: Q
sentence: You’re thinking of the apple versus the – What about though, the actual decision making of the Board itself, and having people who think differently – problem solve differently?  Is that useful, do you think?  Can you think of an example where it’s been, perhaps, useful, or it’s been a problem?

author: A
sentence: I can’t even think of a particular decision that we’ve come to, that illustrated in the Board discussions, a differentiation in the cognitive approach

author: Q
sentence: How many women are on that, for example?

author: Q
sentence: The way people think

author: A
sentence: Which may mean it doesn’t exist

author: A
sentence: Potentially a problem, but we won’t know it’s a problem until we see it

author: A
sentence: Whether I think it diminished the quality of the decision we made – I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: But how would we know?

author: Q
sentence: What about group think?  Do you think you all think so alike that you’re really not thinking out of the square at all?

author: A
sentence: Oh, no

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: We’ve got – there’s people who come – who are on that Board, who have caring responsibilities, naturally, for kids and so on

author: A
sentence: So they bring a coal-face perspective to it

author: A
sentence: I’m not in that situation

author: A
sentence: Touch wood

author: A
sentence: But – so I bring a – maybe I’m the outlier, actually

author: A
sentence: I think there’s quite a number of people who have their genesis, either prior to being on the Board, or right now, in having a direct responsibility to care for someone, as well

author: A
sentence: So, maybe I represent some of the diversity that wasn’t there prior

author: A
sentence: Maybe

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: No-one’s said that to me, but as I think about it, as a person who doesn’t have specific responsibilities to care for someone, then I think I’m in the minority in the Board

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So do you think, when you – do you put forward views that might be at odds with people who -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: -@ are in a caring role

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And so, how is that received?

author: A
sentence: Well, to their great credit, okay

author: A
sentence: And that might bejust me, because I’ve got this honeymoon period

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure how long that goes, but I’ve got to say, when I speak, everyone shuts up, and it’s given me at least the opportunity to make my point

author: A
sentence: And I present arguments fairly forcefully, and with some reasoning and so on behind it

author: A
sentence: And certainly advise the CEO where I think I can see a problem emerging

author: A
sentence: I guess we’ve observed – in a practical sense, the funding arrangements for A NFP organisation are very stressful, because they are program based

author: A
sentence: They start, they stop

author: A
sentence: And as a consequence of that, we have a shifting workforce

author: A
sentence: Moves in, moves out

author: A
sentence: Delivers the program then moves out

author: A
sentence: Which is terribly disruptive for the Board

author: A
sentence: Not for the Board – it’s very, very disruptive for the organisation

author: A
sentence: None

author: A
sentence: None

author: A
sentence: So, the organisation has ticked along, and ticked along, and ticked along, and that’s just become part of the culture of the organisation

author: A
sentence: But it’s a disruptive part of the culture

author: A
sentence: So, that got an airing at the Board level, and we were rolling through the discussion on a “Well, that’s the way it is,” basis, and I said, “Well, that’s nuts, because you just – you’re completely wrenching your organisation every time money runs out, and we need to do a better job in finding more diverse revenue streams

author: A
sentence: So, that’s what we’re going to do

author: A
sentence: ”  So, we’ve now got a working parting within the Board to start thinking about supplementing government money, State and Federal, with commercial revenues

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So, was that dreamt up by people who were not from a caring background? Or what was the stimulus for that thinking outside the square?

author: A
sentence: Me

author: A
sentence: My observation -

author: Q
sentence: Because you said “Project one – abandon, then you lose all your staff

author: Q
sentence: ”  Yeah, so it’s your -

author: A
sentence: That’s a part and parcel the culture of the organisation, and I think we have to break that nexus because that’s – you know, if you always do what you’ve always done, you’ll always get what you always got

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: It’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So, maybe there was a bit of group think around that before you came

author: A
sentence: Maybe

author: A
sentence: Maybe

author: Q
sentence: And, so, no, it’s not a honeymoon period

author: A
sentence: Oh, no

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: You get – it’s three hours a month

author: A
sentence: A Board meeting

author: A
sentence: You get 300 pages to read in the week before

author: A
sentence: You go into the zone of thinking and reading, thinking about what you’re reading, and you’re taking notes about what you’re gleaning from the papers

author: A
sentence: Then you’re in the discussion that going through the Board papers, and it’s a microsecond of an opportunity to intervene and say something that gets everyone thinking and talking

author: A
sentence: That’s what it’s supposed to be like

author: A
sentence: And, the Chair gets upset, because we then lose the schedule, because we have an extended conversation, but that’s nothing

author: A
sentence: But at the end of the day, you’re passing a motion to do this, and so let’s see some management effort in this and this area, and away we go

author: Q
sentence: So, the chair – did the chair really get upset because the schedule was changed?  Or is it -

author: Q
sentence: No women

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Is this the start-up one?

author: A
sentence: Mildly

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: I shouldn't have even mentioned it

author: Q
sentence: There is a hefty agenda, though

author: A
sentence: Oh, there is

author: A
sentence: And there’s a neat three hours

author: A
sentence: We’ve all got obligations, of course, so we have to do it

author: Q
sentence: So, if you weren’t so forceful in your ability to assert your view, do you think that view wouldn’t have been heard?  Did you have to really push it?

author: A
sentence: I didn’t have to really push it, because I thought it was as plain as the nose on your face that this problem was perpetual, was damaging, and needed to change

author: Q
sentence: And could be

author: A
sentence: And could be

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well, I don’t know yet

author: A
sentence: We’ve got to do something, and management will come back to us over the next few months with some ideas

author: A
sentence: And we’ve seen some ideas, and we’ve had a subcommittee – sub-Board committee meeting to thrash out our approaches to raising external revenue

author: A
sentence: So

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Time will tell

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so, without diversity then, that thinking outside the square wouldn’t happen, so to be honest, I see that as an example of cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: You’ve come with your project management hat on and your business savvy, and brought that to this Board

author: Q
sentence: And it’s been a long-standing problem, suggesting there’s been group-think about it – we’ve always done it this way, this is how the world is

author: Q
sentence: So, a good example of how diversity can break through

author: Q
sentence: Now I’d like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on Boards

author: Q
sentence: So, you mentioned the agenda – people bringing - concern that people from particular demographic groups might bring political agendas – social/political agendas to the Board, and that doesn’t belong

author: Q
sentence: Can you – have you an example of that, or something you can -

author: A
sentence: No, not particularly

author: A
sentence: I actually think that the Carers Board is, at this point in time, looking balanced in so far as there’s a range of life experiences, there’s a range of commercial experiences, there’s a range of carer and non-carer experiences, and Scott’s actively dragging to the board the things that we need to attend to that are not within our domain of experience

author: Q
sentence: That’s the CEO

author: A
sentence: Yep, this is the start-up one

author: A
sentence: In terms of La Trobe University, I would image it is a 50-50 mix

author: A
sentence: In fact, it’s probably more – in fact I think it is, by recollection, more women on that Board

author: A
sentence: And then in A NFP organisation, it’s probably 60-40, men-women split

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: That says to me that we’ve got a reasonably balanced board, and we’re not missing the things that we should be attending to

author: A
sentence: Provided Scott keeps doing what he’s doing

author: A
sentence: And it’s only six months, so in my view, he is

author: A
sentence: Done well

author: Q
sentence: What about, perhaps, the other Boards you’ve experience on?  Have you any examples from there of where a political agenda might sort of disrupt?

author: A
sentence: The DIG Board is – we’re very focused on protecting shareholder wealth, so there’s people’s money on the line here

author: A
sentence: So, there’s a strong emphasis on prudent financial management, and in that circumstance, because the majority of the products inside DIG are software based - could be why I got involved in this – I was asked to be involved in this – they’ve leached a hell of a lot of money on really bad technology project planning

author: A
sentence: And bad relationships in that software development space

author: A
sentence: So, they were underdone in terms of their experience there, and you probably see it yourself – you get people talking about things they know nothing about, everyone piles on, and it becomes the conventional wisdom, when there is no wisdom in that at all

author: A
sentence: Because they haven’t got the diversity that they should have had when making that decision

author: A
sentence: So, the cognitive stuff within the DIG Board is really stark

author: A
sentence: There’s a capital raiser, a legal, the accountant comes along, I’m there for from IT, and the CEO

author: A
sentence: So, from a very small business, narrowly focused, we think we’ve got it covered

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: And you think there’s a bit of group-think there

author: A
sentence: Could be

author: A
sentence: Could be

author: Q
sentence: Is that a risk?  Because of that, or do you think it’s -

author: A
sentence: I just think – it’s a pretty small business, really, and we raise a lot of money, and we do a lot to develop the products

author: A
sentence: There’s only a couple of the products are revenue generating now – so they’re all pre-revenues, so they’re in various stages of marketing and testing and all the stuff that goes with bringing a product to market

author: A
sentence: So, I think we’ve got it okay

author: A
sentence: One of the things that I think we might be going to be found out on is having people who understand the automotive industry on the Board

author: A
sentence: So I can imaging that that might be an inclusion – well, certainly it might be a gap now

author: A
sentence: So, we’re making a product for the automotive industry, why wouldn’t we have someone from the automotive industry on the Board?  Good question

author: A
sentence: Good question

author: A
sentence: But we’ve got 10 products in the mix, and ones for real estate, ones for employment, ones – there’s a whole heap

author: A
sentence: Would you have any of those people strong in that industry on the Board?  Maybe not permanently, but this single product, which is our main focus, I think we need that

author: A
sentence: But my view might change if the real estate app was going to be a market leader, and so on – we’d need that skill

author: A
sentence: So, I think on that point, I’d make the distinction between on the Board and being a reference or a source to the Board

author: A
sentence: And, you know, I’ve heard of other Boards where there’s been a deficiency of – particularly in the ITC area – so they invite the IT guy to the Board to make a presentation about that

author: A
sentence: And that’s perfectly reasonable

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Definitely

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the technical aspects can be brought to the Board, just like the consumer aspects for the Carer organisation

author: Q
sentence: So, what about the style of thinking, though

author: Q
sentence: Some people are process thinkers, and others are outcome – you know – outcomes, outcomes, outcomes

author: Q
sentence: 40% women?

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: And so, is there a mix of that on this Board – the start up one –it’s called?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think there is actually

author: A
sentence: I think we’re all process thinkers, and I guess we rely on the fact that if you get a process, you will get the outcome that you’re looking for

author: A
sentence: So, if we do things logically, and systematically, then we’ll get the intent that we started with, as well

author: A
sentence: I mean, to a certain extent, we’re all a bit outcome oriented, in the sense that we’re asking Steven – the CEO in that context – what date is this going to happen, when is this going – all the time based questions, and the milestones and the likes – whilst I don’t think any of the Board have a particular bias to either a process mindset or an outcome mindset, there’s a mix of both

author: A
sentence: And I don’t think we’d even put a red had on the process thinkers or a green hat on the outcome thinkers because I couldn’t make that distinction anyway

author: Q
sentence: You juggle them

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: According to the situation

author: Q
sentence: Yeah?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: What about thinking outside the square, just like you did on the Carer Board – although it’s a square that you apply elsewhere – but to that it was a “outside the square

author: Q
sentence: ”  Do you have people who think outside the square on this small Board, or are you all very focused on -

author: A
sentence: I think that’s – we’re all just focused on the release of the products, and the process of getting products through the organisation and commercialising them

author: A
sentence: So, no I can’t point to any of us – there’s four of us, so, I can’t point to any of us who represent a radically diverse board

author: Q
sentence: Do you that could expose you to a loss of opportunity or exposure to risks – something you don’t see, or opportunities you don’t see?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And the president’s a woman, too

author: A
sentence: Definitely

author: A
sentence: But we won’t know

author: A
sentence: So, we’re blissfully ignorant

author: Q
sentence: So you don’t care

author: A
sentence: Our blissful ignorance will continue

author: Q
sentence: So, group think is a virtue in this situation

author: A
sentence: Well, could be

author: A
sentence: Could be

author: A
sentence: You know, it’s a risk as well, in the sense that you don’t know what you don’t know, and it only comes to your attention when something goes wrong, I suppose

author: Q
sentence: Well, you brought it to the attention of the Carers, because, probably, it sounds very likely something will come right because of this

author: Q
sentence: You know, a major risk for that organisation – HR and financial – is possibly going to be turned around

author: Q
sentence: At least it’s become the focus of a problem solving strategy, rather than just accepted

author: A
sentence: True

author: Q
sentence: So, there might be something similar in your small organisation, your small Board – opportunity loss, or whatever

author: Q
sentence: Do you think is – like, you’re very comfortable with the different things applying in different situations

author: Q
sentence: It might be because it’s a start up

author: Q
sentence: Can you help me understand?

author: A
sentence: Look, I think – in the absence of any other theories about it, I’ll put it down to being a completely different context

author: A
sentence: The context for a Board for a start up is very much about rational decision making, prudent use of finance, ambitious capital raising, and producing good products that the market needs

author: A
sentence: That you think the market needs

author: A
sentence: Out in carer-land, it’s about service provision with limited funds

author: A
sentence: Making the same thing I suppose – making the most of what we’ve got

author: A
sentence: Cutting our cloth according to the needs of the community and the size of our cloth

author: A
sentence: Various – very noticeable difference in risk management and governance, for A NFP organisation

author: A
sentence: As a start up, you have a bit of latitude

author: A
sentence: By very nature, you have to be brave, commercial, and ambitious

author: Q
sentence: And you’re unlisted, so there’s not those constraints

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well that’s good

author: Q
sentence: But in the start-up environment – that’s been your longest term – no change?

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: That’s true

author: A
sentence: On the A NFP organisation Board, there’s a strong emphasis on risk management, probity, governance, and these things are important

author: A
sentence: And as I reflect on the interview with Sue, the Chair, my governance and risk management training from this organisation – AICD – was, I think, part and parcel of what she wanted to do in strengthening the Board, on that aspect of it

author: A
sentence: So, on one hand, you see me advocating for diverse revenue streams, which is seen by the rest of the Board as pretty radical, but at the same time, I’m pretty strong on making sure that everything’s going to smell good, look good, and be good, from a risk management and governance perspective as well

author: A
sentence: Has to be

author: Q
sentence: So, it is the context that explains this difference

author: Q
sentence: And regulatory and social, really

author: Q
sentence: Because it’s a business risk, I presume

author: Q
sentence: If there’s a lack of governance and risk management in the Carer, you know -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Serious

author: Q
sentence: Whereas, okay – an IT product doesn’t sell

author: Q
sentence: You lost some money

author: A
sentence: Investors are affected, and the Board’s affected, but others, not necessarily

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve got other products, hopefully, that will keep your start up running

author: Q
sentence: So you’ve got four products, or whatever you said

author: A
sentence: So, in Carers, there’s 736,000 people have an active caring responsibility in Victoria

author: A
sentence: So that’s a lot of people who are looking to this organisation – a lot of them don’t know exist, however, but at the same time, those that do look to us for the policy settings, on our influence to government, but also look to us to be the creditable sound voice of their community

author: A
sentence: So, you don’t want to be mucking around that, because reputation is hard won and easily lost

author: A
sentence: So, I think we’ve got the settings pretty right in terms of our ambition, and what we say publicly and how we act

author: Q
sentence: Really good

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: That makes a lot of sense

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: It’s good that you’ve got both those hats, because you wouldn’t be able to compare them, and explain the difference

author: Q
sentence: It’s great

author: Q
sentence: Have you any examples of conflict on Boards?  In Board decision making – a conflict

author: A
sentence: The DIG Board can get a bit fractious at times

author: A
sentence: But it’s a personality thing

author: A
sentence: A couple of blokes there are having a crack at each other all the time

author: A
sentence: Not all the time, but sometimes

author: Q
sentence: Is that because they’re different – of diversity, or is it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, no change

sentence: Why’d you do that?  Why didn’t we know all this sort of stuff goes on?”  So, they’re being – I’m not the Chair – but there was a bit of ructions going off, so I got the management guy to get the hell out of the room, and invited Steven, his CEO, to bird him after the meeting, to settle him down

author: A
sentence: We want to hear the truth from management, and we mightn’t get the truth if we’re going to snap their heads off, every time we get a piece of truth that we don’t like

author: A
sentence: ”  So, we fixed that situation

author: A

sentence: But Steven’s the CEO, and the reality is that he’s a Director of the company, and a shareholder of the company, but he’s part of the management team

author: A
sentence: I’ve never thought it was appropriate for him to come when the CEO’s coming

author: A
sentence: Unless he had a specific project update, I thought he would be an invited guest in and out

author: A
sentence: So, to see him turning up for meetings, since 2015, to all of them, I wasn’t happy about that anyway

author: A
sentence: Because you do want to speak candidly to the CEO about things

author: A
sentence: So, anyway, once they had that fractious – Liam hasn’t been back, and I think it’s been to the benefit of the Board effectiveness

sentence: Do you think the Chair might have said something to -

sentence: He might have

author: A
sentence: He didn’t say so

author: A
sentence: But when I booted him out of the meeting, and in fairness to Liam, I said get out of the meeting, but if you want to come back in, you’ll come back in on an apology and you’ll settle down

author: A
sentence: So, he did that

author: A
sentence: He came back an hour later – half an hour later – and said “Okay, sorry about that

author: A
sentence: We’ll get on with it

author: A
sentence: ”  But he hasn’t come to subsequent meetings, so that might mean that the Chair or Steven, the CEO, has said “You’re just noise, so stay out

sentence: And if you’ve got things to say, I’ll represent them for you

sentence: ”  It’s good

author: Q
sentence: Do the Boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to managing or building diversity, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: One Board won’t diversify because it’s just got four

author: A
sentence: And we’re only – it’s just the size the business

author: A
sentence: I think the diversity of the Board will change if the organisation is listed

author: A
sentence: So I think this organisation will be tucked into another ASX listed company in the next 12 to 18 months, and I think that’ll be good, because that will bring capital from a broader range of Mum and Dad shareholders and institutional shareholders

author: A
sentence: But it will also mean new people come onto the Board, and the biggest shareholders will want a seat at the Board

author: A
sentence: Then, as I said earlier, there are some people on the Board who have no appetite for being on an ASX Board

author: A
sentence: For myself – don’t know- never been on an ASX Board, so it might be interesting to have a crack

author: A
sentence: And then – and I think what I’m trying to do with the Board, even at its current state, of being small and private, is to get them onto the footing of being ready for ASX obligations

author: A
sentence: So, your transparency, your regular update of changes of shareholder interests, and all that sort of stuff is all formalities you’ve got to go through

author: A
sentence: And the risk management of something going wrong, and how to manage crises, and the like

author: A
sentence: Will be all important things to learn

author: A
sentence: So maybe we’ll recruit for those skills

author: A
sentence: If we don’t, we’ll all have to learn them
