sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: And quickly

author: A
sentence: And quickly

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so finally, [participant], looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian Boards, and maybe think about this start up space, and also the established sort of service space

author: A
sentence: I think the start up I can’t see change

author: A
sentence: I think it has the inventor of your product, the one with the most passion about the product is always going to be there

author: A
sentence: And they will surround themselves with the people they think that can take that product or service to market

author: A
sentence: So, you know, if that’s a product that’s pitched to the Greek community, then yes, there will be Greeks on the Board

author: A
sentence: I would imagine

author: A
sentence: But in the absence of a specific cultural target, or LGBTI target, or focus on women, or – that will always represent the community in a very precise way on a start up Board

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, how important do you think it is, to have a diverse board?  That’s say, one is not important at all, and 10 is extremely important?

author: A
sentence: In terms of diversity for the likes of A NFP organisation, it will always have – and should have – people who have care and responsibilities

author: A
sentence: So, that’s where you really get the insight you need from the consumer perspective, if you like

author: A
sentence: I think it will always have a range of different functional skills, because the business in itself has a finance piece, an IT piece, accounting, a legal piece, and all the traditional functions of an organisation – HR piece – will always be represented in some – in varying degrees, I’m sure

author: A
sentence: I think just the natural evolution of time will bring the gender stuff into balance

author: Q
sentence: You don’t think quotas or targets will have a – like, they’re pretty big at the moment

author: A
sentence: No, I haven’t thought deeply about it, but I think – I look at the women on the Board, and they’re fantastic

author: A
sentence: They don’t need quotas

author: A
sentence: They’re there because they know what they’re doing

author: A
sentence: And I strongly admire them

author: A
sentence: So, personally I’m not big on quotas

author: A
sentence: I think it’s merit

author: A
sentence: If we over cook quotas, then the blokes will be looking for quotas too

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, affirmative action is not fair

author: A
sentence: You just want the best people, you know

author: A
sentence: I think I’d rather see us increase the size of a Board in order to accommodate a more diverse population, than to specifically exit someone in order to create a spot for someone else

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that the Boards will be bigger in the future then?

author: A
sentence: No, well, I think this

author: A
sentence: I think that there will be almost a European style approach, where there will be a management Board, and a Board Board, if you like – a traditional one

author: A
sentence: So, there’s – this is a – global European organisations have that multiple Boards

author: A
sentence: I haven’t studied it in great detail

author: A
sentence: I’ve got some clients who that arrangement and it’s a point of interest, based on my own Board work

author: A
sentence: But they talk glowingly of it as being quite effective

author: Q
sentence: In what way is it effective?

sentence: I think it produces – the evidence is that it produces better company results

author: A
sentence: I think people – the PWCs and KPMGs have studied the effective performance of European companies with – I can’t remember what it’s called

author: A
sentence: I think it’s called just a complementary Board

author: A
sentence: But it has a different purpose, but it’s like two Boards working concurrently

author: Q
sentence: At different levels – one’s at executive management level is it? And ones at -

author: A
sentence: Oh, I think it’s eight or nine, for sure

author: A
sentence: Could be

author: A
sentence: Could be

author: A
sentence: Not sure

author: A
sentence: I need to study this more

author: A
sentence: And that’s why I can’t talk too strongly about it, because that would be silly

author: A
sentence: But the clients that I have that have had that arrangement, speak well of it, as a positive contribution to the overall effectiveness of the organisation

author: A
sentence: And they have pointed me to research by others that sort of demonstrates that it does lead to some over-achievement, by comparison, to other organisations without the double Board

author: Q
sentence: Wonder if it accommodates more diversity?

sentence: Yeah

sentence: It would be interesting

author: A
sentence: In DIG, it’s very much an organisation centred on building technology products for, in the main, a male market

author: A
sentence: It’s an automotive product

author: Q
sentence: Okay

sentence: And you came from manufacturing?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, the principal product inside DIG is an automotive product, and it’s targeted at automotive dealerships, and for the market, the owners and the franchisees of those dealerships, typically, are male

author: A
sentence: But I don’t think that’s a deliberate connection

author: A
sentence: I just think it’s a small company

author: A
sentence: There’s only four of us on that Board, and we’re all hand-picked, I think, for a range of skills sets – legal, capital raising, self-ICT, and the CEO, of course, has the CEO role

author: A
sentence: So, that explains why, I think, to a certain extent, that explains why there isn’t one or two women on the board

sentence: And I would think, that as that business matures, and becomes potentially a listed company, then that would change, I would think

author: Q
sentence: Why?

sentence: Because we’ll need a new skill-set, for it to become a listed company

author: A
sentence: I would imagine that at least some of that board, possibly even myself, would bow out, because we didn’t have the skill-set required to run an ASX-listed company

author: A
sentence: And at that time, because we would then have a more public face, and a larger face to the community, I think it would be prudent to be balanced against the community

author: Q
sentence: Okay

sentence: So, it’s really reflecting the community, and the market, as well, that you think

author: Q

author: A
sentence: Not so important

author: A
sentence: Not lost

author: A
sentence: We’re – particularly around the Carers, the Board is learning that there are minorities that have a voice and need to be heard

author: A
sentence: And we’re making proactive efforts to educate ourselves on the LGBTI community, for instance

author: A
sentence: And hearing their stories of discrimination, and the like, but whether that translates into Board roles, I’m not sure I see the connection

author: Q
sentence: So, how did the Board hear about their perspective?

author: A
sentence: The CEO - there is a community of carers, in that instance, that are from the LGBTI community, and I think there was a perception within the organisation that our service catalogue was addressing carers as a global group, but not necessarily addressing the specifics of care for different segments of the community

author: A
sentence: So, once we’d agreed that that was a problem, we needed to find ways to resolve it, and the starting point for us – and this is a journey that they’ve been on before I joined, so I’m picking up on – not the end of it, but part-way through – we needed to understand that LGBTIQ community better than we did, and that’ll allow us to reframe – not reframe – compliment the existing service catalogue with services that are specific to that community, or at least respectful of that community, so that they can buy in to the general set of services that we offer

author: Q
sentence: Do you have – I’m thinking – do you have, say people from Muslim background, or Jewish background or other backgrounds where food, and perhaps practices around death and dying might vary?  Do you think, if that’s the case, does this rely on coming from Carers at the point of service who may not be sensitive to this?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So there's a block?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: I think we’ve either started our work, or we’re well into our work – I’m not sure – in terms of understanding the cultural diversity

author: A
sentence: I think we have specific services targeted to the Greek community, the Italian community, and I guess some of the traditional communities that built Australia through post-war Australia

author: A
sentence: Whether we’ve groomed our service catalogue to a particular religion, I don’t think we do that, actually

author: A
sentence: We’re more focused on the cultural background of people, which could potentially mop up the religious diversity as well

author: A
sentence: So, we’re sort of, I think, probably part-way through that journey, in so far as – I’m not sure, I can’t think of a specifically adjusted service that we would offer to the Indian community, or the Iraqi community, or what have you, which would typically be of the Muslim faith

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, if I’m understanding, the cultural diversity – because you’re seeing diversity as serving a community and consumers from this particular Board, then you’re seeing it really as an operational role to identify the service offerings that are needed – the gaps – and the Board would then support that

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: So, having cultural diversity represented on the Board is not therefore important

author: A
sentence: In my view, I’d agree with that

author: A
sentence: That doesn’t mean we’re ignorant of it

author: A
sentence: We’re sensitive to it, but we do rely on management and executive to bring it to our attention

author: A
sentence: And then, of course, there are circumstances where the Board itself brings specific insights to a community that has escaped the notice of management, and therefore that gets specifically documented on minutes, and then the management is sent off to research the needs for that particular community

author: A
sentence: So, I wouldn’t say we totally rely on the management team to bring us those unseen parts of that community that we should support

author: A
sentence: So, it’s sort of a mixed effort, but in terms of the LGBTI community, I think that one had its genesis from the management team

author: Q
sentence: So, from a strategy point of view, then, it’s – you’re accommodating what feeds up to the Board, whether – do you look at complaints?  Do you look at -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: You have that information provided to you on which to base strategy

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: And so, that’s three

author: Q
sentence: And across sectors

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: And your background is?

author: A
sentence: Yes, sort of a qualitative perspective, one of the things that’s in the Board package – is 300 pages – one of the first ones is a carer’s story

author: A
sentence: And it’s often a story – not often – it is a mix – they mix them up for us

author: A
sentence: They give us a story that is positive about that particular carer’s response to A NFP organisation, and then we get some of the war stories from the Help Desk, and the Service Desk, Customer Service, that says “We let this person down in the following ways,” and so on, and so forth

author: A
sentence: So, behind all that’s a database, capturing information we need, and we subsequently get reports to the Board of our general performance and gaps in the service that we need to address

author: Q
sentence: Good, excellent

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think there is any situation – you’ve rated diversity as 9, in terms of importance – do you think there is any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: Not at this stage

author: A
sentence: I think that whether that rating’s going to be reflected on the cross-section of people we have on the Boards – I doubt it

author: A
sentence: I think, we as a Board – well, I can’t speak for them – but my own perspective is that, what is a good thing that a community is represented in the activities of the organisation, whether that translates into Board positions for what we would otherwise see as minority groups, I doubt it because -

author: Q
sentence: Why is that?

author: A
sentence: I think because I think the focus is too narrow

author: A
sentence: I mean, Boards are looking for a broad range of experience, and if you’re coming to a Board with a specific agenda item, so to speak, then your capacity to engage effectively in the broader responsibilities of the Board, I think is somewhat compromised

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good point

author: Q
sentence: Can we explore that a little more?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s fine

author: A
sentence: Well, it’s on there – I’m on the Board because I bring an ICT perspective from a strategic one, but my background, as you’ve noted, is pretty diverse

author: A
sentence: I’m really old – and wise – with years comes wisdom, as you know, and you spend a lot of time observing, and this all stacks towards your experience

author: A
sentence: And so, the corollary of that, of course, is that if you’ve got a fixed agenda item that you want the Board to recognise and represent effectively, then there’s other ways to do it, as opposed to being on the Board, and if that’s your narrow focus, then I think that’s, in some respects, a bit of a distraction to the Board

author: A
sentence: I think, as a Board, we all leave our specific – perhaps we don’t

author: A
sentence: I was going to say we leave our specific agenda items at the door

author: A
sentence: But yes, we bring them, but we bring them with a balance to the broader need of the community

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So there’s a concern about agenda politics disrupting the Board functioning -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: and So you’re linking diversity with that risk of agenda politics, are you?  So, why do you rate it as a nine, as important, then, given that risk?

author: A
sentence: A variety of backgrounds

author: A
sentence: So, originally a farmer, and into manufacturing

author: A
sentence: So, spent a lot of time in regional Victoria running manufacturing plants

author: A
sentence: And then managed IT services – formed a business in the late 90s and did that for 15 years, and just built that to a point where I sold it – subsequently sold it

author: A
sentence: And then since 2014 I’ve been doing a range of things

author: A
sentence: Property development, Board directorships, and running Mullins Advisories, which is a boutique ICT consulting business

author: A
sentence: Because the – yes – so you’re saying that having the diversity on the Board -

author: Q
sentence: So, diverse Boards are important – do you think diverse Boards are important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And we’ve got nine

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well, I’ve got a feeling I might walk back from that a little bit now

author: Q
sentence: You can

author: Q
sentence: Happy

author: A
sentence: In the context, I was focused on the female-male diversity aspect

author: A
sentence: And now we’re drilling into the broader definition aspect of diversity

author: Q
sentence: That’s fine

author: Q
sentence: So the male-female nine

author: Q
sentence: So that’s gender

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But cultural, will we call it cultural -

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Nice mix

author: Q
sentence: So, let’s start by saying, first of all, we’re interested in talking to people who work on Boards or organisations that influence Boards, about diversity

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of research and information out there, but what we want is an Australian perspective, taken from the ground up

author: Q
sentence: So, that’s the point of the research

author: A
sentence: Social

author: Q
sentence: Social diversity

author: Q
sentence: You’ll give it a different rating?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: Yeah, back to say, four of five, with the only cavitate being that so long as the interests of that diverse group are represented by the Board

author: A
sentence: So, that’s why I’m making that point, that I don’t think there’s a need – certainly it hasn’t been my view that the Board has underdone a particular aspect of its deliberations because of a lack of representation on the Board, provided those other things in place

author: A
sentence: That you’ve got a Board that’s aware of the diverse populations that it works with, and that you’ve got an active management team that is focused in on the customer facing aspects of what we do, with a view to bringing those issues to the Board’s attention

author: Q
sentence: That’s really good

author: Q
sentence: So, that’s nice and clear as well

author: Q
sentence: So, thank you

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: So, let’s then now say, what does Board diversity mean to you?  Is it demographics, you’ve got gender, but then you’ve talked about ethnicity, social – age – you brought that in as well, because it’s liked with experience

author: A
sentence: Skill

author: Q
sentence: Skill – yep, functional

author: Q
sentence: What about knowledge, under – you -

author: A
sentence: Skill, experience, people’s knowledge

author: Q
sentence: And inside and outside knowledge

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Like knowing the industry, not knowing the industry

author: Q
sentence: What about cognitive diversity?  And that’s like approaches to problem solving, ways of thinking, ways of understanding?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that kind of diversity is -

author: A
sentence: I do

author: Q
sentence: @ relevant?

author: A
sentence: I do, actually, yeah

author: A
sentence: Because not all of our experiences reflect a modern approach, so I think that – if I think about project management from an ICT perspective, the way we’ve approached projects over the last 20 years has changed, dramatically

author: A
sentence: And for the better

author: A
sentence: So, I think it is important, again do we want a project management expert who is expert – experienced in today’s approach to project management?  I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: But we want to know via the Board, or via management, I was saying previously, that there is a new way of dealing with projects, and we ought to be considering this approach

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it seems to me that there’s a really important – that the Board needs to be open to other perspectives

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Agree, agree

author: A
sentence: Crazy not to

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so that being inclusive is a key feature of a well functioning Board, then
