sentence: So, inclusivity

author: Q
sentence: This is good

author: Q
sentence: So, cognitive diversity, if we think about that, would you rate that with gender, or would you put it with the demographics – you know, the social, cultural?

author: A
sentence: Probably the former

author: Q
sentence: With gender

author: Q
sentence: So, nine

author: Q
sentence: So cognitive diversity it high

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, it’s good

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve explained why

author: Q
sentence: You see representation being an appropriate alternative to having people from different cultural, social backgrounds on Boards in the context of your Boards that you’re talking about, however, cognitive diversity and gender diversity are really important

author: Q
sentence: And now we’re going to talk about – we’ve got that – so, now we’ll talk about Board functioning, and you’ve mentioned the importance of the Board being open and inclusive

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk to me about that?  How does diversity influence Board functioning?  That ability to be open and inclusive?

author: A
sentence: I just think it’s baseline obligation for Board members to have that perspective

author: A
sentence: I just don’t think you can operate in a traditional way and you know, I’ve got to say it’s exposure of the Carers Vic Board for me, has been enlightening, in the sense that I’ve had no appreciation of the culturally diverse - Anglo-Saxon white male – the bane of life – you know, within your own cultural circle you mix with people who are of your own sort of making, if you like, so, to stroll into the A NFP organisation Board and see the diversity of people who are impacted by the need to provide care to their loved ones

author: A
sentence: And we’re talking about Carers Vic representing the unpaid carers who look after aging parents, disabled children, people afflicted with disease and cancer, and so on and so forth

author: A
sentence: So, there’s a great amount of love in that and everyone’s capable of love, and I see it in action

author: A
sentence: These people giving up their life for other people so they can have a reasonable quality of life

author: A
sentence: I think the other key point is to be open to what might be needed

author: A
sentence: And in personal service, that’s been an awakening for me too

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve had very little exposure to minority groups who – LGBTI communities, certain cultural communities having their specific needs, but that’s becoming more and more a part of my thinking, and I’m sure my colleagues would agree

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: I’m hearing something like a transformation in yourself, to not only – including a feeling like you belong, in a way -

author: A
sentence: Well, you have to

author: A
sentence: If it’s a baseline skill, I can’t sit on a Board, and say that the needs of the Italian community don’t matter

author: A
sentence: They matter to them

author: A
sentence: And I’m supposed to be representing everyone’s interests

author: A
sentence: Pleasure

author: Q
sentence: And then another – and that’s two others for - are they in the same industry?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: You would do that, yeah?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: One suggestion I did make in terms of a board I was on was we actually went to the community looking for directors and we got more than we needed and I said ‘Well, look, to build a pipeline of directors perhaps put them on one of our committees which is a much safer way of building that confidence and that knowledge

author: A
sentence: If they have thosediscernible skills or desire to contribute, and their attitude is right, they will develop

author: A
sentence: So with this organisation I have quite a large board, that I give each new boardmember an induction where I spend a certain amount of time with them to take themthrough the organisation’sstrategy and explain their director’s duties to them

author: A
sentence: Another way of building capability is having someone go on as an alternate for someone else

author: Q
sentence: An ultimate?

author: A
sentence: Alternate

author: Q
sentence: Oh alternate, yeah

author: A
sentence: I saw that happen at a previousorganisation that I was at that, the CEO was on another board, a quite well known board, and he was able to appoint an alternate director and he appointed a young female under the age of 30

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: A
sentence: They’re all not-for-profits

author: A
sentence: One is in the allied health services space, one is new economy related, and I’m also on the board of this organisation which is an industry association

author: A
sentence: Yeah, nominated her to be his alternate

author: Q
sentence: Great opportunity

author: A
sentence: So it was a great opportunity for her

author: A
sentence: So she got exposure to the operations of a board without necessarily having the -

author: Q
sentence: The responsibilities, yeah, legal

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that’s an interesting way

author: Q
sentence: And was the – could they both be there at the same time so coaching could occur?

author: A
sentence: Sometimes, yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: I know with this particular board that, related to the company I’m CEO of, I encourage directors to appoint or nominate alternates that we can accept and bring them along

author: Q
sentence: No-one's brought that idea up

author: Q
sentence: That is a great way for cultivating your pipeline

author: A
sentence: That’s a great idea

author: Q
sentence: So it’s intriguing that it hasn’t come up

author: Q
sentence: Is it a sort of not-for-profit process do you think, or would the ASX listed companies, would they have a problem with that? Or is it just -

author: A
sentence: I don’t think they would have a problem with that

author: A
sentence: I’m sure that that is practice in some of the ASX companies

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay, I mean the sample is not huge

author: Q
sentence: But it’s great, and I’ll look up some research on it too, alternates

author: Q
sentence: Great, excellent

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s quite a period of time to reflect back and I’d like you to do that as we’re going, say oh well look, when I first started on boards 11 years ago it was like this, but now it’s like that

author: Q
sentence: That’s really useful

author: A
sentence: When I was in resources as well as part of the piece to elevate the number of female directors we devised a scholarship program for them where we’d pay for them to do the company directors course

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, because that’s quite expensive

author: Q
sentence: Like, the Australian Institute of Company Directors, I’ve talked to them and it’s quite pricey

author: A
sentence: Seven grand or something

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and there’s other courses

author: Q
sentence: Like, that’s the basic one I think

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: It’s incredible but they got a lot out of it and we actually get some of the big mining companies to sponsor those women to do the course

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that’s great

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So that was a way to – because I talked to someone who was an advocate for female engineers to get on boards and she was saying how the pipeline, meaning management, she was referring to management because she’s in the industry, getting women to executivepositions was such a – there were so many barriers

author: Q
sentence: So bringing women along that way she saw as a real – and it was becoming more problematic

author: Q
sentence: She said there are less women in the management pipeline now, that was her view, than in the past, and so I thought oh, that’s a problem

author: A
sentence: That is a problem

author: Q
sentence: But there’s other ways you can get women on

author: Q
sentence: So the companies support women to get on the board perhaps as an accountant or a lawyer, is that the sort of thing?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I’d like to do that

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, brilliant

author: A
sentence: Big issue in mining is there is a certain cohort of - a fairly sizeable cohort of people in the management ranks who are engineers or geologists, and as you know that calibrates into board ranks

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: But I did some work on that, did a study on it when I was in resources, and the problem in resources, and to a lesser extent manufacturing, is that it starts at like the age of three where – there’s two things, girls aren’t encouraged into those occupations by parents -

author: Q
sentence: And play

author: A
sentence: And play

author: A
sentence: They’ve actually done studies of boys building things and girls building things,and the boys build the building or the truck or whatever quicker but they don’t do as good a job as the women, or the girls

author: A
sentence: But culturally we reward the boys for doing more in terms of volume but don’t reward the girls in terms of the finished -

author: Q
sentence: Quality perhaps

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Or innovation

author: Q
sentence: Yes, because not everyone can do that so that’s great

author: Q
sentence: So you sit on three and that’d be the total, yep?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, this comes into cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: Someone has – have you – this term, are you familiar with this term?

author: A
sentence: I’m not familiar with it, no

author: Q
sentence: Well, it’s different approaches to problem solving, so it’s a kind of diversity that some people are very interested in that’s labelled that

author: Q
sentence: But someone defined it as – or understood it as process versus outcomes, decision making

author: Q
sentence: So some people focus on the outcomes and then reward the number of trucks, and other people are more onto the process

author: Q
sentence: How well was it done, blah blah blah? So that’s an example of two different kinds of cognitive diversity from this person’s point of view, and it fits

author: A
sentence: That’s fascinating

author: Q
sentence: So in this example it’s gendered, but not all of it’s gendered is my understanding

author: Q
sentence: So some people are seeing that as very important in understanding good problem solving, which you talked about in terms of different – avoiding groupthink and having different skills and backgrounds and different points of view, and so cognitive diversity is taking it just that one little bit deeper and saying how you think about problems, and problem solving

author: A
sentence: And it’s stepping back a bit rather than -

author: Q
sentence: But you don’t want everyone to step back too much

author: A
sentence: No, no

author: Q
sentence: You’ll never get an outcome

author: A
sentence: Mmm

author: A
sentence: No, no

author: A
sentence: I think as the manager or decision-maker if you step back and think of what quality actually is,I think that’s quite key

author: A
sentence: And they’ve  actually done  - resources seems to have done studies in certain occupation categories, and the most famous one is truck drivers, and they worked out that the women truck drivers were a lot better than the men

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Isn’t that against the stereotype?

author: A
sentence: It is, it is against the stereotype

author: A
sentence: It’s incredible, and they modelled it financially too in that the women are much safer so there’s less OH&S risk and accidents resulting

author: Q
sentence: Liability

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And they’re easier on the equipment so there’s less maintenance costs

author: A
sentence: So the number of women driving miningtrucks is actually above the all mining female participation average as a result

author: Q
sentence: Wow, a disproportionate number of women are driving trucks

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Wow, that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: And they’re all not-for-profits? So first how has the composition of boards that you’re familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: You see that’s not in the newspapers

author: A
sentence: It’s not, it’s not, but it should be

author: Q
sentence: But I think it’s interesting -

author: A
sentence: Oh it’s fascinating

author: Q
sentence: -@ because it just shows that in a stereotypically male-dominated field Women can thrive, and that would be useful for the – you were talking about the role of media, regulators, media and social expectations, Well here’s an opportunity to modify social expectations

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely, and it’s all been costed and proved financially

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so I’d love that study

author: Q
sentence: Do you – can you give me enough for me to find it?

author: A
sentence: I’ll email you a link

author: Q
sentence: Oh that would be great, okay

author: Q
sentence: Do I need to prompt you or are you reliable with – is this good?

author: A
sentence: I think the biggest change has been the move from representative-type boards to skills-based boards

author: A
sentence: I’m reasonably reliable but if you don’t get it within two days  -

author: Q
sentence: So I’ll put truck driver research, that will be enough to prompt you no doubt

author: Q
sentence: So on Tuesday if I don’t get it

author: A
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Okay, we want to understand how diversity influences board functioning now so let’s move to that

author: Q
sentence: You’ve talked a little bit about it, but we’ll go a bit deeper

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that diversity can really help with? And can you give me an example, another one maybe? You gave me that good one

author: A
sentence: I think around strategy, particularly customer acquisition and retention

author: A
sentence: I think having female perspectives is very helpful from that point of view

author: Q
sentence: Yep, so females for relations?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Yep, and other kinds of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think around decision-making, and particularly empathetic decision-making

author: A
sentence: A female board member said ‘Well, what are the implications of actually doing that in terms of supporting the community, and the bigger picture?’

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: And risk to your image

author: Q
sentence: So when did that change happen?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: The image of the company

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Reputational risk

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: So it might on paper make you X hundred thousand dollars but could cost you more if you -

author: Q
sentence: And over a long time

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So other kinds of diversity apart from gender, like the way you talk about to avoid groupthink -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So how groupthink was limited because of diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s been a gradual change over the last decade as directors’ duties have become more onerous

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and particularly around situations regarding risk

author: Q
sentence: So really you’re like the other directors that have talked about that

author: Q
sentence: You’ve given me that example so unless you can think of another one that you’d like to give, the earlier one on risk

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Maybe the one about the environmental issues because that was a -

author: Q
sentence: Reputational risk

author: A
sentence: -@ reputational risk issue

author: Q
sentence: So do you think there are some functions of the board that diversity has little bearing on? You know, it’s just irrelevant to?

author: A
sentence: Only to the extent that every person is different and often with handling situations, particularly say board management relations, that’s more of a skill that’s personally inherent rather than gendered

author: Q
sentence: Okay, yeah, but we’re not just talking about gender diversity, we’re talking about – so EQ, having that distributed across -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s an EQ issue

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so that’s a type of diversity I guess

author: Q
sentence: - on board diversity

author: Q
sentence: As you know, there’s a lot of information out there on diversity of boards but what we’re particularly interested in is an Australian perspective, so we’re talking to Australian board members and organisations that influence Australian boards to get that ground – on the ground sort of experience, and we’re interested to understand how people think about diversity and also how it’s managed -

author: Q
sentence: So over the past decade?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So even if we’re talking about the accounts, like one person said that all those reports, the financial and governance - she was talking in a health context - clinical governance, those sort of reports, that’s all - the experts can present the reports, they’re facts, but we just – so the board comes in and diversity comes in in discussing how to make sense of it and what to do

author: Q
sentence: But I wonder, because you said society’s changed now and we don’t think that people who are experts shouldn’t be questioned, and so the diverse board will question these facts as presented

author: Q
sentence: Is that something – would you see that diversity even in accepting the finances and whatever, how it’s presented, what’s presented as fact, that a diverse board has a role in that? Or is that an area where oh, it doesn’t matter

author: A
sentence: Oh, it does have a role in that and that’s how those facts are received, interpreted, and accepted or not accepted

author: A
sentence: I think diversity is important there

author: A
sentence: I think from the point of view of individuals skillsets like the analytical skills, reading figures or interpretative skills, those skillsets that are inherent in an individual, I think that’s more individually-based than based on someone’s identity

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, gender, cultural background, even experience

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: Because I think that those things, that’s purely individual knowledge and experience coming to the fore

author: Q
sentence: So when you select people for a board do you select them based on those individual characteristics as well as obviously the gender and the social cultural and the educational?

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a strong element of that

author: A
sentence: But having a mind to diversity is also important, and I think there’d be something wrong if you said ‘Well look, gee we need 10 board members, we need them to exhibit all these skillsets’ and you chose 10 blokes or 10 women

author: A
sentence: I think something is wrong with that picture

author: Q
sentence: Yes, there’s some unconscious filter going on there

author: A
sentence: The unconscious bias -

author: Q
sentence: Is showing, yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: There have been a number of corporate collapses over the last 10 to 15 years and it’s come back to what have the directors done? So directorship has become less of a club or a – we’ll put this person on because they represent X or Y in terms of stakeholders, but we need to have a certain amount of expertise on the board to ensure the governance is appropriate

author: A
sentence: - comes through So you have to be aware of that

author: A
sentence: I don’t – I think saying ‘Well gee, you need five men and five women’ is Probably over-prescriptive, but you need a substantial number of both I believe, a critical mass of both

author: A
sentence: So you might have a board with seven Women and three men, So what? as long as there is that balance in some way or another

author: Q
sentence: The critical mass you were talking about earlier -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: - which is really important for gender but not important for all types of diversity

author: Q
sentence: but possibly for cultural, the Aboriginal cultural, you gave that example that there needed to be more than one

author: A
sentence: Yeah, certainly at a workforce level you need critical mass I’ve found

author: Q
sentence: And is that a percentage? Can we say it’s 30%, or the target?

author: A
sentence: The accepted percentage I think on boards is, particularly for gender, is around 30%

author: A
sentence: Workforce we’ve – in resources we thought say with indigenous and with females it needed to be around between 15 and 25 to actually establish that [benchhead] 00:50:42 from which you could necessarily build more

author: Q
sentence: Did you use that as a target in the industry? Was that across the industry?

author: A
sentence: No, no, each company had its own target, and I philosophically have issues with mandated quotas because I think they’re artificial and I think companies need to have the flexibility to choose what’s -appropriate for their operations and what’s not

author: A
sentence: My belief is it’s a bit like unions saying I want to be on the board, or I want X% of the company industrial democracy et cetera

author: A
sentence: Well if you want that, same with government, you share the corporate risk if you want to start mandating decisions

author: Q
sentence: So conflict, now we’re talking - I’ll do the process of conflict, and then the last question I think

author: Q
sentence: No, I’ll do this one

author: Q
sentence: We’ll do selection process

author: Q
sentence: So do people outside the board, or organisations outside the board, influence the selection process for new board members?

author: Q
sentence: So has this sort of followed from the global financial crisis, so more recently then has the – I know it’s not quite your sector, but the Haynes report, is that influencing the kinds of skills that boards understand are key to governance?

author: A
sentence: Depends on the board itself

author: A
sentence: If it’s a representative board the member organisation would have an influence

author: A
sentence: They might make the appointment, or make the nomination for the board to – or in making the appointment

author: A
sentence: There might be external consultants that are used

author: Q
sentence: Yep, the head-hunters -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - and recruitment services, yeah?

author: A
sentence: There are organisations like Women on Boards that have lists of availablefemale directors

author: A
sentence: They’re often consulted

author: A
sentence: There are women in industry groups that are consulted

author: A
sentence: There is Women in Super or Women in Mining or -

author: Q
sentence: Right, okay, yep

author: A
sentence: -@ that sort of thing that might be consulted about boardappointments

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so they’re useful then in certainly facilitating gender diversity

author: A
sentence: Very, very

author: Q
sentence: But maybe other types of diversity, perhaps the organisations for accountants, would they help you find an accountant for a board if you wanted one? Are they influential in that way?

author: A
sentence: It’s reinforcing – I think there were a couple of big collapses like HIH and OneTel that started this particular process, and that was reinforced by the GFC, and the fiduciary duties of directors came into the spotlight as the result of other corporate collapses, and Hayne has brought into focus corporate misbehaviour

author: A
sentence: So it has been a gradual process of course, but as with everything you’ve had your early adopters

author: A
sentence: You’ve had your pragmatic group in the middle, and you’ve had the laggards still dragging along behind, but the landscape has changed

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: Like, I don’t know about the accountants organisations

author: A
sentence: I knowEngineers Australia -

author: Q
sentence: Right, they do

author: A
sentence: - do, or can

author: A
sentence: Australian Institute of company Directors is another one

author: Q
sentence: Yes, yes

author: Q
sentence: They’ll put people forward will they?

author: A
sentence: Well, they might give advice

author: Q
sentence: Okay, or suggest to some of their members why don’t you go -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay

author: A
sentence: And they’re particularly strong on the board diversity piece

author: Q
sentence: Yes, they have a very good – I’ve interviewed a couple of people there who are members there and it’s very active, people are obviously informally networking all the time there

author: Q
sentence: Lovely, so the laggards, what do you think keeps them there and is -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: It’s very interesting, the way it operates

author: A
sentence: Oh, it’s a fascinating organisation and it has managed to be the repository of a lot of wisdom on corporate governance, and they’ve actually cornered the market very well with their company directors and related courses

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so they’re a leader?

author: A
sentence: Mmm

author: Q
sentence: They are a leader, yep

author: Q
sentence: I think let’s go to the final question because I’m conscious of the time, that we’re on the hour

author: Q
sentence: So looking 10 years into the future now how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: I think there’s still more mileage in driving diversity, I don’t think we’re there yet

author: A
sentence: I think if you look at ASX board figures, gender being the obvious example, I don’t think there are enough female directors on ASX

author: Q
sentence: Any of them, and definitely the 50s

author: A
sentence: Oh -

author: Q
sentence: ASX 50s isn’t it, that there’s none? Four with none, or have I got it wrong?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s probably a refusal to acknowledge changed reality, and the end of the clubbiness has prompted the demise of the all-male board as well

author: A
sentence: That’s been a factor

author: A
sentence: And the need for better governance has prompted the need for diverse voices, and that’s underpinned the need for more diversity on boards

author: A
sentence: No, the 200

author: Q
sentence: The 200, there’s four with no women, yeah

author: A
sentence: Which to me is surprising

author: A
sentence: There’d have to be a damn good reason in my book for that to be the case, and I could not think of one

author: A
sentence: And if that’s the case in the ASX 200 it’s obviously the case cascading further down in terms of listed and non-listed companies

author: A
sentence: I think that diversity in general is something the boards need to pay attention to, as per my original comments

author: Q
sentence: How would that be done?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s that consideration of bringing people on with different points of view, different backgrounds, but ensuring they are, if they’re not already up to speed, they’re willing to get up to speed and you’re willing to get them up to speed

author: Q
sentence: Yep, okay

author: A
sentence: I think that will – that impetus for diversity will continue because I don’t think the expectations of directors will diminish, I think they’ll just keep ratcheting up

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the digital technologies might, because you mentioned them earlier so I think let’s go back to there too, might be a shaper of boards and directors and their behaviours more in the future that it is now, and that that might impact on the way you do things in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think so because social media is instant

author: A
sentence: Once it’s out there it’s out there, you can’t bring it back

author: A
sentence: So I think that’s really supercharged the more forensic media focus on what companies do

author: A
sentence: That’s been occurring since arguably the ‘60s, but that just adds an extra dimension to it

author: Q
sentence: Yes, yes, it’s much quicker, as you said

author: Q
sentence: So I guess it gives less time for the board to think about how they can block it or manage it

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk about that a little bit more because that really is key?

author: A
sentence: Respond, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Respond, exactly

author: Q
sentence: It’s – so do you think it might lead to reactivity which might impact the growth of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Look, certainly in politics it’s led to reactivity, hasn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: I know, this is why I’m intrigued

author: A
sentence: The 24 hour media cycle

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, so are we looking at this sort of image? Are we looking at this in the future?

author: A
sentence: I think there are longer term and shorter term issues, and I think if you look at corporate Australia they certainly invested in more spin doctors to combat that kind of thing

author: A
sentence: Public relations, the - if you have done the wrong thing the best thing to do is ‘fess up immediately and apologise and say we’re going to do X, Y and Z

author: Q
sentence: To fix it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, whether it’s an oil spill or some other type of corporate misbehaviour

author: A
sentence: And particularly consumer goods companies like car companies have actually managed to turn – sometimes turn negatives into a positive by responding very quickly on social media with a front foot responsethat provides customer delight

author: A
sentence: So there are ways of handling social media, but it means that everybody has to be more prepared for that worst case social media scenario, because an activist group can form almost overnight around a single issue

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and it can be global

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: It can be global

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so your stakeholder management has to be really super

author: A
sentence: It does

author: Q
sentence: Super speedy, super strong

author: Q
sentence: So on the board does it change – does this - like you need people who are digital natives or something on your board because of this? Or is it, I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: I mean, we’re looking 10 years ahead, everyone will be -

author: A
sentence: Oh, it’s certainly a consideration having someone who knows something about social media in the boardroom

author: Q
sentence: And confidentiality, maybe that will play a bigger – I mean, I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: Because the openness between the board and the organisation is seen as being important isn’t it?

author: A
sentence: It is

author: Q
sentence: A sort of transparency and -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But could this perhaps change that because of concerns of social media getting in the way?

author: Q
sentence: I won’t even go through the questions, let’s go for it

author: A
sentence: Depends how it’s done because I don’t think – if you were to go about it the right way you wouldn’t start putting big barriers up because that can be counter-productive in and of itself, but if you’re open you’ve got to do it in the right way, in a way that can’t be misinterpreted, either accidentally or mischievously

author: Q
sentence: So it’s how you manage the communications?

author: A
sentence: It is, it is

author: Q
sentence: More crafting

author: A
sentence: Well, 10 years ago people would say to you, you need someone with PR or communication skills on the board, but nowadays I think it might even be more specific around social media

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Oh look, thank you so much

author: A
sentence: That’s all right

author: Q
sentence: That is so good

author: Q
sentence: You’re the only person who’s brought up social media

author: A
sentence: I think - the big danger I think in corporate situations is groupthink, and having a group that are too clubby or too similar can lead to bad decision-making because everyone starts thinking as a pack

author: A
sentence: So you do need, I think,a level of small d disruption on a board, at least as you’re coming to a decision

author: A
sentence: Once you’ve made a decision you have to own it, but I think as you’re having that discussion there has to be diverse voices

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think as a generalrule,without over-generalising, the presence of women on boards that had been previously clubby does break up that club somewhat, which is good

author: A
sentence: I think there has been a bit of a tendency with the blokes to be clubby

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if that’s biological or learned behaviour, but I think from a pragmatic point of view while there are positives in that, and sometimes you see that in sporting teams, that clubability, there is another side of the coin in terms of quality decision-making

author: Q
sentence: Right, because that builds a collegiality and that can be, you think, at odds with needing diverse points of view to prevent groupthink?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah? Is that -

author: A
sentence: There’s good collegiality and bad collegiality

author: Q
sentence: Okay, can you talk about that for me please?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: A
sentence: I think good collegiality revolves around a common purpose and a common goal, and the joy of working together and exhibiting team work

author: A
sentence: I think bad collegiality is when I suppose traits of people just going along with things because the group wants to go along with them, and wanting to not break ranks with the group and maintain popularity

author: A
sentence: That’s bad collegiality

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so wanting to fit in rather than -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: -@ contributing a voice to the problem solving?

author: Q
sentence: - on the ground

author: Q
sentence: So that’s what we’re aiming to do here -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: What about - some people have talked about conflict and then it can be a good and a bad thing as well, so I’m wondering how that fits with – it seems to work, your idea of collegiality seems to help to unpack that difference between good and bad conflict

author: A
sentence: yeah, I think as long as conflict is respectful, as long as people are going into a board meeting with an open mind, and prepared to hear other points of view and put other points of view, sometimes having a different point of view can prompt additional thinking

author: A
sentence: And you might have completely opposite points of view at a board table but if you’re good at stakeholder management, building outcomes, you might be able to synthesise those points of view into a sensible outcome

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of that?

author: A
sentence: I could give you probably a hypothetical example

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, hypothetical’s good

author: A
sentence: You might have a situation where you’re building a strategy to take on a particular market or influence a particular group, and one board member will say ‘We should go about it this way and take this approach

author: A
sentence: ’Another board member might say ‘Well,if you do that that way you might offend X, Y and Z and alienate your customer base

author: A
sentence: ’ You might be able to take viewpoint A as valid, and take that overall general approach, but tailor your approach so you’re not offending certain customer segments

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s a good example of how - a good hypothetical example of how people say diversity – because one of the questions is are there particular situations where you don’t want diversity, where it can be a problem? For example ,high uncertainty or risk and someone said to me ‘No, that’s when you actually really need it’ and this is sort of where well that second voice helps you to manage the risks associated with your primary goal

author: Q
sentence: So would you agree with that idea that diversity is important for risk management, even in risk situations?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely, because risk is often complex

author: A
sentence: It’s not we’re going to do X and that’s it

author: A
sentence: You’ve got to consider all those factors and sub-factors when you’re approaching a complex risk situation

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it helps to manage complexity, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: So how important – let’s say we’ve got a scale 1 to 10, 1 is diversity is not important at all, 10 it’s extremely important, where would you put it?

author: A
sentence: Good, good

author: A
sentence: I’d put it probably between 8 and 9

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been that important, or do you feel that it’s changed?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s changed because society’s changed

author: A
sentence: I think the general public are no longer willing to accept say authority figures because they are authority figures, for example

author: A
sentence: They expect more accountability from doctors, lawyers, priests, business people et cetera, et cetera

author: Q
sentence: And is that linked to not to a demographic status sort of thing, the accountability is linked to what, skills or – I’m not sure how to understand diversity and accountability here?

author: A
sentence: The accountability is linked to core behaviour, and that could be to do with environmental practices, it could be to do with ethical business practices

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so diverse perspectives?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yep, like the broader perspective, not just financial?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely, yeah, that’s it

author: A
sentence: Triple bottom line

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, okay, got you

author: Q
sentence: -@ with our questions

author: Q
sentence: So how many years have you been a board director?

author: A
sentence: It could be related to diversity itself within the company

author: Q
sentence: Oh great, okay

author: Q
sentence: And so then that links back to your opening point about good governance and the trends towards good governance -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - so thus the social norms and expectations are travelling along with this rapid change in governance as a reaction to some pretty big corporate crises like HIH, OneTel -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: - the banking sector

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: Probably wouldn’t have been picked up, these issues, these corporate issues wouldn’t have been picked up the same way without that social change do you think?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely

author: A
sentence: I think as part of social change the diminution of respect for people with high status in society, the media has become more questioning since the 1960s, and that’s been supercharged by social media where everybody is now a journalist with a camera

author: Q
sentence: Serious evidence

author: A
sentence: Serious evidence, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Right, okay, that’s really interesting isn’t it? I’m going to think about that

author: Q
sentence: So that’s a good mapping exercise

author: Q
sentence: So now what does board diversity mean to you? I’ve got a number of – it can be a lot of different things, you’ve mentioned gender

author: A
sentence: Yeah look, I think a wide background of different viewpoints and experiences

author: A
sentence: It’s a natural human trait to recruit people similar to yourself, but if you take the wide view, probably two views you can take, they’re not mutually exclusive

author: A
sentence: One is to look at the skills based approach and say well look we do need someone with accounting knowledge and we do need someone with legal knowledge, HR, marketing, comms, whatever, without over-fetishising it which can be a problem in and of itself

author: A
sentence: You can have a problem where you’ve got a lawyer on the board or an accountant and they suddenly get elevated to being the expert and they can stop a lot of things from happening if they’re elevated to being the sole source of knowledge on an issue

author: A
sentence: But I think having people from a variety of social or occupational backgrounds is also fairly good in and of itself

author: A
sentence: So rather than havinga board of just accountants, or rather than having a board full of males or females, I think having some kind of diversity is helpful

author: Q
sentence: I’m interested now to think back to your governance, your original opening line, talked about changing understandings of governance, corporate governance

author: Q
sentence: Have these skills and the social occupational expertise, these sort of things that - these kinds of diversity that you’ve mentioned, are they – have they – has that pattern changed do you think because of the changed corporate governance demands over the last decade that you were talking about?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s changed for two reasons

author: A
sentence: I think it’s the increased expectations on directors

author: Q
sentence: By whom?

author: A
sentence: By regulators, by the media, I think by society in general

author: A
sentence: But I think it’s also social change as well, and in particularfrom a gender point of view that women should have the same opportunities as men

author: A
sentence: Why do you have a board for example that’s all male, or has one woman on it? And people do question that sort of thing, for good reason

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed some directors who have said ‘If there’s not a gender balance on the board I’m not interested in applying’, because they think it’s a sign that it’s too conservative, they would not fit in and wouldn’t want to

author: Q
sentence: So I was intrigued when I heard that, I thought wow that’s good

author: A
sentence: That’s interesting

author: A
sentence: People are making those stands these days

author: Q
sentence: So it’s the social change,and then that’s affecting the supply of directors or the candidates

author: A
sentence: It is

author: A
sentence: And look, I did some work on gender diversity in the resources sector a number of years ago and there’s the observation around critical mass, that resources has traditionally been heavily male-oriented for a range of reasons

author: A
sentence: If you have a site where you’ve got 100 people, and you’ve only got five women, that’s not enough critical mass for them to feel comfortable

author: A
sentence: And the same thing applies, say,if you’ve got a board of 10 people and one is female that can actually be counter-productive to retaining that female and building more female representation

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: And is that with one board, the same board?

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that works with other demographies like age? Only one young person

author: Q
sentence: Only one person from perhaps an Asian background, a culturally diverse background?

author: A
sentence: I think it can, but probably less so -

author: Q
sentence: Oh good, can you -

author: A
sentence: -@ in my observation

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting, can you tell me -

author: A
sentence: It’s only really what I’ve seen over the years that sometimes you’ll get a young director who in some way relishes being on a board with older people, and it really develops them very quickly

author: A
sentence: I think from a cultural point of view it depends

author: A
sentence: I know working in resources with indigenous representation the critical mass theory was true, that one indigenous person out of 100, particularly if they’re from a non-urbanised background, that can be problematic in terms of retention, you’d want more

author: A
sentence: But if, say, a situation if it’s an educated Asian person on a board with educated Caucasian people it’s not as much of an issue

author: A
sentence: And that’s purely observation

author: Q
sentence: Okay, but this is what we need

author: Q
sentence: [We’ll find] 00:24:08 the theory and see if there’s more research that’s needed

author: Q
sentence: So that’s interesting

author: Q
sentence: So I wonder how – so someone from a lower socio-economic background, I’m thinking particularly in the not-for-profit sector or with services to people with - communities with disability and single parents, so people who are from socio – so the services are being provided to people who are single parents, so they’re – it’s part of the business to be able to serve that community

author: Q
sentence: So you might really want to have  people on the board from that community, but maybe this is a barrier just like the non-urbanised Aboriginal

author: Q
sentence: If it’s not having the language – I don’t mean the language, the confidence from an education, that an education can give you - do you think education and money is important I guess is the bottom line?

author: A
sentence: I think education is particularly important

author: Q
sentence: For board members, for directors?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And I think being comfortable, and I suppose being accommodated, and the cultural fit being right is important

author: A
sentence: But your point’s very valid that if your customer base is X or Y having insights from that customer base on the board is quite -

author: A
sentence: That was the first board, which I’m still on, and I’m a director of two other companies

author: Q
sentence: Important

author: A
sentence: Yeah, quite important

author: A
sentence: Female representation – I’m sorry that’s my phone, it might be in the next room

author: A
sentence: I think one of thearguments around improving female representation is women, at least in certain markets, make more of the purchasing decisions than men so it makes business sense particularly in terms of consumer goodsfor women to be on those boards

author: A
sentence: And I think potentially with a not-for-profit organisation who is in aparticular community you often have community representatives, which is useful and helpful in terms of the operation of that business but from a legal standpoint they have to be brought up to speed in terms of what the duties of a director actually are

author: Q
sentence: Would you put them through a course as part of that, like the AICD course, you might pay for that?

author: A
sentence: Mmm

author: Q
sentence: Is there anything else the board might do to – I’m just thinking let’s say for some reason  you’re really a board that governs a lot of NDIS-type service providers so you’d really want to understand that market and the providers in that market, so would you invest in the education of people so that they can?

author: A
sentence: Look, the – if you’re going to have an effective board member you have to have some sort of induction process for them, whether that’s a tour of the facilities with the CEO or Chair, or both, a briefing on the business, what its aims are, its history, where it’s planning to go

author: A
sentence: Included in that has to be some sort of piece on directors’ duties and what it actually means to be a director because you - a) it’s not fair on the person if you don’t do that for them, but b) 00:28:47 a regular board member if they don’t understand the organisation’s imperatives and they don’t understand their legal obligations

author: A
sentence: I know with this board that I’m executive director, I make it very clear to directors when they come on the board that these are your legal obligations as a director, and I include that in the board papers every time, the extract from the regulator’s webpage as to what your duties actually are as a director

author: Q
sentence: Right, so as the director of operations you would be very keen then to have a board that can help you with strategy?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So I’ll go back to the - would you then think it would be a  strategic investment for the organisation to try and find – build candidate capability so that they can come on the board? So – because I’m justthinking some people might be a long way from being able to perform director duties but their community is so important to your strategy, would you invest in terms of scholarships, get them through uni, get them – like, a five year, 10 year plan to get a good director?

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: That’s not a problem

author: Q
sentence: I was thinking, oh, I hope I set it up properly

author: Q
sentence: All’s good

author: Q
sentence: Well, it’s so lovely to meet you

author: Q
sentence: Now, we’re going to talk on board diversity

author: Q
sentence: And I’m particularly interested from - you’re speaking from The Australia Institute’s point of view, yeah?

author: A
sentence: Look, I’d have to say 10, to be quite honest with you

author: A
sentence: And the reason that I say that is it’s always hard to build diversity on boards

author: A
sentence: Oh, sorry, you just froze

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure because I don’t necessarily do that myself

author: Q
sentence: I’ll do that

author: Q
sentence: I’ll look at that

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good lead

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So now can we explore a little bit about what diversity means for you? We’ll just try and clarify that concept from your point of view

author: Q
sentence: You’ve been talking about it - how you’ve been talking about [overtalk] 00:27:30

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Well, everyone has different [unclear] 00:27:34, life experiences, and all those come into a board to help you govern and address issues that come up in the everyday board, things that happen

author: A
sentence: If you don’t have a diversity of experiences and skills, well you can’t address the issues that you need to be addressing as a board

author: A
sentence: And a good example to me is most boards need an accountant to make sure somebody understands the figures that they’re being presented to by management

author: A
sentence: You really need to have somebody with some sort of legal background

author: A
sentence: And I’m just thinking that Menslink, an organisation that I work for, needs to have somebody who really understands mental health issues, and how people can work in that environment

author: A
sentence: ACT Government needs somebody who understood how legislation worked, and how the things that happen at Cemeteries Society need to be dealt with

author: A
sentence: If you work in an organisation that has its core business is around staff, you need somebody who’s got HR skills

author: A
sentence: So you need to bring in those people that understand the operations of the organisation, but also have those - and I’m going to talk about with business, you’ve got your core business and your non-core business

author: A
sentence: And I’ve always, because I’m an accountant, I always stick into non-core [unclear] 00:29:10 so I understand the HR, I understand the finance, I understand the risk management of an organisation

author: A
sentence: You need to have that balance

author: A
sentence: But I don’t necessarily understand - if it was an IT organisation, for example, I wouldn’t be very good with the IT skills

author: A
sentence: If somebody started talking to me about “should I be using WordPress or Drupal?” I’d be going, “I have no idea

author: A
sentence: ” So then you need that balance of skills

author: A
sentence: And I really think that diversity brings that into an organisation

author: A
sentence: And it’s critical

author: A
sentence: You can’t sit on a - an IT company’s a good example

author: A
sentence: You can’t have a group of accountants sitting on the board of an IT company because it won’t work

author: A
sentence: They all understand the finances but not the [unclear] 00:29:50

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But if they didn’t have a person with financial understanding, they wouldn’t be able to be effective either

author: Q
sentence: Is that - you see legal and accounting as being essential for everything, for all boards?

author: A
sentence: And you’re right

author: A
sentence: If you’ve only got one person that understands the accounts, and I have been in this situation too, the management or the solvency of an organisation is the responsibility of every board member

author: A
sentence: You can’t delegate that responsibility by going, “Oh, yeah, there’s an accountant that sits over there

author: A
sentence: So she looks after that

author: A
sentence: ” Everybody has to contribute to understanding that, and knowing what’s happening in that organisation

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think a particular kind of diversity might matter more than others, like is it important to have skills diversity? That’s more important in gender diversity? Or something like that? Are there particular kinds of diversity that matter more than others?

author: Q
sentence: It’s always hard to, sorry?

author: A
sentence: Look, I think you have to have [unclear] 00:31:11 and skills-based

author: A
sentence: You have to have the right skills around the table

author: A
sentence: But then, as part of that, diversity is reality important as well when developing those skills

author: A
sentence: Because if you have some - a group of people that have all exactly the same skills, you get into that groupthink

author: A
sentence: And that’s something that I think is a tragedy for boards because, if no one’s challenging [unclear] 00:31:40 no one’s asking the right questions, no one’s thinking differently, you end up in all sorts of trouble

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a little more about groupthink for me, and an example perhaps of where it’s been a problem, just so we can understand how it works? It’s good

author: A
sentence: Well, I’m just thinking of one particular board, and there are a number of people that sit around the table, and there was a particular issue [unclear] 00:32:12 that was challenging that people didn’t necessarily understand

author: A
sentence: And everyone - nobody wanted to be the voice that went, “I don’t understand this

author: A
sentence: ” And they all sit there and they nodded, and went, “Okay, okay

author: A
sentence: ” And then when we all got out of the meeting, people would go, “I really no idea what was going on

author: A
sentence: ” And you’d sort of go, “Well, why didn’t you speak up? Why didn’t you ask the dumb question and go, ‘Seriously, I don’t know what you’re talking about

author: A
sentence: I don’t think this is a good idea’?”

author: A
sentence: And because nobody did, and [unclear] 00:32:48 organisation, which nobody actually agreed with

author: A
sentence: And they didn’t want to go in that direction

author: A
sentence: But because nobody had had the courage to sit up and say, “I don’t understand the reason why we’re doing it,” it got through

author: A
sentence: It was proved

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And I found that really interesting, because I sat there and I - that particular group of people, I was secretary, so I was the observer

author: A
sentence: And I could see that everybody had these problems, and nobody wanted to say

author: A
sentence: And as the observer, you can’t sort of butt in and go, “Surely someone’s got a question

author: Q
sentence: So, now, that’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the chair has a role to see that, and to try and manage groupthink? How can it be managed?

author: A
sentence: Well, this is an interesting - it’s a problem too because if the chair’s out of the groupthink, they’re outside and seeing what’s happening, and I suppose one of the challenges - I don’t know if I’d even call it a challenge

author: A
sentence: But one of the things I do when I go to board meetings is I do challenge things a lot, and I do - even sometimes, I think, “Well, that’s a really dumb question

author: A
sentence: ” But I’m going to ask it anyway because I don’t know if everybody else around this table understands it

author: A
sentence: And, you know, there’s been - I was thinking about another really interesting issue that I had recently in an organisation, and it was too hard for the [CA] 00:34:29 to deal with, so we put it on the table at the board, and I was chair at the time

author: A
sentence: And I said, “Well,” - nobody else knew what to do

author: A
sentence: “My view is that you have to take some very serious action about this matter

author: A
sentence: We cannot, as a board, allow this to go unaddressed

author: A
sentence: ” It was an HR issue

author: A
sentence: “We have to be seen to be taking a positive action here because this involves people that give us money

author: A
sentence: From a risk management perspective, if it was front page of the Canberra Times, who’s going to give us money anymore because this thing has happened?” And everyone was quite horrified that I took such a strong approach to the issue

author: A
sentence: But I really believed that for the fundamental good of the organisation, you had to - there was a lot of hurt, short-term hurt that belonged to [overtalk] 00:35:23

author: A
sentence: And I see a lot of people who aren’t prepared to do that

author: A
sentence: They don’t want to go, they don’t want to be thinking differently to other people

author: A
sentence: And, again, it comes back to that if you recruit the same people that you’re friends with, it’s hard to have a challenging conversation, and get people to think differently

author: A
sentence: And you see it a lot, you know, “I’m mates with this person, this person, and this person

author: A
sentence: I think they’d be really good for our board

author: A
sentence: I know that my good friend, Margot, would like to come and do this too

author: A
sentence: ” And you end up with a whole range of similar people with similar thoughts and similar [unclear] 00:36:02 similar background that don’t challenge the thinking that’s happening on the board

author: A
sentence: And that’s why diversity is so important

author: A
sentence: It’s hard to build diversity on boards

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Look, this is so interesting because, see, [Participant], I’ve had a couple of people talk from boards, and they’re passionate about conflict

author: Q
sentence: They think conflicting views are fabulous, and they think it’s a problem if the board doesn’t express conflicting views

author: Q
sentence: And so they made me sit back because they actually seemed to really believe it and live by that mantra

author: Q
sentence: Would you join them in that? Is that the sort of picture you have? Or is it a bit -

author: A
sentence: I would [unclear] 00:36:46 and I’ve sat on some boards with [unclear] 00:36:49

author: Q
sentence: Oh, hold on

author: A
sentence: [Unclear] 00:36:53

author: Q
sentence: It’s frozen

author: Q
sentence: It’s freezing

author: Q
sentence: I’m not sure

author: Q
sentence: Maybe it’s right now

author: Q
sentence: Like, I’m losing you

author: Q
sentence: It’s good now

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so I’ve sat on some boards where conflict has been absolutely [dysfunctional] 00:37:10, and it’s been - they’ve been a complete disaster

author: A
sentence: And I definitely would say I don’t think conflict is necessarily a good thing

author: A
sentence: But then there’s that balance

author: A
sentence: I don’t think groupthink’s a good thing either when you’ve everybody in the room who thinks the same, has the same background, has the same skill, knowledge, and experience, and they all agree

author: A
sentence: So there’s that fine line to walk, and I think my view is rather than being in conflict with other people, and I have seen people that believe that, that you’ve got to have everyone [fighting] 00:37:42 to get the best out of them

author: A
sentence: I don’t agree with that

author: A
sentence: But you do have to have courage

author: A
sentence: And you do have to be able to ask hard questions, and put the time into reading your board papers, to understand the issues that are coming forward, and to be able to say, “I don’t really get this

author: A
sentence: Can you explain it to me?” Even if you have a conversation separate with the chair, or separate with the CEO, and say, “I don’t understand this but I want to make sure I make the right decision as a board member

author: A
sentence: Can you explain it to me?” And to challenge other board members to say, “Did you understand that? Can you explain it to me? Because I don’t get it or I don’t know what to do or I don’t know what to say

author: A
sentence: And I think you’ve got to have - if you’ve got 15 people on your board, that becomes more difficult

author: A
sentence: And you’ve got to have the courage to go, “I don’t get that

author: A
sentence: I don’t understand why we’re going to do this

author: A
sentence: Can someone explain it to me?” But, in my mind, that’s not conflict

author: Q
sentence: No, that’s a different way

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Oh, build, yeah

author: Q
sentence: They were talking more - as you were saying before, characterising it - devil’s advocate

author: Q
sentence: Definitely playing the devil’s advocate

sentence: People do travel quite extensively to come and sit on the boards
