sentence: And, again, when some of the government boards that I’ve dealt with from the federal government around - we talk about rather than ACT Government, it tends - I’ve always found it tends to be who you know

author: A
sentence: So somebody within the department, very senior, will know somebody from some other department or someone that they’ve worked with in the past, and they’ll bring them in to sit on the board, because nobody wants to have a board that the chair and CEO don’t get on

author: Q
sentence: So it’s very much the - people who have worked for the government in the bureaucracy - so we’ve got a cultural -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: -@ similarity?

author: Q
sentence: Very interesting

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So I hear from you, [Participant], that we’re not really - The Australia Institute is not part of our discussion

author: Q
sentence: It’s we’re talking about boards, so board experience

author: Q
sentence: So we’ll focus on that

author: Q
sentence: I’ll be clear now

author: Q
sentence: And I need to work through those questions only

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel that it’s always been this important - you raised it as a 10

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel it’s always been this important, diversity of boards?

author: A
sentence: When you say “always been this important”, I think it is important, but I think the importance has grown with the change in demographics in Australia

author: A
sentence: So I think that as we become a more multicultural society, we need to bring those differences into the way we govern organisations

author: A
sentence: Because we’re not governing for one group of people anymore

author: A
sentence: Whereas, in the past, it would’ve been very homogenous

author: A
sentence: Whereas now, it’s very different

author: A
sentence: And I think we need to have that reflected in the way that we govern

author: Q
sentence: So is this diversity about representing the population’s demographics’ interests? Is it a sort of a representational thing? Is that why it’s important?

author: A
sentence: I think that’s part of it

author: A
sentence: But, again, I think it comes back to having that experience

author: A
sentence: So when you’re on a board, and another example that I’m thinking of is when I was on the ACT Cemeteries Authority board, we were talking about building in the - and it wasn’t a chapel but it was like a room or an office or some sort of building where people could go and celebrate someone’s life

author: A
sentence: So we were trying to take the [unclear] 00:14:22 salvation and religion away

author: A
sentence: And the reason that we were doing that was to be able to cater for all faiths and all communities

author: A
sentence: And there’s a lot of people now that don’t necessarily have a faith, but they still want to have a memorialisation for their next of kin

author: Q
sentence: Now, first of all, I’ll just ask an opening question

author: Q
sentence: What I’ve found is that if I just say what I really would like to hear from you, then you talk, and then I’ll sift through the questions where we’ve missed out

author: Q
sentence: But it’s much better if you tell your story, rather than we have these fragmented responses, that’s what I’ve found

author: Q
sentence: So what sort of boards do you sit on?

author: A
sentence: But then when we started - when we had people from different cultures that sat on the board, they had very different perspectives about what that should look like

author: A
sentence: So instead of building that - and I’m going to call it chapel sort of like building, you know, where you have your person at the front, you have all the chairs, you have a lectern to the side where someone may stand up and speak - they talked about having a circular room where everyone wouldn’t necessarily sit in their chair but they would come in, they could stand or they could sit on the floor, because that’s the way their culture, they did those things

author: A
sentence: And I thought that was really important to be able to make it fit for purpose for everyone within our culture to be able to use it

author: A
sentence: But, again, when you’ve got a group of - and I’m going to say white Anglo Saxon people, we only have been into churches and buildings that have all the chairs set out that you sit down in

author: A
sentence: I’ve never ever been to a funeral where I’ve sat on the floor

author: A
sentence: But, you know, again, we would’ve never considered that in the way that we worked, or in our plans for the people

author: A
sentence: And, again, you get an architect that doesn’t necessarily have that background to be able to make that building useful for everyone that you want to use - who wants to use it, sorry

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: So we’ve got the multicultural - the demographic trends in Australia bringing with it religious and other sort of cultural values

author: Q
sentence: So that’s been a driver for the - so it’s not the more importance that you give to diversity, but the different kinds of diversity come into play

author: Q
sentence: Is that what you’re saying? So it’s always been a 10

author: Q
sentence: Is that what you’re saying? It’s always been 10 to have diversity, but there’s more kinds of diversity that have become important because of our demographic trends?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think so

author: A
sentence: Like, everyone’s focused very much on gender balance on board

author: A
sentence: So most boards I sit on now, they all talk about gender balance

author: A
sentence: If a woman leaves, you have to replace a woman

author: A
sentence: It was one of the reasons why I sit on a lot of boards because I tick that box of not only being female but I’m also an accountant

author: A
sentence: So [overtalk] 00:16:59, so to speak

author: A
sentence: So that’s very big

author: A
sentence: And every organisation that I’ve been involved with, they talk about making sure they achieve that 50:50 gender diversity because that’s representative of the world that we live in

author: A
sentence: But in conversations about getting an Indigenous person to sit on our boards, we have a few of those, but’s really hard to find the right person who wants to come into the organisation

author: A
sentence: And then I just don’t know whether the other cultural aspects are even necessarily thought about a great deal

author: Q
sentence: [Participant], you’re the first person to talk about - I’ve interviewed quite a number of people now, and you’re the first person to mention the Indigenous board member

author: A
sentence: Oh, wow, really?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, people aren’t - they haven’t been on a board with one

author: Q
sentence: So can you - you mentioned there are barriers

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a little bit about that, and about how the Indigenous people that you know got onto boards? That’d be interesting if you know that

author: A
sentence: Yeah, look, I do find it really interesting because it’s one of the areas that I’ve tried to work a lot with on - so I think tapping into Indigenous organisations that are embedded within universities, they are bringing people through that - because you can’t just put someone on a board because they tick the diversity box

author: A
sentence: Boards are skills-based, and I truly do believe that you have to have the right set of skills on a board to govern the organisation

author: A
sentence: So you need to tick the two boxes

author: A
sentence: You need to have someone with the right skills who can also meet the diversity requirements

author: A
sentence: And that’s where I think we engage better with universities, for example, as a way of getting those skills in

author: A
sentence: The chancellor of the University of Canberra was an Indigenous gentleman, Tom Calma

author: A
sentence: He was great

author: A
sentence: Look, and I think he was specifically targeted at the time to come onto our board via - we had a wonderful vice-chancellor, Stephen Parker

author: A
sentence: And he went out looking for someone

author: A
sentence: And we use that a lot as being the first university in Australia to have an Indigenous chancellor

author: A
sentence: So it was really important for us

author: A
sentence: And Tom had a great background in working on boards

author: A
sentence: He’d worked with government

author: A
sentence: He’d worked as an advisor to Philip Ruddock, I think it was, many years ago

author: A
sentence: So he had all those including co-relationships as well

author: A
sentence: But they’re [unclear] 00:19:37 to find those people

author: Q
sentence: So do you know how - it was just personal networking, was it, to find him?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I was going to say, at the moment, I do look after the board of The Australia Institute

author: A
sentence: I’m the company secretary here

author: A
sentence: I’m not actually a member of this board

author: A
sentence: I sit on the board for an organisation that does mentoring and counselling services in the Canberra region

author: A
sentence: I previously was the secretary to counsel at the University of Canberra

author: A
sentence: I’ve sat on the board of another Canberra-based organisation called the Women’s Centre for Health Matters

author: A
sentence: I believe so, yeah

author: A
sentence: He started before I started at the university

author: A
sentence: But that was my understanding

author: Q
sentence: So we’re going to get to recruiting activities, and how that might shape the boards

author: Q
sentence: Maybe, you know, you’re talking a bit about it now

author: Q
sentence: How are people recruited, and how do you think that influences the diversity of the board?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, again, look, it’s really interesting

author: A
sentence: Most of the boards that I’ve worked with or for generally recruit through somebody that they know

author: A
sentence: “Who do I know that might like to come and sit on this board?” And generally, most people - unless they’re thinking about diversity, they’ll recruit like

author: A
sentence: So I just find that - and it’s even an unbiased thought process, that they know someone who’d like to sit on the board they think will be really good

author: A
sentence: So they invite them to come in

author: A
sentence: Usually they come up to see how they all go, and then they get put into the board at the next AGM

author: A
sentence: Again, ACT Government has implemented very strict rules around that

author: A
sentence: So you must go through a process now of when you want to fill a government position and this [unclear] 00:20:59 so the local government, not the federal, you must go through a process where the position is advertised

author: A
sentence: You must go to the Office for Women to see if they have - and they have lists now in ACT - to see if there are any appropriate women on that list who you could put onto your board

author: A
sentence: And then we go through, I think, it’s the Office of LGBTQI

author: A
sentence: So we have to go to them as well to find out if there’s a person in that community that would like to sit on or board

author: A
sentence: And then we have the Multicultural Office

author: A
sentence: So we also go there

author: A
sentence: So you’ve got three sort of - well, four hoops that you have to jump through before you can appoint anyone to your board

author: A
sentence: And if you pick from outside of those lists that are generated within government, you need to have a real good reason why you couldn’t find the skills in any of these other areas

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: So are there targets to support this? Or it’s just justify if you don’t have people who are - you don’t have 50% women, like a 50% gender mix, and then you have someone from the LBD - well, you know, that one - and what were the other ones you said? The Indigenous -

author: A
sentence: The Multicultural Office

author: Q
sentence: Multicultural

author: A
sentence: You go to those three organisations first to see if they have someone that they would recommend putting - and these recommendations all go to the Minister to sign off on

author: A
sentence: So unless you’ve got a good reason for picking someone sort of that isn’t any of those things, yeah, they don’t necessarily get a guernsey in Canberra

author: A
sentence: So that’s - and it’s like, you know, [unclear] 00:22:39 the labour organisation talking all the time that they had to implement quotas to build up the number of women

author: A
sentence: This is very similar to that

author: A
sentence: So ACT Government’s basically implementing quotas about, you know, “You need to employ from these lists and, if you don’t, why should I, as the Minister, sign off on somebody else?”

author: Q
sentence: Actually, I -

author: Q
sentence: Are they sort of not-for-profit, these ones?

author: A
sentence: [And it’s actually working] 00:23:00

author: Q
sentence: Isn’t that great? So how long has this been going on for, these -

author: A
sentence: Look, probably a couple of years now

author: Q
sentence: Really? Okay

author: Q
sentence: So since about two thousand and -

author: A
sentence: Well, I think since Andrew Barr got into power

author: A
sentence: So Katy Gallagher was the chief minister here, and she resigned and went to the Senate

author: A
sentence: I’m thinking that was a few years ago, 2016

author: A
sentence: And then Andrew Barr took over

author: A
sentence: And one of the things he implemented when he got into power was that this is the process we shall follow when we appoint boards

author: Q
sentence: This is for state -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, state-based

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, state-based

author: Q
sentence: Because I remember hearing Penny Wong talking about four years ago, five years ago, at a Women on Boards thing

author: Q
sentence: And she said, you know, she’d be given a list of potential candidates for a board, and she’d say, “Where are the women? You can’t tell me” -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, [overtalk] 00:23:56 because federal government tried to do a similar thing

author: A
sentence: And I know they set up a list, I think it was called on Women on Boards, because I put my name down for it

author: A
sentence: And then you never even heard anything again

author: A
sentence: So it actually never generated anything that it was [unclear] 00:24:13

author: Q
sentence: So the federal, you think, was less effective than the state

author: A
sentence: They’re a not-for-profit board, yeah

author: A
sentence: And I used to sit on the board of ACT Cemeteries Authority, which was sort of a trust organisation for the ACT Government

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, and I think it was because at the time, which would’ve been the coalition, refused to mandate any gender balance on boards or any other -

author: Q
sentence: So the quotas have been very effective -

author: A
sentence: I believe so

author: Q
sentence: -@ from your point of view

author: A
sentence: Yeah, [unclear] 00:24:33

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: You’re the first person from Canberra that I’ve interviewed

author: Q
sentence: So I’m thinking, ooh, maybe we better make an effort to interview different states because here you’ve shown us that state government in Canberra has shaped something quite different to anything that I’ve heard here in Melbourne

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and I think we’ve got quite a good - if you wanted to try and google it - the lists have quite a good document around the [creating] 00:25:06 of boards

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: This is the Canberra - the ACT government?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, ACT

author: A
sentence: That said, things have changed a little bit since the last time I was involved in it

author: A
sentence: I’m just thinking

author: A
sentence: I’ve been out of the university now for just over 12 months, so I’m not quite sure what’s happening the last 12 or more months

author: Q
sentence: I’ll look it up, and then I’ll look for similar things in other states

author: Q
sentence: So that’ll be a good lead

author: Q
sentence: Because you’re an example of how it has worked when - because it’s coupled with quotas

author: Q
sentence: Please explain if you don’t comply

author: Q
sentence: Then that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: So now let’s -

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Well, given your perspective as a board member, how would you rate the importance of diversity on boards? If one is - sorry, zero is not important - one is not important at all, and 10 is extremely important, where would you put it?

author: A
sentence: And it’s not just the quotas

author: A
sentence: It’s opening it up so every position on a board for ACT Government now has to be advertised

author: Q
sentence: Advertised, that was the other point, yep, so advertising

author: A
sentence: So anyone has the opportunity to apply for them, and then you have to - the committee or a board committee or whatever will sit down and go through those applications, and enter them, and who they think that these people sit on their board

author: Q
sentence: So when you say -

author: A
sentence: [Overtalk] 00:26:11 opens it up for - you know, not just sort of the person that you know, you know, “My good mate, Margaret, might like to come and sit on this board

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: So it’s breaking through what you were talking about early with that network

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it’s really forcing that

author: Q
sentence: With advertising though, is it using social media as well which is likely to capture younger people? Or is it really the traditional newspaper sort of thing?

author: A
sentence: Look, I was just - so the ACT Government advertises on their website

author: A
sentence: Now I know they did some of that recently through The Australia Institute [unclear] 00:26:53

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if they used Facebook

author: A
sentence: But I’ve never looked either

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I’ll look

author: Q
sentence: I’ll have a look

author: The participant
sentence: [audio begins abruptly] – get apologies over and done with

author: The participant
sentence: I do apologise

author: The participant
sentence: That’s completely my fault and I just completely misaligned my – can you just hold on for a tick?

author: Paul
sentence: I can’t see Margo

author: Paul
sentence: I can see [inaudible] 00:00:38

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, it does come down to the chair competence

author: The participant
sentence: So one of the skills in being a chair is letting people talk but not too much

author: The participant
sentence: Because as I mentioned, once you’re on a board you love talking

author: The participant
sentence: So the thing that I try and tell myself most of all is The participant, it’s time for you to shut up now

author: The participant
sentence: I’m constantly trying to tell myself that

author: The participant
sentence: And a good chair will kind of manage that in way that that is diplomatic, but also move the whole meeting on

author: The participant
sentence: So they will notice if someone’s not talking

author: The participant
sentence: They will notice if someone should be talking and they’re not talking

author: The participant
sentence: Or even things like – so the chair for  not for profit organisation will say things like, I can see that you look a bit concerned

author: The participant
sentence: Is there anything you’d like to add at this point in time? So it does come down to that, picking up lots of different – and not being favourites

author: The participant
sentence: So you will have different – in the boards I’ve been on, you’ll have your chair which is hopefully the natural leader

author: The participant
sentence: But typicallythey’re not the most successful person

author: The participant
sentence: Or they’re not the richest or they’re not the CEO of some company

author: The participant
sentence: That’ll be another person who’s come into the board, just wants to be there for two hours, and so there will be another one or two natural leaders in the board that are probably, if they chose to, could be the alpha person

author: The participant
sentence: So the chair has to manage that and make sure that other people around -

author: Margo
sentence: So they’re all, like the soft issues

author: Margo
sentence: What about, are there any procedures or -

author: The participant
sentence: Well, we do board evaluations at the end of each board

author: The participant
sentence: And one of those questions is – and I could get that for you, if you wish

author: Margo
sentence: Yeah

author: Margo
sentence: That would be very useful, yeah

author: The participant
sentence: There’s a decision making framework that we use that’s aligned to the organisation

author: The participant
sentence: So one of the questions is, have you used this decision making framework? Was time managed well? Were there any issues that you felt – so anyway, there’s a whole series of questions

author: The participant
sentence: And we have a two minute reflection at the end to say, okay -

author: Margo
sentence: Where do we sit here?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah

author: The participant
sentence: And the other thing that we’ve done quite a bit of is – so in February we’ve got a two day strategy day where we go away and we’ve done training with the [AICD]

author: The participant
sentence: 00:37:45 So it’s always good to get other people saying, well this is how a good board will work

author: The participant
sentence: And you have outside people coming in and there’s a big profession of trainers that are happy to do that

author: Margo
sentence: Good

author: Margo
sentence: And there’s no financial barrier to people on the board who might be from a lower socioeconomic background, skilling up?

author: The participant
sentence: I’m just trying to think whether I’ve seen that

author: The participant
sentence: All right

author: The participant
sentence: Let me just -

author: Margo
sentence: Does the board pay or -

author: The participant
sentence: No, the both boards would pay that

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, look that’s a good point

author: The participant
sentence: I haven't seen poor people on a board actually

author: Margo
sentence: Really? Even with the NFP organisation ?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, I don’t think – well, maybe I have but they’re never – yeah, I haven’t seen people where training would have been an issue, but the board do pay

author: The participant
sentence: So you might be right

author: The participant
sentence: There is a diversity issue with regard to – yeah

author: The participant
sentence: The other diversity which is very interesting, and I pick it up, especially because I’ve been – got involved in politics in the last 18 months

author: The participant
sentence: So a lot of people, for example, in  not for profit organisation would be Labour

author: The participant
sentence: And I don’t know why that is

author: The participant
sentence: Or maybe – yeah, so there will be a constellation of people and, yeah, the Liberals are very quiet if they’re on the board

author: The participant
sentence: And the Labour people – yeah, so I’m not -

author: Margo
sentence: So values diversity might be -

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, or political diversity

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, so for example, we’re trying to get [A particular person] to be chair of the board next year

author: The participant
sentence: By the way, all this stuff is really confidential

author: Margo
sentence: Yeah, we won’t write names

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, and that’s very useful for this government

author: The participant
sentence: And almost certainly the Labour government federally will happen in May

author: The participant
sentence: But yeah, whether it’s a long-term thing is another interesting thing

author: The participant
sentence: And it’s not that there’s a bias against it

author: The participant
sentence: It’s just I don’t know why – and whether you – yeah

author: Paul
sentence: So, The participant – I think when talking about the social diversity, the socioeconomic background, there could be a case for a student to be on the SuniTAFE board or [a recent student]

author: Paul
sentence: 00:40:22 Or someone with a need for the services of  not for profit organisation or whatever [we are the board of that’s what Margo was getting at] 00:40:29And there’s another aspect as well, which is to say sure, technically people will sit on boards because of educational needs, curricular outcomes that are required to get effectively [on inaudible boards] 00:40:50 are going to be similar

author: Paul
sentence: However, they could still have different origins or backgrounds

author: Paul
sentence: So I think, if I recall right, you’re an ex-private school boy or whatever [inaudible] 00:41:02

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Margo
sentence: It’s not – yeah

author: Paul
sentence: For diversity, what you need is someone from the other end of town as well

author: Paul
sentence: Of a different background

author: Paul
sentence: Because often they could, or they may see things differently or not

author: The participant
sentence: I agree

author: The participant
sentence: I think the case for that would be – I don’t know how you would even do that, to be honest

author: The participant
sentence: How you would – yeah, because you don’t typically pick board members based on where they grew up in primary school and how poor or rick their parents were

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, I think that would be interesting

author: The participant
sentence: I think those stories do emerge, but it’s all anecdotal and it’s not a selection criteria

author: The participant
sentence: So we recently got two new directors for a NFP

author: The participant
sentence: And we realised that the women – we wanted more women on there

author: The participant
sentence: not for profit organisationis a – we just had just fallen a little bit – it wasn’t because we were at 50% but it just felt that we needed more women around the table

author: The participant
sentence: So the two board members we did go to the [AICD] and say we want two female ones with these set of skills

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, Paul, I think you’ve raised an interesting point with regards to diversity and I don’t know how to answer that question

author: Paul
sentence: [inaudible] 00:42:33 it’s only pushing that or [I believe] 00:42:38 that or whatever is just that again in some of the [literature] 00:42:42 and sometimes the newspapers they would talk about oh, all sort of blue-blooded, Anglo, older males or whatever [inaudible component] 00:42:52 And I’m not necessarily agreeing with that or not

author: Paul
sentence: I was just throwing it out there

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, no I think it’s a really interesting point

author: The participant
sentence: I suppose I’ll just add my little story to that, is my wife’s a physician

author: The participant
sentence: A doctor

author: The participant
sentence: And so I have lots of doctor friends

author: The participant
sentence: And if I had to pick the most extraordinary doctor friend that I have, it would be an ophthalmologist who was in a small country town, who just did it all herself

author: The participant
sentence: She was just – she had to overcome more to get where she was

author: The participant
sentence: And then you have the women that went to PLC that had tutors and all that sort of stuff

author: The participant
sentence: And they’re not as – they’re extraordinary, but they’re not as extraordinary as this

author: The participant
sentence: So if you can get someone like this woman’s name – [Sue] – 00:43:43 if you can get someone like her, who’s just had to travel all that much more, it’s a great get for a board

author: The participant
sentence: Because they kind of get it

author: The participant
sentence: And I remember interviewing a Somalian guy for ANZ who had been a torture victim and he’d had to learn English while on the boat

author: The participant
sentence: And you just think, my god, what a journey that person has had to have done

author: The participant
sentence: What extraordinary depth that person would bring, especially at a not for profit

author: The participant
sentence: I just don’t know how you get – I don’t know even how you’d get selection criteria for that

author: The participant
sentence: You’d have to – you see it when you see it, but you can’t sort of market for that, I don’t think

author: Margo
sentence: Well, see, that’s really interesting

author: Margo
sentence: Because that’s where we’re heading, to the selection process

author: Paul
sentence: [inaudible] 00:44:39

author: Margo
sentence: How do you?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, so I think the selection for gender is easy

author: The participant
sentence: It’s almost the easy way that you appear to get diversity because we do – the board will kind of decide – so for example, I’m in the Labour Party, and we were just voting for the executive

author: The participant
sentence: And they said oh, I think we feel like we need some more women on the executive

author: The participant
sentence: And that what we collectively – it’s acknowledged that you kind of want that balance

author: The participant
sentence: Like a family structures is usually balanced – you just naturally feel that – and then if gender isn’t an issue, if you’ve broadly got it balanced, then you just cast the selection out just generally

author: The participant
sentence: But I think we’ve got well-established processes for bringing women on boards now

author: The participant
sentence: I know a number of women that that’s what they do

author: The participant
sentence: And yeah, they know that there are advertisements specifically targeted to them

author: The participant
sentence: So I think that kind of diversity, in the boards that I’m dealing with, is pretty easy to get

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, at the big end of town, I don’t know about

author: The participant

sentence: Because it’s a very hard decision to make

author: The participant
sentence: Whether they’re making enough bets or whether they’re making the right bets

author: The participant
sentence: And obviously the boards main job is to appoint a CEO and make sure that their performance is keeping to track

author: The participant
sentence: And then the rest is monitoring and governance, but that’s the really hard job

author: The participant
sentence: And I suppose if you’re going to – it’s not trial by jury, but it almost is

author: The participant
sentence: If you’re going to have that, you do need more than just one type of person to do that

author: The participant
sentence: You need someone that’s – so in the NFP organisation , which is mostly about resources and giving programs to disadvantaged women and girls, you need people that are good on that front, on the social front

author: The participant
sentence: You need people that are good on law, especially law

author: The participant
sentence: You need people good on accounting

author: The participant
sentence: You need people who are really hooked into government, because government funding is crucial

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah

author: The participant
sentence: Sure

author: The participant
sentence: So you need that diversity of skills and you need the diversity of attitudes and ability to judge whether someone’s doing an okay job

author: The participant
sentence: Because apart from anything else, CEOS almost are always very clever

author: The participant
sentence: And they're very, very good at marketing, especially self-marketing

author: The participant
sentence: So yeah, I suppose I see it in that way

author: The participant
sentence: It’s not a trial by jury, but kind of like that

author: Margo
sentence: Okay, so you’ve mentioned that board diversity is like the capacities of the different people

author: Margo
sentence: So a functional diversity with different people on the board

author: Margo
sentence: But also their relationships, like networks to government

author: Margo
sentence: But then you’ve also brought in that third kind of diversity, which seems to be like the relationship between the board and the management

author: Margo
sentence: And that you have to be able to be flexible to manage – like board by jury, which is quite independent

author: Margo
sentence: And then is there another way that the board can relate to management? The chief executive?

author: The participant
sentence: Well, I mean, it has to go through

author: The participant
sentence: You have to be very – I mean, the [tricker] 00:06:31 model I think, because that’s the one that says you go through the CEO, doesn’t it?

author: Margo
sentence: Yeah

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, that seems to be the one that is workable that I’ve seen

author: The participant
sentence: I do have a relationship with the CFO – with the two CFOs, just because I’m finance-based

author: The participant
sentence: But there’s kind of an approval process that I’ve seen that you go through the chair, and the CEO, and you say look, just functionally I need to do this

author: The participant
sentence: If it’s anything important I will cc – I will courtesy copy both of you

author: The participant
sentence: It’s by appointment

author: The participant
sentence: It’s by exception

author: The participant
sentence: So you do have that relationship with management

author: The participant
sentence: But a lot of it does filter through the CEO

author: The participant
sentence: And I mean, it’s a hard job, because CEOs have to manage – there’s 12 people on both boards

author: The participant
sentence: It’s such a hard job to do

author: The participant
sentence: And you don’t want loose ends

author: The participant
sentence: As much as possible, you want to give them the capability of managing you to the extent possible

author: The participant
sentence: So you do – yeah, I mean, that’s why everything goes through the chair

author: The participant
sentence: And the chair’s job does seem to be five times harder than being on a board

author: The participant
sentence: And I think a chair’s job, you need 10 years of experience on a board to be a good chair, in my opinion

author: The participant
sentence: I wouldn’t be experienced enough, for example

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, so the diversity mixes in, in that framework if that makes sense

author: Paul
sentence: Yeah, [inaudible] 00:07:57 so do a large degree what you’re describing, to a large degree is more functional line, so say for like the Australian Institute of Company Directors recommend that a lot of boards create their own skills matrices for example

author: Paul
sentence: Where [inaudible] 00:08:14 organisation, some people within the social world, some people who are the legal, financial – sometimes a combination, et cetera, et cetera

author: Paul
sentence: And the debate that’s going on with diversity at the moment – and we accept that

author: Paul
sentence: I mean, that’s understood

author: Paul
sentence: That’s obviously important – is also around other attributes such as gender, ethnicity, possibly age

author: Paul
sentence: But particularly gender and ethnicity

author: Paul
sentence: And gender I think is what gets most of the spotlight

author: Paul
sentence: Is that sort of diversity important, do you think?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, look, just by way of background – and obviously – so my two chairs are women

author: The participant
sentence: My bosses at La Trobe are women

author: The participant
sentence: My boss here is a woman

author: The participant
sentence: My wife is an extremely competent woman

author: The participant
sentence: I accept that there’s a controversy around it, but for me that controversy has – it’s almost – it’s not irrelevant, because I just think you do want women there

author: The participant
sentence: And yeah – just you want them there, as just a part of a natural process I think

author: The participant
sentence: It’s not – I haven’t been a part of a process where they’ve pushed for women to be on there, because the boards that I’m on are half and half

author: The participant
sentence: And it’s just a natural -

author: Margo
sentence: Hasn’t been an issue?

author: The participant
sentence: It hasn’t been an issue

author: The participant
sentence: So I know that you say there’s controversy, and the big end of town is probably there – and I haven’t got experience in that, but the not for profit space and the places that I play, it is – and I’ve had a number of chairs on both of them

author: The participant
sentence: And I really can’t see – the woman chair at the moment for  not for profit organisation– before that there was two main chairs

author: The participant
sentence: She’s the best one we’ve had

author: The participant
sentence: And maybe it’s attributable to gender, but maybe it’s attributable to the fact that she was the chair of Brotherhood of St Laurence, she’s just very competent in that social space

author: The participant
sentence: So I do look at it through the prism of competency rather than – and I also look at it through emotional lenses

author: The participant
sentence: So there will be very specific people that are empathic

author: The participant
sentence: There will be very specific people that are detailed and analytical

author: The participant
sentence: And I think you want that

author: The participant
sentence: So I’m not answering the question, I think, the way you want it answered, Paul

author: The participant
sentence: But I do see it as an non-issue where I’m at

author: The participant
sentence: And so I don’t know whether that’s politically correct or anything

author: Paul
sentence: [inaudible] 00:11:18 That’s fine

author: Paul
sentence: But just to say, a lot of the questions that Margo will be going through moving forward – I mean, not necessarily buying into a debate on one side or the other or whatever

author: Paul
sentence: We’re just trying to [understand] 00:11:34 some of the issues here

author: Paul
sentence: When we talk about diversity and diversity in terms of their competence is assumed as important, but we’re also thinking in terms of gender diversity

author: Paul
sentence: Because your boards are [clearly pretty diverse] 00:11:53 which is fine

author: Paul
sentence: Other boards aren’t

author: Paul
sentence: Some are extremely – you know

author: Paul
sentence: [inaudible] 00:12:00 But also not just gender

author: Paul
sentence: It’s things like ethnic [inaudible] 00:12:08 people from overseas on boards, which may makes sense in certain circumstances and/or any other 00:12:19 of diversity that make up demand

author: Paul
sentence: Now we’ve got [inaudible] 00:00:20 on our screen I can’t see either Margo or you

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah

author: The participant
sentence: So one of the things I think is missing on boards a little bit in Australia that isn’t missing in America is a performance – so sometimes you have boards that are very not diverse, because they’ll have eighth of the 12 people will be very compliance based

author: The participant
sentence: And you’ll get a board that gets stuck in this compliance

author: The participant
sentence: And really you want to – I think you want a board to help performance as well

author: The participant
sentence: So you have that compliance/performance crossover

author: The participant
sentence: So in America you have an expression, you either give money, you get money, or you get out

author: The participant
sentence: So in a way that’s a very harsh way of saying American boards are – they will try and help the CEO on the performance side

author: The participant
sentence: My experience of what I’ve seen on Australian boards is that we don’t have that compliance/performance thing quite worked out yet

author: The participant
sentence: So I don’t think we have diversity in that way

author: The participant
sentence: I know that’s – but I’m happy to answer as many gender questions as you want

sentence: Okay, so do you think diversity of Australian boards is important?

sentence: Yeah, I think it’s vital

author: The participant
sentence: I mean, but I think it’s vital – well, I was having this chat with some board members

author: The participant
sentence: In a way, one of the limitations of being on a board is that you don’t know very much

author: The participant

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: So you might know in your space – so once again, I suppose I do stress that competency and skills

author: The participant
sentence: And the other one is that emotional diversity and the attitude diversity

author: The participant
sentence: So I think you do need that for assessment of the CEO

author: The participant
sentence: And I suppose it was just very fresh –

author: The participant
sentence: So the CEO in example wanted to take the $200 million that the sisters had got for the last – and wanted to invest it in doing micro-insurance

author: The participant
sentence: Wanted to really expand out and start a business that he could name – that he could put his name to and his sort of – well, he’s 50 and he wanted to say in the next 10 years, I want to be a super success

author: The participant
sentence: And I’m happy [inaudible] 00:15:30 but I’m bluffing on two tens or something like that

author: The participant
sentence: And the board needed to go, gees, he’s getting some success

author: The participant

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: Really it’s a very, very difficult decision

author: The participant
sentence: And what’s that book that it gets expressed? The Wisdom of Teams

author: The participant
sentence: To make decisions like that, The Wisdom of Teams is really – I really support the notion behind that book

author: The participant
sentence: Oh, that’s because I think we need to – oh

author: Margo
sentence: Okay

sentence: There’s a few questions around how that – so we can drill down into that process later on

author: Margo
sentence: So you feel that the board’s diversity has have a positive effect on the decision making

author: Margo
sentence: You’ve just said yes, definitely

author: Margo
sentence: Particularly in this – the assessment of the CEO as an example

author: Margo
sentence: So that’s great

author: Margo
sentence: So do you feel the board diversity can negatively impact the board’s performance?

author: The participant
sentence: It has to have a strong chair

author: The participant
sentence: A lot depends on the competency of the chair

author: The participant
sentence: And the chair – so when you’re in a board, and I know you both know this, you’ve got 12 people and you’re looking around for a natural leader

author: The participant
sentence: And if you’ve got – like we’ve got a managing partner of a law firm there, and everyone kind of looks over to him every 20 seconds, just to make sure everything is okay

author: The participant
sentence: So if you’ve got a strong chair that can give everyone a voice – so when I’m on the board, I always say to myself, I’m going to be the fourth or the fifth person that’s going to talk

author: The participant
sentence: I’m not the most skilled

author: The participant
sentence: But I do have value that I can add

author: The participant
sentence: And there’ll be a few people that don’t want to talk on an issue

author: The participant
sentence: But a chair’s got to allow that

author: The participant
sentence: There will be natural leaders in there and the chair does have to be one of those natural leaders to bring that diversity

author: The participant
sentence: Otherwise it’s a bit of a rabble

author: The participant
sentence: Now, I’ve been lucky and had very good chairs

author: The participant
sentence: So I haven’t seen – but it is a very complex task to be able to manage 12 people who are different levels of competency, but you’re not really on a board if you’re not broadly competent

author: The participant
sentence: I mean, there’s not too many – so yeah, you’ve got to manage – you’ve got to herd those chickens

author: The participant
sentence: And if you can do that, and you’ve picked your chair and the chair has been picked well, then I think diversity is a strength

author: Margo
sentence: Okay, so how do we pick a chair?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, I think you let the natural – a natural leader will emerge

author: The participant
sentence: And as much as possible you should let that natural leader be the chair

author: The participant
sentence: So I’m not – yeah, so [ Chair], 00:18:36 who’s the chair on the This NFP board, she’s got an Order of Australia

author: The participant
sentence: She’s extremely experienced in this space

author: The participant
sentence: And so it was just natural that we would defer to her in that case

author: Margo
sentence: She’s was on the board?

author: The participant
sentence: She was on the board previously

author: The participant
sentence: We’re trying to get [a particular person] 00:18:56 as the next chair

author: The participant
sentence: She’s not on the board at the moment

author: The participant
sentence: So the board understands

author: The participant
sentence: So you don’t want to have, oh it’s his turn or it’s her turn

author: The participant
sentence: You want to be able to control that process to the best of your ability

author: The participant
sentence: Not control it, you want it to be – you don’t want the natural leader to be someone who’s part-time and not on the board

author: The participant
sentence: Unless that person has deferred a lot of authority to the chair

author: The participant
sentence: And then they have to be quite respectful

author: The participant
sentence: So I have seen, for example, I’ve seen a CEO sacked because – and they were a great CEO

author: The participant
sentence: This was a woman CEO, man chair

author: The participant
sentence: And she was having a coffee and said oh, I’m not very sure about the competency of the chair

author: The participant
sentence: And she was right

author: The participant
sentence: But you can’t interfere with the natural authority of the chair

author: The participant
sentence: And the chair heard this and the chair said look, I can’t have a board where you’ve said that in public

author: The participant
sentence: Or not in public, but to friends and it got back to me

author: The participant
sentence: So you have to go

author: The participant
sentence: And so that was – and she’s a CEO now of a big company

author: The participant
sentence: But she just made a stupid mistake

author: The participant
sentence: But that authority of the chair is really important in managing that diversity

author: Margo
sentence: Okay, that’s interesting

author: Margo
sentence: And you say a natural leader

author: Margo
sentence: Are there any key attributes or characteristic of that natural leader for the chair?

author: The participant
sentence: I’ll start by saying, they way you identify it is the way people defer to them

author: The participant
sentence: So for example, when we were sacking the CEO, I was on the side to say no

author: The participant
sentence: And the board was pretty much divided

author: The participant
sentence: Two people resigned over this issue

author: The participant
sentence: From the board

author: The participant
sentence: But you could see constantly that they were deferring to her

author: The participant
sentence: They were just going okay, what do you think of this? We’re in territory we don’t want to be in

author: The participant
sentence: So you do identify by seeing who people defer to

author: The participant
sentence: So you do need to be cool under pressure

author: The participant
sentence: You do need to be decisive

author: The participant
sentence: You do need to keep a bigger perspective

author: The participant
sentence: I know I’ve been mentioning the competency a lot but the competency is a big deal I think

author: The participant

sentence: If you don’t have gender diversity – and once again, I haven’t been on a board that does that

author: The participant
sentence: If you had 10 people like me – now, I’m obsessed, for example, with the NFP organisation , of maintaining this corpus of capital and being able to maintain  not for profit organisationfor 100 years

author: The participant
sentence: Now, I can’t get away from this series of questions that say along the lines of, how sustainable is this? Have we costed it? Those are my questions that I ask because I understand the numbers very well

author: The participant
sentence: Now, they’re nowhere near the right question to ask – so you need an [ Chair] 00:23:49 that says, what’s going to be the impact of this social policy? You need someone – there was a director on the Large not for profit organisation saying, how is this going to relate to other entities? So you do need that variety of questions

author: The participant
sentence: And I suppose with the gender – I haven't seen too much evidence of this, but I suppose you do get more questions along the lines – I don’t personally ask questions on how will this affect staff, unless I’m reminded

sentence: And she will always ask, what’s the impact on staff? And I don’t know whether that’s a gender thing or a competency thing, but I suppose I have noticed that you get a further ranger of questions and maybe you get a little bit more holistic organisational questions from the women

sentence: I can’t put my hand on my heart but that’s what I’ve seen, I suppose

author: The participant
sentence: I have been on sales, but yeah, you want people with a diversity of backgrounds

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: Now, I think one of the things I think we lack even more than gender is things like, if we’ve got a massive Asian population, if we’re hooked into – so one of the things, for example, that businesses in Australia don’t do very well in, is in hooking with Indonesia and hooking with – China’s nine hours away, but Indonesia is three hours away

author: The participant
sentence: Our neighbours, and being able to hook in in that way

author: The participant

sentence: To do that?

sentence: Can you see Margo?

author: The participant
sentence: To do that

author: The participant
sentence: So I think – it’s competency, but you can’t – my wife is Asian

author: The participant
sentence: And I only say that because I know enough to know that if you’re not embedded in that culture, you’re wasting your time

author: The participant
sentence: You can’t just say, I’ve read a book on it

author: The participant
sentence: It’s not enough to do that

sentence: So you do need to know contacts

sentence: So for example – and this was the ANZ board

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: We were trying to get into business in Indonesia, and there was a guy – a white male boss that says, look, they’re a hard case to crack

author: The participant
sentence: We can’t get in there

author: The participant
sentence: We’ve just got to do little bit by little bit

sentence: And the board member had lived in Indonesia for 20 years

sentence: And said, I’m just going to ring up the governor of the bank there

author: The participant
sentence: I went to his kids christening

author: The participant
sentence: We’re going to – I’ll set up a meeting for you

author: The participant
sentence: And you go well, that’s the kind of – if you’ve been there for 20 years, you really know that

author: The participant
sentence: You can’t read a book and say, oh gee, they’re all a closed shop

author: The participant
sentence: So that ethnic diversity, you can get the skills

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: But it’s the last 20% of the skills, and it’s the contacts and it’s the networks and it’s the trustworthiness that – and I suppose that hooks into my performance/compliance

author: The participant
sentence: You can be – another example

author: The participant
sentence: We have, when I was at Westpac

author: The participant
sentence: I was at ANZ for 20 years

author: The participant
sentence: If you lend money to a Samoan, for example

author: The participant
sentence: Or if you lend money to an islander, you might write that off after 10 years if they can’t pay it back

author: The participant
sentence: Or two years

author: The participant

author: The participant
sentence: And 20 years later they might come and say look, I’m sorry we couldn’t pay it back

author: The participant
sentence: But now we can

author: The participant
sentence: Here’s the money

author: The participant
sentence: And you go – staff are completely –

author: The participant
sentence: So even on governance, if you run a very legal, contracted sort of economy, you will go by the letter of the law and you need lawyers

author: The participant
sentence: But governance in those islands for example might be a different thing

author: The participant
sentence: It might be recognising relationships and recognising shame and also recognising a sort of an honour

sentence: So the point is, so yes, SuniTAFE, it would be really good if you had a ethnic Chinese person on that board

author: The participant
sentence: But they are – one is the biggest dealer in Mildura

author: The participant
sentence: The other one is the biggest grape grower

author: The participant
sentence: The other one is someone who controls the whole IT for the Mallee region

author: The participant
sentence: So I like the fact that -

author: Margo
sentence: Useful skills

author: The participant
sentence: - those are very useful skills

author: The participant
sentence: The chair runs a law practise

author: The participant
sentence: And we probably need diversity in the way that you would get government – because TAFEs and universities are crucially linked into government

author: The participant
sentence: And government has their own way of talking and their own network

author: The participant
sentence: So for example, the previous chair of SuniTAFE lost her job because she didn’t have a good relationship with government

author: The participant
sentence: So the Minister just said – it wasn’t good, it was just neutral

author: The participant
sentence: And so when the Minister came to see her [refresh form] 00:32:00 he just – I don’t really know this person

author: The participant
sentence: So look, you do need – yes, ethnic diversity is really important

author: The participant
sentence: Also I suppose sometimes I think what you might be fishing for is that women directors are more empathic with students, they’re more empathic with – and I haven’t seen that

author: The participant
sentence: I’ve seen empathy across both genders

author: The participant
sentence: So I suppose I’m not going down that road

author: Margo
sentence: You don’t have to

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, and because I’ve seen women directors be hard or harder than I have at that level someone – yeah

author: The participant
sentence: So for example, when we were sacking the CEO for NFP organisation , it was driven by the chair

author: The participant
sentence: The woman chair

author: The participant
sentence: In fact she was – the other two chairs which were male weren’t decisive on it

author: The participant
sentence: And this issue had been going for a little while

author: The participant
sentence: And she was the one that said, we’re going to fix this up

author: The participant
sentence: We’re going to close it off right now

author: The participant
sentence: And it wasn’t – it was just as hard as you would imagine

author: The participant
sentence: So I’m not going down that road because I haven't seen it

author: Margo
sentence: That’s good

author: Margo
sentence: That’s what we want is your evidence

author: Margo
sentence: Yeah, from your experience

author: Margo
sentence: So can you think of ways that boards can help directors form minority groups to feel part of the board and to really contribute to decision making?

author: Margo
sentence: It doesn’t matter

author: The participant
sentence: Well, one of the boards I was on was an international house at Melbourne Uni, I was a resident there

author: The participant
sentence: And I was the tutor representative

author: The participant
sentence: And I do like – so at SuniTAFE there is a staff representative

author: The participant
sentence: I do like that

author: The participant
sentence: If you can – so I really like – although it’s hard to do sometimes because sometimes you’ve got issues that affect those people

author: The participant
sentence: The other thing I like is I like mentoring programs

author: The participant
sentence: So I like the chair saying, look, I’ve got staff member – I know it’s hard, but I do like mentoring programs that work both ways

author: The participant
sentence: So you do get the voice of kind of the customer at that point in time

author: The participant
sentence: I have seen lots of 360 stuff happen

author: The participant
sentence: And I do think that is good as well

author: Margo
sentence: So that helps?

author: The participant
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: The participant
sentence: I don’t like it, because it shines a light on it

author: The participant
sentence: But it’s the bit – you know how you don’t like – no-ones likes performance appraisals for example, but they’re very useful

author: The participant
sentence: So I think the 360 is just like that

author: Margo
sentence: Okay, and what did you mean by issues that affect – you can have issues that affect people? You didn’t finish that

author: The participant
sentence: No, that train fell off the rails

author: The participant
sentence: Sorry

author: Margo
sentence: Okay, it’s all right

author: Margo
sentence: So the minority people, the chair – you did describe the chair doing that

author: Margo
sentence: Is there something that other board members might do to enable or board selection?

author: The participant
sentence: Is that minority groups -

author: Margo
sentence: Within the board

author: The participant
sentence: Within the board?

author: Margo
sentence: Within the board, like we might have one person in the  not for profit organisation board, for example, you might have one director who actually is close to the consumer needs or service needs of your -

author: A
sentence: Don’t rush

author: Q
sentence: What we’re doing is we’re interviewing Australian directors of companies of different kinds and organisations that influence or govern them

author: Q
sentence: And the idea is to understand board diversity from their perspective, and to develop a model based on that understanding, and some ideas about how it can be managed, leaders and barriers

author: Q
sentence: That’s sort of the game

author: Q
sentence: First, how have the composition of boards that you’re familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Did you see it coming, though?

author: A
sentence: I wasn’t on the Cochlear, but the hearing kids have Cochlear that I worked with, and so I’m not representing Cochlear

author: A
sentence: Did they see it coming?  No

author: A
sentence: Not to the degree it came and not how accessible it came, and not that people put profit before product, but they always will

author: Q
sentence: Now, board functioning;  we want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular functions that it’s really useful for, irrelevant to?

author: A
sentence: You’ve got to go back to what is the function of the board

author: A
sentence: The function of the board is to steward, that’s number 1;  duty of care for people;  to set the strategy, to ensure that risk is being taken care of, and for the CEO to report into

author: A
sentence: They are not to get day to day operational, but they absolutely have to work with the CEO

author: A
sentence: Diversity to me is critical because all those - and is that what you asked?  So for the board to function on its strategy, it must think about, again, the community, the people, the customers, so diversity’s the only way to do that

author: A
sentence: Risk, it’s global now

author: A
sentence: Risk is so global that you can’t now just look and look insular, you just can’t

author: A
sentence: From a duty of care to your people, again, it’s about your people mix

author: A
sentence: As stewardship - well, stewardship’s a really interesting one

author: A
sentence: I think that even that word’s a bit old-fashioned

author: A
sentence: It almost sounds like the captain of the boat, and the captain of the boat was always male

author: Q
sentence: Yes, but a [soft hand] 00:24:06

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah, but I don’t disagree with it

author: A
sentence: It is still driving the boat or whatever you call it

author: A
sentence: So should that be gender-specific?  No;  again, it has to be diverse

author: A
sentence: But that’s the one that I think people were a little bit brave to make the chair also gender-aware

author: A
sentence: So I often think that stewardship - on boards they think that’s the chair, but, actually, I don’t

author: A
sentence: I think it’s everybody’s responsibility

author: A
sentence: And so it’s communal on the directors

author: A
sentence: And then working together is another critical part of one of the journeys of the boards

author: A
sentence: I mean, strategy, risk, all of those functions, absolutely

author: A
sentence: The CEO, working with the CEO, well, I would hope the CEO would want broad thinking for them to challenge their own operation, and also for their own operation to see they’re being guided by diverse thinking

author: A
sentence: But it’s that stewardship where I think we’ve still got a very big mindset shift to come

author: Q
sentence: And because that can focus the lens on the chair, that’s a conservative influence?

author: A
sentence: It can be, very much so

author: A
sentence: And I have seen more male chairs through my time until recently, until the last two years

author: A
sentence: Over the dozen-odd years that I’ve seen working on boards, I’ve seen the calibre of people uplift

author: A
sentence: Previously, particularly because I started on a not-for-profit board, they felt privileged that people would join their board

author: A
sentence: But that has changed so dramatically in the last, probably, six years, that there’s a far greater pool of people out there with incredible competencies wanting to join boards

author: Q
sentence: And the female chairs that you’ve seen?

author: A
sentence: Have only been in the last two years

author: Q
sentence: Only in the last two years?

author: A
sentence: I haven’t seen female chairs from the first 10 years, which is that interesting -

author: Q
sentence: And do they function differently to men, chairs?

author: A
sentence: I think they add a different perspective

author: Q
sentence: So they’re functioning as women

author: A
sentence: And I don’t think they’re trying to act as men in any way

author: A
sentence: I’ve seen incredible deep thought from them, and I’ve found that they’re far more less hierarchical

author: A
sentence: Far less hierarchical

author: Q
sentence: So then the stewardship model is everyone

author: A
sentence: It’s shared

author: A
sentence: Exactly, exactly

author: A
sentence: And that’s what I’m saying should occur

author: A
sentence: I mean, the chair has a place, don’t get me wrong

author: A
sentence: Very critical place

author: Q
sentence: Why do you think they want to join them?

author: Q
sentence: Now, I’d like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards

author: Q
sentence: And if so, how conflict can be managed

author: Q
sentence: And I’ve had people discuss conflict, the difference between that and -

author: A
sentence: Robust discussion

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, the latter being essential

author: Q
sentence: And others have used the word ‘conflict’ and said, “That’s essential”

author: Q
sentence: So let’s not get stuck in the words

author: A
sentence: No, I won’t get stuck in that

author: A
sentence: I like to give from my perspective

author: A
sentence: I think the more diverse thinking you have on a board, the more robust the discussion is

author: A
sentence: I just think that one equals two

author: A
sentence: If you have the diverse thinking, you will get the robust discussion because people are thinking outside the box, and we want that

author: A
sentence: So for one to be gender diverse, of course you’re going to get more robust thinking, diverse thinking, so that’s perfect

author: A
sentence: And that’s a board’s role

author: A
sentence: It’s to challenge respectfully

author: A
sentence: I’m not going to - so conflict would have happened - conflict is such a different thing, and for me conflict isn’t difference of opinion;  conflict is where you can’t resolve in a board an issue

author: A
sentence: And that’s where a chair is critical, to try to allow that robust discussion

author: A
sentence: For me, if you have conflict on boards, it’s very important the directors address that very quickly

author: A
sentence: It’s like any discussion off a board or on a board, you have to give and take

author: A
sentence: And you’ve always got to bring it back to what are you trying to drive?  What is the ship, what is the purpose, and who’s our customer and community

author: A
sentence: If you keep it level at that, you’ll always be able to find a middle ground

author: A
sentence: And it doesn’t mean that someone loses;  it means who has the biggest win

author: A
sentence: Sometimes you have to bring that back, and I think a really good chair will always bring back, ‘What is our purpose’, and will resolve that conflict

author: A
sentence: Because without diverse thinking, you’ll never get to that challenging thinking, and we need challenge on a board, we need it

author: Q
sentence: That’s great, thank you

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of where you’ve had this robust discussion?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely;  got one right now

author: A
sentence: But you can’t quote my board

author: A
sentence: You can say it’s a public hospital, but you can’t say the exact board

author: Q
sentence: Oh, no, no

author: Q
sentence: No, it’s confidential

author: A
sentence: It’s health

author: A
sentence: But I’m more than happy for you to write it down, yeah

author: A
sentence: We’ve just got to be careful because it’ll be obvious if I’m too specific

author: A
sentence: For me, there’s been a lot more females and younger generation

author: A
sentence: Boards have become, I think, dispelled from being something that was always quite exclusive and the same people with the same skills

author: A
sentence: I think we’ve broadened our thinking

author: A
sentence: And I actually think it’s been governments lobbying, and people like the Champions of Change and Women On Boards in particular, because they’ve been over that period out there advocating

author: A
sentence: So now there’s a lot of inner reflection, and I’m seeing matrix skills being used far more in the last, probably, five to six years

author: A
sentence: We have a clinical issue at the moment - and this was a fabulous example, in fact - of whether or not we allow a certain thing in a hospital that other hospitals clearly said - let’s just say it’s smoking - “We do not allow smoking”

author: A
sentence: I’m going to use that as the example, but it’s not the truth

author: A
sentence: “We do not allow smoking”, and it was critical, it could end up in death

author: A
sentence: But so can a lot of things

author: A
sentence: So can smoking;  smoke enough, you die

author: A
sentence: But we hadn’t put on our website that we condone 100% smoking

author: A
sentence: And the reason was, we had at this particular health facility customers would come from prisons, backgrounds of drugs, really tough environments because of where geographically it’s positioned

author: A
sentence: We would have to turn those people away and no-one else will take them if we put that statement on there

author: A
sentence: Whereas other hospitals put it on, and if they’re caught smoking, they’re sent home, even if it’s 2 in the morning

author: A
sentence: But for our customers, where the hell are they going to go, and we need to help them get better to get back to a really good social environment

author: A
sentence: So we made a decision, we condone it, absolutely, but we didn’t advertise it

author: A
sentence: Instead, we managed it

author: A
sentence: If someone did smoke, yes, they could die from that last cigarette because one’s going to get you and it could be during your time at our hospital

author: A
sentence: But we said we would rather sit with them and try to convince them not to smoke, and put all these things in place - low tar cigarettes, e-cigarettes, whatever they might be

author: A
sentence: “We will stand with you to make sure you don’t fall over from that last cigarette and have the heart machine ready”

author: A
sentence: We put in every possible thing, and we will actually spend more time with you, and we had it all documented, what were all the things to do if we saw someone smoking

author: A
sentence: Certainly when we brought them in and we inducted them, we said, “We do not allow smoking”

author: A
sentence: But we know they’re smoking anyway

author: A
sentence: Look at them, that’s why they’re in hospital

author: Q
sentence: So harm mitigation?

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: But we were not prepared to say, as a hospital, “We are not going to accept patients who smoke in our hospitals”

author: Q
sentence: Because you know your community

author: A
sentence: Exactly, exactly

author: A
sentence: And geographically, the people who needed to come to our hospital would have been turned away

author: Q
sentence: And that was the point of your service

author: A
sentence: And a particular board member brought it onto herself, and she didn’t realise - she said a patient could die with that last cigarette

author: A
sentence: It wasn’t a cigarette, it was more serious

author: A
sentence: We said, “But what about all the other patients who could fall over and die?  Or who could jump over the damn ledge and suicide?”

author: A
sentence: Just because everyone else said that’s their one thing because it’s socially not acceptable to smoke anymore

author: A
sentence: Patients die every day in hospital

author: A
sentence: We’re always at risk

author: Q
sentence: With the gender diversity, we’ve then got a skills mix coming in which measures things like -

author: A
sentence: And so she had only thought about - and she absolutely lobbied every director to say, “We don’t have this on our website, and everybody else says” - “and why are we accepting people who smoke”

author: A
sentence: We actually went and we brought the CEO and the operational head of clinical to come in, and they said, “We’d probably do more because those other people are still smoking and they’re all turning a blind eye”

author: A
sentence: Because, unfortunately, any habit you’re going to hide, so we’d rather not hide it, and we’d rather help

author: A
sentence: Work with it

author: A
sentence: And it nearly came to the point where they started to lobby other people, and it was the health people that started to say, “Oh my god, we were allowing smoking?”, and we said no - and so it was the diverse thinkers, actually, on the board

author: A
sentence: It was those of us who weren’t clinical that said, “Hang on, no offence, what about all these other deaths that could happen?”

author: A
sentence: And then we brought in - we said, “No, we need evidence, we’ve got to be prepared that someone could always die in our very specialised hospital, always”

author: A
sentence: So you’ve got to be aware our brand could get hurt

author: A
sentence: But the duty of care says not just to our staff

author: A
sentence: Our staff have a whole process that we would feel comfortable - and we asked the staff this one question, the head of the whole clinical, “Would you be prepared to go up to the coroner’s court or coroner’s hospital” - whatever it’s called, I don’t know what it is

author: Q
sentence: Coroner’s court

author: A
sentence: “Hand on heart and say, ‘We did everything we could and we have no guilt’”, and they said, “Absolutely”

author: A
sentence: And I said, “As long as that’s the culture for the staff, that we’re not forcing them to do something they feel is wrong”

author: A
sentence: And we were able to actually dissipate the issue

author: Q
sentence: And you could indemnify, obviously

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: A
sentence: Sorry, it’s a long example

author: A
sentence: I think it absolutely describes robust discussion

author: A
sentence: And if it hadn’t had us non-clinical people on that director’s thing, that would have gone on our website, we would have turned away all those patients

author: Q
sentence: And it’s fantastic because it goes back to your elements of the functioning of the board, how diversity plays a role at those -

author: A
sentence: Do you know some of the new ones?  What was traditionally - I didn’t even see skills matrixes 12 years ago

author: A
sentence: Now I’m seeing that we’ve got to keep up with what’s happening in the broader environment

author: A
sentence: Because most companies are in a global environment to some extent, or being influenced by disrupters, by the digital footprint out there, by fraud

author: A
sentence: So I’m seeing a lot more looking at understanding our customer base, but also the broader environment

author: A
sentence: And it was me and a few others that said, “Duty of care, risks are much bigger than that”

author: A
sentence: And our staff

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: Is it affecting our culture, but, no, it was the opposite

author: A
sentence: And what was so beautiful, our culture said, “We’re the only place that takes them”

author: A
sentence: These people would be on the street dying

author: A
sentence: And that’s why I was so proud of the staff for how - it was the only time I allowed operational through the CEO to bring in for this particular issue, but we had to

author: A
sentence: We had to hear it as directors

author: Q
sentence: Yes, exactly

author: Q
sentence: And there are other stakeholders, like professional bodies, that might - professional health regulation, professional bodies, their indemnity insurers and things like that

author: Q
sentence: So you negotiated that as well so that the operations were supported

author: A
sentence: We did

author: A
sentence: We basically said the fact we haven’t said anything does not mean we do or don’t support

author: A
sentence: We have a process that will stand up, and we made sure our process would stand up

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: So that’s just to show how it’s multilayered

author: A
sentence: It was fabulous

author: A
sentence: And it was only because - and otherwise it would have gone on the website, and we would have turned away the most needy people on the streets

author: Q
sentence: And your purpose would have been compromised

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Fantastic example

author: Q
sentence: Now, there’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and board function

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that cognitive diversity influences your board’s functioning?  Is this a positive or negative influence?  You’ve [already] [inaudible] 00:35:02

author: Q
sentence: Now, this is about potential new members

author: Q
sentence: Does your board consider ways to increase the diversity of the board?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: What does it do?  What are some ideas?

author: A
sentence: I’m seeing people wanting not just finance or commercial skills, but digital innovation skills, commercial skills with maybe a bit of marketing from a brand perspective because that’s so much more recognised how quickly that can dissipate

author: A
sentence: I’m seeing far more broad diversity from industry, so not just getting health people for a health board, and I’m seeing far more interesting balance in boards from a gender perspective

author: A
sentence: So we as the executive - we have an executive, and that moves as well

author: A
sentence: It’s the chairs of the board and a couple of committees we call the executive

author: A
sentence: And we sit there to look at who’s currently on the board, and we get everybody on our board to self-assess what skills they have

author: A
sentence: We identify a whole lot of skills either we need or don’t need, what we consider are skillsets, and we say, to start with, “Let’s see what skills we have”, and then we look at how broad that is

author: A
sentence: And even if we think we may not need those skills, to drive diversity of thought, we look at, ‘What’s our cross-function’, and if we think these other ones are completely missing and our community might need us to do that - and we should because we serve everyone - that’s what we look for

author: A
sentence: So we do evidence gap analysis to say, ‘Where is it we’re not strong’, and we try to balance that way

author: A
sentence: We also look at it from - so that’s the skills one that we always do

author: Q
sentence: Am I able to have a copy of your skills matrix?  Or is it confidential?

author: A
sentence: I wonder if I’ve got an old one

author: A
sentence: I actually don’t even know if I’ve got one

author: A
sentence: Because [inaudible] 00:36:22 a portal that we can’t share from

author: A
sentence: But if I could print one out, I think - I don’t know if I can because I think they’re protected

author: Q
sentence: Are they?  Yeah, see, I have no idea

author: A
sentence: You’ve not seen the skills matrix?

author: Q
sentence: On Google

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: If you send me an email and remind me

author: A
sentence: Not now, but I’m terrible when I go back, I’m going to get kicked by my staff, and I’ll see if I can find you one

author: A
sentence: And I’ll take names out

author: Q
sentence: So when do you want me to send it, next week?

author: A
sentence: The email?  Oh, no, you can just follow up with an email

author: Q
sentence: So might a health board get someone from, say, a mining industry?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, good, okay

author: A
sentence: I’m saying just send me an email to remind me

author: A
sentence: If I can - I’ll go on the portal and have a look

author: Q
