sentence: Thank you

author: A
sentence: I get to my emails within a week

author: Q
sentence: No urgency

author: A
sentence: No, and if I have I’ll send you one

author: Q
sentence: I understand, that’ll be great

author: A
sentence: But I’m not sure if I can get it

author: Q
sentence: Understand

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence your selection, who you select?

author: A
sentence: What an interesting question

author: A
sentence: Yes, absolutely

author: A
sentence: So on a health board, you are responsible - now, can I give you this as multi - if you’ve got time - and I’ll give you my experience

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I’ve been on health boards now for 12 years and I’ve never worked in health

author: A
sentence: And I was invited - and it was quite an innovative, specific board;  they didn’t want more of the same of what they had

author: A
sentence: They had people who understood the actual specialist skill which was hearing and children, and they actually needed other skills to think more broadly

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Because you’ve got - we are doing so well

author: A
sentence: Oh, good

author: A
sentence: Oh, thank you

author: A
sentence: So this is - can you ask that question again so I’ve got it clear?  Do outside influence - yes

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence your selection?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: On NFP, we were influenced by the people who put the money - the biggest philanthropists

author: A
sentence: Because they had the children who initially they’d built the facility for

author: A
sentence: Because there’s always philanthropists in NFPs

author: A
sentence: And I’ve been on quite a few different boards

author: A
sentence: On public boards for Victorian Government, it’s a government agency that gets the final say, and the most annoying thing about that is, if I can just say - so if you’re a health board, basically it’s DHHS, let’s just put it out there

author: A
sentence: If you’re a hospital, DHHS

author: A
sentence: You can submit with every reason - we actually submit our skillset and it’s all on the safe portal for government - show our reasoning, we give our reasons why we choose these people or [inaudible] 00:38:13 people on the board

author: A
sentence: You can be sure that they will not take our recommendation after all that work

author: A
sentence: What they’ll do is they’ll often put one of their own people on that board and substitute one of ours out

author: A
sentence: And I’ve seen it - off the record - many times

author: A
sentence: But don’t ask me why

author: A
sentence: And there’s never a reason why

author: A
sentence: And when we see the person they give us, it’s not trying to fill those skillsets up is all I’m going to say

author: A
sentence: So, yes, there are other people that you have to get approved on

author: A
sentence: On another board I sat on which was more education, it was more the members - the students, the members - that influenced to some degree removing people off the board

author: A
sentence: So I’ve seen both

author: Q
sentence: The members of the -

author: A
sentence: Well, that was CPA

author: A
sentence: I’ve got to be very careful

author: A
sentence: They basically said - because they own the company

author: A
sentence: So when it’s the -

author: Q
sentence: Own shareholders - stakeholders -

author: A
sentence: And they actually approached me and said, “Look, we need your particular treasury and procurement skills”, which was - I didn’t even really - thought about it

author: A
sentence: And they said, “Because we keep getting the same male accountants that do the same thing, auditing and risk, and we want a different perspective”, so that’s how they came to me

author: A
sentence: Let’s call them stakeholders

author: A
sentence: They’re stakeholders

author: A
sentence: And that’s happening now

author: A
sentence: They’re voting for directors not to be renewed on boards, and this is something new

author: A
sentence: Because of digital media - and I think it’s a great thing - social media, and accessibility to voting rights, et cetera, people are actually voting people off boards, and this is new

author: A
sentence: I actually experienced that on a board

author: A
sentence: And rightly so or not, it doesn’t matter

author: A
sentence: But it was something that - we had to listen to our stakeholders, so that’s the new thing

author: A
sentence: So I have seen all different things happen

author: A
sentence: But then have they listened on ASX-listed boards in the past?  Maybe not, but now they’re having to

author: A
sentence: It’s a new environment

author: Q
sentence: Radically new

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process?  For example, between, on the one hand, obtaining a good culture, collegiate fit, and on the other, to avoid groupthink?

author: A
sentence: Brilliant question, brilliant

author: A
sentence: On one of my first boards, I was very privileged that - we’d decided - and we raised the funds through a sponsorship, philanthropic whatever it was, so as not to spend the kids’ money

author: A
sentence: We recognised that was occurring to some degree, that the groupthink was too influential, but we needed the groupthink because it was a very specialised facility

author: A
sentence: What we did was we brought someone from outside, who was a facilitator, to take us off-site as a board to explain - without even knowing too much about what we did - what was the criticality of not falling into groupthink, and so they helped us drive our strategy

author: A
sentence: By using a facilitator, it helped us stop that groupthink

author: A
sentence: Because we had to challenge the strategy, but the strategy was just very much the same thinking

author: A
sentence: And I’d only recently come on the board, and they started to try and bring diverse people, but what they did was - this external facilitator, being an independent, helped break that

author: A
sentence: And they stayed with us for board meetings for the next year

author: Q
sentence: So you had coaching for over a year?

author: A
sentence: Exactly, but they also coached the CEO

author: A
sentence: Because they were such a specialist

author: A
sentence: Because often you’ll find the CEO - and we recognise - the CEO helps set the agenda for a board, let’s be honest

author: A
sentence: But it was coming from them as much as from us that we were always talking the same things

author: A
sentence: And we said, “No, we’ve got to get brave, how do we do this”

author: A
sentence: So it wasn’t just to coach us, it was to help coach the CEO to think broadly and what were the true issues that they should be bringing to the board

author: A
sentence: They helped the CEO recognise what were the really big items that we could help stewards

author: A
sentence: We did it on both areas

author: A
sentence: And, I tell you what, it worked magnificently

author: A
sentence: But we slowly weaned them out so they became less and less influential, but they watched to make sure we had adopted the thinking

author: A
sentence: And I was so privileged to be a part of that so early in my directorship that I’ve carried it ever since

author: A
sentence: I’ve often said, “Get an external, just even for a day for us”

author: A
sentence: Because it’s pointless you all going into a strategy meeting with the same thing

author: A
sentence: And so I find that if you bring an external - a good one, and there’s the question, ‘How do you find a good one’, but they’re out there

author: A
sentence: Get someone to challenge your thinking, but also who recognises, ‘Is it coming from the board or is it coming from the CEO driving the board’

author: A
sentence: And they were the ones that recognised, ‘It’s coming from the board, yes, but it’s coming from the CEO;  we need to work on both’

author: A
sentence: And it worked terrifically

author: Q
sentence: Is there any way I could interview someone like that?

author: Q
sentence: We’re recording, okay

author: Q
sentence: 20D, thank you so much for agreeing to be interviewed for our study

author: Q
sentence: I just have a few questions before we get into it

author: Q
sentence: So you’re female; discipline background?

author: A
sentence: And I think they were trying to balance it, also, from a female point of view because the finance and risk team in particular had far more males than females

author: A
sentence: I think they thought broadly, and I think there’d been a change in chair as well, and they wanted to bring in different skillsets so that’s where that came from

author: A
sentence: And although I’ve been on health boards, I’ve done that probably because it is something quite lateral to my day job, the industries I’ve been in, and I feel that I can be that diverse thinker in the room

author: A
sentence: Sorry?

author: Q
sentence: Any way I could interview someone like that?

author: A
sentence: Who’s a facilitator for boards?  They’re not in Victoria, that’s the only problem

author: Q
sentence: We’ll talk about later -

author: A
sentence: All right

author: A
sentence: You can put that on the email and I’ll see what I can do

author: A
sentence: But I don’t even know if they’re still - it’s about 10 years ago, and I’m not sure they haven’t retired or even if they’re alive

author: A
sentence: Let me check

author: A
sentence: They were a bit older

author: A
sentence: You never know

author: Q
sentence: Yes, and they probably won’t donate their time

author: A
sentence: Oh, you never know

author: Q
sentence: Yep, they might, their swansong

author: Q
sentence: Do the boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to managing or building diversity, and so what are they?

author: A
sentence: Could you say that again, sorry?

author: Q
sentence: What are the barriers that any boards you’re working on have to building diversity?  What’s holding them back?

author: Q
sentence: And you value that?

author: A
sentence: Look, you tend to have on boards - and this is another one that I fell into years ago

author: A
sentence: There were people that were - given so much of their time to the board, and could you chop them?  Do not recommend them for renewal

author: A
sentence: It’s that courage to say, “How much of this is occurring”

author: A
sentence: And it’s very difficult, if they’ve committed themselves, and particularly when they retire, in my opinion

author: A
sentence: And so often you needed to swap out men to bring in women, or swap out the white - someone told me the term at the AICD recently is “stale white bread”

author: A
sentence: I said, “I’ve never heard that in all my career”

author: A
sentence: I only heard that a week or two ago

author: A
sentence: “Stale white bread”, which means males that are white

author: A
sentence: And I said - and they called themselves that

author: A
sentence: I said, “I’ve never heard that term”

author: A
sentence: But do you get that sort of older, “This I my job, I’ve earnt it”

author: A
sentence: How do you break that?  How do you break having too much of that and non-diverse?  And that was really hard

author: A
sentence: And I saw this in one of my early boards, that they expected a third tenure

author: A
sentence: And to be honest, I wouldn’t have given them one

author: A
sentence: I actually thing second tenures are great on a three-year term, I really do

author: A
sentence: Because I think it takes a year, maybe, to learn to listen, new on a board

author: A
sentence: It takes second year to get the courage

author: A
sentence: You’re still the new kid

author: A
sentence: Until you’re into that third year or second tenure, you’re still pretty much the new one if you have someone come off every year, which is what you’re meant to do, say, on a 10-person board

author: A
sentence: But once you’re talking that third term, does everybody get a third term?  Or do you get brave and say, “We’ve got enough three to six year people, we probably only need one if that”

author: A
sentence: Things are moving too quickly and they’re probably not coming on the journey

author: A
sentence: And that’s the thing

author: A
sentence: I find tenure and that commitment, people aren’t brave enough to say that that skillset - they don’t look at the skillset, they look at the person, that’s it

author: A
sentence: They haven’t thought about this

author: A
sentence: They look at the person and say, “Oh, but they’ve given so much to the industry”, and, “Oh my god, they’ve given us six years of their life and they expect to be back on”

author: A
sentence: But if we’ve got a bit of that already, we need this new world thinking

author: A
sentence: How do we get it?  Well, they’ve had their time

author: A
sentence: And that’s one of the hugest barriers I find, is people are not brave enough

author: A
sentence: And more so if they’re the chair, if they’ve been the chair or if they are the chair

author: A
sentence: And the other thing I’ve found very stagnant is we might have three-year terms for directors, but crikey, I’ve seen chairs that have sat there for six years

author: A
sentence: Don’t say that ain’t still happening because it is

author: Q
sentence: How do you get chairs off?

author: A
sentence: Well, you’ve got to have a policy that says their tenure is one year or two years

author: A
sentence: And I think one year’s too short for a chair, I think two years is perfect

author: A
sentence: But that’s just what I’m feeling

author: A
sentence: But it’s very difficult

author: Q
sentence: Sorry, there’s a name of a document that frames the governance of the board

author: Q
sentence: What’s it called again?

author: A
sentence: Well, the governance -

author: Q
sentence: Is it a constitution or something?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, absolutely

author: A
sentence: Oh, yes

author: A
sentence: Constitution, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Is that where that’s written?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: And it has tenure, and it should have the chair tenure as well

author: A
sentence: Now, I have been on a board where it was annual renewal, and they had two deputies, and it was expected - now, I was also on a committee where I was the president, and your second term was very rare, but sometimes your own people asked you to do a second, but you’d never do a third

author: A
sentence: You had to let the next people for thinking, and for chairing, and for stewarding

author: A
sentence: I think that’s as critical as the constituents on the board

author: Q
sentence: Okay, the chair -

author: A
sentence: The chair position also having a tenure period

author: A
sentence: I just think that changes and keeps you alive

author: A
sentence: Because otherwise you fall into a pattern

author: A
sentence: But I can tell you now, I haven’t seen enough of it

author: Q
sentence: So that is a barrier

author: A
sentence: An absolute barrier

author: Q
sentence: And gender targets and quotas aren’t going to touch the chair

author: A
sentence: Isn’t that interesting?  Well, I think tenure full stop has to be looked at very seriously for the chair

author: Q
sentence: So we’ve got targets, but we need tenure

author: Q
sentence: That’s the gap

author: Q
sentence: What does it give you?

author: A
sentence: Tenure, particularly for the chair

author: A
sentence: I think that’s the gap for the chair

author: A
sentence: And maybe it’s not just tenure for the chair;  maybe it’s gender for the chair and rotating that for diversity of thought

author: A
sentence: But I think by approaching tenure, you’d get that if your board is diverse thinking

author: A
sentence: Because you can only get three stale white bread

author: A
sentence: You can’t, because we’ve got a diverse board

author: A
sentence: And I think that the chair position is the critical position for any committee or board

author: Q
sentence: This really brings us to our last question, which is:  finally, looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: That nobody has a position on a board more than six years, two terms, without it being by absolute exception, that’s fine;  that we rotate chairs;  that we look at the number on boards and we be brave to challenge that maybe each three years

author: A
sentence: Because why are they 10, why are they 12?  Nobody ever tells you why

author: A
sentence: How did we arrive at this?  Should there be 20 for a year because we’ve got a tough year and we need all this diversity, or should there be five?

author: A
sentence: That diversity of thought and the skills matrix are absolutely part of every constitution;  that all these are addressed in a constitution, and that we absolutely look at age as well in part of this

author: A
sentence: And that we relate it to our purpose

author: A
sentence: So our boards must be reliant, I think, to the, ‘What is it we’re trying to achieve’

author: A
sentence: And then I think the global community

author: A
sentence: And maybe there’ll come a time with virtual reality that we’ll look at global boards, global thinking

author: A
sentence: And that’s the one that I think that even now, there’s this absolute rule - and this is another thing that I haven’t mentioned that annoys me, and I don’t mind it, but we restrict people with young kids, I feel, because you have to be there, and the timing of the board is so critical, and it’s got to be in the evening, and there’s got to be red wine, and blah-blah

author: A
sentence: That takes out so many mothers

author: A
sentence: And for me it was the biggest challenge that there were evening boards, and I could never be on more than one or two, and I was on two

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve got kids, and I just felt - and so there weren’t many of me on these boards

author: A
sentence: Because it’s just too hard

author: A
sentence: Weeknights - god damn, the kids and [inaudible] 00:50:20

author: A
sentence: And let alone that 25% are single mums

author: A
sentence: Forget that

author: A
sentence: They have to get babysitters and - oh my god, it gets so hard

author: A
sentence: But, look, I did it, and I did it as a single mum, and I did do it with babysitters because I really, really love boards, the challenge, and I wanted to help this thing

author: A
sentence: But I think we’ve got to get away from that and say, “What is the outcome you’re trying to achieve, how do we address that to make people feel like they’re part of a group”

author: A
sentence: And maybe sometimes all being in the same room isn’t the best thing

author: A
sentence: Maybe we are better to have people in different geographies

author: Q
sentence: And we’ve got virtual video, teleconferencing, whatever

author: A
sentence: Teleconferencing

author: A
sentence: Imagine then, holograms will be in

author: A
sentence: Or whatever it is

author: Q
sentence: Oh, wouldn’t that be great?

author: A
sentence: I’ve got so much out of this because - I always think these places that I’ve been on boards have a purpose, and they’ve always known their purpose

author: A
sentence: They’ve been very purpose-driven

author: A
sentence: So for me, even though I don’t have that particular purpose directly relating to me - such as hearing, I didn’t have a child or a family member

author: A
sentence: Maybe some selective hearing, but I didn’t have that cause

author: A
sentence: It allowed me to give back to a cause and an industry that I wasn’t currently contributing to

author: A
sentence: So very rewarding for me as well, but also learning from those other people on the board that didn’t have the same skillset as me

author: A
sentence: And so that’s why I’m saying I think we have to challenge all of it

author: A
sentence: And then maybe challenge is stewardship really - is even a 10-person board the right thing with a mix of externals?  What is it?  I would love us to do design thinking and say, “Well, what is a board, is it 10 people?  What is it?”, so I think that that’s where we’ve got to challenge

author: A
sentence: Because at the moment we’re challenging the gender

author: A
sentence: But, okay, the constitution say you must have a board, what is a board?  And maybe we should have a few kids on that board, or maybe we should have a few people from overseas - I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I don’t know, I haven’t done the design thinking

author: A
sentence: But let’s challenge, ‘What is a board’

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: That’s fantastic

author: Q
sentence: To enable that to happen, you’ve mentioned the constitution

author: A
sentence: Well, it’s also broader, it’s the company directors - not directors, the corporate law

author: Q
sentence: Corporate law

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s called the - oh, god

author: A
sentence: I even knew -

author: Q
sentence: That’s all right

author: A
sentence: The corporations law

author: A
sentence: The corporations law said, “If you’re this sort of entity, you’re required to have this sort of da-da-da”

author: A
sentence: But we need to challenge it

author: A
sentence: And particularly for government boards

author: A
sentence: They need to go back to design thinking more than anyone

author: Q
sentence: That’s a very hard one, with all the politics at the moment

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I know

author: Q
sentence: So fantastic

author: Q
sentence: Loved it

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: I really like that

author: Q
sentence: That’s sort of a new spin just today, about how being on a diverse board benefits the board, the directors themselves

author: A
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: So how does it benefit the - I should ask you first, do the quant

author: Q
sentence: This is our quant

author: Q
sentence: Let’s say 10 is extremely important and one is not important

author: Q
sentence: How important is diversity of a board?

author: A
sentence: Oh, it’s 10

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been important?  Or is this a recent phenomenon?

author: A
sentence: An accountant, Bachelor of Business

author: A
sentence: I can only talk, I suppose - no, I can actually speak about boards that I’ve worked in companies because I’ve always had to prepare reports and whatever to boards

author: A
sentence: I’ve reported to boards as well, obviously, and I still do to this day;  as in, I prepare - either CFO or director or finance or even GM, you’re always preparing information for boards

author: A
sentence: And I’ve done that for many, many years in some form

author: A
sentence: I don’t think it was as important when I started

author: A
sentence: Maybe seeing a bit of board culture and consistency of how they were formed I think has become more important in the last - again, I’m going to say half a dozen years

author: Q
sentence: Half a dozen?  Okay, so probably -

author: A
sentence: For me, really critical

author: Q
sentence: What’s that, 2013?

author: A
sentence: I really feel it’s been - and I think Women On Boards has had a huge drive on this more than AICD, I’m going to say that

author: A
sentence: And Women On Boards in particular have been in the forefront of advocacy

author: A
sentence: And I think I became a member of them probably about six, eight years ago - maybe eight, maybe a bit longer

author: A
sentence: And I’ve seen the work they’ve done and just how far they’ve come in such a short time

author: A
sentence: I don’t think they’ve been around more than 20 years

author: A
sentence: Maybe 10, I’m not sure;  you’d know more than me

author: A
sentence: But, boy, they’ve made a difference

author: Q
sentence: So why do you think board diversity is so important?

author: A
sentence: It’s diversity of thought

author: A
sentence: For me it’s not gender;  it’s thought

author: A
sentence: And so I look for, again, that matrix of skills, but also the way we think, and the industries we’ve come from, and the exposure we’ve had

author: A
sentence: And I think the best example is you know in your own team, if you just keep employing the same people with the same skillsets, with the same experience, you’ll just get the same thinking, and nobody’s going to challenge

author: A
sentence: So for me, I look for design thinking where we are brave enough to ask someone without the skillset the discussion point and what’s their opinion, and you’ll nearly always get a fresh idea that you haven’t thought of

author: Q
sentence: That’s real out-of-the-square thinking

author: Q
sentence: And are you on Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and that’s why you do it

author: A
sentence: And I always think to myself, ‘The board has’ - from AICD, there were two things I always took away from all the years I’ve been involved

author: A
sentence: One was you’re the stewardship;  you’re the stewardship for the company

author: A
sentence: But the other one that’s always resonated with me was the duty of care

author: A
sentence: Because in most companies, it’s your people that make the difference

author: A
sentence: And that duty of care does not need the thinking of the industry;  they need the thinking of the people

author: A
sentence: Because you drive the people, it drives the processes, and the systems enable

author: A
sentence: And I think that in boards gone past, they perhaps forgot that, and that’s why the cultures got very messy, and we’re now seeing the horrible position we’re seeing in some of the most - what were trusted brands in Australia

author: A
sentence: And so I’m saying, ‘Well, where was the diversity thinking and where was the duty of care’

author: A
sentence: Because if they had’ve had a duty of care to their people, the culture would have been different

author: Q
sentence: And the duty of care to their people, how - sorry, how is that part of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Well, because if you think about it, you have such a range of people in all these organisations

author: A
sentence: You have to think about how broad your employee base is

author: A
sentence: And I think that with all these corporates, when you really hone in on what are our jobs, that’s culture

author: A
sentence: And so they say if you’re purpose-led with a good culture, you’re three-quarters of the way there

author: Q
sentence: Because that brings - that’s the duty of care coming out

author: A
sentence: It is, it is

author: Q
sentence: Because you understand your consumer, your stakeholders

author: A
sentence: Exactly, and it’s the community, the broader community

author: A
sentence: It’s the people

author: A
sentence: So it’s not just employees

author: A
sentence: You say it’s the employees, it’s your stakeholders, it’s your members, it’s your customers, and the broader community, and you keep drilling it down

author: A
sentence: And that’s where I think diversity of thought encompasses a far better way of - rather than just concentrating on one element such as the shareholder

author: A
sentence: You’ve missed the whole point

author: A
sentence: And the culture will change

author: A
sentence: We know that culture is king, we know this

author: A
sentence: And what we’re seeing in the press now, in my opinion, we’re seeing poor culture

author: A
sentence: And if you look back on a lot of those boards, particularly traditionally, not more recently - we always home in on who’s sitting on the board today, but that’s not fair

author: A
sentence: Some of them have just walked on those boards in the last year or two

author: A
sentence: You have to look back at least a dozen, if not 20, years

author: A
sentence: What was the culture in the board themselves

author: A
sentence: And you’ll see, it was the same players in many cases

author: A
sentence: There wasn’t diversity

author: A
sentence: You’ve thrown diversity in the last year and they’re copping it

author: A
sentence: No, culture’s not built overnight

author: A
sentence: And so that’s why I think that now we’ve got this really good understanding and we’re getting the evidence to say, “Let’s look a little bit further back of what that culture was on the board and was that reflective of the company as well”

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So can we go to the skill matrix you were talking about, the modern one

author: Q
sentence: What’s the current one?  How does it differ to, say, one that was used 10 years ago?

author: A
sentence: Well, sometimes they didn’t exist 10 years ago

author: A
sentence: It was more aligned to what are the functions of the business, rather than, ‘What are our duties as a consumer or as a global participant in the world’

author: A
sentence: And I think what I’m seeing now is we’re far more aware of not what’s in our sphere as this industry

author: A
sentence: So in superannuation - and I don’t want this to be the example, but if you were to think of a bank, do you just put bankers on the board?  So any financial institution, do you just put experts on?  No

author: A
sentence: We’ve got to get away from that, and that’s what they used to do

author: A
sentence: And even on health boards, I saw it too often

author: A
sentence: So now what we’re saying is, “No, because we’re part of a far bigger stratosphere, we have to think about what’s affecting us and what’s disrupting us and what’s coming at us;  who are our stakeholders, who are our people, what is our culture, and where’s our place in the community”

author: A
sentence: And this is the more global thing I think that’s coming now, and so you want people who are broad thinkers as well as experts

author: Q
sentence: And so the matrix will measure those kinds of dimensions?

author: A
sentence: And so the matrix is starting to do that

author: A
sentence: So now we’re saying, “What is coming at us”, and I still hadn’t seen it to this extent

author: A
sentence: I would love us to think futuristic and say, broader, “Where do we want to develop for the next” - we want to drive the global picture in 30 years

author: A
sentence: They’re the ones I’m not seeing yet on a matrix

author: A
sentence: We tend to look more current and align it to our next year or two strategy

author: A
sentence: Still a bit too immediate for me, and I think when we get braver, boards will start to say, “Well, let’s think like a futurist”

author: Q
sentence: And have one on the board, maybe

author: Q
sentence: Or think that way

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Or planning day

author: A
sentence: Or on a strategy day, bring in the futurist

author: A
sentence: Because I think everybody just waits for things to hit them, but the really brave companies are the ones who are young and free, almost, without these heavy boards and who are out there, saying, “I’m going to create the future”

author: A
sentence: And that’s where a lot of the corporates I’d love to see - and the public hospitals, et cetera -get to

author: A
sentence: Think beyond that three-year plan

author: Q
sentence: So you’ve explained why you see board diversity as so important, so we’ll move to do you think that there’s any situational context where it’s not important?

author: Q
sentence: What are they?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Sorry, impossible

author: Q
sentence: Some people have said to me it is exactly in situations of high uncertainty and risk - because I said, for example, that, and they said that’s exactly when you need diversity

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: This current world, there’s no room for it

author: A
sentence: Just no room for it

author: Q
sentence: You’re sounding like the start-ups

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed some directors from start-ups

author: A
sentence: Oh, really?

author: Q
sentence: And you have an energy like theirs

author: A
sentence: Oh, they love board work

author: A
sentence: It’s something that I would love to develop more

author: A
sentence: Because I’m now placed where I really get it and I’ve learnt

author: A
sentence: Twelve years ago, would I have fought like this?  No

author: Q
sentence: So now, let’s sit back, what does board diversity mean to you?

author: A
sentence: Diversity of thought;  a very well thought-out and constantly reviewed - like, annually reviewed - broader global picture;  having the right people at the table to help us navigate and also plan

author: A
sentence: So it’s having that broad thinking for immediate, but also for beyond the immediate

author: A
sentence: It has to have a lot of different skills, in my opinion, and the diversity has to be not just gender;  it has to be gender of thinking

author: A
sentence: And that’ll come from - depending on what the board is, what it’s stewarding -what the needs are

author: A
sentence: So I always go back, “Who’s your customer”

author: A
sentence: And if your customer is only women, I still wouldn’t have a board with only women, but I’d want people to think about our customer and challenge that

author: A
sentence: So if our customer is a very diverse racial group, I would absolutely insist that we, anyway, look at that as critical that we don’t try to all represent but think even more laterally

author: A
sentence: So what is our customer, or our member, or our stakeholder, or the broader community and how are we balancing that

author: A
sentence: Well, currently I’m on one board, which is a public hospital board

author: A
sentence: It’s called Tweddle;  it’s a Vic Government-owned public hospital

author: Q
sentence: You said, “Gender of thinking”

author: Q
sentence: What do you mean by that?

author: A
sentence: Sorry, what did I say?

author: Q
sentence: Gender of thinking?

author: A
sentence: Diversity of thinking, which is - the different genders think differently

author: A
sentence: What I’m saying is that the gender of thinking, for me, is about how do different gender - and not just male/female, but also LGTBI, that whole - how do people relate, how do we relate

author: A
sentence: So it’s not just, ‘You’re a male, I’m a female, we’ve done it’

author: Q
sentence: And social networks that people have, is that important?  Is that part of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Now, that’s a really good question

author: A
sentence: On health boards, that’s quite a critical one

author: A
sentence: Why I say that is because we’re always trying to advocate, and they’re always competing with other areas for budgets and for philanthropic funding

author: A
sentence: For both NFP and many industries, your social network is critical, so they will actually choose in many cases

author: A
sentence: But I’m going to draw the line there and say I’ve also known of boards - which I haven’t been on but I’m very aware of them in a competing space - who only put people on because of their social networks

author: A
sentence: And it’s because of that philanthropic network that they’re being asked to go on, but doesn’t necessarily mean they have director skills

author: A
sentence: And so that’s often been the traditional case

author: A
sentence: And I didn’t know if this would come up, but off the record, I really believe this has been part of the problem

author: A
sentence: Do we think of diverse thinking, or do we - in many cases, if you look at boards, the people on there have deep pockets, and so they’ll help drive that funding

author: A
sentence: And that might be essential

author: A
sentence: But often that’ll be part of the thinking, and I’ve often found there was an old school of very wealthy people who are being invited to boards because of their social standing, in their words

author: Q
sentence: And their economic standing

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve been on other boards?

author: Q
sentence: So that has a place, but it can’t replace -

author: A
sentence: Well, it can have a place in some very competitive environments and philanthropic-related areas

author: A
sentence: But should they be on a board?  My question is, ‘Or should they be on’ - and this is what we did on one of our boards, we recognised they weren’t the board members

author: A
sentence: Their thinking weren’t the board thinking;  they were the foundation

author: A
sentence: So sometimes I think this where we’ve got to get smarter with what defines a good director

author: A
sentence: Deep pockets can’t be a criteria for most boards

author: A
sentence: It’s got to be a little bit better than that

author: A
sentence: Do they have the discipline, do they have the training, do they have experience

author: A
sentence: Maybe you put one invitee on there for the skills matrix because they think differently, because they do think differently

author: A
sentence: But is that right?

author: A
sentence: So that’s where I think there was a lot of these social networks that were protecting each other, putting each other on boards

author: A
sentence: And that had to change as well, and I think that one - now we know to use your committees for that, or your advisories, or your foundation

author: A
sentence: And I’ve seen that move

author: Q
sentence: I want to just qualify here, you said, “I don’t want this to be used as an example”

author: Q
sentence: What -

author: A
sentence: Only from my boards

author: A
sentence: Specifically from my boards

author: Q
sentence: But we can use the bank -

author: A
sentence: Oh, yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: No, absolutely

author: A
sentence: But not specifically from the board I’ve been on

author: Q
sentence: No, no

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others?  Or do you see them as all reducible to different thinking?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t

author: A
sentence: I think that some are more critical, and I think I’m going to go back to where you’re placed in the broader community

author: A
sentence: The community - let’s just say - I know it’s not quite, but if it’s 50% male and female, well, clearly that’s going to be a huge criteria

author: A
sentence: If it’s racially, you have a lot of diverse ethnicity

author: A
sentence: Maybe that will be important as well

author: A
sentence: It’s who are you serving, and who do you want to serve, and who is the community that you’re impacting

author: Q
sentence: Now, you mentioned earlier that we’re all part of a global community

author: Q
sentence: How do you fit that in?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, so I’ve been on other health boards

author: A
sentence: I’ve been on boards for roughly about 12 years

author: A
sentence: Health boards, and an accounting board, and I have had a lot of committee work as well, with finance and risk committees attached to boards

author: A
sentence: Well, I think there’s very few industries now that aren’t able to be either disrupted or in part that innovation isn’t impacting

author: A
sentence: Be it because of online, be it because of fraud;  think really broadly

author: A
sentence: Be it because of competitiveness

author: A
sentence: The globe has really shrunk now that we can move goods within days, we don’t have to physically go places

author: A
sentence: So because of accessibility, I believe we’ve always got to look globally for most things

author: A
sentence: Now, for something like a hospital where your patients are your district, it’s still about accessibility, and what we’re seeing is people are moving more to tele practice

author: A
sentence: So even a hospital you think that is in - let’s just say Barwon, you say that’s your community, but it’s not because you can actually do things online now that you never could before

author: A
sentence: So you’re no longer all working in these tiny geographics

author: A
sentence: So globally, if somebody in China can tele practice as good as you, is that now your competitor?  And that’s why I say we’re all part of a global community

author: Q
sentence: Because I was thinking, Chinese medicine, we can all just opt out of -

author: A
sentence: Look at what’s happening with dentistry

author: A
sentence: People are literally going to Malaysia

author: Q
sentence: It’s cheaper

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so who would have thought that five years ago or 10 years ago?

author: Q
sentence: I know

author: A
sentence: So dentists now, some of their competitors are literally - they’re actually flying there because it’s cheaper;  it’s not even online

author: A
sentence: So I just think that the world has shrunk a little bit more

author: A
sentence: Now, there will be exceptions

author: A
sentence: Please understand, I know there’ll always be exceptions

author: A
sentence: But I think that if you can do health for something like a hospital with a specialist skill - and Cochlear is a fabulous example of this

author: A
sentence: The Chinese are absolutely competing against Cochlear now

author: A
sentence: And we had the market completely -

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely cornered

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Just let me check

author: Q
sentence: 21D, I think I need a consent form from you

author: Q
sentence: Is that -

author: A
sentence: So have a look and let me know and I can resend it to you if you -

author: A
sentence: Yeah well I won't name names but I had a situation some years ago where we needed to replace or appoint a person to the CEO position in a particular business

author: A
sentence: Fundamentally that business was involved in women’s fashion

author: A
sentence: I had a pretty strong view that the CEO should be a woman and the owners of the business didn't share that view Margot

author: A
sentence: So that caused some debate, ultimately they got their way because they owned the business but that was – there was some conflict on the board around that situation

author: Q
sentence: Okay so did the resolution, if you could call it that, or the decision outcome, was that really made because of the power of the, let's say the – because they owned the business, their ultimate power to make that decision?  Did they resort to power tactics?  Do you know what I mean?  Was that why that decision finally came down on the side of not appointing a female CEO?  Or was there more discussion and agreement in the end?

author: A
sentence: Well it was ultimately agreed that they own the business and it's their money, but yeah there was a number of – there were discussions with various other members of the board

author: A
sentence: And ultimately it never came to a vote because ultimately they own the business so that's fine

author: A
sentence: But there was a minority of us that felt it was pretty important for the staff and the business and the perception of the business for a female to be appointed

author: A
sentence: The owners had a view and to say that no, we actually – we rate some of the other criteria other than diversity over a female

author: A
sentence: We rate some other criteria rather more highly than that and that's what we want to do, so we had some good discussions about whether that was the right way to rate things but ultimately they had their way Margot

author: Q
sentence: Was the chair one of the owners?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay so what role did the chair then play in that?  How did they manage the division in the group, in the board?

author: A
sentence: Well I think they were respectful

author: A
sentence: Everyone was invited to give their view and it was – early on it was pretty apparent that everyone wasn’t going to necessarily be aligned on that so there was another month passed, we all had some conversations outside and to various people and within the board

author: A
sentence: And the chair certainly did some work, had some conversations with members of the board themselves around this

author: A
sentence: We all sat back together and I think largely the positions were unchanged and respectful conversations and so on with the decision ultimately made Margot

author: A
sentence: So the chair did the right things but there was no doubt there was conflict, as there sometimes is on – conflict is a strong word but robust debate and different views which ultimately weren't reconciled

author: Q
sentence: Yeah so did everyone, like no one left the board, everyone felt respected you said was it?  Respected you said, they were respectful?

author: A
sentence: Yeah I think everyone felt respected for their views, there wasn't any fall out

author: A
sentence: People weren’t being fired from the board

author: A
sentence: It was respectful

author: Q
sentence: That's a really good example, thank you so much because actually getting a feel for how values, different values, different beliefs, different priorities, when they can't be reduced to a point, there is just a difference and one wins, one doesn't, how that's managed by the board in a way that's functional for the board

author: Q
sentence: And the role of the chair in that is really important so thank you so much, that was a really clear story for us to look at

author: Q
sentence: I'll find it, I'm really sorry about that

author: A
sentence: Well I hope that's useful

author: Q
sentence: Yeah it will be, you'll be surprised how useful those things can be

author: Q
sentence: So look, there's a lot of talk about this term cognitive diversity, but you can think about it as different approaches to problem solving, which you sort of alluded to at the beginning

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel that cognitive diversity influences your board’s functioning, whichever one you want to think about, all of them, some of them?

author: A
sentence: Does it?  Yes, it does absolutely

author: Q
sentence: And we've got here is this a positive or negative?

author: A
sentence: Well I think it's positive

author: Q
sentence: Definitely, yeah

author: Q
sentence: And we've talked about why

author: Q
sentence: Do you want to – is there any difference, because of your spread across different kinds of board, is there any difference between those different kinds of boards, the not for profit, the private small and the private big?

author: A
sentence: Yeah there is a difference, there are differences, and it's because of I suspect large – well I guess they have, particularly not for profits have some different objectives

author: A
sentence: It's fundamentally around service delivery and not [inaudible] 00:36:13 loss whereas the other boards I'm on are much more about financial outcomes Margot

author: A
sentence: So and the ones where they're not for profit really I would argue there's more cognitive diversity on those boards

author: A
sentence: [Inaudible] 00:36:32 the private boards are run by some extremely intelligent people, but they're much more – I mentioned similar corporate backgrounds, they'll have some different skill sets but really focused on capitalistic behaviour

author: A
sentence: The other boards are – the not for profit boards, there's a bigger spread of talent and broader spread of talent, possibly maybe not as deep a talent as on the other one

author: Q
sentence: I interviewed someone, they were from a start up, in a start up sort of situation, and only one, so only one person has said this and I've interviewed a few start ups

author: Q
sentence: And they talked about in the context of the private for profit, private profit orientated, the power and influence of the sources of capital in shaping, influencing board decisions

author: Q
sentence: Does that connect with you?

author: A
sentence: Sorry, the power of what sort of capital?

author: Q
sentence: The sources of capital, so for example -

author: A
sentence: No, no problem

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah

author: Q
sentence: -@ private equity

author: A
sentence: That's clearly enormous

author: Q
sentence: Okay so you've got corporate backgrounds dominating that private for profit sector -

author: A
sentence: Yes they do

author: Q
sentence: - and you've also got the influence of private equity sources of capital, private equity, is that right?

author: A
sentence: That's correct, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So how – can you talk to me a little, tell me a little bit about how the board in that for profit, private for profit sector manages the influence of the – so they've got their own goals for profit and they've got a strong corporate background, the members of the board, but then they've got the influence of this private equity organisation or institutions, whatever you want to – sources of capital

author: Q
sentence: Can you unpack that a little for me?

author: A
sentence: Well usually the founders of the business, the founders of the business use from idea to requiring capital to execute on their ideas, the start of sort of land

author: A
sentence: And there's absolutely no way forward unless they can find that capital

author: A
sentence: So hence responding to the goals of the people that derive in capital is vitally important otherwise there is just no future

author: A
sentence: In a more mature business, there are alternatives

author: A
sentence: You might just not grow as quickly or you might not – I'd rather be more environmentally conscious and I'm happy to forego maybe some short term profit to do that or I might – perhaps one of the members of the family that owns the business is very strong on women having appropriate access to high levels of management and so on and hence they'll champion that sort of outcome

author: A
sentence: I think most people these days on boards say, “Yeah we absolutely see the value, we can see the value in diversity, we can see the value in being a good environmental contributor, we can see the value in perhaps having a voice on some more contentious things around worker’s rights, the rights of people for a fair days wage,” and all those sorts of things

author: A
sentence: But the priority, how quickly those things are acted on and what sort of resources we put into those things on the short term, that's an area of debate

author: A
sentence: And there's not a road map really, there's not a book that gives you guidance on that, it's different people will have different views

author: Q
sentence: 21D, just a couple of demographics, you're discipline background?  What's your -

author: Q
sentence: That's interesting

author: Q
sentence: What I'm getting a sense of is that in this stage, with this start up stage, the early start up stage where we've got the idea and we're just trying to get to market, we're trying to get some capital for it, that the private equity company, they might be short term financial profit oriented priorities, that they can act almost like the imperatives, like the legal imperatives in the example you gave of trading while insolvent

author: Q
sentence: So it's almost like the diversity of a board and that richness of problem solving that can result, those benefits are almost lost in this situation or irrelevant because of this -

author: A
sentence: Yeah I think some of these benefits – I think yeah, there's an imperatives early on in – the imperative I chatted about earlier, that within – with a start up, the need for capital support, sadly, is pretty – extremely fundamental

author: A
sentence: And as you grow and have a bit more options -

author: Q
sentence: Autonomy

author: A
sentence: - autonomy develop, there is much more capacity to pursue some of these other attributes, which you could argue, and I think the great case to make, if you are able to do them anyway, maybe you should just be doing it because you won't get a better long term outcome

author: A
sentence: But sadly, in the early days, businesses are managed for the short term rather than the long term

author: A
sentence: I think some of the things that diversity brings are probably more long term optimised outcomes

author: A
sentence: If you're not in that situation Margot, then you don't necessarily have the luxury of pursuing those goals

author: Q
sentence: Yeah it's a power relation, granted short term hopefully, but it's a power relation while you're in that stage

author: A
sentence: It's a short term lower value that I survive, which is – you just have a different horizon

author: A
sentence: Well you're able to have a different horizon if that's another way of putting it

author: A
sentence: It's a better horizon and a higher value horizon, but it's not actually – if that option is that available to you, then you can't pursue it

author: Q
sentence: No however just like in your earlier example of the insolvency, it doesn't mean that a diverse board is not useful, it's just for that particular stage, that particular decision, it was in there, that particular decision it was irrelevant

author: Q
sentence: And you've got boards here who tend to be corporate background dominant because they are in that phase where there is not real autonomy, the driver or the responsibility of the board is to meet the short term financial imperatives of the source of capital

author: Q
sentence: And then once there's more autonomy, then the board needs to become more diverse

author: Q
sentence: So it's sort of like a lifecycle

author: A
sentence: Well absolutely, you just don't have the luxury of pursuing diversity until you get to a certain scale and capacity

author: A
sentence: It's just a bit like you're starting your own business selling lemonade at the front – well you won't have a nice diverse board to think about whether your lemonade is organically sourced and all the rest of it

author: A
sentence: You just have that -

author: Q
sentence: That luxury

author: A
sentence: It's not available to you, that option

author: A
sentence: I'm a chartered accountant, finance

author: Q
sentence: Okay that's great, thank you, that's really good

author: Q
sentence: Managing diversity, now we're moving toward the – we're 45 minutes in so we're nearly there

author: Q
sentence: When identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity?  You've explained that as an extension of the skills matrix so we'll move on

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence this selection process?  And you did say something about using recruitment organisations, is there anything else?  What about the – I know, with the start ups, because there's not – with the situation you were just talking about, the private equity situation, do they influence recruitment on the board?

author: A
sentence: Well they're usually sitting on – they'll have a couple of people from that private equity house on the board, so yes absolutely they'll influence that

author: Q
sentence: Anything else like that in the not for profit or -

author: A
sentence: Yeah well we're just doing that on another, about to look through new principals in the school I'm involved with

author: A
sentence: So we're actually doing – we have a search consultant about to engage, but we're also seeking – we're doing a CareMonkey survey with the parents from the school to get some input from those – because what we ultimately want [inaudible] 00:46:55 because they inform the views of the board around well what are we really looking for here, including diversity and so on and we're getting some input from that

author: A
sentence: And we want to be able to brief the search consultant as to well okay what do we think is important?  So they can bring back some people that look like – so we're trying to get soundings from [inaudible] 00:47:16 the obvious ones being the parents of the school, the alumni from the school, the senior executive team from the school, but also more broadly the staff

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: 21D, have you got any experience of having institutional investors on influencing your board decisions?  I mean like the major superannuation funds or something like that?

author: A
sentence: No I'm afraid I don't Margot

author: Q
sentence: No that's okay, it just prompted me to think of them

author: A
sentence: Yep sure

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process between, on the one hand, trying to obtain a good fit, a collegiate fit with your board, and on the other trying to avoid group think?

author: A
sentence: Yes I do

author: Q
sentence: And boards, there's a lot of talk about board diversity and the focus of this research is to talk to people who are on Australian boards or from organisations that influence people who are on boards

author: Q
sentence: And so my  understanding is you're on a number of boards, or on a board?

author: Q
sentence: How is that managed?

author: A
sentence: Well I think that's – obviously the chair has a key role to play in that and I think a lot of that is around the right board culture Margot

author: A
sentence: I think the constructive – what the board needs to have and the chair needs to create a constructive courteous challenging respectful environment

author: A
sentence: And you need a process that also provides people the opportunity to get together and share ideas but also the opportunity – well yeah, individual thought as well

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant, okay, that's good

author: Q
sentence: And so then that, with that culture, then it sort of removes the tension between those two things, is that right?

author: A
sentence: Yes [inaudible] 00:49:04

author: Q
sentence: Yeah beautiful

author: Q
sentence: And so are you a chair or have you been a chair?

author: A
sentence: I have been a chair on a number of them, yeah

author: Q
sentence: How have you sought to build that right culture?

author: A
sentence: Yeah well there's a range of – there's the whole I guess on-boarding, if that's the right – sort of it's in the induction, (a) do your homework to find suitable people to begin with, have the right criteria and values and so on, so it gets back to that values, that they want certain skills and we went certain values and certain behaviours as part of that matrix

author: A
sentence: So it's trying to find the right people, induct them in a strong way in terms of well this is what we expect, this is how we'll behave, we want feedback, so setting up their understanding

author: A
sentence: And then being pretty strong on encouraging – encourage all board members to contribute, encouraging people to give their best, being a good listener, being – not rushing through points even though you might think it's pretty obvious, take time to bring people along but also listen to alternative views

author: A
sentence: As I say it's around communication, culture, respect, and good process I think

author: Q
sentence: Does the, what do you call it, it's like the legislative framework for the board, constitution, does that have anything to do with this?

author: A
sentence: Well not constitutions from my perspective

author: A
sentence: But I think it's – on none of the boards I've been involved with, we haven't had a sort of written [inaudible] 00:51:16 the behaviour of the board that we expect, but I think there's a lot of literature and so on around about good functioning boards

author: A
sentence: We try to do – all the ones I'm on we try to do annual reviews, so how we're performing, and get survey – each of the board members to contribute and improve et cetera, et cetera

author: A
sentence: So behaviours are pretty well understood

author: A
sentence: I'm on two at the moment and I've been – I guess background really is I've been on – well I'm on two not for profits at the minute, but I've been on half a dozen private boards, ranging from a very large family group where I was actually [inaudible] 00:01:41 on the main board and on all the subsidiary boards, I was the director of the group

author: A
sentence: So very large organisation and I've been on three boards involving private equity backed businesses, and then just another couple of privately owned businesses as well

author: Q
sentence: Do the boards that you're familiar with have any barriers to managing or building diversity?  And how have you sought to overcome these barriers?

author: A
sentence: Yeah well the barriers in – I think all the boards have barriers to do certain things Margot

author: A
sentence: I think the private ones I'm on, they tend to be more compartmentally focused and they don't have – I guess the stakeholder groups ultimately in those sort of boards are more limited

author: A
sentence: They're less concerned public perception

author: A
sentence: Their activity is not really in the public domain, they're less concerned about what others may think of them

author: A
sentence: Therefore to say, “Look we really need someone who's black,” which is not – that would be a good look, well they're saying, “Well that may well be the case but” -

author: Q
sentence: At the moment it's not a priority

author: A
sentence: Not a priority, how does that change the bottom line for me?  It's just not [inaudible] 00:53:08 problem

author: A
sentence: So I think – so there's that, the private ones have that sort of what's the driver for change?  Another situation I think would be school board, well it's hard to get people that don't have a – it's not a paid position so unless you have some sort of a relationship with the school or your children are there or you were there or whatever [inaudible] 00:53:31, why would someone come and contribute time, even though that would be very valuable for them to do that

author: A
sentence: And I'm on a disability services board, the barrier there again, well it's not remunerated so how do you get someone?

author: A
sentence: Someone really needs to dive in and say, “Well I'll spend my charitable time, I like diversity

author: A
sentence: ”  Or some [inaudible] 00:53:59 the guide dogs, and that could be a priority for them so how do you attract them in?  So I think more boards have barriers

author: A
sentence: You can't just click your finger and say, “Well we'll get all these people in,” you have to find a way to attract them to the cause and that's not – any board will be ever, there will be barriers around that

author: Q
sentence: That's interesting, okay

author: Q
sentence: So we've got a supply of members, if there's lack of remuneration, and people have mentioned that before with the not for profits

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that the solution or a solution there is to actually ensure that there's remuneration for members?

author: A
sentence: Oh that would be a solution

author: A
sentence: I think that would be enormously helpful but it's just not -

author: Q
sentence: It's not feasible?

author: A
sentence: It's not feasible for a lot of boards

author: A
sentence: Yeah some people Margot don't like private boards because they know there will be these strong owners, or owners that are very fixed in their ways, and can I really make the difference?  Maybe I can't

author: A
sentence: That's a barrier

author: Q
sentence: Yeah you described that in the example of conflict, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the use of targets or quotas to influence board diversity are useful?

author: Q
sentence: Great, you've got a lot of -

author: A
sentence: Somewhat useful

author: A
sentence: If you're going to a scale of one to 10 I might say three

author: A
sentence: I think it's good to have a light on the hill directionally and I think targets are useful to keep the issue in the front of mind

author: A
sentence: But I don't like quotas

author: Q
sentence: What's the problem?

author: A
sentence: Other than they flag the issue, because I just think look ultimately the person needs to be suitable

author: A
sentence: And even if they are female Somalian and you say we need one of those, well ultimately if they don't have the time or they're not strong people or they're total unsuited – they're impatient or be those other attributes which might just mean well I'd rather actually miss my quota Margot, than have someone who ticks off these two items for me

author: Q
sentence: So your example, your illustration of the skills matrix extended to include diversity is what you’d like to see and targets will work with these but quotas are too prescriptive, is that the thing?

author: A
sentence: Yeah that's my view, that's it

author: A
sentence: I think quotas are useful to keep – if we didn't have quotas or we didn't have – I think it's too wishy-washy to just say, “Oh we need to get more women on the board

author: A
sentence: ”  Well we can keep saying that for the next 20 years, say well we want three women on the board by 2022, well that's – but that's good, but I'd rather miss my target than appoint the wrong person Margot

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that if you found someone when you were trying to recruit, and you found someone who just lacked some skills and experience but they would really contribute to the board you think well, and of a minority group, so maybe gender, would you as a board consider investing time and energy in cultivating the supply of that person?

author: A
sentence: I have done that sort of thing, would do and would do it again

author: Q
sentence: What sort of thing do you do to cultivate a future board member?

author: A
sentence: Usually it is around, into my area, usually it's around well we think they have the – they may not have the, perhaps the corporate skills that others have, and usually the board [inaudible] 00:58:18 plenty of that

author: A
sentence: But they might have a set of values, they might be – I'll give you an example, I could say [inaudible] 00:58:25 around people and how people might be thinking and so on, but they've never sat on a board in their life, they don't know how to read a balance sheet Margot and they don't – well don't know board protocols

author: A
sentence: How do we – do we vote now, that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: I mean you're happy to invest time in those sorts of people because they bring a dimension that's not around the table and you can educate on those sorts of things

author: A
sentence: It's much harder to educate a set of values

author: Q
sentence: Okay so you've got your values fit but – and they've got a useful skill but not all of them, so some of them – you'd have them on the board and you'd coach them while they're on there?

author: A
sentence: And one of them, sorry, one of the ones I was on a subsidiary board of Price Waterhouse Coopers as well, so one of their company subsidiary

author: A
sentence: That's correct and I've seen a number of people on boards where – I'm on a board with a doctor who's never had a corporate role before but offers a really – because there's a health dimension to what we're doing, to have the insight of well how would the patient be feeling or how did that affect the work, that's very valuable

author: Q
sentence: Okay great, that's good

author: Q
sentence: So finally, this is the final question, looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Well diverse Margot

author: A
sentence: Boys club days, we're witnessing the dying days I suspect

author: A
sentence: It will probably take 10 years but I think we've come some way and I guess it's pretty massive if you were sitting back in 1990 looking at what's happened now you'd say, “Well that's an enormous journey

author: A
sentence: ”  You sit here now and you say, “I'm [inaudible] 01:00:10 dissatisfied with where we are

author: A
sentence: ”  But 10 years, I think we keep the quotas and you'll get some generation – I'd like to think – it's a lot of pressure on I think the 60 year old white Anglo-Saxon men, but that will take a while to churn through the system and it is doing that

author: A
sentence: So I think in 10 years time it will be rather different

sentence: That's fantastic, thank you so much

author: A
sentence: Yep

sentence: I wouldn't say reforms, I mean I still think a [inaudible] 01:01:30

author: A
sentence: I think the ARCD needs to keep the issues front of mind

author: A
sentence: I think quotas, as I say, I think as a tool to keep the issue front of mind, I think that's very valuable

author: A
sentence: I suspect – I think some directors have too many boards

author: A
sentence: I think having a pretty good look at the more robust about well how much really can this one white Anglo-Saxon chap do?  I think that would be a fair question to ask

author: A
sentence: I think there's a piece around board rotation probably, a bit like auditor rotation and so on

author: A
sentence: I think that would be useful

author: A
sentence: I think it might be useful to consider some sort of a – in the public domain, something that I think all the boards have it and I think we're starting to [inaudible] 01:02:39 some sort of diversity score card or metric or something like that might be worth considering

sentence: It sounds like you have the beginnings of it with your skills matrix extended -

author: A
sentence: Probably [inaudible] 01:02:54

sentence: I think people will be – I think there's a move really around good super funds and so on, the amount of power; they have now, I think there's a mood around well we can improve

sentence: So it's a good time to start to think about those sorts of – best practice will be – those sort of things need to be mandated but I think encouraging best practice is where the sector could go Margot

author: Q
sentence: So it would be great, because you've got such a spread of board experience, compare, contrast with the questions, because some of them you might be able to say, “Oh yeah this happens here, but look in this situation I think blah, blah, blah,” so that would be great

author: A
sentence: Yeah that sort of thing, yes, I think that's useful and I think organisations like the ARCD and the super funds, they should really, really – not penalising people but sort of really encouraging best practice and they'll get more stories around all the benefits

sentence: We all think it's right but the more you can draw out stories around, “Well hey, we never would have thought” – and I think there probably are plenty of stories from boards around well, “Gee, if we didn't have Mrs so-and-so on the board, we never would have thought about this issue

author: A
sentence: ”  Well wasn't that valuable

author: Q
sentence: So the other question before we go, someone yesterday mentioned tenure, and it was her view that tenure should be limited to six years on a board

author: Q
sentence: What do you think about that?

author: A
sentence: Well I don't know if six is the right number, but I think it should be limited

author: Q
sentence: How, to how many years would you suggest?  How would you come to limit it?

author: A
sentence: Well I wouldn't think it would be any longer than 10

author: A
sentence: I mean the problem with six is, particularly for someone like the chair, there's a corporate knowledge and you build relationships and so on, you sort of have a – but 10 year, it's sort of saying you need to get on the board, okay maybe I'm there for a couple of years and I become the chair, I probably want to be chair for at least a few years otherwise it's all a bit rough

author: A
sentence: And then you probably want the chair around maybe for a year or two after they're not the chair, just to help with the transition

author: A
sentence: So six years, albeit that's a long time, it's, well from my perspective when you sort of think about what is ideal in a substantial and complicated organisation, that's not a long time

author: A
sentence: But 10 years, more than 10 years you'd have to be looking at it and saying, “Well come on,” if you [inaudible] 01:06:33 the value that you might add over 10 years, you'd have to question whether it's ever coming I think

author: Q
sentence: So first, how have the composition of boards that you're familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?  Has it increased?

author: A
sentence: Sadly – the not for profits I'm on, they're quite diverse, they're pretty good

author: A
sentence: But I must admit in the – my boards have been, the other boards have really been privately owned businesses and for the most part they've been pretty non diverse, pretty static

author: A
sentence: So that would be I guess the headline comment Margot, so I haven't – I've sticked with – I mean the private states, I think some of the drivers that are perhaps impacting public companies and public – government owned corporations are not impacting that, my sector as much

author: Q
sentence: Okay so what are these drivers that are affecting the not for profits that's not affecting your privately owned company?

author: A
sentence: Well look I think it's the press and just greater discussion, particularly around the benefits of diversity on board and also particularly regarding women and people from different demographic backgrounds and so on, the not for profits I'm involved with really are aligned to that

author: A
sentence: And the private are more focused on I guess business outcomes and reluctant – I wouldn't say they're not – I mean there's a good argument to say there are business outcomes from diversity but they're taking longer to change

author: Q
sentence: Good, that will be great to explore a little further as we move forward in the interview

author: Q
sentence: So first of all, just a quick idea, get an idea of how important you think board diversity is, 10 is extremely important and one is not important at all, what would you rate it?

author: Q
sentence: Oh did you?  Okay

author: A
sentence: Nine

author: Q
sentence: Nine, and so do you feel that it's always been important?  Has it always been important to you?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: No I think I've been one of the ones that probably not thought about it properly until perhaps the last 10 years, as I became more involved in boards and became more educated about some of the theory behind them and did the Institute of Company Directors course and become a bit more alive to some of the literature Margot

author: A
sentence: You start, I guess I sort of understood more and identified more with the case of diversity

author: A
sentence: So I hadn't always felt – this hadn’t been alive to – I've been around, sadly I've been around a long time so I guess your thinking and understanding of things changes over time

author: Q
sentence: That's good
