sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: So it's courses, literature, and I think just discussion in the media around benefits of diversity and shortcomings of lack of diversity Margot

author: Q
sentence: So there's been no organisations that have influenced you to do this, like any regulation, targets or quotas or – it's really been social media and your -

author: A
sentence: No, none of the regulatory piece or quotas or that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Just for my clarification, when you say privately owned, so we've got not for profits and privately owned, is this a listed company or is something that's not listed?

author: A
sentence: Not listed, so full profit, so large private – an example I was the executive director of a group called the Spotlight Group which owns 180 stores across the country, owns Anaconda, owns a lot of property as well

author: A
sentence: It's owned by two families

author: Q
sentence: So why do you think that board diversity is so important now?

author: A
sentence: A week, 10 days ago or so, I can check to see what date

author: A
sentence: Yeah well I guess probably just a few reasons on that note

author: A
sentence: I think ultimately it's around different skills and insights to problem solving coming from through having people with a diverse – with diverse values, backgrounds, educations, life experiences, et cetera, et cetera

author: A
sentence: It's a better analysis and a better planning environment, rather than having a homogenous, Anglo-Saxon group of chaps who all went to private schools sitting around

author: A
sentence: So I think it's better analysis, better solutions, from diversity

author: Q
sentence: So do you think that there's any situation or context that might cause you to change that rating, for example if there's a high uncertainty, high risk situation, do you think that the diversity is important then or not so?

author: A
sentence: Oh I do think it's probably even more important

author: A
sentence: The only thing that could change my view might be if there was a particular need for speed on a particular matter

author: A
sentence: That said, usually if there's a need for speed, getting a suboptimal can result

author: A
sentence: So that yeah, I guess you need to be – sometimes you have to go for the suboptimal result because of timing

author: A
sentence: But for that, that would be [inaudible] 00:09:45 situation, that would be the only construct I can think of where less diversity would be good, but probably not a great outcome

author: Q
sentence: So in that sort of – it's almost like a reactive decision mode is it, this speed you're talking about?

author: A
sentence: Yeah correct

author: Q
sentence: Okay so in that reactive situation, the board functioning, how might it look?  You've got diversity, how would it look?  How would diversity get in the way of being able to react quickly to a situation?

author: A
sentence: Well I think with more diversity, there's just by definition a greater range of views to canvas, to consider

author: A
sentence: There's more complexity in the analysis and the potential solutions Margot, and that just takes time

author: A
sentence: I have no doubt it probably gives a better solution but sometimes, occasionally, I don't think it's so often, just things that are just so pressing that you may have to sacrifice that

author: A
sentence: Or it might be appropriate to sacrifice that better decision, the less than perfect, but it's a reality

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example?  So it doesn't have to be – it can be just a plausible one, not an actual

author: A
sentence: From the prospect of trading insolvently

author: Q
sentence: Oh okay, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay that's okay, I'll recheck

author: Q
sentence: I was away and so I'm -

author: A
sentence: Which it's obviously a major board consideration, a lot of directors become liable for the debts of the company if you are trading insolvently

author: A
sentence: Well we can all sit around for a few days and work out whether we could and whether we could get out of it and so on, but there's pretty significant implications from that

author: A
sentence: So as I say, yeah, I think it's rare but off the top of my head it would be a reason to perhaps – where a non diverse board might be able to get a – would get a better outcome first

author: Q
sentence: So I mean there's law there that guides that decision making

author: Q
sentence: So I guess if there is a clear legal directive, I mean I don't know if in the real world it is that clear, but is it a clear legal directive in that situation, there might be others as well

author: Q
sentence: I mean there might be other legal imperatives as well, then a diverse board becomes irrelevant or an interference, is that a principle do you think we can draw?

author: A
sentence: Is it a principle?  Well I guess the question was can I see sort of situations where a diverse board could be suboptimal?  [Inaudible] 00:13:02 I guess it's pretty rare constructs, fundamentally around – fundamentally it's around time

author: A
sentence: I think the quality – if it's regarding quality of decision making, a diverse board is always better Margot

author: A
sentence: There could be some legal constructs or perhaps, I don't know, the CEO – sexual misconduct or there's – or criminal activities or whatever it might be, those pretty extreme events, well there might be situations where you need to act very quickly and sort of engage in a – a full analysis from many perspectives is (a) not required, (b) time consuming

author: Q
sentence: Yeah or it's deferred to an external body

author: A
sentence: Yeah [inaudible] 00:13:54

author: Q
sentence: Yeah the analysis, okay

author: Q
sentence: So that's really good

sentence: You're the first person who's been able to articulate that, and that sounds like a really important point for us to consider

author: Q
sentence: So that's great, thank you

author: A
sentence: Yeah I would like to think most – on a diverse board, it wouldn't be everyone would appreciate well, hello, we can all forget where we come from demographical or whatever, this is just a regulation or this is a huge issue, and frankly all the nuances are [inaudible] 00:14:28 issues

author: A
sentence: But I can see a scenario where there's personal relationships or whatever there might be that might become problematic

author: Q
sentence: Right, but in terms of board functioning, I guess even these particular situations you've articulated, you can still have a diverse board but these decisions are really almost the board functioning becomes irrelevant, it's just a decision

author: Q
sentence: The board really has to call it, agree, or the chair calls a decision, right we're at risk of trading and being insolvent, we don't want trade, so we need to stop business and whatever you do, have it all -

author: A
sentence: Yeah [inaudible] 00:15:15 we need to get this [inaudible] 00:15:18, so that's the sort of [inaudible] 00:15:20

author: Q
sentence: Yeah so is that really a situation where the chair – see I really don't know how this works

author: Q
sentence: So is it a situation where the -

author: A
sentence: That's all right, maybe it's in your spam box or -

author: A
sentence: Yeah well that is a situation where you'd like to think the chair would say, “Well hello, we all respect each other, we all have a view, but this is just what” -

author: Q
sentence: What we have to do

author: A
sentence: This is what we have to do, we don't have time to sort of really – it is just required

author: A
sentence: Or we think the CEO has done something inappropriate with a staff member and he needs to be suspended immediately

author: A
sentence: Some might have an alternative view on that, well don't really have time, we need to act et cetera

author: A
sentence: So yes, you'd like to think the chair and the directors would all be very unanimous on that; I guess there is a scenario where that may not be the case Margot

author: Q
sentence: Yeah okay that's great

author: Q
sentence: So that's not against the idea of being a diverse board, that's really about the board – we could construct that as really about there are particular decisions that sometimes it's not democratic, it is an imperative, and it's managed differently to every day board business

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, they're pretty unique, almost like crisis type -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So are there any less extreme – so that sort of imperative, that one must act on

author: Q
sentence: Are there any other situations where you think the functioning of the board around, with diverse voices and drawing all those voices together, so the functions of bringing that diversity together gets in the way of board functioning do you think?  Is there any other kind of -

author: A

author: A
sentence: It's – no, I don't see any other situations

author: Q
sentence: Yep beautiful, that's great

author: Q
sentence: Now let's move back, sit back and think what does board diversity actually mean?  So how do you understand board diversity?  What's it meant to you?

author: A
sentence: Well I think to me, it's having a range of experienced values and perspectives around the board table Margot

author: Q
sentence: What about gender?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly, I was away so it was probably while I was away

author: Q
sentence: Yep that's okay

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah so I guess from that perspective, so I guess the female or – the female [inaudible] 00:18:18 male, so you're having the female, which I see as very valuable, around the board table

author: A
sentence: I don't pretend to be a psychologist and there's different – males think different – some males think differently to other males and some females think differently to other females, but I think having a female voice, a strong female voice sitting around the table, I think it goes – there's much bigger diversity, much bigger with gender, and various other verticals, with age is an obvious one

author: A
sentence: I guess religion probably less so these days but probably values and ethics, or values

author: A
sentence: Some people are very interested in money, some people are very interested in environment, some people are very interested in technology

author: A
sentence: So some people are very interested in people and their growth

author: A
sentence: So I what are the main diversities needed?  Well gender, age, religion, skill set, geography, industry

author: Q
sentence: Would you want people from different industries on your board or do you think a focus on the industry that you're board’s stewarding or directing?

author: A
sentence: Well I think for the most part people with an experience of the industry the company is involved in

author: A
sentence: That said, there are interesting relevant industries which aren't necessarily directly involved in an industry, so the insight – like I've got a lot of background in retail but technology and media is very interesting for retailers at the minute, as an example

author: Q
sentence: What I'm interested in here, there's so many different facets, different types of diversity, how do you choose?  Are you going to have just one female, one person who's interested in - one person – like a spread, or is this a strategic decision?  And if so, how do you make that?  How do you decide what kinds of diversity you want on this board at this time?

author: A
sentence: Well I guess my views on that, and I've done it on a few boards where we've had these sort of conversations, yeah we just – I guess we extend out a sort of skills and experience matrix, which you would normally do for a board, that's the old way of doing board selection, and you extend it across to the diversity lens Margot

author: A
sentence: So you start saying, “Well female,” and then you say, “Okay well youths,” and you say, “China,” if that's relevant or, “Environmental,” or – when I was on a medical board we felt we needed a doctor probably with experience in the sector, just the business people Margot

author: A
sentence: So you just extend out that skill matrix to more of a diversity lens and look at what you're looking at

author: A
sentence: I don't think it's simply just a head count matter

author: A
sentence: You might have four females on the board but if they're all shrinking violets, then you might in fact be better with just one who's much more robust in terms of their nature

author: A
sentence: So I don't think it's an arithmetical exercise, it's more nuance than that

author: Q
sentence: So with the skills matrix, some of those can be quantified, but the shrinking violet versus the – these sort of personal, these characteristics, how do you assess those?  And is it something you do within the board or is it something that you outsource?

author: A
sentence: It can be either

author: A
sentence: It depends on the situation

author: A
sentence: I think search consultants are quite used to dealing with a range of very tangible KPIs they're looking for in a search and in tangibles as well, in tangibles of being well how vocal is this person, how compelling are they, what sort of presence do they have, are they likely to be influential or not?  And you can talk to people, gauge their experience, get references, et cetera, around those sorts of things

author: Q
sentence: So for me, what I'm getting, because this is sort of a bit of a challenge for modelling, understanding diversity and how it functions

author: Q
sentence: One point you've got is likely to be influential, so there's no point having anyone on the board if they're not likely to be influential, so that's essential, would that be right?

author: A
sentence: Agreed, correct

author: Q
sentence: Okay and the other would be to improve or to enhance problem solving, so it's to ensure that problem solving is deep and you've got, what is it, the skills and insights so that problem solving analysis and planning is optimised

author: Q
sentence: So would they be the sort of two guiding things you're looking for or is there something else?

author: A
sentence: The 6th of June I sent that to you

author: A
sentence: No I think that's a good summary Margot

author: Q
sentence: Okay good

author: A
sentence: Perhaps the only element, I mean and it's obviously with the person who's motivated to be involved with the board

author: A
sentence: I suppose that's just a given but people might have all the talent and capability in the world, but if they're otherwise distracted or disinterested, then they won't execute on what they could contribute

author: Q
sentence: Gender diversity has been debated for a while, how do you feel about the recent inclusion of ethnicity, sexuality, as part of the board diversity debate?

author: A
sentence: I think it's very valid

author: A
sentence: I mean that's a better – again, I'm – well sadly I guess I didn't – I'm disappointed I didn't think of it first but it's very valid

author: A

author: A

author: A
sentence: But I don't think – yeah I'm on a school board, a private school, and having a youth voice is probably more important than gender diversity, now it happens that we happen to have gender diversity as well on our board but that youth voice I think is at least as important as gender diversity in that particular instance

author: Q
sentence: So it might depend on the situation or the context -

author: A
sentence: Correct

sentence: My really -

author: A
sentence: I don't know what part of that – well what do we need on the board to achieve what we're trying to – setting out to do

sentence: Yeah I'm trying to think of one where diversity – yeah well I've been on one of my boards, we looked at discussion around replacing the CEO, which is a key role of the board

sentence: And just framing what attributes we're looking for in a new CEO is one where yeah, different people – it's where they find they have different priorities Margot

sentence: Yeah that would be – yeah

sentence: I don't know, it really helps us if we can get a story because it's amazing how powerful a story is when you analyse it

author: Q
sentence: So if you can, without sort of -
So thank you very much for agreeing to participate, and I have those information, the information you gave me
I’ll fill that out later
First, how do you feel – because you’ve been a member of, a director of a company for 11 years you said, is that right?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, really part of the risk mitigations

author: A
sentence: Because if you sit on the board you are so cocooned in that meeting, actually what happened outside you actually don’t know but your responsibility is huge

author: Q
sentence: The inclusivity extends to the staff and there needs to be an openness and a dialogue between the two

author: A
sentence: Yes, absolutely

author: A
sentence: We have had diverse board because now the employees are of a diverse background, they feel confidence in expressing their point of views

author: A
sentence: They will tell you more

sentence: It’s amazing how different information is still coming up

author: Q
sentence: It’s very good

author: Q

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s any board function that diversity can limit or undermine?

sentence: Yes

sentence: How you allocate the funds

author: A
sentence: To do, to be fair

author: A
sentence: I think there is a lot of evidence they will pour in all the money to what they are comfortable with

author: A
sentence: If things are new or something is out of the comfort zone they don’t want to touch it

author: A
sentence: But those are missed opportunities

author: Q
sentence: Diversity is a problem because it won’t get funded because people are still not comfortable with it or things will be funded -

author: A
sentence: I’ll put it the other way around

author: A
sentence: If the board is a diverse board at the time the funding comes along if we’re talking about how to fund a certain number of projects, I always say the project which is English speaking will fund a lot more than other cultures projects, is what I’m trying to say

author: A
sentence: Because it’s out of the comfort zone because they don’t know

author: Q
sentence: It’s like it won’t be known, it won’t be seen, so it won’t get funded, it won’t be thought about, it won’t be strategically – it’s an opportunity lost, as you said

author: Q
sentence: Can I say – so you’re from an Asian background?

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: That’s the different points of view and -

author: A
sentence: Of course the board members need to keep on pushing, every board meeting keep on reminding them that this one is really good, this one is really good until you are sick and tired of it

author: Q
sentence: Sounds like you are a lobbyist

author: A
sentence: They are learning

author: A
sentence: Other board members are learning

author: A
sentence: They didn’t see it as important as what they are comfortable with

author: A
sentence: Which is understandable, it’s human nature

author: A
sentence: Everyone, there’s comfort zone

author: A
sentence: It’s important

author: A
sentence: But being a board member we really should not put ourselves in that comfort zone

author: A
sentence: Because we’re part of a board, boards are the leader, to lead the organisation to bigger and better things

author: A
sentence: We should have the foresight

author: A
sentence: And really need to explain and convince other board members the importance of thinking ahead

author: Q
sentence: Thinking ahead and also it seems you need to advocate for, when you’ve got diverse backgrounds on the board each person from their different background needs to advocate I guess, their background

author: A
sentence: And also lead by example

author: A
sentence: You have to work a lot harder to prove it works

author: Q
sentence: But not in a way – could that therefore become a problem because you might have different people with their different pet allegiances advocating and creating conflict on the board?

author: A
sentence: That means you need to look at, go back to your mission statement

author: A
sentence: Time after time, if we’ve got some differences we just go back and look at the mission statement, look at strategy paper

author: A
sentence: I think that is very important

author: A
sentence: That’s why the strategy needs to be revised every year

author: Q
sentence: And this process of conflict, let’s call it, different points of view it could challenge the strategy because it might be seen as an opportunity lost or an injustice or something?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: That is the best description I’ve had of the way this conflict can be creatively managed

author: A
sentence: I think conflict is good

author: A
sentence: Different opinions

author: A
sentence: We are not sitting ducks

author: A
sentence: We shouldn’t have the same opinion, everyone

author: A
sentence: Some chairs like that but I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: Everyone is different

author: A
sentence: But as long as when in time we have our debate, we can agree, or disagree, we go back to our mission statement, we go back to our strategies so that we will not lose sight of the big picture

sentence: The reason for the – that’s great

author: Q

sentence: You can disagree, you can agree, everyone says their opinion, the reasons why, so that everyone understands

sentence: When you look at the percentage of the populations I think it should be correctly represented on boards

sentence: From my old job when we look at the junior staff Asian was, got a very high number of staff

sentence: But when we go to the leaders Asian actually diminish, their representation

sentence: For myself I haven’t got the foresight in, not visionary enough

author: A

author: A
sentence: I really just cannot imagine, to bring the organisation forward

author: A
sentence: But lots of people are very good and they can see in 10 years’ time what will happen

author: A
sentence: I just haven’t got that

sentence: If I’m not that visionary I shouldn’t be a chair

author: A
sentence: I always think the chair should be very visionary

author: A

author: A

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process between on the one hand trying to obtain someone who’s a good collegiate fit and then some, trying on the other hand to avoid group think?  Do you think there can be tension between those two – the chair might be thinking, I really want someone who’s a good collegiate fit but I also want someone who can bring in different points of view, different industry knowledge, different whatever, so that we don’t have group think?

sentence: I think it depends on the chair, whether they’re open minded or not

author: A
sentence: If they’re open minded they’re quite happy to accept a challenge

author: A

sentence: And then after they mentor them he or she become their sponsors

author: A
sentence: I prefer a target

author: A
sentence: If you cannot achieve that target, why?  And find out what we can do so that next year we can achieve that target

author: A
sentence: So whoever is appointed to the board they are not the one who just need to tick the box

sentence: 1 to say, every morning they need to say thank you to China because customers

sentence: My best experiences on boards have been when you’ve got a diverse board particularly if everyone – I think there are other elements that have to come into that because there’s a lot of pain that comes with diversity as well

author: A1
sentence: So your meetings might go more quickly if you’re exactly the same

author: A1
sentence: So historically, yes, the not for profit sector

author: A1
sentence: However, in more recent years we also work with funders of the not for profit sector and we work with businesses who work with the not for profit sector and we work with, if you like, social businesses so businesses that have a social purpose like, for example, our community ourselves we’re a B corporation

author: A1
sentence: So we’re actually not a not for profit but we have a social purpose

author: A1
sentence: We’re an accredited B corporation

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A1
sentence: But so if you’re all pushing in the same direction towards the same mission but coming at it with different view points there can be some pain involved in that, but often you get the best results, in my opinion, but it requires very skilful chairing in my opinion

author: A1
sentence: And if that isn’t present then you’re in all sorts of trouble in which case I’d go down to a four or something if you want to achieve the mission of the organisation

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Now, I’ll just flag now we’re going to talk about board functioning

author: A1
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk in depth about that and perhaps give an example of effective chairing and non-effective chairing?

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And how your organisation might seek to address that or -

author: A1
sentence: So, again, we run – we have help sheets and books on how to be a good chair and we run training courses on how to be a good chair

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: I personally think it’s the one thing that makes a difference on a board

author: A1
sentence: My research has shown me that but my experience has more so shown me that

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: So an example of where that – I’m trying to think of one that’s not too horrifying

author: A2
sentence: Go for horrifying

author: Q
sentence: Go for horrifying but just don’t let it be identifying

author: A1
sentence: I’m just – I’m trying to think of something that’s illustrative

author: A1
sentence: I’ve just been on many – okay

author: A1
sentence: Well, here – it’s kind of a dumb example but I was once on the board and the chairperson was on the board because it was good for CV but he actually never attended any of the meetings and he didn’t manage any of the business so the board was completely rudderless and there was diversity on that board but there was no cohesion whatsoever so it was a debacle

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: A1
sentence: So that’s an extreme example of poor chairing if you don’t turn up

author: Q
sentence: And this gave you your experience for your job here and some chaos control

author: A1
sentence: Well, yes, chaos control

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: And you know you need someone trying to control chaos, in my opinion

author: A1
sentence: Too much democracy is bad

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me about that

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, because controlling sounds anti-democratic

author: A1
sentence: Which is a business in structure but with a social purpose

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: Well, I’m into people having a say and I think – I mean this is getting sort of more into the structure of the organisation here

author: A1
sentence: I definitely don’t think I have all the best ideas

author: A1
sentence: I definitely want to hear people’s ideas, but at some point someone has got to make a decision and then everyone has got to fall in behind or decide that they’re not falling in behind

author: A1
sentence: And then that’s another way of going about it, but in order to push forward, I think there has to be a degree of decision-making, and that doesn’t mean that someone needs to be a despot

author: A1
sentence: There’s a lot of consultation that goes with that or delegation

author: A1
sentence: That’s part of that as well

author: A1
sentence: Knowing who to delegate to and when and those sorts of things

author: A1
sentence: It doesn’t mean there’s just one person controlling everything

author: A1
sentence: It’s just making sure that there’s not too much chaos

author: Q
sentence: It’s productive

author: Q
sentence: You’re producing -

author: A1
sentence: Productive chaos

author: Q
sentence: Productive chaos, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: A2
sentence: I see – it’s 23IN

author: A2
sentence: I see it’s more – it’s not so much even controlling the board but you actually control the process so that the process of the decision-making is controlled -

author: A1
sentence: Yes

author: A2
sentence: - and so and not everyone is going to agree

author: A2
sentence: And it’s a terrible board if everyone agrees with everything all the time anyway -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: - because there’s no robust discussion, I would imagine, but I’m a 10 for the necessity of diversity on a board as well because I think particularly in the community sector the boards should be representing their stakeholders

author: A2
sentence: So straightaway whatever organisation you’re working in in the community has got 50 per cent females in your stakeholders even if it’s a – and this is a contentious issue for Kath if it’s a Men’s Shed organisation those men who are there have wives or daughters or aunties so they’re all stakeholders

author: A2
sentence: So you can’t have – or women’s family violence shouldn’t have an all female board or a board of all white females in their 50s, even if that’s the predominant stakeholder group the stakeholders are broader than your direct beneficiaries

author: A2
sentence: And so I think if you really are going to represent your stakeholders or you’re going to represent the people that you are assisting in some way then your board should be representative of that

author: A2
sentence: And I don’t mean it in a tick the box, “We need to have one of this sort and that sort and that sort

author: A2
sentence: ”  It’s about casting the net wide to make sure you’ve got that diversity of opinion and representation

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Are you listed?  Do you have shareholders?

author: A2
sentence: But I agree with Kath you have to have really strong chairing just to ensure that it – the process is controlled properly

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Consistently, yeah

author: Q
sentence: And other people have talked about – a lot of conversations I’ve had have focused on the conflict that can be on chairs and some – sorry, on boards and some see it – most see it as the chair role but others see it as the culture of the board which I think is interesting

author: A1
sentence: Well, the chair sets that

author: A2
sentence: It all helps to

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: And in some ways polices it

author: A1
sentence: This is 24IN again

author: A1
sentence: So, again, as 23IN said too in charge of the process

author: A1
sentence: I think also in relation to making diversity work a chair – another place – another time where I’ve seen chairing fail is a chair who doesn’t really know the board members and doesn’t know what their strengths are and what their weaknesses are

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: And he doesn’t seek to draw those out during meetings and in-between meetings

author: A1
sentence: Doesn’t know who is the person who is too shy to speak but would have some really good opinions if you took him for a coffee

author: A1
sentence: Those sorts of – so that’s what I mean about skilful chairing as well to really know how to bring the best out of people and not think they have the answer

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: We have private shareholders

author: A1
sentence: So, yeah

author: A1
sentence: Actually, now I say there’s a danger in saying that skilled chairing is required without saying what that means to me because that’s not a dictatorial view of chairing at all

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: We have to draw down on this because everyone just like with conflict people have different understandings of conflict

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: It’s quite meaningless but it’s a beginning

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: And same with – yeah

author: Q
sentence: So as we go if you think of any other things that the chair and the culture of the board might be relevant to, yeah, bring it up and how you influence it

author: Q
sentence: I presume you provide tools to assess for performance, do you?

author: A1
sentence: We do have -

author: Q
sentence: Who is on your board

author: A1
sentence: This is 24IN

author: A1
sentence: So we have things like there’s a skills matrix template that you can use to work out who is on your board and that includes diversity so that encourages people to think about -

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: A1
sentence: - are you all the same sort of person?  Are you all bringing the same world view to discussions?  And we have – what was the other?  There’s a board effectiveness quiz and there’s a board member effectiveness quiz that you can do to reflect on your own performance or with the board -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: tool you can ask your whole board to do it and that can be used as a kind of assessment tool collectively or individually or we’ve seen sometimes just the Chair does it or just the CEO surveys the board members So they can get a fix on how people think they’re doing in various areas which, of course, is always very interesting because you will have three people who think everyone is managing the finances really Well and three people who think that it’s appalling

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: So I don’t know what you do in that -

author: Q
sentence: Have a conversation

author: A1
sentence: It’s time for a conversation

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel this rating of 10, you gave it a rating of 10, has it always been in that case so important?

author: A1
sentence: Has it always been that case for me or has it always been important for boards to have diversity?

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: So we’re a privately held company

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel it has always been important?  I guess you’re speaking from an organisational point of view so from wearing the hat of the community, our community organisation, has diversity also – on boards always been a 10?

author: A1
sentence: Yes, for our organisation -

author: A2
sentence: Yes

author: A1
sentence: - I think we’ll have – yes

author: A1
sentence: So our founders we’re a foundation full of social justice warriors -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, I read this

author: A1
sentence: - feminists -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: disability activists So, Yes, our very foundations sit on the belief that inclusion is important and diversity is, therefore, non-@negotiable

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

sentence: And how long has your organisation – sorry, I didn’t see that

author: A1
sentence: That’s okay

author: A1
sentence: 2019 – nearly 20 years old

sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Okay

sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Well, thank you, 24IN, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: So why did you shift and when did you shift to expand your circle of influence?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so it’s fairly new

author: A2
sentence: And I might be wrong, Kath has been at the organisation a lot longer than me -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: @ but even in the early years we were working with the Office for Women on diversity on boards projects

author: Q
sentence: Really

author: A2
sentence: So it’s sort of been from the offset we’ve been working in the space as well as having that as part of our foundational values

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: We’ve been actively – we do a lot of work around women being nominated in the Australian honour’s system as well -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: @ and we produced a book to give organisations like a how to to nominate women

author: A2
sentence: So I guess our diversity work has been – we’ve been active in the space as Well as just believing in it from the get go

author: A1
sentence: Well, I guess we’re very – this is 24IN speaking

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: That’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So now do you think that there’s any situation or context where diversity is not so important?

author: A2
sentence: From a perspective?

author: Q
sentence: Diversity of board

author: Q
sentence: I’m always talking board

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: Stunned silence

author: A1
sentence: Thinking silence, truthfully, because there probably is but I’m just trying to think

author: A1
sentence: Well, as I said before, if the other foundations aren’t there so, for example – this is 24IN speaking – if you don’t have a skilful – I wouldn’t say it’s not important, however, if you are driving towards a mission that’s very well defined and within reach and you don’t have the things that will make diversity thrive, thinking as I’m talking, is it okay to trade off diversity for getting to that end quickly?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: So, for example, if you’re talking about something as basic as running a football match, so say your local footy club, if they want to just – their mission is to put on a footy game every Saturday, no, I think – I just think it should have diversity because they don’t know then – from a governance perspective they don’t know what opportunities they’re missing

author: A1
sentence: They’ve missed out on women’s footy perhaps

author: A1
sentence: They’ve missed out on including people with – I can’t think of an example

author: A2
sentence: No, and I think -

author: A1
sentence: I’m trying to

author: A2
sentence: - a football analogy even if it’s like a board of 10 men and they’ve got a really strong women’s football league they’re still missing out on the different perspectives of women around the table and so there may be 10 other things that could be happening as well as that football league

author: A2
sentence: So it’s just not enough to say they’re doing all the right things in the – for the club and women are included or the involvement of refugees

author: A2
sentence: Those blokes are doing a good job

author: A2
sentence: It’s like what else could be happening if you had more diversity around the table?  And I bet you the women are still running the canteen as well

author: A2
sentence: So I can’t see a case – I wouldn’t punish small organisations that have been founded with just five people and I’m big on board turnover, however, because I’ve been in terrible board situations where people have been there for 35 years and things just don’t change and it’s awful, but I think that boards that are starting out and the only people who put their hand up are those people in the initial stages

author: A2
sentence: I wouldn’t beat them around with a stick for lack of diversity

author: A2
sentence: They need to be on the journey to get there, they need to recognise that it’s important and that it’s something they need and at the next election they need to be putting out the call to women and to whoever else they need to diversify their board, but – yeah

author: Q
sentence: And build capacity perhaps in the pipeline

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, for sure, but I can’t see an instance when it’s not – when there’s not a missed opportunity through not having diversity

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: So it maybe – this is 24IN here

author: A1
sentence: Maybe sometimes it’s excusable but it’s always desirable

author: A2
sentence: Desirable, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: I think I had a sense, 24IN, that you were going – this came out in another interview with this question that diversity is wasted without – if there is no inclusion on the board

author: Q
sentence: If there is not the capacity for inclusion diversity is wasted

author: A1
sentence: Definitely

author: A1
sentence: So if it’s tokenistic in the true sense of the word where you invite someone with a disability but then don’t give them any facilities to get into the room or – then you might as well not bother

author: A2
sentence: This is 23IN

author: A2
sentence: Or listen to their perspective and then dismiss it because that’s because they’re disabled

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A2
sentence: Of course they would think that way so it’s not as important

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: We’re very mission focused so our mission has always been – the central vision, if you like, was stronger communities through stronger community organisations

author: A1
sentence: Well, what we realised very early on in the life of the organisation is that you don’t necessarily create a stronger social sector without engaging with everyone who is around the social sector

author: A1
sentence: So just working with not for profit organisations won’t produce the change that we wanted

author: A1
sentence: So we worked, for example, with big businesses who provide services to the not for profit sector to help them provide those services better or more efficiently or more effectively, is one example

author: A1
sentence: Another example of where we came to work with other types of organisation was in the funder space

author: A1
sentence: So when I talk about funders we might use the word grant worker a bit in this conversation because that’s who we work with

author: A1
sentence: That’s local government, state government, federal government, philanthropic organisations, corporates who give money to the not for profit sector and, again, we realised that it was no good just trying to work with the not for profit sector all the time to fix their stuff

author: A1
sentence: That there’s things that other organisations are doing to them that is causing them troubles that needs to be fixed as well so we’ve shifted focus to those as well

author: A2
sentence: And inclusivity is – yeah

author: A1
sentence: There’s proper inclusivity

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A2
sentence: So, yeah, I guess we’re talking about inclusivity as opposed to diversity

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that what we need to be clear about

author: Q
sentence: So let’s – look this language is very loose at board level and I think you guys are really well placed to help to clarify it

author: Q
sentence: Can you help me?  How do you – like when you’re talking about board diversity what’s the difference?  What do these two words mean?

author: A2
sentence: Part of the research that we did last year looked at the fact do you – part of the survey we did was do you provide – I can’t think of the wording of the question now, Margo -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: @ but it was like facilities to promote inclusiveness and to allow it?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: And it was about the example are you serving food that’s appropriate for everyone at the table?  Is there wheelchair access?  Is there men’s and female’s changerooms or toilet facilities?  Are there – so -

author: A1
sentence: What time of the day do you hold your meetings for everybody to come?

author: Q
sentence: So would you work the policy environment for those or – yeah?

author: A2
sentence: Do you take the fact that women have elder care and child care and also there was – I think one of the examples was a group that always met at five o’clock because the members of this particular board were so elderly they were in bed by half past six, but that was a time when some of the newer board members who they recruited, “We need some young folk,” they were still working or they were picking the kids up from after school care or – so it’s we – and explaining the difference between diversity and inclusivity is tricky so we try to use it when we’re communicating practical examples like that

author: A2
sentence: So it’s all very well that you’ve got a young woman on the board but are you allowing her to participate fully by examining these different things to ensure you’re inclusive?  So I think the more practical example you can give the better they can kind of get their heads around it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So where inclusive is about the empathetic engagement of each person around the tables

author: A1
sentence: And I think for me it’s not – this is 24IN now

author: A1
sentence: It’s not about inviting people into your existing structures -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: -@ but bending the structure to allow new people in

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: And coming from a controller -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: I think you’ve got the wrong impression of what control means

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: I think it’s -

author: A1
sentence: We’re more on a practical level than a policy level

author: Q
sentence: I know

author: Q
sentence: It’s another word like conflict

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

sentence: Okay

sentence: So you’ve already answered that

author: Q
sentence: That’s how you influence the priority the boards give and you’ve got it on your website

author: Q
sentence: You said you provide tools that measure it, diversity, and you have information on inclusiveness how to build it, culture, yeah

author: A1
sentence: And at length, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Now, I want what does board diversity mean to you?  Who wants to go first?

author: A2
sentence: I think – this is 23IN

author: Q
sentence: 23IN

author: A2
sentence: - that I Probably gave my definition earlier and board diversity is representing the community that you’re working with or for, people that you’re serving

author: A2
sentence: and So diversity can look different in different geographic locations

author: A2
sentence: big city or diversity is different to some rural and regional and remote areas in Australia as well

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Where often the communities are really homogenous

author: A2
sentence: So if you had an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community that was 99 per cent ATSI -

author: Q
sentence: And we’re all female, so it’s going to be hard for the transcriber, so, 24IN is going to talk sometimes

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: I will say after you’ve spoken, ‘thanks, 24IN,’ or something

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: - then I would see that as foolishness to be reaching out and trying to find how many white people and no one lives within a 300 kilometre radius

author: A2
sentence: That diversity then would be about gender, it would be about the different diversity within that community but that can also be used as a really easy argument against diversity, “We don’t have any people like that in our town or our area”

author: A2
sentence: So I think a diverse board is where there has been a really active and concerted effort to make sure that there’s proper representation on the board of the community

author: A2
sentence: And it’s not always fully achievable in a tick the box way

author: A2
sentence: That has to be monitored really carefully to ensure that it’s not a, “We couldn’t find an LGBQTI person for our board

author: A2
sentence: We don’t really have any in our community

author: A2
sentence: ”  Well, of course you do

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: But it’s also – and it’s like Kath said bending the structures so that those people feel welcome and able and want to put their hand up or are easy to – and sometimes that’s just the whole culture of geography as well

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So is this like – a bit like an organisation defines its purposes is this a bit like the board has to define its stakeholders?

author: A2
sentence: Well, it would -

author: Q
sentence: It represents -

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, well, any good organisation should

author: A2
sentence: I mean nothing – it’s kind of -

author: Q
sentence: And the board would do that as part of that?

author: A2
sentence: Yes, with the senior management

author: A1
sentence: So working out what are their key problems that are occurring and then what role can we play in helping to fix those

author: A1
sentence: I think I see us as a bit of an intermediary between lots of different sectors

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Like our stakeholders here are so broad, so incredibly broad, that most in the community sector organisations would have, I would hope, a good idea about who their first sort of community is

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

sentence: And you provide tools to help them do that?

author: A2
sentence: Of identifying their community?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So someone on Christmas Island can do it and someone here in Melbourne

sentence: I think we’ve got stakeholder mapping exercises and things that are part of our training -

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: -@ just to raise that

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: I think every community organisation has to do that themselves

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, I’d agree

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: It’s such a -

author: A1
sentence: The raising that -

author: A2
sentence: - yeah, a fundamental business strategy thing

author: A1
sentence: I would say so

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: And that’s kind of whether it’s not for profit sector or for profit or -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I know but it’s key to understanding your way of -

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - diversity and it’s not always thought that way

author: Q
sentence: It’s not linked to how diversity of stakeholders and stakeholders might be thought of more instrumentally about, well, who do we want to influence and -

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: I guess it’s a slightly different purpose

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Can I have an example?

author: A1
sentence: And I guess in our stakeholder mapping we talk about all those things

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: A1
sentence: So your stakeholders are not only who do you serve but who do you want to influence?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: And who can help you influence?  And who supports the board?

author: Q
sentence: So who supports?

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And so what about you?

author: A1
sentence: For me, I think a diverse board is a board that brings a variety of world views into the room and I think there’s a lot of ways of going about that and I think looking at your stakeholders is definitely part of that and represent – making sure you have the voices of your stakeholders around the table is useful and important

author: A1
sentence: I think there’s a lot of world views that if you – the ticking the box

author: A1
sentence: We talk about the diversity categories now so women, then gay, the disability, whatever

author: A1
sentence: I think you could take a broader view of world views than that

author: A1
sentence: I think there’s – where people are brought up is often not factored in and it’s hard to categorise but I grew up in a little country town and went to a public school and you don’t see that around some of the boards that I’m on

author: A1
sentence: I think I bring a valuable world view that people aren’t used to sometimes so there’s that factor as well

author: A1
sentence: So there’s just people having – people who are raised in a different country have a different way of looking at the same problem and to me that’s where you get the secret source of great outcomes from diversity is where people can look at a problem, all be pushing in the same direction but have different ways of seeing what a solution might be and feel and you get into the inclusion and then feel enabled and welcomed to provide that world view without feeling silly or talked down to

author: A1
sentence: So one example of getting the grant space is that not for profit organisations many of them exist on grants

author: A1
sentence: They get a lot of grants

author: A1
sentence: 23IN knows more about this than I do

author: A1
sentence: So they seek grants and they get grants and then they have to report on the grants and report to the funders what they do but we were told very early on working with grant recipients and grant seekers that the processes of getting a grant were overly cumbersome or the processes of reporting on a grant were silly

author: A1
sentence: They knew they were filling out lots of reports and that no one was actually reading them

author: A1
sentence: They were just going on the shelf

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: And then you get these great stuff emerging

author: Q

sentence: I’m not so into that

author: A1
sentence: So if you had 10 people from diverse world views in the room -

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A1
sentence: - you may have your black hat thinker or whatever, but you get another 10 different people in the room, you’re going to get – if you’ve got truly diversity, you’re going to get 10 new different ways of looking at things

author: A1
sentence: So I think putting people into, “You’re the this person, you’re the that person,” is not as helpful to me as thinking about diversity as people who’ve just been raised differently, in a different world, in a different context

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A2
sentence: There’s a danger in that too with that cognitive diversity

author: A2
sentence: You could still get a board of 10 white guys who will say, “Well, you’re a this, you’re an engineer, and you’re a this thinker and you’re a that thinker,” and stuff, so I think you could – again, I guess some of the terms are useful to sort of hide behind, in terms of still justifying why your board is predominantly a certain way

author: A2
sentence: It’s kind of like the merit argument with women, “Well, they’re out of the workforce for such a long period of time, so of course the guys have got ahead

author: A2
sentence: Of course that sort of happened

author: A2
sentence: ”  So I think – and I agree with Kath too about the diversity of where you’re brought up or what your background is, what your life experience is

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A2
sentence: But, again, I think you still need to be very aware of the fact that you can still have a pretty homogenous board just saying you were brought up in Broadie, you were brought up in Toorak so that’s a good – that is good but you still have to sort of look broader and say, well, from a different country or from a different – yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: I had this woman I was interviewing her and it was one of the more exciting interviews in terms of this diversity and there was an Aboriginal painting on the wall of all these different colours and ways of interacting and she said, “That’s diversity”, and it’s sort of because it brings – there’s that cognitive different ways of thinking process versus outcomes

author: A2
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q

author: A1
sentence: So we were then able to work with the funding community to help them understand what those problems were and also offer some solutions around this is how you could do it better and one example of that is we built a software platform called SmartyGrants which funders now use to manage their grants process into which we embed some good practices

author: A2
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: There’s da da da da da

sentence: So we’re all – I just think we’re all very complex beings who are made up of lots of different things around our genetics, how we were brought up, what happened to us when we were 20 or -

author: A
sentence: Yeah I’m not sure that there really is, I think most sectors are certainly beneficiaries  in one way or another of private capital investment

author: A
sentence: But what does vary at different points in time, some sectors may be attracting more or less capital than others

author: A
sentence: So over the past ten years now here in Australia for example the one sector that has consistently attracted large amounts of capital investment as compared to others is the health care sector and that's because there's been tremendous growth with the technology and advances in pathologies or therapeutics and diagnostics and coupled with of course the aging population, people receive better healthcare throughout their life

author: A
sentence: All of that has come together in a variety of different ways to make healthcare, even aged care sectors that have them high on the radar for private capital investors because of that future outlook and opportunity that is core to what type of capital investment they’re looking for is sectors and businesses that are in that sector that exhibit strong fundamentals of growth and expansion opportunities

author: A
sentence: So that [unclear] 00:08:22 and that's the reason why private capital is [unclear] track very closely the movements and the opportunities of the healthcare sector for example

author: Q
sentence: Well that’s interesting okay

author: Q
sentence: So I see that your organisation has a role to play, not only on the board which we’ll explore soon, but the regulatory framework, so policy, like an advocacy organisation for your members

author: Q
sentence: So if you’re interested in for example health is a rapid growth area, so you start to become more active in shaping policy around health, is that sort of what that means?

author: A
sentence: Yeah well broadly

author: A
sentence: So we, I mean we could spend a lot of time deep diving into policy areas that relate to the sectors that our members invest into which can get a little bit tricky and very time consuming

author: A
sentence: So what we tend to debate most of our energy to Margot is ensuring that the policy and the regulatory framework that sits within the financial services component of the economy is set up in a way that helps the facilitate greater investment and encourage greater investment

author: A
sentence: So in other words we want government policies to enable more capital to flow into Australian businesses to help them grow and expand to employ more people

author: A
sentence: To make a bigger contribution for the economy and so our interest from a policy and advocacy perspective is ensuring that the government of the day, whoever that might be, understands our role as an industry

author: A
sentence: And then if they put in place policies that support and encourage more investment and in some cases that might be more of a discussion about ensuring that there aren’t policies and regulations that get in the way of investment

author: A
sentence: So it depends on the context and the situation

author: A
sentence: We tend to gravitate towards those areas of policy that help to create a bigger pipeline of investing, let’s get more capital in the Australia economy rather than getting too far into the detail of specific sectors and the policy issues that might sit around the healthcare sector

author: A
sentence: But having said all that, from time to time we do, so there are significant orders of policy where we have worked closely with government in the healthcare sector for example to ensure that there is the right policy architecture in place to support things like the translation and commercialisation of high quality medical research into commercialised products and services in the Australian market then the global market

author: A
sentence: So some of the time we do that where there’s a compelling argument about increasing the flow of capital to particular sectors within our economy

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: So how long has, I think you’re twenty-five years your organisation I think, it’s twenty-five years you celebrated?

author: A
sentence: Yeah we’ve been around for about twenty-five years, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: Are you, would that be how long any sort of private equity has been available in Australia? Does that mark the time?

author: A
sentence: Yeah look I think it depends of course on who you talk to and the line that they want to draw

author: A
sentence: But broadly speaking I think capital investment in the Australia market is about a twenty-five to thirty year old industry and it has its origins in the venture side of our industry in particular

author: A
sentence: So investing in very early stage somewhat risky business ventures to help them commercialise a product or a service in the market

author: A
sentence: That was really where our industry started, yeah in the Australia economy

author: A
sentence: In markets like the US private equity, private capital has a much longer, much richer history and probably can be traced back forty or fifty years and somebody could say longer than that

author: A
sentence: It does depend on the particular line that you might draw

author: A
sentence: But for all intense and purposes here in Australia I would prompted to say it’s about a twenty-five to thirty year old industry

author: Q
sentence: So we’ve adopted competition policy in ‘95, I don’t know if that influenced the growth of private capital, but so -

author: A
sentence: I was just going to say I think the opening up of the Australian economy that occurred in the 1980s and [overtalk] 00:13:57 were part of the [unclear] 00:13:59 helped to redirect the Australian market outwardly and so that brought with it much greater awareness of what was happening in other markets around the world

author: A
sentence: And the fact that those events, those learnings if you like and experience of other markets globally [unclear] 00:14:26 it’s globally in particular helped to inform ideas that then ultimately shaped the Australian economy

author: A
sentence: So whilst you probably can’t draw a direct line between competition policy on its own, you could certainly say that all of the major structural economic reforms that were put in place certainly some years ago has certainly played a key role opening the Australian economy and that allowed us to take the learned sort of experience of offshore markets and bring them into our home market

author: A
sentence: Sure go for it

author: Q
sentence: Great, well that’s really useful context for me, because as I was reading your annual report I was, because we’re focused on board diversity which we will now focus on

author: Q
sentence: But I thought well it’s really this, the diversity of capital investment opportunity that is framing your organisations influence if that makes sense to you

author: Q
sentence: But since, what you bring in, your organisation, your members is I understand capital from all around the globe potentially

author: Q
sentence: And then so the influence that we have here then on Australian boards is shaped by the cultural experiences and other, by the backgrounds of these internationals

author: Q
sentence: So it’s much more global

author: A
sentence: Yeah absolutely

author: A
sentence: That’s very true

author: A
sentence: I mean the capital that our industry raises in order to then be able to invest in to Australian businesses is sourced from all over the world

author: A
sentence: So you do have, and that’s I think the point you’re flagging Margot, is you do have in effect large institution investors, like pension funds, like [unclear] 00:16:23 funds, family offices

author: A
sentence: Very sophisticated global investment now looking at the Australian market, not just with interest but in fact looking at the Australian market as a driver of growth

author: A
sentence: And then there’s another point of view as a driver of investment return

author: A
sentence: So there’s a key interest in what is happening here in the Australian market from a variety of perspectives, economic perspective and policy perspective, a community and societal perspective because there is so much reliance on that offshore capital to help fund the growth of our own investment pipeline here

author: A
sentence: So your point is absolutely right and that is that Australia now benefits from that destiny breeding international experience, that helps to inform what we’re doing here in Australia

author: A
sentence: And it’s informed through the investment capital itself directly

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: And the value add that the private capital seat on the board has will include the interest, the global interest as well to build growth, to create growth in terms of equity, its own equity

author: Q
sentence: So it just brings that other interest, it’s just, do you know what I mean? So the seat on the board is not just looking at the organisation and its particular strategy, it’s also looking at its pipeline capital and the needs, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So it brings that interest

author: A
sentence: Yeah it brings an international perspective that is informed through that flow of capital that comes from offshore into Australia

author: A
sentence: So that’s certainly the role that we looked at

author: A
sentence: The other way to look at it is complimentary and not mutual exclusive

author: A
sentence: Whichever way you look at it is that the international capital if you like, the international investment that occurs also helps to benefit the Australian businesses that are the beneficiaries of that investment capital because it allows them to partner those offshore institution investors to help them open up access to growth and expansion opportunities all over the world

author: A
sentence: So it’s certainly not a one way direction in conversation, it’s very much a two way strategic value piece here where the Australian businesses are benefiting not just from the investment capital but also benefiting from having partnerships, relationships with big sophisticated, very well networked and connected institutions all over the world that can open up access to markets and open up relationships in a way that the Australian business partners would not be able to do otherwise

sentence: It’s fabulous

author: A
sentence: Some years ago, or certainly twenty years ago and I think that’s a good thing for the Australian economy, it’s a good thing for Australian businesses

author: A
sentence: So there has clearly been a transition I think and a discussion is happening now every hour in every day around [unclear] 00:21:18 across the market

author: A
sentence: But I think it would also be right to say that we still have lots of work to do in the Australian economy to set ourselves up more comprehensively around diversity of experience in diversity thinking diversity gender et cetera

sentence: And I think we are still very much in the early days of bringing about that change

author: A

sentence: So we're on our way but more work to do I think is the best way to catch that in my perspective

author: A
sentence: [coughing] Excuse me

author: Q
sentence: Correct, okay

author: Q
sentence: So let’s get into it

author: Q
sentence: First of all how has the composition of these kinds of boards that you sit on how’s it changed over time the composition of these boards in terms of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: So for example your member on the board that’s from a financial services background because they’re key stakeholders for your board?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: That would be an example?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: What about consumers, like people who are small business owners?

author: A
sentence: Well yes

author: A
sentence: So if I look at the [Segay] board for example to have people on the board that are actually close to the membership is helpful because you hear, you mix, you understand their needs, so that would be akin to the consumer

author: A
sentence: To have people that are close to academia, because we – at CPAB, we embrace thought leadership initiatives and projects, even just the changing face of education, so to be able to plug in to that network to discuss where education is heading through to government, development of policy, and development of laws, through to regulators

author: A
sentence: There’s quite a lot of stakeholder management and if you’ve got – life is so much easier if you can reach out to people and be able to have an open door

author: Q
sentence: I imagine it might even be unaware of the potential impacts of regulatory trends or that if you don’t have someone into that field or has an understanding in that field for example

author: Q
sentence: So it helps the board to be more strategic doesn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Yes, yes

author: A
sentence: It just means you’re not acting – you’re not in a little cocoon locked inside a boardroom making decisions with windows, blinds drawn and the windows closed

author: A
sentence: You’re actually using the information that you know to make even better decisions

author: A
sentence: I think it’s quite critical frankly

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so you see social networks as an extension of the diversity of the people on the board

author: Q
sentence: It’s like feeding back into the -?

author: A
sentence: It’s almost what can you bring to the role and it’s – you get me but me means how I’ve got to be where I am is because I’ve had this experience, this experience, this experience and for example with me I do a lot with members, I do a lot with standard sitting boards, so I do a lot with regulators

author: A
sentence: So I can facilitate discussions and when we’re – the organisation may need to be part of I can get them in the room which is important

author: A
sentence: The other is that when we’re discussing things about where the organisation should head that knowledge that you’ve gained from all different parts you don’t leave it at the door, you turn around and say this – that’s really great but it’s not going to work because this – this cohort would be really unhappy with that or I know that this project’s already been implemented by somebody

author: A
sentence: And it’s not giving away confidential information, that’s not what I’m talking about, it’s just that wealth of knowledge that you gather in your life you can harness it and it makes you the person that you are and the skills that you bring to the table

author: A
sentence: I think they’ve gone from being more adhoc

author: A
sentence: The one that I sat on the longest I was the first female on that board

author: A
sentence: They had never had any other females and around the table it was very – whilst they were all different people they were all very similar, similar backgrounds, similar ages

author: A
sentence: So there was no diversity at all

author: A
sentence: As -

author: Q
sentence: It’s a lot for a new – a person wanting to be a member of the board to be part of an interview with this wealth -

author: A
sentence: It is

author: Q
sentence: -@ that you bring

author: Q
sentence: So yeah interesting

author: Q
sentence: does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others do you think?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: But do you have thoughts –?

author: Q
sentence: Would it change, would that vary depending on a situation?

author: A
sentence: I think so, yeah

author: A
sentence: I do

author: A
sentence: I think if depending on the board and the purposes of the organisation it may give rise to the shape of the board being different from just the traditional structures

author: Q
sentence: So why do you think in 2005 you were brought onto the board?  What prompted that?  Why did it become important?

author: A
sentence: Well I think I – maybe if they looked at it and thought that they needed to do something about diversity, who knows, I’m not quite sure

author: A
sentence: They also – they also wanted to – it was strategic from their point of view because they were looking to strengthen the relationship – a relationship and I was a mechanism to be able to strengthen the relationship

author: Q
sentence: So this is a social network as you would define it that you brought

author: Q
sentence: So that was seen as a strength and your background

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And what were the ages and background?

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: So – and then you happen to be a female

author: A
sentence: Yeah I think it – that was perhaps accidental but it – it ticked a few boxes

author: Q
sentence: Because when did targets come in?

author: A
sentence: Much later

author: Q
sentence: It was -

author: A
sentence: I’m not quite sure

author: Q
sentence: - about 10 years later or something

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So this was before targets, so it’s interesting

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Board functioning: we want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: You’ve talked about group think, so are there particular board functions that diversity can really help with and can you give me an example?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s just well making sure that you varies the broad range of skills to be able to discharge all the duties that a board has to do

author: A
sentence: So to make sure that there is that diversity amongst the board that the board can make sound decisions and drawing on the various skillsets of the different board members

author: A
sentence: And I also think that it just helps people – it bring different styles and different thought processes to the board table which I think produces better outcomes

author: A
sentence: All male, 40s/50s, senior in their roles, white Anglo-Saxon

author: A
sentence: So very atypical of what boards, I think, used to look and some still sadly

author: A
sentence: But we – we consciously, when I joined that board I think it was a bit of a oh goodness moment that – and they thought they were embracing diversity by having a female join the board, one

author: A
sentence: I’ve recently rolled off that ball and they now have 30% female and a really good mix of other skills and traits as well and it was a very much a conscious decision when they were recruiting for the board to look at diversity issues

author: A
sentence: So we had made significant changes

author: A
sentence: The other board that I sit on, which I’m only – I’ve only been on just over a year – come in, come in, she’s bringing a drink

author: A
sentence: Thank you

author: A
sentence: Cup of tea

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of that latter one?

author: A
sentence: I think it just is about how we approach decision making and how different people unpack different decisions

author: A
sentence: We’re all presented with the same decision or resolution that needs to be made and then it’s just how we get to actually the end result

author: A
sentence: And that’s why I say it’s really important because I can prepare for the meeting, have my views and then I’ll go to a meeting and I’ll hear someone else and it will either – the way that they have – and different issues that they have taken into consideration, things that perhaps I hadn’t thought about and I also think yeah, you know, they’re right and that’s really good and I hadn’t – I hadn’t thought about that

author: A
sentence: And now that I have I think such and such

author: A
sentence: So it helps and as a consequence of that it makes – I have grown as a consequence of watching how other people also apply things

author: A
sentence: So I have – I feel like I’m a very – I’m a very different person then what I was when I joined the first board all those years ago because I have looked at what other people have done and not mimicked them, but I would like to think that they have educated me to grow and to embrace different thoughts, different ways and that is a – that’s a really good outcome for me personally but it’s also provided a much better outcome for the organisation

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: No-one has articulated that so clearly that there’s a – there’s a benefit for the board member of diversity

author: Q
sentence: It’s actually motivating, reinforcing

author: A
sentence: I am so thankful because I have – I really have enjoyed the experiences that I have and as I said I’ve grown significantly professionally and personally as a result of it

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: That’s great, thank you

author: Q
sentence: Where are we here?  Do you think there’s a situation where diversity might limit or undermine the performance of the board?

author: A
sentence: I think it would be where people are so conscious of diversity that they don’t put the best people on the board

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: And that comes back to what I say is the selection always has to be of the best people with mindful to diversity, and one would think that you should be able to cater for both but you should not compromise quality for the sake of diversity

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So if for some reason your proffered candidates there was tension, conflict between diversity and the best, so it was an either or, you would go for the best person rather than the diversity

author: Q
sentence: But I remember hearing Penny Wong talking of women on boards for example and she said – she was given a proffered list and there were about two women and 50 men and she said, “Give me another list, I can’t believe that there aren’t 50%”

author: Q
sentence: That’s nice

author: Q
sentence: Lovely

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful thank you

author: A
sentence: See that comes down – that thing comes down to the identification in the first instance

author: A
sentence: It’s about people being open minded to ensure that they haven’t – they haven’t adopted an unconscious bias to say, well I’m only – diversity means we have to have two or three out of ten, that’s what we’ll do

author: A
sentence: But if it’s – if there were 10 fabulous women for example then there’s 10 fabulous women, if there’s 10 fabulous men and they couldn’t possibly find a fabulous woman one would have to – you’d have to wonder why but if that was truly because it was so narrow or so unique then I don’t – I think that you’ll always have to make sure you’ve got the best

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: But I just don’t think that it’s that hard to find people from different backgrounds that are not fabulous

author: Q
sentence: I mean it might be – if a cultural background it might be people from a different ethnic background for some reason, you might look for diversity in terms of ethnicity and it might be that you have fewer to choose from because of lack of opportunity in that sector

author: Q
sentence: Probably not in your board, it may not be relevant except if there’s a whole lot of businesses from – drawing from that space, I don’t know, from new businesses from recent immigrants who perhaps from refugee backgrounds

author: Q
