sentence: I know the government is in – there’s some supports to get people like that into small businesses

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know if there’s – but let’s say you had a substantial segment going rogue from that group maybe understanding that sector would be relevant?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: But I don’t think you need to – you need to have an understanding of board level but you don’t need to have someone that’s not got the skills at board level

author: A
sentence: And to me what that means is that an organisation if they are saying, “We can’t find quality candidates with the diversity that we need” we have to ask why is that and are we exercising our conscious bias and ruling people out that are really suitable

author: A
sentence: Or if there are really none how do we remedy that in the future?  And that will be your leadership programs that you put in place so that you do have this pipeline coming up of people who will have, not perhaps right this moment but within a relatively short space of time, the skills that you need

author: A
sentence: But compromising skills on a board is dangerous

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: So the leadership programs you’re talking about?

author: A
sentence: There’s leadership programs that – for example a lot of the banks identified some time back that they had, in their senior ranks, they did not have diversity, and they have consciously set about identifying suitable people and ensuring that those skills are grown

author: A
sentence: And that is – again it’s an investment in the future so they are consciously acknowledging that by a certain point of time – and this is, I suppose, where targets become handy is because you set yourself some goals for in the future that we want to be able to have a representation that looks like this at board level but to do that we need to have the candidates to choose from and we need to grow people into those roles

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Okay so that’s a board driven – that would be a board driven strategy that leadership -?

author: A
sentence: It would be a board driven strategy, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Perfect

author: Q
sentence: So with – are there any decisions or functions of the board that really is irrelevant, diversity is irrelevant?

author: A
sentence: Thanks very much Victoria

author: A
sentence: Lovely

author: A
sentence: The other board that I sit on I’ve only just – as I said I’ve only been on that just over a year or 18 months but there’s been a very conscious decision there to address diversity, and that’s a very balanced board

author: A
sentence: We actually have – currently we have more females than males on the board which would be unusual but makes it a very well balanced board

author: A
sentence: And we all have different backgrounds and different age groups and it works very, very well

author: A
sentence: I think that at the end of the day the decisions made by the board diversity is irrelevant, but how they are made diversity is relevant

author: Q
sentence: So it’s the process that it’s relevant to?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, but ultimately the decisions are not driven by diversity

author: Q
sentence: What does that mean?

author: A
sentence: Well I think you’ve got a job to do whether you’re – whatever background you have you have a job to do as a director how you exercise your thought process, your morals comes through your background and the more diverse that is the more rounded you are as a cohort

author: A
sentence: But ultimately when you’re exercising a decision diversity is not what drives the decision

author: Q
sentence: I see

author: Q
sentence: This links back to your point about was it the role, understanding and respect and other people have talked about it’s the goals of the organisation, the strategy, so it’s that filter that the board, whatever that decision’s about, so that’s the common ground that diversity feeds into and surrenders to in the end?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: That’s it’s not that when you’re making a decision at board level you’re not making it because you have a certain background, you have to make it before the interest of the organisation

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so it’s -

author: A
sentence: Otherwise you are not fulfilling your fiduciary duties

author: Q
sentence: You’re bringing an agenda?

author: Q
sentence: And yet that one is about a particular professional group isn’t it, an association for a professional group?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: And agenda of diversity is not what this is about

author: Q
sentence: This is about bringing diversity so that the decision is well considered

author: A
sentence: Well rounded

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that is really good

author: Q
sentence: Could you please highlight that section for me?  I’m just saying that to the transcriber because that’s a neat distinction thing

author: Q
sentence: Any idea – can you remember a situation or have you experienced a situation where conflict arose that you thought was because of diversity?  Perhaps mismanaged diversity?

author: A
sentence: Not really, no

author: A
sentence: Boards I’ve had the privilege of serving on have been really well functioning and respectful

author: A
sentence: So no conflict has arisen

author: Q
sentence: So we’re specifically focus now on cognitive diversity, do you feel that – that’s a different way of thinking – do you feel that cognitive diversity influences your board’s functioning?  You’ve said – you’ve already said it does, yeah

author: Q
sentence: We won’t go – and how might cognitive diversity be identified?  For example, when you’re selecting board members?  I think you’ve covered it or is there anything -?

author: A
sentence: I think that’s through the interview stage

author: Q
sentence: And the skills matrix

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So that’s that process you described

author: Q
sentence: Yes, you’ve said that

author: Q
sentence: Did the boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to managing on building its diversity?

author: A
sentence: Both were

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: No external barriers, no professional, no legal, no regulatory?

author: A
sentence: No, not that I can think of

author: Q
sentence: Social, cultural?

author: A
sentence: No, we embrace both of those

author: A
sentence: Boards we embrace diversity

author: A
sentence: There was no reasons why we couldn’t consider candidates from quite a broad range of backgrounds

author: Q
sentence: I suppose the barrier that was present was that agenda diversity, lack of it, and you really became the magnet, the champion that opened the field

author: Q
sentence: So you – that I suppose was a turning point?  There was a barrier, cultural barrier?

author: A
sentence: Yes, but the board now that’s not an issue

author: A
sentence: And they consciously consider that when they’re looking at the makeup of the board

author: Q
sentence: Have you contributed to that?

author: A
sentence: Oh yes

author: A
sentence: But everybody on the board did

author: Q
sentence: Were you the prompt for it?  Would it have happened otherwise?

author: Q
sentence: And different backgrounds even though it’s for a particular professional group

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think I was the prompt for it, but I was one of the prompts

author: Q
sentence: Targets and talk about it in the meeting, all that, was that a prompt?

author: A
sentence: Perhaps subconsciously but not directly

author: Q
sentence: AICD? [inaudible] 00:50:27

author: A
sentence: Again, subconsciously, I don’t think it’s certainly that – we haven’t said, “Well, this is what they say, so we must follow it” but all of those things are taken – they just -

author: Q
sentence: Awareness

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: It’s just general awareness and a desire to – and a unified belief that a diverse board is a better board

author: A
sentence: So on both of those boards there was a unified belief

author: A
sentence: So it wasn’t one person driving this agenda, it was quite – it was a consensus board that this was where we needed to be

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: And I guess we – the leadership programs then – I know that you said they’re in the banks but I gather they’re part of the broader – the pipeline for your boards, is it?  Is there a connection that way?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yeah, there is but mainly I think that example was about what other organisations are doing

author: Q
sentence: What does your organisation do to cultivate candidates from different backgrounds?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well what it does is sets the criteria, so when board – when they’re looking for board members there will be the criteria settled by the Nominations Committee and that comes down to that skills matrix so that they are very – they would say they’d look at all the exiting board members and say this is their attributes and their skills and this is what we need for the board, where have we got gaps and that’s what we’re looking for

author: A
sentence: So again it comes back to making sure that that skills matrix is really quite broad

author: Q
sentence: It is key isn’t it?  I’m seeing this as more – I first heard of skills matrix and I thought oh yeah it’s a tool but I’m now starting to see it as more as a deeper phenomena because it’s – it’s changing the rules of the game

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well they’re positive attributes where years and years ago anecdotally you would say well if somebody went to the right club and the right school that was all they needed to be able to perform the role, to get on the board and of some of our major companies

author: A
sentence: Where nowadays one would hope that it’s a little bit more sophisticated, that that – yeah they might have gone to the right school, they might go to the right clubs but fundamentally they have to have the skills to be a director

author: A
sentence: Because if they don’t and something goes wrong then they will be prosecuted, there’s significant responsibilities that goes with the title of director and if they’re breached they have significant and real consequences

author: A
sentence: So people, I think, have to be more aware that it isn’t just a mate’s club anymore

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that call for accountability when did it become quite tight: the regulation, the liability for -?

author: A
sentence: It’s – as lots of things it’s just been progressive but the requirements have always been in the law but it’s certainly -

author: Q
sentence: Tightened

author: A
sentence: - the expectations of directors duties have been more focussed, I think, certainly since the GFC but even after the last big recession that Australia had in the 1990s that was when people said well if you’re going to be a director you have to make sure you equip yourself right because if you don’t you’re going to be held accountable

author: A
sentence: Particularly where there is any large corporate failures, it’s always “what were the directors doing”

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, we had OneTel back then, didn’t we?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, OneTel

author: Q
sentence: And then HIH later, major

author: Q
sentence: No, that’s alright

author: Q
sentence: It’s been going around

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me why is diversity important in that context?  It’s a bit different

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and people look at those and say, “Well what were the directors doing?  What were their skills?  Were they looking at the financial statements?   Did they understand the financial statements?”

author: A
sentence: Well if you haven’t got any skills in that area it’s hard to demonstrate that you could actually read a set of financial statements and understand what they were meaning, let alone as the questions

author: Q
sentence: The relevant questions

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: The skills matrix when did that become pretty standard use of a skills matrix?

author: A
sentence: I would think in the last 10 years but maybe a bit less

author: A
sentence: But if you’re talking to any of the recruiters they would be able to tell you a bit more

author: A
sentence: But I’m thinking five to ten years

author: Q
sentence: I’ll try and find a precise number for that because I actually underestimated the importance of it

author: A
sentence: I think it’s really important

author: A
sentence: I’m not quite sure how widely used it is

author: Q
sentence: It’s widely used

author: A
sentence: It should be

author: Q
sentence: It’s widely used but it’s funny because you’re the one who has shown me the strategic value of it rather than as a – so thank you

author: Q
sentence: I’m conscious of the time

author: Q
sentence: Do you -?  From a regulatory perspective how do you feel about the way diversity on Australian boards is currently being promoted?

author: A
sentence: Diversity’s important -

author: A
sentence: From a regulatory perspective?

author: Q
sentence: Softer gender targets and quota – and firmer as quotas to influence board diversity for example?

author: A
sentence: Sorry I didn’t get that

author: Q
sentence: Sorry

author: Q
sentence: The use of targets and quotas for example

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Look I think they’re good goals to have but as I said ultimately I think it’s important that the best people are put in those very responsible positions

author: A
sentence: So they’re good goals but I don’t think that they’re – they necessarily should be hard targets

author: A
sentence: And I know that there’s lots of schools of thought because I have these debates with my friends about well you need to have a target because if you don’t you’ll never get there

author: A
sentence: But I do always worry that we can’t have that trade-off

author: A
sentence: The roles are too important, we can’t have that trade-off that we have lesser quality people just purely to make up the numbers

author: Q
sentence: That’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Need to avoid creating that trade off which you talked about the conflict, creating a conflict between the roles – the tasks – the skills you need and what’s a good skills versus diversity

author: Q
sentence: If you create that with quotas for example then you’ve got a problem for the board

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: A
sentence: But it is making sure, I suppose, that that selection process that you’ve got people who are prepared to have an open mind about diversity without thinking they all have to come from this particular pot and then ensuring that the people that are put up do have good skills, and if they don’t then the organisation needs to invest in leadership programs so that they provide a pathway and in the future of people with appropriate skills

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s a kind of diversity that’s important but really hard to measure, hard to monitor?

author: A
sentence: Can you give me an example?

author: Q
sentence: Well I’m thinking of the sort of character stuff you talked about for example that comes up in interviews, the type of person which is the fit with the board

author: Q
sentence: Background

author: A
sentence: Hard to measure: look I’m probably not the best person to answer that question

author: A
sentence: I think that there is all sorts of tools that they use when they – those – they can do character assessments and personality profiling and all those sorts of things that they do nowadays

author: A
sentence: So I think if they want to they can mission nearly everything, whether it works out is another thing

author: Q
sentence: Finally, the final question: looking 10 years into the future how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: I would love to think that we’re not even talking about diversity, that it just happens, that it’s just a given and that we don’t even have to be talking about targets or quotas or be surprised that we have diverse boards because it should be the norm

author: A
sentence: That’s what I’d really like

author: Q
sentence: We have no unconscious bias in that world

author: A
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much, that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: We are on the hour

author: A
sentence: Wonderful

author: Q
sentence: We did it

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s important because you get a – if you look at one of the boards it’s the membership based which is akin to the shareholders, but the membership base is very diverse and you need to have a board that reflects the membership otherwise it perhaps doesn’t understand or relate to its members

author: A
sentence: So I think we certainly have, when they look at the skills matrix for that board I think that they look at all the different cohorts in the membership and try to ensure that they – that people have a connection to the various cohorts

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Are the members all of the same professional background?

author: A
sentence: They’re all accountants, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So all the board members are they all accountants?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: The bulk are

author: A
sentence: But there are two independent non-member directors

author: A
sentence: And again that’s just to ensure that we have a breadth of knowledge and are not totally inward focussing

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Would one of those be a lawyer?

author: A
sentence: There are some not practicing lawyer but they would have a legal background

author: A
sentence: I know

author: Q
sentence: Legal background

author: Q
sentence: And the other background is that’s considered important?

author: A
sentence: Financial services

author: Q
sentence: And that’s – is that because it’s associated with the profession?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So it’s like a customer?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and also because it is adjunct to what some of our members do

author: A
sentence: They are very active in that financial services area

author: Q
sentence: Thank you, that’s good, that’s great, ta

author: Q
sentence: Now you mentioned – so let’s follow on from that – about when – first of all how long ago were you the first female on the organisation?

author: A
sentence: That one, that would have been over 10 years ago

author: Q
sentence: Over 10, oh good, so like 2008?

author: A
sentence: Could have been longer than that

author: A
sentence: Might have been -

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well, thank you very much, 26D, for agreeing to participate in the research

author: Q
sentence: We’re going to talk about diversity of Australian boards, and there’s been a lot of research in this area, but we’re looking specifically at Australian boards, and we’re going to the field, we’re going to people who sit on boards and institutions and organisations that influence people on boards, here in Australia, to gain an understanding of what it means and how it’s managed

author: Q
sentence: So that’s basically what we’re looking at

author: Q
sentence: Seven?

author: A
sentence: I’m just trying to think, probably mid 2000s I would have thought

author: Q
sentence: Like 2005 roughly?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Five, first female

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: And the profession that it represents would that be 50% women in it?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Less?  More?

author: A
sentence: It’s heavily male dominated

author: Q
sentence: So to get an equal proportion of women on the board -

author: A
sentence: Well, that is – the [Segay] 00:07:34 board’s got equal representation of women

author: A
sentence: There’s that – the membership of CPA is almost 50/50, particularly with new members, it’s 50/50 gender

author: A
sentence: [Arete’s] 00:07:51 membership was predominately male

author: A
sentence: It just seems to be that a lot of – not a lot of women went into the insolvency field

author: A
sentence: There’s a few more now but they still struggle for gender balance in that industry, in that profession

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: So do you think the board is leading that tendency or influence?  So if it was a more diverse board it would result in -?

author: A
sentence: I think the fact that the board has been more diverse of recent years is one of the mechanisms that we have at [Arete] into implemented to foster the growth of women in that profession

author: Q
sentence: See that’s really good because often people talk in the pipeline as one-way process where it’s people in the field or management in the organisation, it needs to be diverse in order to feed the board

author: Q
sentence: But you’re saying you’re getting a diverse board in order to cultivate more diversity within the field

author: A
sentence: Yeah because it’s leading by example

author: A
sentence: I’m a strong believer of that

author: Q
sentence: Excellent, thank you

author: Q
sentence: So how important do you think diversity is: let’s say 10’s extremely important and one is not important at all?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s 10

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been important?  To you has it always been important?

author: A
sentence: It’s about always been important to me

author: A
sentence: And I think that might be because I have been part of a minority group and can see how it was – when I – for me doing what I did in insolvency was considered to be, at the time, quite ground breaking and a lot of younger insolvency practitioners, both male and female, have, at times, really said they appreciated the hard yards because it was very – it would have been so much easier for me not to keep pushing to achieve what I achieved in some respects

author: A
sentence: But that wasn’t me so – and then I – and because I believed that and I think others then have the courage to say, “Well if she can do it I can to” and as a consequence there’s been quite a change

author: A
sentence: Still a long way to go but quite a change

author: A
sentence: But I just think diversity is important because you – boards need to ensure that they don’t suffer from group think

author: A
sentence: And if you get a whole bunch of people who are all very similar and all nod around the table they never challenge one another, they never – they don’t bring different ways of thinking or different thoughts

author: A
sentence: And I welcome the fact that I can attend – I can go about my board duties, have read all my papers, have formed a view in my own mind – not that I’m easily swayed – but I can hear what someone else has said and think to myself I hadn’t turned my mind to that and is there merit in what they’re saying

author: A
sentence: Or I can turn around and say no that’s just garbage, I still don’t believe

author: A
sentence: Still I think my view is the right view but if I haven’t got that – if we’re all of the same view all the time on everything – you have to have harmony on a board but – and you can’t always be challenging everything but on the important things you have to be able to have critical thinking and if you – diversity encourages that

author: Q
sentence: Look I’m really – there’s two points I really want to pick up there: one is that conflict, how to manage that, how’s that managed so that it’s productive; and the other is how recruiting tensions possibly between that culture of the board so as it can be productive and group think

author: Q
sentence: So you recruit for diversity but there’s a risk of creating too much conflict in the board, so there’s sort of – connect with each other

author: Q
sentence: Could you -?

author: Q
sentence: So you mentioned that you’re on two boards, they’re both in the financial area

author: Q
sentence: Are they listed?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s looking at characters, people’s characters

author: A
sentence: There are people who have extreme views and are quite polarising and become antagonistic, and that’s not healthy for a board and not healthy for the organisation which the board serves

author: A
sentence: But if you have people who bring an enquiring mind to the role, understand their responsibilities and can have the maturity and the respect around the table to be able to discuss an issue and not be offended that somebody’s view is different then that’s a really well functioning board

author: A
sentence: And in some respects the chair can play a big role in that because if the chair shuts down anytime someone says, “Could I please ask this question” and the chair says, “No, we’ve dealt with it move on” time and time and time again it takes a very strong character to say, “No, actually I want to discuss this”

author: A
sentence: So the chair is really pivotal in ensuring that there is a board that can explore and discuss, unpack important issues

author: A
sentence: And invariably in my experience I’ve found as a consequence of doing that we do get a consensus and in most of the time it is unanimous but it’s not without having gone through that process

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Have you ever struck a lack of respect on the board where you’ve felt a different view was -?

author: A
sentence: No, not on the – not of recent times

author: A
sentence: And when I first jointed the [Arete] board it was – it was a bit autocratic in as much as the chair was very strong and their view was their view and no-one else is really entitled to a view

author: A
sentence: But that didn’t last about that long now with us so I think that was just a hang up of what how it used to be and they probably didn’t even realise that they were like that

author: A
sentence: But then the more confidence you get the more you – if you – I think each director has a responsibility to ensure that that does not happen

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So the culture – it’s the same chair, so the chair learnt because the board changed as more people came on from different perspectives?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: It’s a bit like kids educating the parents about respect for difference, whatever

author: Q
sentence: Okay so the culture was transferred

author: Q
sentence: That’s good because some people just refer to the chair and I’m thinking well this is a one-way street again but clearly you’re showing how a diverse board will cultivate the chair

author: Q
sentence: And if the chair doesn’t respond have you heard of, experienced the chair being removed?

author: A
sentence: I have not, no

author: A
sentence: But I think – I think a properly functioning board does reviews the board and reviews peer reviews, so you review not only your performance but others review your performance and the chair is one of those people that the board will review

author: A
sentence: So it will become pretty clear that they’re not – they don’t have the support of the rest of the board and I think they either will understand that they need to change or that a change will need to occur

author: Q
sentence: I’m intrigued how – let’s say the chair is obstinate and is blocking that reform, that process, how – there’s no-one above the chair is there who can -?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: The chair can do it to the CEO but -?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s – but then the board will just say that they don’t support the chair

author: A
sentence: So it would be the board again not revolting against the chair but it would be the board joining together to say it’s not appropriate

author: Q
sentence: So a democratic process?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: And the other thing was the tension, when bringing on new people, new members to the board the potential tension between on the one hand avoiding group think but on the other avoiding people who might disrupt the processes of the board

author: A
sentence: Can you give me an example?  What do you mean by that?

author: Q
sentence: So this is not from experience, this is from literature: there can be conflict, so there’s a concern: one concern is that diverse boards there can be more conflict

author: Q
sentence: So this is to this point about antagonism, passive resistance to different points of view creating resentment, disrespect, that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: So if you’ve got someone perceived to be too different, their point of view too different it can create tension

author: Q
sentence: So you want to avoid group think, you want different ways of thinking but you also want to have a productive board

author: Q
sentence: So this is a recruitment challenge

author: A
sentence: It is, definitely

author: Q
sentence: I’m just wondering how that’s managed?

author: A
sentence: I think in the first instance it’s really important to get the skills matrix right so that you can be clear the skills that you are seeking and those skills and attributes can’t be oh well we need someone with a legal background full stop

author: A
sentence: It has to be broader than that, hence the term “matrix”

author: A
sentence: So you identify what you’re looking for and then part of the process also needs, as I said, to look at the personal attributes of the individual as to how they will fit in with the board, and whether they are someone who is strong enough character wise to be able to hold their position on important issues but not be belligerent

author: A
sentence: Because belligerent – someone that’s belligerent isn’t acting in the interest of the organisation

author: A
sentence: They – a director has a fiduciary duty to organisations to act in its best interests

author: A
sentence: Always being belligerent, the one that never agrees with anything no matter how much sense it makes they’re not acting in the interest of the organisation

author: A
sentence: One would have to say they’re perhaps acting in self-interest and that’s not what a director should do

author: Q
sentence: They’re non-listed companies?

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: So how do you assess that, that person’s -?

author: A
sentence: It’s through the interview process, the screening I suppose, looking at – the applicants all probably look fabulous on paper but it’s getting behind the documentation, checking their references and the interview

author: A
sentence: The interview is critical

author: A
sentence: And then the panel who interviews is also critical as to whether again if you have – you’ve got to make sure that you don’t have a panel that’s made up, that is really just looking for people like us

author: A
sentence: So you’ve got to have diversity on your panel as well because – and that – I know of some organisations where they will have quite – they will have people from within the organisation on the panel but they’ll also have external people on the panel that have psychology skills, HR skills, those sorts of things that look at things from quite a different perspective from someone who just needs to know whether you’re technically proficient

author: Q
sentence: Okay so it’s not just a subset of the board, that interview, you go externally and you go within the organisation as well?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so then you get quite diverse views

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: No-one’s explained that process or [inaudible] 00:22:04 process of course

author: Q
sentence: Subcommittees have been mentioned

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there’s any situation or context that might cause you to change the importance rating of 10 that you gave it like high risk, high uncertainty, just thinking about your -?

author: A
sentence: I’m firmly of the view that you have the best people in the role, so whilst I see diversity as really important there may be times where the best people are all female or all male or all from one particular cohort

author: A
sentence: So I don’t think that the pursuit of diversity should be – should mean that the people that are chosen are less than the best people for the role

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: Which puts a lot of onus on the recruitment process that it is open to diversity

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Because that’s feeding that

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Otherwise it’s very easy to say well there’s – we just don’t have – the best people in the role happen to be all men in their 50s

author: Q
sentence: So if your recruitment process, let’s say people select like for like in that the person section, not the skills matrix but the personal characteristics then you’ll find that

author: A
sentence: Yeah and you’ll have the – this is what we would really like, these skills is what we’d really like, this profile is what we’d really like and then you’d try and find the person with all of those or as close to – close – the person with the most amount of those attributes

author: A
sentence: But if at the end of the day your wish list is not able to be met well then you’ve got to start prioritising what are must haves and what are likes

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Nice to haves

author: A
sentence: Nice to haves

author: Q
sentence: So as the first woman on this board did you have a mentor?  Did someone encourage you to do this?

author: A
sentence: I’ve had several mentors over my life

author: A
sentence: It was – did someone encourage me to do it?  I think it was – no it was an opportunity that came my way and I took it

author: A
sentence: So it wasn’t as if I had a plan that I could say well I planned and five years down the track I got there

author: A
sentence: It was just a – I suppose it was a series of opportunities that arose when they all joined together, that’s where I ended up

author: A
sentence: But it was – and it was being prepared to take the opportunities when they arose

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: So now you – then you became a champion so that as you said that I can see that other women will follow, but that initial start that was really like a hero

author: A
sentence: It was – it was – and I didn’t feel like that at the time and I look back now and I think wow that was really amazing but at the time it was okay I should do this

author: A
sentence: And I think the fact that we have been able to grow the number of females on that board is because people realised the benefits of having people like me on the board and that there is – it’s easy for people say you’re the token when you won, but I think that – I don’t think anybody would ever say that I was a token

author: A
sentence: And certainly, the ladies that are on the board now are far from tokenistic

author: A
sentence: They are strong, strong and worth their seat on the board

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good story

author: Q
sentence: What does board diversity mean to you?  How do you understand it?

author: A
sentence: Obviously gender, but different – different walks of life, different – different backgrounds

author: A
sentence: So you can all have very similar qualifications but you all have travelled different pathways

author: A
sentence: And I think that that’s important too because there are various jobs that a board has to attend to and different experiences and different backgrounds, different qualifications mean that those responsibilities can be covered from the board so that you’re not sitting there saying well we’ve got no-one that’s got audit and risk, it’s such an important part of the board but we don’t have got anyone who’s got risk skills or we don’t – nobody has ever read a legal contract and we’re entering into quite – quite detailed contracts but none of us know how to read legal contracts

author: A
sentence: So you’ve got to – so it’s – diversity is not just in gender, it is in skills, it is experiences both professionally and even life experiences, different backgrounds, different cultures

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: And what about in terms of – you mentioned knowledge also, inside and outside, so organisational knowledge because when you’re recruiting you have people from within the organisation then external and then on the board, so you have the different – and what’s another?  Problem solving, approaches to problem solving, you mentioned group think

author: Q
sentence: So some people label ways, different ways of thinking as cognitive diversity and so it’s – but I found that few people use that term

author: Q
sentence: It must be just in the literate

author: Q
sentence: Social networks that people have, is that important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, because it often helps with stakeholder management

author: A
sentence: So I think it is

author: A
sentence: Not so much as it needs to be a part of the club, totally against that, but vary it to have a network that you can draw on to at certain times it’s incredibly helpful

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that's a good time, isn't it?

author: A
sentence: Mm, it's very complicated, isn't it?

author: Q
sentence: And so feel safe

author: A
sentence: So then having said that, I know a lot of the people that are around the table at two Health Boards and there's still not enough diversity of thought, and there's still not enough of what I would call inclusion

author: A
sentence: So having the new standard of including consumers, carers and community in partners with the board in driving the strategy forward

author: A
sentence: A lot of that is still tick-boxing and that's because of the people that are still around the board

author: Q
sentence: What's the standard?  I don't know this

author: A
sentence: So there's a new standard as far as the national health care standards, standard 2, where the organisation actually has to show that they are doing things to include, because they found that there are improved health care outcomes if consumers are involved in the decision making around their health

author: A
sentence: So a lot of the organisations, because they've been forced to fill the standard, are making a lot of changes, but it's still a lot of what I think is tick-boxing as opposed to real inclusion, and there's a big difference around feedback or input

author: A
sentence: So if you want to be around the table when you're doing the input as opposed to feeding back after you've done all the work

author: A
sentence: So the problem with that is that you can't convince everybody that you can still manage consumers because how I'm treated as a consumer shows me that people are still tick-boxing

author: A
sentence: When we brought consumers to speak to us, the board members were worried about the consumers and how they were going to manage them

author: A
sentence: People seem to think consumers are people that have got too much time on their hands and have nothing to do and just want a feeling of self-importance, which is not necessarily true because I'm a consumer but I think that this is a way that I probably can make a difference if I can, then I find that the differences that I'm making are actually slow and may not necessarily be driving the change that I want because some of it is still tick-boxing

author: A
sentence: You have feedback as opposed to input

author: Q
sentence: That's really nice

author: A
sentence: So for me - like, I see it close the loop, if that makes sense, and I don't know that anybody else - like, a lot of other people that have got board positions wouldn't go and volunteer their time

author: A
sentence: And this is where Safer Care Victoria are wonderful in that they are driving that it should be a standard and they are driving that organisations should be paying their consumers for their time

author: A
sentence: Having said that, there are other consumers that I work with that say they don't want to be paid by the organisation because then they are seen as being paid by the organisation

author: A
sentence: They should be paid by Safer Care Victoria as being consumers on organisations, because it still allows them that sense of independence

author: Q
sentence: So Safer Care Victoria is where the standard comes from, is it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Because it sounds like ACHS

author: Q
sentence: It is complicated

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Very good, very good

author: A
sentence: So Safer Care Victoria was set up as a result of the Duckett Review

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay

author: Q
sentence: This is - yep

author: Q
sentence: Duckett Review

author: Q
sentence: I remember that happening

author: A
sentence: A couple of years ago now

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: A few more now

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that's right

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it's quite a while ago, actually

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: I haven't been working in the field for a while

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think, as a result of the Duckett Review, we got Safer Care Victoria, Better Care Victoria and other ones - working on things as well

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: I looked at private health

author: A
sentence: We need someone to come up with all the answers, I think, but anyway

author: A
sentence: And isn't it funny, because you - because I have two daughters that are studying medicine and one has been - well, actually, they both have done some of their rotations around public hospitals and around private hospitals and they say you can just see the difference

author: Q
sentence: It's completely different

author: Q
sentence: So culturally - I wanted to go back to your point about culture, because culturally they can be very different

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely they are

author: Q
sentence: And private can be very different

author: Q
sentence: But you mentioned culture earlier, like a misalignment of culture, so having someone - so diversity can put at risk that culture

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a little about that for me please?

author: A
sentence: So, for example, if I talk about my experience at a community advisory committee for a health network, we have a bit of diversity at the table from the consumers

author: A
sentence: So we have a Spanish lady, we have a lady with a disability, we have me, we used to have an Aboriginal guy or a guy who represented the Aboriginal community and the problem with the Aboriginal community, is that culturally you have to be accepted as part of their community before you can truly represent them, so you can't just go to the community and say, "We need someone

author: A
sentence: " So it's really hard to get that diversity at the table

author: A
sentence: Then when you do bring one person, is that person truly representative of that community or just their own experiences?  For example, we have one person at the table who, "My neighbour this," and, "My neighbour this," but it's the one neighbour that this person is bringing to the table

author: A
sentence: How else are they representing that community when you talk about diversity?  It's just one person who doesn't speak English but we don't have anybody that represents, for example, blind people or people hard of hearing or we don't have anybody that's young at the table

author: A
sentence: They are all 40-plus

author: A
sentence: So how can you even talk about diversity and feeling the culture, because I'm sure the health network doesn't just see 40-plus people that speak English

author: Q
sentence: So how do you think diversity is understood then?  How do you understand diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think everybody understands

author: A
sentence: So, for example, at the moment the Department of Human Services has said to all the hospitals they have to have a disability action plan in before the 1st of July and they're all working really hard towards having that in

author: A
sentence: So when they've spoken about the disability action plan, they've spoken about diversity and they are talking about people with physical handicaps as well as mental handicaps as well as just being diverse in the LGBTI community, and that's around diversity as well, but when we talk about cultural diversity, I think it's more than just those what I call obvious things

author: A
sentence: I think there are things that are nuances

author: A
sentence: So, for example - they call it the white elephant in the room, the cultural diversity, and so at CPA Australia, a couple of years ago at congress, I actually chaired one of the sessions, and I wish I could remember what the guy's name was, and he gave me a copy of his book and it was something as little as having a firm handshake in Australia is culturally acceptable but having a firm handshake in some Asian countries is actually seen as a sign of aggression

author: A
sentence: So that's a cultural diversity that not everybody would understand

author: A
sentence: So how do you include those kind of nuances around the table?  It's like how many people have trouble doing business in China because culturally they address things differently?

author: A
sentence: I have a friend of mine who works for an IT company and she's trying to do business in the Middle East, and she says the way that they do business there, you actually almost - you have to share a meal, you have to go out together, you have to almost become a social friend before you can do business, because that's the way they learn to trust you around the business table

author: A
sentence: So you can stay years and not be paid and stay years and put tenders to them but, if they don't trust you, it just won't move forward anyway

author: Q
sentence: And you have to pay for the meals?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Are you going to have space in aged care?  Is that a big space for you?

author: A
sentence: No, no, no, they're very generous of spirit

author: A
sentence: They're very hospitable

author: A
sentence: They're very hospitable, but you have to get yourself there

author: Q
sentence: And there's a sort of power issue, because how comfortable do you feel if someone's always buying you meals and then you're putting in a tender?  It's sort of -

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: Are you indirectly being bribed?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: What if it's a car next time?  Interesting, isn't it?  Okay

author: Q
sentence: So when we come back to boards, so then that's cultural diversity

author: Q
sentence: It's complex

author: A
sentence: It's very complex, but then how do you - and then should you just - because then you need to look at your demographics and really have diversity of your demographics at the board table

author: A
sentence: So it would be no good for me, for example, being in - and just as an example - being in Toorak and thinking that I shouldn't have any white middle-aged men on board

author: A
sentence: Or somebody was saying around the election that in the City of Kooyong you will always have people voting for the Greens because that's where all the doctors' wives live, and they're all the ones that are do-gooders and think about the environment, so you will always have a Green vote there

author: A
sentence: So, I mean, you know, it would be stupid to put a - what do you call it - a young Muslim boy in Kew, for example

author: A
sentence: And that's just using a -

author: Q
sentence: An extreme example, and that's if it's a service industry -

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: - that's got a targeted community

author: A
sentence: That's right, that's right

author: A
sentence: Well, we're thinking about it, only because a lot of the aged care is lumped in with the NDIS

author: Q
sentence: But if it was a - you know, one of [unclear] 00:30:26

author: A
sentence: BHP

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, BHP, how do you get the demographics then?  And they're a worldwide country

author: Q
sentence: What do you do?  Is it relevant?

author: A
sentence: You have to get someone from - yeah, that's right

author: Q
sentence: Is it relevant, the demographics then?  The demographic diversity?  Is that relevant?

author: A
sentence: Well, you know, if they were going to, for example - like Exxon Valdez, when they had that whole oil problem, then it would have been very important to have somebody from that area on that board

author: A
sentence: So then do they then just have a working group or do they have someone on the board for that time?

author: Q
sentence: Well, you can't pre-empt all disasters, I guess

author: A
sentence: No, that's right

author: A
sentence: But if they had someone on the board, they would have said, "Oh, look, you know, what are you doing there?  This is people's land

author: A
sentence: "  You know, there would have been - even when, for example -

author: Q
sentence: [unclear] 00:31:11

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:31:11

author: A
sentence: So even if you have a look at what's happening in Geelong around the people that are all getting cancer and they're saying, "Okay, there's something in the land there

author: A
sentence: "  So I'm really pleased to see that people's voices have been heard and that there is an investigation going on, but it really took too many people to die and speak up for it to happen, because it sounds like it's been there for more than 20 years

author: Q
sentence: So you do NDIS?

author: Q
sentence: And death is a pretty extreme indicator, isn't it?

author: A
sentence: Look at what happened at Djerriwarrh

author: A
sentence: I mean, you know, they had to have how many babies for them to see - and I'm thinking, 'Okay, well did nobody ever do a check on this guy?  What's going on?'  Like, the basic processes are falling through

author: A
sentence: So then you look at okay, even if you had diversity

author: Q
sentence: So there was a bullying culture underpinning - like, this is the story of safety and quality and health care and the bullying culture

author: Q
sentence: So with wards, culture - you know, the relationship between the organisational culture and the board culture and then the culture of the board

author: Q
sentence: So you were talking about culture mismatches, because I'm thinking well you've got group think on one side, one extreme, and then you've got the problems of cultural misalignment on the other

author: Q
sentence: So can you talk a little about that for me?

author: A
sentence: For me, I think it's actually - I don't want to say a bigger problem but you need strong people to lead

author: A
sentence: At what point, then, do they become so strong that they're like bullies as opposed to actually leading, and then what does leading actually mean for people?  For some people, leading means leading from behind where you strengthen your team and you move together

author: A
sentence: For some people, leaders is being the head figure where you are the voice, and so you're telling everybody what to do

author: A
sentence: So then how do you train people for leadership to then set the culture?

author: Q
sentence: And managing diversity

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So this is why I'm actually really -

author: Q
sentence: It's good to bring leadership up in -

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: A
sentence: And this is why, because I look at our - so if I look back to the history of our organisation, for example, when we stepped - oh well, I shouldn't say fired

author: A
sentence: When we accepted the previous CEO - the bullying CEO's resignation, the new CEO that we interviewed - around the board, we had agreed that what we needed was an amicable CEO to help the organisation heal to move forward, so that's what we interviewed for: a person that would be able to bring people back together and get them working as a team again

author: A
sentence: Then we went through the merger and the other organisation that we merged with had a CEO that was a micromanager

author: A
sentence: So we had the two CEOs were at either end of the spectrum

author: A
sentence: The guy that was amicable couldn't make the hard calls to fire anybody that wasn't performing and this CEO was micromanaging people so much that they didn't feel that they could actually get their job done

author: A
sentence: So when we interviewed this time, we thought well, we need somebody that's going to be able to do both, and that's a very hard call because, in general, people are not filling all those shoes

author: A
sentence: So when we interviewed this guy, we asked him what his plan was, and his plan was - and I think, to me, having come from a management accounting background as opposed to a financial accounting background, I could see the processes that he was doing where he was going to have a look at the organisation, do a gap analysis, try and train people up that would accept that, performance manage people that weren't going to come on the journey, because the organisation now was double the size what it was, so you needed people at the top level to be performing at a better stage and then to bring the staff with them, and, because the organisation is bigger, you have to recognise what your own capacity is

author: A
sentence: Very heavily NDIS

author: A
sentence: We were one of the first organisations to roll out NDIS when it first came in

author: A
sentence: Can you actually be on the ground with that 500-plus staff now or do you have to manage that through your executive team, and so that's what he's doing and this is why I'm really happy with this choice that we've made because he is making the calls of what he can and can't do, outsourcing where he can't but getting good plans from the people that he's outsourcing from and it is being driven from the ground, and so he is addressing the culture of what I call mateship as opposed to performance

author: A
sentence: So I'm not going to - what do you call it - promote you just because you're my mate anymore

author: A
sentence: I'm going to promote you because this is the criteria I'm looking for, and he's addressing that from the ground up

author: Q
sentence: And the board's used this process itself to shape itself, yes?

author: A
sentence: So the board has consciously chosen a person that we felt could do both because we needed to move the organisation forward because we recognised that this is what was happening previously, and what I love about this new CEO is that he has actually gone and had a cup of coffee with every single board member to, I suppose, see in his mind that we're all on the same page as well

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So you've got a really good bridge builder and leader -

author: A
sentence: And leader, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: - in this man, and this was a - you analysed the board, the merged board - analysed what it needed to merge -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - and he fits that bill -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: - and the board - you all went through a selection process

author: Q
sentence: You all have a similar - like, you've got a congruent approach to that CEO, yeah?

author: Q
sentence: That gives me a sense of context

author: Q
sentence: So, we'll start formally the interview now

author: Q
sentence: So there's a lot of talk about board diversity in the literature and whatever, except what we want to do is look at it from an Australian context and from the ground up

author: Q
sentence: So we're interviewing people who are directors on boards in organisations that influence boards in Australia of all types

author: Q
sentence: So thank you so much for agreeing to the interview

author: Q
sentence: We've got all that

author: Q
sentence: You sit on two boards, don't you?

author: A
sentence: So when we interviewed - we used a recruitment agency, obviously, and all the board members were given the ability - so we have a governance committee who is in charge of basically doing the operational work around getting the CEO or doing the groundwork and then it comes to the board and we all decide, but the chair of the governance committee was very transparent at every stage and we all had the opportunity to give, I suppose, four or five qualities that we saw were most important for the CEO, and then, from that, we did a tally and then agreed to what we all wanted or what we felt was a priority, because obviously no one can fill all 10 of your priorities anyway, and then, from there, when it came down to - obviously we did a job description and then the recruitment agency said to us, "Look, these are the candidates

author: A
sentence: So the governance committee, I suppose, culled till it got to about four and then gave everyone the opportunity to come and be present for the interviewing of these guys, or candidates

author: A
sentence: And we didn't all agree that this was the person that we wanted initially until we had a discussion around the table that - and we didn't actually say this is what the organisation needed as much as, because we'd already agreed that these were the priorities that we wanted, did that person fit the bill?

author: A
sentence: So each candidate was given the same brief: come with a quick plan as to how you would address

author: A
sentence: This guy was the one who came most prepared

author: A
sentence: Actually visited a couple of the sites, looked at the website, and actually said, "These are the issues I think that you've got

author: A
sentence: This is my plan for dealing with them," and actually came with a strategic plan of how he was going to move forward, and he was the only one that did that

author: Q
sentence: Very good

author: Q
sentence: Very proactive

author: Q
sentence: And wanted the job

author: Q
sentence: That's great

author: Q
sentence: Motivated

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: There was one person that I initially thought, 'Okay, this guy's already a CEO of another community health service

author: A
sentence: You know, better the devil you know than the friend you don't

author: A
sentence: "  And that was the person that I initially thought we would get him to fit in because he was coming to the same thing

author: A
sentence: And when he came to the interview - it's not that he didn't want the job; he just was not as dynamic or energetic

author: A
sentence: It wasn't even enthusiasm

author: A
sentence: It was dynamic, energetic

author: A
sentence: It was like yes, he knew he could do it, and for him it really just meant that he was going to be CEO of a bigger organisation

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, the next step

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: But he didn't show me anything as far as having a strategic plan of how he was going to move it forward

author: A
sentence: It was really just going to be more of the same of what he'd been doing at that organisation as opposed to, I suppose, doing a gap analysis of what the new merged organisation needed, and I think probably two other people around the table had that change of mind as well

author: Q
sentence: So let's hope - how long's the CEO been in the position?

author: A
sentence: Since January

author: Q
sentence: That's great

author: Q
sentence: First budget

author: A
sentence: Well, no

author: A
sentence: This is the only board I sit on

author: A
sentence: I'm on the advisory council at a Health Ombudsman and I'm also on the advisory council at a health network as a consumer advisor

author: A
sentence: So although they are both board subcommittees, they're not really boards, so this is the only board one that I do

author: A
sentence: Absolutely first budget

author: A
sentence: And the CFO's father passed away and she's gone to India to see him, so we've had to delay everything till she comes back

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that's right

author: Q
sentence: [It's just a she] 00:41:25

author: A
sentence: Yes, yeah, that's right

author: A
sentence: There's been so many hes that we've been talking about

author: Q
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: That's exactly right

author: A
sentence: But you know what?  Funnily enough, I sometimes think that - and not because I'm being sexist by any stretch of the imagination

author: A
sentence: Sometimes having a male CEO is good in a female environment because calls it black and white, doesn't - what do you call it - pander to some females' antics

author: A
sentence: There could be male antics as well

author: A
sentence: We used to have a director of nursing who was a male

author: A
sentence: He was gay but he was so high maintenance

author: A
sentence: So you don't necessarily have to be a female but unfortunately, when there's a lot of females in one place, there seems to be a lot more drama

author: Q
sentence: So you need diversity

author: A
sentence: Absolutely need diversity

author: Q
sentence: Gender diversity

author: A
sentence: Absolutely need [unclear] 00:42:28

author: A
sentence: So the same as having a lot of middle-aged men around the table is not good; having a lot of middle-aged women or young women or whatever isn't good either

author: A
sentence: You definitely need diversity

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So gender diversity is good

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So first, how has the composition of boards that you're familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Very important, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Regardless of the situation

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Merger

author: Q
sentence: High risk

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: High uncertainty

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: I would love to see a female CEO

author: A
sentence: Love to see it

author: Q
sentence: So we want to get a handle on how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: So you've talked about if there's too many women

author: Q
sentence: So if there's lack of gender diversity, you've mentioned the female aspect

author: Q
sentence: And the male aspect is nepotism, self-interest

author: A
sentence: But females as well

author: A
sentence: I can name a few females

author: A
sentence: Being with women on boards

author: A
sentence: I went to a lot of, I suppose, director PD, and a lot of the times, whether it was AICD or women on boards or anywhere else, some of the women that are on boards are not collaborative women

author: A
sentence: They are quite competitive and very self-interest as well

author: Q
sentence: So does that have a place, do you think, that sort of personality, that trait?  Is that something that you'd want as part of a diverse board or is that something that's universally dreadful?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: 2011, and what we've done is we actually merged with another organisation, and I made it through the second round of interviews to actually get through to the merged organisation

author: A
sentence: It's been wonderful to see the growth of the organisation but, in this instance, it's been wonderful to be part of the selection of the CEO as well, which was - I'm so happy with this guy

author: A
sentence: I believe, unfortunately, there's not enough diversity around the board table

author: A
sentence: It is changing and, in health care, you would think that you would see more females because traditionally more females work in health care, but that's not necessarily the case, but it is changing

author: A
sentence: I think it's universally dreadful

author: A
sentence: Self-interest is universally dreadful

author: A
sentence: It's got to be the interest of the organisation and the community it serves, so not really just the organisation

author: A
sentence: There's more social responsibility now than there ever was and it should have always been that way in my opinion, because it's through diversity, through education that community prospers, and those two being missing means we're just at a standstill

author: Q
sentence: And you can't be responsible more broadly

author: Q
sentence: So the banks, BHP, your local community service

author: A
sentence: And I don't want to - I mean, the most simple example I can give you is if you have proactive parents and non-proactive parents and the results that could possibly happen for the children and their future

author: A
sentence: Sometimes the children themselves just develop their own skills and become proactive anyway, but predominantly having proactive parents that are actually for the welfare of the children as opposed to themselves will actually have children that think about their community and will want to do things for the global world and all that kind of thing, whereas parents, when they're - you know, it's all about me and you guys are just a by-product of my marriage, is like okay, you're not really instilling the right kind of values in those kids, and it just begets that kind of pattern

author: Q
sentence: Narcissism

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well, yes, it happens around the board

author: A
sentence: And in organisations

author: A
sentence: So it's not just a board thing

author: A
sentence: It's also an executive thing

author: Q
sentence: With your talk of culture, you didn't separate board and exec

author: Q
sentence: You sort of see them quite one?

author: A
sentence: Because they work together

author: A
sentence: You know, the exec can work without the board but can lose direction unless the CEO is a strategic person, and the board - well, they'll have nothing to do unless they've got somebody to tell what to do

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: So they [unclear] 00:46:23

author: Q
sentence: An effective collaboration

author: A
sentence: That's exactly right

author: A
sentence: That's exactly right

author: Q
sentence: So you've been around since 2011

author: Q
sentence: So you've been watching the space for eight years -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so if they were competing with each other or hiding - you know, not open?

author: A
sentence: But isn't that what used to happen?

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Literally, CEOs thought that they were the boss and they tell the board what to do and then boards are now saying, "No, we're the boss and we tell you what to do," but more and more it is more apparent that it's about a collaboration

author: A
sentence: It's like okay, this is where we'd like to see the organisation go forward and the CEO says, "We don't have resources to do that so we have to compromise on that

author: A
sentence: This is where we can go and maybe we make that a long-term plan," so it's more about collaboration

author: Q
sentence: That's good

author: Q
sentence: No one's brought that point up

author: Q
sentence: That's a really neat one and it shows that that culture of the board really needs to be one of a team player as well, otherwise it's unidirectional and that's not effective, is what you're saying

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: So that's good

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that diversity can really help with then around this - because we now need to think about how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: You've just said if there's not an effective collaboration between the board and the CEO and the exec team, then you're going to have problems with strategy and everything

author: Q
sentence: So are there other board functions that diversity can really help with or is that the main one?

author: A
sentence: Yeah well, as far as driving the organisation forward

author: A
sentence: So if we all thought that we should just stay where we are and just keep the status quo, then there's not going to be really growth, even though the world around us is growing

author: A
sentence: So there needs to be diversity as far as having strategy and there also needs to be diversity as far as recognising opportunity, because not everybody sees opportunity either

author: A
sentence: Some people are just naturally born with seeing those kind of things

author: A
sentence: Like, my husband has this unbelievable or this uncanny ability to see that this is where something should be

author: A
sentence: I remember 30 years ago we were driving past a place and he said to me, "You know, this place here

author: A
sentence: Perfect for a family medical practice

author: A
sentence: "  Without fail, within five years there was a family medical practice and it's thriving and it's still there 30 years later

author: A
sentence: What do you call it?  There's another place where he said, "Look at this

author: A
sentence: There's a secondary school, a kindergarten and a primary school

author: A
sentence: You know what's missing?  Childcare

author: A
sentence: So we actually built a childcare and it's still going, because it's just in that - so he has this ability to see it that somebody else may not even notice it

author: A
sentence: So if you have people with different skills at the table, it just gives greater opportunity for everything

author: Q
sentence: I can see - and this links with some other directors that have talked about in risk management it's really important to have diversity, because just like your husband could see the opportunities, he would see, "Oh gee, there's a real risk here because no one has anywhere for their children, so what will happen to the children?" or something like that

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yes, that's right, that's right

author: Q
sentence: You know, the gap of the negative side

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that's right

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: Are there board functions that diversity can limit or undermine?  I think you've addressed that

author: Q
sentence: It's really the personality of board members is important it seems

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: That you have to be able to collaborate?

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: And you've said it's an absolute that they're not narcissistic

author: Q
sentence: My final question is are there any other board functions which you feel diversity has little bearing on?  Is there anything that diversity has really no bearing on in terms of board functions?

author: A
sentence: I don't think so

author: Q
sentence: And conflict and diversity?  Is there an example there?

author: Q
sentence: - and you've seen it increasing?

author: A
sentence: So greater diversity can lead to more conflict and so you need to, I suppose, have tools around the table as to how you would manage that

author: A
sentence: I did this with - I think AICD ran a session and about dealing with conflict and it was like what if you had a chair that was a bully, then how do you deal with that?  We never actually came up with an answer because having a chair - and again it's that fine line between being strong enough to drive people but still being, I suppose, a leader to allow other people to step up as well

author: A
sentence: It's not just about you driving

author: A
sentence: It's about giving other people a chance

author: A
sentence: Because I remember when we had the day hospital, there was one girl who'd done a Bachelor of Science and she was just really clever and got things, you know

author: A
sentence: She helped me establish the policies and procedures of the day hospital

author: A
sentence: She helped me set up an accounting package so that we could process things electronically as opposed to manually and everything like that, and I said to her, "Look, have you ever thought about going on and doing a Masters in Healthcare or something like that so that you could have - progress your career

author: A
sentence: Don't just be a processor all your life

author: A
sentence: "  She just was never interested, and no matter how many times I tried to send her to - what do you call it - to professional development to get her to - she just didn't want it, and so then it was up to me to just step back and say I recognise that culturally that was enough for her

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That's what she wanted to do

author: A
sentence: But at least I was running my own business but trying to take her along the journey as well

author: A
sentence: It wasn't just about managing my business

author: A
sentence: It was about making my staff happy that - even if they didn't stay with me, that they would produce the best work while they were there

author: A
sentence: So not everybody is capable of doing that

author: A
sentence: So some people - and if I want to give it as an example, I had a friend of mine who was a single mum and, in the end, she was so protective of her daughter that it showed me it was more about her and her role as a mother than seeing that her daughter grew as an individual

author: A
sentence: So not all leaders have that capacity to step back and grow other people because it basically threatens their position

author: Q
sentence: So this is helping to get an understanding of the root causes of conflict?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: It'll arise because of people's defensiveness or -

author: A
sentence: So what they define as leadership traits

author: Q
sentence: So we'll just use the leadership stuff to look at how boards manage difference

author: Q
sentence: Have you got an example of a really good case - you don't have to; other people have - of how difference has been managed on a board?  You know, diversity has been managed and has led to a good decision?  I mean, you gave me the one earlier where you flagged this is a problem

author: A
sentence: So that chair was very collaborative

author: A
sentence: She used to give people opportunity to run the table and actually canvas each director, and she would, for example, have an annual dinner of the directors and their partners, because she would recognise that directors are actually people and have someone else that's supporting them to come and do these things as well, and so I found that that board had no problem raising any issue and didn't think anything was done enough

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: So it had a good culture

author: A
sentence: Absolutely a good culture

author: A
sentence: We were very collaborative

author: Q
sentence: So was there anything else you did?  So there was the canvassing

author: A
sentence: So the thing that she also did was she made us do the AICD, do a self-evaluation tool, and we use their evaluation tool, and a lot of that is around all the directors answering where they think they fit, where they think other directors fit and where they think that she fits, and then I think that self-evaluation tool also helped her, the chair, to address things that she wasn't aware of herself about herself, and she made changes

author: Q
sentence: Wow, that's commitment

author: A
sentence: She really did

author: A
sentence: And this is where I say - and she's actually got an academe background and she's just a collaborative person

author: A
sentence: She can still be a bully and she can still - you know, what do they call them?  The smiling assassin

author: A
sentence: She can still be a smiling assassin

author: Q
sentence: So in what way is she a bully?  Can you unpack those - and the smiling assassin - what you mean?

author: A
sentence: So if she thought that something was inappropriate, she would still tell you it was inappropriate in front of everybody else and have a smile on her face

author: A
sentence: So that's a smiling assassin

author: Q
sentence: Right, okay

author: Q
sentence: Very comfortable with giving negative feedback

author: A
sentence: With a smile on her face, she could do that

author: A
sentence: Whereas I learnt a long time ago, I would not give you negative feedback in front of anybody else

author: A
sentence: I would take that out of the room

author: Q
sentence: In terms of gender?

author: Q
sentence: Even at the board level?

author: A
sentence: Even at the board level

author: Q
sentence: Is it because it's negative feedback personally or negative feedback on an idea?

author: A
sentence: Negative feedback personally

author: A
sentence: It's about your personality as opposed to your idea

author: A
sentence: If I'm telling you you're talking too much, then indirectly I'm sending the message to everybody else around the table not to talk

author: A
sentence: That's why - so it depends on the feedback that you're giving

author: A
sentence: You are talking and taking things off course and you are told to, "Okay, let's bring it back," that's different, but if you are talking and she just wants you to stop because she has something more important to say, then that's the wrong message

author: A
sentence: Does that make sense?

author: Q
sentence: Yep, yep, yep

author: Q
sentence: It means [unclear] 00:56:58

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:56:58

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: I'm not going to listen to everyone

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: And that's the same

author: A
sentence: Like, when I was talking about the CEO that was very amicable, then, when it came to the board table, it was, "Yes, ma'am, three bags full, ma'am," and it's like okay, well, no, you're sending the wrong message to the other executive that's around the table that you're a pushover and you shouldn't be

author: A
sentence: You need to have some backbone as well as - you still need to be able to guide people and, if they don't trust in your ability to guide, then -

author: Q
sentence: They won't trust your leadership

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: So there are certain leadership skills that you need to have

author: A
sentence: Yes, you need to be able to tell people - give them direction, but you also need to respect them as people and direction that you're going to give them at a personal level shouldn't be in front of everybody else

author: A
sentence: So I'm seeing the level of, I suppose, experience or understanding of what it is to be a director increasing, so what you would call - I mean, so if I can be so blunt as to say what used to be the middle-aged white male domain of meeting in club rooms and giving each other positions is on the decline and it is more about applying to fill a particular skills matrix that's required on the board

author: Q
sentence: I see what you mean then, the smiling assassin

author: Q
sentence: What about the smiling assassin, then?  The smiling assassin

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that was that example

author: Q
sentence: What was the other one you said?  It's not a smiling assassin

author: A
sentence: To bully someone?

author: Q
sentence: To bully something

author: Q
sentence: What's the bully?

author: A
sentence: So we had one person that would come to the table and become involved in the operation

author: A
