sentence: So, for example, if they were going to do a project, she was a project manager and so would want to give templates and everything to the staff to do it, and the chair didn't like that and would try and stop her in her tracks, that this is operational, but the way she did it was, "Doesn't everybody else see that this is wrong?" so getting everybody else on her side to gang up

author: A
sentence: So it can be quiet bullying

author: A
sentence: So you don't actually see it until you actually step back

author: A
sentence: Does that make sense?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So this person was marginalised?  Her view was marginalised because of that strategy

author: A
sentence: Could have been

author: A
sentence: Could have been marginalised

author: A
sentence: Exactly right

author: Q
sentence: She felt marginalised, I suppose

author: A
sentence: I don't know if she did

author: Q
sentence: But could've

author: A
sentence: Could have

author: Q
sentence: How long have skill matrixes been around do you think and been so influential?

author: Q
sentence: Because of how you all saw that strategy

author: A
sentence: And this is hindsight

author: A
sentence: When you're in the middle of it, you don't actually see it until you step back, because, as I said, it does take a strong person to drive, but that person who's driving needs to be respectful of other people as well

author: A
sentence: And as I said, after we did the evaluation, the chair actually took some of that feedback on board

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much for spending the time explaining that, because it's subtle and it's contextual and so you've just illustrated how it works on a board

author: Q
sentence: Because, I mean, there's a lot of literature, but sort of in a way we want to - how does it apply here to the board?

author: A
sentence: So the current chair that I'm working with?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: She's not transparent

author: A
sentence: She's not really collaborative

author: A
sentence: I'm allegedly deputy chair but we never have a discussion around what the organisation is doing, the conversations that she's having with the CEO

author: A
sentence: So if a bus should hit her tomorrow, I would know nothing

author: Q
sentence: So you're feeling a bit vulnerable as a result?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: A
sentence: And that's why, for me, because I can't speak to her, and I've tried to, but I feel like all I'm doing is reporting to her as opposed to her telling me anything, so I'm not really learning much

author: A
sentence: So I'm fostering a relationship with the CEO to be able to, I suppose - well, not sidestep her, but still have the information that I would need if I had to step up

author: Q
sentence: And you need that relationship as well

author: A
sentence: Yeah

sentence: I did the company director's course in 2010 and, when we spoke about it at the company director's course, they spoke about skills matrix then and having the diversity and having not just a gender diversity but obviously the skills around the table as well, but some of the people that I did the course with - so, for example, one of them was from Seek, one of them was from BMW or Bob Stillwell Australia - and, for example, the Bob Stillwell one was a family group and then they had to advertise out so that they could get that diversity so that they didn't have the family group thing, and that  was 2010

author: A
sentence: And I think the guy at Seek said that they didn't have that diversity yet

sentence: That's good

sentence: I hope not all the directors that come in here think they're absolutely fantastic at doing their job

author: Q

sentence: And this is what I say to my kids is, "If you don't reflect, you don't know what you're doing wrong or right to do more or less

sentence: You're good

sentence: We know so many other medical doctors, their children are just really arrogant," and I said, "Well you know what?  Up until they're 18, that's because of me

author: A

sentence: That's so beautifully put

sentence: And I keep telling my kids that mothers have a big responsibility to drive the change that they want to see

author: A
sentence: But it really is we have a responsibility to do that, but not everybody - and this is where I think people have to recognise that not everybody has those skills and then, like that girl that was working under me, not everybody wants to take on the skills

author: Q
sentence: When identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity?

sentence: So, as I said, the current matrix, the skills matrix, and what we are doing - because we feel culture is important, we don't want someone that's going to - not give us a lot of pushback but have different things on their agenda, and what we're doing is we're having independent directors on the subcommittees and they work with us there for a year and then we can ask them to apply for a board position if it fits

author: Q
sentence: So do you think, though, that the skill matrix has shifted the focus to skill diversity, whereas in the past diversity was understood as gender?  You mentioned the matrix being important

sentence: So when we were recruiting, we had an idea, for example, that we wanted somebody with a legal background, or we wanted somebody with a health care background

sentence: "  I said, "That's fine

author: Q
sentence: Do the boards that you're familiar with have any barriers to managing or building its diversity?  The Aboriginal, you said

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely, and I think that that stands for - if I want to talk about diversity, it's not just Aboriginal

author: A
sentence: Anything that you would put under diverse is going to have some kind of barrier just as a natural thing

author: A
sentence: So, for example, when we're talking about women diversity, just because they are the ones that are going to carry the babies and feed them for the first little while, there is a natural - not bias; the opposite of bias - prejudice against them

author: Q
sentence: It's a stereotype, isn't it?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So what I've got here are two types of barriers

author: Q
sentence: One's a supply barrier and the other is a stereotype prejudice

author: Q
sentence: You know, it's about expectations

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: A
sentence: It is about expectations, because I mean, even if you look at - so, for example, both my daughters that are studying medicine are looking at what speciality are they going to have to do, and my husband is saying to them, "You girls are going to have kids and you're going to be at home with the babies," and I'm like, "Stop

author: A
sentence: Don't make decisions for them

author: A

author: A
sentence: So then we had to go back to just the guys

author: A
sentence: You need someone that's going to be there full-time and more than full-time to be a CEO

author: A
sentence: How many women want to do that?  How many men want to do that?  So it's not just when we talk about the gender diversity

author: A
sentence: It's the candidates that want to do it or not do it and how much of it is social norm, so how many guys are actually pushed that they have to be driven and how many women are pushed that they shouldn't be driven

sentence: Finally, looking 10 years - this is the last one - into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

sentence: I don't know if it's necessarily achievable and I don't know - this is something that I think about now at the age that I'm at

author: A
sentence: If I can step away from my job for over a week and no one notices, how effective am I, and is that job even important?  How much paper shuffling do we actually do?  So we were in China and I saw how fast they build roads and how - and people say, "Okay, but they haven't got things in place to deal with crises

author: A
sentence: "  Yet they still manage

author: A
sentence: They are so much more organised than we are

sentence: You go on a train and they've got the arrows that people that are going in go this way, people that are going out - so you have to have the rules in place for these things to happen and people just follow them

author: Q
sentence: So do you think we're lacking the rules to cultivate diverse boards into the future?  Is it about that?

author: A
sentence: I think if more people were educated around it, for sure, and, if there was more regulation around it, probably yes, but then, when you regulate, you're going to end up with group think again

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, group think because you've said, "Right, you've got to have this many of this and this and this

author: Q
sentence: "  How would it be group think, because you've got all these different voices?

author: A
sentence: I'll tell you how it would be group think

author: A
sentence: They tell you

author: A
sentence: They tell you

author: A
sentence: People that do more study start to understand that what they know is actually very small to the amount of knowledge that there is out there and so are less risk takers, so you find that the majority of innovation that happens are by people that are less educated

author: A
sentence: They have a certain amount of education because they have to recognise the risks and everything, but the innovators are the ones that are less educated

author: A
sentence: So the more you teach people, the more they will think alike and be less risk taking

sentence: Wow, that's an amazing claim

sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: So how important do you think it is to have a diverse board

author: Q
sentence: If, let's say, 10 is extremely important and 1 is not important at all, what do you think?

author: A
sentence: No, I'd say it's extremely important

author: Q
sentence: So 10?

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: All the studies show you that having a diverse board, number 1) creates a better culture in the organisation

author: A
sentence: Also, when you have a diversity of thinking, you can also have a diversity of approaches because the people that are working in the organisations are not the same as the people around the table

author: A
sentence: If people in the organisation are not represented at the board, then you're not going to be filling the organisation's needs

author: Q
sentence: And is that the purpose of the board: to fill the organisation's needs?

author: A
sentence: No, no, no

author: A
sentence: The purpose of the board is really to drive the direction of the organisation but, if you don't have an understanding of the people that are working for that organisation, then you could be asking for stars and they only have moons

sentence: That's great

author: Q
sentence: Oh really?  So how would diversity influence or contain self-interest at the board level, or how does lack of diversity sustain a self-interested focus?

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: So lack of diversity; obviously, if you're self-interested – and I think the same as you, I'm going to have self-interest as well

author: A
sentence: So we may actually have competing interests but, in general, you can collude more anyway, because you both have that kind of personality where it is not necessarily about the organisation but about yourself

author: A
sentence: Diversity of thought will at least help to break that down and, even if people around the table may not be strong enough to speak about it at the table, if they feel that there's somebody else that agrees with them only slightly, they can take the conversation out and look at different ways to deal with things anyway

author: Q
sentence: Can you give an example, from your experience, of how that might have been done?

author: A
sentence: In the previous organisation before we merged, there were some kind of indicators that things at the organisation were not going well, and one of the indicators that screamed at me was we had 10 resignations in November and then 11 resignations in December, and I brought it up and I said, "Look, I don't think that this is normal," and they said, "Oh no, it's just because we're going through change

author: A
sentence: "  So I actually took it offline and spoke to the chair and I said, "Look, people don't normally leave their jobs around Christmas

author: A
sentence: "  No matter how bad it would be, they always look at leaving after Christmas

author: A
sentence: And then we only had about just over 200 staff, so that was a high percentage, like if you talk relative to the number of your FTEs, and she said, "Yeah, okay, we'll have a look at it," and that's when we got a letter from the local councillor and from the department about claims of bullying from the CEO

author: A
sentence: So for me there was an indicator and I brought it up and no one else - so I took it offline and then, just by chance, we got those complaints as well, and then we had to do an investigation, stand her down, and all of that, and then eventually she was asked to leave

author: Q
sentence: So do you think the board - most people around the board were actually protecting the CEO?

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily protecting the CEO but didn't think of that as an - and this is where diversity is really important

author: A
sentence: I'd run my own business - I'd had a day hospital - and so I was conscious of, I suppose, staff think and the cycles of staff think around the financial years and all that kind of thing, so to me I would use that as an indicator in my own business, whereas the other people around the table were - one was from academe, one was from a strictly auditing thing, so they weren't in -

author: Q
sentence: Just didn't get it

author: A
sentence: Academe wasn't even something that they would even look at, whereas for me it was

author: A
sentence: So having that diversity led us to look at that, but they didn't think that it was really a - and I think a lot of people still don't think it's an indicator, but for me, from someone who's come from the background of running a business, it is an indicator that tells you your staff are unhappy

author: Q
sentence: So, what I'm hearing also though is - and this is later questions but let's go now because the story's leading there - you voiced it at the table and you were a lonely voice at the table?

author: A
sentence: I was new

sentence: And this is health, isn't it?

author: Q
sentence: You were new?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: A
sentence: So I'd actually made it onto the board in October and then saw this in November and December

author: Q
sentence: That's a tough call

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But still, you were on the board and you weren't heard?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: Q
sentence: So you had to go offline and speak to the chair, and then the chair - did the chair hear what you were saying or it was only -

author: A
sentence: Well, no, she did hear it but I would never know, because hindsight is a wonderful thing, if she would have acted on it

author: A
sentence: It just happened at the same time as the complaint

author: Q
sentence: So the letter then really - but at least the complaint then - you had indicated -

author: A
sentence: Acknowledged what I'd -

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: That's right

author: A
sentence: Community health even, which is very Victoria-specific

author: Q
sentence: - this is the context and this, you know, was a sign

author: A
sentence: And then, as a result of that, we actually established a new grievance procedure where people could actually contact the chair, because the organisation didn't have that process in place so, if there were going to be any complaints, the CEO was the complaints officer

author: A
sentence: So then we revisited that whole grievance procedure so that it could be made to somebody other than the CEO as well

author: Q
sentence: So you identified an issue that would not have been identified

author: Q
sentence: That complaint might have arrived out of the blue and it mightn't have been acknowledged

author: A
sentence: Well, as a result of me noticing that, I actually went back and did a search on the CEO and where she'd been beforehand and then also found out that the CFO had come along with her and then a third person

author: A
sentence: So she had brought people with her and they were actually, I suppose, bullying the staff together

author: A
sentence: But it was only through doing that search that we found out that they were actually working together - oh well, bullying together, as opposed to just the CEO

author: Q
sentence: Interesting, isn't it?  So that sort of suggesting that you want to have diversity in terms of social networks at the exec level as well?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: The current board that we're on now, we've had another director resign, and we've had a look around the table and no one around the table actually lives or works in the population that we're actually serving

sentence: So when we're looking for a new director, that's going to be one of the, I suppose, skills that we want to [fit in] 00:16:55

sentence: So, for example, working with - and I do want to de-identify it because I don't want [unclear] 00:18:57

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: I'll personally - I can send you the transcript

author: Q
sentence: Once the transcript is done, let's send you the transcript before it's send

author: Q
sentence: You can deidentify it because, if you - and then I'll take that, because I'm very aware in health it's a small field

author: A
sentence: And everybody knows everybody

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: And so I mightn't see that this connects to you or your organisation because it's not a name, so would you do that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q
sentence: Thanks, Participant 28D for agreeing to participate in our research on board diversity

author: Q
sentence: Firstly, I’d just like to check your discipline background

author: Q
sentence: So what are you, accountant? What’s your discipline background?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I know it all takes time

author: Q
sentence: Great, okay

author: A
sentence: So I think there are definitely two schools of thought, and that certainly came out in the research that I did around it as well, that there are two schools of thought, there is – not all men think the same about this issue

author: A
sentence: Thankfully more and more men appear to be of the view that we need to get serious about this, and we’re not doing it for tokenism, we’re doing it because we genuinely want a diverse board

author: Q
sentence: Do you think younger men are more likely to hold the view that there should be more women, or it doesn’t matter? Age is not a factor?

author: A
sentence: I think it can be

author: A
sentence: Having said that, some younger men are highly competitive and they – I don’t know that they would be prepared to have a woman on the board ahead of themselves if they – so I guess it can be a factor

author: A
sentence: Definitely some of the men that are very old-school that I’ve come across are older, they are 60 plus, sort of in that age group

author: A
sentence: So I have experienced both

author: Q
sentence: So the board that you are the only female on at the moment, how does – do you feel it’s conservative? Like, how old are the men roughly?

author: A
sentence: They’re all over 50, all of them are over 50

author: Q
sentence: They’re all over 50

author: Q
sentence: And how’s the decision making? Do you feel that it’s conservative? Is there creative problem solving? Is there a bit of groupthink?

author: A
sentence: I have to say that it’s not conservative in its decision making

author: A
sentence: It’s conservative potentially in views of – in some views, but not – it’s not a board who’s not willing to change what they’re doing in terms of their decision making

author: Q
sentence: So groupthink is not an issue?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think so

author: Q
sentence: Yep, yep, because this is where it’s the thinking, it’s ultimately about the thinking, so I’m just wondering whether it’s the respect side or it’s the thinking in your – what you talked about earlier, that the thinking and then with respect, [you like] 00:26:53 the team, based on respect, leads to good decision making

author: Q
sentence: So I was just wondering whether it was the diversity of thinking feeding in through a filter of respect, mutual respect?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So that feeling you’re getting, is that the mutual respect level?

author: A
sentence: The feeling of what, sorry?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, on that board you described a feeling of definitely being the only one -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - so is -

author: A
sentence: I do feel it now that I am the only one, definitely

author: A
sentence: I think, like I say, they are very respectful to my face

author: A
sentence: If – I just wonder as I said I think if they had their choice they would definitely have another of their colleagues or friends on the boards

author: A
sentence: Because I am a different one, I am younger and I’m female, and they are very respectful to me and I felt maybe they just wouldn’t be disrespectful to my face

author: A
sentence: Maybe that’s what it is

author: A
sentence: But I do think -

author: Q
sentence: So there’s a lack of trust there?

author: A
sentence: What’s that?

author: Q
sentence: From your point of view there’s – your trust is qualified?

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Look, by all means draw on your findings and we’ll – if you could shoot me any publications that are – so that we can search for them later -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think – well, I think so

author: A
sentence: I think when I say what’s critical is bringing diversity of thinking to the board that I think the majority of that board is not diverse

author: A
sentence: They do however feel comfortable in challenging each other, which is healthy, and I think my views are probably the outlier at times

author: A
sentence: Sometimes however I’m able to change the course of a decision

author: A
sentence: So I feel that they do respect it when they feel the respect is warranted, when they think I have a good idea they’ll [will use] 00:28:55 it, which is good

author: Q
sentence: Great, now -

author: A
sentence: But there’s not a lot different minds coming from different backgrounds, they’re all coming from similar backgrounds, except for me potentially

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So can you give me an example of how your input led to a different decision? So your diverse input led – so that process, so we can understand how that voice – because this model you gave me is really interesting and I’d like to have it fleshed out a bit

author: A
sentence: So what can happen is the executive will bring in an idea, we have a very capable executive team and they’ll bring an idea, and they’ve thought it out and they’ve considered it and they’ll bring an idea

author: A
sentence: And the view that I can often bring is one of a younger person’s mindset, so I’ll say well – I’ll bring a perspective of social media use, or I’ll bring a perspective of yes, that would work traditionally in the industry but I don’t think, if we’re trying to attract a new demographic or a younger clientele, that have we considered this, or have we considered that? So I tend to – if I [eject] 00:30:17 that because they’re looking for that then often they can say that’s [unclear] 00:30:23 and it’s really good and maybe we won’t do that yet, or maybe – so where I have – where my thinking differs because of my different background, they will listen

author: A
sentence: And they do take it on board and sometimes it doesn’t mean that things are overturned, but it will mean that they will modify the decision to take that into account

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you’ve had evidence of that, that’s -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: So if you then would rate – let’s say I give you a scale where 10, diversity is extremely important and one, it’s not important at all, where would you put it?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s a nine, or a 10

author: A
sentence: It’s right up there, it’s really important

author: Q
sentence: And so why is it so important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, no problem

author: A
sentence: Because you can get the decisions wrong

author: A
sentence: If everybody is the same age, comes from the same background, the same demography, or same demographic background, the same pathway to the board in terms of their executive career then the decisions you’re going to make are going to be shaped by that one frame of thinking

author: A
sentence: That’s dangerous for an organisation

author: A
sentence: What you want is people questioning, people saying ‘I don’t think that will work, I’m concerned about this

author: A
sentence: Have we thought of that?’ And you just don’t get that if everybody comes from the same background and pathway

author: A
sentence: Equally, the other aspect is if people don’t feel respected enough to speak up you’re going to have a problem

author: A
sentence: Because they might come from a very diverse background but if they’re not comfortable opening their mouth they may as well not be there

author: Q
sentence: Oh, brilliant

author: A
sentence: So you have to create a culture where people are very comfortable to challenge, and the challenge is invited, and that an effective chair will scan the room and say ‘I haven’t heard from you yet, could you tell me your views on this?’ And if they don’t do that, and if you have a culture where for example tenure is a marker of importance and value, so therefore the newcomers don’t feel comfortable speaking up against the deputy chairs or the chairs and longstanding directors that have been there forever, again you are undermining the value of the diversity that you’ve placed on that board

author: A
sentence: So it is diversity of thinking and background, but equally it’s the culture at the board table and does everybody feel equally valued? Does everybody genuinely feel like their vote is important and as valuable as anybody else’s vote, despite how long they’ve been there? And if you can really foster that, particularly as chair [but] 00:33:13 those other directors then you can maximise what you can draw from that diversity around the table

author: Q
sentence: That’s fantastic, thank you

author: Q
sentence: That links in to other interviews but puts it together so clearly, so well

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: A
sentence: Oh good, a pleasure

author: Q
sentence: That inclusive culture was a feature in one interview, and so what you’ve said just pulls that in beautifully so thank you, that’s brilliant

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:33:41

author: Q
sentence: - should they be published, that’d be great

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there is any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating? For example, if it’s high uncertainty or risk?

author: A
sentence: Importance rating of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yep

author: A
sentence: Yep, if it’s just tokenistic

author: A
sentence: So if we’re going to put someone on the board because they’re indigenous, but just because they’re indigenous, then that’s insulting to indigenous people and it’s not going to be effective at the board table

author: A
sentence: And the same applies to – sometimes you see government boards say they want age diversity and so they’re looking for particularly young people

author: A
sentence: Well, if you’re going to put a 25 year old on a board who has very limited work experience and no board experience, and not support and train them and develop them, then that’s insulting to young people

author: A
sentence: So diversity for the sake of diversity is incorrect and tokenistic

author: A
sentence: But if you are genuinely wanting to get a diverse board ,and that involves – what you need to do is find people with the ability to do that role, or the capability and then support them and train them and develop them so they understand their obligations and their duties, and they know what they’re there to do

author: A
sentence: That’s fine

author: A
sentence: But don’t just get somebody because they’re a different colour, because that is not true diversity in what I described before where diversity of thinking is what you want

author: A
sentence: If you’ve got somebody on that board who is feeling so out of place that they’re too afraid to open their mouth, what’s the point?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: So are you concerned that this could be an outcome of targets, gender targets and quotas?

author: A
sentence: It could be, it could be, so I’m not in favour of quotas as numbers

author: A
sentence: What I’m in favour of is targets, and if that’s not working and we have to consider quotas, fine, but the onus should be on the board to prove that this isn’t tokenistic, these are people that we have searched long and hard for and found because their skills will be extremely useful at this table

author: A
sentence: And we are developing these people, if need be, to get them up to speed with their obligations

author: Q
sentence: Look, you are the first person to really make such a strong point about tokenism, so -

author: A
sentence: Oh

author: A
sentence: So you’re after the academic journal stuff aren’t you? You don’t want the -

author: Q
sentence: No, no, other people have alluded to it but you’ve got a really good way of describing it

author: Q
sentence: So in the future questions if you have something – please drill down on tokenism at any point you think it’s relevant because it’s clearly important and you’re really showing how and why

author: Q
sentence: So I’m just putting that out there and inviting you because -

author: A
sentence: Well look, I’ll give you a recent example

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, good

author: A
sentence: So we have - as I said I work with some indigenous directors, and one particular indigenous director it’s their first board

author: A
sentence: And they are incredibly capable and they are high level in their executive career, and they are very considered, but they’re learning their stripes

author: A
sentence: Because being a director, a non-executive director is a very different skill to being an executive in the company

author: A
sentence: And so we really want to keep this person, we really want to develop them, so we want them to feel like they are free to speak up on anything, and we want to encourage that

author: A
sentence: So I recently made the suggestion that we put this person through the Company Directors course

author: A
sentence: Now that’s over and above what we would normally spend annually for directors, but I said ‘This person is fantastic, we want them to stay, we want them to develop into this role and we want them to stay on our board

author: A
sentence: So we need to go - we need to get them qualified, and we need to do it

author: A
sentence: So why wouldn’t we do that? This is about closing the gap, it’s about giving that person a leg up, but it’s about saying we’re backing you

author: A
sentence: You’re great, we want you to be here, we want you to be fully up to speed

author: A
sentence: So that’s very much about not being tokenistic

author: A
sentence: It’s about saying we’re glad you’re here, we want you to feel free to speak up and we want you to be really comfortable [unclear] 00:38:17 because we think you’re fantastic

author: A
sentence: So we agreed we would absolutely fund them to do - and the reality is the rest of the board members don’t use their full expenditure of professional development each year anyway so we can divert all of the budget to them for a year, and that would be a great thing for all of us to do that

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant, brilliant

author: Q
sentence: I was wondering whether – because people from low socio-economic backgrounds, financial barriers can be quite real and so this presents a way that a board can create opportunity for people from -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: And sometimes executives, the people – I mean, it’s not a cheap exercise to do the Company Directors course but it is a qualification that’s sought after in this space and some people are [perfect] 00:39:14 in their executive career but their executive employer might not be prepared to pay that much money because it’s not directly impacting what they’re doing now

author: A
sentence: So does that mean that we don’t want them on our board if they’re fantastic? No, it means we should get them on

author: A
sentence: And this person actually – I have kind of taken it upon myself a little bit to just contact them outside board meetings and make sure they’re going okay, and encourage them and remind them how valued their opinion is and that they should feel free to speak up at any time

author: A
sentence: And we’ve kind of formed a bit of a mentoring relationship

author: A
sentence: But I kind of seem that as giving back, and I look forward to seeing their career unfold

author: A
sentence: I mean, they are talented and capable and in 10 years’ time this person will be on multiple boards if they choose to be, so – and being a really effective non-executive director with an indigenous background, which is a highly sought-after aspect of diversity

author: A
sentence: And hopefully they can pave the way for future indigenous directors to see that they’ve done exceedingly well and that this is not out of reach

author: A
sentence: So I kind of think that’s part of my duty and role

author: A
sentence: I’ve been fortunate and I feel very blessed in what I’ve been able to do on boards so far to date, but my role doesn’t stop with me being satisfied with what I’ve got out of it

author: Q
sentence: Oh, look -

author: Q
sentence: Your performance

author: A
sentence: I have to give back

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s brilliant, that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: Does this kind of diversity – is there a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others?

author: A
sentence: Look, when people talk about diversity, and this came through in my research, that when people talk about diversity they predominantly are talking about gender, and that to me - it’s the most visible form of diversity, and it is definitely the right place to start

author: A
sentence: Because I have four children, two boys, two girls, it has always gotten up my nose that from the time of their birth the girls were, on average, less likely to achieve in executive roles and board roles than the boys

author: A
sentence: That is simply not okay with me

author: A
sentence: So that, because half of the world is women, is the right place to start

author: A
sentence: One of the things though that companies are talking about increasingly is that’s the first place to start, but what’s next? We can’t just think about it in terms of gender because we don’t want all white boards that are 50% women and 50% men

author: A
sentence: We have to think about other aspects of diversity

author: A
sentence: So what about disability, what about indigenous people? What about other nationalities? What about age? What about geographic? There are so many other aspects of diversity that need to be considered

author: A
sentence: So it is the right place to start but it is by no means the end, gender

author: Q
sentence: Some people have said that they think gender is like a sign, a sign of commitment to diversity

author: Q
sentence: So they see it as if there’s no gender diversity then the other kinds of diversity won’t be there either, but if there is it’s likely that other kinds of diversity – do you think that’s a reliable indicator?

author: A
sentence: I do think so, and I think that sign comes from that’s where the pressure’s coming from the major - the powerbrokers and the people that are exerting pressure on companies to become more diverse, all of those things – the targets around 30% plus, are all on gender diversity

author: A
sentence: No one to my knowledge has come out and said you’ve got to have a diversity target on indigenous people

author: A
sentence: So I think it is a sign because it’s the one thing is being measured and looked at, but I do also think that if people are inclusive of women they’re going to naturally, hopefully, be more inclusive of other types of diversity as well

author: Q
sentence: Yes, because you see – I mean, in a way this goes back to your idea of the culture of the board, the inclusive culture

author: A
sentence: It does

author: Q
sentence: I mean if it’s got an inclusive culture it will have more women, and if it’s got an inclusive culture it will use other kinds of diversity, it won’t be token and -

author: A
sentence: - other publications [inaudible] 00:02:32

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: - it will attract – yeah, Okay, good

author: A
sentence: I think an all-white male board that doesn’t want women is not going to want indigenous directors either

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: So yeah, it is about an inclusive culture, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so it’s probably a sign of the culture

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: Now we’ve got some questions on board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that diversity really helps with, and if so can you give me an example? Ooh

author: A
sentence: Hi, sorry, I don’t know what happened there

author: Q
sentence: It’s okay

author: Q
sentence: No look, the other publications are fine

author: A
sentence: It dropped out

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I don’t know, but it’s okay

author: Q
sentence: So the question was are there particular board functions that diversity can really help with, and if so can you give me an example?

author: A
sentence: Oh look, I think it’s probably in strategy and thinking about - deliberating on how will we tackle this segment? Or which direction should we take? That’s probably where the most value of diversity thinking comes into it

author: A
sentence: It’s not around so much how should we cut up the budget, or how are our financials going? It’s probably more around that real strategic thinking, and discussions and deliberations about our customers and our products, and what we’re going to do in the future, and what we should stop doing

author: A
sentence: That’s probably where the most value of a diverse background and thinking comes into it

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: And is there any type of function that diversity might limit or undermine?

author: A
sentence: I don’t think so

author: Q
sentence: Yep, beautiful

author: A
sentence: I can’t see any time groupthink would be helpful

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly, putting it that way

author: Q
sentence: So now I’d like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards

author: Q
sentence: Have you experienced, say when people are sharing their different perspectives and the diversity has created conflict?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I have, and I think that’s where culture is important

author: A
sentence: So inviting diversity in the boardroom will invite different views, and without a respectful, inclusive culture that could create conflict

author: A
sentence: Now the last thing you want in the boardroom is conflict

author: A
sentence: You want good, challenging discussions but you don’t want conflict

author: A
sentence: And actually I have had an experience with a board where there was conflict between a couple of people, and it had been occurring a little bit

author: A
sentence: It was completely dysfunctional to the workings of the overall board, and once the conflict would start again, and everybody else would find it difficult to interject and speak, and it was so unhelpful

author: A
sentence: In the end the board got sick of it and it resulted in the termination of a director

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: A
sentence: Because people had lost confidence in them, because they couldn’t manage their – they couldn’t find a way around having differing views

author: A
sentence: So, absolutely

author: A
sentence: But you can have the most diverse board imaginable and it should work so long as your culture is respectful and inclusive

author: A
sentence: You’ve got to really - when you’re putting directors on it’s not only about their skillsets and their background and their diversity of thinking

author: A
sentence: It is also about do you have the values that are needed to encourage an inclusive and respectful culture? If you don’t, we’re going to have a problem

author: Q
sentence: Fantastic

author: Q
sentence: So how do you do that? How do you select people on that basis?

author: A
sentence: It’s difficult, it’s not easy

author: A
sentence: But if I’m interviewing, you actually do want to understand how these people cope and resolved issues of conflict in the past

author: A
sentence: Now – so you do get a sense in talking to people how they’ve managed difficult situations, and the best you can do is understand what process they went through when they were faced with different conflicts

author: A
sentence: It’s not unlike executive interviewing in a way, that you’re trying to get a sense of that person and how they would deal in difficult situations, but it is difficult

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so interviews are an essential part

author: Q
sentence: Do you outsource that component at all to the head-hunters, or is that something that the board would -

author: A
sentence: No, the board subcommittee does that

author: A
sentence: So the head-hunter can run – the recruiter can run the process of collecting applications and [referring] 00:49:26 you a long-list, but it’s always important for the board committee to do the interviews, subcommittee to do the interviews, and fundamentally it’s the board’s decision

author: A
sentence: So I don’t like being on a board where the nominations committee brings me a name and says ‘This is it, we’ve found it, please approve it

author: A
sentence: ’ I want to see who are the top three to five, and what were they like, and why are you recommending this one to me? It is a board decision, we’re all responsible for working together, and I need to get a sense of the process that the committee went through on our behalf in narrowing it down to the top one

author: Q
sentence: And in that process do you want to see that they’ve considered diversity, or not? That’s irrelevant?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I do, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Would others be thinking along the same lines, or is it you’re a bit on your own there?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sure, so originally accounting

author: A
sentence: I did a Bachelor of Commerce majoring in accounting at the ANU, and then I went on and became a CPA, I’m now a Fellow CPA

author: A
sentence: And then I studied, I did a Masters of Marketing and a Masters of Commercial Law as well

author: Q
sentence: I mean the academic ones are great as well, of course, but no, those two ones for the – because they give us contextual information and it’s a reference at least back to you and it can be updated in future

author: A
sentence: No, I think most – well, again it depends on the board

author: A
sentence: But I think many people are looking for aspects of diversity when they’re recruiting

author: A
sentence: There is only a couple of boards that I have been in contact with where that’s outside the thinking and it’s all about experience or something like that, and that’s all we need to be thinking about

author: A
sentence: So I think most boards now know that we have to think more broadly than just people that are like us

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the boards that do think that way, do you think that they perform better than the other ones, the ones that aren’t actively looking for diversity?

author: A
sentence: I do, because again I think that they – if you’re all thinking the same you’re going to come out with the same answer and there won’t be as much challenging or questioning or critical thinking and deliberation, potentially, if you’re all coming from the same background

author: Q
sentence: And that impacts on strategy? You would see it in that area?

author: A
sentence: It does, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, because that’s -

author: A
sentence: It impacts on decision making, particularly strategic decision making about where we’re headed and how are we going to tackle this? How are we going to be ahead of our competitors? What are we going to do? There’s a myriad of things a board can decide to do, so what you have to do is work out - narrow that down and say what’s the most important thing, and how are we going to pull this off? And that’s the deliberations where the diversity can really add value

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant, okay, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence the selection? I mean, you’ve mentioned the recruitment organisation, is there anyone else?

author: A
sentence: Not really on my boards

author: A
sentence: Definitely on listed I think, yes, because fundamentally the shareholder base makes the appointment even though the board does all the work in putting the candidates up, but they will have a say, particularly around diversity

author: A
sentence: In my boards, the government boards of course are influenced by ministers and government departments, but really – for most of them no, it’s up to the board to get it right and there’s not really external pressure

author: A
sentence: The members of not-for-profits in my experience don’t exert a lot of pressure over the board

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: You’re so clear, it’s wonderful, it’s beautiful

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sure, and I’m happy – so what I can do if you like I’ll email you the journal article - sorry, the article I have in the Company Directors magazine, but I can also email you the PhD itself if you like

author: A
sentence: Oh, thank you

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process? Example, on the one hand trying to retain that collegiate fit for your culture, inclusive culture -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: -@ and on the other trying to avoid groupthink

author: A
sentence: I haven’t seen tension

author: A
sentence: I haven’t seen tension because what normally happens is the nominations committee will be tasked with going away, dealing with the recruiter, creating the short list, interviewing, and bringing the recommendation back to the board

author: A
sentence: It’s really unusual that the board would overturn that because – and it’s unusual that the – like the nominations committee, they have a discussion and come to a [landing] 00:53:56 on the preferred

author: A
sentence: There’s not really an argument about that

author: A
sentence: It’s unusual for a board to overturn it

author: A
sentence: But as I said before, I would be uncomfortable with only being brought one name, I would say ‘Where are the rest?’ So it’s not that I would seek to overturn their decision but I would want to understand who did you interview, and why is this one the one that you’re recommending to me as a board member? So no, I haven’t really seen conflicts over that

author: Q
sentence: Right, and so – but that idea of the inclusive culture, that’s so important, but then the diversity of thinking arising out of diverse backgrounds

author: Q
sentence: If you’ve got two candidates, one who’s got such a fantastic – they’d be great contribution to your culture of respectful inclusiveness

author: Q
sentence: And the other person, not so strong on that, but they have, I don’t know, international experience in blah blah blah and you think that would be really useful and – so there’s a tension between those two

author: Q
sentence: So which candidate, which is the most important? So I guess has there ever been a tension between those two criteria?

author: A
sentence: Not that I recall specifically, no

author: A
sentence: I would like to think that the – I fear that the diversity one would be more visible and that’s the one we would go for, but I would hope that equally important would be the values the person holds

author: A
sentence: So you want those, you actually need those, so look harder if you can’t find those ones, is what I would say to that

author: A
sentence: Haven’t seen the tension where one played off against the other though

author: Q
sentence: Oh that’s good, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Now from a – well, hang on, so you’ve said about the government boards, for the not-for-profit boards are there – well, one barrier was when you’re looking for people from disadvantaged backgrounds there are financial barriers to them getting the – becoming competitive because they haven’t done their AICD course or whatever

author: A
sentence: Well that’s true, that’s true, and I think that’s a good point that whilst there isn’t probably direct influencing by other groups in who we should or shouldn’t appoint, there certainly is – there are inherent barriers

author: A
sentence: So really to be on a board, if you haven’t had a reasonable executive career you’re going to find it difficult, and equally that rules out young people too

author: A
sentence: So you - it already [unclear] 00:59:30 the door for you if you’ve got those characteristics

author: A
sentence: So does that mean that we shouldn’t look at those people? Not necessarily, but it does mean if we place those people we have to really support them and develop them to assist them, and make sure that they felt comfortable to share their views and that they were adequately trained in understanding obligations

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay, so build capacity whilst on the board, build capacity

author: A
sentence: In terms of the disadvantage, we – some of my boards are covering areas that are quite remote, and so we tend to like – we tend to have that group represented by people that are living in the regions

author: A
sentence: So whilst them themselves might not be of disadvantaged backgrounds, they are living within or close to disadvantaged communities

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Other people have said that if you want those different perspectives you can have advisory groups informing the board, so they don’t have to actually be on the board

author: A
sentence: We do have that too, yeah

author: A
sentence: We do have advisory community people

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, to bring those -

author: A
sentence: Again though, they’re likely to come from positions where they know about the advisory board and they know what it does, so they’re not – in terms of that community they’re not the most disadvantaged in that community by any means

author: A
sentence: They might be working with them but they’re not from that background

author: A
sentence: Yeah, no worries

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, good, okay

author: Q
sentence: May contribute to conflict, we’ve done that

author: Q
sentence: Do you know, this cognitive, this diverse thinking, before we move to the almost the last question, how might cognitive diversity be identified? Like you know, this diversity of thinking

author: Q
sentence: Is there a way of identifying it, measuring it, monitoring it?

author: A
sentence: You tend to look at what people have – what they’ve done, where they’ve come from, where they’ve lived, what their work experience has been, what communities have they lived in? So it’s – you don’t test their thinking and their ability to think differently, but you’re making assumptions around well, this person has come from a really different background to us and we’ve not got anyone on the board like that before and they’ve lived in really remote areas or they’ve done things that we haven’t done, and so then you’re making the assumption that they will think differently because they’ve had a background that’s been different

author: Q
sentence: Yep, so it’s an assumption

author: A
sentence: And you further glean that in the interview

author: A
sentence: So you kind of ask questions, so you understand – get an understanding of how does this background help us, how will this thinking benefit us [unclear] 01:02:28 at the board level?

author: Q
sentence: So really it’s not until interview that you can start to assess that?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, yeah

author: A
sentence: You can’t tell, I mean you get an idea from a resume but it’s not – you’ll get a lot more from an interview when you’re probing, asking probing questions, for sure

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the last – like, the – has diversity changed over 10 years? You said gender not much, I think

author: Q
sentence: Has anything -

author: A
sentence: Not in my experience

author: A
sentence: To be honest I’ve always had an indigenous person on [my] 01:03:17 board so my personal experience is no, it hasn’t changed greatly

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Okay, the final question is looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: I would love to see more people with disability on boards, more people with an indigenous background, more people that live in remote areas of Australia, more people with varied ethnic backgrounds and understanding, and absolutely more women

author: A
sentence: Wouldn’t it be nice to think that we could look at a board and see 50% woman, and that would be the norm? And that that’s what appears on most not-for-profits unlisted government boards

author: A
sentence: I think then you wouldn’t have situations where there are still boards with no woman, or one or two

author: A
sentence: And as a woman you do feel that you’re not quite one of them

author: A
sentence: You don’t want people feeling like that, you want people – you want to genuinely have a good representation of society on the boards that are managing the organisations of our country

author: A
sentence: Why wouldn’t you want that?

author: Q
sentence: They can make that call

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, look at our governments

author: Q
sentence: So I guess, why do you think it would be good to have someone from a remote area for example on an ASX listed company, why would that be good?

author: A
sentence: Because you - our governments are run by people who live in capital cities

author: A
sentence: Our major companies are run by people who live in capital cities

author: A
sentence: The decisions for all of Australia are made by people who live in metropolitan areas

author: A
sentence: They don’t – so people that don’t live in major areas and who have a very different experience in their work and their lives are not represented adequately, I don’t think, in government departments, and they’re not represented adequately in large companies, and decisions are being made on their behalf

author: A
sentence: It is - geographical diversity is an important issue

author: A
sentence: Many of our governments are recognising that, and they would like to see more geographically diverse people on boards but I think we have a way to go

author: A
sentence: And I think that if metropolitan people think that they know what’s best for country people then I think that they’re probably mistaken

author: A
sentence: So I would really like to see that [unclear] 01:06:15 Wouldn’t it be great to have people living in outback Northern Territory trained up and ready to sit on government boards and, heaven forbid, listed company boards?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I get you

author: Q
sentence: With technology, digital technology communication, do you think that this will – we’ve got it for distance education as well, so do you think that this might be a way of achieving that goal?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I live in a regional area, and I – it is – boards don’t care where you live

author: A
sentence: They fly you in to the board meeting, and when you’re not there you work at home

author: A
sentence: And the reality is that in most of Australia there is enough coverage to mean that you can work from home, and that’s only going to increase with better use of satellite technology

author: A
sentence: So it’s only going to get easier for us

author: A
sentence: So I think absolutely it’s very possible, and we should be looking more to it

author: A
sentence: You don’t have to be there 40 hours a week if you’re on a board, in fact you shouldn’t be

author: A
sentence: So why can’t you fly into a capital city and go to a board meeting, and then be working from home the rest of the time?

author: Q
sentence: Yep, yep, in your outback whatever, exactly

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: Look, Participant 28D thank you

author: A
sentence: You look at the burgeoning cities, they’re a big problem

author: A
sentence: Look at Sydney

author: A
sentence: The roads are increasingly busier, there are apartment blocks going up everywhere, and the infrastructure isn’t quite keeping up

author: A
sentence: So a lot of people are finding [inaudible] 01:08:07 Sydney

author: A
sentence: So there is a definite push, and I think governments should be more proactive with decentralisation of departments to get people out into the regional areas

author: A
sentence: Something has to give here, and we’ve got a vast continent which is largely uninhabited in the middle, so smart thinking would tell you that we should be able to work from home more in regional centres

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: And in my work life I started in finance and accounting, but then moved into IT and strategy and did a little bit of lecturing in marketing, so it actually is multi-disciplinary which is a lot of the reason that I – or part of the reason that I decided that having such a multi-disciplinary background would be useful to do board work

author: Q
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q
sentence: So Australian boards director, how many years have you been sitting on Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Seven years, since 2012

author: Q
sentence: Wow, excellent

author: Q
sentence: And - so 2012, good

author: Q
sentence: And how many do you currently sit on?

author: A
sentence: I’m on – seven [unclear] 00:04:04 boards, and that’s a mixture of government boards and companies, unlisted companies, and not-for-profits

author: A
sentence: And I also sit on a further – oh, seven? Yeah, I said seven

author: A
sentence: And I also sit on a few others that are non-renumerated

author: A
sentence: So one is the Royal Flying Doctor Service, another one is – I sit on some boards and committees for the Catholic Diocese of Bathurst, and also I chair the Australian Institute of Company Directors Western Region committee which meets quarterly as well

author: A
sentence: So they’re not technically boards, some of those, but they’re committees and things

author: Q
sentence: Oh, brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Quite a scope

author: Q
sentence: But no listed companies as yet?

author: A
sentence: No listed, no, no, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: That’s good, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: And how many boards have you sat on altogether?

author: A
sentence: I would say, oh goodness

author: A
sentence: I would say around 15, probably, in my time

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and would any of those have been listed?

author: A
sentence: No, never sat on a listed one, no

author: Q
sentence: Definitely

author: Q
sentence: And I noticed you have a PhD in board governance

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s okay

author: Q
sentence: But your research was in that area?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, no, that’s right, it was

author: A
sentence: And it’s very interesting because it’s given me a big appreciation for listed boards, and I think I thought prior to doing my research that would be where I aspired to end up, and now I’m not [unclear] 00:05:44 on that anymore

author: A
sentence: I might, but I would think so carefully about what listed board I chose to take on I think because it is a whole new challenge around many things such as disclosure, and I just think – I suspect one day I’ll probably end up on a listed company, but I’m not rushing into it like I thought I might previously

author: Q
sentence: So what are the differences in term of disclosure that worry you?

author: A
sentence: Oh well you don’t have to disclose, there’s no continuous disclosure obligations if you’re not on a listed board

author: A
sentence: And so - but of course on listed companies there are, and you have to get that right

author: A
sentence: And as a board director one of the things that was loud and clear to me was that directors, they’re not there every day, they are heavily reliant on the executive for information and resources and things that enable them to complete their all obligations, not only disclosure

author: A
sentence: So you are heavily reliant, and if you don’t – you can easily get it wrong if you’re not being supported adequately, and the buck stops with you as the director

author: A
sentence: So I think it is – and the adequacy and the accuracy of the financials, I mean that’s [unclear] 00:07:15 with unlisted as well, but there is a whole lot of [unclear] 00:07:20

author: A
sentence: And additionally you’ve got shareholders at AGMs that – and you’ve got major shareholders that are increasing their shareholdings and they are wielding, I suppose, a level of power over these organisations that particularly they haven’t had in the past before

author: A
sentence: So that is an added complexity that you don’t have when you’re not on a listed board

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: And do any of those influence diversity or it’s irrelevant, your concerns?

author: A
sentence: The complexities of what I’ve talked about? Or -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Your reasons for holding back on – so a difference you perceive between listed and non-listed companies, is there any impact on diversity or it’s really those other concerns?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s those other concerns

author: A
sentence: I think what we’re seeing since the – I mean, I’m happy all boards, including listed companies, have now been under significant pressure to sort out their lack of diversity on boards over the years

author: A
sentence: And now we see ASX200 companies, I think they’re at 30% now, which was the goal

author: A
sentence: Well, now major – well, major organisations such as [unclear] 00:08:39 are now saying ‘we want more than that’, so I think they’re pushing harder, which I think is right

author: A
sentence: So I think because listed companies do have – there are major shareholders that are wielding significant power, as they are in the public eye they have to find the right people to make up the best boards, otherwise they’re going to continue to be under pressure

author: A
sentence: And you see that with the three or whatever it is left of the ASX200 companies that don’t have any women, and they’re continuously – their names comes up, that they should have done something a bit better by now and that issue won’t go away

author: A
sentence: And I think if anything they are more in the spotlight when it comes to seeking diversity on their boards

author: A
sentence: I do and that was completed - early this year it was conferred, and that was on – it was a qualitative study where I interviewed 41 ASX200 directors on how they govern under the ASX Corporate Governance Council principals and recommendations

author: A
sentence: So it was very interesting indeed, I have to say, and it was a good experience actually

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting in my research when I asked directors about their recommendations around diversity, and also about appointment and re-appointment, and they talked about - basically my findings show that there were two schools of thought around diversity

author: A
sentence: Sorry, around recruitment to boards across the ASX200

author: A
sentence: And one school of thought was around that you should use existing networks and you should talk to people about who do they know

author: A
sentence: So you need the ability to be able to ask somebody that you trust about this person, or if it’s them themselves, because it’s too risky to end up with someone on the board that doesn’t work out, because you can’t get rid of directors easily if they’re – if it’s not working

author: A
sentence: And because we are all collectively responsible, it’s really important that you can work together

author: A
sentence: And the second school of thought was in complete contrast, and it was basically, well, no, I don’t accept it when – I go to recruiters and I ask them for good names, and if they come back with all men, I say ‘I don’t accept that, you need to go look harder and cast the net wider and find me people, because there have to be women out there that would be suitable for my board’

author: A
sentence: So they were very much saying that’s a cop-out first of all

author: A
sentence: No, you’re not looking hard enough, and don’t tell us that you have to play it safe and get known commodities on the board to make sure it works

author: A
sentence: So I think there is definitely – the tide is changing and there is now not one school of thought around how you recruit but there is two

author: A
sentence: But there’s still old-world thinking perhaps around playing it safe and getting known people on the board

author: Q
sentence: That’s very interesting

author: Q
sentence: So the people who thought using the network to play it safe, were they – did you find any reason to justify this distinction or to explain it? Was it a demographic difference, was -

author: A
sentence: No, it wasn’t, and it wasn’t really a gender difference

author: A
sentence: I [think that] (this participant drew these findings (Three rs: relationship, risk and remuneration) from her PHD which she is willing to give us access if you wish)…

author: A
sentence: ASX200 directors predominantly focus relationships, risk, and renumeration

author: A
sentence: And relationships is about ……

author: A
sentence: effective working relationships between board members, and with the executive, and with key stakeholders

author: A
sentence: And without those relationships working and the presence of trust and things like that, that you actually can’t govern effectively because you’re not there every day

author: A
sentence: So you do have to have those relationships in place to be able to trust people to get your job done

author: A
sentence: And risk was about the danger of getting it wrong, and that – it was about internal risk and external risk

author: A
sentence: External being what’s coming over the horizon at me that I hadn’t predicted? What new competitor is going to pop up tomorrow with a brand new business model that will disrupt mine? But it’s also about the risk of things internally, so things like the presence of fraud or unethical behaviour, or things that I’m being assured everything’s okay but it’s sort of not

author: A
sentence: And I think the school of thought around appointment of board directors and playing it safe and going for people in your network, or connected to someone in your network, is very much around that relationship thing, and it’s around making sure that the person you’re going to get you can work with, you can have a trusting and effective relationship with

author: A
sentence: Now, they didn’t indicate that what it meant was that [they’d think] 00:13:10 of getting someone like me, they indicated that it was important to be able to work collectively – in a collegial fashion as a group because collectively you are all responsible

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So what was the third? I’ve got relationship, risk and -

author: A
sentence: Renumeration

author: A
sentence: So the third -

author: Q
sentence: Sorry?

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Oh, have you published from that research?

author: A
sentence: Renumeration

author: A
sentence: It wasn’t [inaudible] 00:13:41 It was all about, and it was probably the biggest surprise for me in the findings, but what it was about was really the process that now exists with this two-strikes rules is that the shareholder base has the ability to vote the board down, to vote – sorry, to give a strike on the remuneration, on the executive remuneration [unclear] 00:14:08 and if there’s two strikes then the board is essentially voted down

author: A
sentence: And so there is – and directors really feel that [that is – that significant power of the shareholder base and the main shareholders] 00:14:20 is significant, and it’s really influencing the process of getting executive remuneration

author: A
sentence: And essentially they’re saying you’ve got to get go us [inaudible] 00:14:32 everyone else is doing, and that takes away your ability to structure short term incentives and long term incentives in the way that you would like to, to motivate your executive

author: A
sentence: And if you don’t do that then you are not as likely to get a vote passed for your rem, but two of those strikes and the board is dissolved

author: A
sentence: And they also felt that the whole process is a [bit role in that benchmarking] [unclear] 00:14:58 the public concern around the executive rem being high, or about it being high, [unclear] 00:15:20 higher than the other salaries

sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I’ll move -

author: Q
sentence: Oh, much better

author: A
sentence: Oh is that better? No problem, I’ll stay here then

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, much better, yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: In process

sentence: And maybe – that’s great, good

sentence: I better – we’ll work on the questions now, I was just following on what you were saying from the beginning

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: But let’s see, how have the composition of the boards that you’re familiar with changed over the seven years that you’ve been a director, in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: To be honest in my board I personally haven’t – it’s not significantly more gender diverse now than it was back in 2012

author: A
sentence: Some of my boards are genuinely gender equal, if not gender equal I think even one of them has slightly more women than men, and that contrasts to another of my boards which I am the only female

author: A
sentence: So – and that’s – so I haven’t seen a significant increase in females on the boards that I sit on in my seven years

author: A
sentence: I can say that -

author: Q
sentence: Can I just ask you, the one – is there a difference because they are government boards are more gender diverse than say not-for-profit, or the unlisted companies? Is there -

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t find that

author: Q
sentence: Okay, perfect, good

author: Q
sentence: And so we’re interested in other kinds of diversity, so is there – are they structured with a mind for other diversities, other kinds of diversity?

author: A
sentence: We do have – I do sit on a board with – two of my boards have indigenous directors on them, and I find that incredibly insightful, and we’re very lucky to have capable indigenous people at the board level

author: A
sentence: I also do have on my board a little bit of an ethnic background diversity as well

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: So are you a chair of any of these boards?

author: A
sentence: I am a chair of one committee

author: A
sentence: Oh sorry, I do chair a number of finance committees but I also do chair one committee for the [AICD] 00:18:06

author: Q
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q
sentence: That’s good because in the interviews I’ve done, the role of the chair is very strategic in some of these questions so it’d be good – it’s good to know that you do a chair role because we can drill down on that

author: Q
sentence: What does board diversity mean to you, before we move on any further?

author: A
sentence: So board diversity whilst it – really what it means is diversity of thinking, and diversity of background and experience and thinking that’s brought to the table, and that - really for me gender diversity, ethnicity, and age diversity are all enablers of the [former

author: A
sentence: ] 00:18:55 So really we know that men and women think differently, we know that people with an indigenous background have a very different experience of life, and we know that equally the same applies with different ethnic backgrounds

author: A
sentence: So what you are getting is not a board that looks different and has - when you look at a picture they all look different and like they come from different backgrounds, but fundamentally that they think differently, they come from different experiences and backgrounds and skillsets and that together they respect each other’s views and ideas that they bring to the table, and collectively you can leverage off that very broad skills base to make the most effective decisions

author: Q
sentence: Excellent, that’s great, thanks

author: Q
sentence: That’s a nice model there

author: Q
sentence: How important do you think it is to have a diverse board to produce this sort of thinking?

author: A
sentence: It is incredibly important
