sentence: So I have published an article for the Company Director magazine, which is the AICD magazine

author: A
sentence: I actually had a phone call and message this morning from the Governance Institute, they want me to publish in their magazine

author: A
sentence: But in addition I’ve just met with one of my supervisors and I’m working towards publishing in a corporate governance academic journal as well, so I hope to have that done this year sometime

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: So long as my name won’t appear, [so nobody knows that I’ve participated in the study, I’m fine with it

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: So how important is diversity? It’s critical

author: A
sentence: In the case where I’m the only female on the board, it is an incredibly different experience for me on that board than it is with most of my other boards

author: A
sentence: Now what I mean by that is they – my colleagues are incredibly polite and respectful, but I do have a sense that I’m not one of them

author: A
sentence: Now, that does not bother me to the point where I think I shouldn’t be there

author: A
sentence: Quite the contrary, I think I should stay

author: A
sentence: And I think I should keep operating the way I do and that they should have to suffer me, because I’m one person that’s not male and actually they should have more of me around, or more women

author: A
sentence: Now they are never rude to me, they never don’t want to hear my opinion

author: A
sentence: I think sometimes I feel like they’re tolerating me, and that if they had their way that they would rather have another of their friends there

author: A
sentence: But – so it’s just the undercurrent I think

author: A
sentence: I probably didn’t sense it quite as much when there were two of us when I first joined the board, but that certainly is the way – the sense I slightly have now, as opposed to other boards where there are 50% women

author: A
sentence: And one of my boards in particular is very strong in gender advocacy, and on that board it feels not only celebrated that we have gender equality at our board level and certainly across I believe a lot of our executive model, but it is encouraged that we find and promote great women to be part of the leadership of that company

author: A
sentence: So it does feel incredibly different

author: A
sentence: I think not only from – that’s my personal perspective, but in terms of the conversation

author: A
sentence: It’s a different conversation, it’s a different feeling in the room when you have 50% women as opposed to 10%

author: Q
sentence: Participant 28D, one interviewee, it was a male, and he said ‘I would not apply for a board position if there wasn’t gender diversity because it’s a sign that it’s a conservative board and I wouldn’t fit

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yep

author: Q
sentence: What do you think of that?

author: A
sentence: I think he’s in an increasing group of men that have got it right

author: A
sentence: And I think he’s right, I think that many men that I’ve worked with they actively do seek good women for their boards

author: A
sentence: And they genuinely believe, they’re not just doing it for tokenism, they’re doing it because it’s the right thing for the company

author: A
sentence: As well as looking good externally it predominantly is the right, good, thing for the company

author: A
sentence: Not all men are like that

author: A
sentence: There are some incredibly conservative men that are old-school whose wives probably never worked, and they do – the undercurrent and feeling is that any female on the board is potentially taking the place of a talented male

author: A
sentence: Yes, and X won’t be mentioned, although –

author: Q
sentence: 14 years

author: A
sentence: Yes? That gas line -

author: Q
sentence: -@ I used your pipes

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Right? Although the majority of the pipe go to LNG plants, and they export gas to Asia

author: A
sentence: So Michael’s got that deep understanding

author: A
sentence: But actually the rest of us aren’t from the gas industry

author: A
sentence: And I think it’s an outstanding board

author: Q
sentence: Tell me why

author: Q
sentence: Why?

author: A
sentence: Because we’ve all got different views

author: A
sentence: Number one, you’ve got those two outstanding women on them – Debbie Goodin and Shirley In’t Veld

author: A
sentence: We’ve got a different set of experiences in terms of our business careers

author: A
sentence: And when we sit around the board we’ve got differences of perspectives

author: A
sentence: And actually, where Michael is such a great chair, he seeks that out

author: A
sentence: And everyone respects the differences

author: A
sentence: No one speaks over each other, so it’s valued

author: A
sentence: That diversity around the board is truly valued

author: A
sentence: And because of that more of it comes out

author: A
sentence: And that’s the benefit of diversity, right?

author: Q
sentence: This has been a thread as well, you’ve just touched on, which is the cXcity for the board to include the different perspectives

author: Q
sentence: Because without that cXcity your diversity is sort of lost

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a bit more about that?

author: A
sentence: Yes, so you don’t want to fill the board up with people who have come from the industry

author: A
sentence: I’m also not an advocate of actually filling the board up with ex-CEOs

author: A
sentence: Although you maybe want one

author: A
sentence: I’m the contemporary CEO

author: A
sentence: But you do want relevant experience, right? If you look at our board, I guess I bring – going back – the reason why they’ve asked me to join the X board is X is looking at globalising – an Australian company looking at globalising

author: A
sentence: Obviously we successfully did that back in Incitec

author: A
sentence: There are too many Australian businesses that have successfully globalised

author: A
sentence: So I’m bringing that global perspective to the board

author: A
sentence: Obviously Michael brings his gas experience

author: A
sentence: Peter Wasow ran Alumina, so he brings deep experience around really heavy manufacturing, if you like, and commodity markets

author: A
sentence: You’ve got Debbie Goodin, and Debbie chairs our audit committee

author: A
sentence: Debbie’s an ex-chartered firm, so she brings that professional services perspective

author: A
sentence: Steve is an ex-investment banker

author: A
sentence: So – and Shirley ran a gas retailer

author: A
sentence: So she brings a customer perspective – a customer’s perspective

author: A
sentence: So if you think about the skills and experience, it’s very diverse

author: A
sentence: And that’s why the board works so well

author: A
sentence: And of course, management bring the deep experience of the business and industry

author: A
sentence: So it’s interesting

author: A
sentence: We’ve just recruited a new CEO, and I think it was Steve who said – and Michael, they reflected on how different the interviews were, as different board members

author: A
sentence: Because we initially, obviously, it’s – the appointments committee will interview

author: A
sentence: And then it’s the full board that will do the final interview, in terms of once a shortlist – in fact, actually, the directors from the appointments committee shows not to make – ask any questions when the full board was interviewing the candidates, because the questions we were asking were so different and so rich, and questions they just wouldn’t ask

author: A
sentence: Obviously I – being such a relatively new contemporary CEO, my questions were very different to – and that’s the gift of diversity, isn’t it? Now, of course, where I think gender plays such a significant role is I do think gender is almost a magic X in all of that

author: A
sentence: Because thinking life experiences for women are different to men

author: A
sentence: And that’s the gift of having more – having a more balanced diversity on the board in terms of gender

author: A
sentence: Right? And you see that

author: Q
sentence: Do you see that in your – is it Rebecca? Yes, do you see that in her? Because that’s a very rational background -

author: A
sentence: And – pretty much fully since then

author: A
sentence: - you do, because once again – Well, it’s Debbie Goodin on our – she’s had a different experience

author: A
sentence: in fact, she’s obviously been a bit of a trailblazer, because to get senior in a chartered firm – my wife sits on the executive board of PWC

author: A
sentence: and I can remember she was the first female partner in Melbourne, in that organisation

author: A
sentence: and So once again she brings that piece of experience

author: A
sentence: you know, I’m a huge believer in weight of numbers

author: A
sentence: So if you put one woman on a board, you don’t get the bang that if you put two

author: Q
sentence: Why’s that?

author: A
sentence: The dynamic – it’s quite hard – because of course you're bringing not only – you’re bringing the experience, and one of the contexts of that is being a woman, right? It’s hard when you're just one of eight

author: A
sentence: When you’re two of eight you get more space, I think

author: A
sentence: Men have this horrible habit of talking over women, right?

author: Q
sentence: Are we talking specifically about – have you observed this -?

author: A
sentence: - Yes, on boards

author: A
sentence: So it was quite interesting, as CEO, when I had just Rebecca join the board

author: A
sentence: The difference was less than when Kathryn joined the board

author: A
sentence: And I’m a huge believer in – it’s why actually I’ve got a fair bit of sympathy for maybe some quotas, because it’s not until you get a critical mass that -

author: Q
sentence: -@ that you get the effect

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So part of that board being inclusive is that you’ve got the numbers

author: Q
sentence: But this seems to be gender

author: Q
sentence: For example, you might have one person from a financial background, and then that doesn’t happen

author: Q
sentence: But with gender, it does

author: Q
sentence: So it’s a bit different

author: A
sentence: Yes, if you have – and one is not sufficient

author: A
sentence: You start to get a difference with two

author: A
sentence: You’ll see a huge change if there are two -

author: Q
sentence: - women? you’re talking gender, yes

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good period to look at change, so that would be great

author: Q
sentence: And were they different boards?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes, and is it – with three – is it exponential? Or two’s enough, and then you start to – it happens?

author: A
sentence: Two is quite different

author: Q
sentence: What is it? What is it then? How does – what makes a difference? Can you flesh it out for me?

author: A
sentence: From a CEO’s perspective, when I was sitting there, I guess – think about what happens at a board meeting

author: A
sentence: So at a typical board meeting the CEO is probably going to – CEO/management are probably going to speak half the time

author: A
sentence: And then by the time you deal with reports from committees, et cetera, that’s probably another 10-15% - maybe 10%

author: A
sentence: And then by the time you take presentations from externals, that’s another couple of per cent

author: A
sentence: So if you actually think about it, as a non-executive director you might get to ask four questions, maybe

author: A
sentence: If you think about the space

author: A
sentence: So I guess it’s just maybe about the power of numbers

author: A
sentence: Four questions have been asked

author: A
sentence: Now, if you think about those questions, to the extent that they bring the gift that comes with actually not only having a different experience, but having an experience from a woman’s perspective, maybe it’s two

author: A
sentence: Maybe it’s one

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s just the weight of the amount of questions that are asked

author: A
sentence: And I think then of course – I think you pick up the difference if it’s asked a couple of times from that perspective

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s weight of numbers

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: It’s not a very good answer, is it? But it is weight of numbers

author: Q
sentence: No-no-no, it’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: You’ve used two words here – one’s the perspective – that’s gender – and the other one is different experience

author: Q
sentence: And that’s also – and both of these are diversity

author: Q
sentence: But they’re fundamentally different things

author: Q
sentence: And one you need the weight of number, the perspectives

author: Q
sentence: And I’m thinking, because there’s politics around groupings of people – it’s a social phenomenon – that might be what perspective is tapping into

author: Q
sentence: And you need a weight, otherwise you’ll have marginalisation, blah-blah-blah

author: Q
sentence: So that’s a social phenomenon

author: Q
sentence: Whereas experience, it’s a descriptor, and it links really to the functions -

author: A
sentence: - Yes, more of the functional experience, doesn’t it? Sorry, functional background

author: Q
sentence: Yes, and then the task of the board to – I suppose – so it’s not a social phenomena as much as it’s providing inputs to decision making

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So maybe – I haven’t read anything about this, but those two words, you just naturally use them to divide that field

author: Q
sentence: But it sort of makes it -

author: A
sentence: - and remember, what a board does too is a board just doesn’t sit in the boardroom

author: A
sentence: a board goes out into the business

author: A
sentence: and this is where having gender diversity just allows the board to shine, because I’ve got to Say, when Kathryn – Kathryn chaired the HSE committee, and Rebecca was also on that

author: A
sentence: So HSE committees tend to be the ones that will do more site visits

author: A
sentence: Oh wow

author: A
sentence: When I first – so I first joined the board of Incitec Pivot as an executive director – as a finance director

author: A
sentence: Way back then there was one woman that was on the board

author: Q
sentence: HSE committees?

author: A
sentence: Health, safety and environment

author: Q
sentence: Right, of course, yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Because you can’t learn about safety culture from the boardroom

author: A
sentence: It’s impossible

author: A
sentence: So if you look at the committees that a board – obviously a board will do a site visit once a year, but typically the HSE committees will do maybe three, yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: And just the difference in the ability of that committee to relate to people on site

author: A
sentence: And just the experience of the business, in having the HSE committee on site, and the value that committee added when it was much more diverse, it was quite a stark – because – now, once again, this will – there’s an element of this where, if you're not careful, you’ll end up role-stereotyping

author: A
sentence: But Kathryn and Rebecca were just so much better than some of the other men in asking challenging questions, but in a way where the people on the other end always felt comfortable with the question having been asked

author: Q
sentence: Yes, they didn’t react

author: A
sentence: Yes, and actually – whereas men can ask a question where the person on the other end of it ends up walking away, feeling like an idiot

author: A
sentence: And it’s just those skills

author: A
sentence: And once again, I’m almost hesitating a bit, because this is stereotyping women

author: A
sentence: But it’s just the far richer – and so I always used to think, “Thank goodness we had Kathryn and Rebecca on site

author: A
sentence: ” Because of course, when you want – as a CEO, the gift of having the board on site is number one – going back to the first question – the first comment – they’re asking questions you’d never ask as CEO

author: A
sentence: And there’s a phenomenon in safety, which we used to call “gorillas”

author: A
sentence: Have you ever seen the film where people are playing basketball, and you look at the film and there’s a gorilla that comes on and off but you don’t see it?

author: Q
sentence: No, but -

author: A
sentence: - Well, in terms of safety, the risk is that in terms of a site will be people – the people will turn up to site every day, because you actually don’t see change

author: A
sentence: and the reason why you want new people coming on the site is they’ll see things that you don’t, right? That’s the gift

author: A
sentence: and So That’s why you want board visits, because That’s where the board adds value, and of course the board also does its assurance processes and looks at culture

author: A
sentence: but it’s that difference of opinion

author: A
sentence: but not only do you want that gift, but you want it in a way that actually management feel comfortable to be open

author: A
sentence: and where actually they’re happy to do some learning, because That’s the whole point, right?

author: Q
sentence: Oh right, okay

author: A
sentence: And having some more diversity means actually the same – the impact’s still there, and things are pulled up if they need to be

author: A
sentence: But in a way where things get done, because it’s not in an offensive way

author: A
sentence: It’s more of a teaching in an encouraging way

author: A
sentence: Once again, that’s the gift

author: Q
sentence: Yes, now, look, this gift that you're talking about, which is, once again, it’s a social phenomenon – it’s a social skill – and you’re attributing it to gender, to female

author: Q
sentence: Is this because – you know the operations of this business

author: Q
sentence: Are they predominantly male?

author: A
sentence: Yes, because remember I was – fertilisers and explosives, it’s men

author: A
sentence: And out on site, so if you looked at Incitec it’s 16% women

author: A
sentence: If you took away the functional, out on site it’s 10%

author: A
sentence: If you go out on a mine site it might be 1%

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so we need to test this emerging concept, which is fantastic, because we want to build a model, with a business that’s not so male dominated

author: Q
sentence: Because a social phenomena, once you’ve got - a woman talking and observing in a male culture is very different to maybe a male, because it might trigger competitiveness or whatever

author: Q
sentence: And that’s just a social phenomena

author: Q
sentence: So it mightn’t be that Rebecca and Kathryn have these fantastic skills

author: Q
sentence: It might be that – well, they do have good skills – but it mightn’t be any better than some of the men

author: Q
sentence: But in this context it works well because of the gender mix

author: Q
sentence: So we need to try to test that in a – I’m nearly at the end of my interviews

author: Q
sentence: I need to try and find someone who’s in a big, ASX company, who can -

author: A
sentence: It may be a – I don’t know, maybe a bank – no, banks actually are just as -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, the big ones are sort of a bit male-dominated, aren’t they? Anyway, let’s keep on with this interview

author: Q
sentence: But this is really interesting

author: Q
sentence: This can be – this is a pilot

author: Q
sentence: We can look for it in the next stage

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s any situation that a company can face where you would change your rating of diversity as being [ten] 00:40:35?

author: A
sentence: Not in terms of what a board brings, and what the role of a board is

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so maybe if it’s a really uncertain situation, or high-risk? What do you think?

author: A
sentence: That ability to ask different questions – if you think of uncertainty, high-risk, what you want to do is you want to think about the business through a prism of a number of possible scenarios

author: A
sentence: That’s what diversity brings, right?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, yes, exactly

author: Q
sentence: That’s what I wanted to hear

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Everyone is saying this – this is so good

author: Q
sentence: So – okay, what does diversity mean to you? How do you define it in your head?

author: A
sentence: And now if you compare that – and then – when did Barbara step down? And for a long – I think she stepped down in – no-no, she stepped off when I was appointed

author: A
sentence: So there was zero

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think it’s just difference of life experiences, and opinions, and views

author: Q
sentence: Yes, yes

author: Q
sentence: What about approaches to problem solving? It’s a bit of a term called cognitive diversity – different ways of problem solving?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think you also find that, because it’s – you do think differently

author: A
sentence: And I think partly your approach to problem solving, it tends to be – you tend to problem solve in a way that you've found has worked

author: A
sentence: And once again, yes, having everyone in the room who thinks the same, you come up with one solution, which – and where I think it’s different is if you look historically in business, a lot of problems were technical problems

author: A
sentence: So if you had a solution they could have been complex, in terms of their solution

author: A
sentence: But there still was a problem with a solution

author: A
sentence: If we think about where the world’s going now, and think about an overlay of stuff like AI, anything that requires a technical solution will be automated, right?

author: A
sentence: And so will likely end up with problems that require more of an adaptive solution, or where there are multiple solutions, or actually where there’s no solution

author: A
sentence: And you need to iterate to find that

author: A
sentence: Once again, if you think about that change, boy, having a bunch of people sitting around the board who all think the same, that’s a great way to destroy a business, isn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, high-risk

author: A
sentence: So I think if you think about the change in the nature of business, the case for more diversity is even broader, right?

author: Q
sentence: And you gave – you opened with that really great example of where lack of diversity actually endangers – can endanger the business

author: Q
sentence: So that was a really good example

author: Q
sentence: Now, the gender diversity has been debated for a while

author: Q
sentence: And you’re a Male Champion of Change

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about the recent inclusion of this ethnicity, sexual orientations, things like that?

author: A
sentence: The reason why I think – the reason why we’ve started with gender is you've got to start somewhere, right? But the lessons that we’re learning as a group are equally as applicable

author: A
sentence: But I guess it was – yes, so I’ve never seen male Champions of Change being anything other than a broader change – in bringing a broader change

author: A
sentence: And it just happens to be we’re starting with gender

author: A
sentence: And what I would hope is it broadens, right?

author: Q
sentence: To what?

author: A
sentence: To all the elements of diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s probably the only area where the US is more ahead of us, Australia, because obviously you’re actually legally forced to report on that broader slate

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s just we had to start somewhere, and that’s what we’ve started on

author: Q
sentence: 14 years ago, zero women

author: Q
sentence: How many directors?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so with, say, sexual orientation and ethnicity, would you see those as perspectives or as different experience?

author: A
sentence: I think it is different experience

author: Q
sentence: So it’s different experience, not perspective? So we’re not going to – this separation of experience and perspective is not really going to hold for you, is it?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: We’ll throw that in the bin

author: Q
sentence: Does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others, do you think? And why? Or does it depend on the situation?

author: A
sentence: No, I actually don’t think – I think it – so, as I’ve described it, [inaudible] 00:45:37 diversity of thought

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so it’s just – yes

author: Q
sentence: So if it’s diversity of thought then the other things are a means to that end, and -

author: A
sentence: - Yes, for me it’s not the fact that we’ve got men and women

author: A
sentence: it’s the fact that that mix and evening up that mix means you have got far better diversity of thought

author: A
sentence: So Yes, I’m – So it’s almost the shortcut to getting better diversity of thought

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so now we’re moving towards functioning, which is really important

author: Q
sentence: Because how do you manage the potential for conflict, or dis-function? Because you’ve got so many different points of view, perspectives?

author: A
sentence: well, it’s to respect those differences

author: A
sentence: And ultimately that’s what a chair does, right? So a chair says very little in a board meeting, until you’re able to bring that together – until, sorry, if there was an impasse

author: A
sentence: But there really is an impasse on a board, because if you think about a board, it’s – if you look at what a well-functioning board is, you seek out those differences, right? So you value them more

author: A
sentence: In fact, if you don’t – if I don’t – as a CEO, if I didn’t hear them, I thought, “Boy, I’ve got the wrong board

author: A
sentence: How do I engage differently with the board to get those -”

author: A
sentence: Back then there would have been eight, yes

author: Q
sentence: -@ discussions?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Is that what you did when – your first example – when the board was actually not -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I actually sat down with the chair and said, “We need to get a different board here

author: A
sentence: ” So initially – a board – ultimately, a board gets to the point where they do have to support the CEO, right? It’s either support the CEO or fire the CEO

author: A
sentence: That’s why appointing the CEO is so bloody important, because once you have, you're stuck with him or her

author: A
sentence: But one of the things we did do, when we did the merger, we actually inherited its directors, because that’s the way you get it done

author: A
sentence: But separately, I sat down with the chair and said, “I want a different board

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the chair was fine

author: Q
sentence: It was the other directors – okay

author: A
sentence: Yes, and that’s the role

author: A
sentence: As a CEO you should have a conversation with the chair about what mix of experiences you need

author: A
sentence: And of course the chair will often push back, because sometimes that’s – “I’d prefer not to have this person because they ask hard questions,” but personally, I always wanted the harder question

author: A
sentence: I’d far rather be embarrassed in front of the board than in front of a stakeholder because you’ve done something stupid

author: Q
sentence: And is that what you’d say to the board?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: And that’s the openness

author: A
sentence: So for me you’ve got differences of opinions, but remember there are differences of perspectives around [it in general] 00:49:11

author: A
sentence: And in my experience, the differences added to the richness of decision-making

author: A
sentence: Ultimately, there are very few boards where you hold a vote

author: A
sentence: If you’ve ever got to a point where in a board, you’re holding a vote, and there’s three to four, and you carry it on four, you’ve well and truly lost the plot, right?

author: Q
sentence: So it’s really quite resolved, usually?

author: A
sentence: Or it’s deferred, where you can then end up resolving it

author: A
sentence: But you’re right, it eventually gets resolved

author: Q
sentence: Wow, okay

author: Q
sentence: And do you have any idea, that board now, how many -?

author: Q
sentence: So out of – you talk to the chair – as a CEO you talk to the chair, try to win the chair over, and then -

author: A
sentence: And if I, as CEO – and as I say, the acquisition was probably at one point – as a CEO, you know, actually, if you’re able to get close – I would quite often – sorry, on – in the few cases where I could see there were differences of opinions, I would absolutely – I would actually take the agenda item off

author: A
sentence: I’d say, “No, I actually don’t want a decision today

author: A
sentence: ” Because bringing a board with you is just as important

author: A
sentence: So if I got to – because what I really valued was actually, “Am I missing something here?” For the three people who don’t see it my way, that’s a gift once again

author: Q
sentence: So then what would you do with that gift?

author: A
sentence: Defer the decision, and then I’d actually engage with those three

author: A
sentence: Why is it I don’t see it like you do? What am I missing? Let me try and convince you, and if you're still not convinced, I’m going to go away and rethink

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Because that’s what a board brings

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I’ve never heard it described that way

author: Q
sentence: This is so good

sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Yes

sentence: And you're crazy if you don’t use it

author: Q
sentence: Yes, but you see you’re unique – have I interviewed – I think I’ve interviewed one person who’s a CEO and a director

author: Q
sentence: It’s that interaction that you’re really clarifying

author: Q

author: Q
sentence: Managing diversity

author: Q
sentence: When identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity? And if so, how do they do that?

author: A
sentence: Yes, so most boards have got to the point where they’ve said – sorry, boards – there’d be very few boards who’d say, “It’s a good thing if we have all men,” yes? So I think boards have got over that

author: A
sentence: And of course you've got this nice 30%, at least, that has pushed that

author: A
sentence: That’s what’s been useful, actually

author: A
sentence: Well, now, if you look at Incitec Pivot, the CEO’s a woman, so she’s obviously managing director, and there are two other women on the board

author: A
sentence: That would be three out of seven

author: Q
sentence: As the targets

author: A
sentence: Yes, and if you show up without 30%  -

author: Q
sentence: -@ it’s embarrassing

author: A
sentence: It is

author: A
sentence: Quite rightly

author: A
sentence: But it’s embarrassing the – so obviously boards do a skills matrix, but actually now the good boards also think about an experience matrix

author: A
sentence: And if you overlay the belief that actually gender is a useful input into all of that, that’s how you get some diversity now

author: A
sentence: So boards will seek out – will actually pretty much understand, in terms of the brief, what it is, in terms of diversity of thought they want for the next person

author: A
sentence: And that will inform who you go and target

author: A
sentence: The good boards do that

author: Q
sentence: How do you find someone who has this diversity of thought that you're looking for?

author: A
sentence: Well, you’ll do that in the spec

author: A
sentence: And so your headhunters will go out and find that

author: A
sentence: Now, I’ve got to say, actually, as a board, on both sides of the fence, gee, boards have had to do a lot of training with the headhunters

author: A
sentence: Because the headhunters actually have been quite slow to make this change, probably because they’re bloody lazy, right? If you’ve got a bunch of people on your books it’s pretty easy just to serve them up

author: A
sentence: If you’ve got boards now saying, “No, I want you to go and find other headhunters that need to get off their bum and -”

author: Q
sentence: - Yes, look outside your current basket

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: And that’s where actually the gender thing has been quite useful

author: A
sentence: Because they haven’t got women

author: A
sentence: So it’s forced when they go out and have a look

author: A
sentence: So once again, I see it as – I see it really as an enabler, which once again is why I like the 30%

author: A
sentence: Because it forces the board to think differently

author: A
sentence: It forces the headhunters to think differently

author: A
sentence: And you end up with a different pool of people

author: Q
sentence: I had an interviewee who said they would not go to a board, work on a board, sit on a board, if it didn’t have at least 30% of women

author: A
sentence: Yes, well, that’s my criteria now

author: A
sentence: So I’m a Male Champion of Change

author: A
sentence: How can I possibly sit on a board – so I’ve said no to a bunch of offers, because I’m not going to join a – how can I possibly join a board – number one, it’s not because I’m a Male Champion of Change

author: Q
sentence: Sorry, who?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: That’s certainly the – over the 30% target, if – I’m not a great numbers person

author: Q
sentence: That’s more your forte

author: Q
sentence: So that’s good

author: Q
sentence: And then – so that was your first board

author: Q
sentence: And then the next board?

author: Q
sentence: This person wasn’t a Male Champion of Change

author: A
sentence: It’s because I’m not going to join a board that’s going to blow up my reputation

author: A
sentence: And if I don’t see a leading indicator, what does that tell me about the board? It’s going to be a whole bunch -

author: Q
sentence: - That’s what this person said, yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, it’s a leading indicator for me, the fact that you're going to join a board that doesn’t think differently, that -

author: Q
sentence: -@ is conservative? is – they think all the same

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Gee, that’s a good way to sued, isn’t it? Because you will get sued

author: A
sentence: Because you will run the company into a cliff

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: So you see it as a signal of a quality board versus a non-quality board – speaking as a director looking for positions on a board

author: Q
sentence: So the poor board that does not currently have diversity, how they attract -

author: A
sentence: - Well, they don’t

author: Q
sentence: Interesting

author: Q
sentence: Survival of the fittest then

author: Q
sentence: They’ll die

author: A
sentence: They will

author: A
sentence: Because there will be a higher performing company

author: A
sentence: Yes, so the next board is X, which I sit on now

author: A
sentence: So that’s a – so Incitec is an $8 billion company by [enterprise V/v] 00:03:05

author: A
sentence: X is $20 billion

author: A
sentence: And so it’s two out of six

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel – this question is interesting – that tensions can arise in the board selection process? For example between on the one hand choosing someone for that collegiate fit – the fitting in with your culture, of [learning whatever] 00:56:50 and avoiding groupthink on boards?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Once again, going back to that [Helen] 00:56:59, I can remember at PWC, she heads up people and culture

author: A
sentence: And they had a theme one year of recruiting the oddball

author: A
sentence: The group really has to value it, otherwise – it’s really interesting, because this is exactly it

author: A
sentence: As I say, I do a lot of work in the gender space, and if you look at the solutions in the gender space, the one – the majority – sorry, a lot of the stuff that hasn’t worked, it’s all technical solutions, right? So, “I’ll put policy in for this

author: A
sentence: ” “I’ll allow men to take parental leave six months when they have a new baby

author: A
sentence: ” I’ll put that in

author: A
sentence: No one’s taken it up

author: A
sentence: Well, actually, the technical is necessary, but it’s not sufficient

author: A
sentence: The adaptive challenge is to rewire the business so it’s okay for you to go and do that

author: A
sentence: Yes?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: So you have to value it

author: A
sentence: And if you value it, of course you’ll look for the odd ball

author: A
sentence: And in fact you will revel in the fact that they’re going to say stuff that you never would, right? And so – and also, you want a bit of tension around the board

author: A
sentence: If you don’t have tension, what have you got? So the idea that you just have nice conversations is not a great outcome, is it? You always want to have respectful conversations, but the idea that – well, then you become a rubber stamp, right?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I think – you mentioned the values fit

author: Q
sentence: And respect is part of that

author: Q
sentence: So respect is an essential ingredient, and probably trust

author: Q
sentence: Probably trust is important on a board too, yes?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: So these are values

author: Q
sentence: And then you’re sort of alluding to a commitment to adaptive change; to the importance of culture; viewing the organisation as open and interacting with broader communities, et cetera

author: Q
sentence: So these images and values are important, or understanding some values are important

author: Q
sentence: So you want that, not cultural fit, not collegiate fit

author: Q
sentence: But you want that, and then -

author: A
sentence: Yes, but by the way, being honest and respectful – it’s pretty low-bar, right?

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know, in the corporate sector, sorry! We’ve had the Haynes report

author: Q
sentence: It doesn’t seem <laughs> - I might be speaking out of -

author: A
sentence: As a CEO, I – the work I’m doing at La Trobe is on cultural equalities

author: A
sentence: So La Trobe had a strategy – they had some cultural equalities, but the cultural equalities sat really on the wall

author: A
sentence: And I’ve been working on bringing those cultural equalities to life

author: A
sentence: Good values though [inaudible] 01:00:41 honest, integrity – shit, if you have to write that as one of your values, what are you doing? God, if you're none of those things, you're not even going to get in the door, are you? Whereas the values are around how you show up

author: A
sentence: So of course you're going to have a mindset of integrity, honesty – of course

author: A
sentence: But they need to describe your orientation every day

author: A
sentence: So back at Incitec, [inaudible] 01:01:17 for everyone, every day

author: A
sentence: Well, bloody hell, we’re an explosives – we blew things up

author: Q
sentence: Two out of six that are female?

author: A
sentence: So safety’s going to be pretty important

author: A
sentence: Treat the business as your own

author: A
sentence: Challenge and improve the status quo

author: A
sentence: They’re the things, right? So you want people to sign onto those as way of thinking and orientation

author: A
sentence: But within that you want that to play out differently, right? Because it has to play out differently

author: A
sentence: So what does “treat the business as your own” mean? Well, it means a whole heap of different things, depending on the context

author: A
sentence: So in one context, it may mean don’t spend a buck

author: A
sentence: In another context it might be overspend, because this is a huge competitive advantage

author: Q
sentence: It’ll sell out! <laughs>

author: A
sentence: Yes, so there is – these are tools that you bring to orientate yourself, but the way you play them out needs to be different

author: Q
sentence: So for the board, what would these tools be?

author: A
sentence: Well, it’s obviously some of the basics, right? So you don’t get onto a board unless you’re honest

author: A
sentence: You don’t get onto a board unless you’ve got integrity

author: A
sentence: You don’t get onto a board unless you respect the confidences within the board

author: A
sentence: Yes? That’s what gets you on

author: A
sentence: But actually, the reason why you’ll choose a business I think is because of the business’s values

author: A
sentence: So that’s kind of what you sign onto

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so aligning it with a business’s values

author: A
sentence: Yes, because if you disagree with – what are you doing? So if I look at X they’ve got – if you read X’s value set, in terms of the way they want to run the business, which is honest conversations with customers, that’s – I look at the business, but then I look at its values

author: A
sentence: So in terms of whether I want to – I start with business, its values, and then I look at whether the board’s any good, right? And you’ve got to sign onto those

author: A
sentence: And a board needs to take up its role, consistent with those

author: A
sentence: Because if it’s not, that’s the problem, right? Because ultimately they describe the culture

author: A
sentence: So if you think about what Haynes found, actually there was – and by the way, you’ve got to go out and seek that – but in banking, which it never addressed, by the way – there is an underlying culture that the bank can win, even if the customer loses

author: A
sentence: That’s what caused charging dead people, right? Haynes hasn’t addressed that

author: A
sentence: But that’s what you're signing onto, and that’s what a board truly is trying to seek out when they’re talking about culture

author: A
sentence: And the question is – because if you look at the banks, they’ve got wonderfully written values -

author: Q
sentence: -@ I know!This is the trouble

author: Q
sentence: yes

author: A
sentence: Well, they’re on the wall, not lived

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I know

author: Q
sentence: They’re like your policy

author: A
sentence: And so you need to sign onto those

author: A
sentence: The board needs to reflect that

author: A
sentence: That’s what setting tone is

author: A
sentence: The board has to set tone through the language in the business, which should be the values

author: A
sentence: And then go and bloody test whether that’s actually what happens in the – out there in the business

author: A
sentence: That’s what a board needs to do

author: A
sentence: If a board’s not doing that – but you don’t come and try to rewrite the values of the organisation

author: A
sentence: Most organisations’ values have been driven from the bottom-up

author: A
sentence: It’s what people truly do

author: A
sentence: Boy, it’s dangerous if you try to do that

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so – but the values – all right, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: That’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Yes, no, it’s really good

author: Q
sentence: It’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Do the boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to managing or building diversity? Are there any barriers to that?

author: A
sentence: <knock on the door> I think – yes, I’ve got to go

author: Female
sentence: You’ve got an appointment with [Jane and Mallia] 01:05:46

author: A
sentence: Great

author: A
sentence: I think it’s always – it’s just embracing this thought, right? The biggest barrier in a lot of boards that I look at is if you’re not careful, boards are about ten years behind

author: A
sentence: Because a lot of them – sorry, traditional boards – and you can almost pick them out, actually – you can see actually the mindset of the board relates to a period – because a lot of – it’s a lot of ex-executives who end up on boards, right? And particularly these professional directors, you can end up with some mindsets related to -

author: Q
sentence: -@ some baggage

author: A
sentence: Yes, so it’s that - so I’m not a professional director

author: A
sentence: I’m choosing to sit on two boards

author: A
sentence: That’s it

author: A
sentence: And what I don’t like is when you end up with people who are professional directors

author: A
sentence: I don’t think they make good directors

author: A
sentence: Because once again, [what’s the ecosystem] 01:06:55? I hang out at a university and pretend I'm an academic

author: A
sentence: That’s a different perspective

author: Q
sentence: Yes, exactly

author: Q
sentence: The last question is just, ten years into the future, how would you like to see diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Far more than just gender, right? So it needs to match the societies and the customer bases in which they operate

author: A
sentence: So, boy, on Australian boards, what’s the huge gap? How many people from an Asian background are on Australian boards? It’s pretty bloody obviously, isn’t it? So I hope we’ve stopped talking about gender

author: A
sentence: Boy, we’ve achieved nothing if we haven’t

author: A
sentence: And I hope they look at lot – and also, I would hope that we’ve broken open this idea that you’ve got to have this background, right? And now I interact with academics, why wouldn’t you bring a couple of academics on board?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve been on that board since -?

author: Q
sentence: I’ll turn this off

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so -

author: A
sentence: I’d love to -

author: A
sentence: March

author: Q
sentence: Oh, so that’s recent

author: A
sentence: Sorry, February

author: Q
sentence: So six months

author: Q
sentence: So the first one you were on for how many years?

author: A
sentence: Ten years

author: A
sentence: The company I sit on the board of

author: Q
sentence: That’s a long tenure

author: A
sentence: No, no, no, 12 – 13 years

author: Q
sentence: Was that typical? Such a long tenure?

author: A
sentence: Well, I was management, so it’s not – so on that board I was finance director initially, and then CEO

author: A
sentence: So obviously managing director

author: A
sentence: Obviously the X Group, I’m a non-executive director

author: Q
sentence: Yes, and this is – you were a director

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So first, you’ve already mentioned that the composition of boards that you’re familiar with have changed quite remarkably -

author: A
sentence: - for the better, I would tell you

author: Q
sentence: - and – for the better? So if you could rate – let’s Say I give you a scale of one to ten – one it’s not important at all, and ten it’s extremely important, where would you rate diversity?

author: A
sentence: Ten

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been important?

author: A
sentence: It should have always been important, because the great gift the board gives an enterprise is difference of view

author: A
sentence: So I’ve always – certainly running the company, as CEO, I always said, “Look, I’ve got 5,000 people who know a lot about the company

author: A
sentence: ” And you tend to get – no matter how mindful you are of wanting to operate at the strategic level, gee, if something happens in the business, you need to go and address it as CEO

author: A
sentence: So by definition you’ve got a whole organisation that thinks – tends to think in the same way, although we’re trying to change that

author: A
sentence: And you're embedded in that

author: A
sentence: And then you've got this gift of a bunch of people you can work with, in terms of a board, whose role is to think differently

author: A
sentence: And I always used to think about a board meeting on – I always used to score the board meetings on whether they were good or bad

author: Q
sentence: How about – X, did you say?

author: A
sentence: And my reference was, “How many questions were asked that I’ve never asked as a CEO?” And boards have a wonderful ability to step out of the business, and because boards tend to be more broadly networked – because in a business you tend to network within your industry and customer group – boards are the opposite

author: A
sentence: It’s far broader

author: A
sentence: Boards have a wonderful ability to triangulate

author: A
sentence: So they typically can speak to a wider group and figure out, “Is the conversation in the company, does it feel right?” And bring a difference of view

author: A
sentence: And I think key to bringing a difference of view is diversity – by definition they’re linked, aren’t they?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, this is – we will explore this

author: Q
sentence: Do you want to do that now? Talk about your understanding? Or -

author: A
sentence: Yes, so for me, that’s why I think it’s vital

author: A
sentence: Because, boy, it’s easy to run an enterprise into a cliff

author: A
sentence: And you want difference of view – number one, to stop believing your bullshit, but secondly because you’re just not going to see stuff that others can

author: A
sentence: And the hindsight is – the thing about hindsight, it’s obvious when you have fundamental errors in an enterprise, hindsight tells you, “You should have seen them

author: A
sentence: ” I think diversity allows you to see them

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so can we talk about – when you were a CEO, 14 years ago, was there any -

author: A
sentence: - Three years ago I was CEO

author: A
sentence: I was on the board for 14 years

author: Q
sentence: Sorry

author: A
sentence: Yes, three years ago

author: A
sentence: Anyway, yes

author: Q
sentence: Were you a finance director and then CEO?

author: A
sentence: Yes, so I started – so Incitec Pivot – sorry, it’s a fertiliser and explosives company

author: A
sentence: So I joined it as CFO, and then was promoted from CFO to CEO, and I was CEO for nine years

author: Q
sentence: For nine years

author: Q
sentence: So that was nine plus two – 11 years ago, was it?

author: A
sentence: It’s X Group

author: A
sentence: I’m a director of X Group

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So 11 years ago

author: Q
sentence: And then you were sitting on board meetings as CEO?

author: A
sentence: Yes, CEO and managing director

author: A
sentence: So obviously the director who managed the business

author: Q
sentence: That’s right, and so you were on the board then

author: Q
sentence: So 11 years ago, during that period, did you find a decision – can you remember a decision or a situation – and we will de-identify – that illustrates this point where the board perhaps either did or didn’t think of something that was not in the operational [mind] 00:09:08, and it turned the business around or whatever?

author: A
sentence: Well, actually, as it turned out, management did that, and we had a huge pushback from the board

author: A
sentence: So the business was a fertiliser business

author: A
sentence: And if you looked at the make-up of a lot of the board they were farmers, fertiliser people

author: A
sentence: And the story of Incitec was quite an interesting one, because we put the business together initially through the merger of two businesses – one which was called Incitec, one which was called Pivot

author: A
sentence: So it wasn’t – and actually both of those entities now are 100 years old this year – the antecedent entities

author: A
sentence: And so the mindset of the board, because it wasn’t diverse, was, “We’re a fertiliser business

author: A
sentence: ” Now, interestingly, we had a [inaudible] 00:10:04 moment when we bought a business from BHP called Southern Cross Fertilisers

author: A
sentence: Bought it for $100 million

author: A
sentence: Paid for it in two months

author: A
sentence: Bought it just as there was a huge boom in fertiliser prices

author: A
sentence: They went from $200 a tonne to $1,000

author: A
sentence: And so there was a period of time where our share price would go up by a $1 or $2 a day

author: A
sentence: We went from a billion to about $11 billion

author: A
sentence: We were the highest performing stock on the ASX

author: A
sentence: And there was a huge view that actually this reflected stronger for longer in terms of fertiliser prices

author: A
sentence: And at the time the world was three months away from running out of food

author: A
sentence: All to do with the industrialisation, urbanisation of China, changing diets, blah-de-blah-de-blah

author: A
sentence: And at that point in time, we had a look at the fertiliser business and said, “We don’t believe any of this

author: A
sentence: In fact, we actually think it’s not the new [norm or] 00:11:22 it will come back

author: A
sentence: ” And also, when we look at our business, we actually don’t like fertiliser industry, because of its volatility, and actually you want it to go global, which we wanted to do – rather than being $10 billion you had to be $80 billion

author: A
sentence: So we could never get the scale to go global, and even if you went global, we didn’t think the returns were that great

author: A
sentence: So strategically we made the decision to use that $10 billion share price to diversify the business, and that’s when we bought the explosives business

author: A
sentence: And the link is modern explosives are fertilisers, right? But, boy, to get the board out of the mindset that we’re an agricultural, fertiliser business, and, “Hey, this is going incredibly well

author: A
sentence: Look at the share price,” blah-de-blah-de-blah, was an incredibly difficult thing to do

author: A
sentence: Now, as it turns out, the business we bought was Dyno Nobel, which Alfred Nobel, who invented explosives, it took the business global

author: A
sentence: And we used that really expensive share-price to buy it

author: A
sentence: So it was a script based transaction

author: A
sentence: And if you look today – so at the time, 75% of the earnings were fertiliser

author: A
sentence: 25% were explosives

author: A
sentence: And that was the ownership structure

author: A
sentence: So the Dyno shareholders, who we bought, got 25% of the business

author: A
sentence: Our shareholders, who were Incitec, got 75%

author: A
sentence: Look at the earnings today, they’re about 80% explosives, 20% ferts

author: A
sentence: So that’s a massive amount of shareholder value that was created

author: A
sentence: But, boy, we were on the cusp of really struggling to get the board across the line, because they just could not see

author: A
sentence: Now, if you fast-forward today and look at that board, that would be an incredibly easy -

author: Q
sentence: -@ decision?

author: A
sentence: Yes, because you’ve got far more diversity sitting around the board, of thought and experience

author: Q
sentence: Yes, what I’ll say for myself is I’ll search for that and replace it with “X”, just in case – you don’t have to – just say “the organisation” -

author: Q
sentence: So back to that time when there was a barrier, that was when they were mainly farmers -

author: A
sentence: - Farmers, agricultural

author: Q
sentence: Their stakeholders were all to do with that farming network, and -

author: A
sentence: - Yes, they were all men

author: A
sentence: Farmers tend to be old, So the board was full of a bunch of old men

author: Q
sentence: Yes, okay, so your classic non-diverse board

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So somehow you persuaded the board to come along with you

author: Q
sentence: When you bought into that bigger company, the ammunitions company, did that automatically put people on the board?

author: A
sentence: Well, yes, fortunately at the same time we were able to change the diversity – the mix that a board – in terms of skills – and that was when Rebecca McGrath – you may have come across – Rebecca sits on a whole heap of boards – came on board, and that’s where we started to change the mix

author: Q
sentence: So how did you bring her on?

author: A
sentence: It just happened to be her experience was oil and gas

author: A
sentence: And it caused a lot of business globally – fertilisers’ gases are feedstock

author: A
sentence: So the gift – Rebecca was a huge gift

author: A
sentence: But she was brought on because of that experience

author: A
sentence: The other director who sits on the board is Kathryn Fagg now

author: A
sentence: It’s just that – as you know, as a non-executive director you’ve got no authority to talk on behalf of the company

author: Q
sentence: I haven’t interviewed either of these

author: A
sentence: Two outstanding women

author: A
sentence: Absolutely outstanding

author: A
sentence: And if you look at Rebecca and Kathryn they’re regularly written up as the women in influence around boards

author: A
sentence: But that was a catalyst to say actually we needed a different looking board

author: A
sentence: And I guess at the time – so this was 2008

author: A
sentence: In some respects we haven’t come very far, because we’ve still got less than 30%

author: A
sentence: But if you look back, we’ve come an enormous – as a community

author: Q
sentence: And they’re not all farmers now?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Yes, are there any farmers?

author: A
sentence: None

author: Q
sentence: Because you're – what did you say -?

author: Q
sentence: - 20% now is fertiliser

author: Q
sentence: And that tends to be Australian focused, not global?

author: A
sentence: Yes, whereas the business is global as it operates in 13 countries now

author: A
sentence: So it was your classic taking your Australian business global

author: A
sentence: So yes, and now if you look around our board, the chair has actually just stepped down

author: A
sentence: Paul Brasher’s an accounting person, so from Price Waterhouse Coopers

author: A
sentence: He’s global chairman of that company

author: A

author: Q
sentence: So you now don’t have anyone on the board representing, let’s say, the interests of the 20% of local farmers

author: Q
sentence: Is this a problem? Is there tension between the two -?

author: A
sentence: Well, not really, because of course you’ve got a business still, that’s a fertiliser business

author: A
sentence: So the customer focus is still there

author: A
sentence: Boards – I’m actually a huge advocate for – not filling boards up with people who know deeply about the business

author: A
sentence: And that’s just – as I said, there’s 5,000 people in Incitec who know deeply about mining and deeply about fertiliser

author: A
sentence: Why you’d need to repeat that on the board, I’ve got no idea

author: A
sentence: And boards spend enough time understanding the business

author: A
sentence: So it’s not as if you haven’t got anyone on the board who hasn’t got a view of agriculture

author: A
sentence: Of course they do

author: A
sentence: Boards interact with customers

author: A
sentence: Boards don’t just sit there and take what management tells them, passively

author: A
sentence: Boards spend time with the customer base and seek out that knowledge

author: A
sentence: And the great confidences – what you're looking for is people around the board who have some customer-centricity

author: A
sentence: That’s what brings the voice of the customer in

author: A
sentence: it’s that mindset, rather than, “I used to run a farm 30 years ago

author: A
sentence: ” So it’s almost dangerous actually, because if you end up with directors, by definition a director’s day job is directing

author: A
sentence: It isn’t farming anymore

author: A
sentence: So you can end up with quite a dangerous view of a customer base that isn’t, if you're not careful

author: A
sentence: Whereas an orientation around customer-centricity, which would be, “I’ll seek out and understand what the customer’s requirements are,” is far more valuable, because you get that independent – so I never saw it as an impediment

author: A
sentence: At the same time we didn’t fill the boar dup with mining people, right?

author: A
sentence: I found that on a charitable board that I worked as company secretary for, it was very interesting, we had Directors from what you would call traditional board backgrounds, so, finance, accounting, law, and it was a health charity, so we also had people with expertise in the relative area, but we recruited some younger people, and particularly with charities a lot of fundraising is now going online - in fact, I've seen this in two charities, so, digital expertise is particularly valued by this sector because increasingly services and fundraising is going online

author: A
sentence: Typically that's a younger group of people who have that expertise, so it was kind of interesting to see how that worked in the context of just how it changed the dynamic, because you'll have a different way of - coming from that sort of background you will have a very different set of considerations from someone who has, say for example, spent their professional career as an accountant or a lawyer or a finance person

author: Q1
sentence: So, can you describe a situation, like, give us a feel for how that was, like, I can see it's very different, especially if it was a fairly established board and then they brought this new, young person -?

author: A
sentence: Well, for example, they just ask - they ask different questions, they think about different things, they take different things into consideration

author: A
sentence: They've got a different knowledge base, and apart from anything else, we moved from doing a dozen hard copies of board papers to most people doing it on their laptop or iPad

author: A
sentence: So, I felt the immediate benefit of not having to prepare 14 sets of hard copy board papers

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q1
sentence: Was it -

author: A
sentence: As did the planet

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, exactly

sentence: [inaudible] 00:57:54

author: A
sentence: I mean, that's not inconceivable, and this wasn't a listed board, it was a charity, so different dynamic again

author: A
sentence: People are there because they want to give back, so you do have a different dynamic - well, I'm not saying that listed company Directors don't want to give back either, but it is a different dy - and unpaid, so it's a different dynamic

author: Q1
sentence: So, you think that unpaid thing makes a difference?

sentence: And I think the girls club exists just as much as the boys club

author: A
sentence: So, -that - and this is talking about the US, but it would be interesting to see whether that was the same in Australia, because there are fewer CEO's, you know, it's fact, there are fewer female CEO's

sentence: So, whereas my mother knew all the people who did the law course with her, and there was a handful, they could count them on one hand, there were lots of women when I went through, which was a while ago, whereas now, as I said, you know, it might be 55/45

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's really just the opening up, particularly in the more traditional professions, to women, and I guess a lot of women might see it as a more palatable way of achieving a really interesting career, than being a partner in a major law firm of a major accounting firm

author: A
sentence: I think diversity on boards in every country is important

author: Q1
sentence: Why is that?

author: A
sentence: Because I think it's quite clear from a number of studies that diverse groups make better decisions

author: Q1
sentence: And better decision - how do you understand that? What makes a better decision?

author: Q1
sentence: Can you see us?

author: A
sentence: I suppose it's really the best decision for the particular entity, but you're bringing, I guess, a broader perspective to your decision making, and particularly given that companies do have to think about a lot of factors when making decisions

author: A
sentence: We've seen the resurrection of the shareholder privacy debate in the last few months, you know, and they do need to take into account a broad range of stakeholders

author: A
sentence: I think that, yeah, diversity is going to be a very important part of that because different backgrounds will have different skills and different knowledge, different networks, so that's going to be important

author: A
sentence: I think the other thing is, too, with change, say, for example, in relation to - you know, technology is rapidly changing, those skills are still not rare, but there are fewer Directors with those skills than, for example, there are with financial skills or general business skills, or legal skills or accounting skills

author: A
sentence: So, diversity is going to be important in getting the sorts of people that you need on boards that have skills that will take them into the future

sentence: How do you think new board members should be selected? [inaudible] 00:49:11

author: A
sentence: It depends on the organisation, but you do need to have a proper process

author: Q1
sentence: So, you say it depends on the organisation, what are the factors there that -?

author: A
sentence: Well, it will depend on what you're required to do under your constitution, so, you know, if we're talking about a listed company or we're talking about a not for profit, or a government board, there will be variations depending on the type of entity, and what you do with a large listed company might be completely different to what you would do for a company limited by guarantee that's a charity, but similar considerations apply

author: A
sentence: You would need to look at the mix of skills that you currently have, you would need to look at what you're seeking to achieve, and then, say for example in the case of a not for profit, you might answer to –

author: A
sentence: I've worked for various not for profits, so in some cases it's a matter of contacting the membership and letting them know that positions are available, or in other cases you might advertise, and depending on budget you might use a search firm or you might use a combination of approaches

author: A
sentence: Typically, obviously, in a large listed company you will have a nomination committee, so they will be very much across that process, but you might, in a much smaller entity, have a small committee of the board who work to look at a suitable candidate

author: A
sentence: Oh, pleasure

sentence: Okay, there's two things there that link to some literature for me

sentence: In part

sentence: Oh, well, you would have a - you set up a committee of the board which is called the nominations committee, and that's usually looking at Director selection, appointment and evaluation

sentence: So, it won't be necessarily people they know, it will be - they might oversee the process with the organising -?
