author: A
sentence: “You are wanting to further your ambition in a particular way and it’s appropriate to be trying to do it in this setting and in the manner you’re going about it so on both counts, we know about what you’re wanting to do and we do not condone either of them

author: Q
sentence: We’re drilling down on collegiate mindset and how - other people have talked about the board - instead of talking about diversity as a noun, they talk about the board’s ability to include diversity, different perspectives, different whatever and that the board culture is about including voices, working with difference productively and I’m wondering how that connects with your idea of collegiate mindset

author: A
sentence: Well, the collegiate mindset, it can thrive only if you create an appropriate setting in the board

author: A
sentence: So, for example, you need to be what I would call ‘generous’ in your spirits

author: A
sentence: So, you need to listen to people and genuinely listen to their points of view

author: A
sentence: If they say something, it is a reality for them

author: A
sentence: You may disagree with it but it is what they feel and therefore, that alone has a validity so consequently, the environment where you can engender discussion, open discussion without fear of, “I’m too silly to ask this,” or, “I shouldn’t ask it because somebody else may dislike what I’m asking

author: A
sentence: You need to foster an environment where those issues are very clearly stated

author: A
sentence: “Ask whatever you want to ask and voice your concerns openly,” and it is the role of the chairman actually, or chairwoman, to foster this kind of spirit of collegiality because invariably in any group of people, you will have people who are more vociferous than others, and therefore, their views will dominate the discussion and it’s important for the chair to say, “Okay, we haven’t heard from you, Jill,” or, “You, Jack,” and say, “What’s your view?”

author: A
sentence: And if somebody jumps in as soon as Jack opens and they’re being smart, say, “No

author: A
sentence: We are now going to listen to Jack

author: A
sentence: Elaborate more on this, Jack,” and coax it out of him a bit and that way, you will actually send a very strong signal to the [inaudible] 00:42:43 of just, “Shut up and listen,” and B, you actually give the other person an opportunity to put their view forward and then that view is there for the entire board to rake something off it and they might think it’s complete nonsense or it’s actually a good issue and they should consider it

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: That explains that really well, thank you

author: Q
sentence: This question is about cognitive diversity which is different ways of thinking

author: Q
sentence: So, there’s a fair bit of talk that we want to work with about that and it says that cognitive diversity has an influence on a board’s functioning and what we want to do is find out from people like you, how does cognitive diversity influence your board’s functioning?  Is it positive, negative?  Is it contingent?  Does it depend?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think cognitive diversity, we set boundaries to diversity and probably our recruiting process corrals us into - we all pay lip service to cognitive diversity and all that

author: A
sentence: For example, I am genuinely committed to have diverse views on the board and diverse skills and diverse ways of looking at problems but also as a group of people, you need to be able to work effectively

author: A
sentence: When I look at the boards that I am on, there is diversity

author: A
sentence: So, we’ve got a great deal of ladies on board, we have people with disabilities on board but not once have I seen a Kalahari Bushman on any of the boards I’m on

author: A
sentence: I bet you that a Kalahari Bushman would think about problems very differently to what we think, so I think that the diversity - so, I am absolutely certain that cognitive diversity fosters your competitive advantage as a board but I also would think that our diversity is somewhat constrained by the cultural realities we live in

author: A
sentence: I live in Australia and therefore - and I don’t know any Kalahari Bushmen so it’d be very, very hard to get one on the board and furthermore, even if there was one, would it be - would the inclusion of that individual be making a positive contribution to the effectiveness of the board?  That person’s views would be so diverse that it could actually render the entire board ineffective

author: Q
sentence: This is a key question

author: Q
sentence: You’ve put your finger on a key question

author: Q
sentence: The question is how - on the one hand, during selection process, on the one hand you’re trying to obtain a collegiate fit because that’s really important, your board culture, being able to function that way, but on the other, trying to avoid groupthink

author: Q
sentence: Trying to avoid groupthink on the one hand but obtain collegiate fit when you’re selecting new members

author: Q
sentence: This is exactly the point I was then going to get to, and you’ve anticipated it

author: A
sentence: [Margot], that’s [hell] 00:47:07 quite frankly

author: A
sentence: I have no idea, really

author: A
sentence: You hope that you would be bringing in people who would not be fostering groupthink but it’s more of a statement of an aspiration an ambition than reality

author: A
sentence: So, what do I do?  I’m interviewing for a board member and I say, “Gee Jenny, do you foster groupthink?”  I know exactly where you’re taking it but how on earth to get there, I have no idea to be honest

author: Q
sentence: Is that a for-profit company?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, you just hope that when you select someone, that they will think differently and will contribute to a broader understanding of the issues

author: A
sentence: I guess there are two elements to it, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: Whether they will think differently, it is my view that it is almost impossible to assess that but also, one thing is to think differently but another thing - and you can actually have a bit of an influence of that - is how assertive you are with your views and that’s a fine balance because you want - if somebody thinks, ‘No, this discussion is going in a wrong direction,’ so you want someone to be freethinking enough to say, “It’s just nonsense

author: A
sentence: We should have a look at it from this perspective,” and have sufficient presence and confidence to express that

author: A
sentence: So, in the interview process, I don’t know whether I could reasonably even aspire to assess whether someone would think about problems more creatively, differently to what I would but maybe you can, in an interview process, gauge whether if they do have a different opinion to the other five or six people on the board, whether they would have sufficient confidence to express the fact that they are thinking something totally different to what the group is thinking and be able to do that in a positive and constructive way, rather than to upset the other board members

author: A
sentence: You can maybe make some assessments about it in the interview process

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: I get that

author: Q
sentence: That makes sense

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got different ways and different perspectives

author: Q
sentence: You’re measuring that with your skills matrix as an approximate -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well, the skills matrix, that’s quite frankly the easiest thing

author: A
sentence: So, you say, [Margot], “Thanks for coming for the interview

author: A
sentence: So, you’re a lawyer

author: A
sentence: What experience have you had?”  “Well, I’ve been a family law expert

author: A
sentence: ”  “That’s good

author: A
sentence: So, how does that relate to raising equity in an international market?”  So, you can - so, the skills matrix, that’s the easy thing

author: A
sentence: It’s the bit you’re talking about that’s not so easy

author: Q
sentence: So, you can’t approximate from that

author: Q
sentence: One person said to me that their skill matrix, they extend it to include criteria for diversity

author: Q
sentence: So, they get the basic skills - you’ve just identified a particular legal background would be useful - and then look at gender, cultural background and they try and get as many ticks as they can but the essential core skills are not negotiable

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: That’s a great thing to do

author: A
sentence: Actually, I touched on it earlier, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: You are 100% correct because for example, you’re looking for a lawyer so you get 10 lawyers and out of the 10 lawyers, you will find that three practise family law - and I’m making this up as an example only - and you are going to be raising equity in international debt markets

author: A
sentence: Well, maybe those three, irrespective of what their cultural backgrounds are, are not suitable but then, you might get a lawyer who is let’s say, of an Asian extraction and has actually worked in a corporate environment and then you think, “Hell, that would be really, really good to have on my board because where am I going to raise the money?  Will I go to Pakistan?  No, because they don’t have any money but I’ll go to Japan,” and there’s a whole bunch of Asian countries that you are likely to be raising money from and therefore, it would be extremely useful to have a person with the corporate skills that you need and the legal skills, plus also, the cultural sensitivity in the markets that you wish to engage with

author: A
sentence: So, the extension of the skills matrix to accommodate other things, I think it’s a great idea

author: Q
sentence: Good, well it’s not mine personally but someone did come up with it

author: A
sentence: Doesn’t matter, appropriated

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: It’s a member - we make profits but it’s a member organisation

author: A
sentence: Then, I’m a member for Brain Injury SA and that’s a not-for-profit for people who are suffering with brain injury and we concentrate on their rehabilitation and to regain as useful life as they can possibly have

author: A
sentence: I’m also a member for [inaudible] 00:02:01 Johnson [inaudible] 00:02:04 Financial Services Group, which is a normal for-profit company

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that the boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to building diversity?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: It’s a - you see, people - [Margot], I need to answer it in a different way because essentially, people on boards, the perception of directors is that they are all-knowing and really clever people and often, it’s not the case actually

author: A
sentence: They’re definitely not all-knowing and in many, many cases, they are not that clever either and the issue about thinking very broadly about, ‘What is it that will bring me the competitive advantage vis a vis the others?’ I think that many people see it through much more hero [inaudible] 00:54:22

author: A
sentence: I’m just not sure that the sophistication of thinking in the boards is there where you can rely on it, to be honest, to be seeking diversity

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s like there’s a myopia but this is about the board itself

author: Q
sentence: You can’t see that it’s lacking diversity and that it could benefit from diversity because that’s its nature

author: A
sentence: Well, I suspect - I could be doing a disservice to some boards - but they would pay not lip service but diversity is good because it’s good and it’s topical so that’s good, but if they really understand why actually, diversity is really, really important, they would take a different view to it, I reckon

author: Q
sentence: So, you haven’t been able to sell it to your boards?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: My boards are reasonably diverse actually, to be honest

author: A
sentence: Well, I sit on one board and I’m the only bloke there so in terms of gender diversity, unless I vote myself off, I couldn’t do any better

author: A
sentence: I sit on a board where we actually do have - and not a token person with disability - a serious board member with a disability and with a serious disability, I should point out, [inaudible] 00:56:30 good so I don’t know what else I could do

author: A
sentence: One thing, one very important feature of boards, [Margot], is that as a board member, you are one amongst equals - and I’m not sure if you’re familiar with that

author: A
sentence: It’s derived from the Westminster system of government

author: A
sentence: As a chairman, you are first amongst equals but the emphasis is on equals

author: A
sentence: So, you can influence people and you can have enlightened discussions but also, the reality is that all the influencing and all the enlightened discussions will become always not sub optimised but there will be a whole bunch of issues where - day-to-day considerations

author: A
sentence: You are not operating in isolation, [Margot]

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re one among equals and discussion brings with it a whole lot of issues, some of which are external to the board, influence external to the board of course

author: A
sentence: [Margot], let me pause you if I could

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, please

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s three I’ve got or are there two industry association ones?

author: A
sentence: I will turn off my engine and in case it cuts us off, call me back on this number in 30 seconds but stay on the line because I don’t think that our conversation should be interrupted

author: A
sentence: It may be interrupted just for a moment

author: Q
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: Are you there?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, I’m here

author: A
sentence: Okay, fine, so we can continue

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: So, sorry, you were asking a question

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s okay

author: Q
sentence: You were talking about board process involving directors as one among equals and that there’s a discussion and the discussion brings with it, issues, a bunch of issues and then some of them are external or something you were saying

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: Let me elaborate on that

author: A
sentence: I think I know where you’re leading it, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: Quite frankly, you don’t go to the board meeting to discuss cultural issues or diversity issues

author: A
sentence: You go to a board meeting to discuss the business of the organisation you’re in and you will find that the issues pertaining to the business will always and rightfully dominate the board discussion

author: A
sentence: So, it is rare, very rare, to have the luxury where the board can just have an enlightened conversation like we are having now because normally it’s, “What is the competition doing?  What are our financial resources?”  It’s a far more business focused discussion at the board level

author: Q
sentence: Of course, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Is this because I was talking about the board reflecting on itself as, “Are we diverse?  Should we be diverse?  Would we be better off if we were diverse?” so that the board doesn’t really have much time to reflect on those things and when you’re selecting new board members, you do your skills matrix and then you get your recruitment organisation to find people and you do interviews

author: Q
sentence: It’s - you don’t spend too much time reflecting on who you are as a board and how you’re operating together

author: A
sentence: Sorry, which ones?

author: A
sentence: I think that that’s true, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: I really do

author: A
sentence: I think you’re right

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, except for when that critical moment came, there was that conflict, the director called them out, the two people and said, “You’re disrupting us

author: Q
sentence: This is not how it should be,” and there were a few ground rules set and then everyone’s moving forward and doing business as usual

author: A
sentence: Well, that’s true, [Margot], and the reason why it was called out and called out quite forcefully was because it was actually impacting on the ability of the board to conduct its day-to-day business

author: A
sentence: So, it wasn’t called out because of some kind of an esoteric consideration

author: A
sentence: It was, “Look

author: A
sentence: We are not talking about the right things we should be talking about because you two don’t seem to be seeing eye to eye

author: A
sentence: So, let’s put it on the table

author: A
sentence: Let’s have a discussion about it and let’s get back to business for the benefit of our organisation

author: A
sentence: ”  So, that was the tenor of the conversation

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think that gender targets and quotas and that sort of thing, do you think they’re useful?

author: A
sentence: Probably not

author: A
sentence: I think what is most useful is the - for example, let’s just simplify it

author: A
sentence: In terms of gender targets or gender mix, I think what is most useful is to develop a cadre of experienced, capable women and then you will not need quotas because they will be hotly sought after whereas if you plonk women in - like that experience I’ve told you in 1989

author: A
sentence: I was a young, young executive with this particular bank and the lady that we had was a highly, highly experienced academic from University of New South Wales and even then, I was looking and thinking, ‘What on earth is she contributing to it?’  I could give you one specific example where I wrote a board paper and the comments I received from her were just appalling to be honest

author: A
sentence: It just completely missed the point

author: A
sentence: To me, the answer is if you want to increase women’s participation on boards, a good, laudable objective, think, ‘How do I get there?’ is develop a cadre of women that are capable, a la we were talking about Julie Bishop

author: A
sentence: I could tell you, she would have zero difficulty getting on any board in Australia

author: A
sentence: Why?  Because she’s tough, she’s knowledgeable, she knows her stuff

author: A
sentence: Yes, I fully understand that it’s difficult for women to get experienced and all that but it’s also classically difficult for guys

author: A
sentence: It’s not easy

author: Q
sentence: Can I just ask you a question?  We’re nearly to the last question

author: Q
sentence: There’s one more question which is just asking you to think about the future but I really like this thing you told me before about confidence

author: Q
sentence: Confidence was one of the requisites for a board member

author: Q
sentence: Capacity and confidence, that’s it

author: Q
sentence: Capacity and confidence to put their view, that’s essential and you assess that at interview

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there could be a bias in that, an unconscious bias?  Maybe women present confidence in a different way or whatever

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: Yes, I do

author: Q
sentence: So, there could be a prejudice with the interview process that people aren’t consciously aware of it

author: A
sentence: There could be, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: There are two elements to it once again

author: A
sentence: There’s cultural difference

author: A
sentence: For example, some cultures would have a very good idea but would not necessarily - our western culture is that we are reasonably forward with our thinking and that would be especially amongst men

author: A
sentence: Ladies may express confidence differently quite possibly and it’s also, so may other cultures as well

author: Q
sentence: I’ve got CPA -

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I’m thinking Asian cultures, open conflict is really not a thing they do and a handshake is quite different, I’ve heard

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: These are things that would come out at interview and without an appreciation of that cultural difference, that interview process might be biased

author: Q
sentence: So, back to targets

author: Q
sentence: Targets can be a way to force people to think about the systems things that might prejudice, limit access of people from other groups, from gender differences but I would suggest that maybe it’s men on the board that you’re only one male among women

author: Q
sentence: There might be a systematic bias against men getting on it, I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: What do you think?  Why are there so few men?

author: A
sentence: Why are there so few men?

author: Q
sentence: On the board where you’re one male among many women

author: A
sentence: Well, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: Because the other ladies are good directors

author: A
sentence: It really is that simple, seriously

author: A
sentence: To be perfectly frank with you, [Margot], do I feel the least bit worried about it?  No

author: A
sentence: Why?  Because quite frankly, when I walk into that room, there are six directors of which I’m one of

author: A
sentence: I would deal with them in exactly the same fashion as I would deal if they were just five other guys

author: A
sentence: I don’t perceive any bias towards me and I certainly do not treat them in any other way that I would any other director and the reason why there is this good [inaudible] 01:08:01 is that they are good directors

author: A
sentence: They’re very competent people

author: A
sentence: That’s the beauty of it, that they got there not because of a quota

author: A
sentence: They got there because they’ve built up very successful businesses themselves

author: A
sentence: They’re successful businesswomen

author: Q
sentence: Thank you for that

author: Q
sentence: The final question is looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: To me, the question of diversity is secondary to the question of effectiveness of the board

author: A
sentence: I would like to see that our boards are as effective as they possibly can be to lead organisations through what is and will continue to be a challenging business environment and if the effectiveness can be improved, the competitive advantage of the boards can be improved by having a greater cohort of - a greater cultural mix or gender mix, I’m all for it because it would only improve the effectiveness of the board

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, as a means to that end

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Beyond that, well, there is no other reason for a board to exist as far as I’m concerned

author: A
sentence: I think I might’ve forgotten another one, being the South Australian Electoral Commission

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: That’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: That was so clear

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much for your time, [30D]

author: A
sentence: It’s a pleasure, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: If there’s any other follow-up issues, don’t hesitate to give me a call

author: Q
sentence: Thanks a lot, [30D], that’s great

author: Q
sentence: Have a nice day

author: Q
sentence: What’s that, a state - that would be a state-owned -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well, it’s the electoral commission of the state of South Australia, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: They’re diverse

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: Have you sat on any other than these five boards?  Have you been on other boards in the past?

author: A
sentence: Professional background or what do you mean?

author: A
sentence: I have

author: A
sentence: I’ve been a board member of the Hooker Corporation

author: A
sentence: That’s many years ago

author: A
sentence: I was on the board of [inaudible] 00:03:12 for a number of years, the real estate agent company

author: A
sentence: A whole bunch of - when I was the Chief Financial Officer of [inaudible] 00:03:25, there was a whole bunch of subsidiaries that I was sitting on as a board member and then when I was a Chief Financial Officer of Jupiters Limited, I was on a number of boards so really, quite a number to be honest

author: Q
sentence: And a lot of those were in the for-profit sector?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: All of them were

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Well, [30D], this research is looking at board diversity and our particular perspective is not to work from theory but to ask people who are on boards or on organisations that are influencing boards what they understand board diversity to mean and how it should be managed, and its [levers] 00:04:23 and barriers, so that’s what we’ll focus on in today’s interview

author: Q
sentence: So, first, how have the composition of the boards that you’re familiar with, and it’s quite a range of them spanning 30 years, how have they changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Well, diversity, I guess if I take it from a different perspective if I could, diversity in terms of skill ranges has not changed a heck of a lot

author: A
sentence: So, consequently if you are looking [inaudible] 00:05:12 I think that fact is governed basically by my skills matrix which should be available to the board and my being present on the board

author: A
sentence: So, typically you need - the skills that you require is a very, very strong financial skill, you need a very, very strong legal skill

author: A
sentence: Typically, you - well, unquestionably, you need a very, very strong corporate governance skill and then depending on the organisation, you may need a marketing skill if it’s relevant

author: A
sentence: The first few I’ve mentioned to you were the core skills

author: A
sentence: The marketing skill can become core if the particular board role requires it

author: A
sentence: The other skills are obviously knowledge of the economic and political system that you operate in

author: A
sentence: So, in that regard, I think that those skills are absolutely timeless and will always be required to be on the board and so from that perspective, I am not seeing any change

author: A
sentence: If you are then asking about the composition of the board, typically those people [inaudible] 00:06:41 skill that can change and does change with time

author: A
sentence: So, for example, I sit on one board where I am the only male

author: A
sentence: The rest of them, five other members, are ladies and it works perfectly well, very well actually and the reason why it works very well just because each and every one of us possesses the key skills to be a competent and able director

author: A
sentence: So, that’s right now, [inaudible] 00:07:22 five ladies, one guy and that probably wouldn’t have happened 30 years ago so change from that perspective

author: A
sentence: Now, I also sit on a board where we have a board member who has a disability but I don’t know whether that would’ve been present 30 years ago or not because that’s the Brain Injury SA board and I suspect that directors like that may have been on those boards previously

author: A
sentence: Was that roughly what you were looking for?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, very good

author: Q
sentence: I’m interested to know then, with the - let’s say the cognitive disability - how does that board facilitate the involvement of the person with cognitive disability so that they can be a fully competent board member in terms of those core skills?

author: A
sentence: This lady doesn’t have a cognitive disability, she has a physical disability

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay

author: Q
sentence: I thought you said it was brain injury

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Are you an accountant, lawyer?

author: A
sentence: Well, actually, I shouldn’t speak so quickly because - well, I can tell that you that sitting around the board, this lady is as sharp as you and I put together

author: A
sentence: No obvious cognitive disability but she’s a stroke sufferer so the most obvious disability is physical, not cognitive but whilst I’m able to observe the physical disability, there could be a cognitive disability which may not be obvious to me

author: A
sentence: So, for example there, it may be that her attention span is shorter - although I haven’t observed that

author: A
sentence: I’m just making it up now

author: A
sentence: So, her disability was brought on by a series of strokes but her brain seems to be functioning really well

author: A
sentence: Better than most I’d say

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Now, the gender diversity, why do you think that’s increased over time?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think that it’s becoming a societal issue that society is looking for greater involvement of women in all aspects of our society and that includes governance of corporations so that’s probably why

author: A
sentence: I think that there is a government push to do it

author: A
sentence: As to how exactly that is, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I do recall that many years ago - and I wasn’t on the board of this company

author: A
sentence: I was an employee but I dealt a lot with the company - we did have a lady on the board of the company and it was not clear to me nor anyone else, why she was there because it was - certainly, her contribution was not that of a competent director

author: A
sentence: So, she - I think - to be perfectly frank with you, I think that she was there, the token woman so that the board can say, “We’ve got one,” but I think those days have well and truly gone to be honest

author: Q
sentence: How long ago was that, [30D]?

author: A
sentence: I can tell you exactly

author: A
sentence: That would’ve been 1989

author: Q
sentence: ’89, did you say?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Wow, that’s a long time ago

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Well, a lot has changed since then, hasn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I’m an accountant

author: A
sentence: I think so, yes

author: A
sentence: I think that the world has changed as it should change and this is a personal perspective, I have the view that if you have a very highly skilled, competent group of people and it doesn’t matter whether they are girls, boys or whatever, you will always come to better decisions collectively

author: A
sentence: So, if you have smart ladies, put them on board

author: A
sentence: If you have smart guys, put them on board

author: A
sentence: If you have dumb ladies, keep them as far as you can as far as I’m concerned

author: Q
sentence: So, tell me, why in 1989 - that was before we had targets, wasn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So, there was not that sort of push

author: Q
sentence: Why was a woman put on the board who didn’t have the skills?  Where was the push?

author: A
sentence: Well, I have to tell you, I was not on the board of that company and it was a large, large, listed Australian bank

author: A
sentence: Obviously, those organisations wanted to show to the government how enlightened they are so whilst there were no targets, they were going to be corporate leaders so they got themselves a token woman

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it was a branding issue

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: They go, “Have we got a woman on the board?  Of course we do

author: A
sentence: There she is

author: Q
sentence: Great, thank you

author: Q
sentence: We’ll be revisiting this as we go through

author: Q
sentence: The next question I’d like to clarify is, let’s say I give you a scale of the importance that you would give to a board being diverse

author: Q
sentence: So, how important do you think it is to have a diverse board?  10 is it’s extremely important and one is not important at all

author: Q
sentence: Where would you rate it?

author: A
sentence: Well, I would rate it at 10 if you are looking at the skill diversity which I described earlier

author: A
sentence: If you are then saying gender diversity or ethnic diversity, I would score it much lower or lower than that because the overriding objective is to have a very, very highly competent board

author: A
sentence: So, competence - diversity in skill is absolutely paramount and how you get that diversity of skill really is of a secondary importance I think

author: A
sentence: How can I answer your question better?  Because you’re trying obviously to rate the [over talk] 00:15:13

author: Q
sentence: This is good

author: Q
sentence: This is really a way to generate discussion

author: Q
sentence: The sort of clarification that you’re making is what we want

author: Q
sentence: It’s not the number so this is good

author: Q
sentence: And the boards that you’ve been on or that you are on - first of all, for how many years have you been a board director?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Once again, it is a contextual thing because let’s say that I’m on a board of the Australian submarine corporation and I was their Chief Financial Officer in my previous life, right?  [Inaudible] 00:16:01 what did we make?  We made warships, submarines and destroyers

author: A
sentence: Well, quite frankly, whether I would have an ethnic or sex - gender diversity on there, probably far less important

author: A
sentence: If on the other hand for example, I am on the board of a house construction company, I think it would be absolutely vital

author: A
sentence: Why?  Because the people who interact with your clients, half of them are women and actually, women make a very important contribution into selection of houses and people - if you have a female or a bunch of females on the board, we can say, “Look guys

author: A
sentence: ”  When I go and look for a house, these are the features which I find important

author: A
sentence: So, then, you see - so, the diversity is important only in as far as it gets you a superior outcome over your competitor

author: A
sentence: For example - this might not - this might surprise you but do you know where it’s also very important to have diversity?  For motor vehicle companies because actually, it’s the females who make the majority of the motor car buying decisions, not the guy

author: A
sentence: So, [inaudible] 00:17:40 to understand what is it that that segment of the market looks for?  And target it and make sure they feel product development [inaudible] 00:17:49

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Upfront, you said one of the core skills was knowledge of the context for certain - like the political and social context of the industry

author: Q
sentence: When you were talking about the core skills, you said financial, legal and corporate governance and then you said depending on the business, marketing, knowledge of the context, the legal, political, social

author: Q
sentence: So, that knowledge of the context, it’s certain stakeholders like the political stakeholders, the regulatory stakeholders, the financial stakeholders or whatever

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: So, you mentioned consumers but it seems that going back to your earlier point, there’s also politics and regulators

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: It’s actually much more so for large organisations than small organisations but large organisations operate in an environment where they interact with governments

author: A
sentence: So, for example, let’s be very specific here [inaudible] 00:19:21 really an example, [Margot] 00:19:22 -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: A
sentence: If we were a - I don’t know what kind of company but I tell you what, I would be absolutely hot on the tracks of Julie Bishop to join my company and the board of my company

author: A
sentence: Why?  For example, if I was a construction company, if I was John Holland for example or [inaudible] 00:19:48, I really would want Julie Bishop to be there

author: A
sentence: Why?  Because she’s a seriously intelligent woman

author: A
sentence: She’s a lawyer and B, she knows the political lay of the land better than most people in this world

author: A
sentence: So, the context is very, very important but once again, it’s always in a context of how do I structure the board such that I have a competitive advantage over the other people in my industry?

author: Q
sentence: That’s nice

author: Q
sentence: That’s consistent with a couple of other interviewees that have come from the for-profit sector and the not-for-profit, instead of competitive advantage, I could probably put services to the community, delivery of -

author: A
sentence: I don’t think there is that much of a difference, [Margot] and I’ll tell you why

author: Q
sentence: Did you say there’s not much or there is?

author: A
sentence: I don’t think so and I’m just starting to think about it with you so we’re having a conversation

author: A
sentence: So, because you see, the descriptor ‘not-for-profit’ is complete and utter nonsense because not-for-profit organisations feel it’s bad to make profit

author: A
sentence: Well, I don’t believe so

author: A
sentence: I’m a chairman of Brain Injury SA and we try to be a financially stable, profitable company with one gigantic difference to - we don’t give our profits to the shareholders

author: A
sentence: We reinvest it all into the company to make a better contribution to the people who need our services and we can do it far better if we are financially stable, if we make profits, but only for the purpose of reinvestment for the benefit of our members, of our clients

author: A
sentence: 30 years

author: A
sentence: So, this issue of competitive advantage in the not-for-profit sector I think is as alive and well as it is in the commercial sector because for example, we are dealing with a whole bunch of - the introduction of NDIS

author: A
sentence: So, we can see that many of our competitors will go by the wayside because they have not prepared for it properly but also, we can see that a number of service providers will try to encroach onto the markets which we currently have and therefore, we need to be able to continue to deliver outstanding service to our clients to be able to compete and board leadership is vital

author: A
sentence: Therefore, why would you not have people with disability on your board?  Because they provide you with a perspective which an able-bodied person just couldn’t because you just can’t put yourself into the shoes of the other person adequately

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: I get it

author: Q
sentence: I see your - so, this imperative or ‘how do I structure the board for competitive advantage’ applies across for-profit and not-for-profit sectors

author: Q
sentence: It’s just the reason you’re doing it is a little different

author: Q
sentence: One is for service delivery to a community and the other is -

author: A
sentence: Well, is to make a profit

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, is to make the profit sustainably

author: A
sentence: I think so, [Margot], because quite frankly, if you fail as a profit-making entity, you’re gone and if you fail as a not-for-profit entity, you’re gone as well

author: A
sentence: So, the ability to survive is important in both instances

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: So, another person discussed how to draw - if you’re looking for characteristics of a diverse board, so you’ve got the people with the skills and the people are from diverse backgrounds, gender, culture or whatever, where do you draw the line?  You can’t have a million people on the board so you have to be selective

author: Q
sentence: What’s your criteria?  And she said it was about what is the strategic intent of the organisation and what’s it aiming to achieve and then what stakeholders do we need to engage with in order to do that?  And then, that -

author: A
sentence: Sorry, too many questions there, [Margot]

author: A
sentence: It’s a complex question you’re asking me

author: A
sentence: So, [over talk] 00:25:24 if you would please

author: A
sentence: So, start again

author: A
sentence: Ask the question but do it maybe in parts

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, good point

author: Q
sentence: I’m just wondering - okay, you’ve talked about how do I structure the board for competitive advantage and in the not-for-profit sector, you’ve told me how it differs to the for-profit in purpose

author: Q
sentence: How do you select members so that you don’t have groupthink or good decision making?

author: A
sentence: Well, obviously for me, it always starts with a skills matrix

author: A
sentence: So, what skills do I need to be able to make effective decisions and lead the organisation effectively?  So, that’s number one and then you look for specialist skills which would be beneficial to furthering your competitiveness in whatever industry you’re in

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure that it actually answered your question

author: A
sentence: Now, [Margot], could I just make a suggestion to you please?

author: Q
sentence: Wow, okay

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got a good span to reflect on

author: Q
sentence: That will be really valuable, thank you

author: Q
sentence: How many do you currently sit on?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: A
sentence: I need to go and jump in my car and drive to my next appointment, which is about – [I don’t know how] [inaudible] 00:27:02 with this interview [inaudible] 00:27:04 so [inaudible] 00:27:07 just jump in my car and we can chat as I go?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Not a problem

author: A
sentence: Hang on

author: A
sentence: So, keep going

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: A
sentence: I don’t think I’ve answered your question because your question was very much in line of how do you go about selecting a board and I said there’s a skills matrix and then from the skills matrix, you draw people in

author: A
sentence: It’s important to have boards which are a good size and that doesn’t mean really gigantic boards because you don’t want - sorry, just a door has been opened

author: Q
sentence: That’s okay, I can hear

author: A
sentence: It’s just not an issue of having a debating society kind of thing

author: A
sentence: One thing which is important when you’re selecting a board member, if you are looking for example, for a key skill, say, a legal skill and you are in a not-for-profit which requires disability experience, you can get a lawyer who actually fits both things and you’re on a winner because you don’t want to have a 15-member strong board

author: A
sentence: You want to have six members on board

author: A
sentence: That’s why you always try to select people who fit as many criteria that are important to you as possible

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, do you see - how do you understand board diversity?  What does it mean to you?  I think we should clarify that now

author: Q
sentence: You’ve mentioned gender

author: A
sentence: Well, the diversity means diversity of skill

author: A
sentence: That’s, as I tell you, my [inaudible] 00:29:32

author: A
sentence: It could also mean gender diversity, not just an all-boys club

author: A
sentence: Also, it can mean an ethnic diversity

author: A
sentence: Five

author: Q
sentence: What sort of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Ethnic diversity, cultural diversity

author: A
sentence: So, they are the - it can also mean diversity in abled and disabled persons across various factors

author: A
sentence: That’s how I understand it

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Some people talk about approaches to problem-solving, different approaches to problem-solving or cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that’s important?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, very, because you see, we all make decisions in very different ways, and we see problems from different perspectives

author: A
sentence: If you just stack the board with people whose cognitive processes are very similar, you will be totally sub optimising the board

author: A
sentence: The old saying that ‘it’s amazing how many problems look like a nail when the only tool you have is a hammer’ becomes absolutely crystal clear

author: A
sentence: So, it is important to have a board which can think in different ways about an issue and you will find that invariably, that kind of process will lead to far richer decision making and better decision making, unquestionably actually

author: A
sentence: I’ve experienced it many times both as an executive but also a number of times as a board member that you really just – but there’s one thing actually, [Margot], which I think is absolutely important for boards, is that boards must have - a successful board member, be it any board member whether it’s - whatever the diversity of a board member is, it must have a collegiate mindset

author: A
sentence: They must be able to and want to work in a collegiate manner with the other board members because then, you actually really unleash a different thinking about the problem

author: A
sentence: You might see problems and you think, ‘The solution is that,’ and then somebody says, “Or is it?  Why don’t we have a look at it from this perspective?” and then you might think, ‘Actually, yeah

author: A
sentence: Why don’t we look at it from that perspective?’ it will become very clear that there is another perspective over and above what you have immediately thought of

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Now, how would you cultivate a board that has this collegiate mindset?

author: A
sentence: It’s not easy and [inaudible] 00:33:15 board meeting that I attended last month, May, it really - there was a very distinct lack of collegiality about the way we were treating each other and fortunately, one of the board members just said, “Look, I’m fed up with this

author: A
sentence: I’m not putting up with it

author: A
sentence: I want to work with you very differently,” and actually, she put it on as a discussion item and said, “I think that you and you,” and pointed to two directors, “I think that you’re not getting on very well and your relationship is influencing the way I work on the board and I suspect it’s also influencing how others work on the board

author: A
sentence: She was absolutely right and it actually was quite - it actually cleared a lot of the issues

author: A
sentence: I think that the two individuals had agendas

author: A
sentence: It’s a good idea to confront the people and really - in a not very politically correct way - bang their heads together and say, “Listen guys or girls, this isn’t working,” and incidentally, this was the board where I’m the only guy

author: A
sentence: The other board members were ladies so they weren’t wilting lilies in any sense

author: A
sentence: [Inaudible] 00:34:52 called them out and said, “Look, you and you, you’re not behaving well and I’m not having this so let’s sort ourselves out

author: A
sentence: ”  So, I think that personally, that a direct approach is best

author: Q
sentence: So, that conflict that emerged, you said it was agendas, they had different agendas, was that to do with different allegiances or different ways of thinking?  What was the root cause of the conflict between these two people?

author: Q
sentence: And what kind of boards are these?

author: A
sentence: Ambition

author: Q
sentence: Oh, it was the ego, okay

author: Q
sentence: Power game

author: A
sentence: It was actually put on the table and then all of a sudden it came out, “Well, you’ve made the following promises to me that if I do this, you’d do that,” and my contribution was, “I don’t give a damn who made what contribution and what promises to whom because actually, the decision will not be made by what promises were made

author: A
sentence: The decision will be made by the board

author: A
sentence: So, if you were foolish enough to make those promises and you were foolish enough to believe them, then you’re both wrong

author: A
sentence: ”  I think it actually was quite an atmosphere clearing discussion to be honest

author: Q
sentence: So, did it effectively set new ground rules for the board?

author: A
sentence: Well, hopefully but you will find that things like this, [Margot], it’s literally like learning to ride a bicycle

author: A
sentence: I don’t know, have you ridden a bicycle in your life?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Okay, well you might remember that when you were learning to ride a bicycle that you were extremely wobbly and you probably fell off a few times and you had to get back on and keep going

author: A
sentence: So, these things I find, we are still at the wobbly stage and we will probably redress the bad behaviour and then it must be made very clear to everything that, “No, we are going back to the bad old ways

author: A
sentence: We are not going there

author: A
sentence: We’re not doing this

author: A
sentence: This is the right path to go

author: A
sentence: ”  You have to hit it hard and point our very publicly, “This is not the way we are going to behave in this environment and the way to go forward is like this and we fully expect you and you to play by the rules

author: Q
sentence: And the rules are about what the board’s purpose is, what the board is about, not what their personal agenda is

author: Q
sentence: Is that the -

author: A
sentence: Spot on, 100% correct

author: A
sentence: No hidden agendas, no little sidebars that somebody whispers into someone’s ears and, “Well, she promised me that,” and, “Okay, you may have been foolish enough to promise and you may have been even more foolish to believe it but none of it matters

author: Q
sentence: So, this rule changing, this clarification of the board’s purpose and the way it runs, works, that will facilitate a diversity because it will allow for the inclusion of voices as long as they are aligned with the purpose of the board

author: Q
sentence: So, it separates out your agenda from - you bring your different views and that’s all about the purpose of the board and the problem solving for the board

author: Q
sentence: Is that -

author: Q
sentence: Have you any questions about the research before we start?

author: A
sentence: I guess governance or law is my training

author: A
sentence: I’m a lawyer by background but I’ve spent 12 years in investment in ESG

author: A
sentence: Again that’s part of that I think tick the box or the narrow set of considerations to that broader –

author: Q
sentence: Culminating in a dialogue between you and the boards, partnering to facilitate improved performance and sustainable performance

author: Q
sentence: That’s a really interesting model

author: Q
sentence: I’m starting to get a feel for it

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Do you think you would change that importance rating in any particular context or situation, perhaps high risk, high uncertainty?

author: A
sentence: To the earlier point about, you don’t I guess judge boards and organisations by, is there a lawyer, an accountant, a basic template

author: A
sentence: It’s similar for diversity

author: A
sentence: Taking the example of geographic diversity, it’s just simply impossible to have every geography that BHP is a part of, represented on its board, sort of United Nations type thing

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: There’s always that or for the Telstra board, should every Telstra customer have customer representation when you have millions of them? I think you can’t go down that path but I think that broader – diversity of skills, experience, gender, all of those paths I think are relevant across and in challenging times it may be hard to get to your point I think or when the question is –

author: Q
sentence: The risk and uncertainty, whether there are some times when diversity is not important

author: A
sentence: I think in any case it’s not diversity for diversity’s sake

author: A
sentence: As long as you have the relevant people skills that’s still important but it’s not for the sake of diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s actually –

author: Q
sentence: For groupthink, to avoid groupthink

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: I guess taking some diversity out of the equation but even that opportunity for challenge among directors

author: A
sentence: Obviously collegiate decision-making bodies but you want the space where people can challenge ideas

author: A
sentence: Even in difficult circumstances I think a lot of boards would to like to ask, is it a really important thing to have? That you obviously make decisions as a group and you need that cabinet solidarity, absolutely but as things are being tested or even in those trying times it’s valuable to have that

author: Q
sentence: I had one director say that’s where you most need it

author: Q
sentence: So is that commercial law?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: That’s very true

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: Do you want to flesh out what board diversity means to you or we’ll leave it with what you’ve said already?

author: A
sentence: I think we’ve covered a lot of it

author: A
sentence: I also think it will evolve over time as well and there are particular challenges for Australian boards in that area about – everyone says we don’t want technology experience

author: A
sentence: The person who’s at the forefront of Silicon Valley, the token 30-year-old billionaire, start-up person, do they want to come back for 12 long drawn-out board meetings in Australia for a nonexecutive director salary? Or even, would they be the technical boffin but what understanding of the accounts or all those other hugely important aspects of being a director would they bring? Because you can’t just be a subject matter expert, you actually need a commercial overview

author: A
sentence: I think that’s a big challenge

author: A
sentence: Finding the right directors, expanding the talent pool are all major concerns or challenges for Australian boards so certainly haven’t –

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed some start-up, people from start-ups in the IT area and they’re amazing

author: Q
sentence: They’re really highly energised but a common thread across the three I interviewed is that they really wanted to be in a board where they could learn

author: Q
sentence: They’ll only go where they feel they’re learning so the culture of the board was really important to them

author: Q
sentence: If they found themselves in a really conservative, where there wasn’t the dialogue and [unclear] 00:31:09, they would not like it

author: A
sentence: I actually was in a conference in San Francisco speaking on Australian governance trends and so on and in one of the other panels there was somebody who had been doing a lot of work for boards in Silicon Valley

author: A
sentence: The interesting part was they had all these IPOs where they would have the founder retains a stake and there’s dual class shares so they can never be moved basically

author: A
sentence: He was the headhunter for boards and said, “Find us a nonexecutive director

author: A
sentence: ” A lot of nonexecutive directors will say, “I don’t want to be part of that board because there’s effectively no power and the founder is so entrenched within the – they’re not interested in challenge or an outside voice or oversight

author: A
sentence: They just want to add names

author: A
sentence: ” I think that can be a challenge here

author: A
sentence: I think the other side as well to all governance issues like that is being fit for purpose so for very small companies, size, scope of the board is different

author: A
sentence: It’s smaller

author: A
sentence: The role of directors can be quite challenging too because in those small companies often they’re asked to roll up their sleeves or we’re 20 people in the organisation, whereas if you’re on the board of BHP you have multiday board meetings

author: A
sentence: You have a huge secretariat

author: A
sentence: You have experts and support staff and independent advisers untapped whereas some of those smaller ones –

author: Q
sentence: It’s like a three-hour meeting, that’s not a really –

author: A
sentence: That’s right or how do we – you’re actually almost tackling the issues along with them and trying to –

author: Q
sentence: More operational as well

author: A
sentence: You may be learning but you’re there and a lot of people are learning from you

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I did an LLM actually focusing on commercial law whilst at ACSI but proudly I’ve never practiced it, proudly

author: Q
sentence: But you don’t tend to deal with that kind of organisations?

author: A
sentence: ASX 300 companies so some of the smaller ones, very different to the BHP board or the some of the global boards

author: Q
sentence: It says does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others to you?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s really hard

author: A
sentence: I mean a bit like the question of independence and somebody’s independence of mind, it’s really hard to assess

author: A
sentence: I think gender has been a really important issue for ACSI and many investors because it’s inherently observable

author: A
sentence: It’s such a huge pool of talented candidates

author: A
sentence: If we think I’m sure of your students in the university or other people you think smart people in the population are spread across and suddenly 50% of that talent pool of the really smart best minds are off the table, already you have that – there’s a name for it that they use, sort of stupidity curve

author: A
sentence: You’re in the stupidity curve if you’re – I think they use it in the US but clearly 50% of the population being off the table

author: A
sentence: All of those other factors are important

author: A
sentence: I guess it depends on your definition

author: A
sentence: I think things like industry experience, knowledge and so on, that’s the nonnegotiable of all boards

author: A
sentence: NAB had a board with had no banking experience in the very early 2000s and we saw how that played out at the time

author: A
sentence: Fairfax had the same with media

author: A
sentence: That kind of core industry experience is obviously critical

author: A
sentence: I think those others, it’s as they are relevant depending on where the company’s operations are

author: Q
sentence: Their strategies at the time

author: A
sentence: Strategies

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive diversity, I should mention the term

author: Q
sentence: What do you think about that and how does it connect with the idea of groupthink that you were talking about?

author: A
sentence: I guess I was trying to get to that point with that independence of mind or cognitive diversity so I think obviously critical

author: A
sentence: From the outside looking in as investors actually it’s extremely hard and I’m sure as a researcher it’s extremely hard to get a sense of it

author: A
sentence: I guess you’d know it when you see it in a way and boards will often talk about that

author: A
sentence: That’s where I think some of backgrounds and experience and other parts matter because that gives you some of that –

author: Q
sentence: A different way of seeing things and problem solving

author: Q
sentence: Careful, I have [unclear] 00:01:08

author: A
sentence: Yeah, not always but it can

author: A
sentence: We had a speaker, a senior company director, very experienced

author: A
sentence: She was in the AICD board and I remember her saying that [unclear] 00:36:30 White Anglo-Saxon Protestant or the male, pale and stale issue but we can then become male, female, pale and stale if we don’t look at these other factors

author: Q
sentence: Keep moving on

author: A
sentence: I think the cognitive element is partly there as well

author: A
sentence: One chairman expressed to me once

author: A
sentence: He said that actually with things like board renewal and age and refreshment and so on, actually you’re having someone with a different background or perspective

author: A
sentence: They may come in and ask the dumb question but actually the rest of the board often think, yes, with a fresh set of eyes that’s he right thing to be asking whereas he said that if you’ve been on a board for 10 years it could be more of a challenge to actually ask that question because you think, we’ve covered it somewhere else or I should know this or I’m pretty sure we’ve dealt with that issue

author: A
sentence: But someone new to the place can actually say, “Explain to me why

author: A
sentence: ” You’re not as closed perhaps or invested that you can ask some of those questions as you walk in

author: Q
sentence: I think with research you can read theory and whatever but if you talk to people in the field they will tell you something and it’s fresh and it will make you think about how you’ve understood it

author: Q
sentence: It’s like, you’re on the board

author: Q
sentence: You understand the organisation strategy

author: Q
sentence: Someone new comes and they ask a question and it makes you rethink

author: A
sentence: Yeah, why do we it this way? Can you just explain to me? That’s right

author: A
sentence: I think that’s one of those great benefits of that cognitive diversity as well

author: Q
sentence: It could help to affirm or to create an awareness of a new opportunity you haven’t thought about

author: A
sentence: I’m sure a lot of the directors you’d speak to would talk to this, that actually having boards create that space where cognitive diversity is valued as well and the same with gender diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s like, that’s the two women weighing in on that issue or that’s the black-hatted thinker over there

author: A
sentence: Making sure every voice is brought in

author: A
sentence: Clearly against collegiate and so on but it’s actually partly having the space where those things are actually valued and taken on the board

author: Q
sentence: A number of interviewees, they took me here to the word of the inclusion

author: Q
sentence: Is the board inclusive and then how does it do that? This I think is what you’re alluding to, creating the space, that ability of some boards to really cash in on the diversity around the table by creating this space for dialogue

author: A
sentence: Even I think from the outside looking in or maybe boards in the past did this where it was sort of, we have an audit matter

author: A
sentence: Let’s ask the former accountant on the board to [unclear] 00:39:46 on that and then we’ll move to the next mining issue and the miner will talk

author: A
sentence: Actually, it’s having everyone engage on every issue which gives you that benefit, rather than just rely on one person for that

author: Q
sentence: Like reporting

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: The woman I interviewed this morning, she referred to it

author: Q
sentence: She’s a chair of this one and she says all those reports, that’s just dealt with, that’s just background

author: Q
sentence: What are we doing with them is the focus of the discussion and that’s always a discussion

author: A
sentence: Some big boards have actually set a four-page maximum board papers for their –

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: There’s a couple out there I know that have – again I think over time that push to say shorten the packs

author: A
sentence: They might have a committee or other offline meetings

author: Q
sentence: To deal with stuff

author: A
sentence: If it can’t be summarised or distilled otherwise, you’re just filling up pages for the sake of it

author: Q
sentence: Sharing information rather than using it to make decisions

author: A
sentence: Yeah, or to monitor on other things

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting

author: Q
sentence: We’d like to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: We’ve talked about that

author: Q
sentence: You’re an institutional investor I guess, you shaped that

author: Q
sentence: Your influence, what industries? Only super?

author: A
sentence: Part of it as well is sometimes people have been investors in their professional life

author: A
sentence: When you engage with them, I’ll actually say here’s how this stakeholder would want us to manage their capital or a superfund wants this type of return for its members

author: A
sentence: That’s important to us and sometimes that –

author: Q
sentence: Putting the hat of the consumer on so to speak

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: That’s one side I guess about this increasing engagement

author: A
sentence: We see it as a positive because actually those boards get more outside voices or perceptions of their organisation

author: Q
sentence: The ones with?

author: A
sentence: The ones who would go out and engage with investors and others and media and actually go to bank branches or spend more time in their organisations and connect with management beyond the CEO

author: A
sentence: They actually I think get a richer view

author: A
sentence: There was one director I remember talking about, the board should be able to smell the smoke coming under the door, was his example and 20 years ago boards would almost be the last to find out about a regulatory issue or issue with customers or other things in the company whereas now –

author: Q
sentence: They should be on the radar

author: A
sentence: The Royal Commission is maybe one example but I guess the issue with customers and other things, you would think there are all sorts of ways to get that perspective or to look at those issues because – I understand it’s a challenge in bigger organisations but getting feedback from external parties or at least getting an understanding of the perception of the company from different views that actually the boards see that as hugely valuable

author: A
sentence: Actually investors see it as valuable because they get a sense of who are the boards appointing and what’s their view on strategy and how does it align –

author: Q
sentence: With our view of what’s a good investment opportunity for us

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: It’s been quite rich on both sides I think

author: Q
sentence: I’m seeing then an image of the organisation as being very much part of its community, engaging, open and the board being therefore, aware of the regulatory and the consumer and other stakeholder interest groups

author: Q
sentence: Strategy is ongoing and responsive or whatever

author: A
sentence: Yes, super and I guess investments

author: A
sentence: I think some of the biggest risks previously with some of those companies where the CEO would manage all communication with the board and deliver the papers or whatever else and be the one point of interaction, how the culture of those places ran, no one was aware or they couldn’t speak to other people in management, or if they did the CEO was there, or it was scripted, and all those other parts

author: A
sentence: Directors have shared a lot of those types of experiences, and say, then you’re not really getting a full picture whereas many of the executive teams of today actually encourage that, be it within the board meeting or elsewhere to interact with different people in the business, go a few layers down, again do site visits in other parts on an ongoing basis to get that sense of the organisation

author: Q
sentence: Transparency between the board and its management

author: Q
sentence: It’s all one

author: A
sentence: The values and all of those things as well because otherwise, you sign off on a great-looking policy on Collins Street about safety or whatever it is but then if the people in the organisation don’t know about it or care about it what good is it?

author: Q
sentence: No and they’re hiding their mistakes

author: A

sentence: We can’t speak up here

author: Q

author: A
sentence: Diversity is not a silver bullet for these things but I think it’s –

author: Q
sentence: I wonder how it connects

sentence: I feel like I’m going in so many tangents

author: Q

author: Q
sentence: Super, like self-managed superfunds?

author: A
sentence: I think that greater interest in engaging internal and external stakeholders, diversity is partly is a function of that

author: A
sentence: If you see yourself as there on behalf of shareholders and more about the company and sitting above the culture and strategy and overseeing the management team, the company shareholders, its customers, employees, all these people are critical to that, its interaction with governments

author: A
sentence: Anyway, most good directors really see that quite strongly

author: Q
sentence: Interactions with multiple stakeholders is another form of diversity because you have their views then you bring to the table
