author: Q
sentence: What do you see is the main barriers to building diversity on Australian boards and how do they work?

author: A
sentence: I think all sorts of things

author: A
sentence: I think you have an extremely narrow or you have had still a relatively narrow pool of directors and part of that is relationship-driven so someone had to be hiring for a role

author: A
sentence: I guess someone you know is lower risk than someone you don’t or can you get a referral from a colleague and so on

author: A
sentence: I think that’s the challenge

author: Q
sentence: When you say narrow do you mean not many or they’re not diverse?

author: A
sentence: Both

author: A
sentence: I think both and also I think boards can fall into the trap of hiring in their own image

author: A
sentence: I’m a former CEO of this company

author: A
sentence: I’ll appoint the next, whoever is in my role prior to that or who’s the next head of KPMG after the one that’s just retired

author: A
sentence: I think hiring in their own image has been a big issue

author: A
sentence: People bag the search firms a lot or as contributing to that narrowness but I think the other thing we hear is that chairs and nomination committees actually want to find people outside the pool or add a new skill

author: A
sentence: If they get served up the same names they can actually ask for more and they’ve challenged that and changed that a bit

author: A
sentence: You see some very large companies who do appoint people that aren’t sitting on other ASX 200 boards

author: A
sentence: They just go outside the usual suspects

author: Q
sentence: Your organisation would be comfortable with that?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Some of our members, we call them asset owners

author: A
sentence: IFM investors are a member because they owned not-for-profit funds and we had the New South Wales Treasury Corp and other similar institutions

author: A
sentence: They’re not superfunds per se

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I think the other side is sometimes boards say, “He or she is on these other three companies

author: A
sentence: That must be fine

author: A
sentence: ” That doesn’t tell you that much about what they’ll add to your business

author: Q
sentence: They’re less likely to threaten the decision making processes or something, disrupt it but how well will they contribute?

author: A
sentence: I guess there is that natural challenge of I guess the time commitment of boards, the level of knowledge and liability and other requirements

author: A
sentence: If you can’t understand the accounts or other things I think that’s pretty tough to be a director, no matter what your sort of background

author: A
sentence: Interesting, I mean clearly former CEOs of listed companies and others or executives at the front of the queue would be overrepresented in the pool

author: A
sentence: Questions about other backgrounds being brought in

author: A
sentence: If you run a private company or a university or a hospital or something like that, does that qualify?

author: Q
sentence: Help you with BHP

author: A
sentence: I think it could in all sorts of places but does it actually get you in on to the radar? Again, we had a conversation the other night at the 30% Club about that

author: A
sentence: Does it even –

author: Q
sentence: Seem relevant

author: A
sentence: Yeah, or you get into the [unclear] 00:51:06 list, probably not

author: A
sentence: To the relationship side, I mean clearly and it was explored the other night

author: A
sentence: There wasn’t a certain element and you saw it with the AICD’s mentoring program when it was first run

author: A
sentence: Effectively they found hugely-qualified women so people who run international law firms or have been executives of all these other things then paired them up with an existing male chair in the ASX 100

author: A
sentence: Often all those male chairs would do – somebody said this to us

author: A
sentence: It was like, “She didn’t need my help” but the help was I’ll introduce you to Egon Zehnder and then vouch for you as, here’s this really smart board candidate

author: A
sentence: Here’s her background, over to you and then that vouching process actually made a difference

author: A
sentence: I think to that world of relationships, and again it came out the other night in the conversation they would hear of a thousand coffees

author: A
sentence: I think that is still alive and well, interconnections with the board

author: A
sentence: I’m chair here and you sit on this board

author: A
sentence: You’re chair there and I’ll – those things are still very much alive and well

author: Q
sentence: How it works

author: A
sentence: People are vouched for or they have a name and often want somebody as one ASX 100 board [unclear] 00:52:29 because it’s almost like you’re anointed now to the [unclear] 00:52:34

author: Q
sentence: But they’re not –

author: Q
sentence: The cluster effect

author: Q
sentence: This is the same as five years ago?

author: A
sentence: I think it is broadening over time but using the lens of gender diversity I think it also demonstrates it as well, particularly with the initial push around this or 30% was first introduced

author: A
sentence: You’d have boards looking narrowly and saying, who are that small group of highly-qualified women that are now the 10% of directors? So Catherine Livingstone or all of these hugely-qualified people, can I just now invite them to their 5th or 6th or 7th board seat?  It showed that there’s a narrow pool and it was referring back to itself

author: A
sentence: Whereas our reaction or our response to many boards was, there are all these other qualified candidates

author: A
sentence: You actually just need to look

author: A
sentence: You need to have some tokenism for a couple of companies

author: A
sentence: I know headhunters who are called and said, “Can you find two women candidates for our board?” They said, “What are the criteria?” and they said, “It doesn’t matter

author: Q
sentence: That’s insulting

author: A
sentence: Yeah and it was like, you should think of some because that’s pretty – sort of hang up the phone there and we’ll talk again

author: A
sentence: I think that’s largely gone and I think that was in that early time of, geez, we’ve never done anything on this

author: A
sentence: Quick, let’s try and change or improve so we’ll invited Catherine Livingstone or we’ll do that

author: A
sentence: As we all know Catherine was a successful CEO of Cochlear, so ASX 50 company, that standard background

author: A
sentence: But going beyond I think is the challenge but people seem to be doing more often now

author: Q
sentence: The female network is pretty strong

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed a couple of pretty top female board members who are on a number of boards and there’s a whole group of enrichment

author: Q
sentence: There’s a whole group of women who are on boards that meet once a quarter or something

author: A
sentence: Again it’s that shared knowledge

author: A
sentence: It’s becoming more and more common I think with nonexecutives generally

author: A
sentence: I think the annoying part of us – Graeme Samuel was out saying there’s this club of – if anything there might be a director’s club or a narrow pool but I think that’s male and female, particularly in a situation where I think about 10% of chairs in the ASX 200 are women

author: A
sentence: The idea that women were somehow controlling the supply of directors to boards or this narrow niche, I just have not seen that and it’s quite bizarre because it’s still that 70/30 split the other way

author: A
sentence: I think the challenge, again male and female, kind of expanding that pool over time so people are really busy or sitting across boards

author: A
sentence: It’s actually, who are the other people that can –

author: Q
sentence: Would you do anything to help build the pool of women or build diversity?

author: A
sentence: We’re really interested in that area

author: Q
sentence: What do you do?

author: A
sentence: We’ve done things to influence individual companies including, we’ve had policies to fight against all-male boards in the ASX 200 because we’ve had years of engagement so that has been hugely beneficial particularly inviting people

author: A
sentence: When we started there were 52 zeros and now there are four so three years later

author: A
sentence: No, not all

author: A
sentence: I’m aware of the other research done in this space, and it’s great, sort of more focused

author: A
sentence: I think we met briefly at the 30% Club party the other night

author: A
sentence: We just do asset owners

author: Q
sentence: You’re doing well

author: A
sentence: It actually does change that and that has increased the pool but I think doing more work on one of the blocks

author: A
sentence: Is it the role of the search firm? Is it nomination committees? Is it backgrounds? Is it the pipeline? We haven’t bought too hugely into the director pipeline

author: A
sentence: I think long term it’s absolutely critical and the representation of women and management in companies is critical

author: A
sentence: But particularly in the early days if I think about the ASX 200 and its goal of around 30%, we’re talking about a pool of 1,200 people and the sorts of numbers and so on

author: A
sentence: There was one point in time people were saying, “There’s no talent pool” and you think this is 50 people or 50 appointments that need to be made to really make a huge difference

author: A
sentence: I’m pretty sure there’s 50 people –

author: Q
sentence: Incredible women up there

author: A
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: I think too much can be made of that

author: A
sentence: We won’t find a list of company, ex-CEOs and it’s like, that’s true but you’ll actually need financial experts

author: A
sentence: You’ll need all of these other backgrounds on the board

author: A
sentence: To that point, as you say, mining is way behind and there are no women in mining and so on

author: A
sentence: I think that’s not true from the point being made

author: A
sentence: But the other thing was healthcare

author: A
sentence: It was one of the biggest laggards

author: Q
sentence: I know

author: A
sentence: You’d say, there are no women in healthcare

author: A
sentence: Predominantly female actually right through the chain to not just –

author: Q
sentence: Until the exec

author: A
sentence: Even the exec, it depends on the company, and middle management, there has been definitely a glass ceiling in a couple of them

author: A
sentence: But females actually at senior levels, actually they are more diverse, particularly compared to mining and others are way more

author: A
sentence: But it was just getting on to the board then of Ramsay Health Care or –

author: Q
sentence: Healthscope

author: A
sentence: Yeah, those was more of a challenge at the time

author: Q
sentence: Asset owners, beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Interesting, isn’t it? It’s come down a bit which is a bit disappointing

author: Q
sentence: Probably one of those females who are on a lot of boards has retired or something

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I think it will continue

author: Q
sentence: It’s the final question now

author: Q
sentence: Looking 10 years into the future how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards and why do you think this would be good?

author: A
sentence: I think again that richer – in a way it’s to achieve that cognitive diversity to effectively have better decision making or boards that more reflect – I think the companies that they oversee or the industries they’re a part of, I think that’s a really important aspect, not only for their workforce but more broadly

author: A
sentence: If you have a narrow set of backgrounds on a board you –

author: Q
sentence: You’re going to miss all this

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: I think boards that can do that is important

author: A
sentence: We’ve seen small examples over time but I think for that to become more commonplace

author: A
sentence: We have boards of global companies where everybody is based in Melbourne, because that’s the circle or the narrow look around participants, and I think for those boards you [unclear] 01:00:19 for 10 years and say, “You should actually have representation from some of the geographies you’re a part of or more relevant backgrounds

author: A
sentence: ” A much expanded director pool I think would be really beneficial too

author: Q
sentence: And the same, do you think – digital technology allows us to, we can be in this room and we could be speaking to people anywhere, so board meetings could be in a virtual space

author: Q
sentence: Not just the inclusivity, those communication skills or whatever but we’ve got different communication technologies

author: Q
sentence: Could that -

author: A
sentence: I think that is being used by quite a few because one other challenge is just the role of boards in the US markets, four meetings a year, a lovely lunch and then sign off the accounts and you’re done

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: A
sentence: That has been the background whereas here, far more involved in a major company in terms of the number of meetings you have to be in person, the committees, all of those other things

author: A
sentence: I think that will evolve

author: A
sentence: I guess in 10 years you would hope we have a far better sense of actually what makes boards tick

author: A
sentence: I mean I’ve talked about narrowly the gender diversity on boards and Credit Suisse’s work which showed that correlation

author: A
sentence: I guess more of a sense of the value of that diversity I think within those boards

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if we’ll be able to quantitatively prove every factor and its influence but certainly a better sense of –

author: A
sentence: Some of our members are offshore too so we have members in the UK, Netherlands and US

author: Q
sentence: That works

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right and more case studies of really high-performing companies and boards and also, what about the narrow companies or the values? What prompted those? How did chair-CEO relationships or narrow thinking on the board contribute to those? It’s certainly been a hallmark I think in some of the issues in the past but I think in 10 years hopefully we’d have a much better indicator of those

author: Q
sentence: Of that dynamic, what contributed to it and [unclear] 01:02:52

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think an important catalyst over recent years too is just a better understanding from investors of the boards they appoint

author: A
sentence: I think we’ll see that change and an increase in engagement and probably an increase – or we’ve seen this with large companies where investors actually meet the entire board in various forms because often it’s just the chair who will go out or the remuneration committee chair

author: A
sentence: We’re going to change remuneration

author: A
sentence: Let’s do a road show

author: A
sentence: I think that’s evolving as well

author: A
sentence: So it’s interesting, the changes, people from names on a page to here are the people we’re asked to elect and so on

author: A
sentence: One thing ACSI’s floated recently in their policy area, one on gender, the 40/40/20 goal is there on gender

author: A
sentence: The other is annual director elections and one of the reasons we’ve put for that is that actually in the UK where they’ve had annual election for eight years, it’s changed some of the dynamic there where if there are concerns over individual directors or lack of engagement or issues with financial reporting or whatever they may be, actually directors are voted on annually so there’s more of a feedback mechanism

author: A
sentence: In Australia, the average voting for ASX 200 directors are 96%

author: A
sentence: There are some anomalies

author: A
sentence: So you have two of the AMP board voted off the board last year by a majority of investors but those are rare occurrences

author: A
sentence: It’s something where potentially more accountability via the vote over time as they have in the UK

author: A
sentence: That’s one of our focus areas

author: A
sentence: But the other side is with annual elections it’s actually been an important step for a lot of boards in their own self-evaluation because here, you have the three-year election cycle so we know it’s very hard to remove a board member

author: A
sentence: It basically cannot be done unless they resign

author: A
sentence: Often boards may really evaluate somebody’s performance when they’re up for election in front of shareholders and that happens on a three-year cycle

author: A
sentence: There’s often a feeling, I have three three-year cycles

author: A
sentence: I can serve 10 years

author: A
sentence: Is this comfortable? Potentially or in some companies whereas in the UK, the feedback we’ve had from boards and investors over there is the annual cycle makes it that a bit more, the review more significant so actually each year you’re assessing the board’s performance

author: A
sentence: You’re doing the 360 where you’re thinking how is everyone adding value and so on, rather than waiting three years until an individual –

author: Q
sentence: Can we change that here?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: It can be changed

author: A
sentence: Over there it’s the effect – it’s a bit like the corporate governance principles over there

author: A
sentence: It’s a voluntary adoption around annual elections and basically the FTSE, almost every company in the FTSE 250 have annual elections

author: A
sentence: It hasn’t made boards more short term or hasn’t been spilling boards willy-nilly but it certainly has tightened up that accountability side

author: Q
sentence: That’s something that could be done as a regulatory thing but once again, industry, it’s not government

author: Q
sentence: Is there anything that government can do or is it hands off?

author: A
sentence: That may be influenced by government in Australia because while the ASX is obviously not a function of –

author: Q
sentence: This research is focused on Australia so any questions I ask will be focused on the influence

author: Q
sentence: The first question is how does your organisation influence Australian boards?

author: Q
sentence: Government

author: A
sentence: Yeah, government

author: A
sentence: I mean one thing that’s sometimes discussed is director’s duty

author: A
sentence: Does it need to be more broadly cast as it is in the UK to get that more well-rounded?

author: Q
sentence: That’s in the corporations? What does that mean?

author: A
sentence: Over there the companies actually say, “You have duties to the company but you should have due regard to the long-term impacts of a decision, its impact on employees, its impact on the environment” and spell out the considerations

author: Q
sentence: All the stakeholders

author: A
sentence: There have been no test cases as to you didn’t do due regard to x, y or z whereas here it’s best interest of the company, duty of care, skill and diligence

author: A
sentence: I think the argument is really or that a lot of Australian directors say as well, we do take that into consideration

author: A
sentence: It’s a bit like the current debate around climate change and the Hartley opinion

author: A
sentence: This is a foreseeable risk therefore it’s within a director’s standard duty

author: A
sentence: I think that will evolve too

author: A
sentence: It doesn’t go directly to diversity but it’s clearly one of the things that do matter

author: Q
sentence: That was great

author: Q
sentence: You’ve brought lots of different things

author: A
sentence: If there’s anything that occurs after or we missed or whatever else, feel free to pick up the phone

author: A
sentence: I guess to the background I’m talking about, ACSI was founded in 2001

author: A
sentence: We’re an association working for those superannuation fund and asset owner members

author: A
sentence: The reason that the organisation was set up is as funds became larger and larger investors, particularly in western companies, they came to realise that the kind of governance or ESG risk in those companies were shared across a group

author: A
sentence: If you take a long-term investor perspective, you may be invested in BHP or CBH today, you’ll be invested in 10, in 20, in 30 years’ time so sort of governance and other issues in those companies is really relevant

author: A
sentence: At the time or shortly after we had the cases, for instance HIH –

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: It’s right at that time

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: I think all of those things about, what questions are we asking the companies we are investing in or the regulators and so on within markets? Are we simply just putting our money out and hoping for the best or can we engage influence and so on? So ACSI was formed and really I think our core function is to do three things

author: A
sentence: One is ESG research to –

author: Q
sentence: ESG?

author: A
sentence: Environmental, social and corporate governance

author: A
sentence: Sorry, many, many acronyms

author: Q
sentence: It’s good

author: Q
sentence: I didn’t –

author: A
sentence: It was very much governance in the early days too and it sort of built out but really the material risks or issues within those areas so research to discover them but then where they relate to individual companies

author: A
sentence: Actually they’re mandated and engaged with those boards and have a discussion and conversation, influence who you need to where there are concerns and where the issues at the regulatory level, actually to engage with the regulators or the ASX or policymakers

author: A
sentence: There could be shareholder rights issues or takeovers regime or disclosures around, and diversity is one of those

author: A
sentence: We’ve been a long-term member of the ASX Corporate Governance Council so we see influence and those regulatory settings is really important

author: A
sentence: Sometimes it’s just more efficient than convincing companies one by one to do something

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: System of disclosure or requirements

author: Q
sentence: Have you had any influence in the ASX principles that came out recently?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: All council members do but we’ve always been a supporter of those and participant on that council, right from the beginning actually

author: A
sentence: Taking the gender diversity issue, I think now there’s a much better consensus in these things

author: A
sentence: If I think about 10 years ago we were not just in that forum but I think broadly, why are you talking about this? I know there’s a huge debate or fight within the ASX Corporate Governance Council, those first round of disclosures around setting targets, disclosing board level diversity

author: A
sentence: It wasn’t universally supported

author: Q
sentence: It was sort of saying, diversity? What’s that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right or why are you being prescriptive about this? There’s all sorts of diversity

author: A
sentence: Why are we only looking at gender and so on? I think our point has always been, there’s certainly a broader conversation but at the time it was quite an observable factor

author: A
sentence: We had 50% of the director talent pool unrepresented [unclear] 00:06:18 accounting for about 9% of the seats, and the numbers were going backwards so it was like, let’s start here

author: A
sentence: We can have the conversation about broader inputs about the places we’re obviously lacking

author: A
sentence: That became more popular as time went on

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but it was initially a shock

author: Q
sentence: Like 10 years ago it was – and a shock so what are we talking, 2009?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and I think even when we challenge companies or boards on the issue at that point, I think they’ll say, “We can’t find women in our industry,” all those hackneyed lines

author: A
sentence: Where I think the move has gone is that now with the 30% Club and other, and through years of engagement and so on, actually boards now talk to us proactively

author: A
sentence: So they know our view on the issue

author: A
sentence: They’ll actually say, “Here’s what we’re doing to address the issue

author: A
sentence: We’re thinking of our next appointment” and so on

author: A
sentence: You don’t even have to raise it

author: A
sentence: It’s become the norm and why wouldn’t I subscribe to the norm as opposed to an issue from outside?

author: Q
sentence: That’s nice, soft governance

author: Q
sentence: I’ve got so many questions

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know if I’m –

author: A
sentence: Or in some discussions or something

author: A
sentence: No, that’s all right

author: A
sentence: We can follow up

author: Q
sentence: Do you help them find people for their boards?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: We do occasionally actually

author: A
sentence: They’ll send us out about views and people

author: A
sentence: We’ve done longitudinal research over some time about the challenges around – I can remember again if you wind back 10 years, between 80% and 90% of appointments to ASX 100 boards were already directors of other ASX 100 boards so you had quite a narrow gene pool

author: A
sentence: I think part of the gender diversity story is actually the story of boards looking broadly and saying, “What skills do we need to bring? How do we broaden the talent pool? How do we get relevant skills or directors with relevant experience that we’ll add to our boards?” Because prior to that I think it was very much, I know –

author: Q
sentence: Mateship

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that mateship or [unclear] 00:08:39

author: A
sentence: I always make this sort of joke

author: A
sentence: They were serious

author: A
sentence: Some boards will say, “We have diversity

author: A
sentence: We have Melbourne and Sydney on this board

author: A
sentence: ” They were serious, without batting an eyelid and you try not to laugh but that’s how people viewed it

author: A
sentence: I also think that time when people were reappointed to the board they might have a short bio or CV and you think, how does this relate to the company they’re joining? Whereas now, a lot of director appointments is, we’ve actually been looking for someone with mining and geology experience because of all – health with the corporate strategy which is x or someone with North American experience because this is how the company is expanding

author: A
sentence: It’s actually matching the person to the needs of the company [unclear] 00:09:30 as well

author: A
sentence: This person is a former accountant or a lawyer role, CEO

author: Q
sentence: Very experienced
