sentence: That level of detail of board recruitment, member recruitment they show you that, do they, so that they’re doing this?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: We ask questions about this

author: A
sentence: Particularly on renewal they’re thinking about skills, diversity, all of these factors

author: A
sentence: We like to talk about it, not only what appointments have you made, but what are you planning to do? Are there school gaps, and looking at those

author: A
sentence: You’ve had those experiences over time – in Fairfax, where I had a board with no media experience

author: A
sentence: Rio Tinto had no mining experience for a certain time, and you think, how does this happen?

author: Q
sentence: It’s sort of a joke, isn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That’s amazing

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I was there

author: A
sentence: So again, as a major investor – or ACSI members now own at least 10% of most ASX 200 companies, so they have a huge stake in the success of these businesses

author: A
sentence: So for us it’s about, are the best people being put forward? Are boards looking at a broad range of talents?

author: Q
sentence: I’m just thinking interference, how do you – the market doesn’t like regulation

author: Q
sentence: Potentially you’re aware of people’s strategies so that you could be aware of the strategies of competitors?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Although I think we’re careful in our discussions and I think boards – we deal with ASX 300 so we don’t deal with tiny companies or less-polished companies

author: A
sentence: I think we’re pretty clear about, here’s our strategic direction or here’s our thinking about board appointments and so on

author: A
sentence: We’ve never had issues around material or sensitive information

author: A
sentence: I mean, one we don’t share one response of one company with another and so on but even there, inside information, all those sorts of things we’ve never had issues there because I think people are pretty careful about what they say to investors

author: A
sentence: I think if a company is thinking about, we’d actually like to increase our gender diversity at our next director appointment or that we’d like more IT experience or someone with a background in this, ideally at our next board appointment, I don’t think, wouldn’t categorise that as market moving or sensitive side

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: But there’s a really rich discussion and I think it’s an area where, and again through the broader governance lens where superannuation funds fund managers and others actually take a lot of value from those conversations, even if it’s just to actually assess, well, we’ve met the CEO of the company and we’ve been to the strategy day and others but it’s interesting just to get the boards’ perspectives on those issues

author: A
sentence: Does one match the other? Does the board have the skill or the appropriate oversight? I think in some ways the governance and I guess to the 10-year piece as well, the governance discussion has changed so rather than the nice checklist and check the box, are you independent? Yeah, whatever the narrow side is and they’re fine

author: A
sentence: I think it’s becoming a far more rich discussion

author: A
sentence: It’s actually, think about the company strategy, its performance, its P&L, all of those broader disclosures, as well as, how are these people interacting or how does the governance framework actually support the board’s oversight role, things like they were hiring and firing CEOs on succession and those things

author: A
sentence: Are they equally important as other factors like remuneration? They’re more important actually but remuneration is an outworking of some of those strategic issues as opposed to an academic consideration on the side

author: Q
sentence: But would you have an interest in, I’m just looking at the media report, the very large remuneration for some of the chair of boards and stuff like that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think that [unclear] 00:14:22 famous words around governance, culture and remuneration march together and a lot of those observations

author: A
sentence: I think another one that was close to our heart and we’ve certainly seen for some time is that there’s actually alignment between investor interests, customers and other employees and other stakeholders over time

author: A
sentence: Companies actually do well on those factors

author: Q
sentence: Factors do well overall

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: You can’t succeed long term if you’re undermining customers or you’re not dealing properly with regulators

author: A
sentence: We don’t see a huge separation of interest there

author: Q
sentence: You have very much a stakeholder model view of the organisation

author: A
sentence: I did leave early, so I didn’t have time to –

author: A
sentence: Most companies do

author: A
sentence: Most switched-on directors do

author: A
sentence: I think they’re licensed to operate in those things in their front of mind, kind of do it for me

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good overview

author: A
sentence: One thing I should mention also we do, do, we have a set of guidelines for western companies which we update and feedback from our members, as well as, external bodies and other stakeholders over time

author: A
sentence: But we use those and we actually make voting recommendations to our members using those guidelines so part of closing the loop between engagement and research and interactions of companies so there’d be a reference point

author: Q
sentence: You’re influencing all investors in potentially –

author: A
sentence: Yeah, or our members

author: Q
sentence: Your superannuation members, not all shareholders?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: You’re very influential, aren’t you? I’d say so, 10%

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think part of that is the understanding on the company in our side of, we’re here for the long term so UniSuper member or AustralianSuper member

author: A
sentence: Actually the success of this company over the long term will have a direct bearing on their members’ retirement savings

author: A
sentence: Therefore, if we think about the alignment of incentives or long-term value creation and all the strategy, actually that’s key to that success

author: A
sentence: So in that way, we’ve developed really strong relationships with a lot of companies

author: A
sentence: We get very good access

author: A
sentence: We probably meet over, today it’s 180 boards per year across the team to discuss these issues

author: A
sentence: Again now, and I think gender diversity is a good example but more broadly we actually have companies approaching us quite often

author: A
sentence: So we’ll have issues of concern or other meetings we’ll contact companies about but actually they approach us and say, “We’re planning changes to the board or we’re thinking about changing our remuneration

author: A
sentence: What do you think about issue A or B? It’s become a two-way –

author: Q
sentence: To be honest, I left after the toast, because I was there early

author: Q
sentence: It’s a dialogue

author: A
sentence: Dialogue whereas in the early days I think some companies are across it but it wasn’t as common

author: Q
sentence: This is really nice

author: Q
sentence: We’ll go to the importance

author: Q
sentence: How important do you think it is to have a diverse board? 10 is extremely and 1 is not at all and then we’ll work from there

author: A
sentence: I’m biased but I’ll say 10

author: Q
sentence: I already know your answer to this

author: Q
sentence: You feel that it hasn’t always been that important

author: Q
sentence: What do you feel has led to the change and importance? Because you said 10 years ago people didn’t even know what diversity was, let alone –

author: A
sentence: Are we talking gender diversity or more broadly?

author: Q
sentence: We will define that so however you want to define it

author: A
sentence: I think in both ways, I mean there’s so much in the – there’s a lot of actually research and I think the 30% Club in the UK know those references when they first started

author: A
sentence: There’s so much in the psychology world and group dynamics that for instance when you have – I forget the name of the study now

author: A
sentence: I should have done my background before this, where they use, they do tests of groups of male and female students against one another and then they use mixed groups in this huge study they did

author: A
sentence: They found that mixed groups performed better overall

author: A
sentence: I obviously don’t why

author: A
sentence: But I think the issues around groupthink are really important

author: A
sentence: People think of groupthink as a whole bunch of people agreeing with one another but actually digging into the background in the behavioural psychology research, it’s more about, if you have people, all have the same background, experience, learning, they’re not agreeing with one another but they will all independently to a view on an issue

author: A
sentence: But because there’s that following the same pathway or same set of experiences actually that is a major input into that groupthink situation

author: A
sentence: On the gender front I think things like the Credit Suisse’s global, it’s called the Global 3000 where they actually looked at a huge suite of companies and they said, “How can we compare companies with gender -diverse boards and gender-diverse management?” and surprise, surprise, there was a correlation between higher financial returns over time, lower risk, lower gearing and so on

author: A
sentence: Again you can’t point to the whys of that but that’s the quantitative aspect

author: A
sentence: I would say the qualitative aspect, and we’ve heard this from a lot of chairmen, male chairman and people who had been part of all-male companies and so on, actually said, you just change the discussion so the more views you can have around the table, the more you break out of that potential groupthink

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: I think also that sort of diversity of experience, background, people have seen the same issues but maybe in different industries or different arenas that the qualitative aspect is actually, that’s beneficial

author: A
sentence: I think many more of them are thinking a lot more around skills, backgrounds, even age, diversity and so on because you’ll get those differences there

author: A
sentence: There’s all of those and it’s a much richer discussion

author: A
sentence: But also mindful with that as an investor analysis, coming from the outside looking in, you cannot use a template and say, do they have one lawyer, one accountant, whatever it may be, check, check, check

author: A
sentence: That board is fine

author: A
sentence: You are dealing with people and group dynamic so you need something more than that

author: Q
sentence: But you would be worried if a board of a large company didn’t have a lawyer or an accountant on it, would you?

author: A
sentence: It depends

author: A
sentence: Boards often say we can hire lawyers as independent advisers so we can mooch that

author: Q
sentence: I thought you’d always hire a lawyer

author: A
sentence: But I think different from the old world, and private equity firms used to do this when they’re lodging an IPO

author: A
sentence: They’ll say, “Here’s a great former politician and sports star” and some great names as opposed to, “Here are people with really relevant strong industry experience who will be able to guide, not micromanage but actually oversee and guide this company

author: Q
sentence: [Unclear] 00:23:06

author: A
sentence: I think there’s also a much different attitude among directors today, again, as it’s been previously where people are actually interested and engaged with the boards that are joining so it’s less of a case of, I’ve retired from a great glowing career in corporate life

author: A
sentence: This is a transition to retirement

author: A
sentence: I’ll have a few good lunches and whatever else

author: A
sentence: I don’t really care about what’s happening in the company

author: A
sentence: I think now directors they do more due diligence with the companies they get involved in

author: A
sentence: They’re probably more across the detail and passionate about the institutions they’re a part of

author: A
sentence: They’ll have more skin in the game

author: A
sentence: Often they own more shares and so on

author: A
sentence: It’s becoming more and more I think professional

author: Q
sentence: That’s been over the last 10 years?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so too

author: Q
sentence: It was a big shakeup wasn’t it, the global financial crisis and all that sort of stuff?

author: Q
sentence: I’ve just got a few demographic questions, your discipline background?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: There’s also the regulatory changes for boards too like liability, the liability insurance and that

author: A
sentence: The AICD every now and again comes out and says liability is too high but I think if you look at the extremely small number of directors pursued by ASIC and the circumstances around the Centro or James Hardie or other cases, I actually think one, they’re not unfair issues to pursue and it’s a very tiny list of people who have been found wanting or faced really penalties in those situations

author: A
sentence: Again I don’t see any – the other day at the 30% Club launch I think it’s all still more people wanting to join boards

author: Q
sentence: People aren’t running away

author: A
sentence: No, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Like the doctors in New South Wales when the medical internship –

author: A
sentence: One tangible and coming from a legal background, I think we need to focus a lot on Section 180 and the base level requirements of director’s duties

author: A
sentence: I think the interesting thing in the governance consideration and where investors look at is actually, how do we appoint and promote really high-quality, high-functioning boards? Above and beyond, have we met our very base level legal requirement or actually how they add value to the organisations and how do you have top-quality people? Which is very different so I think the legal thinking is how do I meet bare minimum and avoid liability or –

author: Q
sentence: Compliance first

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: Q
sentence: Stretching, adding value

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, thanks 32D for agreeing to be interviewed about board diversity

author: Q
sentence: We're interested in, like, there's a lot of talk about board diversity, but we're interested in the perceptions of people who are actually on boards like yourself

author: Q
sentence: We also are interviewing institutions that influence your performance; you know, what you do on boards here in Australia

author: Q
sentence: So, we really need people like you to come and talk so thank you so much

author: A
sentence: And am currently on four

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that it’s always been important?  Has it always been the case?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I do

author: A
sentence: Because I mean the main reasons, I think is avoiding groupthink

author: A
sentence: I mean, I start to worry when everyone’s nodding and agreeing

author: A
sentence: In fact, there are some people certainly the board that I’m president on, that I’ve been on the longest

author: A
sentence: You know, there’s a couple of people on that board that are quite quiet in meeting but every time I speak, they go, “Look, playing devil’s advocate

author: A
sentence: ”  And I go, “Oh, good, I knew you were going to come up with that

author: A
sentence: That’s good

author: A
sentence: ”  Challenging each other I think is really important, not just comfortably, as I said being a chair warmer and just going along, you know, for the ride

author: A
sentence: That is not making the contribution and it’s not adding value to the organisation

author: A
sentence: So, I think it’s very important to have people who have another point of view

author: Q
sentence: So, we could – so cognitive diversity then

author: Q
sentence: Would you think that might be the term?

author: A
sentence: Yeah maybe, I don’t know whether it’s cognitive but just a different lens, a different perspective who have the ability to look at it different ways

author: A
sentence: I mean, even in my executive career running teams, if people just kept agreeing with me it would come up in their performance review and go look, I know I’m fabulous but if you just keep agreeing – like if we all agree with each other, then all but one of us might as well go home because we’re not actually adding to make the work better if we’re all just going, “Yeah, that’s fine, that’s fine, that’s fine

author: A
sentence: ”  So, I absolutely encourage people to say what they think and I they don’t agree with me even better

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there’s any – I’m going to come back to that because I think you’re going to help me a lot there

author: A
sentence: Oh, good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there is any situation or context that might cause you to change that rating, like high risk, high uncertainty?

author: A
sentence: The rating of 10?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Look, I can see why for example on the boards that I sit on, I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: But on ASX boards, this is just what I’ve gleaned from talking to recruiters as well, is they point – I don’t know whether I mentioned this to you the other day

author: A
sentence: But as one of them quoted out to me, you know, people like me are actually a risk to them because unless I’m known by – you know how it’s all that, there’s a bit of a perception or a reality that it’s always people who are known that get appointed to those boards

author: A
sentence: One of the recruiters said to me, as in the case that we had, “You appoint a CEO, it doesn’t work out, you can fire them, or you can move them on

author: A
sentence: ”  If you appoint a director who turns out just to be a complete pain in the butt and just disruptive, not collaborative, a road blocker, continually just being disruptive, it’s very hard to get rid of them

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re currently on four and you've had five?

author: A
sentence: So, when I say, “What would change my mind

author: A
sentence: ”  I guess probably nothing but getting the right amount of diversity for the right reasons, again for the right skills is I guess what I’m talking about

author: A
sentence: Not diversity for diversity sake

author: A
sentence: I have seen that as well

author: A
sentence: On the national board, there was a young nominated member, like quite young compared – I mean, like most people are at least over 50, only a couple in their late 40s

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Or older

author: A
sentence: And there was a young guy of indigenous heritage who was on that board and although he was a nice guy, he said absolutely nothing and so I’m sure the board felt very proud of itself that they had somebody who was both indigenous and young

author: A
sentence: But made no contribution, so I don’t see the point of that

author: Q
sentence: We’ll come back to that as well

author: Q
sentence: I just want to get through those questions before I want you to really drill down on this

author: Q
sentence: So, this is the – So, the right amount of diversity at the right time

author: Q
sentence: Is that right?

author: A
sentence: Well, just as I’m saying, like, diversity to me is different opinions different lens, different skills

author: A
sentence: But you wouldn’t just go, “Oh they’ve worked at the zoo let’s get them in because we don’t have anybody on this board who worked at the zoo

author: A
sentence: ”  Even though it’s completely irrelevant, that would tick the diversity box

author: A
sentence: But it doesn’t necessarily, it’s not necessarily what the organisation needs

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so that does link to strategy, mission?

author: A
sentence: I think the board composition needs to be very strategic

author: Q
sentence: So, it needs to link, so that -

author: A
sentence: Yeah and there also needs -

author: Q
sentence: -@ appropriateness is linked

author: A
sentence: I was on the board of Clemenger BBDO Melbourne which was the last agency I worked at before I started my own

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: There also needs to be a culture within the board and that’s also really important and that’s where I think in a bygone era white middle-aged men felt very comfortable in the company of other white middle-aged men

author: A
sentence: So that was a very easy choice

author: A
sentence: But sometimes that just turned into homogenous thinking, whereas I think we need to be getting different thinking into challenge

author: A
sentence: Because things are changing so quickly

author: Q
sentence: Now there's one question before we move into that because this is really where all your stuff's really heading on the functioning on the board and culture, and I want to explore that in-depth

author: Q
sentence: But before we do, can we just say, is there a particular kind of diversity that you think matters more than others or is really contingent?

author: A
sentence: I would say being able to bring a different lens to the organisation and its strategy, its strategic direction

author: A
sentence: I mean, when I'm saying a different lens, so some people's lens might be financial or operational or someone might be more about creative thinking

author: A
sentence: I think they're the important to me, the main ones

author: A
sentence: And that's why someone who's much younger might have a whole lot of ideas around where to take the organisation because they're more, you know, they're digital natives and they know here are some things that you old codgers might not have thought about

author: A
sentence: So, to me, it's having those different lenses of how to drive the business forward

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: So now, you've been talking about culture, the culture of the board, developing the culture of the board and bringing in voices, say the Aboriginal didn’t contribute his voice and that was a problem

author: Q
sentence: He had potentially a very useful different lens but didn’t bring it to the table

author: Q
sentence: So, is there a connection between how you might develop the culture of the board, perhaps the one that you’re chair of and the different voices, potential voices you have around the table

author: Q
sentence: So actually, harnessing the difference

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: So, I mean in my role as president when I’m chairing board meetings I deliberately, if anyone goes quiet I will deliberately single them out and ask them what they think

author: A
sentence: But normally it’s quite systematic particularly if we’re dealing with something that’s, you know, we’ve had a paper distributed

author: A
sentence: If it’s relatively, not controversial, but something that I imagine people will have a firm opinion on

author: A
sentence: And this is more the - less the reporting because I just go that's a rear vision mirror, that’s what happened last week, let’s worry about where we’re going

author: A
sentence: I will deliberately go around all directors and seek their input

author: A
sentence: In the case of that board where we had the indigenous guy, the chair would ask him his opinion and he would just go, “Yeah, I’m fine with that

author: A
sentence: ”  So, I mean it’s not that he – I certainly am not suggesting that the environment created on that board didn’t invite comment and it’s always asked of people

author: A
sentence: It’s just that individual chose or didn’t feel comfortable or didn’t have the experience, I don’t know what it was, but anyway

author: Q
sentence: So, I guess this term inclusiveness has come up and the ability of the board to cultivate inclusiveness is important

author: Q
sentence: So, I guess I’m wondering if you have some ideas about how this might be done?  Because it seems to be important for us to develop, to benefit

author: A
sentence: It’s extremely important

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so can we talk that?

author: A
sentence: How do we foster inclusion?  Well, I think it's; this is only my own style

author: A
sentence: So, I'm not speaking of anything

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: So, you've been doing this over how many years was it?

author: Q
sentence: You don’t have any universal

author: A
sentence: For me, it’s validating what people are contributing, whether that’s the direction it takes or not

author: A
sentence: So even this morning I was chairing the Victorian disability awards panel where we had to decide who’s going to get these awards and whatever

author: A
sentence: But it was really important to me

author: A
sentence: If somebody makes a comment, even if I don’t agree with it, it doesn’t mean it’s not valid and we shouldn’t consider it and talk about it

author: A
sentence: So, I think creating that environment which I try and do, as I said on my board is make sure everyone is heard and to absolutely validate what everyone says

author: A
sentence: Sometimes someone will something, I think oh gee, I’m not sure about that

author: A
sentence: In which case I will say to the whole board, “Gee, what do you think?”  And get more discussion around that

author: A
sentence: So that to me, you need to sometimes encourage people to put forward their opinion

author: A
sentence: Always have an atmosphere of not shutting people down and particularly if it’s not in agreement with what you’re saying and validating everyone’s point of view, so they feel – it’s almost like small children isn’t it, you’ve just got to encourage that kind of behaviour, so they repeat it

author: A
sentence: So, to me, that's very important

author: Q
sentence: I heard one person told me that they were in a meeting and someone was really quite a bit offensive in what they said and how they said it, and so they weren’t the chair and they were a fairly new person to this board and they told this person it was completely inappropriate and that they should leave

author: A
sentence: How did that end?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, it ended well, because that person actually wasn’t a board member I think, they were part of a legacy that they would sit on the board, but they were actually not separate

author: Q
sentence: So, it helped to sort of keep a separation

author: Q
sentence: A distance, yeah

author: Q
sentence: But that was a very brave move of this person I thought

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: But possibly a very necessary one, because then like he felt there were no, you know, that no-one took it out on him

author: A
sentence: There were no repercussions for bad behaviour

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, no-one thought he was, yeah, bad or inappropriate or anything

author: A
sentence: Oh, gosh

author: A
sentence: Now that's a -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think that is very important to call out bad behaviour

author: A
sentence: One of the things that has struck me unbelievably about all four boards that I’m currently on is the degree of professionalism

author: A
sentence: In fact, conflict that I mentioned earlier that’s going on, I kept saying to everyone involved in that, that I think it’s absolutely - there’s a lack of professionalism and there’s a lack of respect that is contributing to that conflict

author: A
sentence: I said, “Yes, there is some lack of alignment, but adding fuel to this fire, we need to be trying as grow-ups to defuse this situation and find, you know, discuss it reasonably, find a resolution to move forward

author: A
sentence: Not just to just vent and complain and everything else

author: A
sentence: ”  I don’t find that constructive at all

author: A
sentence: I think maybe for me; my background is advertising was as client service

author: A
sentence: Which I didn’t realise until just the last couple of years, I think the skills that I learnt in client service can put me in very good stead to be on the board because I need to convince my client, the person who’s paying the money for us to provide a service to make a decision to get everyone in agreement so we can move forward

author: A
sentence: But in a very polite and respectable way, because they could fire me

author: A
sentence: I think it’s absolutely essential to maintain that professionalism

author: A
sentence: And if people speak out of people aren’t right - in fact, I’m coaching a business owner at the moment, we’re talking about their culture and I said, “Poor behaviour needs to be called out at the right time and in the appropriate manner

author: A
sentence: So, you don’t shoot someone down in front of everybody else, it’s just afterwards you go, “Look, I just don’t think that was quite the right way to go about that

author: A
sentence: ”  But just keep calling it out so it changes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think selection plays a role in this?

author: A
sentence: As in the people that you put on a board?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, selection of candidates

author: A
sentence: Yeah, totally

author: Q
sentence: So how would you screen for this?

author: A
sentence: It’s kind of for me it’s a little intuitive

author: A
sentence: The CEO that we appointed that turned out to not be so good, there was a cultural is32D and we did have to be very brave

author: A
sentence: So, I actually was the one who, I was approached by several people within a matter of weeks and my mind went from having to have a bit of a chat to maybe he needs some executive coaching, to you have to go

author: A
sentence: So, gathered the board, we had an extraordinary board meeting, met with the lawyers and just made that decision because that couldn’t go on

author: A
sentence: What I have learnt from that Margo, is that even though that person came to us through a recruiter and we had them psychometric tested and they had to do the presentation on the first 100 days and all that kind of stuff

author: A
sentence: I just said to the recruiter, “Just something, my intuition is telling me there’s something not quite right here, I just feel we’re missing something

author: Q
sentence: Isn’t that interesting

author: Q
sentence: Boards

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, my big lesson from that is if my intuition is telling me something’s not right, chances are something’s not right

author: A
sentence: So, I don’t whether that’s – that’s probably a real bad answer to go I just use my intuition

author: Q
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: No, there are no bad answers, I mean that sincerely

author: A
sentence: Well, you know, that’s one where you just, your female intuition kicks in, you go yeah, something just doesn’t feel right about this

author: Q
sentence: But you know what that says to me from a rational point of view?  That says our tools and instruments don’t capture something that’s meaningful and significant

author: Q
sentence: So, we need tools, if we want to move down that sort of, you know, measuring path

author: Q
sentence: But until then, we have to listen to hunches or whatever

author: Q
sentence: And it also says that outsourcing to head-hunters or search agencies or whatever is not the – you can’t sort of give all the responsibility to them

author: A
sentence: No, I did the next one

author: A
sentence: I read all 64 applications for the next round and we did it ourselves internally

author: A
sentence: I went, I am not using a recruiter; I’m not paying money

author: A
sentence: I didn’t even appoint that recruiter, the outgoing CEO, the old one, original one said, “I’ve appointed these recruiters and we’ll manage the process and blah, blah, blah

author: A
sentence: ”  And then she left and on we went

author: A
sentence: So, after that I just went yeah, I feel too much of a sense of responsibility

author: Q
sentence: It’s too hard to work with conflict between the chairperson and the CEO, that must be terrible

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Feel like we’ve got a great one now

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Oh, isn’t that wonderful?  So, have you got – some people have come up with some – I like this question because it gives you a - is there an example that you can think of where diversity really helped make a decision or something on the board?

author: A
sentence: Well, I’m coming back again to diversity of opinion

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: Well five, six, seven, I guess the Clemenger Board, seven, eight, nine, was maybe nine years ago that I was on that one

author: A
sentence: Where, yes absolutely

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily the right decision as it turns out

author: Q
sentence: Doesn’t matter

author: A
sentence: But it certainly had an influence, because we had a situation in the merger that we were exploring, where one of the directors on the other organisation had been on a local council that had been stood down by the Minister for Local Government, pending investigation

author: A
sentence: We’ve gone yeah, that’s a risk

author: A
sentence: So, my opinion in that was, like, cut it loose, cut it loose, cut it loose immediately

author: A
sentence: One of the other directors said, “Look, we haven’t got the findings of the investigation yet, this person could be a force for good, we’re just assuming that they’re a force for evil

author: A
sentence: ”  Turns out they were, they’ve since been charged

author: A
sentence: But that aside, I must admit I felt that I had been influenced in my opinion by my personal encounters with this person who is very un-professional basically, would just sum it up

author: A
sentence: And I thought, not sure about this

author: A
sentence: I would have just cut it loose

author: A
sentence: But it was interesting, and I was very pleased that that – I mean, still after all those meetings and everything else, it still stands out in my head that this person said, “Well we don’t actually know

author: A
sentence: Like, we’re assuming that

author: A
sentence: ”  There’s my intuition again going, I’m pretty sure she’s a force for evil

author: A
sentence: But she said, “She could be a force for good

author: A
sentence: ”  And I went, “Well, actually that’s true, I don’t know that

author: A
sentence: So, let’s have another look

author: Q
sentence: So, was that person from a legal background that said that?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: She is and she’s a woman, she’s an academic and she’s great, but she’ll often do that

author: A
sentence: She’ll pick the opposite side and that’s what I really enjoy about working with her

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and I mean, why I thought a legal background was because that’s a managing risks from a legal perspective, is to not attribute blame until they’re found guilty

author: A
sentence: And now there’s plenty

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but you’ve done the right thing

author: A
sentence: Actually, that’s a really interesting point because I did the company director’s course with another girl who was also, she’s not anymore, but she was on this board at the same time

author: A
sentence: We had to do some role-playing and it was just so funny, the scenario they gave us, I’m like, “Wow, that’s great let’s charge on

author: A
sentence: ”  And she’s gone, “Hang on a minute, we haven’t followed any process

author: A
sentence: ”  And I looked at her and I’ve gone, “And we’re on the same board

author: A
sentence: ”  Which again is where that diversity comes from

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, like 2010?

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve come from advertising, marketing, communications, it’s like don’t seek permission, seek forgiveness later

author: A
sentence: Oh, we weren’t allowed to do that?  Oh, sorry

author: A
sentence: Which is terribly different

author: A
sentence: So, I'm much more in the case compared to a lot of other people on the boards, I'm much more risk ave – I'm not risk-averse

author: A
sentence: I'm going, “Oh yeah, give it a crack, spend the money, why not

author: A
sentence: This looks good to me, let’s give it a shot

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and go for outcomes

author: A
sentence: Yeah exactly

author: A
sentence: Whereas other they go, “Oh, you know, it looks a bit risky

author: A
sentence: ”  And go, “Yeah, but the upside could be really good too

author: A
sentence: ”  So that I thought was quite, that was a great illustration I thought of diversity of risk appetite

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: And your lawyer example was really procedure versus look, my gut sense is this is bad let’s just cut it and the appropriate process is blah, blah, blah

author: Q
sentence: And you listened, like you heeded that

author: A
sentence: And it was the right thing to do actually

author: A
sentence: I agreed with her because I thought - but then I sort of have to self-reflect which I like to think I do a lot of

author: A
sentence: But when she goes out, I thought actually she’s right, I have no evidence to say, other than I just don’t really like her

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got a good gut feel

author: A
sentence: As I said, she’s since been charged

author: A
sentence: I think that’s evidence enough

author: Q
sentence: You could save a lot of juries

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think that there are some board functions where diversity of views has little bearing, it’s really irrelevant?

author: A
sentence: That's an interesting question

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think there are some situations and some circumstances that you might be in where you have got the lawyer or somebody who's, yeah not me, I'm not a lawyer

author: A
sentence: Somebody who's saying, “Well my opinion on this is that

author: A
sentence: ”  Like, I’m not going to go in and go, “Well I reckon

author: A
sentence: ”  Like if that’s the law, so no diversity is required there as far as I’m concerned

author: A
sentence: I may have a different opinion about the outcome or what we do with that information

author: A
sentence: But it’s the same even with I do have an accounting qualification, but if the actual CFO says, “Well, , these are what we’re going to be doing for these reasons

author: A
sentence: ”  I go, “Well, that makes sense

author: A
sentence: ”  So, I think in those very operational reporting stuff there’s no need for diversity, it’s just these are the facts

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, is it 2010?  Maybe it was around then

author: A
sentence: So that would be about right

author: A
sentence: And they’re the experts in those areas and I think it’s appropriate to defer to – not necessarily their opinion, but their interpretation

author: A
sentence: You go, “Okay, that’s your interpretation, now we can talk about that

author: Q
sentence: So expert technical information, it’s irrelevant, and so that might be your financial reporting

author: A
sentence: I’ve always got a lot of – it's not that people can't question it, I'm just saying that those people who are delivering the facts, I suppose if they are the facts then I don't think we need diversity

author: A
sentence: What we do with those facts is absolutely where everyone should be weighing in

author: Q
sentence: But then as a board are these facts that’s the pre-reading, you said that they’re like the reports

author: Q
sentence: You know, that’s not what you focus on, you focus on right, now what are we going to do with this as a board

author: A
sentence: Oh, let me give you another example, I’m not explaining this very well

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s all right

author: A
sentence: Let’s say I come up with some crazy wacky idea that we should be doing x and our legal person says, “Actually, that’s not legal, you can’t do that

author: A
sentence: ”  Well that’s the end of the conversation, isn’t it?  It’s not open for discussion if she goes, “Yeah, no, not allowed to do that

author: A
sentence: ” I go, “Okay, I believe you

author: A
sentence: ”  That kind of thing

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Or if I say, “Why can’t we just role that investment into something else?”  And the finance guy goes, “Well because - just again for example - well the caveats that are on that mean that we won’t be able to access that money to

author: A
sentence: ”  “Yeah, that’s not right, we’re done

author: A
sentence: We’re not doing that

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re coming from left of field and you’re creating, like the board might create ideas, possible strategies, possible [overtalk] 00:41:15 but then there will be an expert opinion that basically closes down

author: Q
sentence: Any discussion beyond that is a waste of time

author: Q
sentence: So, since -

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q
sentence: Because, oh it's illegal

author: Q
sentence: But that's still diversity, like the diversity brings up these possible futures and it's just, thank god you’ve got the lawyer who saves you all the trouble by saying, “Oh well, that’s illegal

author: A
sentence: I guess you’re right

author: A
sentence: I guess what I think about with diversity of opinion that even though that person goes it’s illegal, but I could push on

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well look never mind that, let’s discuss the law

author: Q
sentence: Let’s just keep going

author: Q
sentence: Maybe we could get away with it

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, it’s more in that aspect, but you are right I suppose that is diversity as well

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, in terms of the structure of the board?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: It’s not so much in the process of decision making but, in the structure, because you’ve got different perspectives

author: Q
sentence: What about can diversity limit or undermine the functioning of the board in particular?

author: A
sentence: As I said, only in those cases where again having a look at the composition of some of the ASX200 board

author: A
sentence: As I said, a lot of them have one or two women on them and if that person also is of ethnic diversity, well there’s two boxes ticked

author: A
sentence: Now, maybe I’m being and I’m sure I am being incredibly simplistic about that, but you’ve got to out sometimes and go, “Well are they actually the right people on that board or is that just a bit of box-ticking exercise?”

author: Q
sentence: And this brings us -

author: A
sentence: My pleasure

author: A
sentence: But then I was on that one for maybe two years and then I didn’t get onto another board until maybe 2013 or something

author: A
sentence: Might have had a year out, something like that anyway

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: -@ over here to targets

author: A
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So, is this a side effect of using targets do you think, and quotas that it becomes a box-ticking?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know whether it’s targets or quotas

author: A
sentence: In fact, I was absolutely fascinated by Louise Davidson, who said we’re actually asking our members to vote against incumbent directors who are up for re-election if they don’t have women on their board

author: A
sentence: I mean, that is – I was just like, wow, that’s interesting

author: A
sentence: Like, that’s incredibly powerful that the superannuation investors have over those boards that they can actually do that

author: A
sentence: So yes, so I don’t know whether it’s quotas, but I’m not – sorry, let me back up

author: A
sentence: I’m not saying that the women who are on those boards and with their ethnic diversity are not right, I just think well if the whole board had more diversity to it rather than just fiddling with the edges

author: A
sentence: Do you know what I mean?

author: Q
sentence: If it was the decision-making diversity and the skills diversity and whatever, but if it was all grey

author: A
sentence: And if that were truly being embraced, that we want different opinions, different lens, creative thinking, how can we drive this business forward, then gender shouldn’t really be a problem, shouldn’t be an is32D, it shouldn’t even come into it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: Because I mean, the 50% will be randomly distributed among these skills

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: I thought it was interesting a person said they sort of, because it’s very visible the gender diversity of a board, they wouldn’t go onto a board that was gender diverse because they thought that was an indicator that to them that the board was too conservative

author: Q
sentence: They wouldn’t fit in with the culture of that board and they wouldn’t want to

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But you've really been watching this space since around 2010

author: A
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s any – does that connect with you at all?

author: A
sentence: I can see what – maybe it’s an individual personality type, as I said I’ve had to spend a lot of time dealing with clients of perhaps that ilk

author: A
sentence: Like, I’ve worked on power tools

author: A
sentence: I had one client who went, “We can’t have her on the account, we need a bloke, it’s power tools

author: A
sentence: ”  They go, “No, you’ve got her

author: A
sentence: ”  And of course, it worked out absolutely fine

author: A
sentence: You know, that kind of thing, it wouldn’t concern me

author: A
sentence: I think I would eventually manage to make my way and integrate

author: A
sentence: Because, you know, as a client service person that’s what I have to do, or that’s what I’ve always done

author: A
sentence: So, for me, no I think I would be prepared to give it a go

author: Q
sentence: Now I’m just thinking, you’re a female, he was male

author: A
sentence: Oh, really?

author: Q
sentence: That said that

author: A
sentence: He thinks that they’re too conservative if they have no gender diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: It just depends on the board too, because I would imagine if you were a Fin Tech for example, and the founders were blokes who had been to uni together or something and that was just there, then I can see again that might not be wrong at the start of that business to just be those people

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Oh, definitely

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So, I don’t think, you know, forcing it sometimes just doesn’t feel right either

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, you don’t see it as a signal at all?  That’s good

author: Q
sentence: You see it more as an opportunity to transform?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So, the conflict that can possibly arise with diversity, it’s interesting, I’ve had different – because I’m fairly well into the interviews now and I’ve had - the word conflict is very comfortable to some people

author: Q
sentence: Start-ups, males very comfortable it would seem, and I’ve got the very small sample size, so really, I shouldn’t generalise, but that has been the pattern

author: Q
sentence: But conflict, other people have said, “No, not conflict, it’s -

author: Q
sentence: ”  And they’ll have another word

author: Q
sentence: It’s debate or that’s good

author: Q
sentence: But conflicts bad, because they see conflict as like bullying

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I guess it depends on again, having worked in communication

author: A
sentence: When I have developed brand strategies, quite often we spent a lot of time discussing what we mean by certain words

author: A
sentence: Because what I have discovered over my time in comms is that different people have different interpretations of words

author: A
sentence: I know the dictionary says that’s what it means, but some people there’s a whole lot of baggage that can come with a particular word like conflict

author: A
sentence: So, for some people conflict, I’m sure, conjures up thoughts of aggression and being adamant and inflexible and that’s conflict

author: A
sentence: Whereas other people just interpret conflict as having a difference of opinions and working your way through it

author: A
sentence: So, I think it just depends on – I don't have an opinion on the word one way or the other

author: A
sentence: But I would just imagine that for some people the word conflict immediately has a whole lot of aggression and negativity associated with it

author: Q
sentence: Well given that, what sort of conflict or disagreement is dysfunctional in a board, if any and what is functional?  Can you describe it for me with your greatness?

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah, totally

author: A
sentence: Well again, from my days in advertising there’s plenty of conflict there, let me tell you

author: A
sentence: Where I think it’s constructive and it’s good is if everyone is sticking to the topic, is professional and talking about what’s in the best interest of the work

author: A
sentence: In those circumstances to me it’s always like that, it’s never personal

author: A
sentence: Like, I’ve been in meetings where people have come out and gone, “Oh, that was shocking

author: A
sentence: ”  I go, “No it wasn’t

author: A
sentence: ”  I don’t care, it’s all about making the work better

author: A
sentence: So, I think it’s a case of, you know, as I’ve often said in advertising, he or she with the best case and the best argument and the best reason to do whatever it is will win

author: A
sentence: However, I have also been told that she who is more articulate has an advantage, by one client who might have been pointing a t me at the time

author: A
sentence: But anyway

author: A
sentence: My partner would absolutely agree with that

author: A
sentence: When I become destructive in that conflict, I think is exactly the situation I was describing in this federated one, is where it's unprofessional, it's overly emotional, it can become personal

author: A
sentence: I mean, that’s just inappropriate behaviour

author: A
sentence: But if you don’t agree, I mean that’s fine, you just need to keep working through it and saying, “So tell me more about that, why do you think that?  What do you think the outcomes are?  What are you concerned about?”  Can you see this working?”  I mean, it’s just having a conversation

author: A
sentence: Be that conflict, debate, whatever you want to - discussion

author: A
sentence: But I see that as the major role of the board, having that discussion and those different opinions

author: A
sentence: As I said, if everyone agrees, only need one person there, don’t we?

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s it

author: Q
sentence: That’s why I really want; and I thought you would be a perfect person

author: Q
sentence: I got a bit excited because you would be a perfect person, which you just really given a nice analysis of it

author: Q
sentence: That's brilliant

author: Q
sentence: And are the boards mainly of a particular industry like not-for-profit, for-profit, state-owned, big, small?

author: A
sentence: Oh good

author: A
sentence: I hope I haven’t discounted

author: Q
sentence: No, no

author: Q
sentence: To help unpack what we need in terms of, because the different lens of course bring different points of view to a discussion and when does difference become dysfunctional and you’ve really articulated it and people have used words like conflict or whatever to try and articulate it

author: Q
sentence: But you have described it, so thank you

author: A
sentence: Oh, you're most welcome

author: A
sentence: Again, being in advertising for so many years, there were many occasions where I heard from – well, in fact, I was on some management teams as well, but, you know, swearing at people

author: A
sentence: No, not okay people

author: A
sentence: I mean, I don’t mind swearing I couldn’t care less, but actually swearing at somebody

author: A
sentence: No, not okay

author: A
sentence: That kind of behaviour I just go, “That’s not all right

author: Q
sentence: So, if that happened at a board meeting, would you say, “Look, now that’s not okay,”  straightaway, or would you wait?

author: A
sentence: I am quite good at being passive-aggressive as one of my kids would tell me

author: A
sentence: But I was in a board meeting where I felt that one of the directors was becoming quite condescending and lecturing

author: A
sentence: And I must admit, when he started off on another a rant, I said, “We’ve all read the papers thank you

author: A
sentence: ”  When he was starting to lecture us again

author: A
sentence: I think he got the gist

author: A
sentence: And then afterwards I spoke to the president and I went, “You know what?  Not okay

author: A
sentence: ”  But that’s probably the worst that – if I were in that situation, I just can’t see it on the boards that I’m on

author: A
sentence: They’re all just so respectful

author: A
sentence: And having come from advertising, where people do scream at each other and are highly inappropriate and probably would make it personal as well, I’m just finding it so refreshing

author: Q
sentence: So, you have high-risk tolerance and high conflict tolerance?

author: A
sentence: Oh, yeah

author: A
sentence: Look, I’ve been yelled at by clients and screamed at by creative and all of the above

author: A
sentence: So, to actually - I’m finding – in fact that was part of, not just that, but the calibre of the conversation in board rooms and the professionalism that’s exhibited, I find highly appealing

author: A
sentence: That’s what I really enjoy

author: Q
sentence: That would be great

author: Q
sentence: That would be really good

author: Q
sentence: So, I’m conscious now of the time

author: A
sentence: That’s all right, as I said I’ve got -

author: Q
sentence: I’ve really enjoyed this so much

author: A
sentence: I’m currently sitting on two not-for-profits, a start-up which is also actually a not-for-profit but it’s not, you know, it’s just so interesting isn’t it?  It’s not a straightforward not for profit, it’s setting up a special purpose vehicle that will be commercial that will generate money for charity

author: A
sentence: No, no, that’s okay

author: A
sentence: And as I said, I’m not seeing Gerard until 2:30 but you probably have something else to be going too

author: Q
sentence: I do have another interview to do

author: Q
sentence: You talked about that

author: A
sentence: Good, tick that one off

author: Q
sentence: So, when identifying potential new members, does your board consider ways to increase diversity as you prioritise it?

author: A
sentence: Look, to be perfectly frank because we’re unpaid not-for-profit board, when we did our last round we only had, we put out a call, I think we only had four people apply

author: A
sentence: It makes it pretty slim pickings

author: A
sentence: So that really has - and two of them were great and we appointed them, and one was from that gaming industry

author: A
sentence: We’ve gone, “Yeah, no, I don’t think so, not for what we do

author: A
sentence: ”  So yeah, not really

author: A
sentence: Depends on what we get

author: Q
sentence: Okay yeah, so there’s a lack of supply really?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, really, a total lack of supply

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence this selection process?  Like you described, which was great, the use of a – the CEO used a – sorry, the previous chair used an outsourcing?

author: A
sentence: That was to get the CEO

author: Q
sentence: To get the CEO

author: Q
sentence: So, with boards do you tend to outsource on some of your boards?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay

author: A
sentence: Well actually, let me just think about this for a moment

author: A
sentence: So, the two that we’ve recently appointed to the one I’m president of we just ran the ads in the appropriate places, wrote the description, decided what we were looking for, that took longer than we thought actually, because we looked at our skills matrix and went why is some of these things even on here?  That doesn’t make any sense

author: A
sentence: So that was quite a good exercise and we’re happy with those appointments

author: A
sentence: With the national board that I’m on, I was actually on the recruitment working committee

author: A
sentence: See this is where this work thing keeps coming up

author: A
sentence: We needed to appoint a new chair and a new independent director, and I think that might have come through a recruitment process or maybe they advertised, but on that working committee, we had a lot of applications for that one

author: A
sentence: So as working team, we just had to work through them all and then we went back to the board

author: A
sentence: So, it came down to three of us, pretty much

author: A
sentence: And obviously with the executive as well, but it pretty much came down to a working group of three

author: A
sentence: There was no-one external on that

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you’re not big users, you haven’t been users of the external services?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Only probably because none of them have got much money

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Because they would cost a fair bit, wouldn’t they?

author: A
sentence: Well that’s the other thing too, I’ve been told by various people that appointing directors isn’t overly lucrative for recruiters compared to say sweet appointments

author: A
sentence: So, they go, yeah, they’re not their first priority

author: A
sentence: So even though I’ve been going around seeing 14 recruiters and trying to put myself forward for boards, I have been told it’s not their number one priority

author: A
sentence: They almost do it like a favour to organisations who use them to appoint their executives

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: A
sentence: Because there’s no – the money is just not the same as for appointing a CEO or a CFO

author: Q
sentence: That surprises me

author: Q
sentence: I assumed it would be more

author: A
sentence: Oh god no

author: A
sentence: No, no, no, no

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that's quite an interesting one

author: A
sentence: And I'm also on a state government-appointed board

author: Q
sentence: Quite often [unclear] 00:56:21

author: A
sentence: Yeah and quite often too the board will have a couple of people in the wings and the board often starts with all right we need to get somebody, a recruiter, but who knows somebody, put them into the recruitment, into the mix as part of the process

author: Q
sentence: Gee, that’s a good point

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that's great

author: Q
sentence: Do the boards that you're familiar with have any barriers do you think that you're aware of to managing or building diversity?  Well, you've mentioned supply

author: A
sentence: Other than supply

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, supply is really the is32D?

author: A
sentence: Well, accept that national one as I said, where they’re nominated appoint -

author: Q
sentence: Federation, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Federation nominations

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:57:01

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s a real formal network isn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Oh, it’s shocking

author: A
sentence: Well, it's not really, that’s the problem it’s not formal enough in some ways

author: A
sentence: But anyway

author: Q
sentence: They’re varied, aren’t they?  That's great

author: Q
sentence: Oh

author: Q
sentence: It’s not accountable?

author: A
sentence: No and there’s no formal arrangement between anybody, between the network and anyway – it’s terrible

author: A
sentence: And hence we’re in conflict

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, the conflict there can we go back to that then?

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: That’s political is it?

author: A
sentence: Totally

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: It’s about who -

author: A
sentence: Who’s controlling what

author: A
sentence: Who has a say, who’s allowed to – if we want to look at the constitution, should everyone be involved?  Look, it’s just a nightmare, it is political

author: A
sentence: I think it’s terribly political and a power play

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, there’s conflict but then there’s politics

author: A
sentence: In a federated organisation, there absolutely is at both the CEO and a board level

author: A
sentence: I like that

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: Do you think a state one where you’re appointed by ministers and various things, could there be conflict there do you think, due to politics?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: Well I have heard, and I don’t know whether this is true or not, but I have heard that I was appointed by the Labor Government and look my political persuasions are probably even further left than the Labor, so I don’t know that it had anything to do with that

author: A
sentence: But I did hear from somebody that they like you to have done some unpaid director work before the will appoint you to a – so you look like the kind of person is happy to give back, without being paid

author: A
sentence: Which I had before I got that appointment

author: A
sentence: But after I got that appointment someone said to me, “Oh yeah, that makes sense, because they like people to have that

author: A
sentence: ”  I don’t know whether that’s true or not, but yeah, I don’t know whether it’s – whereas maybe if the Liberal Party are in, maybe they don’t care about that

author: A
sentence: Maybe they just go, “Mate, get in there, do a job

author: A
sentence: ”  I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I don’t have enough visibility

author: Q

sentence: ”  I mean, I’d never been on a board, but I go, “This is not how a board operates

author: Q
sentence: As you know the research is about diversity of boards and we’re asking people who sit on boards and organisations that influence them, how they understand diversity and how it might best be managed; so thank you so much

author: A
sentence: What have - it’s a really difficult thing to answer in one way because there’s so many different things that you see

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a lot of evidence of boards out there being really focused on building a diverse board and you see particular focuses around bringing on gender - meeting gender diversity aspirations and I think there’s a certain sector of board too - probably more in the not-for-profit space that looks to have a representation of what their target client or member base is which I think to me, points to the fact that it’s not impossible if that’s a conscious decision that you’ve made at your board

author: A
sentence: The way that that program runs is that you have 12, and I mean we were the pilot group so we were kind of testing the model

author: A
sentence: You have 12 women with the chair and the chair’s role is to help prepare the group to make sure, you know, your CV’s ready, your value proposition’s ready, that you really clear on who you are and what value you bring to the table and where you’re going to target yourself

author: A
sentence: Then they bring a series of people to the table to talk to us about what we’re dealing with, where they see that we should focus, how they could help

author: A
sentence: There were directors who’d been on company boards when they’d gone through a crisis, women who’d been real leaders in the past in terms of breaking down the barriers and getting on to ASX boards, ASX experienced people like David Gonski who have been there and seen a lot of war stories

author: A
sentence: In terms of, did they tell us - not really because it was more about facilitating a conversation around the table of our collective experiences and supporting one another

author: A
sentence: It’s been a brilliant way of having a network to support other women

author: A
sentence: We’ve done a lot a work for one another since that ended last year, and introductions, and tips, and sharing information

author: A
sentence: I think that’s good

sentence: I’ll talk to you about that later

sentence: I need to - because you’ve got some great stuff -

author: A
sentence: Is it good?

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely, do you think that there's any situational context that might cause you to change that 10 rating?  That diversity’s not important, in a particular situation that the board might face?

author: A
sentence: In a particular situation?

author: Q
sentence: Or is it always important?

author: A
sentence: If you think about the role of the board, you’re there to govern and guide and help management achieve the best in terms of performance and success - whatever that success criteria is for the organisation

author: A
sentence: To me, that's a lot about asking questions and making decisions and to make, or to be involved in robust decision making, you need to have lots of different perspectives

author: A
sentence: So if you've got six people that all look largely the same, from the same privileged white Caucasian background - that I come from by the way

author: A
sentence: How are we going to make a good decision?  We’re going to make a decision that’s based on our bubble and I quite often have this conversation with my husband who’s also involved in a lot of boards, and you really can’t

author: A
sentence: It seems to be, to me, without facts and figures in front of me, it seems that the bigger end of town holds a lot of - or holds the most resistance to that focus on building a diverse board that is reflective of what your staff group or target client or member base is; or indeed the broader community

author: A
sentence: I don’t think anybody could argue the point anymore that diversity on a board increases performance of the organisation irrespective of what the performance, the success criteria in terms of performance for any organisation is

author: A
sentence: Even when we talk about things that are happening in our local community and you start to hear things about home invasions and people pulled up in the street and that lady who someone jumped in and drove off in her car with her baby in the backseat

author: A
sentence: It's really hard to fathom that that could happen in our street, it’s happening a few suburbs away but by the same token if you don't bring that thinking about these are the things that might happen, to the table and you’re only thinking about your very safe, happy little bubble; well how can you make a good decision without other people’s perspectives and life experiences?  So, no, I cannot think - very long answer, I’m really good at long answers- I cannot think of a situation that a board wouldn't benefit from diversity at the table

author: Q
sentence: That's pretty consistent

author: Q
sentence: I don’t think I’ve - one person has given a qualified yes, out of forty, I’ve interviewed

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I was going to ask you how many people you’re interviewing

author: A
sentence: I just can't think of one

author: A
sentence: And they say if you’re running something that's really ho-hum and there’s nothing changing, and you've got no challenges and you’re not looking for growth - maybe

author: Q
sentence: Is that a board?

author: A
sentence: There’s no pulse, it’s not alive

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly

sentence: Approach to problem solving is- like cognitive diversity is a term that’s out there and so [approach] 0:41:44

author: Q
sentence: 2 as problem solving - that diversity of that, that kind of diversity is seen as important by some people

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that’s important?

sentence: I think so

sentence: You’ve got diverse perspectives; this is approaches to problem solving, cognitive diversity

sentence: We had the woman with the acquired brain injury but she was presenting the perspective of people with disability rather than different ways of thinking

author: Q
sentence: Is that important, do you think - different ways of thinking?

author: A
sentence: Different ways of thinking

author: Q
sentence: Different approaches to problem solving

author: A
sentence: We’ve seen study after study after study pointing to that, so you really then beggar’s beliefs that not only are we not getting to reasonable equality in terms of gender diversity but as I was saying to you before the interview, I despair of how we’re going to reach true diversity of all groups within our community when we’ve had a topic that’s been talked about adnauseam for decades, and we still can’t even get what to me, looks like the simplest one and that is gender diversity

author: A
sentence: I don’t know what it is in my mind, but I'm not - I haven't got a different way of thinking about that particular element

author: Q
sentence: One person said to me people on boards -

author: A
sentence: Perhaps give me an example [overtalk] 0:42:49

author: Q
sentence: People on boards are often from backgrounds where they’re outcomes focussed, very much outcomes focussed, and the process thinker is very useful

author: A
sentence: Okay I get where you are coming from now

author: Q
sentence: So process thinking is very -

author: A
sentence: The system’s thinking, the problem solving

author: A
sentence: I guess for me, that is part of what you get by bringing diverse groups and experiences to the table

author: A
sentence: Because you’re right, some people see in very black and white, others will look at it from a systems perspective and you get to a very different approach

author: A
sentence: The other thing that's a really good way of thinking about things is to be more long term as well

author: A
sentence: One of the things that I've seen historically with boards and management teams and strategies is you kind of get this three to five year focus and you're might renew it annually; and there's been lots of conversations about keeping strategy live in the boardroom, keeping strategy live with the management team, and constantly reviewing it

author: A
sentence: To me that's very much a different way of thinking, other than a set and forget style of thinking

author: A
sentence: What I have been encouraging on the boards that I’m on is to think out to20 years

author: A
sentence: Because to me, that gives you another way of thinking, even for people who are black and white, it's yes or it's no, you’re in or you’re out, or you’re a systems thinker and think about where else you should planning or thinking or what else should you be thinking about?

author: A
sentence: I think broadening out that to a 20 years scenario - and I had a very real example of that, with our private health insurance -  by thinking out to 20 years, we're all of a sudden instead of thinking that we need to deal with government reforms and the potential two percent gap that the labour government was proposing as part of their election platform, and looking at what all the changes in terms of prosthesis costs and inflation and the cost of medical technology - you sort of think about all these things and what's going to happen in five years, how we’re going to deal with it

author: Q
sentence: Do you think the same barriers to gender diversity impact other kinds of diversity?

author: A
sentence: All of a sudden with that 20 year mandate, well we might not be here but what do we want the organisation to be?  And that opens up thinking and people who I had seen very much drill down into the numbers or down into the what do we do to engage with the community

author: A
sentence: We’re all of a sudden thinking more broadly and we changed our strategy from - I can’t even remember what we used to call our longer term vision but it was pretty ordinary; and now it’s all about being the number one regional private health insurer in Australia

author: A
sentence: Now without that20 year perspective, we wouldn't have got to that position

author: A
sentence: We might have said we want to be the leading regional insurer in Victoria maybe, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: But we’ve now got a board and a management team that is open to so many different conversations and different ways of thinking

author: A
sentence: So to me, that again, maybe that goes to your cognitive diversity -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: That’s a really nice - nice Participant 33D, very good

author: A
sentence: Once I understood the question, I had an answer

author: Q
sentence: Well you make your own sense of the question because I mean these are just terms, different ways of probing, understanding the diversity that - yep, that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s a - you know, we’ve now talked about a lot of different kinds of diversity, is there a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others or are they -

author: A
sentence: What kind of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Does it depend or the -

author: A
sentence: Particular kind of diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s a really hard one to answer because I don't think you can section out any one group, or gender, or sector and say one’s more important than the other

author: A
sentence: I think it's about getting the mix right and in a very, I guess, simple approach I think is that skills matrix to me, and as I mentioned earlier, I think if you focused on, here’s our board - sorry here's our organisation, here’s our strategy and what we want to achieve, here are the skills that we think we need at our board and management level, and from a board perspective here’s our skills matrix, what have we got; and be really honest about what you're good at and what you’re not so good at

author: A
sentence: To me, you’re going to get the diversity factors that are the most reflective of what your organisation needs

author: A
sentence: I think to say that one group’s more important than the other is not a simple answer because I think the answer is it depends on your organisation and what it’s setting out to achieve, what diversity factors might be more important to you

author: Q
sentence: So the purpose of the organisation and depends whether you’re framing it 20 years from now or three to five; so your premise - your systems thinking and an outcomes focus, because you might use your - because we’re thinking - we’re developing a model and so I’m trying to addend - people are saying in to something that could be modelled

author: A
sentence: In my mind, I think other kinds of diversity are going to be up against an even tougher climb uphill

author: A
sentence: I think it becomes a real struggle against people’s unconscious bias, I think

author: A
sentence: Because there seems to be general conversations that you have that, well what do we do if we’re going to have a diverse board?  Do we really need to go out and get one Asian, one black person, make sure that somebody’s from a tech savvy background and how can we possibly have a 25 year old on our board?

author: A
sentence: I’ve seen great things happen

author: A
sentence: When I did my MBA, it was when I was first exposed to the thought or the theory of systems thinking and it really blew my mind, particularly in the role that I had with VMIA, but also in the management roles I had before that

author: A
sentence: I think that systems thinking filter gives you that, I guess, that frame to start to make sure you’re considering all the things you need to consider

author: A
sentence: One of the things I found in my role at VMIA is there’s some really smart people in state government departments, and there's also a tendency for operating in a silo, and even within the organisations that sit around that; just this kind of silo approach to I’m doing my job and they’re doing really good work and they’re working really hard but that ability to sit up and think about, “Well how can we work together?”  And I’ve seen that first hand at [VBA] 0:49:28

author: A
sentence: 1 in particular; that making it almost a mandated thing to collaborate

author: A
sentence: When we brought in a new CEO and the conversations we were having at board and with the management team was around we can’t just stay in our universe here and do a great job

author: A
sentence: If we don't talk to other people, that doesn't matter so much

author: A
sentence: So it’s around collaborating with other regulators, collaborating with our lead department, collaborating with the insurer

author: A
sentence: I’ve seen it in private health insurance which is now regulated by AHPRA

author: A
sentence: There was a real fear factor around, “Don't go near the regulator, we don't want to get noticed

author: A
sentence: ”  Because I’d worked really closely with regulators, I’m like, “Yeah let's go and meet with the regulator

author: A
sentence: We need them to know who we are you and have confidence and trust in us because they’re new to regulating this space too; let’s be part of the conversation

author: A
sentence: ” So that kind of don’t just play you're part in the universe, bring in others around you and seek to engage and I think everyone ends up all the better for it

author: Q
sentence: You talked about the purpose defining getting the mix right, well then it's the view of how do you view your organisation in relation to broader players, stakeholders or whatever -

author: A
sentence: You are not the system, you’re a part in it - you’re a little cog

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and they that might think, “We need some people who understand regulation

author: A
sentence: Whereas is you’re sitting there thinking, “Don’t go near the regulator”, well -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you’re getting the mix right, you won’t have anyone who understands regulation because you’re keeping away from them, they’re not part of you

author: A
sentence: So it’s almost a dismissive - some of the conversations I’ve had there’s been almost a dismissive approach to diversity rather than a let’s embrace it for the value that we could get from it

author: A
sentence: Yeah, not going to talk to them

sentence: So that’s another part of your model, exactly

sentence: Now I've got some questions on board functioning and managing diversity
