author: Q
sentence: Do you think - well how do you think that diversity can contribute to conflict on boards?

author: A
sentence: I think that comes back to culture

author: A
sentence: If the board doesn't promote the right culture and it also comes back to something I referred to earlier around inclusion

author: A
sentence: So if you don’t overtly - and I think this is the board's role, as it is with everything

author: A
sentence: If the board doesn’t lead by example and set the time at the tone at the top, how on earth is the management team or the organisation going to reflect that cultural need for inclusion

author: A
sentence: If you don’t have that inclusion factor working well then diversity’s dead anyway because it's just a whole bunch of people, isn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: And then it’s conflict

author: A
sentence: Not feeling empowered or I think, if you’ve got people who are disengaged, that in itself promotes conflict

author: A
sentence: I think at the board it’s really important to have a chair who encourages input from everybody and really sets the scene from the start that I will be seeking the views of each director

author: A
sentence: Thankfully in my experience, I’ve got chairs who do actually do that and they start out with - particularly on the strategic items, I’ll go around the table and get everybody’s view

author: A
sentence: Sometimes that falls in to there’s a lot of people talking about not too much, but it's also creating that space where - and I think the chair is really integral to this, creating that space where he or she is going to make it clear that they're coming around to get your views, but also making it clear if the person before you said what you wanted to say, you don't have to add something else to it for the sake of it

author: A
sentence: So making it okay for you to go, “Agree with everything that's been said, haven't got anything else to add

author: A
sentence: I think we're on the right track

author: A
sentence: ”  Or, “I agree with those two points but maybe on the third one we should also think about - or how much we look at”, kind of leading on rather than repeating or saying something because you feel the need because they’re going around the table

author: A
sentence: Make it safe to say nothing further

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and that shows listening by other directors which is part of inclusion, you listen to other people’s points of view, I guess

author: A
sentence: With this interview coming up, I’ve been very conscious of asking other directors that I’m on boards with just - not specifically from the perspective of I’m doing an interview what can you tell me, but just to get a sense of what people are currently thinking because it changes from time to time

author: A
sentence: I’ve had some fellow female directors citing recent examples of an ASX board that one particular lady I know is on, recruiting for two new directors and in her view, one role just screams out for being a really good fit to a female background in skills and experience, and she said and the second one when they’re looking at their skills matrix, could fit either or

author: A
sentence: They’ve got eight men to interview and two women

author: A
sentence: And that’s coming through whatever recruitment agent they’re working with and she was appalled for having just joined this board a few months ago, to look at it from the point of view that we’ve got 10 people that are all of a similar age group and cultural background, and out of those we’ve got eight men and two women and a recruitment firm saying there are no women

author: A
sentence: And management notice that

author: A
sentence: Management notice how directors interact

author: A
sentence: We all sit there and you know you forget that you are - we sometimes can forget that people really look up and look to the board for leadership and for setting an example

author: A
sentence: I think directors really need to understand their role in sending a really clear message that if they’re behaving badly at the board table, well you’re not going to - you can’t expect inclusion across the organisation, it’s just not going to happen

author: A
sentence: That filters down in a heartbeat, bad behaviour at the board table

author: Q
sentence: So it really is setting the tone at the top

author: Q
sentence: Have you an example of when conflict or suppression of voices occurred?  Have you got an example to help us understand that?

author: A
sentence: I’ve got a few examples of that

author: A
sentence: I'm just trying to think about the link back into diversity rather than it’s just bad behaviour

author: Q
sentence: This is a culture then that is against hearing different perspectives?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I guess on a no names, no 0:55:27

author: A
sentence: 3, I’ve been involved in a board where the model was managing director rather than CEO and board, and that kind of - I'm actually a fan of the CEO and the board model

author: A
sentence: I think it frees the board up to have, in a lot of cases, broader conversations

author: A
sentence: And I also -

author: Q
sentence: So what’s the difference?

author: A
sentence: Well managing director, you’re the CEO and you’re on the board

author: Q
sentence: You’re actually a member of the board, right

author: A
sentence: Yeah, rather than reporting to the board

author: A
sentence: So there’s lots of arguments for and against that but this particular case that I’m reflecting on, the managing director - in the role for quite a long time, quite bullying behaviour with his management team and I could see that in the way that if the managers were - well they came to the board meetings, but if they were asked questions that you can see them looking to the managing director to answer them first

author: A
sentence: So however it had happened, they were pretty clear on the fact that they didn’t open their mouth unless the managing director said it was okay

author: A
sentence: What I saw there was a board that lacked life

author: A
sentence: I think were quite fearful of the managing director and it meant that the board wasn't getting the information from the management team or the managing director that it needed to undertake its role, and whenever we tried to get pieces of information there was push back on it

author: A
sentence: It was just meant the organisation was going to fail, ultimately

author: A
sentence: Where in her view, the roles that they’re looking for and the skills that they identified on their board skills matrix are absolutely suitable to a female executive background or a female board member’s background, and that’s what’s coming to the tables

author: A
sentence: So you also question what’s the role of - or what could the role and the value of recruitment agencies be?  There is a core group of recruiters that are quite active in director roles and what are they experience and what role can they play in helping to shift this

author: A
sentence: She actually challenged her board on the fact that we’ve got no diversity here, let alone gender diversity, and the board were quite - or the other members of this board that were on the interview panel were quite comfortable with the recruiter’s done their best and they’ve only turned up two women, so there’s not enough women out there who are looking for these roles

author: A
sentence: Thankfully there are a lot of changes made, but if that had of been allowed to go on, you know that was an absolute perfect example of a lack of diversity, a lack of inclusion; the board had no role, and indeed the management team had no role other than to do what the managing director said

author: A
sentence: So you’re running a whole organisation on the mandate for you on perspective of one person

author: A
sentence: I don’t care how brilliant you are, you’re not going to have the answer to the universe

author: A
sentence: So to me, that a really -

author: Q
sentence: That’s the antithesis

author: A
sentence: I was going to say it’s a fabulous example, it’s a terrible example but it really proved to me that without the right information, without robust discussion, without consideration of other views, you’re not know doing - you’ve got no hope of fulfilling the mandate of the board, of a director’s role; and indeed, the board role

author: Q
sentence: It’s really a good example

author: A
sentence: Fun to be a part of fixing; it actually is; it’s very rewarding to be a part of fixing and seeing the management team shine

author: Q
sentence: So did you see it when, I presume the managing director was removed; did you see it through?

author: A
sentence: Hm

author: Q
sentence: How did it [unclear] 0:58:51

author: Q
sentence: 2, let’s see the transformation then

author: A
sentence: The transformation is profound by taking that one person out, bringing in a CEO, setting the scene, being completely open and honest about the history, the culture, the problems that we’re going to be need to be dealt with

author: A
sentence: Absolute transparency with the management team about what expectations are for the future; really working at bringing in other experts to the table to really quickly broaden out our mind on strategy

author: A
sentence: Getting the CEO engaged in - find all the problems, bringing out all the bodies, get them all out, work out what we’re dealing with here and you know that’s less than 12 months down the track and just looks like a different place to be

author: A
sentence: You’ve got managers bringing papers to the board that are well thought out, insightful, encouraging discussion, open to feedback

author: A
sentence: You know directors now are kind of sitting up and a whole new less of life

author: A
sentence: So again, that takes me back to, if we can’t get that even reflective in who are we interviewing, how then do you start to bring different cultural backgrounds, abled, disabled points of view youth

author: A
sentence: I think one of the other factors that you look around a board table, there’s always that kind of - and maybe this is a little bit cliché - but there’s always the accountant, the lawyer, the subject manner expert; and if you’re going to take that approach, where’s the innovation expert?  Where’s the person with the technology expertise?  The reason we don’t see those, in my view, on boards, is because that people with those skills are younger and boards, I don’t think in the main have figured how to bring younger people through that world

author: A
sentence: There’s almost a perception that you must have been a CEO, you must have run enormous organisation to bring value to the conversation

author: A
sentence: To me, the board is a collaboration and whilst you all need to be across governance, whilst you all need to be across finance and be accountable for what the organisation that you’re charged with governing an oversight, you don’t need to be an accountant, you need to be a lawyer, you don’t need to have run a massive organisation in the [C-suite] 0:08:12

author: A
sentence: 9 to bring value to that conversation, if you have got the other competencies that you need to be a good director

author: A
sentence: But there’s no - to my mind, I’m seeing very little evidence of that in people’s thinking

author: A
sentence: It’s oh no they’re too young, how can we possibly bring them in?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, so this is your cognitive diversity, this is an example of how it was closed down by this tyrannical thinking and then remove that and you’ve got -

author: A
sentence: And we’ve got general managers now coming up to directors at the end of the meeting and saying we love this, this is fantastic, we’re so glad we stuck it out and you’re doing everything you said you would do, we’re so glad we’re still here

author: A
sentence: And that’s great

author: A

author: Q

author: A
sentence: Nice, might be fun and easily to be a part of; but then, I'm much more interested in having a conversation where people bring different views to the table

author: A
sentence: That’s another thing that I love about being on a board, that I can read a board pack and I always try and single out the top 3 or 4 things that I think I can add value to the conversation or that I want to ask question on or focus on, and there’ll be some things where I’ll think that one’s a no brainer, tick tick, right, look forward to hearing management’s update on that and we’ll being approving that and then I hear three other people say, “Hold on a minute, what about”, and I’m like, “Yeah, wow

author: Q
sentence: That’s really easy, yeah

sentence: If you have a collegiate, I’m just going to agree what the person next to me said rather than challenge it

author: A
sentence: Again you’re losing the potential value that people bring

sentence: Yeah, that’s great

sentence: That’s the consistent three - now I’m interesting in these values fit

author: A
sentence: Well most organisations focus for plenty of years now on defining what the values of the organisation are

author: Q
sentence: The values of the organisation

author: A
sentence: So there's that element and to me, being in a board role you need -in my view you need to have a sense of alignment or care factor about what the organisation is doing to bring your A game

author: A
sentence: There's a lot of work you know when you come down to an hourly rate for a board role, you know, probably get more in a fish and chip shop but that’s not why we do it, is it?

author: A
sentence: So I think that sort of underlining alignment of your own personal values with the stated values of the organisation is important

author: A
sentence: So to me, I find that the engagement with directors if you come from that similar values approach is stronger because you’ve all got the care factor that’s driving you, and that’s different from collegiality

sentence: I used to be dead against them

author: A
sentence: I used to think that was - I used to think as a race we’d evolved enough not to need targets and mandates, but now I think if we haven't evolved enough to just do the right thing then maybe we do need a rule book that says - you know, set them

author: A
sentence: Again, I’ve heard a few blokes go, “You know I can never get a role now because all they want is women

author: A
sentence: ”  I’m like, “Isn’t that terrible, imagine how we felt when all they would hire is men

author: A
sentence: ”  “Oh yeah

author: A
sentence: Look, it seems to me again, its 2019, why the hell do we need them; but we do

author: A
sentence: It hasn’t happened without them

author: A
sentence: Maybe we do just to get it from zero to hero and then maybe we can see the value of it and it will just happen in time

author: A
sentence: But to me, we need them

author: A
sentence: I hate to think that we need them but we do

author: Q
sentence: So what is it acting against - before the last question

author: Q
sentence: What do you think those targets and quotas - what are they influencing?  What barrier are they working against?

author: A
sentence: Working against?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah what are they -

author: A
sentence: What’s my journey?  It hasn’t been easy

author: A
sentence: One of things that I’ been really surprised at is - and this is again, I've spoken to some other male and female directors and there’s a bit of a sense that there’s quite a group of influential great female board directors but not all of them will put their hand out and help the next generation coming through

author: A
sentence: What are they coming up against?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, what are they coming up - because - they’re needed because there’s something working against achieving these targets otherwise they wouldn’t be needed

author: A
sentence: Maybe it comes back to that unconscious bias factor where people think you know someone else's fixing it or they're not really - the conversation we had earlier about perhaps we’re not aware of what the problem is

author: A
sentence: What are we working against?  It's not one thing, it's so many factors

author: A
sentence: There is still some directors who say you don’t need diversity to make good decisions

author: A
sentence: There are still some directors who think you don't need women, that you don't need different cultures, that we know what we're doing, look how successful we are

author: A
sentence: So you've got that, to the gentleman I was talking about who’s there trying to build density at board space but not completely across all the factors that are meaning that we’re not getting there

author: A
sentence: Yeah that's a massive question

author: Q
sentence: That systems thinking verses- and also then the other stuff you were talking about which was more cultural, women's views of themselves and their preparedness - readiness for boards and challenges

author: A
sentence: What are we working against?  Everything we just talked about

author: Q
sentence: Exactly let’s just dot point the above

author: Q
sentence: Okay so it’s multi-levelled?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful, final question

author: Q
sentence: Ten years in to the future, I thought that was a long way, you said 20 but anyway, if you want

author: Q
sentence: How would you like to see the diversity with Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: How would I like to see - that it was no long part of the conversation, but was just happening

author: A
sentence: I would like to think that we’re going to be in a world where anybody who aspires to be on a board and has the requisite governance, skills, experience and knowledge, can put their hand up and find a place

author: A
sentence: That it is - I think I used this term earlier, that it’s a right not a fight, for everybody

author: A
sentence: At the moment it’s a right, not a fight for a certain sector

author: A
sentence: Yeah, 10 years - that’s [overtalk] 1:09:16

author: A
sentence: I’ve actually had some quite overt conversations with people because how did I get on and how did I get my roles is I networked, networked and did more networking; I know where all the best coffees are in Melbourne and Sydney

author: A
sentence: What I’ve been truly surprised at is the low level of preparedness for people who are in positions that could help others, of evidence of putting their hand out

author: Q
sentence: What needs to be done to for this to happen?

author: A
sentence: What needs to be done?  In a funny way I think that men are a much bigger part of the solution then we might like to think and I think if we can work by getting the gender issue addressed, that perhaps the lessons from that can help drive the other diversity factors

author: A
sentence: I think honest and upfront engagement by people in positions of influence and particularly men, I think can drive and challenge each other; I don’t think they see that need to

author: A
sentence: So perhaps encouraging - there’s an ad on television at the moment, it’s about sexual harassment and there’s a girl sitting on a train and some guys ogling at her, and another man sees it happening and then, doesn't do anything violent or combative but just steps in between his line of sight

author: A
sentence: I think men and women, but I think particularly men because there’s more of them in these positions at the moment, I think looking to see where are the opportunities where they can stand up for somebody

author: A
sentence: If they challenge when there’s a situation like my friends had recently where the recruitment company has only brought two women to the table

author: A
sentence: So, go away and get me 50/50

author: A
sentence: You know, I had a fabulous CEO in my last executive role who - he and I went to meet with a really large multi-national insurance company and he and I were the representatives from our organisation and four guys flew down from Sydney to meet with us

author: A
sentence: The very first thing that he said after the introductions, you know, this is who, who - so haven’t you got any women in this department?  Just in a nice tone, probably nicer than I just used

author: A
sentence: And they all looked and went, “Yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: ”  Then they tried to name one

author: A
sentence: He said, "Well I'm really surprised that I've got four men to meet with today

author: A
sentence: And he sort of turned and he said, “Because we've got 50/50 here and that's what we expect of all the service providers

author: A
sentence: So after we’ve had this conversation today, if we decide to keep dealing with one another that's part of the requirement

author: A
sentence: I want 50/50 women and men at the table

author: A
sentence: ”  He did it in a way where I thought, “Bloody hell that’s not hard is it?”  You can just say it

author: A
sentence: Don’t bring me four blokes, where are your women?

author: Q
sentence: But if you had said it, it would have sounded - the message -

author: A
sentence: I would have sounded like a whining female

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, it would have been a -

author: A
sentence: Which takes me back to my comment of I think there’s a really big role for men to play here and how do we let them know that it's not that hard

author: A
sentence: It is stepping in front of the pervert on the train; it is saying that we’re sitting in a meeting -

author: Q
sentence: Other women?

author: Q
sentence: Believe it

author: A
sentence: - where are your women?  We're talking about an issue that affects youth, where’s a young person, how are you getting that view

author: A
sentence: Just being a bit more overt in what they’re prepared to - what they’re not prepared to accept

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, this is leadership isn’t it?  So leadership, because I could imagine there would be some situation s where a woman may be in a position of power to call it

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: But even to your comment [Margot] 1:13:00

author: A
sentence: 1, if a woman had of - if I had of said that -

author: Q
sentence: In that because it was a gender issue

author: Q
sentence: But if it’s not a gender issue -

author: A
sentence: It’s not a gender issue, yeah look, everyone’s got a role to play

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, and that situation - I didn’t want to say the victim but you know what I mean, the disempowered one in the group and that the issue being called out, this minority is being is being disrespected in - if the minority speaks, it’s a very different voice -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: - to if others Say, “Hey come on mate

author: A
sentence: I think that’s what needs to change, people need to stand up and be explicit about what they’re not prepared to accept

author: A
sentence: Other women in particular

author: A
sentence: Somebody flippantly said to me, “Maybe they’re not seeing you as the right fit for their boards?”  And I said, “But I’m not actually asking them to put me on the board

author: A
sentence: ”  Sometimes when you ask them for an introduction to somebody else in their network or you’re sitting having a networking meeting with them and they’ll say, “Yes, I can help you do rah, rah, rah, and I’ll introduce you to these three people

author: A
sentence: ”  Then following them up after the meeting, it doesn’t happen, and I’m not about to stalk people, so you just give it up if it hasn’t happened after the first time

author: Q
sentence: That is fantastic, thank you so much

author: A
sentence: You're welcome

author: Q
sentence: It was really good

author: A
sentence: It was really good to get my brain working on something different too

author: A
sentence: On the flipside of that, I’ve been for interviews and where I’ve gotten down to the final group of selection for a particular board role and - actually only four months ago I got down to the final two and missed out specifically because they stuck to their skills matrix analysis which I admire

author: A
sentence: I think that’s a very smart way of bringing on new board directors and the feedback that I got from the chair of that particular board was that she would have hired me in a heartbeat because she loved the syncing and the intellect and the experience that I brought to the table, but because they’d just lost their main grassroots banker, and they’re a bank, they really needed to bring in grassroots banking to bolster up their skill set

author: A
sentence: She asked if she could keep in touch with me which I thought, “Yeah okay, fine, I like you

author: A
sentence: I only met you in the interview

author: A
sentence: ”  But she has since followed me up three or four times

author: A
sentence: I’ve seen her at different events around the place

author: A
sentence: I saw at the AICD 30% event

author: A
sentence: She’s introduced me to three other people in banking networks that chair other member based banks

author: A
sentence: We’ve kept a conversation going and she’s really gone out of her way to do those things, it wasn’t something that she just did in five minutes, she’s drafted individual email introductions for me to these other people; when I met her at the networking event she specifically knew who I’d met with, what we discussed, and to me that’s what I would aspire to be

author: A
sentence: I do what I can on a tiny little level with my credibility in early stage and being a non-executive director

author: A
sentence: But somebody who’s in a position of influence like the chair of quite a large member based bank, has really gone out of her way and that gives me heart that there’s hope in there

author: A
sentence: But this is why it’s such a difficult question because you can’t say yes, people do this or no they don’t, there’s such a mix

author: A
sentence: And I think we’ve just boiled down to the fact that we need more of it in order to - you can’t successfully stage a movement without enough people moving in the right direction, can you?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly and this phenomena with some women of not helping the young, cultivate the young, and yet others do

author: A
sentence: In total I’ve been a board director for around about six years and the last three years it’s been my full-time role

author: A
sentence: Well I had another lady - strangely enough I’ve ended up - I targeted getting on a private health insurance board and I’m on a private health insurance board which is fantastic, I love it

author: A
sentence: All men by the way, I’m the first woman, and to their credit we’re looking to bring another director on later this year and we’re already talking about here’s our skills matrix, what else do we need

author: A
sentence: And the chair has said we must hire another woman

author: A
sentence: He said, “I don’t care if the best man on the planet lands and says he wants to be on this board, we’ve got one woman now, we’ve had - Participant 33D’s joined the board two years ago, we need to have another woman, we need to find somebody that we can bring on to the board to keep the balance happening

author: A
sentence: ”  I then cheekily threw out, “Well let’s make sure she’s young

author: A
sentence: ”  And they’re like, “Why?”  I said, “Because we’re all old

author: A
sentence: Having that kind of conversation around here’s our skills matrix, we’d really like to get somebody who’s been involved in a community engagement role, we’d really like her to be a woman and then I’ve thrown in there let’s make sure - we’re all 50 and 60-something, let’s try and see if we can find somebody in her 40s, just to spread it out a bit

author: A
sentence: That to me is really heartening, particularly because that board is made up of older men who have had a very staple board in terms of there’s people there that have probably been there a little bit too long

author: Q
sentence: Which is more than 10 years?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, like 20, 25 years

author: A
sentence: So you could in some ways look at that and think well they’re probably of the demographics that are going to be more resistant to change but they’re embracing it

author: Q
sentence: Why do you think?  [Overtalk] 0:15:00

author: A
sentence: I think they’re smart enough to recognise that - they all come from different backgrounds as most boards do, but I think they’ve got the nous to understand that private health, we’re promoting ourselves as a regional community focused organisation, done a lot of work on culture and values over the last two years and I think they’re all recognising that if we want to be famous for community engagement well we better reflect the community

author: A
sentence: It’s a start, having two females -

author: Q
sentence: Strategic decision, yep

author: A
sentence: - and four males isn’t the best balance in the world but it’s a start

author: A
sentence: The Victorian government put themselves out there in terms of having a 50% target and essentially just did it

author: A
sentence: Now there’s also an argument that I’ve heard, I think even at the AICD, I’ve heard it articulated that, well we’ve done that but they’ve put women on to some pretty low level community based boards to get to that number

author: A
sentence: Okay, it might not be perfect, but it sends a really strong signal doesn’t it, to the broader community that this is something we care about

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and it’s cultivating skills

author: Q
sentence: It’s like training wheels

author: Q
sentence: Wow, okay

author: Q
sentence: How many boards do you sit on?

author: A
sentence: Yeah and I think some of those community boards, not-for-profits base is some of the hardest work you ever get to do

author: Q
sentence: Politics, yeah

author: A
sentence: And lack of support around you to do some of the non-director style work, it’s more of a roll your sleeves up universe in some cases

author: Q
sentence: You’ve worked in that space?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I have

author: A
sentence: More in an executive role where I’ve seen that happen and worked with training and upskilling and building governance skills for boards on some of those community sector organisations

author: A
sentence: Because largely they’re manned, in my experience at least, the people that I’ve worked with come to the table with a lot of, I guess [domain] 0:16:54

author: A
sentence: 0 experience and they’re driven by a particular passion for an organisation wanting to be a part of providing a solution but don’t necessarily bring the governance and board skills to the table with them

author: A
sentence: That can be a pretty tough gig, bringing yourself up to speed with that and working in an organisation that runs on the smell of an oily rag

author: Q
sentence: Yeah and you might have another job as well, or two

author: A
sentence: Yes, being prepared for a crisis

author: Q
sentence: Your background is you work in governance, what’s your background?

author: A
sentence: My background’s financial services

author: A
sentence: Sorry, I grew up in general management, financial services roles

author: A
sentence: Throughout my career though I really focused on looking for challenging opportunities to lead projects to get involved in whatever new was coming in that space as financial services reform projects and I worked for a non-bank lender that wanted to grow in to general insurance; so just looking for those, I guess, growth and performance improvement projects

author: A
sentence: My last executive role was with Victorian Managed Insurance Authority and that was servicing risk management in insurance services for all the state departments in our agencies

author: A
sentence: So that gave me, I think, a pretty good background to translate into board world, because I’ve been involved in not only that kind of, how do you grow and build performance of an organisation in my general management roles but with VMIA how do you manage risk and looking at diverse organisations, and how is that all managed across this whole enormous group of entities that could be a tiny community service organisation or could be the Department of Health and Human Services

author: A
sentence: At the moment I’m on four, and they’re a mix

author: A
sentence: I’ve got two government boards, one private health insurer and one private education organisation

author: A
sentence: So it really gives you a good strategic focus on what are the drivers for the organisation, where do you need to focus, what are the sorts of questions you need to be asking

author: A
sentence: And even as a manager in helping those clients build and develop, specifically with a focus on risk management; but I was always blown away by if you just kept asking questions, the things that you find out about what their real problems are and what you need to do in terms of improving or finding a solution

author: A
sentence: Yeah, ask questions and to me, that translates in to board work really well because you just can’t take anything on face value

author: A
sentence: You just have to keep asking questions the whole time, which in terms of diversity, one of the things that I’ve focused on in my board roles is understanding what the diversity policy is

author: A
sentence: In some cases they haven’t existed and more recently I’ve started to think about it from an inclusion point of view

author: A
sentence: So rather than just saying well we need to have a diverse board, a diverse management team, a diverse - reflect the diversity of the community and our employment practices and what our organisation has in terms of the team, the people that it employs

author: A
sentence: But if we bring them all to the table, but they don’t feel part of the conversation, what’s the point?

author: A
sentence: So it’s all around - and I’ve been reading some great things about people with autism being brought in to organisations because they’ve got really strong skills in mathematics and technology systems and that kind of - I don’t say this flippantly but it sounds flippant - that kind of Rain Man focus on the number crunching side of the world

author: A
sentence: But then the challenge is how do we make sure that we make those people feel included and that the rest of the organisation or community don’t just kind of treat them as a little offshoot, make them feel part of the organisation

author: A
sentence: So I think there’s lots of really interesting benefits that we can gain from bringing in people who we typically see as different and treating them as just another part of the community

author: Q
sentence: Do you think they need to be on the board or can they be brought in as consultants?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, good question

author: A
sentence: Again, I - with that roadblock I was talking about before around the age and bringing the skills that people might have in innovation and technology

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a really strong case for having advisory boards working in alongside the board, so not necessarily part of the entire board, I guess, agenda

author: A
sentence: But like we focus of strategy up front in board meetings, or should; bringing in experts as an advisory committee for, you know, let’s have a look at artificial intelligence, what might that do for us?  Just having a topic for an advisory committee to be a part of and to participate in the board and that would also enable us to see the benefit of different cultures, different ages, different backgrounds and if a board can get the conversation going there and see the value, well perhaps that will help in time to bring different diversity factors in to the mainstream board world

author: A
sentence: I think that would be a great way for pale, stale males to see that it’s not all about them

author: A
sentence: And I say that with a smile on my face because I hear that pale, stale male a lot, but they’re not all like that

author: A
sentence: They can be pale, male and exciting sometimes too

author: Q
sentence: But it can always get tired so you need that bit of additional information, bit of insight

author: A
sentence: And look, I think there are a lot of great blokes out there doing good things too, so we can’t - that’s the thing, you can’t speak in generalisations, can you?

author: Q
sentence: Male champions have changed

author: Q
sentence: I’ve been interviewing some of them and they’re amazing

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and women on boards

author: A
sentence: I did their program last year which was the ASX board ready program that they’re doing with women and I was part of the pilot group for that and we had a chair, John [Bread]0:23:09

author: A
sentence: 1, who’s been on a number of ASX boards, great guy, no nonsense, but he brought together over the series of eight sessions that we had with him, a wonderful group of people who were all prepared to sit around the table with twelve women and we treated it a bit like a boardroom meeting

author: Q
sentence: None of these are - private health insurance is for profit?

author: A
sentence: They were all really open in terms of their support, so people like David Gonski or someone from a recruiter in Sydney; so from all different sort of stages and credibility levels, and that's an example of people who are in those positions being able to really help people move and progress into different roles and they also had a really good focus on bringing people - there was a lady there that had an acquired brain injury

author: A
sentence: She told us right up front she said, “I'll probably say things that you’ll think I’m rude

author: A
sentence: I’m not rude, I had a really bad car accident I've got - I had a terrible brain injury and I’m fine, but sometimes I don't process things as others might

author: A
sentence: Sometimes you know once you know that and she’s up front and open about it everybody gets it and I think that was a really good example of us firsthand experiencing how somebody else can interact and provide just as much value as the rest of us did, but recognizing what her difference is

author: A
sentence: I still remember one of the other ladies saying, “Yeah well I’m really direct, people call me rude too, don't worry about it

author: Q
sentence: So this woman who had a acquired brain injury, she's already been on boards?  Because I met an organisation, I’m doing some research in that space and I met - different research, and I met an organisation in New South Wales that is actually about facilitating people with acquired brain injury or cognitive disability to have a voice at all levels, so it's very interesting to hear completely out of the blue, women on boards running a program for ASX ready directors that you had someone who identifies with having an acquired brain injury, brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So that difference is not why she’d be on the board though?

author: A
sentence: Well that difference is the reason she was on one of her boards, because one of her boards was - and this is where I talk about some of these specific focused disability or health based boards, typically have somebody who has experienced whatever their core mandate is, so she was on a board that was focused on support for people with acquired brain injury

author: A
sentence: Then you see things, my husband was on a board - was it disability - the name of it absolutely escapes me at the moment because it was quite a few years ago, but it was a disability focus and so I remember him saying that they had three people around the table and one person always had her guide dog with her because she had very limited sight, and there was somebody else there who was in a wheelchair, so that disability focus they brought people to the table as part of the board who had firsthand experience with the issues that they were trying to provide a better world for and solutions for

author: A
sentence: That shows you the value of diversity and whilst there’s specific for their experience with the disability or health issue, what's the difference in terms of what any organisations ultimately offering in terms of product or service to the community

author: A
sentence: Those people live in the community too, so why not get their perspective?

author: Q
sentence: She was targeting an ASX company?  So that wouldn’t be focusing specifically on disability services, would it?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: So she is pushing to get through to the broader corporate world, that’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: A really good example

author: A
sentence: There was another girl in that group who was targeting mining which we were all going, “How on earth are you going to break in to a mining board

author: A
sentence: ”  She has

author: A
sentence: It’s technically not-for-profit because it’s a member based organisation, but it’s, I think largely run with more of a commercial focus

author: Q
sentence: That's wonderful, was she an engineer?

author: A
sentence: She came from a legal background and a lot of her legal work had been done with companies that are created internationally in mining and resources

author: A
sentence: So she had a lot of knowledge about it, but again, that’s kind of an industry that is known for blokes

author: A
sentence: But she really sold herself on the fact that she used to say, “Give me my steel cap boots and a hard hat, take me out to the mine”, she found someone who obviously liked her style and liked her approach and I think they’ll do really well having her on board

author: Q
sentence: It’s brilliant, I wonder if she will bring other women?

author: A
sentence: Well she was the one that I was telling you about with the eight men, two women to interview, so she's really pushing for other women

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant, okay

author: Q
sentence: So how important do you think it is for diversity? Let's say one’s not important at all and ten is extremely important?

author: A
sentence: Diversity, I think it’s a 10

author: A
sentence: To me, it’s a no brainer

author: A
sentence: If you were operating in the world providing a product or service to the community, you need to - whether it's on your board or whether it's on advisory members, or however you go about bringing those voices to the table, I think you’re crazy not to

author: Q
sentence: Can we drill down on this a little more?  With the advisory, the role of an advisory to bring in perspectives from - diverse perspectives verses having diversity within the board decision makers

author: Q
sentence: How can we work out when to have some diversity - It’s okay to rely on advisory or consultants for this but we want diversity around the table, the board

author: Q
sentence: When do you do it?

author: A
sentence: I guess to me, I see it as the thin edge of the wedge and then if we’ve got so many road blocks and conscious or unconscious biases towards having a board that reflects the broader community that we operate in and live in; to me, as I was saying earlier, if we did have a world that could at least open itself up to the advisory board, I think that would help build the case for the value

author: A
sentence: To me it’s not either or, it’s that -

author: Q
sentence: Developmental stage maybe?

author: A
sentence: - another way of looking for how you can start to have that conversation

author: A
sentence: For me, when I'm looking at the boards that I’m on and have any influence with, they’re the sorts of things that I would talk about

author: Q
sentence: Of course

author: Q
sentence: So we’re not-for-profit really, across these

author: Q
sentence: You sit on four and a director for six years

author: A
sentence: There's no point going to a board that’s a bunch of blokes, hasn’t got a diversity policy, it’s not even on their radar and saying get yourself a diverse board, you need one of each of these factors

author: A
sentence: But to have those kind of conversations and with the board that I talked to you about that are all men, one of the things I’ve said very early on is how do we hear the voice of our customer , how do we know what they want?  “Well you know, we do surveys,” and I looked at the questions they asked the customers and I went, “That’s not telling them what we want

author: A
sentence: ” We were leading them to tell us that we’re great

author: A
sentence: So let’s throw those questions out

author: A
sentence: Now the voice of the customer, how do we get that?  But to me, it’s about playing the long game and figuring out where's the organisation at now and what steps can we take to get to what is, to me, a desirable end state

author: Q
sentence: And what’s that look like?

author: A
sentence: Well that does look like that you've got you've got a board you've got a management team and you’ve got an employee group that does reflect the community that you're operating in, that you might have different ages different backgrounds different abled, disabled tags or different cultural background, and that you really recruit on the basis of, “Here’s our skills matrix, what skills do we need to succeed”, and go out and recruit without any kind of bias or favour of, “This will be a man

author: A
sentence: This will be a woman

author: A
sentence: This will be an Asian, this will be a 25 year old female IT guru

author: A
sentence: You know, really focus on what’s the skill set we need and go out and find the person and I think that would give you a very different outcome than what we’re seeing

author: A
sentence: You’re just getting a whole bunch of blokes and the occasional female in the mix

author: Q
sentence: So the assumption is then that the lack of - if I can - the lack of diversity that we have is the product of bias

author: A
sentence: That’s my invalidated view point

author: Q
sentence: If we remove bias and just focus on skills we will have diversity and get the best person for those skills; we will have diversity

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: It sounds really easy doesn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, the question then is who defines the skills, how are they defined, what biases might be in that

author: A
sentence: And that brings us to another interesting position that I've heard from more than one person

author: A
sentence: That - and I think women bring it on themselves if we just single out women on this as well - that women typically look down the list of selection criteria - of any role, not just board roles, and feel the need to tick every box before they’re confident enough to apply

author: Q
sentence: First, how has the composition of boards changed over time?  You’ve been involved for six years, what have you seen?  Any changes?

author: A
sentence: Whereas we constantly hear that a guy will look and go, “Yeah, I can do most of that, off I go

author: A
sentence: ”  We’re very hard on ourselves, I think, in the main

author: A
sentence: Without sounding like to much of a tosser, I think women put everything else before they get to themselves as well, in a lot of cases

author: A
sentence: I think sometimes from a female perspective and perhaps this might start - also apply to other diversity factors, that you feel like it is a fight rather than a right to be in those roles so you really feel the need to be the absolute 100% top performer, top fit, before you’ll put your hat in the ring for the role

author: A
sentence: So I think we work against ourselves in that regard, but I also see examples of where men will be considered for roles even if they haven’t had board experience and might not have all the selection criteria as a fit, but I’ve seen real examples and heard real examples from other directors and people looking for roles where they get the feedback that they just haven’t got enough of the right fit and then they see the person who gets the role and it’s, they haven’t either

author: A
sentence: Is that conscious or unconscious bias?  It could be both, I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: It’s cultural too, isn’t it?  Okay that’s good

author: Q
sentence: So, that applies across minority groups, whatever that kind of self-esteem, confidence, whatever we're talking, which is culturally sustained and reproduced; is having an influence

author: A
sentence: I spoke to the chair of an ASX 100 board just the other day and we were having a conversation - because he's getting involved with the Women on Boards group, the ASX board ready group, and he was asking me about my experience in it and I was talking to him about what we were talking about earlier, about women not necessarily - whilst they might be in a position of influence, they don’t always see themselves as being in the position or choosing to have help others

author: A
sentence: He was really blown away by that but after we spoke about it for a bit longer he said, “I think you’ve hit on something here

author: A
sentence: ”  Because he said, “Whenever I’m looking for a new director and I put the call out to the female directors in my network, I’ve never gotten anyone

author: A
sentence: I’ve never gotten anyone recommended to me that’s another woman

author: A
sentence: ”  But he said, “When I go to recruiters, I do get a few

author: A
sentence: ”  But he said, “Other women haven't recommended other female directors

author: A
sentence: So this was across the course of about an hour-and-a-half conversation and we’d started out at that point very early on in the conversation and he’d just looked at me like I was a bit nuts and I just kept talking about something, other topics

author: A
sentence: But when it got to the end, he’s like, “Yeah, I’ve thought about what you said; I think you're right, that might be why I’m not getting any referrals from my female networks

author: A
sentence: ”  I said, “Okay, what are you going to do about that?”  He said, “I’m going to ring them up and I’m going to specifically ask them why have you never referred another female to me?”

author: Q
sentence: Fantastic

author: A
sentence: So, it’s those kind of things too

author: A
sentence: I think there’s probably a lot more opportunity for men to be part of the solution, the good guys, if they actually understood the problem

author: A
sentence: Because he's someone who's already got quite a good mix of gender balance and is really focus on age as well, and in fact he was one of the ones who’s recently talked to me about the advisory board and the that he does do that

author: A
sentence: Where was I going with that thought?

author: A
sentence: Because, even with his focus on wanting to support women specifically in getting board roles, he didn't even have that perspective that he and I talked about; that other women don’t necessarily help the next generation

author: A
sentence: So if we haven’t defined the problem maybe that's why people don't know what they could potentially do to help

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Did Women on Boards, you know the ASX 100, did they talk about this?

author: Q
sentence: So thanks very much Participant 34D, for agreeing to be interviewed for our research on the diversity of Australian Boards

author: Q
sentence: We're particularly interested in speaking with people like you, you're a Director of a Board, or more

author: A
sentence: And then the publicly listed Board was last December, so it was for about seven months, six or seven months

author: A
sentence: And the advisory board's been about a year, a bit more than a year

author: A
sentence: Yeah, 'tool' is fine

author: Q
sentence: The different perspectives, how you're bringing the different perspectives using this method

author: Q
sentence: It has helped you to identify a gap, I gather, because you look through the different lenses, you want this, you want blah-blah-blah

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: This, 'We find it hardest here, to tell a story, so we need someone to help us

author: Q
sentence: ' Is that sort of how it's worked?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that would be true

author: A
sentence: That's a good way of putting it

author: Q
sentence: That's so interesting because this is so different to any other interview and I tell you what, I am at the end of the interviews, we're nearly 40

author: Q
sentence: We've nearly done 40 interviews and I'm amazed to hear

author: Q
sentence: This is so out there

author: Q
sentence: [laughs] It's great

author: A
sentence: Well, I'm still relatively new to the Board world, so maybe I haven't been [unclear] 00:39:19

author: Q
sentence: It's great

author: Q
sentence: No, it sounds terribly sensible, don't worry

author: Q
sentence: I'm not being critical in the least, it sounds really, really good

author: Q
sentence: Really effective

author: Q
sentence: It's very different though, so I'm trying to get the questions so that we can see how it maps against more traditional ways of thinking

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the Board influence your selection? So you've identified a gap using your method, how do you then going about getting someone? Like, how are you trying to find someone with this perspective, this funder's background?

author: Q
sentence: Have you been on Boards before that, or is the first -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the checking with that, absolutely, it's almost like the social media story I was talking about before, we're testing the environment, just who's out there, who's a good person and does anybody know anybody that has this background, or cares about this particular background? So that's probably another factor here too, the care or purpose side of the person needs to be aligned with the Board that they're talking about

author: A
sentence: I guess that's particular in a not-for-profit, but there's no reason why it shouldn't be elsewhere

author: A
sentence: So yeah, no we are definitely testing broadly, and we're not going to choose quickly

author: A
sentence: We will if we find the right person, but we're not going to rush to something, just to fill a role because - we're conscious of the gap and we cover it, but we're not just going to add somebody in and then still have the gap, kind of

author: Q
sentence: I was meaning to ask you, what gender ratio do you have? Like - what's your female/male on your different Boards?

author: A
sentence: Yeah okay, so on the not-for-profit there's - two females and then there's two males, including myself as the Chair; and the CEO is a male

author: A
sentence: But the Company Secretary is a female, so it's kind of 50/50 if you look at gender on management end Board

author: A
sentence: The iSelect Board is two female and three males, so it's sort of 40/60 I guess

author: A
sentence: And then the startup is one female and four males, so it's a bit of whack, but the industry that that comes from probably pushes it to that space, because it's an automotive industry

author: A
sentence: There's not a lot of females in automotive unfortunately

author: Q
sentence: So do you use recruitment organisations?

author: A
sentence: We do

author: A
sentence: Yeah we do

author: A
sentence: For the not-for-profit we do, definitely

author: A
sentence: The Chair of iSelect has a pretty extensive network, but yeah, he would use recruitment places when he needed to, I'm sure

author: A
sentence: But yeah, we do, and there's definitely ones that specialise in the not-for-profit space that I use, particularly one of them which I get a lot of advice from that organisation as well

author: A
sentence: I meet with that organisation probably every quarter, just to understand what's going on in the not-for-profit marketplace, at the Board level

author: A
sentence: And I think they also do a bunch of work for Boards, as well as recruit, so they're kind of making their space in the not-for-profit

author: Q
sentence: Oh right, so why do you use them, what's your reason?

author: A
sentence: Just to understand what's happening, how are decisions being made

author: A
sentence: Social impact is a fairly recent trade, and social impact investing

author: A
sentence: So how do we understand what the social impact investors are thinking and wanting, and what does your organisation have to look like to attract that investor? That's been one of the discussions over the last six months or so

author: A
sentence: Prior that, I was actually looking for corporate, kind of, not-for-profit connection linkages, so people who have that linkage and we were able to find two of those

author: A
sentence: Both a different gender and differing thinking, or different experience, to be able to add to the Board as well, so that worked that way

author: A
sentence: Then just generally, what else is happening; who are the other not-for-profits we should be talking to? We talk to them a bit about how they run their operations, what they do, so it's more kind of who should be in the discussion

author: A
sentence: It's probably that external view, you know, what else is going on out there that we should know about?

author: Q
sentence: Is that more the industry as well as what do we want in terms of Directors on the Board?

author: A
sentence: Yeah-yeah, and that's definitely what's going on in the not-for-profit industry, and like I say, social impact investing is a very specific situation

author: A
sentence: It's probably been around for a long time, but even more so now that there's a number of people creating funds that are just for social impact

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I've talked to organisations that influence investment, they've got a long-term view in terms of socially sustainable investing, and they seek to influence ASX listed companies and stuff

author: A
sentence: No, this is the first one

author: A
sentence: As a partner in Deloitte and an auditing firm, it's extremely hard to do that, so most of us didn't do it

author: A
sentence: You'd do the odd not-for-profit, but not any other Boards, no

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, they definitely do, yes

author: Q
sentence: So it is similar to that, or is this something

author: A
sentence: Yeah-no, no-no this is exactly

author: A
sentence: And some of them have gone even further, they don't invest in listed companies or anything like that, they're there to fund not-for-profit

author: A
sentence: They don't just fund any not-for-profit, you have to meet certain criteria to be able to access their investment story, so that's the picture that we're trying to get to

author: A
sentence: You're right, some of those do invest in organisations, listed companies or whatever, according to their story, which may have social aspects to it, or maybe socially responsible in some form, or whatever they've decided they're going to do

author: Q
sentence: So how do you feel, are there ever tensions between when you're selecting a new Board member, between on the one hand trying to obtain a collegiate fit, like someone who's got your - get in with your Board, other members, and on the other hand, trying to avoid group think, or to broaden your view

author: Q
sentence: Do you think this is a potential conflict or tension?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, definitely

author: A
sentence: Group think usually comes around by dominating - some level of domination by a person

author: A
sentence: So I think it's probably a good Chair doesn't let that happen

author: Q
sentence: Oh, let's talk about what a good Chair does

author: Q
sentence: You have to talk about this, I'm afraid

author: A
sentence: Yeah well, in my mind, a good Chair is the last person to speak; is there to help the Board get the decision and not force a decision

author: A
sentence: So therefore a good Chair really needs to be trying to understand what's going on in the room with the Board members and to use questions or discussion, to dig out concerns, or what's going on really

author: A
sentence: Not the best way of explaining it, but yeah, really sitting back and listening, watching, observing, really trying to understand what's happening

author: A
sentence: First of all - I'll just step back a little bit - a good Chair in my mind is one that knows what decision the Board need to make, and then it doesn't have a preconceived idea of what that decision should be; and then makes sure that the Board had the ability to make that decision, firstly in an informed manner, but also using all the skills of that Board

author: A
sentence: Therefore sitting back, listening, seeing what's going on; watching the body language; creating discussion

author: A
sentence: If it's not digging deep enough, or people are trying to rush a decision, not letting them rush the decision; making sure everybody's had their say; consider different angles, so using the tool we were talking about, using the tool to draw out more discussion; and then getting the Board to really be comfortable that the decision they're making is the right one, given all the information that's on the table

author: A
sentence: I think that's probably my summary of what a good Chair would do, and then obviously a Chair is identifying where is this business going, and what skills and capabilities do we need to be able to guide it to the right place? How do we actually fill those roles; what external help do we need?

author: A
sentence: Interestingly, the Chair of iSelect, he quite often brings in external people to spend half an hour talking to us about a topic

author: A
sentence: At the time you don't quite realise why he's done it, but in three months' time it becomes obvious because we're now about to make the decision, that he's helped us create some level of being informed along the way so that we're building our knowledge of what it is that respectively, we're going to have to make a decision on down the track on it

author: A
sentence: So that's a neat way of doing things as well

author: Q
sentence: So is your background in accounting/finance sort of thing, or

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay

author: Q
sentence: So what I'm hearing then, to sort of summarise, the Chair's role in facilitating or building diversity is: (1) to build the capacity over time; and (2) to facilitate the decision making process so that it is inclusive?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yes, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: And creative

author: Q
sentence: So it's sort of working at two levels then as the Chair?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, definitely

author: Q
sentence: That's really interesting, that's great

author: Q
sentence: That could be a nice model, good

author: Q
sentence: So are you familiar with any barriers to managing or building diversity, apart from - implied by the Chair role?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well when I did the Directors course, probably about five years ago now, and had to role play a number of things, and I can see how they play out, dominating Board members; people who have their opinion and don't want to change and like to throw their weight, they like to talk first and all that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: And when those situations aren't managed, I can see how those things could easily evolve into places where Boards don't make real, proper decisions

author: A
sentence: And if you read some of the cases and some of the various things that we went through in that course, you can see how it actually did play out in those situations, with different Boards that have not operated well

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so like, the HIH crash and stuff like that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, HIH, I was actually just going to mention that one because that is one that they actually teach during the AICD course

author: A
sentence: They actually go through that and I think you spend at least a day on it, going through what had happened at each Board meeting; who was the nominating factor; what didn't they do; what did they do; who did stuff outside the Board that was inconsistent or they didn't tell the Board what they'd done, et cetera, et cetera

author: A
sentence: So there's a whole range of things there that - you look at it and go, 'Oh my god, that's a nightmare'

author: A
sentence: No wonder they went under

author: Q
sentence: So Participant 34D, do you think your strategies for building diversity on the Board, diversity of thinking, would that have prevented some of this bad decision making?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think there's a couple of aspects to it

author: A
sentence: One is the internal view and the kind of, Board not thinking they had to have any external perspective, that in the HIH situation, they had it all under control, they were in command and certain people were acting in a particular way

author: A
sentence: Now, the other thing that I haven't actually experienced either, but could be an impact here, is the connection between a shareholder and a Board member

author: A
sentence: So you find where significant shareholders actually have a Board member, that Board member in my mind, is quite hard to see how they could be there for all shareholders, when in reality, they're there for their shareholder, that kind of thing

author: A
sentence: So that's an interesting situation that I've never really had to deal with

author: A
sentence: Yeah sort of

author: A
sentence: It's more management consulting

author: Q
sentence: Because that happens in private equity, doesn't it?

author: A
sentence: It does

author: A
sentence: Well private equity, they're very clear about it

author: A
sentence: They basically say, 'This is what we're doing

author: A
sentence: We're running this show and we're running it

author: A
sentence: ' No, but it's something that we're aware a major shareholder might have a Board seat and they're there to try and make sure that shareholder's views are the ones that the Board accepts

author: A
sentence: So it's kind of, you're not acting on behalf of all shareholders in that situation

author: A
sentence: It's hard to argue that you are

author: A
sentence: I'm sure they will argue that they are, but it doesn't feel that way from the outside

author: A
sentence: So that situation I haven't seen, but the diversity of thinking, if everybody takes it seriously, it's really hard for it not to be effective

author: A
sentence: Especially when you're doing it in terms of thinking

author: A
sentence: Where it falls down in my mind, is like where I was saying before, if you add three females to a Board and they all have personality A and are driving for financial outcomes, you actually haven't changed the way that Board works

author: A
sentence: It doesn't matter whether they are male or female

author: A
sentence: You might get a slight element of diversity by doing that, but the reality is, unless you really force diversity of thinking to be in play, then you haven't got diversity

author: Q
sentence: So given this, what about gender targets and quotas to influence Board diversity, what do you think of this?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think like I say, I think you do get a level of natural diversity by having different genders, different race, different religions on the Board, or anywhere, it doesn't have to be a Board - so I think you do get an element, and you do force - if it's a male dominated Board and all of a sudden half of its female, they do operate slightly differently, but you're only addressing a small component of it

author: A
sentence: You really haven't got to proper diversity of thinking

author: A
sentence: And yeah, you could get a whole Board of females who -

author: Q
sentence: Think the same

author: A
sentence: - do not have diversity of thinking either

author: A
sentence: They might go the other way

author: A
sentence: They might have diversity of thinking in a particular area now, forgetting all the other aspects kind of thing

author: A
sentence: I think to do it, you have to carefully think it through

author: A
sentence: You've got to find the right people, and some people aren't the noisy ones that stand up and want to be selected

author: A
sentence: It's kind of, if you really think about it, all politicians feel the same, because only a certain type of person would stand up and make all of that noise in front of the community and try and get themselves elected, so most politicians are going to look pretty much the same

author: A
sentence: From our perspective, you're actually not getting the representation of the community in our parliaments because only a certain type of person will put themselves forward

author: A
sentence: So we're actually missing the ability to actually make our society better, by having just politicians be in there

author: A
sentence: Now the good thing is, typically there's people who really care about that go into the public service and actually influence from inside

author: A
sentence: We do get a bit of a different story going on, it doesn't quite work the way it could work

author: A
sentence: Now, corporates have - and corporations - have the ability to actually do it without all that fanfare and public debate and all that good stuff, so you can actually select a fairly diverse team to be at the Board level, as much as at your management level

author: Q
sentence: I think we're nearly finished now

author: Q
sentence: There's one question, but before I ask this question, I'd just really like to ask you, do you think we should be doing something to develop the capacity of Chairs, given the important role you've really described, to develop their capacity to maximising the ability of Boards to include different ways of thinking

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: Management, yep

author: Q
sentence: Good, well let's start

author: Q
sentence: First of all, how has the composition of Boards that you're familiar with changed over time do you think - let's look at the two and a half years - in terms of diversity? If at all

author: Q
sentence: Instead of like quotas and targets for gender and stuff, should we be doing something with the Chairs, and if so, what do you think might be able to be done?

author: A
sentence: The answer is yes, absolutely

author: A
sentence: If we look at the way in which CEOs have evolved in the last 10 years or so, that's exactly what's happened

author: A
sentence: Our CEOs have gone from being the dominating decision maker, to being the leader and helping the management team make the right decisions, so they are exactly what I'm talking about at the Chair level

author: A
sentence: So yeah, the answer is absolutely the Chair needs to be that leader as well

author: A
sentence: Whether we need to do something specific for it, yeah probably

author: A
sentence: How would that happen? I haven't really though that through, but I'm sure the same way the CEOs come - or maybe it's more the case of who is the Chair and how do you source the Chair?

author: A
sentence: The Chair is that dominating decision maker, that might have been of the past, who kind of goes around the room and gets the five decisions, those five ideas, and goes, 'Right yeah okay, well we're going to decide X', that's the way maybe a CEO used to work 15 or 20 years ago as well

author: A
sentence: It doesn't happen anymore

author: A
sentence: Now perhaps it's actually naturally evolving today and therefore the leaders coming through, are recognising that they have to be leaders, a Chair is a leader, not a Chair kind of

author: A
sentence: So I think, I'm not sure what specific things would need to be done, other than recognising that that's what it should be and shareholders and ASIC and APRA and people like that, need to be doing more than just, 'Does the Board comply?' it's what's the composition of the Board; how is the Board making decisions; what's their way of thinking; is the Chair a leader? There's probably a magnitude of things that could be done to review Boards, rather than have they complied

author: A
sentence: Which is probably way more valuable than how was that decision made, or does that decision comply or not kind of thing

author: Q
sentence: That's brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Well we're at our final question which I'm asking you now to look 10 years into the future, and how would you like to see the diversity of Australian Boards?

author: A
sentence: Well I think the starting point would be the role of Boards, and I would like to think that Boards are an essential element of a business' strategy in that they're bringing another dimension to the decision making of that organisation, that it helps management, that it doesn't hinder them

author: A
sentence: They don't get into the operating side of things; and that it is bringing perspectives that perhaps beyond the boundaries of today, that's bringing a diversity of experience and thinking to that organisation, that gives it a dimension that allows it to take opportunities and be more successful

author: A
sentence: I would hate to think that Boards get lost and therefore become irrelevant and therefore not used by management, or shareholders or anybody

author: A
sentence: So from that perspective, I think Boards need to continue to evolve in terms of how do they build their composition; are there specific roles for specific people; how does that then evolve into training and development as Board members take on those roles; what level of operating experience should you really have had, before you become a Board member

author: A
sentence: There are a whole range of things like that, that are important

author: A
sentence: But yeah, in 10 years time I would hope to think that Boards are an essential element of a business' strategy, rather than kind of compliance and/or irrelevant

author: Q
sentence: Wow, okay

author: Q
sentence: I love it

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: So different

author: Q
sentence: I cannot believe it Participant 34D, it's been a great interview

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: A
sentence: No trouble

author: Q
sentence: Enjoy the winter

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: [laughter]

author: A
sentence: Yeah, how much it's changed

author: A
sentence: Well the thing I think I've probably noticed the most is Board members originally coming in as a Board member, came in as having a long history in business usually

author: A
sentence: The expectation is therefore that the Board member would know all aspects of a Board role and I think the things that have changed, and the reason why I joined the iSelect Board, was to bring a specific capability to the Board and I think the evolution of the Board members, is to play more designated roles, rather than everybody trying to be a jack-of-all-trades kind of situation

author: A
sentence: That's probably the thing that I've noticed the most in the last period of time, is that Boards really have to be much more understanding of how the business really works

author: A
sentence: But as a Board member, it's hard to know all aspects, so therefore making sure that the Board is composed of people who can complement one another and create the value that a Board should have as a team

author: Q
sentence: Thank you again, and we'll send you an invitation to anything, anywhere where we're - so you get some sense of the outcomes of the research

author: A
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: A
sentence: No trouble and if you need to check anything, that's fine

author: Q
sentence: Thanks very much Participant 34D

author: Q
sentence: Oh that book, if that title - Juliet Bourke, I mean, just her name

author: A
sentence: Yeah, 'Two Heads are Better Than One' or something like that

author: Q
sentence: Oh okay, and it was B-O-U-R-K-E

author: Q
sentence: I'll find it

author: Q
sentence: 'Two Heads are Better than One', that'll be enough

author: A
sentence: Let me know, I can actually just do a quick search here

author: Q
sentence: I'll just turn this off

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it's a team

author: Q
sentence: What do you think might be driving this focus on each Board member bringing a particular skills?

author: A
sentence: I think business is a lot more complex these days, with keystone changes constantly changing

author: A
sentence: The technologies, they're re-arranging of business models, the evolution of customer demand, the scrutiny from Regulators and from society in general, is way stronger now than it was previously, and continues

author: A
sentence: I guess from that perspective, that Boards, whilst not becoming management, have to understand a lot more about what management is doing, how they're thinking and what's impacting the business

author: A
sentence: And if they can't trust the decisions that are made inside the business - there's significant destruction going on all over the business world which the Boards really need to understand what that means

author: A
sentence: It has various impacts in terms of somebody in the Board really needs to understand why and how a business model might need to change; and then somebody else, and quite possibly somebody else, would need to then understand, well what does that do to governance, to reporting requirements and to structures? Then somebody else might need to know what that really means in terms of the financials and how profitability would be impacted, et cetera

author: A
sentence: And it's very hard for a single Board member, in my view, to be able to cover all of those aspects, in the required level of detail, so hence they're moving, in my mind, to Board members playing specific roles and the Board team being a complementary set of skills and capabilities

author: Q
sentence: Excellent, so are there core skills that every Board needs, or is it pretty well tailored?

author: A
sentence: Yeah-yeah no, I am the Director of a couple of different Boards, but one's listed

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, in my view

author: A
sentence: Experience, operational business experience

author: A
sentence: If you don’t understand how businesses work and what customers need and want, and how parts of the organisation need to operate to provide those activities, then absolutely

author: A
sentence: Now obviously there is a core base level of governance and understanding of the compliance side of the world that each Director must have

author: A
sentence: Each Director must also have some financial ability to be able to understand at least what a P&L means, and how the business is operating in that sense

author: A
sentence: But I think today's Board members, need to be a lot more specialised beyond just the basic Board that might have been in the past

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so these specialised skills, are they sort of specific to the Board, or what might that look like?

author: A
sentence: How do you mean specific to the Board?

author: Q
sentence: Well say, would a startup, perhaps a Board of a startup might need different - you know, like there's those core skills that everyone needs, which you just talked about, but then some special skills that you might bring particular -

author: A
sentence: Oh yeah sure

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: In a startup situation, there's probably two real factors that are important: one is there's usually a general assumption, which is probably correct, that the startup founder knows the product or thing that they're trying to build, so the two factors then that are typically needed in the startup world is how to extract funding and what would be required from an investor, and therefore, how do you organise the startup to be ready for an investment, and that is a very specific skill

author: A
