sentence: So, I think they’re the two extremes for me

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve had both of them quite a few times this last year

author: A
sentence: So, I’ve had nights where I just lay awake, I can’t sleep after a board meeting sometimes

author: Q
sentence: Now, this is interesting

author: Q
sentence: You’ve got – some people have mentioned outcome thinkers and process thinkers, as being a source of diversity as well

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve mentioned both

author: Q
sentence: So, the plan that addresses all the issues that have emerged as an outcome

author: Q
sentence: And a process is like understanding the issues emerged, that’s sort of process work

author: Q
sentence: So, are both equally important, are both important as diversity contribute to both or?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I’m sure it does

author: Q
sentence: Sorry, did that – is that synopsis, does that work for you, does that make sense?

author: A
sentence: It led me to doing a big project looking into a big acquisition in Europe, where we said we’d put money next to Telstra, 49% or 51% whichever way they wanted it

author: A
sentence: It might be all Macquarie money or it might be some pension funds, the Canadian pension funds were very large

author: A
sentence: Now a lot of the Australian super money would probably have filled that gap

author: A
sentence: What happened was, Telstra, you might remember, were going through that T3 period

author: A
sentence: There was a lot of to and fro with government

author: A
sentence: They were in favour and out of favour

author: A
sentence: And they decided they couldn’t do this big European deal, it was a multi-billion dollar deal

author: A
sentence: Government wasn’t supportive and they were still their major shareholder

author: A
sentence: So, we ended up doing that

author: A
sentence: I moved to London and ran it

author: A
sentence: We just did it with other private money, if you like, or non-corporate money, small pension fund money, et cetera

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I was thinking, just trying to – I think it is – I’m a big believer that you do have to be outcome focussed

author: A
sentence: There’s no doubt about it

author: A
sentence: Just feeling like you’ve got a good process but ignoring the fact that you’ve got a deadline -

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: But equally, you can’t just keep looking at deadlines and have no process either

author: A
sentence: Because people need to have, I think management teams want to know how good the board process that they need to address, et cetera

author: A
sentence: They need some direction in that regard

author: A
sentence: We did a budget process yesterday, and I think the management team really liked the fact that they all got to come in and present their own budget, their part of the budget to the board

author: A
sentence: Rather than just hand it over to the CEO and he talk on their behalf and maybe make compromises and so on, without their involvement

author: A
sentence: So, that was a good process

author: A
sentence: Other times you feel that was a lousy process and it’s not – so, I tie the two together

author: A
sentence: That’s why I’m struggling with the question because I think that you can, but you’re less likely to get to good outcomes with a poor process

author: A
sentence: And so, it’s an end in itself to have good process

author: Q
sentence: I’m thinking process thinking, as a style of thinking

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: It’s probably the semantics

author: A
sentence: I’m probably thinking about it the wrong way

author: Q
sentence: You’re talking about board process

author: Q
sentence: So, this is – I’m not a board person

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re automatically thinking board process – oh right, okay

author: Q
sentence: It’s good

author: A
sentence: Some boards do have very different processes, where a lot of the decisions are made outside of the room and you’re almost rubber stamping

author: A
sentence: I don’t think that’s regarded as good process by most people, because you’ll have decisions that people are responsible for under the law, but they haven’t had real input to

author: A
sentence: Or even necessarily a good level of understanding

author: A
sentence: Because it’s already come into the room where a subcommittee has sort of, committees have their roles, but you still need to bring the board along

author: Q
sentence: So, conflict on boards arising because of diversity of the board

author: Q
sentence: Have you had any experience of that?

author: A
sentence: Well, yes

author: A
sentence: I think, that example I started with, with this fellow that was playing a very particular role on the board

author: A
sentence: He was an executive director, and that was a point of disharmony too

author: A
sentence: Because he wasn’t really sitting in the company, he was arguably, he was providing those services from a distance, if you like, and nominally an executive director

author: A
sentence: And he had experience and expertise in an aspect that others of us on the board did not have

author: A
sentence: But it did become a source of dysfunctionality because he would just say, “Trust me” and “I know this

author: A
sentence: Whereas others would take that as an opportunity to softly say, look my experience in this area, without saying you don’t have any

author: A
sentence: They’ll just say, “I’ve done a fair bit in this space, that’s really where my focus has been for over a decade now” and “My experience working with both government and private sector and small and large, is this” and that can be really helpful

author: A
sentence: People get comfortable and they sort of say, well I’ve only done a little bit of it, but you’ve done a lot and what you’re saying makes sense

author: A
sentence: So, you buy into it

author: A
sentence: Or you say, well your experience is sort of at a particular level and I need to – but it does seem to me that a lot of it is the human, the communication style and just whether the individual has got that innate ability to work as part of a team

author: A
sentence: That was sort of the evolution of my career through Macquarie and I spent four years in London doing sort of non-infrastructure private equity

author: A
sentence: Because Macquarie had done a lot of private infrastructure deals, which you would say were private equity, but they were of that particular class and then we branched out

author: A
sentence: And then there was a family driven move to come back to Australia and not really my preference

author: A
sentence: But that proved quite fortuitously timed because the GFC hit

author: A
sentence: Some people, dare I say it, should have played a few more team sports or involved in team activities

author: A
sentence: It might not be sport but some people just grow up doing solo things and they never really seem to be able to mesh into a team

author: A
sentence: And I think that’s as big a – I did the AICD course last year, and which I had been gunna, gunna do, because I thought it would both add and refresh bits that I already knew, but also add to my knowledge

author: A
sentence: And that was a big, big point being made that it’s the people that you get on the board with that’s the biggest bit of due diligence

author: A
sentence: Learning about the company’s one thing, but your fellow board members is fundamentally, much more important

author: Q
sentence: And that’s where we are now

author: Q
sentence: That’s what we want to ask

author: Q
sentence: We want to explore that

author: Q
sentence: How you -

author: A
sentence: Good segue

author: Q
sentence: Exactly –identify potential new members

author: A
sentence: We’re doing that right now

author: A
sentence: Had dinner on Monday night with a potential new board member

author: A
sentence: On paper, outstanding

author: A
sentence: And I’m really delighted that after the dinner, I feel the personality fit would also be very, very good

author: A
sentence: It’s a person who has quite a celebrated career as a CEO

author: A
sentence: You’d recognise the name, I suspect, for a smaller company he would be a good catch

author: A
sentence: And he gives diversity, I think

author: A
sentence: Definitely, quite a different background to my own or any of the other directors

author: Q
sentence: So, you’re the chair of this?

author: A
sentence: I am

author: Q
sentence: So, the chair having dinner with a potential new member -

author: A
sentence: Well, actually the whole board did

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I was wondering where you were then

author: A
sentence: It was an interesting one

author: A
sentence: I know it’s going to be treated confidentially, but in this instance, this company is a founder entrepreneur who then, in the pre-IPO stages, when I invested, asked me would I join the board and then asked me if I’d be the chairman

author: A
sentence: But in a funny way, he still likes to think he can pick his board

author: A
sentence: And I don’t think you get to pick your board as CEO

author: A
sentence: To me that’s not the way it works

author: A
sentence: Now it might be if you still own half the company

author: A
sentence: Because if so, in that factor, you can sack the board and appoint whoever you like

author: A
sentence: But when you’re actually now quite a minor share, sub 10% shareholder, you don’t get to pick the board

author: A
sentence: And really the board picks the people to approach to come onto the board or a group of shareholders get together and say, well here’s our ticket, we’re going to vote for this ticket and you’ve got a real rebellion on your hands

author: A
sentence: Or they do it in a sensible manner with the current board or something

author: A
sentence: But I don’t think the CEO should be the one picking his board

author: A
sentence: Having said that, we are all living interstate from where the company is based

author: A
sentence: He thinks he needs a local director

author: A
sentence: He did bring on a very good local director two years ago, two and a half and we lost him to a very senior role in government interstate

author: A
sentence: Couldn’t stay on a private board or a private sector board

author: A
sentence: So, he scraped to that person who remains good contact with him and said you buggered us up by leaving who can you help find for us that would be in your general mould and also bring the right skills, you know the company well enough now

author: A
sentence: And that was how this came about

author: A
sentence: I’m not too critical, but I was a little – when we got two years ago with the first guy, he said would you come over and meet this guy over dinner and it was sort of the CEO introducing me to a potential new director and I liked him and I thought he would add enormous value

author: A
sentence: He had great credibility, relevant sector expertise, and so on and networks

author: A
sentence: So, it was not hard at all and then the rest of the board met him

author: A
sentence: This time it was sort of like, one of the other board members had already met him on a previous trip

author: A
sentence: And I felt like I was – it’s an interesting dynamic

author: A
sentence: When you push back on a CEO as a chair – and we had a rough patch

author: A
sentence: The guy that I had to move on, was very close to the CEO

author: A
sentence: And there was this -

author: Q
sentence: This is the same board, we’re talking about?

author: A
sentence: Same board

author: A
sentence: Some misplaced loyalty through a director

author: A
sentence: And all the other directors agreed he had to go

author: A
sentence: And the CEO finally got there– MD, I keep saying CEO, but he’s the MD

author: A
sentence: So, he’s on the board

author: A
sentence: So, there was – it takes its toll on a relationship

author: A
sentence: The bruising’s fading and we have good chat and it’s all ostensibly fine

author: A
sentence: But there’s this -

author: Q
sentence: It was tough

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: He felt like I really forced his hand

author: A
sentence: It suited the other director to make me the bad guy

author: A
sentence: I was the one driving it

author: A
sentence: Funnily enough, it was, if anything, the other directors were more -

author: Q
sentence: But you’re the chair

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: And so, he just decided – there’s lots of background to it, but he decided, it was easier to have one bill and then everybody be the bad guys

author: Q
sentence: So, this is a small board?

author: A
sentence: So, that really made it much less appealing to stay in a large investment bank, to me

author: A
sentence: I was coming back anyway, it was a real juncture

author: A
sentence: So, I just stepped out to do my own thing

author: A
sentence: I ended going back, funnily enough, and doing some advice work for Telstra under my own steam and then with some other clients

author: A
sentence: But it’s evolved towards now helping, I’ve helped a few companies raise capital and I’ve then ended up sitting on the board of a couple of those companies

author: A
sentence: And I’ve ended up doing more stuff at the small end of the market whereas at Macquarie it was all very large, big corporate clients

author: A
sentence: Well, relatively small

author: A
sentence: We had six directors and we lost two to job changes that they just couldn’t stay on, on a public board

author: A
sentence: So, we’re back to four, including the MD

author: A
sentence: And we want to have at least a fifth member

author: A
sentence: And ideally, we think one in Adelaide, because that is where the company is based

author: A
sentence: There is a little bit of parochialism

author: A
sentence: And we’ve had support from the government and it’s sort of good for them to see another senior Adelaide figure on the board

author: A
sentence: It plays well

author: A
sentence: I’m not so big on that, unless that person has other – you want more than just being seen -

author: Q
sentence: Skills matrix, all this sort of stuff

author: Q
sentence: I’m not hearing 00:52:47

author: A
sentence: We did do that

author: Q
sentence: Oh, you did do that?

author: A
sentence: Yes, we did

author: A
sentence: We did a skills matrix and we looked at the gaps

author: A
sentence: And for me the South Australian bit was low on the pecking order

author: A
sentence: I wanted relevant industry knowledge and networks and expertise

author: A
sentence: Maybe the stage we’re at, challenges were facing, growth

author: A
sentence: Some people have generally only worked in a multinational, they’ve never known what it is to be short of capital

author: Q
sentence: They’d have no idea

author: A
sentence: It’s a really different set of challenges

author: A
sentence: They look in horror that you’ve got nothing got in the bank

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: You’re insolvent

author: Q
sentence: So, okay

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in the board selection process between on the one hand getting that collegiate fit and on the other hand avoiding group think?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: And how do you manage that?

author: Q
sentence: So, you’ve got both, you’ve got experience of both

author: Q
sentence: But from a board perspective, a director perspective in the start-up area

author: A
sentence: I think just by, and I don’t think I’ve always been very good at it, but I think, being better at it lately

author: A
sentence: I’ve really worked a lot harder this last year or two, at really trying to invite as chair, try to remind myself to be aware of the body language in the meeting and just to keep an eye on the eyes and if people look like they’re a bit sceptical or a little bit, not fully bought in or they want to make a point but they’re sort of waiting for the moment, try to draw that out

author: A
sentence: So, I think more likely you end up with group think if the chairs rushing things through and/or not shifting the conversation around

author: A
sentence: So, someone is not allowed to dominate it for too long

author: A
sentence: And I think that’s part of the skill for a good board

author: A
sentence: And that shouldn’t just be the chair, by the way

author: A
sentence: I think that’s -

author: Q
sentence: Everyone

author: A
sentence: -@ everyone’s got a responsibility there to speak up for themselves and/or notice, to sort of Say, “Excuse me Chair but I think Rob wants to make a point” or Betty or whatever

author: A
sentence: I think That’s where you can avoid the group think, where you’re really inviting, does anybody see it differently

author: A
sentence: rather than are we all agreed

author: A
sentence: I think the way you couch questions and you invite that moment of difference

author: A
sentence: where, it’s not a bad thing, I’m saying, it’s Okay to see it differently

author: Q
sentence: So, the communication process on the board is, your strategy for avoiding group think, employing the person or engaging, recruiting the new member, is really about what they bring, the [collegiate fit] or around skills

author: A
sentence: So, I think, I don’t think you have to have someone that’s just, he or she is very pleasant and lovely to have dinner with and I think we’ll all have a laugh and be nice, nobody will ruffle the feathers, far from that

author: A
sentence: But do you want someone who’s a total arsehole, no

author: A
sentence: Because it makes meetings

author: A
sentence: I have another board, I won’t go into too much detail, but where there’s a background there and somebody was formally chairman and it wasn’t working and they stayed on the board because they’ve got a significant stake in the company

author: A
sentence: And they’ve never got over the fact in ten years, that they were the chair and they’re not anymore and they’ve just been difficult forever

author: Q
sentence: Are you chair of that?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: And we tried and the chair is a very capable person

author: A
sentence: But he’s been a must better chair and is quite capable of taking care of himself, so we don’t have to protect, because that would be sad

author: A
sentence: But equally, there is an element to which we have to be – because we don’t want to lose that chair, because we’ve got a good chairman

author: A
sentence: That’s not about diversity there, that’s just about somebody just taking every chance to point score

author: Q
sentence: It’s an example of the bad dynamics

author: Q
sentence: And it’s not just the chair, it’s the culture of the whole board

author: Q
sentence: As a chair, do you cultivate that culture on your board?

author: A
sentence: Try to

author: A
sentence: Yes, and as I say, I had that real problem of one guy who would sort of undermine, I think outside of the meeting, and so on

author: A
sentence: “Well you know why he’s saying that, because he doesn’t want

author: A
sentence: ” It wasn’t something I wanted to do, to have to move someone on, but eventually it became really black and white

author: Q
sentence: Are there any regulatory barriers to moving someone on from a board if its listed?

author: A
sentence: I’ve got a bit of that

author: A
sentence: And I’ve sat on family boards since I was about, well a university student really or finished my law degree

author: A
sentence: Because my father had his own business, right through from the time he was a teenager or younger

author: A
sentence: So, as he hit retirement, or he sold out, he had an investment company and he asked a couple of us to sit on the board for him

author: A
sentence: It was more of an advisory board, at the end of the day it was his money and we knew where the decision making lay

author: A
sentence: But he did decide that he had a few kids that had been well trained and he would get the best out of us

author: A
sentence: So, we sat on that board and then that evolved into a business with my brothers

author: A
sentence: So, I’ve had a reasonable sized tourism or sorry, really more hospitality and leisure business that has had tourism assets

author: A
sentence: That’s been a sort of 20year board experience too, in a private company sense

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: There are

author: A
sentence: It’s a real challenge

author: A
sentence: It wasn’t obvious

author: A
sentence: This person – I better not go into it

author: A
sentence: But just made it relatively straight forward

author: A
sentence: Relatively they could have really sort of stuck their oar in the water and made it such that we had to actually at the next, call an EGM or wait for the AGM or something

author: A
sentence: But it’s a bad look for the company

author: A
sentence: Nobody thinks, oh isn’t that great, they’ve moved a director on

author: A
sentence: But it’s sort of – some people will say well if they had a problem it’s good that they addressed it

author: A
sentence: But most people would go it’s not a good sign

author: A
sentence: So, it's much better if you can have that relatively calm transition where somebody just leaves for family reasons or career reasons

author: Q
sentence: Like we have in the media

author: A
sentence: Luckily this guy, there was an issue there, there was a compromise to be struck this year, if you need the company to

author: A
sentence: And we thought about it long and hard to make sure it was in the best interest of the company and we were comfortable with that

author: A
sentence: But it was, that was the condition, the quid pro quo

author: Q
sentence: So, it is possible, even for a listed company, to do this, the way that you’ve described it

author: A
sentence: Oh, look, we were lucky

author: A
sentence: He put himself in a corner

author: A
sentence: And it made it possible

author: A
sentence: I really feared I was going to have another six months or more

author: Q
sentence: And regulation, do you think gender, targets, quotas, those sorts of things help with diversity? Is more regulation needed?

author: A
sentence: I actually do, because I look at the Liberal party and the Labour party and that sort of to me, I know it’s only a sample of one instance, but it’s living proof, the Liberal party just keep – my partner works as being a ministerial advisor in the Liberal party and she also does media commentary when she’s not being – she’s just left again

author: A
sentence: After the election, she’s had a couple of offers to stay, and she does not want to

author: A
sentence: And one of her pet hates of her own party is that issue

author: A
sentence: And it is one of the issues where she will in the media make that comment quite clearly, that targets aren’t working

author: A
sentence: The quota and she can elaborate on the point much better than I

author: A
sentence: But there are simple reasons in politics that women, those that do choose to have children, those key years are when the guys are going to all these branch meetings and winning the brownie points and they can’t do some of that stuff

author: A
sentence: And then there’s all those things that have been stacked on

author: A
sentence: And they’re gradually sort of evening up

author: A
sentence: But it’s not there

author: A
sentence: To say, oh the women can – they don’t get the seats that are the safe seats and so on

author: A
sentence: And then she talks about why [Kelly O’Dwyer]01:01:00 would leave in exasperation with the boy’s club and so on

author: A
sentence: And [Kelly] obviously bit her tongue a fair bit on what she was quoted and she’s never really said that’s completely untrue

author: A
sentence: But some of those comments about the boy’s club and all that

author: A
sentence: So, I think in corporate –to translate across – the problem with doing that do boards

author: A
sentence: It’s one thing at parliamentary level, I feel like with boards and some of them are four and five people, we’re four at the moment

author: A
sentence: To mandate there’s got to be at least 33% women or something like that, then we have to have two out of the four

author: A
sentence: And would that be right

author: A
sentence: It might be, but it’s a lot harder still in some instances, depending on what industry and so on

author: A
sentence: So, it’s a pretty tricky one and you actually sort of just putting the bar too high, but I think there needs, there probably does need to be a quota and there maybe just has to be really sophisticated nuance thinking about the size of companies and so on

author: A
sentence: I think major, the top 50 without a doubt

author: A
sentence: It would just be shameful to be sitting there and saying we couldn’t find a woman to be on this nine person board or seven person board, in this industry

author: A
sentence: That’s pretty hard to believe

author: A
sentence: But is it three women out of seven, as a minimum, I don’t know? I haven’t thought about it deeply enough to, but I do believe that quotas are probably part of the answer

author: Q
sentence: So, when you were talking earlier, you talked to define that it was you were after cognitive diversity to achieve risk mitigation and value creation

author: Q
sentence: Is the gender quota, what’s it got to do with that, the gender target – how is that going to contribute to this, which is cognitive diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: A
sentence: Well I think there’s two aims here

author: A
sentence: Maybe I’m out on a limb

author: A
sentence: But I think there’s one that’s good for the company and the shareholders and everybody involved the company, the employees and other stakeholders

author: A
sentence: And then there’s what’s good for society

author: A
sentence: And what’s just overall sensible

author: A
sentence: I think those two melt into one another to a fair degree

author: A
sentence: But I don’t think it’s necessarily all about just saying what’s good for the company

author: A
sentence: It’s really what sort of society we want to have

author: Q
sentence: And you want to have a society that gives women a fair go

author: A
sentence: Well I think it should be, yes, women, and it should be minorities and it should be a whole lot of -

author: Q
sentence: So, that’s where the demographics come in

author: A
sentence: I think any guy with a daughter, should just look through that lens and say, how would I feel if my daughter is sitting there at Freehills

author: A
sentence: She’s a very capable girl, she has high honours degree, she’s got a masters now that she did in London before she started at Freehills

author: A
sentence: Why should she sit in the back row because, as my partner says, “No vagina is required here

author: A
sentence: ”It really irritates her

author: A
sentence: And I get that

author: A
sentence: I try to imagine what it would be like to be sitting on the other side of that fence and how frustrated I’d be

author: A
sentence: You’re watching people less capable, but it’s just they happen to be born with a penis

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: A
sentence: Or whatever

author: Q
sentence: Or gone to blah, blah, blah

author: A
sentence: Or they had white skin instead of brown skin or something

author: A
sentence: Or they just happened to be born in this country not – therefore you might not look to be the right mix for us

author: Q
sentence: Final question

author: Q
sentence: Ten years from now

author: Q
sentence: How would you like to see diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: So, I’ve had a range, from Macquarie I sat on a number of large boards but they weren’t public company boards, they were Macquarie investment vehicles and things

author: A
sentence: So, we had a five billion dollar, in terms of enterprise value, was chairing two five billion dollar companies

author: A
sentence: I’ve also had pretty extensive vehicles

author: A
sentence: I’m now chairing a couple of companies that – well one is a small listed tech company that’s market caps ranging between 40 and 80 million depending on the day of the week

author: A
sentence: But then I’ve got a little start up business

author: A
sentence: We’ve just bought, I’ve done a management buyout with an old friend

author: A
sentence: I helped him out and he asked me if I’d chair that and invest in it

author: A
sentence: And that’s sort of worth, I don’t know, 15 million dollars

author: A
sentence: And another one that is worth, well we don’t know whether it’s worth anything yet, but we’ve put money into it, with one of Melbourne’s big billionaire families

author: A
sentence: So, they’re bringing a good discipline to it

author: A
sentence: So, it’s a real range of things

author: A
sentence: The best answer is, we wouldn’t even be thinking about it, because we’re sort of there

author: A
sentence: So, that’s probably my base answer

author: A
sentence: I think 10 years, that’s not going to happen

author: A
sentence: I’m just being a realist, not because I don’t think it’s a good thing to aspire to

author: A
sentence: I just don’t think we move quite that quickly

author: A
sentence: Having said that, I reckon, I look at women’s sport and I reckon, the progress in women’s sport in the last ten years has been extraordinary

author: A
sentence: So, you do get inflection points and all of a sudden a couple of things happen

author: A
sentence: And if you told me how many girls would be playing AFLW, or junior levels of that, I would have laughed and said girls don’t want to play, there’s a tiny minority of girls that want to play football

author: A
sentence: Most of them they want to play netball and basketball and soccer maybe, but football no, my daughter wouldn’t want to play, therefore I assumed no other girls did

author: A
sentence: And I was totally, totally wrong

author: A
sentence: And even the number that want to play cricket surprises me, less so

author: A
sentence: And those sports, particularly the women’s cricket now

author: A
sentence: I'm still amused that they’re referring to the Ashes, the Ashes don’t start for another two months, but they’re talking about, they don’t say the Women’s Ashes they just say –maybe it’s because I listen to the ABC

author: A
sentence: But it is interesting

author: A
sentence: The mindset shift, therefore, it could happen in a corporate world, a slightly different one

author: A
sentence: There are so many women in the professions at senior levels now compared to – when I started at Minter Ellison, there was one partner, one female partner, but it wasn’t a huge partnership then, it was probably 13 or 15 or something

author: A
sentence: And then they merged and they merged

author: A
sentence: When I left four years later, there was still only a very small number of female partners

author: A
sentence: And then I’m back there as a client a number of years later and I’m looking at the letterhead and so on

author: A
sentence: A lot more female partners

author: A
sentence: It’s been a rapid change in a sense

author: Q
sentence: The last two decades is that, you’re talking?

author: A
sentence: I would say the last two decades

author: A
sentence: And probably gaining pace, I would say, I don’t think its losing pace, or I don’t think it’s linear

author: A
sentence: I think it’s been slightly been a -

author: Q
sentence: What’s stopping it, what’s stopping it then? What are the main barriers?

author: A
sentence: To female

author: A
sentence: I don’t know whether it’s stopping, I think it’s just not moving as quickly as it should

author: Q
sentence: What’s holding it back?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I don’t think culturally we’ve probably come to grips with the true sharing of parenthood

author: A
sentence: I think that’s a big part of it

author: A
sentence: And maybe I’m oversimplifying it and there’s a whole lot of stuff for women that aren’t having children as well

author: A
sentence: But I think it still ties back to that

author: A
sentence: As my partner and my daughter were discussing the other night [Christie]01:08:35 says there was also this assumption that even if she wasn’t having children, that she might

author: A
sentence: She might go and have a child and therefore, better choose a guy because he wasn’t going off on maternity leave

author: A
sentence: It’s safer

author: A
sentence: Certain countries have been – Scandinavian have probably been the leaders in this, it’s very progressive policies

author: A
sentence: But the Canadians –I had an old friend in here yesterday, a younger guy

author: A
sentence: He’s – what’s Alex – in his late thirties and his wife be mid-thirties

author: A
sentence: And she’s got a senior job at [Lululemon]01:09:08 in Vancouver in their head office

author: A
sentence: Big marketing role

author: A
sentence: She’s taking – they’re having their first child in a couple of months

author: A
sentence: She’s going to take three months off before the baby

author: A
sentence: She’ll take 12 months off after

author: A
sentence: And she might take a few more after that

author: A
sentence: Because the Canadian and the corporate, it might be partly their corporates, I don’t know how much is Canadian law versus their corporate policy

author: A
sentence: But that sounded extremely flexible to me compared to what I think would be available here

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Well this is fabulous

author: Q
sentence: If you can think, I’ll be asking you questions, but if you can say, well if it was this situation, that, because it might vary and be good to know if-

author: A
sentence: Is that the barrier? We just need to gradually see that as a much more equal sharing of raising children

author: Q
sentence: It’s certainly a role of New Zealand Prime Minister

author: Q
sentence: Her husband is holding the baby

author: A
sentence: Well one of the women that started with me at Minters switched to Allens Arthur Robs, she had four girls

author: A
sentence: Her husband was a landscape gardener, I believe he still is

author: A
sentence: He raised the four girls

author: A
sentence: She’s had a big corporate career

author: A
sentence: She’s now CEO at Tiger Airlines

author: A
sentence: She went through years at Virgin as corporate counsel and then ran one of the divisions and then ended up running Tiger, [Merren McArthur

author: A
sentence: I had a partner at [McKinsey] I worked for, she wasn’t just making partner,[Alison Watkins]01:10:27 who is head of Coca-Cola Amatil

author: A
sentence: [Alison’s] husband has largely raised their kids

author: A
sentence: And there are a handful like that

author: A
sentence: But it’s the fact that I can rattle off a few examples, I’m not struggling to think of examples

author: A
sentence: There is limited number in the pool

author: A
sentence: There just probably needs to be a bit more of that

author: A
sentence: That’s a big cultural thing, turning the Queen Mary I suspect

author: A
sentence: It’s not like the male Australia wakes up one morning and says, we ought to do it differently

author: Q
sentence: But anyway, you’ve talked about the different kinds of diversity like for the decision making and all that

author: Q
sentence: And you’ve talked about the culture of the board as being an important part there

author: A
sentence: I’m trained – I did undergrad in law and commerce

author: A
sentence: Well I thought it would be worth elaborating on that background, because it is quite a mish mash of different stuff

author: A
sentence: It’s not the sort of – some of my colleagues are sitting on a handful of big corporate boards, but they don’t touch small business much

author: Q
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: And then we tend to then work between interviewees, but it’s really good to have the same person reflecting across

author: Q
sentence: Plus, you were around with the GFC so, you can talk about how that might have influenced things as well

author: Q
sentence: So, how many years does it span then, that you’ve been a board director?

author: A
sentence: I suppose it’s probably 30

author: A
sentence: Early stuff was, as I said, advisory board

author: A
sentence: And I sat on school – my old school asked me to come back and sit on the board at probably a pretty tender age

author: A
sentence: I think that’s probably, not 30 years, but 25 years

author: A
sentence: More than that because it was before I went to business school

author: Q
sentence: How many do you currently sit on?

author: A
sentence: I was trying to count that up when I was thinking

author: A
sentence: I’m sitting on – probably, if I just group some, because they are a group of boards that are related and you almost have the board meeting back to back

author: A
sentence: So, if I just took them as groups, I’d say there’s six, that are sort of corporate boards

author: Q
sentence: Six corporate

author: A
sentence: Only one listed

author: Q
sentence: One listed

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: A
sentence: Probably about three philanthropic

author: Q
sentence: Of the six?

author: Q
sentence: Law and commerce

author: A
sentence: No, separately

author: Q
sentence: Well, let’s just put lots

author: Q
sentence: It says, how many boards have you sat on? But it is, it’s lots

author: A
sentence: In terms of past, there’s a lot

author: A
sentence: Because it’s just been part of my life with Macquarie, for a number of years there representing Macquarie on – there were some that were much chunkier and more relevant though

author: A
sentence: There were two big ones when I was in London, which were quite mature

author: Q
sentence: Amazing

author: Q
sentence: Amazing experience

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: I can see why Paul grabbed you

author: Q
sentence: So, first, how has the composition of boards that you’re familiar with changed over time, in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: That’s pretty clear cut

author: A
sentence: I think about the two big boards in Europe and I don’t think it necessarily reflected on Macquarie but maybe a bit, but they were all male

author: A
sentence: If you just limited the diversity question to male/female to start with, that’s been a big shift

author: A
sentence: It’s probably even more so, for me, because I grew up in a family of six boys and one girl

author: A
sentence: My sister, who is extremely capable, and now running a big spiritually centre, she’s the National President and so on

author: A
sentence: So, she’s a very capable person

author: A
sentence: But she wasn’t much interested in commercial matters in her twenties

author: A
sentence: And she actually went and did teaching and had a family young, and then has probably come back later to those sorts of matters

author: A
sentence: And I think would have been every bit as competent as her brothers, but she wasn’t involved in those family boards, because her career choices and other choices – she had four young kids by the time she was 30, I would say

author: A
sentence: So, that’s going back through the 90s and the 2000s, the Macquarie stuff

author: A
sentence: We had quite a few senior female colleagues, but nowhere near what the legal profession or the accounting profession did, because of the nature of the work in my part of Macquarie, could be incredibly intensive

author: A
sentence: And there was an element to which we always said women were smarter and knocked it out of that, because it would just take over your life

author: A
sentence: But it was also not conducive to anybody wanting to start a family

author: A
sentence: It just really, I think, was very difficult to match with a period of pregnancy and/or post pregnancy period

author: A
sentence: And there were only a few women I saw try to do that

author: A
sentence: Talking to friends and observing it, I think there’s been a lot more effort made in that area to make it a more conducive environment

author: Q
sentence: Now?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: For how many years?

author: A
sentence: That’s interesting

author: A
sentence: Because I’ve been out of Macquarie for 10 years

author: A
sentence: So, it's really only anecdotally and talking to friends, et cetera

author: A
sentence: But I feel like it’s more achievable over this post GFC period

author: A
sentence: Maybe it’s – and also, I was also overseas for the previous four, so it’s hard to tell between offices, et cetera

author: A
sentence: But I’d say Law and Accounting probably still provide a better opportunity to step in, step out

author: A
sentence: Maybe to do more from home or from choosing your own, whether you can be four days a week, et cetera

author: A
sentence: I think Mergers and Acquisitions, whether you're a lawyer or a banker, they tend to be, everybody’s expected to just put their life aside and get that done, sometimes

author: A
sentence: Practiced as a lawyer for about four years, during which time I did a Grad Dip in Applied Finance and was sort of taking a stronger interest in that area

author: A
sentence: And then I decided to do an MBA

author: A
sentence: I had an older brother studied in the US and I was envious of the career opportunities that had opened up for him and I was talking to him and decided to apply myself

author: A
sentence: So, I ended up making those applications, got lucky and got in to my school of first choice at Harvard

author: A
sentence: So, I did that MBA, early 90’s

author: A
sentence: I’m going back for my 25th reunion, funnily enough, in the next couple of months

author: A
sentence: So, time flies

author: Q
sentence: Even now

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: I don’t believe it’s all of a sudden become a game where everybody says well, we’ve all got to have a life and let’s go home now and have dinner with the family and we’ll start this again in the morning

author: A
sentence: People just say the competition are – this bids going in and somebody else might make a counter bid or there’s a regulatory deadline

author: A
sentence: There’s always a deadline

author: A
sentence: And there's always that sense that it’s got to happen yesterday

author: Q
sentence: An urgency

author: A
sentence: It’s rare that big corporate deals happen, just roll along at a gradual pace

author: A
sentence: They don’t

author: A
sentence: Whereas if you’re doing property law or litigation, they have their own rhythm

author: A
sentence: Property you lodge it and you wait for the title’s office

author: A
sentence: But my observation as a young lawyer was that, the female partners would often choose not to be, they weren’t in the [M&A] area, for example

author: A
sentence: Now that’s changed, I’m sure that there are probably more

author: A
sentence: But I still think that that’s one of the issues that they’re combining -

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s the work/life balance possibilities

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: And it’s sort of, you can try and work around that a bit

author: A
sentence: But my daughters just started at Freehills, so it’s really interesting for me to hear her observations of what partner she’s working with

author: A
sentence: She’s very keen to work under strong female partners that are setting– I connected her with one that I knew well, who’s been in the projects team which is sort of, probably not far off Mergers and Acquisitions, for huge deadlines and things

author: A
sentence: If you’re working on a big government pitch for a toll road or something, then that will have huge time pressure, potentially

author: A
sentence: And she’s a mother of two or three girls on the board at, I think [St Cath’s]00:16:42 in Toorak or [Mandeville]00:16:43 or something

author: A
sentence: I know she’s got teenage to later age daughters now and so on

author: A
sentence: And she’s been able to balance that, find a way through that

author: A
sentence: But I know from talking to her over lunch, that it’s not been easy

author: A
sentence: She’s had to fight to create some of that balance

author: Q
sentence: And get a mentor

author: A
sentence: Well, that’s the partner

author: A
sentence: And she would have had probably only male mentors

author: A
sentence: I don’t reckon there were too many female partners ahead of her at [Freehills]

author: A
sentence: Because she’s a woman close to my age

author: A
sentence: She’d be similar, she’d be 50 something

author: A
sentence: So, I think she’s great for the ones then that are my daughter’s age, at 25, saying you’ve got to stand up for yourself a bit, and find and not put up with –interesting discussion, I might be diverting too much

author: A
sentence: My daughter just told me over dinner last week that they had – actually just a few nights ago with my partner – she was saying that they had, basically I suppose a diversity session, and there were some guys there, but it was 80/20, 90/10 sort of crowd

author: A
sentence: Much more about the women and they had that discussion

author: A
sentence: Well we’re preaching to the converted here

author: A
sentence: We’re all agreeing on it, but it’s really the guys that need to hear some of these messages

author: A
sentence: Because one of the big things was that the male partner in one of the teams there, and he went unnamed, had organised a golf day with the clients

author: A
sentence: And they’re not even invited, any of the women on the team, to go

author: A
sentence: And that was still happening now

author: A
sentence: Which I would have thought, I wouldn’t have been surprised if it was happening five or ten years ago, but I probably was surprised when she told me that the other day

author: A
sentence: And it really riled her of course, just because it was taking very junior guys in the team, but not quite senior females

author: A
sentence: So, it was really incredibly stereotyped

author: A
sentence: So that was – that’s just an anecdote to show that, even though I think the law firms are much more progressed and have been forever, ahead of, I think, say banks, investment banks, they’re still not there

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: But when I came back, I was very tempted by an offer join Macquarie

author: A
sentence: I can’t remember, it was just a good friend, and I suppose, there were a couple of factors, my brother had gone to [McKinsey]00:01:21 and really enjoyed it and that’s where I went for a couple of years

author: A
sentence: But I ended up taking the offer at Macquarie two years later and moved a few hundred metres down Collins St, and spent most of my career in Finance as a result

author: A
sentence: 13 or so years at Macquarie, including the last four in London

author: A
sentence: And I guess to give the full picture there, that was intended to be in the private equity space, but they were getting an offer set up in Melbourne and they were taking over a smaller private equity operation and going to incorporate that into something else Macquarie was doing

author: A
sentence: But as is the way of these things, it wasn’t quite timed perfectly so, they said come and sit with the corporate finance guys in the M&A team and that all sort of evolved over the next six months, but it never did

author: A
sentence: The deal fell over

author: A
sentence: I liked M&A and the people I was working with and I just stayed there

author: A
sentence: In terms of boards though

author: A
sentence: Which is really your -

author: Q
sentence: We’re focussing on boards

author: A
sentence: I have a listed board that I was with yesterday

author: A
sentence: We have an excellent female director

author: A
sentence: We would be very happy to have more

author: A
sentence: The company background, sorry focus, is technology and it’s in the medical and defence sort of areas

author: A
sentence: Defence has been a male dominated area, I think, and therefore the people with the networks and the experience that you’re likely to want to get on to the board for those reasons, are more likely to be male

author: A
sentence: That’s just sort of unfortunately, it’s not to say its exclusively that way, and we’ve got an opportunity for somebody that’s got those sorts of connections to make, because we lost a director or two just change of jobs, location, et cetera

author: A
sentence: But we’ve definitely, I see a huge value in having that diversity

author: A
sentence: I do think, it does change the dynamic and it’s just you get a different perspective and it’s hard to put your finger on exactly, but it’s just, I think there is a slightly different approach

author: A
sentence: And some women think more like men and some men think more like women

author: A
sentence: I know it’s a spectrum

author: A
sentence: But I just think if you’re generalising, you will get a definitely slightly different approach and a slightly different approach to the discussion in the meeting too

author: A
sentence: And I think it can be quite helpful to tone down some of the bulls in the paddock sort of behaviour

author: A
sentence: It doesn’t always work

author: A
sentence: We had a guy on the board who was very problematic for me as chairman and we got rid of him

author: A
sentence: Just because his behaviours were just unhelpful

author: Q
sentence: Can you describe those unhelpful behaviours?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think I could

author: A
sentence: It happened in this room sometimes when I opposed

author: A
sentence: He would – he was a very enthusiastic fellow, with some real strengths

author: A
sentence: I’m not pretending

author: A
sentence: But the weaknesses were around talking over people

author: A
sentence: Just wouldn’t let people finish a question

author: A
sentence: He’d anticipate the questions and start answering what he thought it should be or would be

author: A
sentence: Which was very frustrating

author: A
sentence: And would bluster sort of his way through when he was in a slightly awkward spot as to whatever he just tried to, loud, more correct sort of approach

author: A
sentence: I’m just going to – and sometimes just like a “Trust me, trust me, I know what I’m talking about here

author: A
sentence: This is my neck of the words

author: A
sentence: ” Blah, blah, blah

author: A
sentence: And it was no, no, we all need to get comfortable with this

author: A
sentence: We’ve got to talk it through

author: A
sentence: And it’s not enough for you to just say, I know

author: A
sentence: So it was that sort of style

author: A
sentence: And frankly, didn’t have a – he lost the confidence of the rest of the board

author: A
sentence: But that was probably a separate issue

author: A
sentence: But the behaviours that were bad for the dynamics were sort of coming all prepared and then sort of tried to bluster over things

author: A
sentence: And just short circuit conversations where we did need to get deeper and we did need to get everybody to understand, so that they could all contribute or at least get comfortable with the decision making that was under way

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Because an idea of inclusiveness, cultivating an inclusive culture, on the board, it sounds like he was at odds with that?

author: A
sentence: He was

author: A
sentence: So, it would be quite difficult for everybody

author: A
sentence: And we had one older director who, he’s quite good, but if he gets frustrated, he will say, “Excuse me I need to understand that better

author: A
sentence: ” But for the first year or so, he wasn’t used to being on a public company board

author: A
sentence: He had lots of value to add, but he wasn’t really an experienced director, at least for these sorts of matters

author: A
sentence: And I knew we weren’t getting the benefit of his insights, because he would just throw his back a bit

author: A
sentence: So, it was just a difficult dynamic

author: A
sentence: And about, I guess, five, six years in, we had a restructure and with that [Nicholas Moore]00:02:31 who became the CEO of Macquarie, eventually took over our group, and was big on the idea of Macquarie playing a principle role alongside our clients, or even instead of, maybe being the client

author: A
sentence: And that was quite a shift and created some ripples in commercial Australia

author: Q
sentence: So, what did you do to help him move forward, this old guy?

author: A
sentence: Well, I would just sometimes bring him directly into the conversation

author: A
sentence: I’d say “Alexander, I’m sure that you’ve seen this sort of thing in different guises and what would your take be?” And try to draw that out of him

author: A
sentence: I’d also talk to him offline and say, I want you to not feel the least bit of hesitation in interrupting and saying, I'm not comfortable that I've fully understood this fully

author: A
sentence: Because you might be speaking for all of us when you say that

author: A
sentence: I said I’m going to have to do it more often, because Richard is a difficult personality and we’ve got to work our way through that

author: A
sentence: In the end, it became obvious that we just – the CEO took him aside and spoke to him, I spoke to him as chair

author: A
sentence: I’d inherited, he actually approached me to join the board, so it was a funny –then they asked me to chair the board

author: A
sentence: So, I just had to say to him – it wasn’t that we were long term friends – but we were more just business colleagues

author: A
sentence: But yes, difficult, because likeable, but it often makes it even harder when they’re likeable rogues, but they’re rogues none the less

author: A
sentence: That was probably the – and we tried to concentrate as a chair to make sure you pick up the body language and see if people are feeling exasperated or just confused or thwarted in their attempts

author: A
sentence: And try to bring them in to the conversation and try to say, “Richard, is that the question you were asking Alexander? Because I don’t think it is, Richard

author: A
sentence: Can we just address the question?”So, try to do that

author: A
sentence: But in the end, we had to just move him on

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think any of this, from this gentleman, was because of an inability to cope with diversity on the board?

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure

author: A
sentence: I think it helped when [Yasmin]00:25:32 joined because she brought a different perspective, but she also was a very strong personality and very capable of just saying, “No, hold on, this isn’t my home ground, I need to understand that better

author: A
sentence: ” And she had some very relevant background, but not in the same space as this guy

author: A
sentence: And I think his view was he could just sort of –it was the whole snake oil salesman, you know, trust me

author: A
sentence: Look, I think his behaviours weren’t necessarily driven by a problem with diversity, they were helped, I think, by in a sense having some different ears on the table

author: A
sentence: But in the end that wasn’t enough to solve for it

author: A
sentence: I think skipping past him, she’s just been a very strong sort of extra presence on the board, who’s brought a different perspective and that’s diversity and background as well as an experience, et cetera

author: A
sentence: Her expertise and her experience is different to mine and to the other directors

author: A
sentence: So, it's not just about her being a female by any means

author: Q
sentence: So, can you expand on what board diversity means to you?

author: A
sentence: Well, those things

author: A
sentence: I think it is experience and it is expertise

author: A
sentence: But it is also you’re broader background

author: A
sentence: I think someone who has grown up sort of where a little stereotype, the silver spoon mouth, you’ve been through private school, mum and dad got you a tutor and the school made sure that nobody was going to fail

author: A
sentence: And you got through to your university course and you still had tutors or whatever

author: A
sentence: And you’ve done your fair bit of work, but you haven’t really ever known what it is to get up at five in the morning and do that couple of hours of work before or whatever it is

author: Q
sentence: A barista

author: A
sentence: Yes, being the barista or something and squeezing stuff in as much

author: A
sentence: My kids meet half of that description

author: A
sentence: They haven’t had tutors and stuff, they’ve worked hard, but they’ve never known that real pressure

author: A
sentence: So, I think, having people with different degrees of that

author: A
sentence: I think people that have grown up in a – if it's not a battling environment, maybe a very different environment, rural environment or a foreign environment and so different sort of backgrounds that bring different perspectives

author: A
sentence: And I think women coming through, see things differently, because they see these subtle sorts of barriers and some not so subtle

author: A
sentence: So, I think that’s part of it

author: A
sentence: But I think people who have emigrated or people who have had big challenges, could be health challenges, could be disability or something

author: A
sentence: I’m working with a lawyer who’s a fantastic guy, who’s severely health challenged all his life

author: A
sentence: Amazingly capable and productive person

author: A
sentence: And I think the fact that he’s overcome that, probably really gives him a certain edge over many other people

author: A
sentence: So, I think it can come in lots of ways

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive diversity, different ways of problem solving, thinking about things

author: Q
sentence: When was that?

author: A
sentence: And I guess I’m just thinking that that’s a result of lots of that

author: A
sentence: But it is also true that you just meet some people who are, might have gone to the same school and university as you, but by virtue of their genetics or whatever else, think differently to you and I think that’s always a real positive

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: How important, let’s say ten is extremely important and one is not at all

author: Q
sentence: How important is it for diversity in Australia?

author: A
sentence: I think, Australia or anywhere, it’s really important because group think is usually dangerous and -

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s about avoiding group think

author: A
sentence: If everybody sort of just gets on board and says yes, that sounds right to me

author: A
sentence: If you don’t get that person who’s sort of going oh well just because it’s always been done that way

author: A
sentence: There are alternatives and so on

author: A
sentence: Yes, it worried me at Macquarie

author: A
sentence: My team on the private equity space, we had a whole lot of ex-pat Aussies living in London, we did have some local poms, but generally male and generally in the 20 to 35bracket

author: A
sentence: My team sort of had a real sameness about it

author: A
sentence: One young guy was a Pakistani, but he had grown up in Toronto so, he wasn’t that different to us really

author: A
sentence: And all had done similar finance undergrads and so on

author: A
sentence: And they all worked in corporate finance and then slipped over to the private equity team

author: A
sentence: And I just said the next person has got to be, maybe from a management consulting background, instead

author: A
sentence: Where they’ve been going into companies and working on different types of issues, not corporate finance issues

author: A
sentence: Ideally a woman, ideally a European with multiple languages, because we’re working in Europe

author: Q
sentence: Of course

author: A
sentence: And I found that really interesting

author: A
sentence: Going across sitting on this board

author: A
sentence: We had eight European national operations that had been cobbled together under one head office in Amsterdam

author: A
sentence: And every one of those companies operated so differently because of the national characteristics

author: Q
sentence: Do you think being in Australia, that we need to have that kind of diversity to work, to link with Europe?

author: A
sentence: I think it helps a lot

author: A
sentence: I think if you just had a bunch of young, not even the age, but your classic never left Australia sort of 50-year-old blokes, sitting here, maybe gone on the odd European holiday, trying to work with companies that span, whether it’s Asia or Europe

author: A
sentence: And if you haven’t lived there, got some sort of cultural understanding of it, I think it’s harder by a long way

author: A
sentence: And your odds of success are probably a lot longer

author: Q
sentence: Is that pretty well – do you think it’s more important in a finance sector, than perhaps other sectors?

author: A
sentence: That was about 2001

author: A
sentence: Not really

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: I would have thought that’s true, whether you’re manufacturing goods and you’re trying to work out how people buy things

author: A
sentence: And if you don’t understand the decision makers in – let’s take some European markets and say that in Germany – I’ll make stuff up

author: A
sentence: That it’s actually the women in the household that are making all these decisions, they’re doing all this purchasing, even though they might, in Australia, be deemed to be the Bunnings type male purchase

author: A
sentence: But in Germany they’re not

author: A
sentence: If you didn’t understand that and grasp that you could be -

author: Q
sentence: Your advertising campaign is over

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: You could be right out of touch

author: A
sentence: If you didn’t understand that – let’s look at a failed thing

author: A
sentence: They did try to take Bunnings into the UK using them and didn’t understand that the UK doesn’t have – there’s not those spaces for big box retail, in the sort of places that most people do their shopping

author: A
sentence: So, you’re trying to wrench them into a whole new type of purchasing behaviour

author: A
sentence: That on a Saturday instead of going down the High Street they’re driving out to the edges of London, which is no mean feat

author: A
sentence: Takes you your full hour or so to get to the edge of the city and two hours to get to the other edge of the city

author: A
sentence: So, that failed in London

author: A
sentence: Not just London, but the UK, as an overall move

author: A
sentence: So, I think you do need to understand culturally

author: A
sentence: And that’s, it doesn’t mean you have to immediately go and find a pom and put them on the board

author: A
sentence: But you’ve got to recognise your weaknesses

author: A
sentence: And you’re more likely to do that, the more opinions and mindsets around the table, the more likely you are to recognise those gaps

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: And then you can fill it in through research or whatever

author: Q
sentence: Your advisory board

author: A
sentence: You bring advisers on and you maybe bring on a new director from that location

author: Q
sentence: So, would you say it’s a nine or a ten or an eight or -

author: A
sentence: In terms of importance?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Can you tie into it?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: It will vary by where you’re selling and what you’re selling, et cetera

author: A
sentence: And whether it services and so on

author: A
sentence: But I think if I was just trying to throw a blanket over it, I would have thought it was up there at the eight or nine

author: Q
sentence: And it does depend on the situational context

author: Q
sentence: So, the reason it changes is – is there because of risk? Do you think it’s important in situations of risk? Or not important

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think it’s – are we talking diversity generally?

author: Q
sentence: Diversity, generally

author: A
sentence: Generally

author: Q
sentence: And it’s very broad what you said

author: Q
sentence: But ultimately to avoid group think, I think is your -

author: A
sentence: I think it – but I wouldn’t want to limit it to saying it’s a risk mitigant, because it’s much more than that

author: A
sentence: It’s about your creative

author: A
sentence: You can look at it, and say you’re eliminating some risk of the downside, but you’re also creating a huge upside potential

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: No-one’s put it so succinctly

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Is there a particular kind of diversity that matter more than others, do you think?

author: A
sentence: I think the type of – I do think it’s really important to have people who come at problems differently

author: A
sentence: And that can be driven, as we said, it could be your experience, it could be your expertise and it could just be your background, where you’ve lived and family experience and so on

author: A
sentence: But to me, it's about having people come at things differently

author: A
sentence: So, they’ll look at the same painting on the wall, and they’ll think about that quite differently

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: I notice that

author: A
sentence: So, that to me, is more important to me than saying, oh well, she’s a woman, she’ll understand how women purchase

author: A
sentence: That might be true, but there’s probably a bunch of really intuitive male marketers out there who’d understand that just as well or better

author: A
sentence: You don’t have to be a woman to understand, you don’t have to have played league football to coach it

author: Q
sentence: So, it seems that, and this is a theme that I think has come up

author: Q
sentence: You’re about number 38 that I’ve interviewed

author: Q
sentence: That other kinds of diversity like background, gender, all those demographics, they are contributing to this cognitive diversity or different ways

author: Q
sentence: And it’s that what you want

author: Q
sentence: It’s not how you get, whether it’s your background, whatever

author: Q
sentence: But that you get cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: Because through that you get risk mitigation and value creation

author: Q
sentence: Is that it?

author: Q
sentence: Thank you very much, 37D, for agreeing to participate in our research, it’s fabulous, we’re really pleased to have you onboard

author: Q
sentence: We’re talking about board diversity, and we’re really interested to hear from people like yourself, who are on the ground, who sit on Australian boards, and then we’ll look at building theory from that experience

author: Q
sentence: So, thank you very much for contributing your experience

author: Q
sentence: So, we can reflect across four boards, three of which are not for profit and one is for profit

author: Q
sentence: That will be great

author: Q
sentence: What year were you first a director?

author: A
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: I’d like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards

author: Q
sentence: Have you ever seen it create conflict, and if so, how was it managed?

author: A
sentence: I haven’t seen it create conflict, and I think this is where the basic rules need to be put down, as far as the respect, integrity, communication, and how that all plays out

author: A
sentence: So, no I haven’t ever experienced that, to be honest

author: Q
sentence: That doesn’t arise from diversity, that arises from a poorly developed culture, does it?

author: A
sentence: I would suggest so, yeah

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and board functioning; do you feel that cognitive diversity influences your board’s functioning?

author: A
sentence: When you talk about ‘cognitive diversity’ can you just elaborate more on what you mean with that?

author: Q
sentence: Well, I don’t mean anything

author: Q
sentence: There’s a term out there called cognitive diversity, it’s not fleshed out consistently in the theory so I can’t give you an objective view, but what I understand it to mean is that people have different approaches to problem solving

author: Q
sentence: Some people, for example, might be process oriented, some people might be outcomes oriented

author: Q
sentence: When you talked about the test you did to see how different people on the board think, that would be part of cognitive diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: That’s fine

author: A
sentence: I would suggest that cognitive diversity, if you don’t have it, I think, you would run the risk of having that groupthink

author: A
sentence: So, you do need your people who are risk averse, like the checks and balances people, but you also need the future thinking people

author: A
sentence: I guess this is why boards often will ask for a mix of people at the board, but they often will go for the education and skill base of a lawyer, a marketing person, an IT person

author: A
sentence: Now, whether that’s the ideal type of way to advertise for people, I’m not sure

author: A
sentence: You do, perhaps, need technical expertise, although on a board, you and conceivably ask for technical expertise to be brought in as you need it

author: A
sentence: So, I’m not totally convinced that you do need all that technical knowledge at the board, but I do think you need that way of looking at things

author: A
sentence: For instance, generally, not always speaking, but older generations we may be more risk averse with our thinking because we’re in a different place in our life, and not always the case

author: A
sentence: Whereas, a young person my see many different opportunities and ways a problem could be solved

author: A
sentence: So, it’s important, absolutely, otherwise, I think, we could run the risk of that groupthink

author: A
sentence: With the  Credit Union, that was 1999 that I was appointed to that board, and in 2009 I voluntarily exited, and we may well get into why I did that, I’m not sure what the questions will be

author: Q
sentence: Do people outside the board influence the selection process?

author: A
sentence: Outside?

author: Q
sentence: Like recruitment organisations, do they influence the process of selection?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think it depends on what board you’re looking at

author: A
sentence: Some boards do go through recruiters and will be that first point of call

author: A
sentence: Some boards do their own recruiting, government boards it can be a variety of external recruiters or advisors from politicians seeking out various people to sit on government boards, although there is a more rigorous way of selecting people for government boards now, having to register, for instance, up front

author: A
sentence: I think there are a variety of ways, and it might just be a word of mouth search, as well

author: Q
sentence: Do you think, the boards that you’ve been on, when they’ve been selecting new members, have they considered ways to increase diversity?

author: A
sentence: If I look at Australian Central Credit Union, when I was on that board we were purely member elected, and then, over time, we brought in a board selection subcommittee to interview candidates and we would have someone independent on that particular board, but mostly it was made up of board members, which is an interesting combination, in itself

author: A
sentence: Over time, with now what’s turned into People’s Choice Credit Union, I notice they’re really orchestrating the directors they have on their own board

author: A
sentence: So, they’re trying really hard to vet out members who put their hands up before the election comes, so there’s no competition for the people they’re wanting on their board

author: A
sentence: Can you prove it?  Probably not, but that’s what it looks like

author: Q
sentence: Wow, and that’s more recent, these are recent practises?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: The first question is, what does board diversity mean to you?

author: Q
sentence: So, very inward looking?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So, regulation hasn’t been able to change that?

author: A
sentence: Its interesting, isn’t it?  Because I would have thought regulation would contain it, but, I suppose, with any regulation, you can look at the rules and work around it to get what you need

author: A
sentence: So, in the case, I suspect, with People’s Choice, for instance, they’re looking at particular skills and backgrounds of board members, so they would probably be arguing the case that, “These are the people we need on the board

author: A
sentence: ”  So, I imagine that’s how they’re doing it

author: Q
sentence: Then, they’re presenting this group to their members who vote them on, is that it?

author: A
sentence: That’s right, that’s exactly right

author: A
sentence: And, unless there’s quite a loud dissent it will just carry on as it is

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel tensions can arise in the board selection process, between on the one hand trying to avoid groupthink, and on the other to obtain a collegiate fit to support that culture of the board?

author: A
sentence: What was the last part you said?

author: Q
sentence: A collegiate fit to support the culture of the board?

author: A
sentence: It’s an interesting balance, really, because you certainly don’t want a board that’s just forever having a big talk fest about everything and not making decisions

author: A
sentence: That’s why I think education of board members, when they are first reporting to boards, is really important, so they understand their role, they understand the process, they understand decisions need to be made, they understand the organisation they’re with

author: A
sentence: So, those types of introductory processes and ground rules are really important

author: A
sentence: I think there’s a fine line between collegiate and diversity

author: A
sentence: It’s an interesting point you raise, really

author: A
sentence: Board diversity is, to me, much broader than just the male/female bit

author: A
sentence: It’s something that needs to address the changing landscape, of our population, in cultural mix as well as age range

author: A
sentence: I think countries, generally, are aging, so we need to have the younger to older generations, the different cultural backgrounds, and also the male/female things, and the skill mix, as well

author: A
sentence: So, it’s multidimensional, it’s not just what, I believe, was initially the discussion of the board diversity, and that was simply male/female mix

author: A
sentence: I would, probably, feel happier with diversity as opposed to the collegiate gathering, depending on how deeply all the relationships ran and what the connections were

author: A
sentence: There is talk in Eastern states, particularly in New South Wales, that there are particular old boys’ networks that just continually support each other to be on boards

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if it’s true, but this is what I’ve heard

author: A
sentence: That would worry me more, I think, as well

author: Q
sentence: I’ve interviewed board members, and they’re male, who have said, “I wouldn’t accept a board position if there was not gender diversity,” they can see that, because it’s a sign that board is too conservative for them

author: A
sentence: Yes, that’s really encouraging, that’s very good

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s what the women say

author: Q
sentence: So, the boards that you’re on and are familiar with, do they have any barriers to managing or building diversity?

author: A
sentence: The two I’m currently on, no there are no barriers

author: A
sentence: I guess it’s just really how they’ve landed, to be honest, and it’s to do more with the interest of the people involved in these particular bodies

author: A
sentence: With the previous ones, the only barrier with Australian Central was to have the members support you; that was the biggest barrier

author: A
sentence: Over time, what could have become a barrier, and did become a barrier to some, members who wanted to become board directors and who were not on the board currently, was the actual board interview process, and they didn’t, necessarily, pass the appropriate test of understanding corporate governance and fiduciary duty and things like that

author: A
sentence: That’s an interesting thing, in itself, given that some members owned financial institution to knock people out

author: A
sentence: So, that’s a dilemma, in itself, in many ways, knocking members out of running for a member institution, ist’ probably more of a moral, ethical dilemma, I think, more than anything; perhaps not a legal dilemma, but morally and ethically, I think, very challenging

author: Q
sentence: To understand that, are you saying that if a person is a member of an organisation that they can’t become a member of the board unless they understand board governance, [overtalk] [00:33:13]

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: There were a number of questions about understanding the organisation, the fiduciary duties, the governance, just all those structures, which, in my view, can be learnt

author: A
sentence: It’s not, necessarily, something you need to go to a board with

author: A
sentence: It’s an old age question, isn’t it?  When you go for an interview and they’re wanting experience, if you don’t have experience how do you get experience if you don’t ever have the chance

author: A
sentence: So, I think, entry into boards and onto boards is something, I think, is addressed by a number of organisations but we, probably, still have a bit more work to be done on that

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting, isn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: Q
sentence: Do you think approaches to problem solving, or cognitive diversity, is also important in the way people approach decision making?

author: Q
sentence: Where I also thought there was a parallel, you’ve got the union where you need the members to support you

author: Q
sentence: With a government appointment, do you need the minister or someone to support you?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, the ministers sign off on those appointments

author: A
sentence: Government boards are interesting because while there needs to be the robust discussions there can be constraints to how far you can go with, say, strategic plans

author: A
sentence: So, with SA Water, for instance, the aim of SA Water, besides delivering water bulk and domestic water to South Australia, was to raise enough profit to then go back into government, to support the government processes

author: A
sentence: So, there was a mandate there, even though it was a corporation, and not, necessarily, run by government, there was still that understanding that’s what needed to happen

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So, that’s communicated to the Chair or to all board members?

author: A
sentence: More or less to the Chair, and also the Chair of the Audit Committee, they understand that very well, and they’ll have meetings with the minister periodically, an update session

author: A
