sentence: When you become a board member on a government body, in my view, you do understand that there is room to suggest change, but there are certain constraints that you may need to work within

author: Q
sentence: Sure

author: Q
sentence: As board members, you are all aware of that?  Tt’s transparent to the board members, is it?

author: A
sentence: Well, I don’t know if it was ever said to me, if that’s what you -

author: Q
sentence: Oh

author: A
sentence: I don’t know that it was ever said, I think it was just something I instantly understood, and I don’t know about the others, I think we all just understood it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, well -

author: A
sentence: I’ve never thought about it before

author: A
sentence: Definitely, and in fact, one of the boards I was involved in what Australian Central Credit Union, and we undertook the HBMI, which looked at how we operated as directors

author: A
sentence: What that identified was a number of board directors operated very much in information sorting, some operate in the communication, where some operated with emotional leads in their conversations and how they behaved, and some of us operated in a very futuristic thinking way

author: Q
sentence: Otherwise it’s like the transparency problem

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: But it wasn’t experienced as a problem

author: Q
sentence: So, you were all selected well by the minister?

author: A
sentence: It’s interesting

author: A
sentence: I think there’s that presumption that you won’t embarrass the government, and, I guess, the reason you won’t, as well, is because to go on a government board, in my view, you have some sort of loyalty to government, as well

author: A
sentence: So, yeah, that’s interesting, I’ve never thought about it

author: Q
sentence: It’s a class thing, the culture of the board is powerful

author: A
sentence: Isn’t it, yes

author: Q
sentence: So, from a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about the way diversity of Australian boards is currently being promoted?

author: A
sentence: I think we still have a long way to go, from all accounts, and the reports on diversity, those boards that have diversity, and it still is the gender diversity we’re talking about and they appear to function better and they have more robust systems in place

author: A
sentence: Look, I think there are still some ASX companies, I don’t remember how many, that do not have any female members on their board

author: A
sentence: Whether they have other sorts of diversity I wouldn’t be sure

author: A
sentence: So, there still is that resistance to the gender diversity on boards

author: A
sentence: I think we might see another, maybe, 20 years before we have true genuine diversity, where it’s not tokenistic

author: A
sentence: Some are still tokenistic where they feel they have to appoint someone just for the sake of it, so I think we’ve still got a long way to go

author: A
sentence: A bit like the wage gap, we’ve still got a long way to go there

author: Q
sentence: What’s holding it back, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Now, it was really good to do that exercise, but I never believed it was brought together so we all worked out how we worked with each other from there, it was still – because it was a financial institution, in my view, it was still seen that the accountant type of personality were the dominant personalities and they would lead the board direction, and they were quite risk averse, as well

author: A
sentence: So, as far as future thinking went, it could happen, but it was, often, very watered down, in my view

author: A
sentence: I think Australian society is still, generally, very patriarchal, and I think we see this demonstrated on many fronts

author: A
sentence: In my view we saw it when Julia Gillard was PM

author: A
sentence: While she was greeted with open arms by some, there was absolute anger towards her for what had happened

author: A
sentence: Now, we’ve seen it with male PMs overthrowing other male leaders and it doesn’t seem to even ripple, really

author: A
sentence: So, I do think we still have this gender divide and we are, generally, a patriarchal society

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q
sentence: So, in that context then, do we still need gender targets and quotas?

author: A
sentence: I think we need legislation

author: A
sentence: I think we need to be like Iceland, for instance, where there’s legislation that says, “If men and women are employed in the same organisation in the same position, they do get paid the same, otherwise there are fines that will be applied to the company

author: A
sentence: I think we need to see that through, not just our general employment, but particularly government boards, which I think we are doing better at

author: A
sentence: The ASX boards and other boards, I think we need to look at the legislation to apply to them as well, which I think is better than quotas

author: A
sentence: I think quotas can sound a bit tokenistic, but if it’s in legislation it can’t be avoided

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Good on you

author: Q
sentence: So, looking 10 years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Well, I would like to see no more discussion about gender diversity, because I find it quite an insulting discussion and one that I don’t feel comfortable having

author: A
sentence: I think we pride ourselves on being a civil society, yet we still have these very basic discussions on equality, for instance

author: A
sentence: So, I would like to see a more robust framework applied to boards, that actually is transparent, that board directors are held to account, that boards do have diversity across all the lengths and breadths that we’ve discussed

author: A
sentence: And, where shareholders and members do actually have a say if they’re not happy with how their board is performing

author: A
sentence: And, not a tokenistic say, like we’ve seen recently with the AGM season where shareholders can be outraged, but where actual action can be taken to make board directors walk the talk, if you like, about how corporate governance should be applied

author: Q
sentence: Like the Commission of Enquiry into Banking, like that?

author: A
sentence: Oh, we need some prosecutions on that for that to ever have any teeth, I think, and whether we do see any prosecutions, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: Often what happens is, it falls down the tree to those on the front line and the less empowered who can be prosecuted

author: A
sentence: We’ve seen it, for instance, in the Aged Royal Commission, that it’s not the people in management or more senior, but it falls down to the aged care workers who are on the front line, who are the ones who are prosecuted, which I think is so unfair, because they’re only responding and acting in a position that they know best

author: A
sentence: So, with the Banking Royal Commission we need to see some action from that

author: A
sentence: Now, whether we do or not, I don’t know, and it’s becoming further and further out

author: A
sentence: I think if there aren’t any prosecutions, we’ll just see banking slowly slide back to how it was before

author: Q
sentence: What I sense was a democratic process, that boards are accountable to its members or shareholders, or whatever

author: Q
sentence: But, if Australian society is patriarchal, how will that form of accountability ensure the sort of equity that you’re concerned about, equality

author: Q
sentence: Can I just clarify?  Is it HBMI test?

author: A
sentence: I think governments can set the tone from the top

author: A
sentence: So, if you have legislation that has to be enacted through laws and regulations and policies, which says, “This is how our boards need to look, this is how they must act, this is how they must behave,” that, I think, goes a long way to changing how society views itself

author: A
sentence: It’s not then, just about one particular group being in charge, it’s about the equitability of diversity, because the framework says, “This must happen

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s wonderful

author: Q
sentence: This legislation that you’re talking about, for boards, and it’s pay as well, will assist a transformation in our patriarchal society here?

author: A
sentence: Yes, because we see that expectation then, actually from the highest law makers in our land, that that’s what’s expected

author: A
sentence: When you look at wage equity, you’re look then also at equity in parenting leave, for instance, and it can then run onto childcare accessibility and affordability, as well

author: A
sentence: So, there are a whole lot of knock on effects from looking at equitable wages

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: That’s brilliant

author: Q
sentence: So, this is a seriously multi-level, we’re talking government, government institutions, and probably director programs, because you’re saying education is very important of board members

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: That’s wonderful

author: A
sentence: Very good

author: Q
sentence: Do you have any last final comments?

author: A
sentence: Well, I don’t mean to be a pessimist, but I don’t know that anything is going to change in the short term

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it will change in the 10 years?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I’d have to get back to you with that, I’ll let you know, I’ll give you a call, that will be helpful for you

author: A
sentence: As far as the legislation for equitable wages, I don’t think we’ll have the appetite for that, in the foreseeable future, because within equity in wages is people business, so unions, for instance, have a platform, they have a reason to exist, for example

author: A
sentence: So, I think we’ve got a lot of work to be done yet

author: Q
sentence: So, some of the barriers are not just social then, are they economic?

author: A
sentence: I think so, and I think there a stakeholder investment in self-interest, as well

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: We can just start this interview again and explore the stakeholder interest

author: Q
sentence: That was fantastic, that was really great

author: A
sentence: My pleasure, I enjoyed it a lot

author: A
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: Thanks 37D

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to turn it off, so we –

author: Q
sentence: END OF TRANSCRIPT

author: Q
sentence: It’s interesting, yeah that would be great

author: Q
sentence: This culture of risk aversion and focusing on finances, was that, do you think, cultivated by the regulation of the financial industry, at the time?

author: A
sentence: My pleasure

author: A
sentence: Sorry, say that again

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that the culture, of this financial board, the risk aversive culture and the focus on financial decision-making styles, was that, perhaps, influenced by the regulation of the board, at that time?

author: A
sentence: It possibly could have been

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think regulation was a factor, and risk aversion was also a factor as well, so I do think, in some degree, that was the influence

author: A
sentence: Also, at that time, they were bringing in the requirement, it was for financial institutions to hold so much in capital against their loan book, as well, so there was quite a bit of, I guess, turmoil in the industry, at times

author: Q
sentence: How did this fit in with the global financial crisis?

author: A
sentence: Well, this was just before the global financial crisis

author: A
sentence: What we were finding before the global financial crisis, loan books, particularly for smaller institutions, were becoming quite challenged, and for smaller institutions, in fact, in some ways they were shrinking

author: A
sentence: So, therefore, there was that thought that the bigger big four were being supported by government to more of an extent than the smaller institutions

author: Q
sentence: So, how was the government intervening, here, in that industry?

author: A
sentence: From what I remember, the government was looking at – I’m sorry, I’ve been thrown off my game, I just read an email that took my attention, I wished I hadn’t looked at it, actually

author: Q
sentence: Do you want to have a pause?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, can I have a pause for a minute?

author: Q
sentence: Of course, I’ll turn this off, and do you want to email me when you’re ready?

author: Q
sentence: There are a couple of demographic questions; how many years have you been a board director?

author: A
sentence: Yes, or I can give you a ring back, one or the other, yeah, sure

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Interruption- part 2

author: Q
sentence: Okay, thanks 37D

author: Q
sentence: The question we were exploring was, whether, and if so, how government was intervening in the financial industry, and this was leading up to the financial crisis and you mentioned someone about the four major banks, they were being affected differently than the smaller -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I can’t remember the details now, but in effect, the big four banks were given more guarantee, from what I remember, like deposits and what have you than the smaller credit unions and banks, like say the Bendigo Bank, and there was a real us and them mentality

author: A
sentence: That’s probably all I recall, at that point, which is probably not that helpful, I’m sorry

author: Q
sentence: No, but it might reinforce the culture of the board that you were on, being risk averse and financially focused

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: I think, also, the risk averseness, you can be risk averse in certain ways, with a financial institution, as in any other business, I believe, in fact, you’re handling people’s money responsibly and investments responsibly is certainly top of mind, but I think there could have been more risks taken with marketing and with engaging with customers in the future, for instance

author: A
sentence: So, there were elements where we could have taken, I think, more risks

author: Q
sentence: So, lack of diversity was playing a role in how risk was managed, and your exposure to risk, in your view?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so, and I think, also, there was quite a significant – if I remember rightly, I think we had nine directors plus the CEO, who was non-voting, but from what I recall, there was quite a significant group of risk averse accountant type thinking people, all these auditing type thinking people who wanted to be more careful with the strategy

author: A
sentence: The other observation I made was the Chair and the CE, which I would expect had pre-meetings, but then I felt I would witness the Chair really moving the meeting how he wanted to, and, possibly, in relation to the conversation he had previously with the Chief Executive

author: A
sentence: So, my view is, these conversations do need to happen between Chairs and Chief Executives, but I do think there needs to be a certain disclosure element in that conversation, as well, if we’re going to have full transparency there needs to be that frank and feel of disclosure, as well, of those side conversations

author: A
sentence: I have been a board director, on the current two boards that I’m involved in – with one it would be about six months because we’re formulating that one, and that’s an Australian Association for a group of health practitioners, so I’m an inaugural board member

author: A
sentence: There is an advisory board, of an Australian Research Fund, and that is set up to support students looking into PTSD

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that’s a strategy that reduces diversity of decision making?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so, because what I witnessed, and I did speak to a few of my other board colleagues, was that conversations would be directed in a certain way, and conversations that were not welcome would be shut down

author: A
sentence: Often, the line would be used, ‘in the interest of time’, which, I think, if you’re going to have a board you need to let people explore ideas and voice their views, whether they’re mainstream or not, they need to be heard

author: Q
sentence: So, the culture of the board wasn’t inclusive of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think diversity of thought, absolutely, and I think there were some situations where – well, I did, I witnessed people being, “Thank you very much for your contribution,” and not allowed to finish what they were saying

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: How many women were on the board?

author: A
sentence: It varied over the 10 years

author: A
sentence: The most females we had, at any one time, I think I recall three of us, yeah, three of us

author: A
sentence: Now, none of us ever held significant positions, we were all directors, but we didn’t hold Chair or Deputy Chair, we didn’t hold Chair of any of the subcommittees either, from what I recall

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it was quite male dominated

author: Q
sentence: More recently, there’s an inclusion of sexual differences and other things, ethnicity and different sexuality

author: Q
sentence: Do you think these kinds of diversity are important?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: I don’t know whether you need to list every single diversity, but I think we need to be mindful that this could be an inclusion in a particular board, and boards are meant to be representative of their stakeholders or their community

author: A
sentence: So, I don’t see any reason why not, and dependent on the board

author: A
sentence: I mean, for a financial institution, I suppose, before same sex couples had equal rights to same sex couples, that would have been quite a valuable person to have on a board to really voice that view

author: Q
sentence: Because home loans and things, yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: Apart from that, I was on a couple of boards

author: A
sentence: An Australian Central Credit Union, and I was on that one for 10 years and there was also a state utility, that was for six years that I was on that particular board

author: Q
sentence: Very interesting, good point

author: Q
sentence: So, how have the composition of boards, that you’re familiar with, changed over time in terms of diversity?  You’ve had quite a spread of time since ’99

author: A
sentence: The two I’m involved in now; one is totally all women, and the reason being, the person who set that board up that was her focus, was to do research into first responders in the medical field, and particularly focused on women, it was the Medical Women’s Memorial Research Fund

author: A
sentence: The other one I’m involved in now, is more female dominated and probably due to the fact that in the nutrition profession there seems to be more female nutritionists than male

author: A
sentence: So, I think it’s purely from that point of view

author: A
sentence: For instance, with the board of the Nutritionists Australasian Association and Register of Practising Nutritionists, over time, I would suggest to them we would need to diversify

author: A
sentence: I’m the only non-nutritionist on the board, at the moment, so I think, over time, once it’s settled, we do need to look at different skillsets, for instance

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s in its formative stage, at the moment

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: If I gave you a scale of 10 as extremely important and one as not at all, how important do you think having a diverse board is?

author: A
sentence: So, 10 is important?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, 10 is extremely important and one is not at all

author: A
sentence: When we talk about diversity it’s all encompassing, it’s not just male/female, its everything that you and I talked about just now

author: Q
sentence: As you defined it, as you discussed it, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Was the credit union one a for profit?

author: A
sentence: That’s right

author: A
sentence: I would say it’s closer to 10 because of the want to have that strong governance, and transparency, there in that particular decision-making body

author: Q
sentence: How does it contribute to transparency, diversity?

author: A
sentence: In my view, the big way this would contribute to transparency is the fact that you wouldn’t run the risk of having directors from similar thinking backgrounds, or similar thinking friendship groups, or similar thinking professional groups

author: A
sentence: You could bring them all in to be individual thinkers rather than having formed those connections

author: A
sentence: That can happen, for instance, on government boards it can happen, and on financial institution boards it can happen

author: A
sentence: You can have like, “Bring your mates in,” that type of arrangement on boards

author: Q
sentence: Have you seen this happen?

author: A
sentence: Well, I would say, for instance, in the financial institution one that I was involved in, there were directors who were appointed to the board who were not members of the credit union, which was one of the prerequisites, because it’s a member owned institution

author: A
sentence: They were appointed to the board for their skillset to, supposedly, bring a different level of skill to the board

author: A
sentence: I think it might have been done clumsily, though, because it did look a bit like bringing in people who knew each other

author: A
sentence: How do I know?  I’m not quite sure, really

author: Q
sentence: It’s just the appearance, yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s just how it looks

author: Q
sentence: We’re going to have questions later about board selection, so we can look in more detail at that

author: Q
sentence: I’m still working on the transparency – like not having social networks that might collude and create group think, I can see that as good governance

author: Q
sentence: The transparency side is, I suppose, because of the networks, is it?  How is it transparent, how does it -

author: A
sentence: I would suggest that if you had solid friendships on the board, you may be less likely to see frank and feel of conversation, particularly if there are disagreements

author: A
sentence: You may be less likely to have total declarations; there might be part declarations of interest but may not be total declarations of interest because of that friendship running so deep

author: A
sentence: There may be that protectionism belief in place

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure, I don’t know whether I’ve witnessed it, I think it would be hard to prove or out unless someone knew of some backgrounds of some close colleagues on boards, but I have heard it talked about

author: Q
sentence: So, what it definitely does, it reduces your confidence in transparency?

author: A
sentence: With the credit unions it really is a for profit, it would call itself more of a not for profit, a mutual organisation, but it operates under the banking sector regulation

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think, what could happen also, is there may be a bit of laziness that can creep in thinking that, “He’s my friend, she’s my friend, they probably read the board papers, I don’t need to worry so much

author: A
sentence: They’ve got strength in this, I don’t have strengths in that,” so maybe not getting the most out of every director could be a result, as well

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there is any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating, like high uncertainty, high risk?

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure what you mean?

author: Q
sentence: The importance rating of 10 for diversity

author: Q
sentence: Are there some situations where you might think it’s not so important?

author: A
sentence: No, I think in any board it needs to be taken with importance because there is legislation that does govern boards and board performance

author: A
sentence: No, I think it’s important all round

author: A
sentence: I think, though, when it comes to not for profit, non-paid positions, it can be challenging to get the right mix of people because, purely, having people volunteer their time can be quite a tall ask

author: A
sentence: But for a not for profit, a non-paid position is just as important as a paid position because they’re all governed under the same umbrella

author: Q
sentence: And, still exposed to as much liability risk?

author: A
sentence: That’s right, yes

author: Q
sentence: We can talk about that in a minute, as well

author: Q
sentence: Does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others?

author: A
sentence: Well, I guess, really, we do need to make sure, because we do live in a society where it’s half male half female, that there is an importance on having that inclusion represented in a board

author: A
sentence: I also think it’s important to recognise younger and older people, and having that representation on boards, as well

author: A
sentence: So, they’re two groups, I think, that need to be considered, and there are others that cascade behind that, as well

author: A
sentence: It may be specific, dependent on your board that you’re looking at, as well, what other categories of diversity you look at

author: Q
sentence: Do you mean the organisation’s strategic direction and all that?

author: Q
sentence: I’ll put that down as a for profit

author: Q
sentence: Then, you’ve got a professional one and the research funds, are they both not for profit?

author: A
sentence: Yes, what its mission is, the strategic direction, why it’s there, why it exists

author: A
sentence: That may be important to consider for other cross sections of diversity

author: Q
sentence: That’s a more enduring factor, that’s not, “Oh well, we’ve got a global financial crisis looming, so let’s do something to change our diversity ranking

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So now board functioning; we want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular functions it really helps with or that it can limit?

author: A
sentence: I think, if we’re talking about women and men, or we’re talking about young people and older people, I think we all have different perspectives on life, and we all tend to come at situations through different perspectives

author: A
sentence: When I’m talking about this, I’m feeling like I’m getting tangled up in knots in many ways, because at the end of the day, you don’t want a groupthink on a board, that is a dangerous practise to have groupthink

author: A
sentence: So, to have diversity means that robust conversation should be encouraged on points that are listed on the board papers or points that are raised

author: A
sentence: So, I would say, diversity, just from experience, education, background, knowledge, that is all brought to the board table

author: A
sentence: However, that won’t be harnessed unless the board has set down it’s ground rules of mutual respect, listening, understanding, giving each person the opportunity to speak

author: A
sentence: So, there’s a whole communication and just general respect that comes into play, as well, and encouraging every board member to make sure they put forward their perspectives, and accepting that there is no silly contribution, no silly question, no wrong way to look at things

author: A
sentence: It’s all part of having a robust discussion

author: Q
sentence: This is sounding like there’s an emerging model from all the interviews I’ve done

author: Q
sentence: Let me put it to you and see what you think, because it’s like what you’re saying, I think

author: Q
sentence: Fundamentally, the benefit of diversity is that it avoids groupthink, it provides excellent problem solving by avoiding groupthink, and including strategic thinking, vision and stuff

author: Q
sentence: You can only get that if the culture of the board is, as you say, includes different voices and uses the sort of strategies you talked about, and it has a culture to support that, to reinforce that

author: Q
sentence: I’ve got a triangle idea; so at the base of the triangle is the demographic diversity, and that can depend on, as you say, the purpose of the organisation and things like that, but that’s where you need the gender diversity, geographic diversity if that’s relevant to the purpose of your board, aged diversity, all those things, those more tangible things, so they’re at the base

author: Q
sentence: Then, they come up through this decision-making process, which is supported or not by the culture of the board, and what comes out of that is decisions that avoid group-think and add value to the society and the company, the organisation

author: Q
sentence: So, if it’s clear, is that consistent with your view, or would you tinker with it some way, add something?

author: A
sentence: The first two I mentioned, yeah, they’re not for profit

author: A
sentence: Okay, so let me get this triangle

author: A
sentence: At the bottom is the general demographic?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Then, along the sides, just go through that again for me please

author: Q
sentence: You can think of it as an arrow, if you want, it doesn’t have to be a triangle

author: Q
sentence: So at the base is the gender, the demographic diversity, then we’ve got the decision making, and that’s supported by the culture of inclusion

author: Q
sentence: Without that culture the view is, “Well, it doesn’t matter if you’re got the people, if they’re given token recognition, etcetera, then that’s not going to contribute to decision making in an effective way

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Then, you’ve got decision making that, for example, avoids group-think, and then, the outcome for that decision making by the board, is that you’ve got value creation, and risk mitigation, I forgot that one; value creation and risk mitigation that adds value to the company and to the broader society

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I think that sounds like a good sound model

author: A
sentence: I think vision is really important when it comes to developing a culture and really engaging that vision in every layer of the organisation

author: A
sentence: So, starting with the board and the management team, and filtering it all the way through

author: A
sentence: So, the vision needs to come to life and that will, I think, unlock the values and the culture as well

author: Q
sentence: Why does there need to be this consistent thread, in terms of culture, between the organisation and the board?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think it’s important because you don’t want to have two separate organisations working within one, so the board, with it’s strategic direction, needs to know and live what it’s there for as far as the organisation goes, and also be aware of the value it delivers, not just to the organisation, but to its shareholders, if it has shareholders, or members

author: A
sentence: Then, that needs to cascade through the organisation to make sure that the whole organisation is working as a whole

author: A
sentence: So, the board is really orchestrating, if you like, how the organisation operates within the environment

author: Q
sentence: That’s brilliant, thank you, that helps a lot

author: Q
sentence: Good, thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: 38IN, I just wanted to check a demographic before we go forward – the discipline background, your discipline background

author: Q
sentence: What is that?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: Now, there is a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and Board functioning

author: Q
sentence: You have alluded to this

author: Q
sentence: Can you talk a little more about how you think it influences Board functioning?

author: A
sentence: This will have to be very separate from the Australian shareholders opinion because as I said, we don’t really, as retail shareholders or representatives of retail shareholders, get any access to how the Board dynamics are working in that sense

author: A
sentence: So back from my Board performance days, which followed on from my insti investor days; the importance of how the Board thinks and how they interact and their ability to be - mindful is the only word that comes to mind but be aware and self-aware in those Board meetings, that is really crucial to how the group will operate

author: A
sentence: And that’s where taking those little things where someone gets the feather to talk or the talking stick, you usually don’t have to do that for a professional Board but that’s where they have a gain because some people can’t do that on the fly

author: A
sentence: But it really makes a difference and I just love that year of my life or year and a half of my life where we got to go into read all the minutes and the like for the meetings as we did the Board assessment and question all the different Directors

author: A
sentence: I suppose I had thought from the outside they must be more professional in doing this than they appear from the decisions and the trajectories their companies are taking

author: A
sentence: But they’re not

author: A
sentence: It’s just as messy as your local club lunch

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting

author: Q
sentence: So this role you had, what was that?

author: A
sentence: I was with Lyn Ralph who used to be an ASIC Commissioner and various other things and she was a Director and Alan Cameron who is also a lawyer and long-standing Director

author: A
sentence: For years he did the AICD Director update

author: A
sentence: They developed a firm with Phil Khoury and they needed someone to work on developing the model

author: A
sentence: And I got to do that

author: Q
sentence: Fantastic

author: A
sentence: And I did that, I was on a three-month contract but then it just morphed because they couldn’t interview people that they had relationships with, professional relationships with, so Phil and I would get to interview some of the Directors

author: A
sentence: The more important the Director, the more likely they would have that relationship with Alan Cameron or Lyn

author: A
sentence: And so Phil and I got to do those interviews

author: Q
sentence: Very exciting, very interesting

author: A
sentence: It was really interesting because I had some beliefs and I suppose I really had hoped they were better and more self-aware beings

author: A
sentence: And just having it confirmed that they weren’t made me feel more comfortable about my own assessments

author: Q
sentence: That would be harsh

author: Q
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: Because as an institutional investor it’s a big thing, we would interact much more with the executives and the investor relations because even you are projecting forward models 10 years and you really needed those details

author: A
sentence: They’re not really inside information but, because it’s all available out there that it makes it very much a mosaic

author: A
sentence: And then you make your own judgements and you just decide whether you feel, I think it’s a Chair, the CEO is a good reflection of the Board

author: A
sentence: If you have a really quality CEO who is on top of things, quite often their Board was similar

author: A
sentence: Good questioning, good support and that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So you could just say the CEO is my exemplar for the Board

author: A
sentence: But as a retail shareholder you’re a step further away

author: A
sentence: They’re not projecting even six months

author: A
sentence: So it interacting with the actual Board who are responsible for making sure that everything is stewarded correctly, the stewardship is carried out

author: A
sentence: That’s where we engaged

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Really interesting

author: Q
sentence: We want to focus on that process side of it though

author: Q
sentence: Does your organisation do anything to cultivate Board candidates?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: No? What might your organisations do to perhaps influence the Chair in selection of Chair apart from that conversation which you have already said? Anything else?

author: A
sentence: In terms of selection of Chair? Probably not

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Or influencing the Chair’s decisions or the way they manage the Board?

author: A
sentence: Nothing other than what we’ve talked about already

author: Q
sentence: That’s okay

author: Q
sentence: So your organisation wouldn’t do anything to help candidates from minority groups or anything like that?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Quite often we’ve seen self-appointed candidates from left-field, such as in Ramsay Healthcare last year, the one who purports to be the daughter of Ramsey put herself forward

author: A
sentence: And actually, closer to home, one of our former directors Stephen Mayne would quite often put himself forward for a board position

author: A
sentence: And we would vote against him

author: A
sentence: He didn’t do it while he was on our board, but prior to that

author: A
sentence: We feel that the occupation of a board seat needs to be done by someone who adds value to that company, and it’s a waste if it’s not

author: A
sentence: From the original contact

author: A
sentence: In terms of those externally put forward candidates, usually we have no tools that would meet our judgement to say that person would really add to that Board

author: A
sentence: But in the Carly Ramsey example, she did not put forward anything that suggested she would be able to evaluate multibillion-dollar capital decisions for example

author: A
sentence: We would look to their history for that, and as mentioned before we do like people on the Board more than just the Chair to have prior experience in the industry

author: Q
sentence: So if your organisation votes against a candidate is there a chance that they still get up?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: What? A 20% chance?

author: A
sentence: Quite often, it depends really on the company

author: A
sentence: Something like Commonwealth Bank, we might get what’s called a [inaudible] 0:42:08

author: A
sentence: 5 [of faith], $500 million worth of investment, but that is still a small amount of capital in the scheme of things

author: A
sentence: Where we really get a gain is in the embarrassment, either the embarrassment or the straw that breaks the camel’s back

author: A
sentence: So if a number of people are also voting against and then we just tip it over

author: A
sentence: I think Gerry Harvey is particularly negative about the ASA and Singleton I think was calling us names at the last meeting as well

author: A
sentence: If you’re happy to be embarrassed you could withstand our suggestions or our engagement

author: A
sentence: A lot of people aren’t

author: A
sentence: So where there is a sizeable against vote we have seen people withdraw their candidacy

author: A
sentence: And that’s a tricky thing because I think for the first time Navitas last year, Tracy Horton got 50

author: A
sentence: 1% vote, she’s the Chair and she got in by

author: A
sentence: 1%, and I had not seen that before in a larger company

author: Q
sentence: It’s usually much?

author: A
sentence: People would walk, if there was a 15% vote against the Director, they would say how dare you, how embarrassing, I’m out of here

author: A
sentence: Obviously you don’t want me

author: A
sentence: Whereas it was tied up with a takeover so I think to my mind that actually shows that she did the right thing with the takeover because they would have needed 75% vote to go through with the takeover but it actually got 50% in her favour means that there wouldn’t have been 50% in favour of the vote, of the takeover vote

author: A
sentence: But that’s would have been tough in the face of dissatisfaction is really why they get paid the big bucks

author: A
sentence: But it isn’t common

author: A
sentence: Most people with just withdraw

author: Q
sentence: Okay, you might be selecting the worst kind, those who don’t feel shame, are the ones who survive

author: A
sentence: Well, I use this one as an example because yes, shame is an important part of how we can influence people but we actually, I wrote about Tracy Horton and how supportive it was

author: A
sentence: It is unusual but good on her for sticking to her guns and looking after shareholders

author: Q
sentence: Yes that’s right, it’s not on my thing to ask for it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, firstly how have the composition of Boards that you’re familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity do you think?

author: Q
sentence: Good on her

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: So what do you see is the main barriers to building diverse Boards in Australia? And how do they work?

author: A
sentence: I think we still have a general sexism

author: A
sentence: And a general lack of awareness

author: A
sentence: I am still hearing, many years after leaving uni that women wouldn’t want to do that job, or there’s not enough women and yet in my daily life I run into people who have been engineers and worked on remote mines and the like and it’s just they have not drawn the attention of the general populace

author: A
sentence: I think where Boards need to be more aware and more - combative is not the right word

author: A
sentence: I know for example that when I was at Macquarie, just in the general employment sense we would get a shortlist roll which would be all male and we would go back and go what? How is this so?

author: A
sentence: And HR at that particular time would come back and say well, we choose the best candidate

author: A
sentence: We’re not going to put any quotas over the top of that

author: A
sentence: But if you have an industry that’s sexist already or really gender weighted to blokes, then everybody who has got 20 years’ experience, there’s going to be more blokes than females and so maybe you have to say I want two women on that shortlist no matter what

author: A
sentence: You know, do your shortlist your way and then get me the next two women

author: A
sentence: Because if you haven’t got two women on that list by the way you’re constructing it I want you to go and find the next two that would be on there if we were taking a bigger pool

author: A
sentence: So I think there is still that old attitude that there is no sexism, that lack of awareness that people think people like the people around me are successful

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there is, apart from gender maybe cultural, age, sexuality, that these kinds of types of diversity are also important?

author: A
sentence: I think overarching diversity, so yeah basically everything

author: A
sentence: I’m not so aware of whether sexuality is being impacted on Boards because we have had openly gay is such a stupid term but basically I’m not trying to fix anyone up with their partner so that doesn’t actually come up

author: A
sentence: But I don’t know that I look at the Boards and think wow, they’re all hetero

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that’s an unconscious bias with ASA then or is it that it’s not necessary?

author: A
sentence: No I’m thinking not that they don’t need to be balanced, just that I mean this is the issue that our members would like people to put their age in so they don’t have the calculate it whereas I think you look at the pictures you can sort of -

author: Q
sentence: Tell

author: A
sentence: To get near enough because 36 to 39 there’s not much of a difference

author: A
sentence: Really if you want age diversity and more youth you need 35-year-olds and 70-year-olds, not 70 and 68

author: A
sentence: No, what I mean is that when I think of variety of business people, when their sexuality has become apparent, they have positions and I don’t know that Boards, I think Boards have been more resistant against female participants than gay men

author: A
sentence: But I have nothing to, that’s just an absorption feeling

author: A
sentence: Now thinking it through maybe there is less representation but harking back to my earlier comments, about 50% female being an easy metric because it’s so large, half/half, that is why it’s very difficult to make those judgements about Board diversity

author: A
sentence: Should 3% be Mandarin speaking at 3% be Cantonese and 2% be indigenous and that sort of numbers when you’re talking of a group of eight people

author: A
sentence: When we are highly focused on Boards

author: A
sentence: 12% is typically your mark-up

author: A
sentence: Which is why we are actually quite happy with 30% minimum of either gender, because quite often, smaller boards are three people

author: A
sentence: You can say 40%, but as a base for all companies, we’ll be happy with 30%

author: A
sentence: Which doesn’t stop you having 60% being the other gender

author: A
sentence: But the other diversity is important, it’s just that I think an awareness of bias is probably the biggest - that’s one hurdle, and again, similar to the females, the idea that the existing pools where you draw your people from, if that pool is already not diverse, then you have to start being clever and introducing outsiders from somewhere

author: A
sentence: And where do you introduce those outsiders?

author: A
sentence: When I started in the equity market in the 80s the Boards were comprised purely of males of a certain age

author: A
sentence: Actually I tell a lie there, we had a lot more younger men on Boards, people would be appointed in their 30’s if they were particularly skilled or connected or both

author: A
sentence: So predominantly male, predominantly Anglo-Saxon

author: Q
sentence: That’s really interesting because some Directors have talked about, quite differently about the sort of experience that is necessary for their Board members

author: Q
sentence: And some, the experience of the industry is very important, whereas others, I had one just recently preferably not

author: Q
sentence: No experience of the industry, because you’ve got your CEO bringing all of that

author: Q
sentence: What the Board is bringing is X, Y, Z

author: Q
sentence: And that was amazing

author: A
sentence: That was interesting

author: A
sentence: Can I just ask what size that Board was?

author: Q
sentence: How many people on it?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Eight

author: A
sentence: So one where we’ve actually been public on that one, that would be Rio

author: A
sentence: It was felt that because the Chair and the CEO, we don’t like having two executives on the Board and they have their CFO on the Board but we argued that that means that somebody is there with their boss and that kind of changes the dynamics of the room

author: A
sentence: But if your Chair has to be very close to your CEO

author: A
sentence: So there’s no one outside those three who can really say hey, every project I’ve ever been involved in does this

author: A
sentence: I personally feel that Directors can acquire that experience of being one step away from the action, but our members, particularly feel that companies go astray when you have that situation where the Chair, CFO and CEO are the repository for all that knowledge

author: A
sentence: And basically the rest of the group, it is felt the rest of the Directors have to go along for the ride on some of the details

author: Q
sentence: It’s interesting isn’t it? This person, I have to then put it in context

author: Q
sentence: The way this person described their organisation; the Board was very open and interacted with the organisation, Directors would go through and they had various committees

author: Q
sentence: So the organisation and the Board was seen as much more interconnected than perhaps I had heard from other Directors

author: Q
sentence: So probably I have to put it in the context of this is how the Board functioned in the organisation

author: A
sentence: Yes, that does make a difference and just from doing lots of company you know, trying to pick where companies have been going for a long time, I do see a risk with that that you are a little beholden to the company with that openness and I just wonder if they could veer off into some sort of disaster which only in 10 years’ time you will know the answer to that

author: Q
sentence: So ASA as an organisation then; how open? When you go and talk to the Chair or whatever, have a conversation, so it might not be about tenure, it might be about the kinds of industry experience of the members on the Board or lack of it

author: Q
sentence: And if the Chair was saying well, this is how we do stuff would you accept that and think oh yeah fine that’s how you do things? Or would you raise your concerns?

author: A
sentence: Typically the Boards don’t share that style of information

author: A
sentence: For example when we say hey, we’re concerned with this person’s workload they will quite often, they might say something like you know they don’t play golf, they don’t play tennis

author: A
sentence: They have six Boards and that’s their life

author: A
sentence: And they always contribute in a meaningful fashion

author: A
sentence: That’s the style of dialogue we have with them

author: A
sentence: And we have all also had the ‘just trust us’

author: A
sentence: They never say just trust us, but they will not give sufficient information usually for you to feel comfortable that you know how that particular Board works

author: A
sentence: AMP for example, when that was all going messy last year

author: A
sentence: They basically were answering things as they became public

author: A
sentence: So we commissioned this, that and the other and then like I said before, you don’t get any internal information in any of these dialogues

author: A
sentence: It is much more like the Board is representing - sorry, the Chair is representing the Board

author: Q
sentence: And when you say - what were they connected to?

author: Q
sentence: And they will use you to reinforce their public image?

author: A
sentence: Well I think that there is a certain amount of information that is intimate to the Board but it’s not to be made public and in our position on the ASX corporate governance council we have argued that companies should report on their performance assessments for example and what gaps have been identified in their skills

author: A
sentence: But there has been pushback on that, although I know that Woolworths did it in their last annual report I think it was

author: A
sentence: I think they did it quite well

author: A
sentence: But typically that information is very much kept within the group

author: A
sentence: And we don’t think it should be

author: A
sentence: We understand that you can’t say oh yes well this one’s mother died yesterday and they missed this meeting because of that and they thought that this capital idea, they were really concerned about this

author: A
sentence: Understand that the Board is like a collective and it’s commercial in confidence that is subject to these discussions

author: A
sentence: But determining a public statement such as it has been identified that we have a skills gap in this particular area and until we recruit somebody we will be hiring in that expertise

author: A
sentence: We think that is what companies should share

author: A
sentence: And then we are better able to make judgements about whether we want to vote for any of them

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: The final question now

author: Q
sentence: 10 years into the future how would you like to see the diversity of Australian Boards and what role will ASA have in achieving this?

author: A
sentence: I would really like to see the gender diversity thing be totally off the table

author: A
sentence: Even now people are suggesting that there are not enough female CEOs to fill the CEO side of the pipe for Directors

author: A
sentence: So I would like to see the gender side totally off the table

author: A
sentence: I would like to see a more mindful recruitment where people do look objectively at what is required on the Board, what skills and the like and then how to fill it and be able to vet people appropriately rather than there is still an element that you don’t want people on the Board that you don’t know

author: A
sentence: Because sometimes those people don’t just act like mavericks for the benefit of the Board, people who are different may also not have the same values

author: A
sentence: So for example I’m aware of a Board where one of the Directors, it was not a listed company, wouldn’t contribute to the Board and then what hold a press conference after the Board meeting

author: A
sentence: They would sit through it to not say anything and then go outside and tell the media because it was an organisation going through rupture, tell the media what had been said

author: A
sentence: So you do need to be able to trust that the person will observe the laws and the spirit and the ethics of the organisation, and that’s where it becomes tempting to get someone just like me as your Board member

author: A
sentence: And I would hope that we come to a point where we are better able to discern those differences, what differences are important and what similarities are important

author: A
sentence: So just a more mindful collection of people for the Board

author: Q
sentence: And the idea of importance; you say what similarities and what differences are important? Are important?

author: A
sentence: Well the importance of the benefit of the company

author: A
sentence: So you want people who are similar to well, hopefully we all are similar in the sense of I will follow the law, I will follow ethics, I will also make sure that it’s the spirit of the law and dare I say that the company has identified its purpose in the sense that if you’re in the payment system your purpose is to make sure the country functions on a financial level, so that the similarities, other commitments and all those things, and you might achieve that by bringing different skills

author: A
sentence: But it might be the differences are that you don’t need to tell someone you’re the black hat or the devil’s advocate for the meeting because the way the group dynamics work the third item that is picked up on a particular interrogation of a capital project is do we have an exit strategy?

author: A
sentence: What happens if this goes wrong? How can this go wrong? Anyone can pick that up in the Boardroom

author: A
sentence: That there is enough dynamics and understanding that someone will go okay, well this group needs to ask the negative question now

author: A
sentence: I will ask that

author: A
sentence: So that’s what I mean by knowing what the important things and similarities are and what the important differences are

author: A
sentence: There might be someone always asking the question, a particular question

author: A
sentence: What’s the exit strategy, that becomes their thing

author: Q
sentence: That’s fantastic

author: Q
sentence: 38IN, thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: It has been different which is what I want

author: A
sentence: Each other

author: A
sentence: In a diversity study? Good

author: Q
sentence: Pardon?

author: A
sentence: In a diversity study

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, it’s absolutely imperative in a diversity study

author: Q
sentence: If I get all the same thing I would be worried wouldn’t I? Okay, thank you so much 38IN and I hope you’re having a nice warm day up there because it’s freezing down here

author: A
sentence: I was down there yesterday, well not there but Melbourne yesterday and it was a bit cold and it got sunny

author: A
sentence: It was pouring with rain

author: A
sentence: 10 degrees, so that was a plus this morning

author: A
sentence: And I look forward to reading about it in the future

author: Q
sentence: Yeah we’ve got all your email addresses so we will include you all in communications so you can find out where we go from here

author: Q
sentence: Thanks very much 38IN bye

author: A
sentence: Thanks Margot, bye

author: A
sentence: End of transcript

author: Q
sentence: Yeah okay

author: Q
sentence: So when did that change? Or how has it changed?

author: A
sentence: It changed rather slowly with being - I would say that when I had this role, I used to be at the ASA in ’03 to ’07 and there were a limited number of female Directors

author: A
sentence: And maybe a little broadening in the ethnicity

author: A
sentence: And then I re-joined the ASA in 2017 and with the requirement in the corporate governance council principles and recommendations that 30%, oh no actually I think it might have been the AICD who set the 30% female for ASX 200, that target

author: A
sentence: We gradually saw that moving and it seemed to move forward for a few years and then kind of get stuck, slip back a bit and now we see that almost all the ASX 200 have at least 30% of their members being women, the diversity across other elements is still a bit vanilla, like unchanging

author: Q
sentence: Thank you for that

author: Q
sentence: Not many people have been able to give me such a historical perspective so that’s really helpful

author: A
sentence: Accounting financial systems

author: A
sentence: You mean in terms of degrees?

author: A
sentence: Age is wonderful isn’t it?

author: Q
sentence: Isn’t it wonderful? Yes, exactly

author: Q
sentence: So how does your organisation seek to influence Australian Boards?

author: A
sentence: We engage with the Chairs of companies and hold them to account and so with each of the companies that we monitor which is the ASX 200 give or take that - we can't really monitor them if they have their meetings offshore for example so there's about 170 of the ASX 200 we cover

author: A
sentence: We will meet with those companies Directors or Chairs prior to the AGM and then ask questions at the AGM

author: A
sentence: Then we also engage with the media through the year with issues that we have

author: A
sentence: And at the start of the year we work out what our focus issues will be and Board composition has been an important focus issue for some time

author: A
sentence: Which includes diversity

author: Q
sentence: I noticed that, I’ve got your areas for 2019, the ASA focus areas, that document, that media release

author: Q
sentence: So do you want to speak to that? The focus on Board composition and Director skills, how long? You said it’s been for a number of years you've had this

author: A
sentence: Yes, it pre-dates my joining ASA again in 2017

author: A
sentence: I think it’s probably gone back some time prior to that because we have been part of the ASX corporate governance council and the working groups working on those principles and we were supportive of that particular criteria, Board diversity, avoidance of groupthink, it’s really important

author: Q
sentence: I’ve got a scale here that I’ve been asking people

author: Q
sentence: If one - if diversity - if a rating of one means it’s not important at all, and 10 means it’s extremely important how would you rate diversity?

author: A
sentence: Eight

author: Q
sentence: Sorry?

author: A
sentence: Eight

author: Q
sentence: And so do you think it’s always been important, considered important?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, no, that’s good

author: A
sentence: By ourselves and people who look into corporate governance yes, it’s always been considered important but it is sometimes difficult for retail shareholders to penetrate the veil of the Boardroom and figure out how this particular group of people operate in a superior fashion to that particular group of people

author: A
sentence: I think it’s really been driven more by people who are mindful and analytical about how you get the best out of Boards

author: A
sentence: That that concept of diversity is an important thing

author: A
sentence: And I think diversity is a chicken and egg thing in that we see that Boards that are more diverse actually perform better

author: A
sentence: But some Boards become diverse purely because they’re not - they’re either more analytical themselves and aware of what their biases are or they just look for the best person and they’re not blinkered as to how that person will look or what their CV will look like

author: A
sentence: That the diverse Boards become because of the way the business is structured and the Board is structured

author: A
sentence: Or it may be that you bring a diverse Board together and then they become more analytical and more mindful of assessing what is a proper influence or an effective influence they’re experiencing and what is coming from their own biases

author: A
sentence: Not sure if I conveyed that appropriately?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so is it whether the diversity of thought is a function of people from different backgrounds getting together or whether -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, they already had the diversity of thought which ended up with different people getting together

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so this Board was like a magnet for people from different backgrounds to come sort of thing?

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily a magnet, that sounds a bit, well I suppose that sounds a bit more like the company is drawing the people in, I think it’s more not rejecting those that are different when you have an applicant for a Board seat and you don’t look at them and go, “Well that one looks just like me, I’ll take that one

author: A
sentence: ” But I suppose if you were a Director and you were looking at joining a Board you - the monocultures like the ARB, you will have to take me out of the room in a box before we get a female Director

author: A
sentence: I know a lot of Directors would look at that and go yeah, I’ll just wait until you die and then we’ll think about it

author: A
sentence: It’s not like one you put your hand up to join

author: Q
sentence: Yes, I had one Director said if it wasn't a gender diverse Board I would not apply

author: Q
sentence: Like I don't apply to Boards that are not gender diverse because he saw that as - and it was a male

author: Q
sentence: He saw that as a sign that it was a too conservative - its way of thinking would be too conservative

author: Q
sentence: So it’s a signal for him

author: A
sentence: Yes and I like the sound of that

author: A
sentence: I think that’s how it should be

author: A
sentence: I think a lot of the investors are getting to a similar point of view

author: A
sentence: Although something that’s particularly blinkered may actually have a lot of upsides once it joins the beginning of the century

author: A
sentence: Oh, maybe just a bit before this century

author: A
sentence: You know, why bother? Just wait until it has its crisis and then look at it when it has to regroup and reinvent itself

author: Q
sentence: Now this is interesting

author: Q
sentence: Coming from an organisation that seeks to influence Boards do you think you play a more proactive role in shaping the Boards rather than -

author: A
sentence: No, I think that the AICD requirement [and ACSI] 00:10:05, industry funds being much more strident is more influential

author: A
sentence: But it does - when the retail shareholders say, “Well, of course you’re doing that, aren’t you?”, that means another impediment is moved out of the way

author: A
sentence: I just point to the population and say, well, there’s a whole bunch of mum-and-dad investors who believe that male WASP directors are the best

author: A
sentence: We have to be mindful of our retail shareholders

author: A
sentence: That’s not available to people, because we are supportive of diverse boards

author: A
sentence: We actually feel that we don’t get enough information ourselves to make good judgements about boards

author: A
sentence: So we have this rule that if you had an underperforming board and you’re a CEO or chair of that board, that we won’t support you for the next role

author: A
sentence: Accounting financial systems, postgraduate diploma in applied finance

author: A
sentence: And years of institutional investment and corporate governance

author: A
sentence: Which having - in the length of my career of being an institutional investor and more on the governance side of these Boards and not as assessments

author: A
sentence: You can see the Board’s group dynamics, I mean an individual can be in a badly performing Board and be a strong contributor on a well performing Board

author: A
sentence: It’s probably if they’re clever enough they’ll disengage from the bad performing Board

author: A
sentence: But retail, just we don’t have enough information about people’s skills and how they’re contributing to be able to say oh well, you were a dud

author: A
sentence: That was a dud Board and you’ll be great with this one

author: A
sentence: So we would like more information to be able to make those types of decisions

author: Q
sentence: And so how do you get that information, that additional?

author: A
sentence: We’ve made that one of our focus issues, so when we go and talk with companies, we will raise that issue

author: Q
sentence: This is the standard of information in the annual reports?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: And highlight the skills of individuals

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: And when people come to us and say, “How dare you vote against this person”, because the poor female Directors of AMP, some of them have performed well at other Boards and people come and say how dare you vote against them at everything

author: A
sentence: And it’s like well you really need to give us more information about what these people are adding to the Board so that we can say “Hey, this particular skill is really useful

author: A
sentence: ” It might not have been the priority at that Board that was going under but for this particular company that’s a great skill and experience to bring

author: A
sentence: So we will gauge the companies and when they come back and go oh well you can’t vote against that person just because they did badly and the other company, they were at did badly, we will reinforce that

author: A
sentence: And we’re trying to with retail shareholders that quite often, from time to time, people will want to say we’ve respected the retail shareholders

author: A
sentence: So the points that we bring up are the ones that they may address, so skin in the game for example is one of our focus issues and at one time people would say I don’t want to insist but the Directors have to have shares

author: A
sentence: Whereas now it’s becoming far more common

author: Q
sentence: So that they have a share in the company, the Directors?

author: A
sentence: Shares equivalent to one year’s worth of fees

author: A
sentence: So it’s substantial considering that you have to pay tax on your fees and that would mean that they accrue it over three to five years but then you basically have to turn your fees back into shares in the company, which if you’re a professional Director becomes a bit trickier because you’re actually eating it and paying your mortgage out of that

author: A
sentence: Hopefully you’re financially successful

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: So as you’re aware at La Trobe we’re doing - the business school at La Trobe, we’re doing some research into the diversity of Australian boards and we’ve been interviewing board members to get their perspective and also key organisations such as ASA, who we think influence Australian boards

author: Q
sentence: That’s why we’re having the discussion

author: Q
sentence: So thank you again for agreeing to participate

author: Q
sentence: First have you any questions before we get on?

author: Q
sentence: I see

author: A
sentence: But that sort of thing, we see those sorts of things that we request and chip away at, I think it’s the way the companies - as long as the companies are aware of what the top thing is, that they may well, if they can, address that issue

author: A
sentence: Might not be able to help you on everything but it will be that issue and Board composition is one of those issues for us

author: Q
sentence: You mentioned diversity of thinking? I think you said - did you use that term? That that was important

author: Q
sentence: How do you measure that?

author: A
sentence: It's really an observational metric

author: A
sentence: And the assumption is that if you have a bunch of people that don't look like each other and they have different specialities, that that will encourage diversity of thinking which is also a protection against groupthink

author: A
sentence: Well you can still have quite diverse people who end up getting sucked into a particular chain of action

author: Q
sentence: I was just talking to a Chair who was saying - describing how some techniques he uses to facilitate inclusion and to facilitate thinking from different perspectives, from different points of view through, let’s say, while you’re making choices or decisions you think, right

author: Q
sentence: From this perspective, from the customer perspective, from this customer perspective, from the risk perspective, from a financial

author: Q
sentence: So going through and getting - so he described these techniques he used

author: Q
sentence: He said that helped to avoid groupthink because you could have half women, half men, half people, a good proportion from different ethnic diversities and backgrounds and stuff but everyone can still think the same

author: Q
sentence: That’s what he was - that’s what he’s been doing the last 18 months and he thinks it’s been quite successful

author: Q
sentence: Have you heard anyone else talk about that sort of thing?

author: A
sentence: I haven't heard of people with that in action but I have read about similar things

author: A
sentence: It’s a bit like in any group you appoint the black hat, it’s the term for the person who is doubting everything, but their job is to actually doubt -

author: Q
sentence: Be sceptical

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Devil’s advocate

author: Q
sentence: Devil’s advocate

author: A
sentence: That’s the thing I was thinking of as well, it’s like how Biblical is that? Yes, you basically tell someone their job is to be the Devil’s advocate

author: A
sentence: The whole thing about a company, particularly if it’s in a pinnacle of health

author: A
sentence: So CSL when you look at the outlook in CSL, it seems like it has so many positive challenges that it can undertake and take advantage of opportunities

author: A
sentence: Being successful means you can be better

author: A
sentence: But imagine if you’ve got a dire company that’s maybe diminishing and someone comes up with a project

author: A
sentence: And I’m remembering - remember David Jones, I’m not sure how long he’s had in the market, but when they did that food venture?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Vaguely, really vaguely

author: A
sentence: 2002, well it blew up before 2002

author: A
sentence: But you could just imagine the company’s not doing too well, people are circling thinking maybe if they just sell off their property they’ll make more money? And then they come up with a project

author: A
sentence: And people don’t want to query the capital decisions and the different assumptions aggressively because they don’t want to stymie all hope

author: A
sentence: But somebody has to ask, what is the exit strategy, what would happen if this went bad? And rather than having everyone going nah, nah, you nominate a person and you probably nominate the person whose skills are best aligned to it, to this particular discussion

author: A
sentence: You - that person is the black hat or the devil’s advocate

author: A
sentence: But everybody knows that it’s not them personally

author: A
sentence: That’s their role in the meeting is actually to make those negatives become apparent, make sure they’re addressed

author: A
sentence: I’ve heard of, you know, you look through Harvard and McKinsey and the like and there’s all those sorts of different practices which you think a professional Board actually would be able to - an experienced professional Board would probably hand that around

author: A
sentence: People build their social capital and the person who has got enough social capital can ask that difficult tetchy question

author: A
sentence: Make sure that the risks are actually all interrogated

author: A
sentence: So all credit to that Director who is using that technique

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: It was interesting

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there’s a situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating for diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I reckon if they were - if Boards were generally diverse

author: Q
sentence: Sorry if they were what?

author: A
sentence: If Boards were generally diverse as opposed to having the ASX 200 just reaching the 30% female and one of the reasons we focused on females I think is because gender diversity is such a large number, you know half the population are female

author: A
sentence: So it’s really easy to pick, whereas if you pick ethnicity or whether you need IT experience or that sort of thing, the numbers vary so much

author: A
sentence: I think that if we had Boards that were really diverse, and you think well a bit less diversity is not going to hurt

author: A
sentence: Because I think that if you had a truly diverse, like a 40% diverse, in a group with [inaudible] 00:20:16, who is a Director, and she’s like female and Asian, and I can’t remember, I think she might be accounting but she basically ticked a couple of diversity boxes in one person

author: A
sentence: You often see that, where people go whoa, this one person is our diversity! So seven of the people are all the same, but the one person ticks some diversity boxes

author: A
sentence: Well, to me, that is still only 12% diversity, even though you have a multiplicity of diversity in that 12%

author: A
sentence: But say we had a truly diverse Board, 40%, 50%, 60, 70, then slipping a bit

author: A
sentence: I think as long as you’ve probably got a base level of 40% total diversity, that the companies who have floated have slipped into groupthink

author: A
sentence: However if it was running at 70% truly diverse then I wouldn’t think it’s so important, or rather I figure it’s not the thing to choose to change

author: A
sentence: Because even if it slips back it’s still above a threshold, whether that’s 40 or 50% when we look at all those other characteristics

author: Q
sentence: So you’re saying it’s not important to manage it, it doesn’t become a focus to manage if it’s already diverse but diversity is important because you’re saying you’ve got to have that? Is that right?

author: A
sentence: Well I’m basically saying that it’s a continuum and once you’re above a threshold, provided you stay above that threshold then you have other priorities

author: A
sentence: If you’re close to that threshold or falling towards that threshold then it would have to go back up in your priorities

author: A
sentence: You have to ask yourself “Why is this happening?” But if it’s near nicely diverse and you’ve had a changeover of one or two people and it doesn’t change it from being nicely above the threshold I would only start worrying as you lost one or two people

author: A
sentence: I would be worried about other things

author: Q
sentence: Yep good

author: Q
sentence: What does Board diversity mean? How do you define it?

author: A
sentence: We’ve gone for that simplistic in our focus, this is just the 30%

author: Q
sentence: Gender?

author: A
sentence: Gender

author: A
sentence: But we feel that you can’t have all CEO’s, you can’t have no CEO’s, you can’t have no people with experience of operating the style of business, so for Rio for example we’re a little concerned that the actual operating expertise resides in the Chair and the CEO and CFO

author: A
sentence: Whereas the rest of the Board, none of them have run anything at any time in their careers

author: A
sentence: Sorry, run, mines

author: A
sentence: Large mines

author: A
sentence: In their careers

author: A
sentence: So we think that there needs to be a certain quantum of people with that sort of experience

author: A
sentence: You need IT/social media, modern world techniques, exposure in that side, you need accountants, an accountant, a lawyer, everybody needs to have finance understanding

author: A
sentence: Even if they’re an engineer who has had experience running a particular division or the like

author: A
sentence: The Board just shouldn’t look the same

author: A
sentence: So you need to have- it’s really weird if they all end up just being born in 1946 for example

author: A
sentence: Or went to the same school

author: A
sentence: So basically look different and when you write their credentials down or a blurb about what they do for the company, that needs to look different

author: A
sentence: My concerns with Wesfarmers where everybody is a Western Australian, who worked at - sorry I don’t mean Wesfarmers, I mean Woodside

author: A
sentence: But everybody worked at Wesfarmers on the Board

author: A
sentence: And that’s just a little bit of a concern, it’s got to be too much of a clique

author: A
sentence: But they’re all grown ups so hopefully they’re all able to argue with each other and have totally different opinions and carry them through

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so that would be like a social, it’s like an in-group

author: A
sentence: Yeah, like an enclave

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and so it will influence, undue influence on decision-making because of that

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it can be that your social capital, because you see with Boards and, I know retail shareholders have trouble understanding that you can’t just walk in

author: A
sentence: Because sometimes it’s hard for a retail shareholder to understand the difference between executives and Boards

author: A
sentence: Especially if they have been exposed to small companies where that distinction is far less but in the larger companies you turn up to your first Board meeting, you really can’t start critiquing efficiently and effectively in your first meeting

author: A
sentence: It takes 6 to 12 months because what is laid before you is curated to a great degree, you have to start building behind that but also you need the social capital to be able to pursue lines of enquiry

author: Q
sentence: So given that, what do you think is the ideal tenure, time for Board members?

author: A
sentence: I’m happy to go ahead, yes

author: A
sentence: I’ll ask anything I need on the way through

author: A
sentence: With the ASA we consider people lose their independence at 12 years

author: A
sentence: But I really think that if we move to annual elections this might change it

author: A
sentence: But between nine and 12 years, and then it really depends on the Board itself

author: A
