sentence: So for example if for some reason there has been a disruption, you’ve got someone who has been on the Board for nine years and the others are all new for some reason then that person may well be the Chair even though we would consider that they’re really heavily invested in the earlier decisions of the Board

author: A
sentence: So we would query their independence at year 10

author: A
sentence: But if that Board has no other continuity than that person may well be the appropriate Chair, even though we want an independent Chair

author: A
sentence: And these are the things you have to balance out

author: A
sentence: But a really well curated Board has people joining, their longevity should be dispersed

author: A
sentence: So you have some people who have three or less years tenure, some with six and less and others with, nine to 11

author: A
sentence: And the Board should be a living thing

author: A
sentence: It should be curated so that the older ones start to move on and it may be, I know a lot of people wanted to vote against Andrew Moll in his last role but he was important for a particular divestiture and was leaving after that period

author: A
sentence: So we have to understand the nature of the Board

author: A
sentence: It sometimes means that people should be there longer but we really hate seeing a Board like think Gerry Harvey’s Board

author: A
sentence: The last meeting their most recent appointee may have been 2007

author: A
sentence: I can actually look that one up

author: A
sentence: And so it’s obviously not a living thing

author: Q
sentence: So what do you to when – how can you influence that?

author: A
sentence: When we go and talk to them we ask your job is Mr Chair Miss Chair, to look after this Board

author: A
sentence: How are you making sure that it’s a living being and, you know, you’re adding people with new experiences and new backgrounds and people who have contributed substantially are retired with great thanks

author: A
sentence: It’s not like you burnt out or anything but in 10 years you would hope that you had given all you had to give

author: A
sentence: And again it’s like 10 to 12 years just because of whatever is going on at the time and just with Harvey Norman for example the first Director started in ‘87 which is their listing date, so probably pre-dates that

author: A
sentence: Until March 2019 the next most recent appointment was their CFO in ’07

author: A
sentence: So 1987 to ‘07, that was where the Directors sit

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Wow, that’s incredible

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that doesn’t look like living

author: A
sentence: A living thing that is supposed to make the company better and keep Directors and keep executives to account and all that sort of stuff

author: Q
sentence: So you go talk to the Board, to the Chair or whatever and then do you communicate to shareholders? How do you?

author: A
sentence: At the AGM with a Board like that, we’d basically vote against them

author: A
sentence: Well it depends on the independence and the like but we would vote against the Directors in such a Board because really they should be appointing a new Director which they have

author: A
sentence: And so in that vote against there’s a fair amount of media attention so we would express that to the media

author: A
sentence: Our voting intentions are made available to our members, so they would be aware that we are voting against

author: A
sentence: And then we would be advising the company

author: A
sentence: We try not to broadside the company, we would advise the company that we will be voting against them, and that is the reason for lack of Board renewal

author: A
sentence: And if the company was in a bit of a dire situation – so, at times we have voted for people in one company because they have been important to, say – so, the Chairman of Amcor we consider has too much workload, but they were doing a huge acquisition

author: A
sentence: So we voted for him, [Graeme Liebelt] 0:30:38

author: A
sentence: 0 in Amcor, but against him in his other roles

author: A
sentence: Because we considered that he really needed to be continuing with that company, that had – Amcor, which had the acquisition

author: A
sentence: But we thought he was doing too much, because you always end up with crises happening at every company at the same time

author: A
sentence: So we voted against him for others

author: A
sentence: So we go public and we basically tell the people we’re going to vote against, we tell our members, we tell the media

author: Q
sentence: So when you’re using this kind of influence is there any tension, because you’re talking to the Chair so you would probably be privy to information that might not be public

author: Q
sentence: Is there ever a tension between making something public and –?

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: And have I received a consent form for you?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: The way listed companies work is that in their engagement with shareholders or shareholder representatives, they are not able - anything that’s disclosed to some needs to be disclosed to all

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: So you would typically have those meetings with the company secretary or an investor relations manager in the room so there is no, and also hold yourself to account so you don’t have selective disclosure or disclose things that can’t be disclosed

author: A
sentence: Because that’s insider -

author: Q
sentence: It’s anti-competitive

author: A
sentence: And it can be insider trading and from my institutional time, if we ever did become privy to anything inside we had to then stop everything in the whole business trading in that

author: A
sentence: So if you’re at Macquarie for example and one arm of your business is working out a debt prospectus that’s huge for the company, rather than, you know, you’re one of 10 and everyone knows about it

author: A
sentence: You can’t do anything on that company until it all becomes public

author: A
sentence: Your clients can’t buy it or sell it, you can’t buy it or sell it, you can’t publish on it

author: A
sentence: So there will never be anything inside disclosed at those meetings

author: A
sentence: The only thing is what we say in public needs to be couched in a respectful manner

author: A
sentence: So when we’re talking with these companies and saying we’re going to vote against you because you’ve been on the Board for 18 years and the last person was appointed 10 years ago and we think that you are really letting the company down by not renewing the Board

author: A
sentence: We would publicly state that to that person, sorry we would state it to the person privately and tell them we’re going to put that in our voting intentions and we’re going to talk about it

author: A
sentence: And to some degree I suppose there is nothing personal about it, we’re paying attention to a criteria we think is important

author: Q
sentence: That great

author: Q
sentence: That’s quite significant influence that you can use

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: So, are there any other - you talk to the Chair, the Chair is very influential in renewal of Boards and of course the Chair position as well

author: A
sentence: Also the person who leads typically a remuneration and nominations committee

author: Q
sentence: Okay, Yep

author: A
sentence: So the Chair of that particular committee is also influential in encouraging a Board to renew

author: A
sentence: So they would be the two positions we would target if we felt the Board had been stilted by

author: A
sentence: But we might, depending on how [stultified it is,] 0:34:33

author: A
sentence: 3 we might end up just voting against everyone until they get their act together and appoint a new person

author: Q
sentence: Thank you 39D for agreeing to be interviewed for our research on board diversity

author: Q
sentence: So, there’s a lot of talk about board diversity but we’re interested in an Australian perspective and to obtain that information from people who are actually on boards or influence boards so, that’s why we’re talking to you

author: Q
sentence: And look I’ve got from the internet your background so about 25 years board experience

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: It’s the hands-on experience that we have

author: A
sentence: I mean that is such an old tradition, I don’t know how that could be disrupted

author: A
sentence: But it probably needs to be

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay, that’s really good, thank you 39D

author: Q
sentence: From a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about the way diversity of Australian boards is currently been promoted through gender target quotas?

author: A
sentence: Are you talking about a regulatory perspective? Well there’s no regulation around diversity

author: A
sentence: The ASX has got principles around reporting diversity and stuff like that

author: A
sentence: But there’s no regulation; there’s nothing that says you need to have the 40:40:20 rule in place for example

author: A
sentence: So, there is no regulatory environment around that

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so we need to talk about the soft governance of the system in terms of traditions about how chairs are appointed; traditions around targets and shared goals, recognised goals; do you think we need to firm it up and make quotas?

author: A
sentence: Do you know who I think needs to apply more pressure, and that is the large investees, sorry investors like the superannuation funds, because at the end of the day we’re talking about the commercial world and money is the language of the commercial world

author: A
sentence: And I don’t think that the large investors have been exercising enough of their financial power to make sure that the governance structures which includes the board and the composition of the board, are optimised

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, excellent

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the financial lead fellow

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: [over talk] 00:25:43

author: Q
sentence: So, that will be good, that will link in nicely

author: Q
sentence: Finally, the final question and you’ve got four minutes; looking ten years into the future, how would you like to see diversity of Australian boards and how do you think we can get there?

author: A
sentence: Well I’d certainly like to see more gender diversity and more age diversity and more ethnic diversity

author: A
sentence: And the fact is that Australia is part of the global world

author: A
sentence: We have a racially mixed population and if we’re looking to be part of the global market, then we need to understand how those particular cultures, those particular parts will work

author: A
sentence: And what’s going to give us insights, is actually to have people like that sitting around the table with us as fellow Australians, giving us the insights that we need; so, that’s what I’d like to see in ten years

author: A
sentence: The gender is being addressed

author: A
sentence: The women of my generation are really pushing it and we’re not going to let it go

author: A
sentence: And we going to stay completely vigilant for the next 20 years that it stays in place because when you lose the vigilance –

author: A
sentence: You know we have a situation like we had when Tony Abbot was our prime minister and we only had one woman around our cabinet table, which was absolutely unacceptable

author: A
sentence: And so, we as women must remain vigilant that we are fully represented, because we are not a minority

author: A
sentence: But we need to make sure also that we have around our board tables the sort of people who will represent us as a global citizen and as a global player

author: Q
sentence: So, it is a natural barrier

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Look this is completely left of field, if we were exporting say to Muslim countries where women not really tend to be out there, on a board -

author: A
sentence: Well certainly it’s the Arab Muslim countries where women - but if you have a look at the situation in Indonesia, there are women who play key roles in those countries

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: But the ones where women are really kept behind closed doors

author: Q
sentence: If we’re gender diverse, our boards, is there a tension between – if they’re a major party in say Saudi Arabia, can you talk to that; because I’m just thinking, yeah but we are in a diverse global economy, however some aspects of the economy are very anti-diversity; so, do we compromise in order to -

author: A
sentence: Well you won’t be surprised how pragmatic and opportunistic the Arab Muslim countries are when they’re dealing with Western societies

author: A
sentence: And also, when the women, and of course, it’s women of a certain class which is wealthy and privileged, how they are represented and behave when they’re outside of their countries

author: A
sentence: Because a lot of them travel a lot and live outside of their own country for a great part of the year and are very active in the commercial world

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it’s not an issue really

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: At the end of the day you’re talking about money and pragmatism also

author: Q
sentence: I love it

author: Q
sentence: 39D, I have taken your time, we’ve finished 30 seconds before, how is that?

author: A
sentence: Oh, great, thank you

author: Q
sentence: That is fabulous thank you so much

author: Q
sentence: END OF TRANSCRIPT

author: A
sentence: I think so, yeah

author: A
sentence: I mean, as I said I think that in this sort of technological age not to bring younger people on, younger people who are potentially your customers, younger people who are more technologically savvy than the older people sitting around the table, I think is a big mistake

author: A
sentence: But there’s still resistance

author: Q
sentence: Is there a way to bring that diversity to the board without them actually being a board member with full governance responsibilities?

author: A
sentence: Well that’s an interesting point

author: A
sentence: There is a Board Services Program, I don’t know whether you’re aware of that; but it’s mainly in the not-for-profit sector that that operates where younger people are brought on as participants and they can participate but they don’t have any of the fiduciary duties of a director

author: A
sentence: And very often from the insertion they then are invited to come onto the board because they tend to make a big contribution

author: Q
sentence: So, how important do you think it is to have a diverse board?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely crucial

author: Q
sentence: So, would that be on a scale, one to ten, ten is extremely important

author: A
sentence: Yeah, a ten

author: Q
sentence: Yeah perfect

author: Q
sentence: And do you feel that it’s always been important, and why is it so important?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, I do

author: A
sentence: Well I think it’s hugely important to create the optimum decision-making outcomes that we can possibly create; and that’s the research, I mean, everything has been pointing to that for decades now, but things have been slowly changed, unfortunately

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of a decision that you thought illustrates the importance of diversity, without divulging?

author: A
sentence: Well I can’t be specific to an organisation but I can certainly tell you that in decisions around a composition of executive teams, that having diverse people around your boardroom table certainly puts pressure on management to ensure that their executive teams, even at the highest levels are more diverse and inclusive

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: No one has mentioned that downward pressure, that’s fantastic; a connection between the two but not expressed it

author: Q
sentence: So, that makes sense because the questions are coming left of field so to speak

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there’s any situational context where diversity might not be so important in a board?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t but I do think that people do get hung up on 50:50 in the context of gender diversity

author: A
sentence: I’m a great believer in what’s called the 40:40:20 rule and I also like to talk about minimum numbers of men rather than quotas for women

author: A
sentence: So, I like to talk about minimum numbers of men, minimum numbers of women and then you have a floating number

author: A
sentence: So, that’s 40:40:20, so we had a minimum percentage of 40:40for men

author: A
sentence: And we have a minimum percentage of 40 for women and then we have 20% floating

author: A
sentence: Sometimes you might have 60% women, sometimes you might have 60% men and it gives that flexibility which I think is very important

author: Q
sentence: You’ve worked across all sectors not-for-profits, do you think the not-for-profit sector is predominantly women like there’s a tendency to have some men on board?

author: A
sentence: If you have a look actually at the not-for-profit sector, it’s quite interesting

author: A
sentence: For small not for profits, yes

author: A
sentence: For not-for-profits that have revenues of over $5 million, the women tend to be taken over by the guys

author: A
sentence: So, most of those, the larger not-for-profits, achieved by men and they do tend to be men on the board

author: Q
sentence: So, we should look at the financial -

author: A
sentence: Yes, that’s right, definitely

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: What does diversity mean to you 39D?

author: Q
sentence: So, first, how has the composition of boards changed over time?

author: A
sentence: Better decision-making

author: Q
sentence: Can you give an example; can you illustrate that for me?

author: A
sentence: Well I think I did in terms of the executive management

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: What about the social networks that people have; do you think that’s important as an aspect of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Because it’s often from our social networks that we learn about what our customers like or don’t like; what they’re looking for? I mean, nowadays through social media we have much more access to that sort of data in a much more broader sense

author: A
sentence: But I still think that social networks are important for feedback and general intelligence

author: Q
sentence: And social economic background, do you think that kind of diversity is important on boards?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Gender diversity has been debated for a while, how do you feel about the recent inclusion of sexual differences and different orientations; do you think that’s important?

author: A
sentence: Well I think it’s important if a society think it’s important

author: A
sentence: So, it’s now a conversation that’s happening globally within our society, so therefore I do think it’s important, yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, do you see social values being an important influence of boards?

author: A
sentence: Oh, well there are definitely more diverse boards particularly in terms of gender, I would say

author: A
sentence: Not so much in terms of different ethnicities or different age

author: A
sentence: There still seems to be a reluctance to bring on younger people, for example, that may have different perspectives and also, different experiences particularly in a technological age, by older, more mature board members

author: A
sentence: Although I have to say when I’ve had the opportunity to bring younger people onto boards that I’ve been involved with in the not-for-profit sector and arts, I tend to do that because I think it’s great to have a range of ages as well as a range of different backgrounds

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, because the social values of your employees are absolutely crucial to the smooth functioning of the organisation

author: A
sentence: So, for example a number of the organisations that I’m involved with now have LGBTQI committees and they acknowledge that

author: A
sentence: And what that does in the context of the organisation, it actually, and this was expressed to me in a very good way, in fact just the other day, that; are you comfortable to bring your whole self to work, to your workplace? And I think that unless your employees are comfortable and also believe that the organisation that they’re working for reflects their values, you’re not going to have a successful workforce

author: A
sentence: And if you don’t have a successful workforce, you do not have a successful company

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, you’ve got the decision-making of a board and you’ve got the performance of the organisation; you’ve got those two outcomes from diversity

author: Q
sentence: Do you think a particular kind of diversity matters more than others?

author: A
sentence: Well for me gender diversity matters because women are not a minority

author: A
sentence: So, whenever anyone sort of talks about the argument that well, if we open the floodgates to gender diversity, then we’re going to have this sort of diversity and it is complete rubbish

author: A
sentence: I mean the fact is women are better educated than men in terms of tertiary outcomes and they are not a minority in our society; in fact, they’re a small majority

author: A
sentence: And so therefore, not to have women equally represented is I think, absolutely ludicrous

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Do you think, when you’re recruiting people, there can be conflict or tension between recruiting people with a collegiate fit and recruiting people who would prevent groupthink on a board?

author: A
sentence: On a board it is important to have both

author: A
sentence: And I don’t think that they’re mutually exclusive

author: A
sentence: I think that you can be incredibly collegiate and respectful but voice a different point of view

author: A
sentence: So, I don’t see those two things as being mutually exclusive

author: Q
sentence: So, it’s really then the culture of the board, ad hoc managers

author: Q
sentence: Now, look you’ve been a chair of a number, or you are a chair of a number, can you talk to me about how you cultivated the culture, because this is an important aspect and I’m aware of the time?

author: A
sentence: What I do is I always make sure that everybody has a voice around the board table

author: A
sentence: So, what I do is I try and manage meetings so that nobody dominates and that everybody has an opportunity to speak

author: A
sentence: And if that means that I need to go around the table and individually ask people, ‘what do you think about that,’ I do that

author: A
sentence: Because of course, in terms of diversity you have introverts and you have extraverts

author: A
sentence: You have people who are happy to speak about people who are more resistant; so, it doesn’t mean that they don’t have valuable things to contribute, but they’re not as forceful in terms of putting their views forward

author: A
sentence: So, I always make sure that those people feel absolutely empowered to speak and I invite them to speak

author: Q
sentence: Do you mentor behind the scenes, people on the board as part of that role?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t necessarily mentor people on the board but what I do is I talk to my board directors, fellow colleagues, in-between meetings

author: Q
sentence: All right, give feedback, encourage, whatever

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, we’ll follow that through a little, what are the barriers to recruiting people onto boards who are younger?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that’s right

author: A
sentence: And you know what, and I receive the same from them

author: A
sentence: So, it’s not just me encouraging them or giving them feedback, it’s me getting that from them; how am I going; what do you think of how the business is going? Do you know what I mean, because I’m a very good communicator and I think that that communication is really crucial in-between board meetings

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: And so, that is not seen as a lack of transparency and openness

author: A
sentence: On the contrary, it is seen as being very transparent and very open

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Do you think diversity can contribute to conflict on the board?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely and it’s the way it’s managed, usually by the chair

author: A
sentence: But often by colleagues just sitting around the table

author: A
sentence: And I think it goes back to your point about collegiality and respect

author: A
sentence: So, if there’s collegiality and respect, there can be conflict

author: A
sentence: That’s fine, but it just needs to be managed

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of how conflict, let’s say where the small ‘c’ is managed and how a big ‘c’ is avoided, where it’s disruptive or whatever?

author: A
sentence: Look I can think back onto a situation, only a couple of times where I felt that colleagues behaviours have not been appropriate, where I have not been chair and where I have actually called the chair after the meeting and said, 'I thought that colleague’s behaviour was out of line and I think that you need to call them up and explain to them why it was out of line and why you’re not going to put up with it? And if they don’t like it, they can leave the TAL board

author: Q
sentence: Did it work?

author: A
sentence: Yeah it did

author: A
sentence: It usually does

author: A
sentence: So, it goes to your point about transparency and openness

author: A
sentence: You need to have a chairman who can be frank and fearless

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Have you been in a situation where you’re not chair, and the chair has been weak and has not done that kind of thing and what has been the result?

author: A
sentence: Not enough experience

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I left the board

author: Q
sentence: Why?

author: A
sentence: Because I’m not happy that the organisation has been properly governed and that can lead to – it will be issues for me as a director

author: A
sentence: So, I’d rather not be in that situation

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: So, do you think if it’s a diverse board, it’s even more important that the chair is able to manage conflict, the culture of the board and the governance?

author: A
sentence: Well I guess that’s why historically boards haven’t been diverse because the network, I won’t necessarily call it the old boy network, but the network has been familiar; you’ve got people who look alike, who sound alike who are from the same type of background sitting around the table all agreeing with each other

author: A
sentence: So, of course diversity is going to require more management

author: A
sentence: But as I said, I think that’s a good thing

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: Do, you think then in the interest of promoting or building diversity, do we need chairs having been cultivated with more skills to manage these kinds of diversity and the complexities that arise?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: One would hope that through their executive experience that they would have developed that because let’s face it, work forces are their very nature to diverse

author: A
sentence: If you look back at the history of Australian companies, I think that there have been some very mediocre chairmen who probably haven’t had that sort of experience and who probably never thought that they needed it

author: A
sentence: And the organisations have suffered as a result

author: A
sentence: I guess, subjects like in the MBAs like organisational behaviour, address those sorts of issues

author: A
sentence: But then, if you look at the amount of chairmen currently on the ASX, a lot of them have very sort of ordinary single degrees and have never advanced beyond that

author: A
sentence: So, they’ve either learned by experience or they’ve not learned, and the board isn’t necessarily governed as well as it could be

author: Q
sentence: So, if you’re looking to recruit, would you include – you’d look for diverse credentials?

author: A
sentence: Oh definitely

author: Q
sentence: Very good

author: Q
sentence: So, what might you look for when you’re thinking about building diversity on the board?

author: Q
sentence: What kind of experience?

author: A
sentence: Oh, I look for all sorts of diversity; particularly today, in any business that I would be looking to recruit for a board for, I would be looking for aged diversity and also innovation and technology

author: A
sentence: Because even though you might be in an industry where you think what you need is a lawyer and an accountant and someone with industry specific knowledge, you need somebody who’s got technology and innovation, because these are people who see what your future’s going to look like

author: A
sentence: And I think also, you always need somebody from outside the industry who has a different perspective and who also brings experience of their industry into the mix which I think is very important, because we all learn from each other or we all hope we learn from each other

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: And they are all things available from just a CV

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you look for someone who’s got an arts background as well as a law background, so that sort of credentialing, do you look for that?

author: A
sentence: Are you talking about for a business board?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, for the sort of boards you’ve been on, all your range?

author: A
sentence: Well I wouldn’t necessarily look for somebody from an arts background to go onto a property industry board

author: A
sentence: But I would look for someone who potentially has for example, an engineering degree to go onto a property industry board

author: A
sentence: But also, somebody who’s potentially got an arts law background

author: A
sentence: When I say arts law, I mean, a humanities background

author: A
sentence: So, I would be looking for people with a science background and for people with a humanities background as well

author: A
sentence: I think the humanities is very important, and you know in these days a focus on STEM

author: A
sentence: I think if we think about where the creative ideas all come from, it’s usually from humanities, not from science

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: So, when you’re identifying potential members, do you use recruitment organisations to help you or do you use your networks, or does it depend on -

author: A
sentence: All of the above

author: Q
sentence: All of the above

author: Q
sentence: So, if it’s a large business organisation, would you tend to definitely use a recruitment organisation or a small one -

author: A
sentence: Well governance experience and even I guess, having experienced different sorts of cycles within industry and businesses

author: A
sentence: Well I think in terms of governance you have to, because you need to make sure that you’re covering off the field

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, in the past you said if there’s not enough women on the boards, is it in part because people haven’t been using recruitment organisations or were recruitment organisations contributing to that underrepresentation of women in the past?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think they were

author: Q
sentence: Are they now; has that changed you think?

author: A
sentence: Some of them do

author: Q
sentence: So, do you select them based on –

author: A
sentence: I do

author: Q
sentence: - and is that easily available, that information; where is it, I haven’t seen it?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: You mean which recruitment agency sees – just talk to women directors

author: Q
sentence: I just talk to them, okay, use your networks

author: Q
sentence: Is this something schools could address do you think?

author: A
sentence: Yes, that’s right

author: A
sentence: You pretty much know who’s good and who’s not

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Do boards that you’re familiar with have any barriers to managing or building diversity and what might they be?

author: A
sentence: It’s usually the chairman

author: A
sentence: So, if the chair isn’t pro-diversity, then it’s not going to happen

author: A
sentence: I mean, in fact it was interesting to see there was a Tweet today that said that the 500 companies in the S&P listings in the US, none of them do not have at least one woman on the board, whereas in Australia we still have four companies that don’t have women on their boards

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it’s amazing, isn’t it? So, because I know within the banks, the chair has sort of lost their jobs, how important is the chair nowadays?

author: A
sentence: Hugely

author: A
sentence: The leadership comes from the chair; the governance, the values, the collegiality, the respect, the smooth working and the relationship between CEO and chair is crucial

author: Q
sentence: Well what are we doing to cultivate good chairs?

author: A
sentence: Good question

author: A
sentence: We’ve had a lot of very unqualified men in those roles for a very long time, haven’t we?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so perhaps that’s an opportunity for us to actually try and cultivate

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think that there’s a real issue with the chairman nominating their successors because the way it works is very often just a tap on the shoulder to a mate

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, could that be regulated?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, [the participant] , thank you so much for agreeing to the interview for this research into diversity on Australian boards

author: Q
sentence: The interview should go for less than an hour, and you know Paul

author: Q
sentence: I’m Margo [Sheehan] 00:00:16, the senior research fellow for the project

author: Q
sentence: Are there any questions you had before we go ahead?

author: A
sentence: They do

author: Q2
sentence: And they’re usually very skilled at managing -

author: A
sentence: Exactly, and as I said, our chair is pretty good at that, and – but it’s done slightly differently in terms of he will usually not say his piece until everybody else has finished, rather than say, “Here’s what I think

author: A
sentence: What do you all think?” It’s, “What do you all think?” and then, “Okay, this is my take on it

author: A
sentence: ” Yes, so definitely third party facilitation for those sorts of things is -

author: Q2
sentence: [Big things] 00:30:23

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Back to the chair, because you’re – this has been coming up in the interviews, as the role is key – is there training or development for chairs to do this well?

author: A
sentence: There is training, but I’m not sure it’s any use

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: A
sentence: The AICD does have training for chairs

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure it’s entirely useful

author: Q
sentence: Why do you say that?

author: A
sentence: Just from anecdotal evidence from people who’ve been there, saying those who’ve done the AICD course and said it was really great, but the chairing a board course is not that good

author: A
sentence: I think really partly it’s because it comes down to the individual’s personality and skills

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: What, the facilitating -

author: A
sentence: Yes, if you have those skills, and if you have that sort of personality

author: A
sentence: If you’re fairly dominant that’s kind of hard to do, but you have to be dominant enough not to let things run off, but not so dominant that nobody else gets to put their – or is afraid to say anything that negates anything that you’ve just said

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So it’s more of an innate skill?

author: A
sentence: I think there are some innate skills

author: A
sentence: I think it comes down to experience

author: A
sentence: I really – it’s – I’ve been on a couple of boards, and I think it makes a big difference

author: A
sentence: Chairing is definitely a skill, and it’s an art as much as a science, I think

author: A
sentence: You have to play the people the right way

author: A
sentence: Also – I think that’s also an argument for not having very short board terms, because I think it’s very hard for, A) people to get to know each other, but also for the chair to get to know the individual

author: A
sentence: If they are there a year and then they’re gone, which happens in some organisations – it’s typically more of a committee-type thing rather than a board of an organisation, but yes

author: A
sentence: Often people are fairly quiet the first six months, or maybe a bit longer

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So how long has your board position -?

author: A
sentence: Ours are three years

author: Q
sentence: Three years, and the chair is the same?

author: A
sentence: The chair is elected every year

author: A
sentence: All office bearers are elected every year

author: A
sentence: Committee heads are appointed every year

author: A
sentence: Chairs, and vice-chairs, and treasurer are elected every year

author: Q
sentence: Is that typical of state sector -?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: They make the appointment

author: A
sentence: The shortlisting is ours, but the final choice is down to the minister

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: In the health sector anyway

author: Q
sentence: Yes, in the health sector

author: Q
sentence: You can’t speak about other types of boards?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Not in the state sector, no

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Well, what about the for-profit then?

author: A
sentence: I think chairs are usually there as long as they want to be, until you are usurped in some way, for a lot of organisations

author: A
sentence: That’s why there’s a deliberate – they have to be re-elected every year, but most people don’t want to put their hand up for it anyway

author: Q2
sentence: [Big enough time to have] 00:33:25 fixed terms? Yes

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: But usually they’re reappointed -

author: Q2
sentence: But often the constitutions will have, “No more than X –”

author: A
sentence: Yes, “X” total years of director plus chair – yes

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: You mentioned age – so you said – so what’s the process around -?

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: In your experience, how are new board members selected? We talked a little bit about it

author: A
sentence: How are they selected? As I said – well, we have criteria

author: A
sentence: We have several pieces of input

author: A
sentence: One is our own – every year we construct a skills matrix around the board and see what’s missing, with having regard to who might be retiring or stepping down for this year

author: A
sentence: So we see what gaps there are, and what we’ve got, and what we’ve maybe got too much of and not enough of

author: A
sentence: So that’s one piece of input

author: A
sentence: The other piece of input is the vibe from the minister at that particular time

author: A
sentence: There are often directives from the department, from – there’s directive from the secretary and from the minister, and they usually – they sometimes are oblique but often they’re quite blunt and say, “You must do this

author: A
sentence: You must – we would look very favourably upon X, Y, Z

author: A
sentence: ” So -

author: Q
sentence: And that would be someone – a medical someone from a medical background, or a particular person?

author: A
sentence: Yes, because hospital boards used to be – basically consist only of clinicians, and then they caused havoc and so they got rid of that

author: A
sentence: Then they had the opposite problem: there was nobody who understood clinical issues

author: A
sentence: So at the moment the big push is clinical governance

author: A
sentence: That’s a huge push in the hospital sector at the moment after the [Garrawarra] 00:35:23 issues, and some other ones

author: A
sentence: So that’s been a huge push, and so there’s been a push to get some clinical – not necessarily clinicians, but people with an understanding of clinical governance

author: Q
sentence: So it can be nursing? Or it has to be medical?

author: A
sentence: No, it doesn’t have to be medical, but there is a push to get at least one clinician onto the board – one medical clinician on the board

author: A
sentence: So there’s that piece of input, and the rest is, from time-to-time they change the criteria

author: A
sentence: The government – the department changes the criteria

author: A
sentence: Was it last year? No, the year before – there’s now an advisory board for health board appointments that comes out with recommendations from on high about, “This is what we should be doing

author: A
sentence: ” So they set up criteria as well

author: Q
sentence: Who runs that?

author: A
sentence: That’s an independent board reporting to the minister, I think

author: Q
sentence: Advisory committee for -

author: A
sentence: I think it’s called health board appointments, or something

author: A
sentence: It was a part of a slew of things that came up with – following the [Garrawarra] and the [Towards Zero] 00:36:38 Report

author: A
sentence: There is some drive to get a bit more youth into the – I’m on a board in the health sector, a hospital board – and there’s some drive to get a few younger people onto the boards

author: A
sentence: We have – I think we’ve got a couple in the 60s range, and three or four in the 50s, a bunch in the 40s and two in the 30s, because that’s been a particular – because we particularly went out to put that in our list of – we have a matrix of – we have a skills matrix that we have to hire to, and we also have then some diversity requirements, yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it’s probably recommended in the [Duckett] Report

author: A
sentence: Yes, it was in the [Duckett] Review

author: A
sentence: Yes, it was

author: A
sentence: Yes, and we – everything that’s [Duckett] we take as -

author: Q
sentence: -@ gospel?

author: A
sentence: Our CEO was also working on that review with [Duckett] so we’ve had lots of presentations from him

author: A
sentence: Yes, we tend to go that way

author: A
sentence: Yes, so there’s that criteria, so – people that apply have to rate themselves against that criteria

author: A
sentence: You can only pick three out of the eight areas that you say you have expertise in, and you have to rate them, and that gives you an explanation of – so if you say “law” – it’s one to five or something – and if you give yourself a five in law, you have to have a law degree and be admitted to practice, preferably in either corporate governance or health law

author: A
sentence: So that’s how you – it helps you determine – with accounting and finance you have to be an accountant or a financial something or other, and have to have a degree and whatever

author: A
sentence: So that’s – are you talking about process now of appointing people, or are you talking about thinking about it? Or what are you -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, it’s how new board members are selected

author: Q2
sentence: With a particular twist on diversity

author: Q2
sentence: So what we’re really after is how the selection process is fashioned, but with a particular regard to – I think it’s well established that if you’re short of accountants you get accountants

author: A
sentence: Yes, but that’s part of the diversity criteria that we have

author: Q2
sentence: Correct, correct, but looking at some of the other stuff as well -

author: A
sentence: There are no – there is no guidance from the department about any other diversity, except for gender diversity

author: A
sentence: So we make those determinations ourselves

author: A
sentence: We determine what sort of other people we might like on the board, whether that’s age or whether that’s local community affiliations, et cetera

author: A
sentence: The board determines that themselves

author: A
sentence: So we get – the board has a conversation about that, and gives writing orders to the committee – the sub-committee that deals with that

author: A
sentence: The department and the minister have determined the approach to gender diversity

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so when you say there’s an informal push, is this coming from the state or from within your board?

author: A
sentence: We have to abide by those rules

author: A
sentence: We are aiming for 50/50 with our female board membership, and also, as I said in the list of shortlisted candidates we want to put up as close to 50/50 – meaning we have to put up 50/50

author: A
sentence: In reality, we have to

author: A
sentence: Otherwise there’d be questions

author: A
sentence: They’ll – we can, but there will be questions

author: Q
sentence: Yes, it will come back -

author: A
sentence: If we get one female applicant and they’re rubbish in terms of fit, then we can not, but we have to be prepared to answer a lot of questions

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Your skills diversity list, I was wondering, could we have a look at that? Is that something you can -?

author: A
sentence: Yes, maybe

author: A
sentence: I could ask

author: A
sentence: I could see

author: Q
sentence: If you can? It would be great if you could

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: But is that a way to justify your list?

author: A
sentence: Without names on it, obviously

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: No names on it -

author: A
sentence: Sorry?

author: Q
sentence: - justify – it can show that, “Look, no female applied with an appropriate skill mix?” Is it used in that sort of [comprehensive] 00:40:12 way to -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well, the matrix that we create when we get the responses, we have to set up a matrix with all the people who applied, the way they’ve rated themselves on all skills, male/female, local – whatever

author: A
sentence: Then, are they suitable for shortlisting or not suitable for shortlisting, et cetera

author: A
sentence: So that matrix is created and we use that to – we send that to the department and say, “This is who we are shortlisting

author: A
sentence: ” On occasion they come back and say, “No, you’re going to talk to that person as well

author: A
sentence: ” We have had that

author: A
sentence: But usually -

author: Q
sentence: On diversity grounds, was it?

author: A
sentence: I believe that particular one might have been on they were a medical practitioner, I think

author: A
sentence: I don’t think it was on – it certainly wasn’t on gender diversity, but I think in that case that that’s what it was

author: A
sentence: I can’t quite remember

author: A
sentence: I think that’s what it was

author: A
sentence: So yes, we have to justify why we’re interviewing the people we want to interview – the people we want to interview – on all sorts of grounds

author: Q
sentence: I get a picture for how it works, yes

author: Q
sentence: So you research – the board’s – sorry, there’s some research that suggests that boards should consider cognitive diversity as part of selection

author: Q
sentence: You’ve said that whether male or female, or things like an accountant, and whether male/female – lawyers -

author: A
sentence: Well, if they’ve got the same background, yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes, same background, same school, whatever – so very similar

author: Q
sentence: So what do you understand by cognitive diversity and do you think it matters? What role does it play?

author: A
sentence: Yes, it certainly does matter, for the reasons I mentioned before

author: A
sentence: It’s your entire approach to discussion

author: A
sentence: It’s your entire approach to decision-making and deliberation and working with others

author: Q2
sentence: I think you’ve talked about that in terms of skill diversity, et cetera

author: A
sentence: Yes, and so – yes

author: A
sentence: Obviously it makes a big difference to the way you just approach life

author: A
sentence: I’m on a board, so I’m hesitant to say too much there, just because I teach a subject called “Ethics and Diversity”

author: A
sentence: So there’s lots of – yes

author: A
sentence: I don’t want to talk about stuff that’s not really my own viewpoint

author: Q
sentence: Okay, sure

author: Q
sentence: Have you seen – can you give an example of how it’s worked well, and how it hasn’t? Apart from the marriage one, I guess

author: Q
sentence: From the state?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think in most of the decisions that require discussion, and they are usually fairly obvious, but sometimes not – sometimes things come up and you go, “I hadn’t thought of it that way

author: A
sentence: ” That’s typically how that manifests itself

author: A
sentence: People go, “Oh, I’d never actually thought of it that way

author: A
sentence: ” That’s usually – I think that’s usually been because somebody is a member of a group that others are not members of

author: A
sentence: For example, we have one board member who has got very small children, and there was something that came up, and it was a very different point of view from those whose kids were 35 or teenagers or whatever

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s a – it’s that sort of, “I hadn’t considered that, because it doesn’t really apply to me

author: A
sentence: ” Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Did you want to say something?

author: Q2
sentence: Yes, I just wanted to say – as I said, I think we talked about the cognitive diversity before, but do you – in your experience, is things like gender, ethnic, social, those physical characteristics and blah-blah – is that a good predictor of cognitive diversity, or not?

author: A
sentence: I think in some they are, but not each – any particular one

author: A
sentence: I think you have to take them in combination with each other

author: Q
sentence: Meaning?

author: A
sentence: Meaning gender, plus ethnicity, plus socioeconomic – if you’ve been an academic for ten years, probably you have a lot of similarities with other academics who’ve been around for a while

author: A
sentence: You may be very different to somebody who’s got their first job as a level A academic after just finishing a PhD

author: A
sentence: It’s a combination of things

author: A
sentence: That’s something I think you haven’t touched on, but length of tenure is definitely part of that cognitive diversity picture – how long you’ve been on the board, how well you know the other people

author: A
sentence: But it’s that sort of intersectional idea

author: A
sentence: As I said, if you’re a lawyer and have gone to a Melbourne private school and been to Melbourne University, whether you’re male or female may not be as much – it might bring – in some conversations – in others, of course it will make some difference, but you may not get the diversity of thought from that diversity

author: A
sentence: In others, it will

author: A
sentence: I was talking to somebody who employs lawyers and says that they really – they like to employ lawyers from the law school, because they’re often first in the family to go to university - they’ve struggled, they’ve scrambled, they’ve got through it – rather than people whose parents were lawyers and whose grandparents were lawyers, and yada yada

author: A
sentence: It’s a different way of thinking

author: A
sentence: Even though they’ve both done a law degree, it’s a different way of thinking

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s a combination

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Does your board consider ways to increase the board’s cognitive diversity when identifying potential new members? Given it’s so hard to identify, does it actually try to cultivate -?

author: A
sentence: By proxy

author: A
sentence: By all those things, by those skills

author: A
sentence: The differences – you have to do it by proxy

author: A
sentence: You get to interview someone for half an hour or whatever it is

author: A
sentence: You get some idea

author: A
sentence: But it’s by proxy

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So all things being equal, in a scenario where you’ve one board vacancy only, would you prefer this vacancy to be filled by a candidate who increases demographic diversity – for example gender, ethnicity, age, social diversity – or cognitive diversity?

author: A
sentence: From the state, but also internally

author: A
sentence: There’s a fair bit of conversation about that

author: A
sentence: Internally it’s mostly around office bearers and committee chairs

author: A
sentence: So the president – well, it used to be – that’s just been changed now

author: A
sentence: It’s now called the chair of the board, but they were called the president of the management committee, or something – but – so the chair is male, and has been there for a while

author: A
sentence: We now have two deputy chairs, one male, one female, and the committee chairs – I just [wrote] 00:04:19 that down for that reason – committee chairs we’ve got two male committee chairs, and five female committee chairs

author: A
sentence: So basically the leadership positions are – they try to balance that out a little bit

author: A
sentence: It depends what already exists

author: Q
sentence: It depends on what already exists

author: A
sentence: So if we have a big -

author: Q2
sentence: All other things being equal -

author: A
sentence: Yes, well – it’s a get out of jail card

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Ceteris paribus

author: A
sentence: That’s great

author: A
sentence: It’s an experiment

author: A
sentence: Well, personally, if everything was equal, and we already had the same amount of cognitive diversity on the board as we have demographic diversity already existing, and this person will be adding to one or other of the aspects of diversity – if that’s what you’re asking -

author: Q2
sentence: That’s the – yes

author: A
sentence: - Probably cognitive diversity, I think

author: A
sentence: but I would be greedy and go outside the square and Say, “Why not both?” and look for somebody with both then

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive diversity and gender

author: A
sentence: If you can

author: A
sentence: But no experiment is ever constructed that way

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Anyway, the point there also was to look at, “Well, can sometimes gender trump because of the situation?”

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So you’ve got age and gender

author: Q
sentence: Anything else, like economic background, cultural background?

author: A
sentence: It can in our case for sure, absolutely

author: A
sentence: In our board, yes it can, because of the rules that we have – the minister said, “You must -” so we do

author: Q
sentence: And also, you might be opening a whole new range of services for women, for babies

author: Q
sentence: You might be opening the replacement for – then do you want – would you go for women -

author: A
sentence: Well, they’re board members

author: A
sentence: They’re not operational, so maybe not as – it’s not as big as a driver really

author: A
sentence: I can see the point, but yes, we do have – we have quite strict rules and so we follow those

author: A
sentence: So for the choice between some cognitive diversity and we are short of a female board member, then we will get a female board member

author: A
sentence: If we don’t, we’ll send it to them and they’ll change it, which has happened

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so strategy is overwritten by the rules

author: Q
sentence: How convenient

author: Q
sentence: Board diversity seems to be quite complex

author: Q
sentence: There are different kinds of diversity and the relative importance probably differs, and the usefulness or riskiness of different kinds of diversity can depend on the situation that the company is facing

author: Q
sentence: Have you any last comments on this complexity before we move onto cultivating?

author: A
sentence: On complexity – a lot of the risk that the board is willing to take on appointing people depends on who’s already on the board, and if it’s in a happy state

author: A
sentence: So I think on our board we could probably say yes to almost anyone and say, “We’ll make them fit in some way,” or, “We’ll deal with them

author: A
sentence: ” If it’s a bit more fractured I think it’s quite difficult to do

author: A
sentence: But I think that’s – I think you can drive yourself completely mad

author: A
sentence: What I didn’t say in the process part was – we have a governance remuneration sub-committee of the board who deals with the board appointments, as well as CEO stuff

author: A
sentence: So there’s usually a smaller group of people that deal with all the staff and drive themselves mad, and I’ve done that on previous occasions, [touring agencies] 00:50:24, et cetera, and then present that to the board and say, “Are you okay with this?” But you can drive yourself mad if you don’t take a punt at some stage and go, “Look, I think this person will fit

author: A
sentence: They’ll grow into the role

author: A
sentence: They’re missing this and this, but they’ve got these good things over here

author: A
sentence: We’ll take a risk and do that

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: A nice picture of a resilient [ford] 00:50:44

author: Q
sentence: So cultivating diversity – does your board do anything to cultivate new potential members?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: As I said, we try and get people on the sub-committees, but also, for example, we were sitting around talking about sub-committee membership, because that changes – can change every year

author: A
sentence: Somebody said, “We’ve got [a vid of] 00:51:11 renewal in this committee,” because somebody left the board, and a new committee chair – “We should see this more often,” and I said, “Okay, fine

author: A
sentence: [Ange] 00:51:19, do you want to be -?” because I was chair of the governance remuneration committee – I said, “Well, are you interested?” She said, “Yes, okay, fine

author: A
sentence: ” You just – because she’d been on the committee for a year or so, and she’s a lawyer, she was able to step up to that

author: Q2
sentence: So these – in terms of cultivating potential, future directors, et cetera, are these sub-committees or families, whatever you call them in your domain, are they entirely board members?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: There’s certainly skills diversity

author: A
sentence: We have – cultural background, not so much

author: A
sentence: Certainly in terms of skills, yes

author: A
sentence: We have requirements for certain skills which must be present on a board: legal; accounting; there has to be a clinician, of some sort on the board -

author: Q
sentence: So you put in people [from outside] 00:51:56?

author: A
sentence: You can, yes

author: Q
sentence: So, is that then seen as a mechanism to test people?

author: A
sentence: Not so much test, but allow them to – see whether they’re interested

author: Q
sentence: Get a feel for it

author: A
sentence: Yes, get a feel for it, see whether they’re interested

author: Q
sentence: [Like an advert

author: A
sentence: Whether they can – yes, test in the other sense of test

author: A
sentence: Yes, to make sure they’re interested and – do people – a lot of people really don’t know what goes on in those situations

author: A
sentence: So it’s not all shouting and carrying on and making wild decisions

author: A
sentence: It’s discussing the accounts for the last finances, whatever

author: Q
sentence: Sub-committees?

author: A
sentence: Sub-committees, yes

author: A
sentence: I think – local community members who want to be involved, we find a way of involving them

author: Q
sentence: Because it’s a hospital?

author: Q
sentence: What about appointments of CEs and things like that? Giving people senior management experience? Making sure that’s a diverse – that diversity happens there

author: A
sentence: Well, that’s – the board tends not to get too much involved in the next level down, but we have – except in terms of continuity planning, succession planning – we have noted the progress of the deputy CEO in terms of their ability to step up when the CEO – I’ll just give you a quick sketch

author: A
sentence: Our CEO is seen as a shining light in the health department

author: A
sentence: Everybody loves her

author: A
sentence: The minister loved her

author: A
sentence: So another neighbouring health service found themselves suddenly without a CEO, and came to us for help and said, “Could we borrow yours for the part-time please?” because they were out of – they were in danger of not being compliant, and that’s a bad thing

author: A
sentence: So we set up something so that she is now currently the CEO of both [Karrington] 00:54:01 Health Service and [Hepburn] Health Service, which services that whole shire out there

author: A
sentence: So the deputy CEO, we created that position, and allowed the person who was director of nursing to step up into that role and to get more of a – because she had applied the previous round for CEO of our hospital, and was unsuccessful in getting that position

author: A
sentence: So there is a bit of that, but not too much of it

author: Q
sentence: Okay, and that’s – do you think in terms of diversity, or just -

author: A
sentence: It’s a bit difficult in terms of diversity, because you have to have a particular skillset to be the CEO

author: A
sentence: You have to have pretty much – you have to be either a medical administrator, or you have to be a nursing director

author: A
sentence: There’s pretty much – you don’t have too much other choice

author: A
sentence: We’re a bit constrained in that regard

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Do you send people off to courses and things with a view of helping them -

author: A
sentence: Lots of stuff

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: There are a lot of development activities for senior staff

author: Q
sentence: And a [unclear] 00:55:03 of diversity, not just gender, but -

author: A
sentence: We don’t have a lot of diversity in our senior staff

author: A
sentence: They are all females of about 50-plus

author: A
sentence: All of them

author: A
sentence: I think that’s just the way it works

author: Q
sentence: It’s the demographic

author: A
sentence: Because it’s a hospital

author: A
sentence: But you’re not allowed to have more than two clinicians, but you have to have at least one -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Nursing is very, very female-dominated, and by the time you percolate up to those positions you tend to be 50-plus, so they’re pretty much -

author: Q
sentence: In that age group

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Good, so more generally, how do you think diversity should be increased in Australian company boards?

author: A
sentence: This – is that the quota question?

author: Q2
sentence: We’ll come to that

author: Q
sentence: Yes, you can answer that one, if you want

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I personally – I prefer targets to quotas

author: A
sentence: I think – it’s a difficult question, because there are still a number of people who are incredibly resistant to any change

author: A
sentence: And so it’s difficult to know how to do that

author: A
sentence: I don’t know whether there’s an incentive that you can provide

author: A
sentence: Certainly rule changes are useful

author: A
sentence: Certainly in the state-owned sector, in state-owned entities, rule changes are very helpful

author: A
sentence: For example, the changes made to tenure – because there had been people who’d been on a board for 20, 30 years

author: A
sentence: You are never going to get change when somebody has been on a board for that -

author: Q
sentence: - for that long, yes

author: A
sentence: - the record was 43, I believe, 43 years

author: Q
sentence: Shit

author: A
sentence: Now, it was a woman

author: Q
sentence: Does it have to be a doctor?

author: Q
sentence: Was it?

author: A
sentence: She was 90-something

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: Q2
sentence: You’re kidding me

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s age diversity

author: A
sentence: Yes, they tried to get rid of her a few times, but no, she was a local legend and the community wouldn’t have it

author: A
sentence: But – so rule changes can help, because when you get those entrenched people – we were already at around 50/50

author: A
sentence: I think we were 45/55 or something, and so it helps

author: A
sentence: It absolutely can help

author: Q
sentence: It can help with demographic, but cognitive diversity?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: No, totally, it can’t

author: A
sentence: You can’t legislate for cognitive diversity

author: A
sentence: I think that’s pretty hard

author: A
sentence: It’s up to the board to do that

author: A
sentence: The board should be – as long as they’re aware of that, then they can try and select for various things that will make life better

author: Q
sentence: And quotas won’t get in the way of that

author: Q
sentence: Because you’ve said there’s only – it’s a coupling of different demographics that -

author: A
sentence: No, it doesn’t

author: A
sentence: So at the moment we have no doctors on our board

author: A
sentence: We did have, but at this certain moment we have no doctors

author: A
sentence: We have the CEO of a very large metropolitan hospital on the board, who is a – was a nurse

author: A
sentence: And we’ve got, I think, a physio

author: A
sentence: But – yes

author: A
sentence: In terms of culture, not so much

author: A
sentence: In terms of community more – we try and make sure that there’s a balance between out-of-towners, if you like, and people who live in the local – because it’s a service that services the [Macedon Ranges] 00:05:58

author: A
sentence: It’s a catchment area

author: A
sentence: So we try and have a mix of people who are local to the [Macedon Ranges], as well as a whole bunch who aren’t

author: A
sentence: Quotas – I find quotas a bit problematic for many reasons, but I can see the point behind them, because some people will not change unless you make them change

author: A
sentence: There’s that, as I said, rule changes, but maybe there are rules that are not quite so – don’t have maybe the side effects of quotas

author: Q
sentence: What might they be - the side effects of quotas?

author: Q2
sentence: A couple of the big issues -

author: A
sentence: I think you’ll end up with people on boards who are there because they want to be on a board, not because they necessarily have the right skillset or background or whatever, or somebody wants them to be on a board

author: A
sentence: There have been a lot of changes because of pushes from various groups

author: A
sentence: We get a lot of applications that come through a group called Women on Boards

author: A
sentence: We get a lot of applications

author: A
sentence: We also get a lot of applications, which are being pushed, for example, by the colleges – the medical colleges

author: A
sentence: They say, “You know, you should – you’re a senior surgeon

author: A
sentence: You should get board experience

author: A
sentence: You should go and apply for these things,” through the AICD, through board training and the AICD

author: A
sentence: So I think those are – they’re nudges

author: A
sentence: They are quite good nudges

author: A
sentence: They get a lot more people

author: A
sentence: We used to get probably fewer females applying

author: A
sentence: Now there are lots of females applying, for example

author: A
sentence: A lot of medical practitioners are applying

author: A
sentence: So those nudges I think can be helpful

author: A
sentence: But in terms of quotas I think that’s like a sledgehammer approach

author: A
sentence: It may be necessary in the corporate arena, because it’s harder to nudge businesses that the government doesn’t have much control over

author: Q
sentence: Which the government doesn’t have control over?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: It’s harder to provide those nudges

author: A
sentence: I don’t know what sort of incentives you could apply, but maybe there are some

author: A
sentence: A tax deduction, that’ll do it

author: A
sentence: That’ll do it

author: Q2
sentence: You talked about a resistance to change idea, but any other barriers – what are the other barriers or the main barriers, do you think, to increasing diversity in terms of gender, ethnicity and social – that sort of stuff?

author: A
sentence: I think – there’s resistance to change, sure, with the clubbiness of certainly the corporate world

author: A
sentence: “You’re not in the right golf club, you didn’t go to the right school, university,” whatever

author: A
sentence: There’s a barrier, because you don’t know the people

author: A
sentence: There’s no network effect for you

author: A
sentence: You don’t know the people, right? I think there’s also a tension between trying to get more skills-based boards, and increasing the diversity

author: A
sentence: Sometimes it’s hard to do both, and so you run into – if you try to do this, you’ll run into arguments from the other side, and if you try to increase the skills base and they’re all men then you’re in trouble if you try to include the gender diversity

author: A
sentence: But I think that diversity of background is really missing, because we talk about gender diversity and we talk about skills-based boards, et cetera, but there’s I think a lot of people who don’t get a look-in just because of social background, whatever their educational attainments and professional attainments, just because they don’t know the right people or because they come from a particular ethnic group

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so do you think diversity of Australian boards is important?

author: Q
sentence: So is there any way the government or your board can help with that?

author: Q2
sentence: This is a more general question, so – it’s a more general -

author: A
sentence: I don’t know

author: A
sentence: I find it difficult to believe that in Australia at the moment that anything much would change, driven by the government, just because they’ve got their own problems

author: A
sentence: They see [silly] 01:01:46 between whatever they want to do all the time

author: Q2
sentence: It’s [more of] 01:01:47 issue for them, yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, but of course, having said that of course, the issue of women in the liberal party, and in parliament in general, is actually – if they would sort that out, maybe they would provide an example for the corporate world, maybe

author: A
sentence: But -

author: Q
sentence: And the ABC

author: Q2
sentence: Would you feel differently about targets, as opposed to hard quotas?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think targets as a good thing, and the AICD has had targets for a long time, and they’ve been quite successful, hitting pretty much their – what is it? 30 per cent? I think they’re pretty much hitting those now

author: Q
sentence: Why are they successful? How does that work, do you think?

author: A
sentence: It’s just been years of nudging and carrying on, I think

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: What is it, peer pressure?

author: A
sentence: No, it’s just noise

author: Q
sentence: Just noise

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: Yes, it’s just noise

author: A
sentence: There’s been some sort of turnover and – as people have been dislodged, maybe, a little bit, from things

author: A
sentence: There’s been a woman as the chair of the AICD for a while now, but she just -

author: Q2
sentence: She’s just stepped down, in the past -

author: A
sentence: She’s stepped down, yes

author: A
sentence: She’s quite vocal about it as well

author: A
sentence: So that’s helped, I think

author: A
sentence: It’s made it seem acceptable from – she is part of big boards at the big end of town, and so she’s made it seem quite – an acceptable topic of conversation, I think, and that’s part of it

author: A
sentence: I think it’s modelling some behaviours

author: A
sentence: I think that’s probably – so targets; modelling behaviours – I think probably it’s slower, but maybe it will have a better effect in the end than quotas

author: A
sentence: Quotas might have a difficult effect, I think

author: A
sentence: Part of the problem is a couple of levels below that, because – okay, take one step back

author: A
sentence: Part of the problem is it’s the same sort of people who are appointed to Australian corporate boards – CEOs or ex-CEOs, lawyers and accountants

author: A
sentence: That’s whom you appoint

author: A
sentence: If you don’t have lots of senior women in those roles, you can’t appoint them, but you can get around that, A) by promoting more women to those senior roles, or you can start appointing different sorts of people to those boards who’ve had different sorts of experience

author: A
sentence: There are very few technology people on boards, even though that’s the subject of lots of conversations for boards

author: A
sentence: It’s about technology, about cyber-crime, about privacy issues, data, blah-blah

author: A
sentence: But there’s no technology people on boards

author: A
sentence: Nobody understands it

author: Q
sentence: Even your 30-year-olds?

author: A
sentence: They’re all right

author: Q2
sentence: It’s a lot more complex than that

author: Q
sentence: Why?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: A
sentence: But you see what I mean

author: A
sentence: You can appoint different sorts of people to the board, and/or you can promote more people to that sort of – for CEO and next level down positions

author: Q
sentence: And it will all work out -

author: A
sentence: And to – so there are people to filter up then

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So it would upstream – build downstream rather, to come up

author: Q2
sentence: I think we’ve covered the -

author: Q
sentence: We’ve done it all

author: Q2
sentence: Yes, it’s just the final -

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so the final thing

author: Q
sentence: Thank you very much

author: Q
sentence: If you have any other thoughts on board diversity and how it should be managed, that would be great

author: Q
sentence: Otherwise we’re finished

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Not really

author: A
sentence: The only thing I’d say is that depending who you’re talking to, cognitive diversity is a big topic in academia, but maybe not so much in the corporate world, maybe

author: A
sentence: It is, for the diversity of thinking that that brings, in board deliberations

author: A
sentence: But also just not in the actual deliberation, but in maybe the attitudes or determining what’s important to make a deliberation upon, and the way you go about that, I think

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Is there another word for it?

author: Q2
sentence: We’ve got it the other way actually

author: A
sentence: Have you?

author: Q2
sentence: You talk to [Jeff Sozena] 01:05:37, for example – I can assure you, in the academic thing the big issue is around the gender and that sort of stuff, right? Because, to be honest, let’s call it skills diversity – that’s always been there – but the matrixes are there, of the AICD, because they’ve got the templates, et cetera

author: Q2
sentence: I think that’s so understood, and it is [unclear] 01:06:10

author: A
sentence: Sort of, but I don’t think it’s acted on

author: A
sentence: There are a lot of people with the same – it’s not just skills, but it’s also – it’s background

author: Q2
sentence: No, no, sorry, I’m not talking about – we’re interested in that sort of diversity primarily, in this study

author: Q2
sentence: I’m not talking about those issues

author: Q2
sentence: Agreed

author: Q2
sentence: That’s off

author: Q2
sentence: Right? That’s not happening

author: Q2
sentence: There’s no dispute there

author: Q2
sentence: What I’m essentially saying – the interview is over -

author: A
sentence: You can turn it off?

author: Q
sentence: Will I turn it off?

author: Q2
sentence: No, I’m not going to say anything too outrageous – what I’m trying to say is that we need at least one accountant, one lawyer, one clinician, if it’s a hospital, or one marketer if it’s a real [unclear] 01:06:57 or whatever

author: Q2
sentence: That sort of thing is well established

author: Q2
sentence: There are matrixes for that, et cetera

author: Q2
sentence: I think the response we get from a lot of corporates when you just say, “Gender diversity,” or, “Diversity,” they say, “Well, all that is nice

author: Q2
sentence: What’s really, really important is this cognitive diversity,” i

author: Q2
sentence: e

author: Q2
sentence: , the sort of thing I’m describing

author: Q2
sentence: They arrive in their role and that’s -

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think sometimes that’s a -

author: Q2
sentence: Can I just – a quick follow up on that – you talked about skills diversity, and clearly that will bring a diversity of thinking

author: Q2
sentence: But do you feel that some of the other markers of diversity, which newspapers love – gender being the big one – but possibly cultural, ethnic, socioeconomic, age – do you think that that does the same?

author: Q
sentence: -@ excuse?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: It’s about making – everybody’s diverse – if you cast everybody as diverse, it has a different effect than saying there’s a group here or a group there

author: A
sentence: It’s, “Everybody as an individual is diverse,” which is true, and that’s what I was saying – there’s an intersection of all these different things

author: A
sentence: But sometimes it’s a bit of an excuse to say, “Well, we -”

author: Q2
sentence: No, but it’s complex because, for example, if – we’re now just straying away, but if for example we said, “Why is gender important?” because the sight theory, which essentially talks about, as an average, men thinking differently from women, et cetera – however, if you had this marvellously gender diverse board, which was five and five, and you have five Margaret Thatchers sitting on the board, well, I’m not sure

author: A
sentence: They’d kill each other, those board people

author: Q2
sentence: No, but I’m not sure that that is real diversity

author: A
sentence: No, it’s not

author: A
sentence: That’s what I was saying

author: Q2
sentence: She was a product of her time

author: Q2
sentence: She was a – her – from everything you could see, she had a very male orientation, in a lot of what she did

author: A
