sentence: But also I think if you – again, if you only appoint CEOs or former CEOs to the board, those people have had to fight their way up that ladder to get there

author: A
sentence: They’re going to be very similar in a lot of ways

author: A
sentence: You don’t get to be the CEO of a large company without being aggressive, to some extent, without being willing to do the dirty deeds that you need to get done

author: A
sentence: So I think – yes, it’s more than that

author: A
sentence: You have to – but -

author: Q2
sentence: I think the point you made earlier about the overlapping sets, the intersections being important, I think is a good one

author: Q2
sentence: Because yes, if you’ve got two females who’ve – or a male and a female who’ve gone to Scotch and PLC, similar backgrounds, Melbourne Law School, did their four years with [unclear] 01:09:47 -

author: A
sentence: Not that one

author: Q
sentence: Okay, perfect

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so there’s a lot of talk about board diversity, but we’re interested to hear from people like you who are actually sitting on boards

author: Q
sentence: Let’s start by hearing about what you understand board diversity to mean

author: A
sentence: Yes, it does, and that’s why I’m – that’s why I think some of the current conversations around gender diversity are not particularly useful, because – I’m just going to pick an example

author: A
sentence: If you pick two women who have been to school at PLC Melbourne to replace two men who’ve been to Scotch at Melbourne, and have also all gone to Melbourne Law School, then the diversity of thought is not necessarily there

author: A
sentence: You’ve flipped genders, but – the point of it – there’s two points to diversity, I think

author: A
sentence: One is that it brings diversity of thought and approaches, et cetera

author: A
sentence: But also, to some extent, you want to have some reflection of your community for an organisation such as this one, because you’re there to serve the community

author: Q2
sentence: That’s a [unclear] 01:09:52 - like [Glad news] 01:09:54 or – [no news] 01:09:55 is better

author: Q2
sentence: Then you’re going to end up with a very similar beast at the end of it

author: A
sentence: I think so, yes

author: Q
sentence: Hold on, can I just clarify – what’s come to me with this interview, you’ve got cognitive diversity here, then you’ve got all this demographic diversity

author: Q
sentence: Now, you said, “Well, you can’t – gender alone is not going to cut it, but if you have gender and you have social background, and CEO experience, [or not a word about] 01:10:26 then that’s where you start to get cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: ” So you can say, “Yes, this will be – this person will think different -”

author: A
sentence: You can’t predict it, I don’t think

author: Q
sentence: “- to another person who’s got a different group of demographic

author: A
sentence: Maybe

author: Q2
sentence: I’m not sure that’s what [the participant]  said, because by and large, when cognitive diversity – weren’t you talking about skills plus a style of thinking?

author: A
sentence: All of the above

author: A
sentence: That was actually my original question when I said about academic and business, is – the point I was going to make was maybe you need to define what you mean by cognitive diversity, as opposed to other – because I’m going on – I’m pretty much – I think I started off talking about skills and experiences and yada yada, but it’s also those other things as well

author: A
sentence: And so because your socioeconomic background, religious background, ethnic background, all plays into the way you think about things, to quite fundamental levels

author: A
sentence: If you have a same-sex partner, for example, you might be thinking about those sort of discussions in a very different way to not, no matter whether you’re an accountant or a lawyer or whatever

author: A
sentence: So I think you – yes

author: A
sentence: So to me there’s a bit of – what’s the definition? To me, cognitive diversity is thinking – a diversity of the way you think

author: A
sentence: But then again you can bring that down to, is everybody’s – none of the three of us think the same way about probably a lot of things, and so – I think it’s more – what’s the word I’m trying to find

author: A
sentence: It’s much more fuzzy, I think, than just “it’s either that or that”

author: A
sentence: I think it’s a bit of – there are probabilities and overlaps and fuzziness

author: A
sentence: So if we were both accountants we probably will think about some things in a similar way, but if I grew up in Tanzania and you grew up in Sweden then we’d probably think about other things in different ways

author: A
sentence: But yes -

author: Q
sentence: [unclear] 01:12:45

author: A
sentence: So if they don’t see some sort of reflection of their own community – now, it turns out that the [Macedon Ranges] community is 90-something per cent Caucasian, so that’s what makes up the board too

author: A
sentence: We have no ethnic diversity -

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s just not that -

author: Q
sentence: -@ compartmentalised

author: A
sentence: But I think both things are important for a board – people that can bring something in terms of the discussion, and that comes from cognitive diversity

author: A
sentence: Whether that’s engendered by your gender or your experiences or whatever – but also it is – a board is the, along with the CEOs, the big shiny thing on top of the building, right? It’s like this is what everybody sees and says, “Hey, look at these people

author: A
sentence: This is the top of the tree

author: A
sentence: ” So to some extent you want them to be reflective of whatever community it is – whether that’s people that work there, or the wider community, or whatever, or the professions, whatever – but also to set some sort of an example

author: A
sentence: Because if the board is – and that’s one of the things, for example, I set students in the class, is – we were talking about diversity issues, and gender diversity and age diversity – but one of the conditions that I set is that the board is currently all male, all over 60, right? So nearly all the students say, “Well, the first thing you have to do is the board has to think about itself

author: A
sentence: How can you be telling everybody else that they should be hiring this way or doing this without eating your own dog food?” – as the Americans like to say

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Thank you very much

author: Q
sentence: -@ in the community

author: A
sentence: On the board

author: A
sentence: There’s not much in the community

author: A
sentence: I mean, about as exotic as it gets is people from Scandinavia

author: A
sentence: That’s about – there’s a few – maybe five per cent of people are from elsewhere, but a lot of them are Australian-born, and those who aren’t Australian-born are English, New Zealand – yes – and Northern Europe, yes

author: Q
sentence: So do you think if the community was more diverse, like perhaps a hospital network in Sunshine, for example, would the government be looking for more cultural diversity in that situation?

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure

author: A
sentence: I’m not sure what the government is looking for at any particular time

author: A
sentence: It changes – when you change minister – we have just changed minister, so I’m not sure what the new minister is looking for

author: A
sentence: But I believe she was, at some stage, minister for multiculturalism, so who knows? But I personally believe that’s a good idea then, to be a little bit more reflective of your community

author: A
sentence: So you should be there to serve the community, but also be of the community, to some extent

author: A
sentence: I think that’s helpful with engaging with the community when people who have the ultimate signing authority for things kind of look like at least some of them – look like the community

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that’s particularly important because it’s health? Would it be the same if it was selling – if it was tyres?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think it is particularly important because it’s health, because it’s a service to the community

author: A
sentence: It’s very much a part of the community

author: A
sentence: Certainly up our way there would be a huge human cry if you started trying to close down the hospital, just because it’s part of the community

author: A
sentence: It’s part of the community identity that there is such a thing, and it’s been there –it’s the second oldest public hospital in Victoria, in fact, after Melbourne, I think

author: A
sentence: So yes

author: A
sentence: I think in the commercial context, often that reflection of your customer base is a little bit – it’s a bit tokenistic sometimes, rather than being real

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: But I do think it’s more important in something like health than selling tyres, yes

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it might be important if you were – you’re in public health, but let’s say you were in private health and exporting services, say, overseas

author: Q
sentence: Do you think you would want your board to reflect your potential -

author: A
sentence: -@ overseas client?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I’ll give you a couple of different takes on it, maybe

author: A
sentence: In terms of the board that I sit on, we have requirements for diversity, because it’s a state-owned entity

author: A
sentence: Other than that, a lot of the chatter around board diversity is around increasing gender parity on boards, and not quite as much on other dimensions of diversity

author: A
sentence: That’s probably where most of the conversation comes in, for me, and with perhaps the exception of youth – a bit of diversity in terms of age range, because boards tend to be over 60, generally

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily

author: A
sentence: I think you’d need to have people who understood that market, but part of the reason that people would be coming to buy those services is because it’s of the local expertise side of thing

author: A
sentence: You have to be careful not to dilute that

author: A
sentence: Maybe to some extent, but yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so expertise is another really important thing on your board, to preserve that, and that’s technical as well, is it? Or just your financial, legal -?

author: A
sentence: Well, definitely the financial, because life in a public health authority is always driven by the dollars that are available

author: A
sentence: But no, we have clinical expertise and we have legal expertise and we have other – and also board expertise is actually – is quite sought-after

author: Q
sentence: What does that look like?

author: A
sentence: Just people who have had experience on boards, or as senior executives

author: A
sentence: That’s one of the criteria that we look at, is that success in professional life, outside of this

author: A
sentence: These used to be voluntary positions

author: A
sentence: They’re now paid, on a sessional basis, but you’re not going to – you’re not going to buy yourself a new Mercedes from it

author: A
sentence: So when it was voluntary, that was definitely the case, that you’ve got something to offer

author: A
sentence: But board expertise or senior executive expertise was always sought-after

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so do you cultivate that expertise in your community by some way, to people within your community?

author: A
sentence: Not as much as we should probably

author: A
sentence: There’s been talk about it, but no more than talk, I think

author: A
sentence: We have gone a little ways in terms of inviting external people onto the committees of the board to sit as external members of us

author: A
sentence: So for example we have a local accountant on the audit and risk committee, and we have a consumer and – what’s it called? Something consumer advisory committee, and there are lots of external people that sit on that from the community

author: A
sentence: So that’s the way we, at some stage, the last time we had that conversation, have decided to approach that – it’s by bringing people into committees and giving them some experience on how does a board committee work, and then that’s the way of giving them some board experience

author: A
sentence: Mind you, we have people on that consumer advisory committee who have had long – who are retired, and have had very long experience themselves as chairs of boards of various sorts – community organisations up to fairly large commercial concerns

author: A
sentence: They come back when they want to contribute something

author: A
sentence: Members of parliament – they usually get a gong when those – they have one

author: A
sentence: We only have one of those

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So they get on your boards and -

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you say it’s a state-run one, so what proportion of your board would be female?

author: A
sentence: The larger public hospital boards tend to get many more political appointments, because they’re more in the public eye, so the Royal Melbourne and even Bendigo Hospital has one or two – it might even be two ex-health ministers on them, [unclear] 00:14:53

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so would there be political diversity between them? Like one’s from labour, one’s from -?

author: A
sentence: Yes, it depends who’s in power at the time, yes, at the time of appointment

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: The person who was – he was a member of the Victorian Upper House, he was deputy speaker I think, at one stage, and was on our board

author: A
sentence: He’s been there – he was appointed by a liberal health minister and has been reappointed by labour health ministers

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if there’s too much of that going on, I don’t think

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Does the network they bring benefit the board?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: How? Can you tell me?

author: A
sentence: Of parliamentarians, do you mean?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: How does that work?

author: A
sentence: Because it’s the way that government works seems to be quite different to the way the rest of the world works

author: A
sentence: So those with parliamentary experience certainly – and definitely have had government experience – it’s kind of a – they seem to understand how things will work

author: A
sentence: We’ve got merger talks that we’ve put off now because of the state election that was, for example, and it was like, “What do you think?” But they also have networks and so we’ve spoken to – we’ve spoke to the current member of parliament for the region, as well as the opposition candidate, and a member of parliament from the other party, from a neighbouring region, et cetera, because of those networks

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so they understand the culture, they understand the rules -?

author: A
sentence: We have – at the moment we have 12 board members, of whom seven are female, and five male

author: A
sentence: It was the other way around – it was five and seven, and then it went to six and six, and this last round has been – so it’s -

author: A
sentence: What’s likely to fly and what’s likely not to fly, and how would you couch it in order that it should fly

author: A
sentence: So there’s two different parts to that

author: A
sentence: One is how would it fly with the department

author: A
sentence: So we’ve got people with health department experience, and also how would it fly in the ministerial world

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Well, that’s very important for a public hospital

author: Q
sentence: It’s very strategic

author: Q2
sentence: Just getting back to board diversity issues, we’ve talked a bit about positive impacts, in [terms of] 00:16:55 diversity on [clinician] 00:15:59 performance, et cetera

author: Q2
sentence: Do you feel that board diversity can negatively impact performance?

author: A
sentence: Yes, sure it can

author: Q
sentence: And how might this happen? Can you give me an example?

author: A
sentence: It can happen when the diversity is predicated, for example, on the political side, but also really deeply held beliefs

author: A
sentence: The most robust conversation we’ve had so far as a board – I’m assuming this is all confidential, by the way?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: It’s around the same sex marriage bill, and should the hospital, as an entity, say anything? Say nothing? If so, what? Because it was felt that it was a public health issue for mental health reasons, for example, that we should maybe say something

author: A
sentence: But that was probably the longest and most contentious debate the board has had

author: A
sentence: There were views that were quite polar opposites

author: A
sentence: So that’s okay if you are able to work to a consensus view

author: A
sentence: If you work to a consensus view and neither that side nor that side is happy with it, maybe that’s not so useful, because the board has to speak as one

author: A
sentence: So, that’s where diversity can get in the way, I guess, if you like, on the more deeply felt, deeply held issues

author: A
sentence: I think there’s also – it can lead to process conflict, where people are deciding how to go about something

author: A
sentence: I think I’ve found that mostly with age differences – of how you should go about things, or direct action, or perhaps a little bit more sit back and not do so much and let things take their course

author: A
sentence: It can get in the way, but as I said, I think there’s probably been one occasion where it’s gotten to a quite heated, robust conversation

author: A
sentence: But our chair is pretty good at controlling those

author: Q
sentence: How does the chair manage that sort of conflict?

author: Q2
sentence: And the requirements for diversity is entirely round gender?

author: A
sentence: Well, it’s a very well behaved board in the first place

author: A
sentence: It’s not very formal, at times, but quite well behaved

author: A
sentence: People listen to each other, and I think because it was that sort of background it was easier for the chair to say, “Okay, we’ve heard that now

author: A
sentence: We’re going to move onto the next person,” or, “We’ve talked this one to death

author: A
sentence: Let’s do something else

author: A
sentence: ” So there’s a couple of ways, in terms of the content of things, or the way you go about things, then diversity can be problematic

author: A
sentence: I think the other way too is where there is a diversity of one

author: A
sentence: So if there’s one person who’s not of one type – so I think then what happens is that person will either constantly be at odds with everybody else, or they’ll just shut down and won’t say anything

author: A
sentence: They just won’t speak up, because maybe they think that they’re just going to get overruled anyway, so what’s the point?

author: Q
sentence: That’s a really good – that one comes out in a process question

author: Q
sentence: We’ll go to that and then go back, I think

author: Q
sentence: Here: can you think of any ways that boards can help directors from minority groups to feel part of the board and to feel free to fully participate in decision-making?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think you need at least two people

author: A
sentence: If you have an all-male board and you appoint one woman you’re probably not going to get as much out of that appointment as if you’d appointed two

author: A
sentence: I think

author: Q
sentence: But if we’re talking about – back to the marriage one – if you’re talking about, say, sexual identity, if you think of the very different – many ways that we can have diversity: gender; age; socioeconomic; cultural; sexual orientation – if we have two of everything, you’re going to have a very big [ship] 00:21:29

author: A
sentence: No, no, I’m not saying you have to have two of everything, but you shouldn’t have isolates, I think

author: A
sentence: That’s what I’m saying

author: A
sentence: If you are deliberately trying to make your board more diverse then a token appointment of one may be -

author: Q
sentence: And have everyone else the same, you mean?

author: A
sentence: The other thing too – and look, I’m speaking from maybe some other knowledge as well as being on the board – but when you start getting coalitions going, it can be really problematic

author: A
sentence: You can see that, even on our board, which as I said is a very, very well behaved board

author: A
sentence: But you can see coalitions forming around certain things

author: A
sentence: When there’s more than one – where they form around more than one characteristic – so let’s say if it’s around younger – if there’s younger and female, you can see – it’s a much stronger coalition than if it was just females or just younger, and a male/female mix

author: A
sentence: As it happens, both of the younger members are in fact female, and so you do see a bit of that coalition forming

author: Q
sentence: Yes, so do you see that as a problem?

author: A
sentence: It’s only a problem if it’s unchecked, I think

author: A
sentence: If it becomes – it can become a problem, I’m sure, but it isn’t a problem at the moment

author: A
sentence: As I said, the chair is pretty good at making sure everybody is heard

author: A
sentence: That includes, in our case, we have – our CEO is not a member of the board

author: A
sentence: They report to the board

author: A
sentence: We have a CEO and a deputy CEO, and usually the director of corporate services sitting at the board meetings

author: A
sentence: So they’re included

author: A
sentence: So when we ask people’s opinions, their opinions are included as well

author: A
sentence: The decision is the board’s to make, but they’re not excluded from the conversation

author: A
sentence: We do have executive sessions, or in-camera sessions at the end, where there’s no staff present, but – yes, I think the chair is pretty good at managing that and making sure everybody’s heard

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So when – to come to a decision then where there’s been – there’s lots of different views, does it have to be a consensus? Is it voted – how does the chair manage the resolution?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: A
sentence: The formal requirements for diversity is around gender parity – achieving gender parity, to the extent that when we interview for new board members, the candidates that we put to the minister must be equal numbers male and female

author: A
sentence: It’s usually consensus

author: A
sentence: Usually we come to a consensus view

author: A
sentence: If it looks like it’s coming to a vote we usually see if there’s any way of recasting that so there’s something that everybody could buy into, rather than – I don’t think there’s been a point yet where it’s come to a vote and stayed that way

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so that would be seen as a bit of a failure, as a risk, on something?

author: A
sentence: I don’t know if it would be seen as a failure

author: A
sentence: It would certainly be very unusual and make people think as to why this has happened, because yes, it’s unusual enough

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the marriage one, what happened there? What was the outcome?

author: A
sentence: We came to a – yes, we came to a consensus decision about what the – that we would just stick to the medical facts and that there are other agencies who are more skilled at this, and we’ve taken – the local community health organisation for example put out quite a strong statement, as did the [Baker – it wasn’t the Baker institute] 00:25:05 – it was one of those institutes that’s out there at the Alfred there anyway

author: A
sentence: But they put together quite a strong statement, and we took pieces from that and said, “Look, medically, blah-blah, this is a concern, and by the way if you are concerned, here are some numbers to call, but this is our take on it, that we just want people to interact respectfully about this

author: Q
sentence: And use those resources

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Great

author: Q
sentence: That’s good, so now we’ll move onto process

author: Q
sentence: How does diversity influence your board’s functioning? You’ve described a little bit there about conflict

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that the different kinds of diversity, like gender, might influence things differently to age, differently to social background, differently to ethnicity? Like -?

author: A
sentence: In terms of process?

author: Q
sentence: In terms of board process, yes

author: Q
sentence: The board’s functioning

author: A
sentence: I think it does

author: A
sentence: I think different sorts of people have different preferences in terms of discussions and deliberations

author: A
sentence: So that makes – I think that makes a difference

author: A
sentence: If you get a group of 50-year-old, or 60-year old men, of which I’m part of that group, together, there are a lot of statements

author: A
sentence: So I think female board members tend to maybe ask more questions that aren’t quite as pointed – more open-ended questions maybe that aren’t as, “What is the answer to this?” It’s more of a, “What could we do?” or, “Is there a way of -?” something

author: A
sentence: So I think that makes a difference

author: A
sentence: I’m sure there are cultural differences too, but as I said, ours is not a very multicultural board

author: Q
sentence: Yes, and the age difference -

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Do they make the final choice?

author: A
sentence: I think age – yes, it does

author: A
sentence: I think the younger members of our board are definitely more gung-ho about things, maybe

author: A
sentence: They’re not quite as maybe measured sometimes, as some of the older ones, who’ve -

author: Q
sentence: How does that work in the group, say for strategy or something?

author: A
sentence: I think it balances itself out

author: A
sentence: Where we’ve had – we have – annual, at least, but they’ve been actually more often, because we’ve been having these talks about the merger, et cetera – strategy away days, et cetera – they’ve been facilitated quite well

author: A
sentence: I think that’s been important

author: A
sentence: Again, staff have been included, so executive staff have been included in those, and so the conversations get a bit broader and you’re mixed up, and so there’s – the facilitation, I think, makes a big difference to that sort of thing, for those strategic kind of conversations

author: Q
sentence: Can you – this facilitation idea is so key to what you’ve talked about with conflict, and now with strategy

author: Q
sentence: Can you unpack that a little for us?

author: A
sentence: Well, in terms of the board, obviously, but the chair – that’s one of the – a good chair, in my opinion, anyway, should be a facilitator as much as anything

author: A
sentence: They should aim to get the most out of all, and maybe a little less from some, and maybe a little bit more from others

author: A
sentence: That’s one of their key roles, I think, is to shape the conversation but also to make sure that everybody has had a chance to have their say

author: A
sentence: In a strategy day context, that looks a lot different, but it’s about, again, making sure that there’s no people dominating

author: A
sentence: There’s no – whether that’s the chair or the CEO or whoever else dominating

author: A
sentence: We have a couple of quite strongly opinionated board members, but – so that nobody dominates

author: A
sentence: So you have to do that by blending things in the right way

author: A
sentence: So I think facilitation is key to all of that, and certainly at the board level as well, you have to – At the committee level – the board committee level, there’s not as much of that that goes on, and so the conversations are maybe a little bit more one-sided, or a little blunter, maybe, sometimes

author: Q2
sentence: So things like your strategy or whatever, presumably there’s some element of some external facilitation?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q2
sentence: Yes, so that kind of helps

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: So whether it’s – I think last time – who was it last time? PWC or somebody, yes

author: A
sentence: Yes, absolutely

author: A
sentence: Having a neutral third part, I think, is -

author: Q
sentence: Okay Participant 40D, thank you so much for agreeing to participate in the research on diversity of Australian boards

author: Q
sentence: As you're aware, there's quite a bit of research in the area

author: Q
sentence: But what we're particularly interested in is the Australian perspective

author: Q
sentence: We're interviewing Australian directors of companies and organisations that influence Australian boards

author: Q
sentence: We're gathering data from the field and we're working from the ground up to develop a model to understand how diversity is understood here and how it's managed

author: Q
sentence: So that's basically it

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Then once I went overseas in 2006 - so then there was some foreign boards as well

author: A
sentence: There was, again, I suppose you'd probably call it a listed investment company that was NYSE - so New York Stock Exchange listed that I was on for a number of years called Invesco Mortgage Capital

author: A
sentence: I was on a number of - and chair of a lot of different Invesco what you'd think of was really internal boards rather than external boards

author: A
sentence: But then, towards the end, I was actually chairman of - I should have got them to take that - can I steal your -

author: A
sentence: In fact, it goes all the way back to what I was saying before

author: A
sentence: That the boards, in fact, are typically going to be trying to appoint people that are like them

author: A
sentence: So they're not truly looking for - I don't think they're actually looking for true diversity

author: Q
sentence: What do you think holds boards in that pattern of not looking for diversity as you've defined it?

author: A
sentence: It goes back to your comfort zone; that you're going to feel more comfortable if you've got people around the table that are like you

author: A
sentence: We tend to group ourselves together with people who are like minded and who think like us

author: A
sentence: We only have to see the extreme nonsense that's, unfortunately, been the consequence of the internet - with the way that we've all gotten our little tribes and stuff - that people feel comfortable in that

author: A
sentence: So that's always going to be the way

author: A
sentence: That’s your natural inclination is to be - is to have people around you that are like you

author: A
sentence: And if you're an executive and you're hiring people, you've got to always work hard to push back against your natural inclination, which is to employ someone like you

author: Q
sentence: That's right

author: Q
sentence: Is it an unconscious bias or a conscious bias?

author: A
sentence: That's what I think

author: A
sentence: I think it's a really strong unconscious bias

author: A
sentence: Then partially, it's going to be conscious as well

author: A
sentence: So to actually force yourself out of your comfort zone and to go to - to get people who are truly different is actually not easy to achieve

author: A
sentence: Then you go to the boards - and you get to the point of knowing the board, to be effective, they're probably going to have to work well together, etcetera

author: A
sentence: So as soon as you've - and I've certainly seen people who come onto boards and don't work effectively

author: Q
sentence: Is that because of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Interestingly, it's less about that, honestly, than oftentimes, these are people who don't understand how a board dynamic works

author: A
sentence: In other words - and are not, therefore, able to figure out how to influence outcomes and decisions the way they would like

author: A
sentence: In other words -

author: Q
sentence: So what's the board dynamic that people have to learn to work with?

author: A
sentence: Well you have to learn that - a lot of people struggle - it's very hard for a lot of people to make the transition from management and exec - particularly being CEO - to a board

author: A
sentence: Because if you're the executive, you've been used to - if you're a bad manager, which a lot of them are - of being - just telling people what to do

author: A
sentence: [Laugh][overtalking] 00:31:28 -

author: Q
sentence: [Overtalking] 00:31:28

author: Q
sentence: This? Yeah, sure

author: A
sentence: What I call the old school command and control type manager

author: A
sentence: And all joking aside; you would see a lot of them in academia

author: Q
sentence: Oh definitely

author: Q
sentence: Definitely

author: A
sentence: You've got a lot - no disrespect, but a lot of academics have very high IQ; they have zero EQ

author: Q
sentence: It's very hierarchical

author: A
sentence: Sorry, that's a bit harsh

author: A
sentence: But you know what I mean

author: A
sentence: So it's the people with the low EQ skills that are the ones that are really going to struggle around the board table

author: A
sentence: Because they come around - they're not understanding how the board dynamic works

author: A
sentence: They're not understanding that, just because - they may think they're the smartest person around the table - which is always sad when you have people like that

author: A
sentence: But they may think they're very smart

author: A
sentence: They may think they're most knowledgeable on a particular topic so, therefore, people should just do what they're saying

author: A
sentence: It's like, well that's fine, but that's not the way it works

author: A
sentence: You've got to understand that dynamic; ie

author: A
sentence: Who are the different people around the table? What is the - what are the things that influence them? In other words, you've got to have - to be effective - so we go back to my comment about you've got to understand the industry, be knowledgeable about it and the company's business model, etcetera

author: A
sentence: But if you're going to be an effective board member, you then next need to have good EQ skills so that you know how to get your view across

author: Q
sentence: Let's say the organisation that you're working in - your board of - like you're at the board - is a very hierarchical organisation

author: Q
sentence: Should the board dynamics reflect that of the organisation or - Do you know what I mean? Let's say it's a very old fashioned, command and control model in the organisation and the board is trying to do - work the model that you're talking about where people are engaging more as a team - in that dynamic

author: Q
sentence: Is that a mismatch between the two? Will that board try and transform the organisation? Is there any connection between these - the tone of the two levels of the organisation?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, good point

author: A
sentence: I'd go backwards and say that the board's primary task is to do its job well and to be as effective as it can be

author: A
sentence: So if it makes a decision that the way to do it is to act in - it's pretty hard to be command and control around a board table

author: A
sentence: But I've seen chairs try to do that

author: A
sentence: The ones that are - you can imagine being on a board with Donald Trump as your chair; it would be a nightmare

author: A
sentence: So what happens in that sort of scenario is the people who may want to be expressing a different opinion - if you have a really dominating chair, they're just going to leave

author: A
sentence: They'll just leave

author: A
sentence: So you end up - you can end up with it -

author: A
sentence: Is that good for the organisation? I'd say absolutely not

author: A
sentence: Because you're not going to have - that means you don't have an effective board because you've got it dominated by an individual or two

author: A
sentence: That's certainly not going to help an organisation which may already, if you've described it correctly, is controlled that way

author: A
sentence: So that's going to be pretty close to a lose-lose, I would have thought

author: Q
sentence: Is there anything in Australia in the context that would prevent that happening? I presume you haven't actually seen it here in Australia

author: A
sentence: Was chairman of what we called Invesco UK, I suppose it would have been, or Invesco Perpetual

author: A
sentence: This was the ultimate entity of the UK organisation that had two external directors

author: A
sentence: It was the entity that the local regulators and so on wanted to be the primary board for the UK in particular, but also the - well the UK more than the European

author: A
sentence: Because post the financial crisis, the regulators, globally, got very hung up about reporting lines and independence of local groups vis-à-vis parents

author: A
sentence: I'm sure there's boards out there that are like that

author: A
sentence: I haven't [overtalking] 00:34:53

author: Q
sentence: You haven't [overtalking] 00:34:53

author: Q
sentence: So there's nothing in the regulatory environment or in our cultural environment that would prevent that kind of tyranny at a board level

author: A
sentence: Tyranny

author: A
sentence: I think Australians, we pride ourselves on being independent and all that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: We're not quite as far out of the spectrum as the Texans are, but we think we are

author: A
sentence: That would help a little bit

author: A
sentence: But experience tells me that the tone from the top - and we're now getting into cultural issues rather than diversity issues, which I think are -

author: Q
sentence: Is it different? Because [overtalking] 00:35:33 -

author: A
sentence: No, I don't know that they are

author: A
sentence: Because the culture -

author: Q
sentence: - background was part of -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, culture - I think board culture and organisation culture's absolutely critical

author: A
sentence: One of the pre-conditions from having a decent organisational culture is that you've got the right way in which people - so you don't have this - the tone is set from the top

author: A
sentence: Maybe put it in positives rather than negatives

author: A
sentence: The tone is absolutely set from the top

author: A
sentence: So if you've got the tone from the top which is a command and control; that is going to - that will - to greater or lesser degrees, will run through the board and has the potential to run through the organisation

author: A
sentence: I don't think - it's not one for one

author: A
sentence: The board cannot - you know, can I have a different way of operating relative to the organisation and vice versa

author: A
sentence: But the tone from the top in the management team will be set absolutely by the CEO

author: A
sentence: And that man or woman has a staggering amount of control, frankly, over what the organisation's going to look like culturally

author: Q
sentence: But the chair - the board can sack the CEO if they're not happy

author: Q
sentence: So there's that link

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: So that gets then to - precisely

author: A
sentence: So if you get - and this is something that's problematic for boards is getting to the point where you've got a - if you have a CEO - just a simple example

author: A
sentence: [Inaudible] 00:37:00 you've got a CEO who's delivering good business results - and by that, I'll define it as good results for shareholders, for staff and for clients or customers

author: A
sentence: So imagine that the weird world that they're doing all three and actually thinking about all three

author: A
sentence: You can imagine someone who's doing that, but is not doing it in a way that the board thinks is well aligned culturally with the sort of organisation they'd like to have

author: A
sentence: Where you've got someone who's delivering results but failing on the cultural side; they find it really hard to make the decision that they have to, which is, “You know what? We haven't got the right person

author: A
sentence: ” They find that really hard

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: That would be hard

author: A
sentence: Because I don't know if you remember with - the big issue was Lehman Brothers went broke

author: A
sentence: When Lehman Brothers went broke, basically what - sorry, what they ended up doing was they shunted a lot of money out of their UK and European subsidiaries back to the US to try and support the US business

author: A
sentence: So that meant that when the thing went belly up, it was not just the parent and the US entities, but also the UK and European ones went because they'd basically funnelled all the money out of them

author: A
sentence: So the regulators then became paranoid about the independence of local boards

author: A
sentence: And ditto within a board context

author: A
sentence: It gets really hard that, if you have someone who's behaving around the table in a way that's not culturally aligned with the way the board would like to behave, the same thing applies

author: A
sentence: It's oftentimes that - that's one thing I've noticed

author: A
sentence: It's really - boards find it really difficult to have the - so it falls to the chair - for the chair to talk to the board member and say, look, that behaviour is just not acceptable

author: A
sentence: We don't expect to see that anymore around the table

author: A
sentence: Or more to the point, to get to the point ultimately of saying, you know what, Fred? You're really not behaving - you're not being the sort of contributor that we need

author: A
sentence: You really should not - we're not going to support you standing at the next re-election or you should stand down or something

author: A
sentence: To have that tough conversation is - it doesn't often happen

author: Q
sentence: Yet that kind of conversation seems to me would be essential in - to ensure inclusivity -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Because it's the soft stuff - the EQ you're really talking about

author: Q
sentence: Because they're doing the task well -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: Because if you've got these strong people around the table, it means that people who may have a - will feel threatened - they'll feel - threatened too strong

author: A
sentence: They'll find it hard to speak up

author: A
sentence: You've got to have an environment which is - the chair in particular has got to create an environment where the members of the board feel safe to - feel it's safe to speak up

author: Q
sentence: Thank you for that

author: Q
sentence: Can you give me an example of how diversity of thought or perspective influences board functioning? Like how it's - can you give me an example - an Australian context one?

author: A
sentence: I hadn't thought about that one

author: A
sentence: [Long pause] okay, so one that's maybe close to home is that we've been thinking, in A superannuation fund, about what the default [long pause] fund should be

author: A
sentence: You know, should it be this defined benefit or a different one? I think it's fair to say that if it was only the views of people like myself and Ian, who've got a very strong, pure investment background, we would have gone pretty strongly down one track

author: A
sentence: But it was the views of some of the others and, in particular, some of the academics and the people representing the academic staff, and the university and the unions and whatever – say, well, yeah, look, we hear that, but you're not really putting enough of a premium on this risk and the - what we'd call an uncertainty premium in our [minds] 00:40:31

author: A
sentence: In other words, the big advantage of the defined benefit is that it's giving the people who've got it some certainty as to what their retirement income looks like

author: A
sentence: So what I'm saying is that for those of us who are the pure investment people, we'd go down the track of saying, the optimal investment outcomes is probably going to actually be - if we did - and we have done

author: A
sentence: We've done [Monte Carlo] 00:40:51 simulations, running out 20, 30 - you know, done all that sort of stuff that you do and you've got your -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: [Overtalking] 00:40:56 -

author: A
sentence: Then it's like, see, this is going to be on net-net, on average, on balance, majority of people are going to be better off with this than that

author: A
sentence: And it's like, well yeah, we hear that, but

author: A
sentence: So that's an example where people with a different frame of reference and a different perspective - we're going to therefore lead to the board to come to a conclusion which maybe you wouldn't have thought of to start with

author: A
sentence: I've been typically on the industry associations where - I was on the industry funds management industry association here in Australia

author: A
sentence: Again, that would have been back in the '90s - later part of the '90s

author: A
sentence: And was on the equivalent - not in the US, because they didn't really have one

author: A
sentence: But was on the equivalent in the UK in those last years

author: A
sentence: So that would have been '15 - '14, '15, '16 type timeframe

author: A
sentence: I didn't bring my CV, but there was quite a - there were some others as well

author: Q
sentence: That's a really good example

author: Q
sentence: Thank you

author: Q
sentence: And it works really well with the definition of how you understand diversity, which is great

author: Q
sentence: [Long pause] the example you gave - have you experienced or - have you experienced conflict - because of these different perspectives, conflict -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: This is where the chair plays a key role to manage this

author: A
sentence: Because you absolutely have conflict because, hopefully, you've got people who are quite passionate about what they're doing, so they are going to have sometimes strongly held views on this

author: A
sentence: So it can be quite the challenge for the chair - and hopefully supported by other members of the board - to say everybody's got to have their turn

author: A
sentence: Everybody's got to be able to say their piece and try and have those views listened to

author: A
sentence: And try and - and the role of the chair is, to me, to - particularly for people who might not be experts in the field

author: A
sentence: If they're trying to express a view - to help them express it in a way that is understood by the experts - in a way that's helpful for changing or influencing opinion - because for the non-experts, it can sometimes be pretty easy to belittle them or to knock them down

author: Q
sentence: That's a really good point

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So unless you've got - so the role of the chair, therefore, falls to not letting - just because someone's not able to actually present their case really strongly, therefore the case has got to be dismissed - but [in a way] 00:43:06, just about to do the opposite - to say, okay, what's the point they're trying to make here? How can we try and look at this in our context? So it's one of the arts of good chairs, which you honestly don't see very often [laugh]

author: A
sentence: Honestly

author: A
sentence: But a good chair will do that

author: A
sentence: In other words, they won't simply seek the views of the people around the table, but they will try and get them out on the table in a way that they are actually being properly expressed, if that makes sense

author: Q
sentence: It makes a lot of sense

author: Q
sentence: Because it's like a negotiation tool

author: Q
sentence: Part of conflict can be just a misunderstanding

author: Q
sentence: I could understand that, if someone's from very much a financial background and someone's very much HR; there's room for just complete misunderstanding

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: So the chair translates -

author: A
sentence: And if you're in a business like ours, or an industry like ours - finance - I mean, the finance people are always going to have the upper hand

author: A

author: A

author: A
sentence: If you just think about it for 30 seconds; why do you think that's a sensible decision? What you need is to have a board that becomes more informed about IT issues

author: A

How do you get - whatever the product or service that you're offering, how do you get it to the client? How do you make money? Because you've got to make money

author: A
sentence: How do you make money as a result of this? How do you square the circle between satisfying the client and making money for the organisation at the same time as having a workforce that's being looked after? So that's what I mean about the business model

author: A

author: A
sentence: And perversely -

author: Q
sentence: [Overtalking] 00:56:35

author: Q
sentence: And that's been in Australia, a lot of it

author: A
sentence: - it gets us - so if we look at the perspective of the regulator, they say, you've got to have a skills based board

author: A
sentence: You've got to have - when you're appointing a director, you should be clear about what the criteria are, etcetera

author: A
sentence: And if you think about our model, it's going to come in conflict with this because, (a) there's people who are certainly appointed - elected by the consultative committee that we don’t have control over

author: A
sentence: In other words, we can't say we'd like someone with - bad example - IT skills or HR skills or investment skills or whatever

author: A
sentence: Because they can select who they want

author: A
sentence: But perversely, we end up with actually a good -

author: Q
sentence: A more diverse board and -

author: A
sentence: A diverse - the more diverse board as a result

author: Q
sentence: So in a way then, you're suggesting that the use of the skills matrix is -

author: A
sentence: You've got to be -

author: Q
sentence: - can be a conservative element - can actually undermine diversity [overtalking] 00:57:31 -

author: A
sentence: I think it won't necessarily get you what you want

author: Q
sentence: Okay, it won't necessarily - one person raised this - I suggested this idea where you have your skills matrix, but then you extend it with diversity criteria as a way to try and bring the two together

author: Q
sentence: Which was interesting

author: A
sentence: Yeah, which is possible

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that boards are familiar - are there any barriers to diversity - you've just gone through that

author: A
sentence: Well it's been in Australia, but a lot of it - it's been both in Australia and the US

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think I have

author: Q
sentence: And you can't overcome it because it's written in the constitution of the board

author: Q
sentence: Except for the way you use your skills matrix could be modified

author: Q
sentence: What I'm saying is your - your constitution - the constitution of A superannuation fund requires different processes feed in different directors

author: Q
sentence: So there's a - the board itself does not have full control over who gets on it -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: - is what I understand

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So there's a lack of control

author: Q

author: A
sentence: You can't have a lot

author: Q
sentence: You can't

author: Q
sentence: Right

author: Q
sentence: So you've got - but does it prevent diversity? You're saying no, well it actually adds to it because these feeders bring it in -

author: A
sentence: I don't think it prevents it at all

author: Q
sentence: So it might make it harder for functioning of the board, but not really

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: - because you've described - the chair role is probably complex, but -

author: Q
sentence: And there's - at a really interesting time

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, last question

author: Q
sentence: Ten years into the future, how would you like to see diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: In simple terms, I think I would absolutely love us to have some true - some actual true diversity as defined - as I've defined diversity

author: A
sentence: In other words, a diversity of thought and perspective

author: A
sentence: So people with different educational backgrounds, people with different cultural backgrounds, with different life experiences

author: A
sentence: And yes, both genders and so on

author: A
sentence: But we really need to be looking at diversity in this much broader context than I think we oftentimes think about it

author: A
sentence: And I think if you do that, you will end up with stronger boards

author: A
sentence: I know, in my time as the boss, if you like - it was something I would always say to my senior staff - is, please don't tell me what you think I want to hear, because I already know that

author: A
sentence: It's of no value to me at all

author: A
sentence: Only give me something that's a different perspective than the one I already have

author: A
sentence: That's the only thing that's going to add some value to me

author: A
sentence: Now the issue is that you need chairs and boards to have that mental attitude

author: A
sentence: So what they're wanting to actually - so they've got to go in there trying to get - with a deliberate aim to get a difference of thought and perspective and, therefore, thought around the table

author: Q
sentence: That's wonderful

author: Q
sentence: And it fits in nicely with a hunch that the lead researchers for this research have - is that cognitive diversity, which is just a fancy word for what you've been talking about - the role it plays - so thank you very much

sentence: That's great

author: A
sentence: Pleasure

author: A
sentence: Yes

sentence: I did economics at university; specifically economics and then moved to the Australian Treasury - so studied economics there

sentence: Then joined National Mutual as their chief economist and then moved into the investment side of their business in - it would have been mid-'80s

author: A

sentence: Okay, so this is public investing

author: A
sentence: When I was looking - when I was with Invesco, the groups I was looking after were managing US$250 billion; so bigger than anything here in Australia

author: A
sentence: So we're, by definition, investing in the biggest - the major corporations, etcetera

author: A
sentence: Therefore, the teams that were working for me, we were going to be the people that were actually voting on all of the different board resolutions that were being put forward

author: A
sentence: So it's actually us that were actually influencing all the - all of this

author: A
sentence: And if we put it in the Australian context, which is what you're wanting; the big superannuation funds are the people who actually control the assets these days

author: A
sentence: So again, we're the people who will be actually - and for us, as A superannuation fund, we will be doing this behind the scenes rather than - we'll be doing it privately rather than publicly

author: A

sentence: Do you sit on boards? Do you have -

sentence: No

sentence: So the investment committee - in fact, I've just come from a meeting with our chief investment guy, John Pearce

author: A
sentence: So I end up being a bit conflicted because any of the - I mean, we will have major investments in lots of the major corporations so, all of a sudden, I can really appreciate - but I'm effectively a bit conflicted out of a lot of them

sentence: So no, we don't sit on [overtalking] 00:10:11

author: Q
sentence: Yes, to sit on [overtalking] 00:10:12 -

sentence: The only time any of our teams will sit on boards is where we've got - it's an unlisted entity – so, not listed on a stock exchange, but unlisted - so private, if you like

author: A
sentence: And if we've got a major holding in the company, we may have board seats associated with that, so there will be some of the investment team who might sit on those boards

author: Q
sentence: Is that because, if it's a listed company, you're happy with the regulatory framework, and you're not if it's not listed?

author: A
sentence: When it's a listed entity, the process for director election is one where you will typically have not an alignment between shareholders and directors

author: A
sentence: In a private entity, you will typically do the reverse

author: A
sentence: So what you're wanting in a listed entity is for these directors to be "independent"

author: A
sentence: So if it's – well, let's use CBA

author: A
sentence: If it's Commonwealth Bank [inaudible] 00:11:13 – well, ANZ was [inaudible] 00:11:14 a good one

author: A
sentence: So if it's ANZ or NAB, even though we might hold - pick a number, just to make it up

author: A
sentence: If we hold 3% of the shares, that's probably not big enough to be given a board seat in the normal scheme of things

author: A
sentence: Agreed

author: A
sentence: But more to the point, what you don't want is that these shareholders who've got board seats - you're wanting the seven or eight directors or whatever it is to be seen to be properly independent; so not aligned with any shareholder

author: A
sentence: By contrast, in private - in a privately held vehicle, that tends to be the reverse

author: A
sentence: Because you're wanting a different alignment of interests

sentence: So you could sit on boards of private, not listed [overtalking] 00:11:55 -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A

author: Q
sentence: So first, how do you - so you can look back to the '80s

author: Q
sentence: How has the composition of boards in Australia changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Not much

author: Q
sentence: Really? Wow

author: A
sentence: No, I don't think so

author: A
sentence: Do you? Can I go back and say, do you - what do you mean by diversity? Can I tell you -

author: Q
sentence: Well this is your - this is the question

author: Q
sentence: No, you tell me what you think

author: Q
sentence: Because [overtalking] 00:12:25 -

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Well let me maybe - let me maybe tell you what I think about diversity and then, if I haven't touched on all the things that you were hoping to touch on, happy to come back

author: A
sentence: I think the first thing is to be clear about what we mean by diversity

author: A
sentence: And the way I think about diversity is that it means that you've got a group of people sitting around the board people - around the board table, sorry, who have a diversity of thought or perspective

author: A
sentence: [Long pause] so that's the - my sort of - this is the key definition

author: A
sentence: So diversity doesn't mean that you're a different colour or a different gender

author: A
sentence: That doesn't mean diversity at all

author: A
sentence: And I'll come back to that

author: A
sentence: The next thing to say is that, in a board, it's fine - and we'll get to what I define as diversity in a second

author: A
sentence: Okay? But what I would say to you is that, above and beyond all of that, any board member must actually have what I would see as two critical criteria to be an effective board member

author: A
sentence: The first one is they must have a knowledge of the industry in which they're - the company is operating

author: A
sentence: And hopefully they have both knowledge and understanding of the industry and the company and, in particular, how that company does business, how it generates revenue and how it generates profit

author: A
sentence: Because what is the - a proper detailed understanding of the business or business model

author: Q
sentence: For how many years have you been a board director?

author: A
sentence: And the reason I'm saying this is that - and I'm sure you've seen the research by [McKinsey] 00:14:09, which highlighted that only a third of directors of the ASX 100 or 200 - I don't know if they surveyed all of them

author: A
sentence: I don't know

author: A
sentence: Only a third of them actually understood how the company that they were sitting on the board of generated what their business was - or was - how they actually generated a profit

author: A
sentence: So the reason I'm starting there is that you can be as diverse as you like, but your opinion is not going to be respected around the board table if you don't actually know how the business works

author: A
sentence: So it's fine to talk about [laugh] diversity in any way you want to; but if you're one of the people who's supposed to be the diverse one sitting around the table and you don't actually understand how the company works, your views are not going to be listened to

author: A
sentence: So if you're thinking about diversity from - so you can have diversity from the perspective that I can tick a box for somebody who's doing a questionnaire - you know, how many members have you got that are female and these - you know, males, females, etcetera

author: A
sentence: But if you're actually wanting diversity, you're going to have to have, as a starting point, members of the board who actually understand -

author: A
sentence: So then you get to this point of, okay, if we're going to want - if we're defining diversity as being a different perspective, what does that mean? That, to me, means that you're probably going to need people that have a different educational background

author: A
sentence: So this means you've got to get away from what I think of in the UK parlance is the Oxbridge syndrome

author: A
sentence: Now you've heard -

author: Q
sentence: [Inaudible] [overtalking] 00:15:47

author: A
sentence: So Oxbridge - one of the critical things about the UK is that all the senior positions in the UK are heavily dominated by people from Oxford or Cambridge University

author: A
sentence: Hence Oxbridge - the combination of the two

author: A
sentence: And it's the politicians on both sides

author: A
sentence: It's not just the Conservatives, but it's the Labour Party

author: A
sentence: It is big business

author: A
sentence: It is the boards

author: A
sentence: It is the BBC

author: A
sentence: It's Sky News or whatever

author: A
sentence: It is all the major institutions

author: A
sentence: It's all the senior bureaucrats, etcetera

author: A
sentence: They're basically - the numbers are scary in places; 70%, 80% are Oxbridge

author: A
sentence: So these people, they've all had the same education

author: A
sentence: You're then going to say, well the second one we could have a difference in perspective is that maybe you've got some cultural differences; you've come from different culture in terms of - or else you've had a different background

author: A
sentence: So you've had a different set of experiences

author: A
sentence: What that would mean would be something, for example, like location

author: A
sentence: In other words, if everybody comes - and let's use - we're here in Melbourne

author: A
sentence: If they've all come from the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, they've all gone to the private schools - and look, I was one of them

author: A
sentence: I went to Wesley College and all that

author: A
sentence: But if we've all come from that same - at least I live on the northern suburbs in Ascot Vale

author: A
sentence: I'm just north of the city

author: A
sentence: But seriously, if they've all - if everybody on your board - and I don’t care what colour or gender they are

author: A
sentence: If they've all come from the eastern suburbs, they've all gone to the same group of private schools, they've ended up going through the same universities; they're going to think basically the same

author: A
sentence: You therefore get - and that's at a - so they - and they do think differently than if you want to go out to the western suburbs or northern suburbs - I mean, there are differences here

author: A
sentence: Then you've got the issue of Australia versus OS

author: A
sentence: In other words, if the people - if they've been predominantly - is most of their experience domestic compared to someone who's had overseas experience? So for someone like myself; lived and worked in Hong Kong, lived and worked in UK, lived and worked in the US, so obviously my perspective on the world is going to be different than the people I interact with who are - frankly, they've travelled, but they've never actually had to deal, business wise, with people outside Australia

author: A
sentence: So obviously we can be different with gender

author: A
sentence: There are clear gender differences

author: A
sentence: So yes, gender's going to be one of the bases for difference, the same as culture

author: A
sentence: So if you've got - and I suppose even, in a way, religious background I think's - particularly if you're Islamic; that's going to probably give you a little bit of difference

author: A
sentence: But then it comes down to experience

author: A
sentence: So how different is your experience?

author: A
sentence: The reason I'm going with all of these is that if you look at the way that the boards go through the process of selecting people, what do they do? They select people that the board knows

author: A
sentence: They select people that are like them

author: A
sentence: They select people that are not going to rock the boat

author: A
sentence: Because there's -

author: A
sentence: So, this safety in numbers means that you actually probably -

author: A
sentence: A lot of the time, boards - don't believe that boards are actually trying to select people that are giving them true diversity

author: A
sentence: All right? I mean, they will probably be going down a track where, if there's pressure on them for diversity - say, gender diversity, well, they'll go and try and find a woman when they might have otherwise been looking for a bloke

author: A
sentence: But what they're going to do is they're going to find a woman that looks very much like the man that they would have appointed

author: A
sentence: In other words, someone like them

author: A
sentence: Someone who's not going to rock the boat

author: A
sentence: Someone who's got the same sort of background and upbringing as they do

author: A
sentence: It goes back to this safety in numbers, because if things go wrong, you're going to want to be [laugh] - they're going to want you to be - the board's going to want for everybody to be aligned

author: Q

author: A
sentence: No

author: A

author: A

author: A

author: A

author: A

sentence: Diversity as I define it? How important it is at the board?

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: Gee, seven

author: A
sentence: [Long pause] maybe eight even

author: A
sentence: I think it's very important

author: A

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that it's always been considered important - as you define it, has it always been important for boards? Or do you think it's been - it changed at some stage? In Australia

author: A
sentence: I don't think it was important in the past and I think true diversity is not seen to be important today

author: Q
sentence: As you define it

author: A

author: A

author: Q
sentence: Okay, yep

sentence: Well, you don't need to de-identify

author: A
sentence: Everything I say can be put on the public record

author: A
sentence: I wouldn't be the least bit upset if it appears on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald

author: A
sentence: That’s the principle I have adopted throughout my career, okay?

author: A
sentence: So, are you doing your PhD or have you done it or what?

sentence: Yes

sentence: I'm sorry to see it's not still

author: A
sentence: Well, no, no

author: A
sentence: We used those organisations for a number of years and then we tend to suggest to people that they fund a [unclear] 00:32:15 because 'We can do so much for you', you know?

author: Q
sentence: That's right

sentence: You probably exhausted us all

sentence: So, now, we want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

sentence: Yeah

sentence: You do have to be a bit careful that you don't stereotype your female board members, I think, is probably a way for [unclear] 00:32:52

author: A

author: A
sentence: It doesn’t always work quite appropriately

author: A
sentence: Alternatively, because a HR or staffing issue comes to the board, some of the members ask Helen because she knows about those things

author: A
sentence: So, you've got to be a bit careful

author: Q
sentence: Can we drill down on that because as a chair of a number of boards, when you talked about - like, you define diversity and then it might matter depending on the business you're in and the strategy probably you're  about - why you're looking for someone new, I guess, the purpose behind that, then what - oh, dear, what was I going to say? I was going to say the stereotyping, how do you as chair know that it's not stereotyping, that it's genuine? What processes do you do? What procedures do you undertake to avoid it?

author: Q
sentence: Yep, perfect

author: Q
sentence: That makes it very easy for me

author: Q
sentence: Okay, fire away

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: This is during a board meeting, we're talking about, or -

author: Q
sentence: I don’t know; when it happens

author: A
sentence: - when I'm recruiting somebody?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, when you're recruiting

author: Q
sentence: Yep, yep

author: Q
sentence: I don't know if it happens in the board meeting or out of it

author: A
sentence: Okay, when you're recruiting somebody, it's an easy trap to hire somebody just like yourself

author: A
sentence: Given I'm a lunatic, I’ve got a habit of hiring lunatics

author: A
sentence: I mean, that's not meant to be quite literal, but we have - I'm a person of adventure who has got lots and lots of interests and who has got lots of good ideas, so it might be that I might hire somebody who is full of ideas and talks a lot

author: A
sentence: So, that might not be a good idea

author: A
sentence: That might be one form of stereotype

author: A
sentence: There is a temptation to say we've got these sorts of [unclear] 00:34:56 set of skills that we need in our board members, so we go and look for some of those, and then you don't do things like think a bit more outside the box

author: A
sentence: Well, perhaps a younger person or perhaps somebody from another culture, or perhaps somebody who isn't of a sort of scientific or rational background might be useful

author: A
sentence: So, it's very tempting to say here is our list of skills and we'll go and look for somebody like that

author: A
sentence: It's something that you have to be continually aware of and ask yourself the question: well, am I just hiring in my own image sort of thing? I mean, and it's quite hard to do that, so perhaps that's why you need a couple of people on the exercise sort of thing, or to just back and forth

author: A
sentence: So, generally boards that have got nominations, would need to be your next part

author: A
sentence: Often they’ve done the head hunt, but not always

author: A
sentence: Sometimes the head hunt is useful, but sometimes they're not

author: A
sentence: Some of the roles the head hunter is often trying to get on the board a bit more broadly, on the sort of person that might be suitable

author: A
sentence: I mean, the classic example is that we’ve got somebody to fill in the board of this energy company and of course they expect them to work in the energy sector

author: A
sentence: Well, that may not be a good idea, and I'd suggest that if it's a large developed company, it's probably a really poor idea

author: A
sentence: It's a bit like when people say - and they used to criticise the Myer Board years and years ago saying that it's got no retailers on it

author: A
sentence: And that was really a lobby that [unclear] 00:36:40 the legal and all that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: But it was a bit short of retail people for a while, because they've got lots of other people

author: A
sentence: And perhaps they did need somebody from retail on the board, and I think they probably would have

author: A
sentence: It's always nice to have one subject matter expert type of person on your board, but you can go to a board and say we want everybody from retail

author: A
sentence: Now they've been in [the past] 00:37:06 moving consumer goods, and these people have been - more bulk good, or whatever, so that's diversity? I think not, sort of thing

author: A
sentence: But you can construct the argument that we're a diverse bunch by doing this old sub-dividing - a bit like the [unclear] 00:37:23 argument

author: A
sentence: You can sub-divide and sub-divide and say, well, we've got one of these, and one of these, and one of these, so we're diverse

author: A
sentence: And they're all from a very small band of something that is a larger issue

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, or they might all be from the Melbourne Club

author: A
sentence: Well, that could possibly be true

author: A
sentence: I had - you live in Melbourne, aren't you?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I wouldn't dream of saying such a thing

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:37:54

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: So, some of the boards I'm on

author: A
sentence: I'm the executive chair of Women on Boards, which is probably why you are interviewing me; I'm the chair of a thing called the Australian Chocolate Company, affectionately called 'Charlie', which grows and manufactures chocolate in Queensland; I'm a chairman of a thing called AHSI, which is the Australian Health and Science Institute, which is an RTO that's got regulatory approval for taking international students; I'm also a director for the National Foundation for Australian Women, which is basically a social policy board; and, that is about it for the time being

author: Q
sentence: It doesn't matter; that was just a line

author: A
sentence: It was

author: A
sentence: That was just a line
