sentence: Yeah, we can move on

author: Q
sentence: Now, look, I'm going to force you to take this one

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and board functioning and we want to explore that

author: A
sentence: Do we?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I'm afraid so

author: Q
sentence: This one is an imposed question

author: Q
sentence: So, what we sort of think of cognitive diversity as different ways of problem solving, different ways of understanding things, different ways of interpreting the world, so it's as distinct from different experience

author: Q
sentence: So, do you feel the cognitive diversity influence -

author: A
sentence: Sorry, I missed that

author: A
sentence: You faded

author: A
sentence: Say that sentence again

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel cognitive diversity influences a board's functioning?

author: A
sentence: I'm sure it does and probably for the better

author: A
sentence: I mean, one of the examples that is often quoted is that when you've got a board of all males or all people who are accountants or they've all worked in business that's focused on profit, the most important item they always talk about is the financial reports

author: A
sentence: Now, this is a bit stylised, this example: when you then introduce some females onto that board who come from perhaps different backgrounds, the financials aren't the most important thing, or other things get talked about sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, that could be the issue about this collection of people who we can call a team or we can call a board, but think in different ways

author: A
sentence: All that research that was done that was published in the Times magazine, was all about a diverse collection of people from either diverse IQ or diverse ways or preferences for thinking produces a better outcome than a bunch of geniuses or a bunch of people who are very similar sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, in my terms, there's good arguments for having people who have got different ways of thinking

author: A
sentence: Now, it might piss people off a bit, because I'm the person who likes to - I'm action man

author: A
sentence: Let's make a decision

author: A
sentence: Other people who want to mull the issue around for and think of some of the other options, et cetera, and as a board member you have to understand that those people bring valuable insights and valuable contributions

author: A
sentence: And you just have to appreciate the differences that people bring, and that means as a chair that it's harder to run a board or manage a board  or whatever you want to call it when you've got people who are on different sort of parts of the thinking spectrum, or the action spectrum or whatever

author: A
sentence: But in the long run you will probably get a better outcome

author: Q
sentence: It's part of a good conversation, having a good conversation

author: Q
sentence: That's good

author: Q
sentence: Well, look, I'll tell you, your chair experience could be very useful for us, because we're looking at diversity and processes around that

author: Q
sentence: So, as a chair - so, I might sort of deviate from my form for women on boards perspective to include some questions around process, if that's okay

author: Q
sentence: Yep, good

author: Q
sentence: And so many industries - cool, excellent

author: Q
sentence: So, we'll get on with it now, the questions

author: Q
sentence: So, first, how have the composition of boards you're familiar with changed over time in terms of diversity?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, a good conversation

author: A
sentence: But remember you can't spend all your time in board meetings having long and involved conversations

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you do need the outcome

author: A
sentence: Yes, you do need the outcome

author: A
sentence: So, yes, all these things are balancing acts

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that's why the diversity - so, as a chair do you think there's a special role that the chair plays in this?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I mean, you have an orchestra leader or a conductor which you challenge to the point where you do make decisions and you make them after due consideration

author: A
sentence: Well, that's a nice and easy thing to say, and the judgment is how much effort do you put into getting to the point where you can say it's time to make a decision? Because chairs judge in part, well, is this a well-running organisation that actually does things and makes decisions and progresses that strategic plan or whatever, but it doesn’t do it in a reckless way

author: A
sentence: So, with all that wisdom and judgement

author: Q
sentence: Yep, okay

author: Q
sentence: So, inclusivity - do you as a chair try to be inclusive, include the different voices, but not let that end up being the point of the game? The point of the game is to actually make a good decision

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I always expect everybody to have a say, even if they say I haven't got anything to say on this topic

author: A
sentence: So, I don't appreciate passengers who sit there quietly and never make a contribution

author: A
sentence: There are people who are a bit like that, they just sit there and they have probably read all the papers and they're just quiet

author: A
sentence: And one of the challenges is to get the best out of everybody around the board table

author: A
sentence: And so, you've got people who are quiet, and the sorts of people who are quiet are probably people from different sorts of backgrounds

author: A
sentence: Like, Asians won't sort of stand up and say my turn to speak

author: A
sentence: They need to be invited

author: A
sentence: You have to appreciate that sort of stuff as well, and you have to appreciate that perhaps new members are a bit hesitant to say much, and you've got to nurture that along

author: A
sentence: So, you really do have to get contributions from everybody, and some of the contributions might not be quite so much during the board meeting; it might be behind the scenes

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, I'm not doing my job as a chair if I can't get a contribution from all my board members

author: A
sentence: I mean, and although there are some boards that get [parodied] 00:43:53 that the chap or the girl - it's usually a chap who will never stop talking, or the person who always wants to talk on every topic

author: A
sentence: Now, the rules broadly speaking for a board meeting - because I don’t know how many agenda items [unclear] 00:44:08 item - you as a board member want half a dozen people who don't get to talk for every item, necessarily

author: A
sentence: You might get to the point where you say, I'm okay with that Mr Chairman, or Miss Chairman, or Madame Chairman, but you don't rattle on forever

author: A
sentence: So, discipline as well

author: A
sentence: So, that's another challenge for the chair, is to know that everybody gets to make a contribution, but it may not be on every item sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yep

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it's something that could be included on a matrix, these tools that people sometimes use to select board members? You know, where you analyse what you need, performance matrix, or whatever it is? It says you -

author: A
sentence: You mean capacity to contribute?

author: A
sentence: Okay, now, women on boards is later driven, and so, we have for the past almost ten years now collected a dataset called the 'Boardroom Diversity Index', which looks at, I think, typically rating sectors in the economy, so ASX200, ASX300, the evaluation board, government board, housing authorities, et cetera, so basically just about all of those sectors have shown a steady improvement in diversity as far as women are concerned on their boards

author: A
sentence: For example, if that's any help to you, Boardroom Diversity Index appears on our website, so ASX100 in 2010 was 11 or eight per cent women

author: A
sentence: It's now - when we did our last data collection in 2018, or the start of 2018, it was 29

author: A
sentence: We're due to do another data collection this year

author: A
sentence: For example, cooperative research centres have managed to get from 17

author: A
sentence: 3 to 28

author: A
sentence: Credit unions have managed to rise from 21 to 37

author: A
sentence: The story is pretty consistent

author: Q
sentence: Dear

author: A
sentence: Let's put it a different way

author: A
sentence: This is actually something a little bit easier than my International Directors' Program - the five energies of directors - and I've forgotten what they are, but hang on two secs and I'll find them for you

author: A
sentence: Normally you say you want board members that know something about accounting -

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, yeah

author: A
sentence: - that know something about, I don't know -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, skills matrix

author: Q
sentence: That’s it

author: Q
sentence: The skills matrix

author: A
sentence: Skills matrix

author: A
sentence: But what about a version that says - I'll just put my spectacles on here, because it's quite small

author: A
sentence: High Fundamental Energy Battery according to Professor [Ludo] 00:45:41 is you've got emotional and relationship skills

author: A
sentence: Now, that usually does appear somewhere on the skills matrix, because it's usually split into skills and personal qualities

author: A
sentence: So, yeah

author: A
sentence: Inspirational skills

author: A
sentence: Gives sense to the [unclear] 00:45:57

author: A
sentence: You want people who are a bit enthusiastic about the business and make an inspired - and sort of encourage them

author: A
sentence: So, that’s another one

author: A
sentence: Rational and logical skills

author: A
sentence: You are basically, in a for-profit enterprise, dealing with people's money that they have given to you to do something useful with

author: A
sentence: So, your objective is to actually make them money in some shape or form, or to satisfy your customers or whatever

author: A
sentence: Now, there is a large component of rationality and logic behind these things

author: A
sentence: Then you've got to have people who have got the time to put into it and you avoid the glamour hunters, or people who are there because they've got a profile

author: A
sentence: Beware of those

author: A
sentence: And then you've got something called physical skills, which is the capacity to do the job sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, if you were to analyse - assess people on those five elements, and then - sorry, another one is experience

author: A
sentence: So, you’ve got a range of experiences that are useful to [unclear] 00:47:07

author: A
sentence: So, that’s a quite different way of looking at a skills matrix shall we say

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

sentence: Can I have a copy of that or is that private/confidential or something?

author: A
sentence: No, that’s not confidential

sentence: I'll photograph it if you like

author: Q
sentence: That would be brilliant

author: Q

author: A
sentence: I'm talking on my mobile

author: A
sentence: My mobile can only do one thing at once, I'm sorry to say

author: A
sentence: When I'm talking, that's all I can do

author: Q
sentence: Oh, well

author: Q
sentence: If you send it to me after, I would be very grateful

author: A

author: A
sentence: So, there's two sides to the card

author: Q
sentence: All right, I'll look for two pictures

author: Q
sentence: So, can you think of any ways that - now, we'll talk about women on boards

author: A
sentence: And you better send me another email with your email address on it

author: Q
sentence: I shall

author: Q
sentence: I shall

author: Q
sentence: Can you think of any ways that your organisation helps candidates from minority groups? So, do you do anything to help candidates from minority groups?

author: A
sentence: What is a minority group by your definition?

author: Q
sentence: Well, low socioeconomic background perhaps, people who can't afford to do the courses -

author: A
sentence: Clearly some people will say it's not quite fast enough, and women on boards, of course, have the view that it should be a 40/40/20 split

author: A
sentence: We always say that we will offer concession for people who claim poverty, or whatever, and we get a few people who approach us to do that, and we accommodate their needs generally speaking

author: Q
sentence: What about people from an Aboriginal background or backgrounds that - like, ethnicity, different ethnicities? And you might -

author: A
sentence: We've got hordes of members who look like they were born in China

author: A
sentence: In fact, they are Australians, but they are of Chinese or Vietnamese or whatever - I mean, I don't view those people as a minority as a member of Women on Boards, but the general community might view them as a minority

author: A
sentence: There's lots of highly-skilled women here from migrant backgrounds

author: Q
sentence: And young people - are you helping young people get on?

author: A
sentence: Yep, we are particularly keen to encourage young people to become board members

author: Q
sentence: Well, you are doing it

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and we do it

author: A
sentence: We do it

author: A
sentence: We have sessions called information evenings for young people and we send emails to our people and say, bring a young person along

author: A
sentence: And we spend a lot of time and energy explaining to young people they have a set of skills that many boards would be the better for having them

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: A
sentence: Often they're reluctant

author: A
sentence: They think they haven’t got the experience

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s great

author: Q
sentence: I have interviewed one person in her late 20s, so I did well, I reckon

author: Q
sentence: A 40/40/20 split, did you say?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, regulation - what do you see as the main barriers to building diverse boards in Australia and how do these barriers work?

author: A
sentence: Well, the main barriers - for example, when I went to an annual general meeting one year - some time ago, so times have changed a little - and I stood up and said, I note that you don't have any women on your board

author: A
sentence: Is this something that you're planning to do something about, and the chairman was so incredibly honest

author: A
sentence: He said, we never thought about it

author: A
sentence: And that actually is exactly true

author: A
sentence: They'd never noticed

author: A
sentence: So, the first barrier to have diverse boards is somebody has to notice that you don't have one

author: A
sentence: Now lots of boards do notice and they do something about it, but in times gone by for publicly-listed companies, remember there is no data on 'were there are any woman on listed company boards' that I could find before about 1995, and the only reason I had any data is because I met Adrian Clarke who was one of the first people in the story, as far as I could tell, to be on a publicly -listed board

author: A
sentence: So, clearly, nobody thought about it at all

author: A
sentence: I mean, that's the actual dilemma that we face when we say do, we need more diversity? People don't notice

author: A
sentence: It's like if there's one female on the board, that's okay

author: A
sentence: If there's two, the guys think there's been a takeover

author: A
sentence: I mean, it's like they're so unaccustomed

author: A
sentence: So, awareness-raising really is the first sort of battleground for improving diversity on board

author: A
sentence: And that is sort of happening

author: A
sentence: I mean, there's lots of topics, lots of talks about it, lots of articles and lots of media, so it's coming along, but that story I recounted to you of my visit to the AGM was probably 12 years ago

author: Q
sentence: Right, yep

author: A
sentence: So, yeah, just didn't occur to it, but it does now

author: A
sentence: So, that's one good thing

author: Q
sentence: Do you think regulation - you know how we've got people with targets; you've got targets, do you think that is a major factor in raising awareness and making it a visible problem/issue?

author: A
sentence: It's a major way of changing outcomes

author: A
sentence: I mean, the history is with the governments that have targets, some are longer than others, but even they - it's obvious; if 50 per cent of the voters are female and 50 per cent are male, and also some of your, I don't know, Liberal Party [unclear] 00:52:45 at Parliament are filled with Chinese ethnicities, then it raises your awareness level and public policy often precedes the behaviour in the board room or whatever

author: A
sentence: So, the activities the government has taken over the years and the public sector as well, they have more women in senior roles on boards, et cetera, is probably the thing that drags everybody else along to a very large extent

author: A
sentence: They very often get quite enough credit

author: A
sentence: They get lots of brickbats, sort of thing

author: A
sentence: But generally speaking, they've done the right thing

author: A
sentence: And the not-for-profit sector, of course, because they initially, no board members got paid, often there were lots of women on those - free labour type of thing, so there's always been a reasonable representation there

author: A
sentence: And the really poor areas are the things that are really in our Boardroom Diversity Index: listed companies, superannuation funds, credit unions in days gone by because - that was business

author: A
sentence: Always chaps, girls in business -

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so it was a business culture excluded -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yep, 40 men, 40 women per cent, and then seven per cent of either gender and/or because it's the numbers that really [speak out] 00:04:28

author: Q
sentence: So, that culture, would that also exclude, say, people who think in a more process way? Like, a business culture is more outcome-focused do you think, the cognitive diversity issue?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: I think if you're in the club, you're in the club

author: A
sentence: You can be left legged, or whatever, but if you're in the club, you are

author: A
sentence: So, in a funny sort of way, the club is quite tolerant

author: A
sentence: I mean, it might expect performance, it might expect competence, or it might not, but it's all part of it

author: Q
sentence: So, is this club still functioning, still effective now?

author: A
sentence: Well, how many football clubs do you know about? How many - I mean, the clubs are always effective

author: A
sentence: Tribes are always effective

author: A
sentence: It's just a question of which clubs they're in predominantly, and are they in any way changing their views? And, in fact, they're being pressured by things like government expect women on boards, times are changing

author: A
sentence: Clubs, often if they have premises, they discover that they're running out of members and they need women

author: A
sentence: I mean, the reality in Sydney - there's a couple of the stodgy old male clubs that don't make any money anymore, so they need extra members

author: A
sentence: Where are we going to get them from?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Who don't need to be paid?

author: A
sentence: What sort of - the practical outcome

author: A
sentence: But if you say, well, we're looking for another board member who is, you know - remember that one of the great benefits of Australian society is that we have a cadre of accountants and lawyers and bankers who, in fact, are very good at what they do, and the glue to make sure that we can do transactions at a cheaper cost than other places perhaps, is trust, longevity and the club

author: A
sentence: So, you can't completely shoot down the club

author: A
sentence: It's the glue that holds our professional services world together, which is the facilitators of business and all that sort of stuff, or the servants of business, et cetera, et cetera

author: A
sentence: So, clearly [unclear] 00:56:34 if you went to university with somebody 40 years ago and you're now a senior partner or whatever you are, or a CEO in something, then clearly will have those relationships

author: A
sentence: We always say that networking is really, really important and is absolutely, because you can call upon someone [over talk] 00:56:53

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so cronyism, how do you as a chair of a board and how do you as a person - you know, very influential in Women on Boards, how do you try to prevent the problems of cronyism limiting or undermining your strategy to have adequate diversity?

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: Now, there is a strategy called 'Fund it Forward'

author: A
sentence: You offer assistance to people and that means that at some point they owe you a favour

author: A
sentence: Now, if it works the other way and you decide not to offer assistance but you ask for favours, you are then beholden

author: A
sentence: And once you are beholden, then the [unclear] 00:57:38 sets in

author: A
sentence: So, that is my simple solution, be alert

author: A
sentence: Don't put yourself in a position where you can be subject to an influence that will result in cronyism

author: A
sentence: So, that is a bit of a pure answer, but I'm sure no-one else has given you that answer

author: Q
sentence: Definitely not

author: Q
sentence: I love it

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So, gender targets, what do you think? Quotas, targets, do you think they're good?

author: A
sentence: Measured targets are a fine idea

author: A
sentence: We do that all the time

author: A
sentence: We've got targets for how much money we're going to make, how many senior memberships we're going to have, how many gender break-ups of our senior membership

author: A
sentence: Quotas - there's not much difference between a measured target and a quota other than the brouhaha that goes with it

author: A
sentence: Quotas are not a good idea if you want to change people's behaviours because - particularly with regards to women on Boards

author: A
sentence: I mean, the reasons behind that

author: A
sentence: Despite that, of course, the federal cabinet has got quotas, you realise, from a geographic base and, in the case of the liberal nationals, you have party vote

author: A
sentence: So, there are lots of quotas about, but when we talk about quotas for women it’s an entirely different matter

author: A
sentence: It's been a really bad thing

author: A
sentence: So, it might be a bad thing but not for the reasons that -

author: Q
sentence: Okay, perfect

author: Q
sentence: Are there other kinds of diversity that you think matter?

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me why you think it's a bad thing, please?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think it's a bad thing because you can do it in a way that is less confronting by having a managed target and it's a bad thing because the downside of quotas is often women will say they only want me because I'm female

author: A
sentence: They don't understand that even if you have a quota, you actually have to find some skilled people

author: A
sentence: And in fact, it means you have to go and look harder; it doesn't mean you sacrifice quality because of the quota

author: A
sentence: But the rhetoric behind quota is such that people will say, oh, you're forcing us to do this, this or this with any old woman or any old Asian or any old left-legged whatever on our board

author: A
sentence: And it's just bad karma, because sometimes you do get that outcome

author: A
sentence: Often if you say to somebody in an organisation, the top priority - well, the old brush and shoe example

author: A
sentence: We want to have maximum production of shoes out of our factory, so the best way of achieving that is you produce right foot, size 8

author: A
sentence: And you get unintended consequences

author: A
sentence: Or, people perform - men that are a bit silly, and don't underestimate people's capacity to actually follow the instruction and not think about it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: It's the easy way

author: Q
sentence: Look, 41IN, I'm aware of the time

author: Q
sentence: This has to be a gift from you if you answer this question

author: Q
sentence: We can't have, I owe you anything

author: Q
sentence: Ten years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards and why do you think it will be good?

author: A
sentence: Well, clearly, we struggle in Australia to find our place - sorry, first up, an open-trading economy is what we are

author: A
sentence: We're struggling to maintain our place in the region, as other countries do better

author: A
sentence: That’s all taken as a given

author: A
sentence: We have a huge resource available from the people in Australia, because lots of them work [unclear] 01:01:11, including me

author: A
sentence: So, if you can't value that difference/diversity, then you’ve missed the boat

author: A
sentence: And that's the bottom line, in my terms

author: A
sentence: So, we can envisage that we will move on from the argument about women and certainly the argument about more Asian persons or migrants or whatever you want to call them in leadership in Australian companies is gaining pretty good

author: A
sentence: That will increase over time, I'm sure

author: Q
sentence: That's fantastic

author: Q
sentence: That’s fantastic

author: Q
sentence: I think that is a really good way to conclude this because it is such a strong economic argument and that is great from a business perspective

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I am a business person after all

author: Q
sentence: I can tell

author: A
sentence: Now, paying it forward, I'm not going to send you a selection of Charlie's chocolates, but being the chairman of Charlie's Chocolates, we make sensational chocolate and its award-winning and we don't use slave labour

author: A
sentence: So, there you go, all of my worthy efforts

author: Q
sentence: That's wonderful

author: Q
sentence: You're a scream

author: Q
sentence: Well, I'll just turn this off

author: Q
sentence: END OF TRANSCRIPT

author: A
sentence: That's fine

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: I mean, I was the gender diversity - the leading index for diversity, and  after you've got women on boards, that we should start on the thing that is easiest to do something about, which is there was a ready supply for women to sit on board seats, but clearly things like geography are important; things like ethnicity are important, although that's quite - that's harder to find people; and people who are not born here necessarily

author: A
sentence: So, they're all important, but they’re more difficult to tackle, and our aim is women on boards

author: A
sentence: Okay?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, from your organisation

author: Q
sentence: I know

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: That's good

author: Q
sentence: So, can you explain how Women on Boards seeks to influence Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I can

author: A
sentence: Well, we do it at a strategic level, so we advocate in the public domain

author: A
sentence: We talk to politicians, we talk to company directors, we talk to chairs, we put it up on our website, we've got a large membership and we seek to put forward the argument that diversity is important

author: A
sentence: That's the first top-tier activity

author: Q
sentence: Can I just clarify? When you advocate, is it for gender only or do you include the other kinds of diversity you mentioned?

author: A
sentence: We advocate for all sorts of things to do with women's aspirations towards leadership

author: A
sentence: So, we obviously advocate for more women on boards and in leadership positions, but generally it's women that we advocate for

author: A
sentence: But we also advocate on matters like gender pay gap, paid parental leave, et cetera, those issues that impact women's capacity to offer themselves to leadership roles

author: A
sentence: That’s quite a broad remit and a lot of that we do in conjunction with the National Foundation for Australian Women and some of it we do ourselves sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, it's a pretty broad remit sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So, you advocate in the public domain - yep

author: A
sentence: The next thing we do is we offer experiences to women and men, who wish to come along, to enable them to understand what it is to be a board member, how they get there, and give them a good network to assist them in that regard

author: A
sentence: You can call that workshops, seminars, if you like, but it's a bit broader than that

author: A
sentence: And the third thing we do, is because - it's like the management cycle: we then have to offer up people board opportunities for them to apply for, so we started off on the premise that transparency and openness are a preferred way of hiring board members, but the world doesn’t necessarily agree with us on that foot

author: A
sentence: Many people don't do it that way still, but it is increasing

author: A
sentence: So, since about 2005 we've had a board, jobs board, and first week in we had 25 new postings this week and there's [unclear] 00:07:54 available things on our website

author: A
sentence: Something for everybody

author: A
sentence: So, that gives people something to aim for

author: A
sentence: So, that is the third chunk of our platform

author: A
sentence: Now, we do do other things as well, so we have a program that's called WOBSX, which is relatively new  and sort of innovative in the sense that it aims to enable women to access hard-to-find boards, which is principally ASX, because the majority of those are done by word of mouth in some shape or form, so we're trying to attack the rest of ASX and other boards that are not available for public advertising

author: A
sentence: That's one new thing that we do

author: Q
sentence: So, what was that called again?

author: A
sentence: WOBSX, and that's on our website as well, if you want more information

author: A
sentence: So, we do a whole range of things, and of course, we've got members from all around the world

author: A
sentence: We've got corporate members and so we can really influence these [unclear] 00:09:08

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that's great

author: Q
sentence: And how important, then - or, first of all, how effective do you think these four strategies are and is one sort of more effective than the others?

author: Q
sentence: Fantastic

author: Q
sentence: I'll call you 41IN, but I'll remove your name from the transcript when it's finished

author: A
sentence: They're all - it's a holistic thing

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, they all work together

author: A
sentence: You can't do one without - well, you can do one without the other, but if your aim is to get more women on the boards, you've got to actually complete the cycle somehow

author: A
sentence: Remember that until about 2002, when Catalyst in the United States started their website and their research into women on boards, and their data collection exercises, there was no data available really about women on boards, about women in leadership

author: A
sentence: And it's sort of interesting that even today you'll discover that many datasets that get collected don't differentiate on the basis of gender, which is pretty sort of interesting really

author: A
sentence: So, if they don't differentiae on the basis of gender, they're unlikely to differentiate on the basis of any of the other diversity elements, and one of the things - in fact, the National Foundation for Australian Women did was encourage the ABS to have a gendered basis theory, which indeed, they do have and is available and talks about female participate in the workforce and what they earn and a range of other things

author: A
sentence: So, it's not obvious that women are catered for

author: A
sentence: It's easy to forget about them and not to collect the data

author: A
sentence: If you don't collect the data, you've just go no basis for putting forward a rational position

author: Q
sentence: I'm just thinking now, because we're moving to a plural - very diverse understandings of gender, of sexual identity and things like that, the 'other' box is growing instead of male/female/other

author: Q
sentence: Do you think this might be a threat to your data or -

author: A
sentence: Not particularly

author: A
sentence: I mean, I take a sort probably not very modern view about gender

author: A
sentence: Gender is - perhaps it is modern - gender in my terms has always been a continuum

author: A
sentence: There’s not been definitively male or definitively female, and along the spectrum is people who have got characteristics that you can define as this, that and everything else

author: A
sentence: Last I heard they were reporting three different genders, that we name them on the list

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s what I'm thinking

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I mean, I just think that is such a small portion of the population

author: A
sentence: These people are desperate to be heard and to be considered and to be recognised, and that's all fine, but statistically it's insignificant

author: Q
sentence: Okay, fine

author: Q
sentence: So, that won't affect - I'm just thinking in terms of the future if this trend continues, it might affect the use of data, the way you use data

author: A
sentence: I don’t think so, because the other point is there's so much difference of opinion about what these sub-categories, [unclear] 00:12:26 are, but I think that that is not a very fruitful way of collecting data

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that's good

author: Q
sentence: It was just a bit of an aside

author: A
sentence: Oh, don't worry

author: A
sentence: Personally

author: A
sentence: That's an old-fashioned way to [over talk] 00:12:36 -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, it's okay

author: Q
sentence: That's good

author: Q
sentence: Happy to have it

author: Q
sentence: How important do you think it is to have a diverse board? If I give you a scale - don't be too critical of it: one is it's not important at all, and ten is it's extremely important, where would you put it?

author: A
sentence: Well, I'd say it's extremely important, wouldn’t I?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Well just that you've got to say it

author: Q
sentence: [laughs] Good on you

author: A
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I mean, I'd so want to tell you, but there's too many items in the list

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, why do you -

author: A
sentence: I mean, there's lots of evidence that suggests that diverse boards, diverse teams perform better

author: A
sentence: Okay, or produce better outcomes

author: A
sentence: There's some research that suggests it's not a significant factor, but that's in the minority sort of thing

author: A
sentence: When you talk - a lot of the research is anecdotal, you go and talk to people and say, what is different when you have female board members and stuff like that

author: A
sentence: But if you haven't got a board that represents, firstly, your customers, you're really not going to do terribly well, are you? And most people have customers who are equally, or if not more, predominantly female than male

author: A
sentence: That is just one example why logically you would speak - you would want different perspectives on your board

author: A
sentence: And that's the principal thing that people say diversity brings to the board

author: A
sentence: It brings different perspectives, you talk about different topics, you've perhaps got different priorities

author: A
sentence: That’s why it's important, because you get a better conversation and you consider more options than perhaps you would have if you were a board that was only sort of anodyne, or standard or visual sort of background

author: Q
sentence: Now, look, your experience as a chair on a number of boards, have you seen this? Can you give me an example of perhaps where diversity has contributed to these multiple perspectives and whatever, and perhaps where it has limited - there hasn't been sufficient diversity so you feel the decision has been poor as a result?

author: A
sentence: Well, the fact that I'm on the board makes it diverse, okay? So, truly it's a highly-performing board, I'd say, sufficiently

author: A
sentence: An example, back to my data example

author: A
sentence: When I was chair of Australian Ethical Superannuation, we used to get reports every time we had the board meeting, about our membership base, and when I got there, we had members

author: A
sentence: Shortly after this we had female members and male members, and that was important because you and I probably realise that there are different outcomes which regard superannuation for males and females, and you might want to do different things in your marketing or whatever to your cohort of members - I mean, just as you might different messages to your younger superannuation members as compared to your superannuation members who are near retirement

author: A
sentence: Of course, you would, because they’ve got different circumstances, but as do males and females

author: A
sentence: That's just an example

author: A
sentence: As I said, because I'm a female on a board and usually there's more than one female, I can't really say a lot about why it was better

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Well, 41IN, can I just get some demographics first? Your discipline background? Are you an accountant? Are you a lawyer?

author: Q
sentence: Have you been on a board where there is perhaps only women and so lacking diversity because of that?

author: A
sentence: I have, actually, the National Foundation for Australian Women only has female board members, at least today, and I suspect it might benefit from having a male board member sort of thing

author: A
sentence: And another example is the Netball board, Netball Australia

author: A
sentence: Traditionally, it's occasionally had a male on it, but usually it's all female, and clearly I think - they're doing quite well, netball, as regards promoting the sport and getting financial support and stuff, but I would have thought a male or two board members would be quite useful, apart from the fact no males apply

author: A
sentence: I don't know

author: Q
sentence: Well, it's interesting, isn't it? What is the barrier? It could be illuminating

author: A
sentence: Well, yeah, netball has done a really good job doing sort of joint ventures, if you could call it that, with AFL clubs in Melbourne, so in that sense they are, in fact, pretty aware of that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Sort of building alliances or -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and that's perhaps the proxy for having males on your board in a funny sort of way, or a first step perhaps

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do you think, how would it work? What, at a cultural level, like a social level?

author: A
sentence: I don't know

author: A
sentence: I mean, I can only -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, hypothesise

author: A
sentence: -@ make up a story

author: A
sentence: I've done a lot of things

author: A
sentence: I started off in - I did computing to begin with, and then I became an accountant, and then I generally became a company director

author: Q
sentence: You haven't seen it happen

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: I suggest you might go and talk to the netball people

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good idea

author: Q
sentence: I'll keep it in mind

author: Q
sentence: But we're at the end

author: Q
sentence: Anyway, do you think there's any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating? For example, in a situation of high uncertainty or high risk?

author: A
sentence: A few stereotypes float about, but women get nervous when there's high uncertainty and high risk, and so some chairs have been known to say that the women don't sort of pull their weight

author: A
sentence: Those comments haven't been made very often

author: A
sentence: I don't know if that's true or false

author: A
sentence: I mean, women are perhaps a little bit more cautious than men about some things, a bit more careful perhaps about some things, but I'm not sure, really

author: A
sentence: I mean, I would say that if you're a board member, you're a board member, and it comes with risks and uncertainty

author: A
sentence: If you're a board member you've got to understand that you operate in an environment where you don't have all the information, so you're making decisions in circumstances where you're not all knowing, and there are always risks on the horizon that perhaps you have not contemplated

author: A
sentence: That's the life and times of being a board member and that's what you have to realise when you take on the challenge

author: A
sentence: Now, if you're joining the local P&C or the local - well, think of the local disability services provider

author: A
sentence: There are hordes of organisations with boards that need board members

author: A
sentence: Would you think that's a high-risk area to get into or not, compared with, say, a large mining company that might have an accident at its mine? Not sure what the answer is

author: A
sentence: Certainly, the actions of the mine well get more publicity, but then again, it might not

author: A
sentence: So, your questioning is a bit general, I think

author: A
sentence: I think there is probably a perception out there among some people that if there is a terrible crisis, you don't want too many females on your board, but I just think that is probably a very narrow view

author: A
sentence: Experienced board members are experienced board members, and they understand the ups and downs and the risks in these spaces, good ones, anyway

author: Q
sentence: And you're building that capacity through your programs and that

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And the talks I'm giving this year - I've got about three to give in the next little while, and I've already given a couple - are really trying to impress upon people that if you want to be a board member you've got to think about how you operate in a situation where you don't know everything and decisions are often not black and white, and you have to understand that you have to compromise

author: A
sentence: It's like the modern version of how teams work, really, in today’s sort of knowledge economy

author: Q
sentence: How what works?

author: A
sentence: How teams work

author: Q
sentence: Oh, how teams work

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Okay, good

author: Q
sentence: So, look, I'm interviewing you as an institution, as an organisation from that perspective, but you're on a number of boards, aren't you?

author: A
sentence: Teams

author: A
sentence: Most things in organisations get done by teams these days and teams have to work together, and that means compromise and concessions and whatever

author: Q
sentence: So, now, this sort of moves us in the direction of diversity of - it could be thought of as cognitive diversity or different ways of thinking and how that might be brought together

author: Q
sentence: Do you know what I mean?

author: A
sentence: I think I do

author: A
sentence: Carry on

author: Q
sentence: Well, some people have talked about it being very important, diversity being very important in situations of risk and uncertainty because that's the time when you want diverse perspectives to come together and inform the decision - as you said, have a good conversation

author: Q
sentence: That's when you really need it

author: Q
sentence: So, it becomes critical

author: Q
sentence: So, they’re saying, that's when you most need diversity

author: A
sentence: Well, that might be true, but if a building is burning down, I'm not sure we need to have a discussion about it

author: Q
sentence: [laughs] Yes, true

author: Q
sentence: Oh my god, you sound like a philosopher

author: A
sentence: [unclear] 00:22:59, just to have sensible procedures that have been developed and sensible risk assessments that have been done that in fact do encompass diversity of thought and opinion

author: Q
sentence: And do the board have a role in that? Is that something the board does?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I mean, risk assessment or risk matrices or risk whatever are one of the very key things that boards are expected to pay attention to, because remember, if you're a board member you don't know completely how an organisation works in every detail, but you do bring with you in that board role a range of experiences from other places, and the value you add as a board member is often your understandings of what happens in other places to add value to the board that you're sitting on today, sort of thing

author: A
sentence: It's your life experiences that you bring

author: A
sentence: Those are particularly valuable when you think about risk spaces and organisation

author: A
sentence: And an example the other day that rose in a meeting was that somebody said the top two risks in this organisation are A and B, and clearly they decided that from their perspective as an executive in front of the organisation

author: A
sentence: And in fact, they sort of made the classic mistake and forgot about the customers in the sense that perhaps there are some more important risks than the ones that have been mentioned up to that point, like safety and customer engagement stuff

author: A
sentence: So, we as an outsider could appreciate that and add a bit of value

author: A
sentence: That’s sort of a simple example, but board members potentially have got great value to add from their life experiences, when thinking about, in particular, risk, in my humble opinion

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that’s a good example

author: Q
sentence: It's really clear

author: A
sentence: I am indeed, yes

author: A
sentence: Plenty

author: A
sentence: Do you want to know something about them or not?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: And one of the downsides of things like the banking Royal Commission is to sort of having to put people into boxes a bit and get to the point where there is a list of things you must do and that actually removes the capacity to add in some of the other things

author: A
sentence: Now, that wasn't the intent of the report, I don't think [unclear] 00:25:35, but that is always the temptation for people to do exactly what they've been told

author: A
sentence: And similarly, with risk regimes - you might get consumed by the fact that you've got a smart web-based system that manages a compliance and risk management system, and then you forget to ask what else is happening

author: Q
sentence: See, when I think of these major public reviews that shame organisations, so pose reputational risk, culture seems to come up as a problem, and that's a soft issue

author: Q
sentence: You know what I mean? It's about the people stuff, the interactions between people, the values

author: Q
sentence: What role does the board have in that, because that seems to me to be an important part of risk management?

author: A
sentence: Sorry, can I just get you to repeat that, please?

author: Q
sentence: The culture

author: Q
sentence: The culture of an organisation, the culture of a board - do you think that's an important part of diversity or has diversity -

author: A
sentence: What culture -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: My turn - well, I heard someone talk about culture and express, are we doing the right thing by our customers? And this is a financial services enterprise sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, clearly the board needs to be conscious of how things are done in the organisation

author: A
sentence: They need to understand what the priorities are

author: A
sentence: For example, if you sit on a Qantas aeroplane, they will tell you that safety is our first priority

author: A
sentence: If you walk around Qantas, I hope when you talk to people and say what's important, they’ll say, well, when we have a choice, it's safety, sort of thing

author: A
sentence: If you walk around the financial services institutions, post the Hayne Royal Commission, and you ask them what's important, hopefully they'll say, 'Making sure that we sell the customers things that are fit for purpose for them' type of thing

author: A
sentence: So, culture is a general term, but I think people need to understand what it means on the ground sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, in the organisation

author: A
sentence: That's a very non-culture answer to your question, but it's all gets back to, well, culture; that's the way we do things around here, and then you say, what are the rules? And when I have to make a choice, what is the balance between a and b sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So, that is clearly something that boards should pay a lot of attention to because they're at the top of the organisation

author: A
sentence: If they know people - I mean, they should be on the watch for certain sorts of things, and what might those things be? I don't know, but it could be that our IT systems are so out of date that we know very little about our customers

author: A
sentence: So, we're not servicing them appropriately

author: A
sentence: It might be that we haven't had any security reviews for quite some time

author: A
sentence: That might be an issue, et cetera

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the priorities

author: Q
sentence: Does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others, do you think? And if so, what kind of diversity and why?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, because we can de-identify it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, how many boards are you on?

author: A
sentence: That's a [unclear] 00:29:29

author: Q
sentence: Well, it has to be to you as in your position - well, in your position as a chair on one of your boards - not the women's one - let's say on the Australian Ethical Superannuation when you were there, what kind of diversity matter most in that position, do you think?

author: A
sentence: What kind of diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I mean, diversity is a collection of items that you might think about

author: A
sentence: You've also got to think about what skillsets you need, also think about what experience you've got around the board table from the sector and from outside the sector

author: A
sentence: You need to obviously think about gender diversity

author: A
sentence: You might need to think about geographic diversity because it might be that you've got [unclear] 00:30:32 to have lots of people who were very environmentally conscious and they tended to live in environmentally interesting places, which was outside public view, sort of thing

author: A
sentence: You need to appreciate that

sentence: So [the participant], if I just can jump in – the use of skills matrices obviously fairly old hat and used fairly regularly and it’s certainly been in the ICD, so training material for a while, and behaviour matrices are talked about but have you – there’s obviously some challenges around that but have you – in your experience have you heard of companies endeavouring to use some behavioural matrices in addition to skill matrices?

sentence: I actually thought making an overarching observation and [inaudible] 00:30:27 running the discussion around ethnicity [inaudible] 00:30:29 performing there are a highly specialised role and it’s very easy to set some generalities around it would be good to have people with different ethnicity, etc

sentence: , etc

author: A
sentence: Look I think it’s always helpful to be thinking about how you can increase the pool, people that are candidates for roles

sentence: And if you start off a position where you’re not thinking about 50% of the population that’s not [inaudible] 00:32:40

sentence: So what barriers are there to increasing diversity in Australian company boards do you think?

author: A
sentence: There’s still some – I think we’re still seeing some generational issues if I can say that in those terms

author: A
sentence: [inaudible] 00:33:03 stale as they’re sometimes referred to

author: A
sentence: It wouldn’t necessarily be its opened to views that most people have these days around gender diversity, the same way they wouldn’t be open to views around same sex marriage

author: Q1
sentence: So it’s like a culture of a board then?

author: A
sentence: Not the board, it’s the [inaudible] 00:33:40 sees its values and views of individuals

author: A
sentence: And those views and values tend to differ across generations

author: A
sentence: And there are still some of an older generation on boards of directors that would have different views and values

author: A
sentence: Yeah, correct

author: Q1
sentence: Some boards have to – they only have a three year tenure then they have to go, do you support that idea of a limited timeframe?

author: A
sentence: They don’t have to go

author: A
sentence: If they’re ASX listed companies to my understanding was that you are subject to re-election every three years

author: A
sentence: So in some cases you resign but you have to stand for re-election after every three years

author: A
sentence: Some jurisdictions [inaudible] 00:34:34 my trip to the UK, actually have a requirement that everyone stands for re-election after one year not three years

author: Q1
sentence: What do you think about that?  It’s short

author: A
sentence: I think it’s too short

author: Q2
sentence: I think possibly what Margo was getting at and what I started thinking of in that context was some boards, not necessarily jurisdiction, have caps on the number of terms a director could have, so it could be six years, nine years or whatever

author: Q2
sentence: I’m just interested in whether you think that’s a desirable way to go or not?

author: A
sentence: I think the danger with that approach is if you make it a hard and fast rule you inevitably excluding some people for making a significant contribution to the board

author: A
sentence: It’s an area that we do give some guidance on in the principles and recommendations because one of the relevant considerations for a board is independence, being independent from management and independence from too many shareholders who might have a different view than shareholders as a whole have different interests and other investments

author: A
sentence: And we’re now toying with the idea of putting in a provision which says that, for example, after three terms, nine years or ten years, which is the other common number that people bandy about

author: A
sentence: You should no longer be considered independent

author: A
sentence: We have actually gone so far as principles and recommendations to stress that to the board to determine whether someone has been around theorganisation are no longer a candidate in particular for management

author: A
sentence: I mean a great example outside of that, there’s a very well regarded I don’t know director of a – I won’t name him – of a very large and significant Australian mining company who’s been on the board for the past 20 years who I think all investors would say he’s done a brilliant job as a director and they would rather have him on the board than not

author: Q1
sentence: But do you think if someone’s on the board for that long that there’s then the risk of what you were talking about of the generational affect: the culture of against gender diversity for example?

author: A
sentence: The answer to that is say well what’s the – what’s the counter proposition?  That everyone should be sacked after a period of time?  I don’t think that’s right

author: A
sentence: But you see that in particular the chairman of the board needs to be sensitive to and understand and to work out as part of their succession planning when the director can come off the board, are they stale, are they too closely connected with management and not providing a critical assessment?

author: Q1
sentence: That’s good

author: Q1
sentence: I’ll look closely at the succession planning principles in the – good

author: Q1
sentence: Well that’s – we’re really -

author: Q1
sentence: Right

sentence: Please do

author: Q2
sentence: You’ve talked, understandably, a lot about the governance principles that applies to the listed companies, I’d just like your thoughts – this is actually not in our script but I’d just like your thoughts on what impact you think – let’s just speak gender because you talked about that and there’s a specific prescription – things like the targets and the suggestions and the please explain that it takes place with listed companies to what extent you think it influences the SMEs and unlisted entities?

author: A
sentence: You’re talking about a different scale of operation there

author: Q2
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: So for all what’s appropriate for a listed company might not certainly going to be appropriate for a plumber or an electrician

author: Q2
sentence: But I’m just trying to ascertain whether you think it could be influential, a medium sized enterprise might say these are the behaviours at the big end of town for using that expression, maybe that’s something we need to be looking at as well

sentence: Look I think coming back to that point about with maximising the pool or the talent that you can recruit if you’re ignoring people from particular genders or ethnicities you’re obviously diminishing the pool of available talents to recruit

author: A
sentence: So there’s something for everyone in that but I don’t think you can say because listed companies attack that issue in the way that we are through the governance principles that shouldn’t mean that the should be applied elsewhere

author: A
sentence: That said, there are three other larger organisations that look for the Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations for listed companies for providing guidance on good governance practice

author: A
sentence: And they're often picked up by for example government organisations where not-for-profits and in some case large charities as the benchmark for testing their governance frameworks against

author: Q1
sentence: Good

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, great

author: Q1
sentence: So -

author: A
sentence: What might be appropriate for the listed company might not be appropriate for the local club or an electrician

author: A
sentence: And if you start dividing them into categories, ethnicities, you end up working between hundreds of categories and the whole process becomes meaningless

sentence: Okay so do you have any other thoughts to share on board diversity and on how this diversity should be managed?

sentence: As I said before there are plenty of 18 year olds out there who think they should be entitled to be on the board of a listed company but the reality is they don’t have the skills and experience to do so

author: A
sentence: Wherever possible within the rules we try to have one set of standards apply to all listed companies

author: A
sentence: Now that said it’s proposed then in the fourth edition to make an exception to that general rule and we consulted on the proposition in the fourth edition which, without giving any secrets away, is pretty much soon to be in the fourth – final register of the fourth edition issued that the genders address the targets for the boards to have not less than 30% of each gender on board

author: Q1
sentence: And what happens if people don’t meet that target?  What’s the enforcement?

author: A
sentence: It’s not a legislative provision, it’s a recommendation in a governance code that listed companies are required to report against all, if not one on basis

author: A
sentence: So by that I mean that if you don’t meet the recommendations you have to state that fact in your annual corporate governance statement and it’s like why you don’t meet a recommendation

author: A
sentence: So that gives listed companies the flexibility for example to say we’re in this – for example we’re in this niche specialist area where it’s difficult to get women [inaudible] 00:07:10, specialisation of directors onboards, blah, blah, blah or men for that matter

author: A
sentence: And to explain why if they’re not meeting that that recommendation - so it’s not a hard rule of law it’s a recommendation that could be explained away as it were through that if not why not disclosure requirement

author: Q1
sentence: And who reads these reports, investors or?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well they have a wider circulation than that

author: A
sentence: With the governance disclosures are either contained on the company’s website or in its annual report

author: A
sentence: So anyone who has the chance to pick up an annual report or open a company’s website to find these disclosures

author: Q1
sentence: And do you think it has – makes a difference say to superannuation funds or big investors like that?

author: A
sentence: It most certainly does

author: A
sentence: The level of female participation in the ASX 200 at board level’s gone from around 5% at the time the recommendations were first introduced to actually being close to 30% now

author: A
sentence: So it’s had a dramatic impact since they were introduced in 2010

author: A
sentence: ASX and the Corporate Governance Council’s taking – has taken a fairly leading position ongender diversity on all listed company

author: A
sentence: That started with an amendment to the then second edition of the Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations in 2010 to add gender diversity recommendations

author: A
sentence: As such those recommendations was that a board should have a diversity policy which should set measurable objectives for keeping gender diversity and it should report against those objectives on annual basis

author: A
sentence: That recommendation was typed in the third edition that was issued 2014 and is about to be further typed in the fourth edition which God willing will come out this month – sorry not this month in February

author: A
sentence: But the substance remains the same that boards should be setting [inaudible] 00:01:17 diversity policy setting diversity targets with their organisation and report against the achievement of those targets on an annual basis

author: Q1
sentence: That’s a very quick change

author: A
sentence: Yes needless to say it’s starting to slow a little bit

author: A
sentence: But you could see the – the intent is actually came into effect with the way listed companies – particularly the larger listed companies – is modelled because it’s the large listed companies, that institutional investors are the primary investors and who pull sway with boards and who do regard these domestic issues as significant, particularly gender diversity

author: Q1
sentence: Right

author: Q1
sentence: And do you think that importance is because of their concerns about impacts – the influence of investors or do you think they think it’s important as intrinsically so?

author: A

sentence: Good answer

author: Q1
sentence: Okay the intrinsic side: can you tell me how they think it’s important, like why?

author: A
sentence: Yeah well there are some strange little [inaudible] 00:09:38 that I've referenced in the principles and recommendations that suggests that boards reach better – a better ratio of male and female representation tend to perform better than companies that don’t have a balanced gender diversity

author: Q1
sentence: And do you find that a persuasive argument?  Is that your personal position as well?

author: A
sentence: I aggressively agree with that, yeah

sentence: If you think about [phone ringing] – excuse me – sorry one second

sentence: So you focussed on gender diversity and I understand that - and the stance that come through over the years through the governance principles, but are there any other aspects of diversity that come to mind that you think are important?

author: Q1
sentence: Why you think it’s important

author: A
sentence: If you think about what likely to drive that decision that hands – the type of people who are likely to make that decision around carrying a more diverse – gender diverse board it kind of stands to reason that they’re more likely than not to be more forward thinking rather than lie in the past and probably more closely connected to the investors and their customers and aligning in terms of the values that their investors and customers have and you would expect the companies that are more reliant to the interest of their investors and their customers, they’re going to have to perform better than ones that are not

author: Q1
sentence: Okay so it’s a really – it’s a signifier of a more functional board rather than the gender diversity creates it?

author: A
sentence: Correct

author: Q1
sentence: That’s an interesting -

author: A
sentence: [overtalk] 00:11:49 there’s no longer a board who are making the decisions as to who will replace it eventually

author: A
sentence: More attuned to those types of issues

author: Q1
sentence: Okay so the causal story is still a bit – we’ll leave that aside for a while will we or do you have a sense of how diversity might influence or benefit a board apart from just being a sign of a more forward thinking board?

author: A
sentence: Well as I say there are studies out there, financial and market studies, that suggest that companies with better diverse – better representation by genders on the board tend to perform better than those who don’t have that

author: Q1
sentence: But how it works is a bit vague

author: Q1
sentence: It’s a bit of a black box

author: A
sentence: It’s not so much a black box, as I said before if you think about what they are meaning about the type of people on a board it means they are more likely to be attuned to [inaudible] 00:12:52 if I can use that expression

author: A
sentence: That’s an issue that there’s a little bit of guidance on in the Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations

author: A
sentence: If you have a look at Recommendation 1

author: A
sentence: 5 of the existing third edition you will see there’s a reference in there to it being desirable with the diversity policies that the board sets for the organisations should cover more than just gender diversity

author: A
sentence: But the Council’s recommendation is to specifically focus on gender diversity because for the obvious reasons 50% of our community, slightly more than 50% of the community is of the female gender and therefore the female representation on boards was historically nowhere near that figure of course

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: It’s more likely to have voted yes in same sex marriage is pretty random

author: Q1
sentence: I understand

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, do you feel that board diversity can negatively impact?  So do you think it can negatively impact a board’s decision making performance?

author: A
sentence: Not in and of itself however if you appoint someone to a board just because they happen to be male or female without regard to whether they have the skills or capabilities and the experience to people [inaudible] 00:13:28 then that’s likely to lead to less than optimal outcomes

author: A
sentence: So people who appoint female directors for the sake of just getting their numbers up without actually thinking about whether the female director they’re appointing is the right person for the role, you can see how that would cause issues

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, definitely

author: Q1
sentence: If it was seen to and if it in fact was, yeah

author: Q1
sentence: What about other kinds of diversity though: social, ethnicity, skills, mix, what about those kinds of diversity?  Do you think they might negatively impact board performance?

author: A
sentence: Potentially yeah

author: A
sentence: It really depends on which accent to suit

author: A
sentence: If you’re talking about skills generally you want to have a board that’s got a really full mix of skills carrying off things like obviously accounting and financial issues, some sort of skills and experience in the history of which the company’s operating, legal skills, people skills

author: A
sentence: You want to have – in fact one of the recommendations in the Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations is that boards should have a skills matrix and have regard to that skills matrix when they’re making their determinations around rotation of directors and replacing of directors

author: Q1
sentence: Good

sentence: But let’s move now to the process, could you explain to me how your organisation might seek to influence boards and in particular the priority that they might give to diversity?  And I think you’ve really identified one way

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah with your recommendation

author: A
sentence: [overtalk] 00:15:30 through leadership roles displayed on the ASX Corp Governance Council and that also in its own – ASX obviously sees itself as the exemplar for good corporate governance and it would be [bad] 00:15:49 if it weren't

author: A
sentence: So our board takes the issue of gender diversity fairly seriously

author: A
sentence: We have for quite some time now have a third of our directors as women – more than a third

author: A
sentence: Now there’s a reference to the other types of – I’ll just pull out my copy of the third edition – just bear with me for one second while I find the relevant passage

author: A
sentence: There’s a reference in the statistics and the content of the Diversity Policy in box 1

author: A
sentence: 5: “Organisations should recognise that diversity not only includes gender diversity but also includes matters of age, disability, ethnicity, marital and family status, religious or cultural backgrounds, sexual orientation and gender identity”

sentence: So you’re role modelling?

sentence: Yeah, correct

sentence: , etc

sentence: Okay so the role model and the guidelines

sentence: That’s great

sentence: So regarding selection how do you think new board members should be selected?

author: A
sentence: For large listed companies they would normally have a nomination committee and the nomination committee would suitably determine where there is or what lies being a gap because for example a director’s retiring or – and they would the suitably through the CEO engage a head hunting firm to find a replacement

author: A
sentence: That’s the way it should be done

author: Q1
sentence: And your – the guidelines that you’ve produced do they guide this process?  Do they have a focus on selection and board – well board composition they do but selection process?

author: A
sentence: Yes, there is some guidance around having a nomination committee or if you don’t – if you’re not a large company we warrant having a nomination committee at least disclosing what your processes are around addressing board succession issues

author: A
sentence: So it’s very much the disclosure approach is similar to the approach taken with diversity

sentence: Yes, we do

sentence: For example, because we perform a [inaudible] 00:18:45 in every position that we interview for that there be at least one female candidates and the instructions to look into our [inaudible] 00:18:53

sentence: Can you think of any ways that your organisation helps candidates from minority groups to become attractive board candidates?  Maybe from a low socio-economic background or something like that?

author: A
sentence: If you don’t have the education and experience that you should have skill level, you shouldn’t be on a board

author: A
sentence: These aren’t instruments representing the populous, so we’ve had some politicians, these are people who are running listed companies with serious businesses, so you need to have a set of skills to do that

sentence: Look that’s really interesting

sentence: Could you – that comparison between governance represented democracy versus the governance of a board, could you flesh that out a little more?

sentence: As I said it’s you can’t think of the boards of companies in the same way it would seem for example that parliament should be presentative of the community

sentence: It’s there to make money for shareholders

author: Q1

author: A
sentence: So, again, the best way I can describe it is on - I think one of the reasons that academics are getting more involved in boards is that we think differently

author: A
sentence: Everyone says you have to have a lawyer and you have to have an accountant, and they think - not they, but the layperson, when you say that, they think it's because you need them to do legal stuff or numbers stuff, that [inaudible] 00:29:15

author: A
sentence: That's not what they're doing

author: A
sentence: The lawyer on the board is not doing the legal legwork, and the accountant on the board is not doing the books, but we think differently

author: A
sentence: So, my skill set on our board is my breadth of knowledge about sport, not that sport, but sport in general, my breadth of knowledge and depth of knowledge on governance process, policy, practice, but also, academics brains work differently

author: A
sentence: We look for more meta, bigger, [inaudible] 00:29:45 you know, that kind of stuff

author: A
sentence: So, I'm like, okay, well, I think we're going over in this direction, whereas my banker is very granular in the details of the financials, and my lawyer is all about risk

author: A
sentence: He's a litigation lawyer, so, it's about - and I'm on a number of boards now where I'm watching people who are Directors for a living, so, they are professional Directors, and we had a talk about how you get through all the papers, and one who I expect a lot, she's on lots of big government infrastructure boards, so, very high level, she says that she skims everything, and then the stuff that she knows is her sweet spot, she goes deep, because that's where she can contribute best

author: A
sentence: I think if everyone's the same expertise in depth then you're going to miss all the other stuff

sentence: So, realistically, my only point of diversity is my gender

sentence: Yeah, so, we do have a nominations committee process, and we have a very good, probably too detailed, skills matrix, and we are very aware of requiring different perspectives, to the point where, traditionally sport boards have always been just from the sport, whereas now we've recognised that we needed, in our previous election, we needed someone from more hard core tennis, because we had a great skill mix and a great set of Directors, but we didn't have anyone who lived and breathed it

author: A
sentence: So, I think that that's where you, you know, you need to look at what your skills matrix is

sentence: So, I think there needs to be a visual representation of that board diversity, but really what we're looking for is less about the having the full house of different colours and genders and abilities, but more about having diversity of thought in the board room

sentence: The second one is, if you really do think you need that skill set in the boardroom where you're discussing the strategy you can co-opt

author: A
sentence: So, I think we have mechanisms in governance which allow us to bring that expertise in for specific discussions or decisions, but I think that's a perfect example for a co-opted member to come in, to lead through that particular decision

author: A
sentence: I think we're stewards, and we're meant to have a long term horizon, and I think if you're creating a board structure where every three years you're pivoting and bringing people into the fit, yeah, we're meant to be stewards and we're mean to be the ones who are forward looking and, you know, assessing longer term risks and managing through - because your management, by definition, has to manage the day to day, it's our job to keep that longer scale

author: A
sentence: So I think if you're continually going, oh, well - I mean [inaudible] 00:49:35 blockchain's the next big thing you need to get a whole lot of people who know blockchain on the board, yes, but only if you think that it's part of your longer term, which it should be for everybody because it's going to be, but that idea, it's because it's part of where our industry is going and where our industry is moving, not because it's the latest thing
