sentence: Okay, so you separate fad from a serious long-term major paradigm

author: A
sentence: Yeah, because the people on the board are setting the strategic direction for your organisation

author: A
sentence: Generally they should be on for a minimum couple of terms, so you're looking at about a six to maybe 10-year horizon

author: A
sentence: You don't look to be pivoting every three years because you're getting new people on involved for a specific project

author: Q2
sentence: So, clarifying that, blockchain, fine, I understand that, but for example, a common criticism, or an issue, I know, with a lot of boards at the moment is, there's not a lot of people who really are on top of IT, IT governance, data, algorithm governance, et cetera

author: Q2
sentence: Now, the way the world is going, in any organisation of any size I think getting someone who can provide those sorts of skills is very different from the latest fad

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and that's long-term horizon, absolutely

author: Q2
sentence: Okay, so that's the distinction, yeah

author: A
sentence: So my thing's about the horizon, that if you're looking at appointing Directors for actually a three year thing, then that's not - we know that they can have three year terms and they might be gone, but realistically you should be assuming that they're contributing, even if they're only there for three years, their view is longer than three years, and if it's less than three years, employ a consultant

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, it's a project

author: A
sentence: It's a project, it's not a strategy

author: Q2
sentence: I'm just conscious of time, so, Margo is -

author: Q1
sentence: The means to that end is having a diverse group?

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, the last questions

author: A
sentence: [overtalk] 00:51:19 me, I'm literally going to go home to bed, so, you're fine

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q1
sentence: So, now we're just at, the final questions are on cultivating diversity as you've discussed it

author: Q1
sentence: Does your board do anything to cultivate new potential members?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: So, we have an active nom-comm, and we trawl our connections and go abroad, we choose our Chair really carefully

author: A
sentence: So, the reason we've got such good gender diversity now is because five years ago the nom-comm Chair was chosen as a woman who had been tasked by the government to find more women on boards

author: A
sentence: So, she completely changed [inaudible] 00:51:56 put a nom-comm in place, and her job was to find, because we can't find any, to find women, and she provided a list of 10 ready to go women

author: A
sentence: Some of us were [inaudible] 00:52:08, some of us do not, but that process was cultivated absolutely

author: Q1
sentence: So, was this like a Women on Boards thing held, or -?

author: A
sentence: No, the Australian Sports Commission made it very clear for national bodies that they had to have 40%

author: A
sentence: Basically, National peak sporting organisation saw the writing on the wall, so we gotto 50% just before the announcement was made that they were going to make it

author: A
sentence: It was very clear in the sort environment that it was going that way, but also then it's now paid off, so the CEO last election with no prompting to a list, there was no list anymore, we had three women apply for two vacancies because we were visibly a board that encouraged and welcomed female Directors

author: A
sentence: So, I know at least a couple of them would not have put their hand up five years ago, the candidates

author: Q1
sentence: So, it's encouraged women to come forward?

author: A
sentence: Yep, so now we're like a [inaudible] 00:53:04, we've got the women sorted, and we still are very aware [inaudible] 00:53:08 the requirement to have 40%, so the succession process is looking at who's going to roll off, at what year do we need to focus back on women, that kind of stuff, because it's a legislative requirement, but then there's also that skill based thing

author: A
sentence: You know, one of our lawyers dropped off, we had a long discussion of, what is the skill set that you need, where would we go for that, those kinds of things

author: A
sentence: So, yeah, we have a really good nom-comm

author: Q1
sentence: Non-comm?

author: A
sentence: Nomination committee

author: A
sentence: People that aren't the same, yeah

author: Q1
sentence: Right, thank you

author: Q1
sentence: That's good

author: A
sentence: You'll learn the acronyms

author: Q1
sentence: So, more generally, do you think diversity should be increased in Australia -?

author: Q2
sentence: Or how do you think it can be?

author: A
sentence: How?

author: Q1
sentence: Or how

author: A
sentence: Go and look for them

author: A
sentence: The only thing that stops them is people say they can't find us, and I say 'us' in the [inaudible] 00:53:55

author: A
sentence: The fact that we still have boards saying that they cannot find suitably qualified women is just delusional, because there are so many programs out there

author: A
sentence: It's a very good time to be a woman wanting to be on a board, because there are people clamouring for you

author: A
sentence: Now, that being said, I'm not saying everyone is ready to go, but the fact that people still come out and say they can't find them, and it would be exactly the same for any group, that, well, we just can't find you

author: A
sentence: Well, just go and look

author: A
sentence: I think the difference is, the lesson learned from the women's thing is we don't necessarily put our hand up, we wait to be asked, and that's where you have to have that nominations process or that recruitment process

author: A
sentence: We actually go and engage people

author: Q2
sentence: That's a basic psychological trait [inaudible] 00:54:40 show

author: A
sentence: But also, like, I assumed I wasn't qualified, and two and a half years later I'm the Chair

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q1
sentence: Do you think it's an informal network thing where maybe the dominant, like, males might be told, this is how you ask?

author: Q1
sentence: So, you would question, if you saw a homogenous group, whether there could be diverse thought?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: It's also the smoke and mirrors of how you get on a board, because - again, in some ways, sport boards are easier because they're elected, so we still generally have more elected than appointed, and people will like people like them, so of course you're going to keep getting the same until, as I said, we created the shift where women, like, it's a safe place for me to put my hand up

author: A
sentence: Corporate boards, it's a very different process of how you get on

author: A
sentence: They're using more head hunters now, so the head, there could be some work needed to be done with international search firms

author: A
sentence: But that being said, there is a shift, so, the fact that ASX companies now have to report on diversity and it's seen as a point of difference and that kind of stuff, and the [Raeger] 00:55:46 stuff, you know, there are carrots and sticks that are starting to roll out

author: A
sentence: But I think the biggest issue is that people love to work with people like them, and it's easier for me - so, we're going through this recruitment process, I was very aware the candidate that I preferred was very like me, so I constantly had to check myself that I wasn't just - that she was a good candidate, it wasn't just because I was like, oh, that's like me

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, comfortable

author: A
sentence: Comfortable, yeah

author: A
sentence: Whereas I think traditionally we haven't had that level of visibility of our unconscious bias or those kinds of things

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: A
sentence: But you're also trying to change 100 something year old organisations

author: Q1
sentence: Yes, but this unconscious bias you're talking about, in the selection process is it the role of the chair to talk about this?

author: A
sentence: Yes, and the Chair of the nominations committee

author: Q1
sentence: And the Chair of the nominations

author: Q2
sentence: That would be the critical one

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Now, obviously, everyone's not going to think exactly the same, and I know that some of the push for gender diversity on boards has been criticised, it was like, well, a rich/middle class, white, well-educated lady is, not terribly different to a rich/middle class well educated white man

author: A
sentence: There is some difference because of gender, but realistically if they've come through the same private school system and they both work in banking, you know, they're more similar than not

author: A
sentence: So, I think homogeneity doesn't mean that there's no diversity in thought, same as having diversity in how the board looks doesn't mean diversity in thought

author: A
sentence: I think that's why I separated out the people from what they look and feel like, because I think there's also that messaging of diversity in the view of the board, as opposed to knowing how the board works as a brain

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q1
sentence: And so they do?

author: A
sentence: They don't get to the board until they've come through the nominations process, so not for profit or State boards that [inaudible] 00:56:49 nominations process, so State - statutory authorities have to, you have to go to a register

author: A
sentence: Corporate boards, it's a bit more smoke and mirrors, and that's where you'd need to talk about international search firms, but also, there's still a lot of nodding and winking

author: Q1
sentence: So, what's the way around that if we want to increase diversity on boards?

author: A
sentence: I think there's a shift, and I say this with love, but some of the women in corporate environments, when they started as the ceiling breakers there was only one position for one woman, and they fought for it and over it, and there was a, not everyone, but there was a kicking of the ladder out behind you

author: A
sentence: I don't see it that much anymore

author: A
sentence: So, I now see women saying, "I know someone who's perfect for that role

author: A
sentence: " So, a bit like that discussion around mentoring versus sponsoring

author: A
sentence: Paul is less my mentor and more my sponsor, so, yeah, I can chat about where my career should go, but Paul's also the one that goes, "[the participant] should do this role, you should talk to her

author: A
sentence: That's what women lack, and the reason - and that's why mentoring hasn't worked, per se, is because the men were still getting tapped on the shoulder by the men above them

author: A
sentence: That's that sponsoring mechanism, we need to sponsor people up, so as soon as we get a few up then they start to - then they see, oh, that's a great person, the other people we've never ever seen before

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's just about getting to the point of having enough diversity that then it just naturally starts to come

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: Q1
sentence: So, we're talking gender

author: Q1
sentence: The other kinds of diversity?

author: A
sentence: I think it would be the same

author: Q1
sentence: But it's because of - these mechanisms are dependent on the current culture, which you say is changing, but the story is around gender

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Carrots and sticks

author: A
sentence: It's about -

author: Q1
sentence: Right

author: Q1
sentence: That message of diversity -?

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: Q1
sentence: [inaudible] 00:58:50

author: A
sentence: I don't think you're going to see it - I believe in quotas

author: A
sentence: You're not going to see a fundamental change until there is a stick

author: A
sentence: The fact that my organisation has had a sport for men and women for over 100 years and had never had a decent amount of women on the board - it had its first woman on the board in the '70s, and it had world champions, and it has never had a female chair

author: A
sentence: So, I was the first in the country, State female President, and only 18 months before I started, we had Australia's first female Chair of the national body

author: A
sentence: So, it's not about the environment, because it's not like there aren't women tennis people

author: Q2
sentence: So, you're talking quotas as opposed to a target? [inaudible] 00:59:40 the ASX going?

author: A
sentence: No one meets targets

author: A
sentence: Why would you?

author: Q1
sentence: Quotas are regulated

author: A
sentence: Quotas are regulated, and I think the idea - no one wants to commit

author: Q2
sentence: So, I'll flip it another way, because we've heard this as well, and we're going to hear this, particularly when we've got the corporates, isn't the danger, though, particularly when you've got a corporate who's saying, yeah, it's great to have all this diversity, but ultimately we've got to have the diversity of thoughts, skills, et cetera, et cetera to deliver profit to an organisation, all that sort of stuff, isn't it the danger that because you've got to rigidly adhere to a quota, you end up appointing a couple of people who are suboptimal on the other things we've been talking about, and then, if either a bad decision happens or they're just performing badly in the board or whatever, you actually can send things backwards

author: A
sentence: So, I think my response to that is, yes, that's the fear

author: A
sentence: There have been centuries of men stuffing things up, and no one has ever said, well men have shagged this board

author: Q1
sentence: They shouldn't be on the board, yeah

author: A
sentence: They shouldn't be on the board, so, no, you will have women who stuff it up

author: A
sentence: The thing I always find, because I come from a quite political family, the thing I always find the most amusing about the NLP's approach to not having quotas to their party is that they have shitloads of quotas

author: A
sentence: They have a designated number of National positions, and the Deputy Prime Minister has to be National, and they have to have this much media representation

author: A
sentence: There are quotas everywhere, they just don't want that one

author: A
sentence: So, if shareholders are looking at what the board looks like, or in my case, its members are looking at the board

author: A
sentence: My members can look at my board and they can see that it's now 60% women, they can see old and young, they can see tennis and not tennis, and they can see people of colour

author: A
sentence: So, it looks diverse

author: Q2
sentence: Well, the Party thing I can understand, because [inaudible] 01:01:18 representatives as well, but just pushing the board thing a bit further, ultimately when you're so performance driven, it's not about [inaudible] 01:01:33 or what, but isn't there a problem -  and we're just going to get this, right, so I'm just rehearsing it here, isn't there a problem if clearly, because you've got a quota, you've got to get this last person on, or these two people on, who, sitting around the table, within 30 seconds it's very clear that they're operating at a different level

author: A
sentence: So, my response would be, you've not looked hard enough

author: Q2
sentence: Sorry?

author: A
sentence: My response would be they've not looked hard enough

author: A
sentence: Sure, in the '70s when there hadn't been as many women with business careers or business, you know, entrepreneurs or academics or whatever, there have been professors in business schools and partners in the Big Four, and whatever metric you want to use, Supreme Court judge’s blah, blah, blah, who have been women, for about 50 years now

author: A
sentence: You can't tell me that there's not, I mean - and again, that analogy,there's more Johns than there is women

author: A
sentence: So, it's a straw argument, and I know the people who have that argument believe it, so for them it's not a straw, it's a straw man argument

author: A
sentence: They're not looking for them

author: A
sentence: Either they don't want to look for them, or they've created a culture that the women don't want to work for

author: A
sentence: So, I don't think it's as much about - yeah, some of it's about not being let in, some of it's, oh, Jesus, I wouldn't want to touch that with a 10-foot pole

author: A
sentence: Or, the thing that we often see is, but it's in politics as much as with business, that they get the golden parachute, where they get given the reins of the business just before it's about to crash

author: A
sentence: So, the blokes all get kicked out and they give it to a woman to fix it, and then as soon as it's back on some sort of track the men strut back in and take it back off them again

author: A
sentence: So, it's not that they're not capable or they can't find t hem, they're just not really looking, and there's - I will always point out that if you did, in any organisation, a real skills assessment of the men who are in charge, you would find a decent number who are pretty shitty at their job, who could be replaced by an equally shitty woman

author: A
sentence: Do you know what I mean? I don't think it's about the - you know if they're talking about -

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q2
sentence: Oh, okay

author: Q2
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and feel free to use that in the quote, but you know what I mean, the whole idea about it being on merit, it's like, well, if your bar of merit is pretty low, then we can find you women with equally bad skills

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, we can match

author: A
sentence: We can match it, so - and I think also, too, it's that thing of, that we do have to try harder, so I have to be way better than my male counterparts, because I have to be

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, so, demographic diversity

author: Q1
sentence: Yes, if it's on merit alone it would be -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I have to be infinitely better to get the gig

author: Q1
sentence: But in a - with gender I can see that you would see this, but with other kinds of diversity, going back to our earlier conversation, gender's 50% of the population, but other kinds of diversity like cultural background, ethnicity, disability, whatever, what about those? Quotas? Targets?

author: A
sentence: It would - I would be less comfortable about that, because you can have a woman of colour, and then you've ticked two boxes, so again, which box is - are you putting them in the woman box or the colour box, or do you get two boxes for the price of one? I think -

author: Q1
sentence: Or don't have women, women are part of the population? Move on to something else?

author: A
sentence: Yeah and that's the end point

sentence: I think the reason that women are easy to quota is because it's a binary - sorry, it's not a binary, gender, queer, you know -

author: Q1
sentence: I know

sentence: It used to be

author: A
sentence: Realistically it's a binary

author: A
sentence: Again, you would argue - there would be a number of people that would argue if you look at the ASX200 boards there's a whole lot of second-generation Australians, that their parents were post war immigrants, do we count them as diverse? Probably, if we were being genuine, but because their names Peter we don't

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, we don't count it

author: A
sentence: That's what I mean, so I think it's about the - it's much harder to, like I said earlier, and I was being flippant, but how brown are you? Another thing about me is same sex attraction, I'm sure there's heaps of gay people on company boards, they just don't tell everybody about it

author: A
sentence: There would be lots of people with disabilities involved in boards, we don't count it, so I would be hesitant to put quotas in place for stuff that we don't know what the benchmark is

author: A
sentence: We don't know what the baseline is

author: A
sentence: It looks kind of white, but is it literally colour or is it diversity, because Australia, and particularly in Melbourne, we have 50 something percent of the community are born somewhere else or have parents who are born somewhere else

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: We might all think exactly the same way

author: A
sentence: No, we don't, but we could arguably all think the same way, but we look diverse

author: A
sentence: So, I think there's a bit of the look as well as the actual thinking

author: Q1
sentence: Dual citizenship

author: A
sentence: Yeah, or dual - you know, if they're English immigrants or Irish immigrants, is that -?

author: Q2
sentence: Yeah

author: A

author: Q1
sentence: Like, how far back do you go?

author: A
sentence: It gets contrived, because when people talk about ethnic diversity what they're really talking about is the visible bit of what colour are you? And you could have been - I mean, indigenous Australians are the perfect example of that

author: A
sentence: That's, you know, it's about the colour of them, not their background, so I think that's where it gets -

author: Q1
sentence: I get that, but there's a part of me that then things, well, now we've reduced diversity to gender if you go along the idea of what unit of measure you can then regulate around, or you can promote and allow the market to choose accordingly

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think we just don't know enough yet -

author: Q1
sentence: What -

author: A
sentence: So, I mean, we talk about the bamboo ceiling, so, there's all the Asian graduates coming in the '70s and '80s who hit the bamboo ceiling, so every - I think basically the message is that everyone who's not old white man has got a ceiling

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's less now about - the quotas is a good way of kind of busting something through, the idea now would be, now that you've broken it, that you can then do bigger cultural shifts

author: Q2
sentence: So, just to push that a bit further, I can understand, particularly in an organisation like this, with rugby or tennis or whatever, that that look is really important, because ultimately, it's kind of, you're looking after the interests of the members and so on

author: Q2
sentence: Would you think that look, I'm not talking about [inaudible] 00:05:15, I accept that, but that look is as important if you're a for profit corporate, without that sort of -?

author: A

author: Q1

author: A
sentence: So, yeah, I think it's a cultural shift now

author: A
sentence: I'd just be really hesitant putting quotas on stuff that it's really hard to measure

author: Q1
sentence: Age? What about age?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely, age

author: Q1
sentence: So, you could do a quote on age?

author: A
sentence: I wouldn't do a quota, but absolutely you could - but I think that - and again, organisations are starting to do it

author: Q1
sentence: Yes, you could

sentence: Do you want a pen?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, because it implies, now again, [inaudible] 00:05:26, I'm not naive, but it implies that they're going to be very similar life experience and very similar way of viewing the world

author: A
sentence: So, as I said, bringing women in implies diversity of thought

author: A
sentence: Now, there would be, I would argue that there's not - that women, even if they are very similar background and experience and things like that, are still going to be slightly different

author: A
sentence: I think just what I was cautioning is that sometimes we overstate that difference, that if we get the same type of people, even if they're different genders, you're still not going to have the broader diversity you're looking for

author: Q1

author: A
sentence: Because you'd [inaudible] 01:08:23 of skill and experience, and that sometimes comes with age, but not always

author: A
sentence: So, if you found a 20-something year old candidate who was a genius in all the stuff you wanted them to do, get them

author: A
sentence: But they are, and I mean, I feel very old saying this, they are few and far between, so it would depend again on what the purpose of the organisation was

author: A
sentence: Do I want a 25-year-old [inaudible] 01:08:44 a business or running a bank? No

author: A
sentence: Do I want them running a not for profit for youth mental health? Sure

author: A
sentence: So, again, it's not about - it's fit for purpose

author: A
sentence: What's the mission of the organisation, what's the best board to fulfil that mission?

sentence: Okay

sentence: So, again, you've got to be representative of the community that you're responsible for

author: A
sentence: So, if [inaudible] 01:09:15 based organisations or advocacy bodies don't represent [inaudible] 01:09:21, so if you're talking about mental health, you'd want people who have either caring or actual experience of mental health, and vice versa, what I wouldn't want is then that to be translated into, you have to have someone who's had mental [inaudible] 01:09:33 on every board, everywhere

author: A
sentence: That, it's not fit for purpose

sentence: Whereas a gender quota is very clearly - there is no one in any organisation that gender is not, they're not represented

sentence: But absolutely, when I talk about the importance of - so, our organisation is a champion of change for gender diversity in the sport sector in Victoria

author: A
sentence: We very much talk about you can't be what you can't see, we need to be representative of our members, we're a 50/50 gender sport, you know

author: A
sentence: The fact that before I was on the board there'd been never more than 20% women, and there has never in 100 plus years been a female president in a sport that has equal - you know, it's not like we're footy or soccer or rugby, we're tennis

author: A
sentence: Tennis has always had women playing, so I think that was an important step in basic representation, but I - it's not enough to just throw women at it and it's going to fix it

sentence: So, you're associated with State sector boards?

sentence: So, how do mandated requirements such as quotas influence public sector boards, when and how were they introduced on your board, and what are the pros and cons? We've talked about some of that, but when, just, was it -?

sentence: So, State government board, MOPT, Melbourne Olympic Park Trust, is mandated, so it has to have 50%, and I think that got ratified last year

sentence: So, all the State boards now, government boards, would have to have 40% in 2018

sentence: All evidence points to the fact that a more diverse board makes better decisions

author: A
sentence: I don’t hold the position that women are more moral or anything like that, because I'm sure - I mean, I can think of some high-profile political examples where they're pretty [inaudible] 00:07:12 some horrible people, so I don't think that women are all the good guys and men are all the bad guys

author: A
sentence: I know that there are equal - but I do think because of that diversity of thought you get better decisions

author: A
sentence: Same as, one of the examples I will often use, Cheryl [inaudible] 00:07:30 book gets criticised a bit, but one of the things that was really clear is that she didn't realise how important parking was for women who were pregnant until she was pregnant

author: A
sentence: So, even if there are women who are rich bankers in their 60's on the board, if they've had a family, they will have a different experience of, this is what maternity leave was like, or this is what it's like trying to juggle family, so let’s not forget about people who have other caring responsibilities

author: A
sentence: I think even more so now, that's less about parenting and more about that sandwich generation, so probably people like yourself, Paul, who are caring up and down, so, looking after grandkids and looking after elderly parents

author: A
sentence: So, I think that sort of stuff is where those diverse - the women can bring - even if you're a hard-arse business woman, you're still going to have had in most cases some caring responsibilities

author: A
sentence: Even if you don't have kids, you might be caring for parents

author: Q1
sentence: Yep

author: Q1
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q1
sentence: Thanks

author: Q1
sentence: Do you think -

author: A
sentence: Sorry, I said a swear word

author: A
sentence: I little bit of a swear word

author: Q1
sentence: Oh, it's okay, we'll delete it

author: Q1
sentence: Do you think diversity of Australian boards is important?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q1
sentence: Because of that decision making?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, that would be great

author: A
sentence: I think more for business reasons, yes, but I also think Australian culture, we like to think that we're egalitarian and we like to think that everyone can, so I think it would be an important part of our narrative that we don't - we are, but we don't see ourselves as a class-based community

author: A
sentence: So, I think that idea that if you're got broader representation fits better into people's narrative

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, but, is there a particular kind of diversity that you think matters more for the outcomes you think are important, like decision making?

author: A
sentence: Like sociodemographic type, or [overtalk] 00:09:14?

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah, any particular - it doesn't matter

author: A
sentence: No, and I think

author: A
sentence: to be honest, the biggest step change that is noticeable in my industry, in sport, is that we're seeing a larger number of younger Directors

author: A
sentence: So, Holly Ransom is a perfect example of that, who's on the - she's one of the world's social tech entrepreneur type people, she owns very big businesses, she's on the speaking circuit, but she's on the Port Adelaide Football Club board and she lives in Brisbane

author: A
sentence: So, they brought her on, obviously, women, but also a completely different football team, so she's not a fan of that team

author: A
sentence: She sees it differently, she's young

author: A
sentence: I think the youth aspect is where boards are starting to reach down into, again, not as representation, but acknowledging that they might not have 30 years’ experience, but they have experience or skills in those fast-movingmarkets or understanding what your new market's going to do

author: Q1
sentence: Yep

author: Q1
sentence: What about disability? Physical disability?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, look, if it's the right person, sure

author: A
sentence: Again, I would always caution, and I do this with my broader diversity inclusion work, of them having to have a full house approach

author: A
sentence: I think sometimes people feel like they need to have one of each set, to collect them all

author: A
sentence: You can have a wide range of people on your board, if some of them happen to have a disability that's great

author: A
sentence: I think it would depend also, too, on your organisation

author: A
sentence: So, I've always, I'm a bit of a lefty, so, don't talk about us without us, so if you're a disability organisation you should have people with a disability on there, same as if you're an indigenous organisation

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so, there are times when actual representation is important, so in my case it's tennis, we can't not have no tennis on the board

author: A
sentence: If there is someone from the tennis community who is a wheelie, then that's great, but am I going to actively fight for my bank to have someone with a disability on there? I don't know if that's - I think it shouldn't be an exclusion, I don't know that you need to - yeah, that's getting the full house trump approach

author: A
sentence: Not Trump, as in politician, but trump card approach, is not - I think that then becomes a mechanism of tick-boxing as opposed to actually looking for ways to be inclusive

author: Q1
sentence: So, I keep wanting to - there's other questions that could lead off of that, but I better stick to the thing

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: Q2
sentence: So, as you know, this is just a pilot, and we will re-sort out the questions and that sort of stuff once we've done the pilot, the usual stuff about confidentiality, aggregation, et cetera, some of that

author: Q2
sentence: Margo will be the one asking all the primary questions, because she's going to be the constant through the main study

author: Q2
sentence: Karen [Farquharson] 00:00:28, Suzanne Young and I are the others on it, and [inaudible] 00:00:31 one of the analytics people

author: Q2
sentence: We'll be hit and miss

author: Q1
sentence: Do you feel the boards diversity can have positive effects on the board’s decisions? You've already said that

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q1
sentence: Do you feel that board diversity can negatively impact the boards decisions and performance?

author: A
sentence: In a living example that I'm going through right now, we're trying to recruit our CEO and it is taking us three weeks to make the decision, because we have strong diversity of opinion

author: A
sentence: so, we have two final candidates, they're both excellent, they both can do a good job

author: A
sentence: We are struggling as a board to land on a decision

author: A
sentence: I think we've just about got there, but it's taking exceptionally longer than if we just had have had one majority of thinking versus another

author: Q1
sentence: Right

author: A
sentence: Because it's not so much about the people now, it's more about the strategy of the organisation, so what, which direction we are going will point to which candidate, and we are diversing where we think the organisation is best placed to go

author: A
sentence: So, it's taking us a longer time to make a decision, which means it's going to be a better decision, but for someone like myself who, Paul will know, I don't like waiting around and not making decisions, so - yeah, I think that's a double-edged sword

author: A
sentence: I think you can view it as a negative because it can get drawn out and complex, but I do think at the end of it, it will be a better decision

author: A
sentence: But it's frustrating

author: Q1
sentence: [the participant], you are in a unique position, so I'm going to ask you this question, as Chair, because you're the Chair of this board, how are you managing that decision? What are some of the key things you do?

author: A
sentence: I'm trying to lead from behind

author: A
sentence: So, I do have a tiebreak, we're in a nine-member board, so I can come in over the top, but that's not how we roll

author: A
sentence: We are a consensus board, and we're not, you know, track - we're a six and a half million dollar, 50 plus staff operation, not for profit, so I don’t, you know, want us to be in that situation

author: A
sentence: We need to be a consensus board, so I have been encouraging dialogue and discussion with the Directors where we've landed those that we ended up having - that was largely done in person, but a lot by email after the final interviews, that we've very clearly landed in a nearly 50/50 split, so I'm now forcing another meeting because we need to sit down and nut it out, it can't be done by email anymore

author: A
sentence: So, again, avoiding coming in over the top with just a simple tiebreak, because effectively, the way I view this is you would disenfranchise half your board, and you would have a new CEO, regardless of who it is, starting with half the board not happy with the decision

author: A
sentence: Now, I'm not suggesting we'll get to a consensus where everyone's happy, but we will get to a consensus where we will have a united decision to take to our members that we will all talk as, that decision is our decision, not -

author: Q1
sentence: Them

author: Q1
sentence: [inaudible] if you want to withdraw

author: Q1
sentence: [inaudible] 00:00:40

author: A
sentence: Not that they've all decided it, if that makes sense?

author: Q1
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: So, I'm pushing that, yeah, that we now - I've now had a small tanty and told them they have to turn up to another meeting

author: Q1
sentence: And you said that it's based in a difference of opinion about strategy, so will that be resolved as part of this, or that will be [inaudible] 00:14:38?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and look, I don't think all of the board have articulated that that's what it is, but again, I've got a different level of, sorry, that my day job as an academic helps, kind of - you can get [meta] 00:14:49, and that's where I've, you know, we were going around in circles, and with that leading from behind I was able to go, okay, well, it's actually not about the skill, because we're going, well, the skills are the same

author: A
sentence: You know, same but different, equally qualified in different ways, equally engaging in different ways, equally good cultural fit in different ways

author: A
sentence: So, it's like, okay, it's not about the people, it's about where we're going, and who will best deliver that

author: A
sentence: So, I don't know if most - if all of the board have articulated that that's actually what we're arguing about, not the people

author: A
sentence: Because we would be fine with either, we'd just go slightly different directions, and again, we're not doing a 180 with each, but there's enough of a difference that, yeah, it's been -

author: Q1
sentence: And each CEO option is seen as taking a different direction?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and, I mean, the best analogy is a safe pair of hands versus a bit of a step change, and half the board, as human nature, would like a safe pair of hands and for things not to change too much

author: Q1
sentence: Great, okay

author: Q1
sentence: Well, that's helpful, because we come up with the questions -

author: A
sentence: You didn't know I was so grown up, did you?

author: Q1
sentence: So, how does diversity influence your board's functioning, do you think? Do different kinds of diversity make it - do you think different kinds of diversity might have a different effect on the board functioning?

author: A
sentence: Withdraw back to the house, but -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Look, I think we've got - at our last election in October, we ended up with 60% women, so for the first time ever we had an election with two vacancies and three females stood, so we've now got that, which has been interesting

author: A
sentence: In this decision making process there has been a push back that we're corporate, and it's like, well, none of us are actually corporate, we just feel different, but we've got - so, a Mayor of a regional city is one of our - we've got the second in charge of the Institute of Sport, we've got, of course, a lawyer, a banker, you know, all of those different types of people, academic, and then we're got someone whose entire lifeblood is tennis, so they've been a high level coach and they run big tennis centres

author: A
sentence: We've got a good mix

author: A
sentence: I think it makes our decisions - and, I mean, the best example I can give you is, we've got an older lady who has been on the board since the dawn of time, we've finally brought fixed terms in a year ago and she's on the very end of a grandfathered fixed term arrangement, but she has played an important role of being, one, incredibly annoying, but two, reminding us about what a whole chunk of our membership is like, and if we're not helping her understand why we're doing what we're doing, then we're not going to be able to do that with our members

author: A
sentence: So, I think that's where the diversity plays in

author: A
sentence: Even if you think, okay, that's old, and old way of doing it, we need to move, there's a whole lot of our community that are still very much that way of doing it, so we need to understand them

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: Q1
sentence: How is it that she's not a token?

author: A
sentence: Well, she was there first

author: A
sentence: If anyone was going to be a token it would be me, because I'm appointed, I'm not elected

author: A
sentence: It was interesting, we were a bit nervous about how the community would respond to an appointed Director being elected Chair, because that's a board appointment, and there was none, but we were ready

author: A
sentence: There was initially some push back in the constitutional change that happened before my time, that that shouldn't be allowed, a President shouldn't be allowed to be appointed, they should only be elected from the membership, but there's been nothing

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's about the people in the role, not the [inaudible] 00:18:48 probably get people coming in, not the mechanism behind it

author: A
sentence: But, yeah, so, she was there first

author: A
sentence: But that being said, the new people - so, one of our Directors was just appointed, elected for the first time in October, she has a corporate background in her day job, but she's from a local community tennis club and the local community voted for her

author: A
sentence: Her platform isn't, I'm a digital IT project manager, her platform is, I'm the membership secretary of the Carlton Gardens Tennis Club, you know, which is very much community focused

author: A
sentence: They have a very strong queer community, so they have an annual drag tournament, you know, so it's - her day job might be quite corporate, but that's not the club that she comes from

author: A
sentence: So, I think it’s - yeah

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, that's good

author: Q1
sentence: Can you think of ways that boards can [overtalk] 00:19:41

author: Q1
sentence: This relates to that, can you think of any ways that boards can help Directors from minority groups feel comfortable with the board, and to feel free to fully participate in decision making?

author: A
sentence: It has to be genuine, so, that's why I think I made that comment I did about people with a disability

author: A
sentence: If you're only putting them on because that collects the set, then they're going to know that

author: A
sentence: No one wants tokenism, it's the same as all the research supporting that you need a minimum of three women otherwise they're not going to be listened to, or they will be deferred to as fixing the women’s - oh, this is a women’s thing, so we'll talk to you

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's about making it normal that we are diverse, and that it is about diversity of opinion rather than anything else

author: A
sentence: The reason I can say that confidently is, our person of colour on our board has come from a very privileged background, he's a litigation lawyer, from a long time ago Portuguese/Sri Lankan heritage

author: A
sentence: So, he's dark skinned but he's been brought up in Melbourne with a very white, private school kind of background, and it wasn't until he was at a national tennis event where all of the other Presidents and stuff were in the room that he ever realised he wasn't the same as all of them

author: A
sentence: It's the first time he'd ever twigged that he was [inaudible] 00:21:30, because his live wasn't brown

author: A
sentence: I know this sounds very esoteric, but his life wasn't as a coloured person, his life was as an influential, well paid, private school lawyer

author: A
sentence: Because he called me straight afterward and said, "I felt for the first time what women must feel like when they walk into a room full of men," because it was the first time he looked around a room of 50 people, and he was the only person there who wasn't an old white man

author: Q1
sentence: Wow!

author: Q2
sentence: You get used to it, as well, I can say from experience

author: Q2
sentence: I don't notice it now

author: Q1
sentence: Yes, but not from the study [inaudible] 00:00:46

author: A
sentence: He didn't think - it was the first time he had looked around and went, wow, no, they are all very white, very particular cookie cutter, and he was more reflecting on, oh, this must be how [the participant] feels, as opposed to his experience

author: Q1
sentence: So, apart from that [inaudible] 00:22:14 what you see, was there anything that that group did that made him feel that way, or it was just sheerly the visual impact?

author: A
sentence: I think it was just, you know, I think he got bored in the meeting and looked around -

author: Q1
sentence: For a reason

author: A
sentence: -@ and became very aware that everyone looked exactly the same

author: Q1
sentence: Okay, because you are about what it looks - what you see is really important, the visual cues?

author: A
sentence: I think so, because I think, even if you're not - you know, you can be exceptionally well qualified, and I think most women would say this, but you are very aware if you're the only one, and you would change your behaviour - and they change their behaviour around me

author: A
sentence: There's a lot of very old white men who do not know how to engage with me, and not because I'm not skilled or can do my job, they think I'm doing a great job, they just don't know how to talk to me because they're not what I'm used to - I'm sorry, I'm not what they're used to

author: Q1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q1
sentence: So, they're asking - so, it's like they're asking them, then, you're different -

author: A
sentence: Well, it's more that you can just see them, and I mean, it's groups of men versus groups of women, we really have different behaviours when we're in group versus mixed, but you can see them kind of be aware of how they're talking or what they're saying, those kinds of things

author: Q1
sentence: So, what do you do to smooth over that?

author: Q2
sentence: Before we start off, whatever -

author: A
sentence: It's been my entire career, so I don't know any different

author: A
sentence: So, I've worked in academia and sport, everyone is generally a bloke, although that is changing

author: A
sentence: I think the benefit I've got in my industry is it is sport, so I can talk about sport, which is [inaudible] 00:23:43 Paul and I got along so well

author: Q1
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: That, unlike lots of women, I can speak their language, so I just start talking about the tennis [overtalk] 00:23:55 something like that

author: Q1
sentence: Okay

author: Q1
sentence: So, is that what you do with a minority group? Like, if someone comes from a different background to your board, how do you help to draw them in to the fold?

author: A
sentence: We just treat them the same as everybody else

author: A
sentence: We don't do anything special, but again, that being said, my entire career's been working on access and equity and inclusion, so I don't know how to do it differently

author: A
sentence: Again, that may be why my board is diverse, because we don't do it differently

author: A
sentence: That being said, we are all very similar socioeconomic status

author: A
sentence: I don't think we've got anyone who's not earning a decent coin or not well educated

author: A
sentence: Again, I would argue that's probably a prerequisite, that's where the merit kicks in, not about the money but the education and the skills

author: A
sentence: But no, I don't think - and I'm also very aware that sometimes when you're, you know, how should we include this person, the fact that you're actually even - means that you're probably not naturally including them, so it comes across as a bit contrived

author: Q1
sentence: Yep, it's a strategy rather than a -

author: A
sentence: So, when we had a guest speaker once, Daniela Di Toro, who's one of Australia's best wheelchair tennis players, I know Danni from other activities in my life, and she wheeled up to the table, and there's - you've got to move the chair so she can put her wheelchair up, we just moved the chair

author: A
sentence: Like, there wasn't a big thing, it's just we could see her wheeling in and one of us just went and, I think it was me and maybe someone else, just went and shifted a chair so she had some space

author: A
sentence: So, it's not like the, "Danni, welcome, how can we make you comfortable? What do you need?" We just do it, literally gave her a seat at the table

author: Q2
sentence: Going back to your Portuguese/Sri Lankan person, or whatever, if, as you say, all his life he's probably been in those situations and probably walked into other boardrooms and other forums where - is it an issue, or is it such a challenge to walk into a boardroom and be the only one?

author: A
sentence: I think it depends on how used to it you are

author: A
sentence: So, as I said, I don't get too weird about that because I don't know any different

author: A
sentence: Mark's experience has always been like that, so he won't know any different

author: A
sentence: I think if you were the first - and I'll use the first in family analogy for university, I don't have - I'm the third generation in my family to do it, so there was no mental leap of, this is a big deal, it's like it just is

author: A
sentence: I think it would be, if you were the first of your type, or you hadn't had an experience in a gentler way, like, through a committee, or there wasn't an easing in, then it would be really daunting, because you wouldn't know how to act

author: A
sentence: So, even things like how formal your board meeting was run

author: A
sentence: If you sit in a board meeting and you've only ever been in informal committees where people say, yep, I'd like to talk, and you just start talking, as opposed to the super formal ones where they go to the Chair and then the Chair directs them, you know, if you don't know the language, or things like - and this is, again, thanks Mum and Dad for teaching me manners, but we go to lots of fancy functions, so if you weren't comfortable in how to make small talk, or which side the glass was on - you know, just those basic things

author: A
sentence: There's some niceties around governance that we just assume everyone knows because they're come from a similar background, so if all of a sudden you haven't come from that background, you don't know, necessarily, all of the language and that, the social constructs around how we do this

author: Q2
sentence: Of course, that wouldn't be part of expert selection and criteria

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: [the participant] -

author: Q
sentence: Because that can sometimes make a difference

author: Q
sentence: I am interviewing a headhunter soon -

author: A
sentence: Oh, yes

author: Q
sentence: - so I will see -

author: A
sentence: They're quite interesting

author: A
sentence: They have their own little stables

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I'll see

author: A
sentence: Well, we've got - I've recruited two women to our board at A large FP organisation (autoparts) and the headhunter didn't [inaudible] 00:14:50

author: Q
sentence: So what - what do you think - what's the limiting factor?

author: A
sentence: Vision? Vision

author: A
sentence: Their network - if you're not in the network

author: A
sentence: Again, they may not even know who you are

author: Q
sentence: Okay, I'll explore that

author: A
sentence: Yep, explore that

author: A
sentence: They're paid roles

author: A
sentence: It's quite interesting, actually, because particularly in the smaller regional and country ones, they're not paid very much

author: A
sentence: As an industry, we've been agitating, saying, "You want good people to do it

author: A
sentence: If you want women on these boards, they have to give up other things

author: A
sentence: They should be paid properly

author: A
sentence: " You know, I'm reasonably well paid for my chair role

author: A
sentence: So if you're on, say, one of the urban authorities, like City West or Yarra Valley, you're probably on about 45/$50,000

author: A
sentence: But if you're on a small country one, some of them would be on $16,000

author: A
sentence: You know it's quite a burden of work

author: Q
sentence: I will, because it will be interesting

author: A
sentence: You know, they have their stables

author: A
sentence: They have their people that they like to promote, which is fair enough, I'm not criticising it

author: A
sentence: But to get on their radar, you need somebody to mentor you into the network

author: Q
sentence: So I'll ask: How do they mentor people into their network?

author: A
sentence: Well, somebody else mentors you

author: A
sentence: So for example, if you wanted to get on an ASX board and - like in my case, coming back from China where I didn't know anybody - the way I got introduced to the headhunters was through my mentor

author: A
sentence: So she said, "What can you do - what can I do for you?" I said, "I can't get in to see them - the headhunters

author: A
sentence: " She said, "I'll make some calls

author: A
sentence: " That was the key because they get lots of CVs but until you get in the door and have a face-to-face, they're not going to remember who you are

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you're invisible

author: A
sentence: You might have the skills but they don't know you

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so this is really, really important

author: Q
sentence: So mentoring then - you've said this a number of times - this is a very key thing

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me what you mean by mentoring and how that might -

author: A
sentence: Well, part of it will be introducing you to networks

author: A
sentence: Or when people say they don't exist, they certainly do exist

author: A
sentence: Part of it is around - mentors are good at helping you get realistic about your expectations

author: A
sentence: Because I mean, I see lots of young women who are 35 years old and think they should be on a board

author: A
sentence: I am going, "No, you shouldn't

author: A
sentence: You need much more experience before you even think about it," particularly an ASX listed board

author: A
sentence: So mentoring can do that

author: A
sentence: Some of the mentoring I do, which I do for - you know who Wendy McCarthy is? Wendy McCarthy? Former deputy chair of the ABC? Famous Wendy?

author: Q
sentence: Oh, yes

author: A
sentence: So she's got a mentoring business and I do mentoring for them, for lots of young men and women

author: A
sentence: Part of what you do in mentoring is just help people decide what path they want to pursue

author: A
sentence: How they contribute - and I mentor for women on boards, as well

author: A
sentence: So they have - they run a mentoring program

author: A
sentence: I do mentoring for them, as well

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, what's the difference in the workload?

author: A
sentence: They've done a lot - they've done a lot - they've been a huge contributor to the number of women on - by simply demanding

author: A
sentence: You know, the name of their company, Women on Boards, speaks for itself

author: A
sentence: Then they door-knock the chairman

author: A
sentence: They door-knock government

author: A
sentence: They have pushed really, really hard and they made it a business

author: A
sentence: Aspiring women go there and join their organisation

author: A
sentence: They now run it like - they run a site where they advertise - where people advertise roles coming up, which never used to be available

author: A
sentence: So again, when you think about a network, what they've created is this big network of women who can go to their site

author: A
sentence: A lot of sites are not-for-profits or government ones, but [inaudible] 00:19:32

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I'm familiar with them

author: Q
sentence: I - because they were at La Trobe

author: Q
sentence: La Trobe sponsored - anyone who was staff at La Trobe could join for free, Women on Boards

author: Q
sentence: So I went along to one of their workshops and I experienced their difference

author: A
sentence: Yeah, they're very different

author: Q
sentence: Amazing

author: Q
sentence: But yes, so - but that's a long time ago, [overtalk] 00:19:56

author: A
sentence: Yeah, so they've been a big reason because you need to get some experience

author: A
sentence: What they've - because they advertise a lot of not-for-profit ones, and a lot of women get these roles now and start to get the experience

author: A
sentence: First of all, start to work out, "This is what I want to do

author: A
sentence: This is the sort of role I enjoy

author: A
sentence: " You know, you've got a - you can't go in and say, "I want to be an ASX director," if you haven't had some experience

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there's a particular kind of diversity that matters more than others?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: I don't, actually

author: Q
sentence: Can you tell me, what do you understand diversity means? Because I have -

author: A
sentence: For me?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: What does it mean? Diversity of age? Diversity of Outlook? Diversity of background? Diversity of ethnicity? Diversity of business experience? All those things [overtalk] 00:20:47 -

author: A
sentence: None

author: A
sentence: None

author: A
sentence: It's on the basis that you've got fewer customers, but the workload is the same

author: A
sentence: In fact, in the regions it can be a bit tougher because they're short of money, all their customers can talk to them when they're standing at the queue in the bank

author: A
sentence: Like, you're really in touch with your customers in the country towns

author: A
sentence: For boards?

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: You know, you want a board, for example - say our A large FP organisation (autoparts) - which is - we distribute automotive parts, so in great big warehouses

author: A
sentence: So on that one, we've got Margo - Margie [inaudible] 00:21:02

author: A
sentence: So she worked for Mars, the big fast-moving consumer group

author: A
sentence: She knows all about how to shift product around the globe

author: A
sentence: We've got Jenny McDonald, who was a CFO

author: A
sentence: So she really gets the finance

author: A
sentence: You've got me on the legal side, but I'm also really hot on the Occ health and safety side because I've come from industrial backgrounds

author: A
sentence: So you get - you know, our chair, Andrew, finance background but big capital markets

author: A
sentence: So it's that sort of diversity

author: Q
sentence: Do you use a skill mix thing to work out -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, we do

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Does everyone have to do that? Is that a -

author: A
sentence: You don't have to, in short

author: Q
sentence: You make it public? It's -

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: I'm on a superannuation board where you definitely have to do it in superannuation

author: A
sentence: APRA insist that you do it, and quite right

author: A
sentence: So you have a big skills matrix, all the skills we need

author: A
sentence: So that's been a big change

author: A
sentence: I think probably, Margo, that contributed to more women becoming directors because once you've said, "I don't have a skills matrix," it's not being an old boys club

author: A
sentence: So, "Well, have we got those skills? Where can we find them?" Then you get this, "Oh, well, you can't - what you get is oh well

author: A
sentence: " But women come from law, they come from finance, they come from HR

author: A
sentence: everyone is going, "Well, that's not good enough

author: A
sentence: " They did do other things

author: A
sentence: So the skills matrix shone a light on a lot of that stuff

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: No one has shown that aspect of a skill matrix

author: Q
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: It's like being a doctor in the little villages

author: A
sentence: It's really important

author: Q
sentence: Thank you, that's perfect

sentence: I want to [go back] 00:22:37, please

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that's good

author: Q
sentence: Good functioning

author: Q
sentence: This is where your chair thing comes in

author: Q
sentence: We want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that you think diversity really helps with? Can you give me an example? Then another one is - it's relevant to, and another, it can undermine

author: A
sentence: Interesting

author: A
sentence: I've only been on one board that was all-female

author: Q
sentence: All-female?

author: A
sentence: All-female

author: A
sentence: One Victorian government board called VMIA

author: A
sentence: You've got the details there

author: A
sentence: Chaired by a very experienced female director, Elana Rubin

author: A
sentence: Really experienced

author: A
sentence: We used to sit there and say, "Oh, we probably should get a bloke

author: A
sentence: " Then we go, "Business is doing well

author: A
sentence: We seem to have all the skills we need in the room

author: A
sentence: Why do we think we should get a bloke because we don't look very diverse?" Well, bad luck for the blokes

author: A
sentence: Look, here's where I come from

author: A
sentence: Because I've heard - you know, people say, "Well, prove to me that diversity works

author: A
sentence: " I say this, "Prove to me the opposite

author: A
sentence: " No one has ever done a study to say that a monoculture is the right way to go

author: A
sentence: No one

author: A
sentence: I've never seen a study

author: A
sentence: So I take the view, "I don't think I have to prove anything anymore

author: A
sentence: " Because there is no study showing this as a preferred - the male - all-male model

author: A
sentence: I had somebody once try that on me, who was - when I was on the Fire Brigade board

author: A
sentence: He was a former general

author: A
sentence: He hated diversity

author: Q
sentence: Oh, I bet he did

author: A
sentence: I'd push him and push him and push him in the Fire Brigade because there's so few women in the Fire Brigade

author: A
sentence: He sent me an essay about - he couldn't find any research that would justify having women in the Fire Brigade

author: A
sentence: I said to him, "Have you found any research that justifies why there are men in the Fire Brigade?" Because there is none

author: A
sentence: Look, it all depends on your particular board

author: A
sentence: I mean, successful boards are a really good mix of skills or personalities and an ability to make decisions and to get the right information

author: A
sentence: I don't think whether you're a male or a female, that's the key

author: A
sentence: The key is that particular group of people and how they operate together

author: A
sentence: You can - you can, for example - you can get somebody come into a board who is a very dominant personality

author: A
sentence: That can be male or female and it's very disruptive because it shuts down other voices

author: A
sentence: I've seen dominant males and I've seen dominant females to do that

author: Q
sentence: It's bossy people

author: A
sentence: Yeah, there's nowhere to hide

author: A
sentence: Anyway, the logic is they're big, you're small

author: A
sentence: So that's changed a lot

author: A
sentence: I think when I first came back from China in 2010 there wouldn't have been 30 or 40 women on publicly listed boards

author: A
sentence: That's really changed a lot

author: A
sentence: A lot

author: A
sentence: It's just bossy people

author: A
sentence: Doesn't really help in a board

author: A
sentence: You need people who aren't afraid to make a decision, but you don't need people who drown out everybody else

author: A
sentence: Because then you get a single line of the board

author: A
sentence: So that's where the diversity is

author: A
sentence: It's different ways of thinking, or different ways of approaching a problem [inaudible] 00:25:50

author: A
sentence: That can be - doesn't have to be based on gender

author: A
sentence: You know, the focus is - we've had a focus on gender because it was so unbalanced

author: A
sentence: It was ridiculous

author: A
sentence: But the focus now should be on: What is your cognitive ability?

author: Q
sentence: Yep, cognitive diversity

author: Q
sentence: Can we - do you think there's room back with the gender for an argument about justice? It's just morally wrong not to allow - have women on boards? Give them a fair out go

author: A
sentence: Of course it is

author: A
sentence: It's 50% of the population

author: A
sentence: It's -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so it's a -

author: A
sentence: So for me, it's like, really? It's 2019

author: A
sentence: You want to run an argument that women shouldn't be there? Yeah, get over yourself

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so you would use not just the performance of boards, like [overtalk] 00:26:41 -

author: A
sentence: It's simply you can't exclude half the population from big decision-making

author: A
sentence: It's [inaudible] 00:26:47, you can't just say, "Well, you'll have to wait

author: A
sentence: " In fact, tell me why we should wait?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: A
sentence: For me, it's - you know, I don't know about you, Margo, but this argument has been going on since I was a 21-year-old clerk and I would say to young women, "You know, stop asking

author: A
sentence: Just demand it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, [overtalk] 00:27:07

author: Q
sentence: In the last 10 years?

author: A
sentence: Because asking implies that it's not yours as a right

author: A
sentence: I think it's ours as a right

author: Q
sentence: Yes, that's a good point

author: A
sentence: You know, we're a little bit apologetic

author: A
sentence: I say, "Don't apologise

author: A
sentence: " It's ours as a right

author: A
sentence: We're half of the population

author: A
sentence: We don't have to prove anything special

author: A
sentence: Trust me, I know as much as you do at that subject

author: A
sentence: So my view [inaudible] 00:27:38

author: A
sentence: If the answer is it's because of gender, that's not a good enough answer

author: A
sentence: The answer should be, "I've got a better skill set than you've got," or, "They need a different way of thinking in this board because they've got a - a matrix of skills and you've got that skill and you don't

author: A
sentence: " I can accept that argument

author: A
sentence: I just don't accept the argument about [inaudible] 00:28:00

author: A
sentence: I'm as well educated as anybody else

author: A
sentence: My life experience is broad

author: A
sentence: It's like saying I want the green plate and not the blue plate

author: A
sentence: Really?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, yeah

author: A
sentence: But anyway, don't let people apologise because I don't

author: Q
sentence: So do you think there are particular board functions that diversity is irrelevant to? I'm just trying to think, is there anything that you would -

author: A
sentence: All of them

author: Q
sentence: It's irrelevant to - diversity is irrelevant to your board positions?

author: A
sentence: It's a skill

author: A
sentence: So if you're talking - you need to have diversity for this

author: A
sentence: The only diversity you really, really need on a board is diversity of thinking and diversity of experience

author: Q
sentence: Okay, thinking and experience is key

author: A
sentence: A lot

author: A
sentence: They're the key

author: Q
sentence: That's - they're the roots

author: A
sentence: You know, the skill set

author: A
sentence: It's all about - have you got the skills we need? What's missing on our board and how can we fill that gap?

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so there's two levels, aren't there then? This is - because I'm now - there is a model coming

author: Q
sentence: Because there's two levels

author: Q
sentence: The motor, or what we want - the output - is thinking and experienced diversity

author: Q
sentence: The input is openness to gender, to different genders, to different cultural backgrounds, to different whatever -

author: A
sentence: Age?

author: Q
sentence: Yep, Age

author: Q
sentence: All those different factors, they're up here, but they're leading through, they're influencing through diversity of thinking and experience

author: Q
sentence: That's the root -

author: A
sentence: That's the key

author: Q
sentence: - that we need

author: Q
sentence: Okay, beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Now I can help to make sense of this because the literature has it all everywhere

author: Q
sentence: Now I'd like to explore how diversity might contribute to conflict on boards

author: Q
sentence: If so, how such conflict can be managed? This is where people talk about - the chair is key and that it ends there

author: Q
sentence: So I want to know what the chair does to manage -

author: A
sentence: What does the chair do? So first of all, the chair should have an open door to every board member

author: A
sentence: Because, you know, the chair is only first among equals

author: Q
sentence: Is only what?

author: Q
sentence: What's caused that change, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Equals

author: A
sentence: First among equals

author: Q
sentence: Oh, okay

author: A
sentence: Your chair, because - well, putting [inaudible] 00:30:08 boards

author: A
sentence: Your chair because the other directors, sort of, "Oh, she's taking the position

author: A
sentence: " Those are often influenced by a perspective of, let's say, in a listed environment, is that a person that the market will say, "Yes, we understand that

author: A
sentence: " Or is it because you've got a dysfunctional board and you need somebody who's really good at pulling people together? So the thing about chairs is to remember that they are just first among equals

author: A
sentence: They're just one

author: A
sentence: Their vote is one vote

author: A
sentence: I mean, some constitutions say the chair has a casting vote if there's a tie

author: A
sentence: In the government space, the minister appoints a chair

author: A
sentence: A lot of that is based on experience and - but the role of the chair, I reckon -

author: Q
sentence: Political alignment?

author: A
sentence: Sorry?

author: Q
sentence: Would a political alignment the important to the appointment? Or you can't say?

author: A
sentence: I'm sure it happens from time to time

author: A
sentence: In fact, I'm quite confident it happens from time to time on both sides of politics

author: Q
sentence: So politics is an important - political parties are important influences for boards?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I mean, a lot of government boards, the decision is made in Cabinet

author: A
sentence: Either by the minister or in Cabinet

author: A
sentence: So - look from time to time they're apolitical in their appointments, but occasionally there will be a political appointment because it might be a highly contested political hot area and they might want a board that knows how to navigate and also not embarrass them if there is a big policy issue around - for example, I'm on the Forestry board

author: A
sentence: So I'm deputy chair of the Forestry board

author: A
sentence: That is a very hot, political environment

author: A
sentence: So we've got a few new board members who were appointed by the Labor Party who are well-connected

author: A
sentence: But that's helpful for us because it's such a political environment

author: A
sentence: That gives us channels to go back to the department and say, "This is where we sit on these issues

author: A
sentence: So government boards - I'm not a policy maker

author: A
sentence: That's government's job

author: A
sentence: But you are trying to run a business for them and you've got lots of stakeholders

author: A
sentence: Things like that, the role of the chair is critical

author: A
sentence: Because in those ones, the chair has to have credibility - a government [Liberal] 00:32:43

author: A
sentence: So if the chair wants to meet with somebody normally, it's that, "Yes, they will meet with you

author: A
sentence: So the chair is definitely the spokesperson for the board externally

author: A
sentence: The chair's job is to manage the CEO

author: A
sentence: Because if you've got a board of eight, eight people can't manage the CEO

author: A
sentence: So typically, as the chair, you will have quite the honest relationship with the CEO

author: A
sentence: Not buddies, but talk to each other regularly

author: A
sentence: We'll try to be aligned

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I'll report back to my board, but the CEO and I can talk on the board

author: A
sentence: I consult with my board about things

author: A
sentence: If I'm not happy with the way things are going, I will talk with them

author: A
sentence: Part of it's just political pressure

author: A
sentence: Women insisting

author: A
sentence: Acknowledgement that they're ready

author: A
sentence: Because it used to be a mantra - "Well, we'll put some on there but none of them are really -" it's just not true, is it?

author: A
sentence: Sometimes I'd ring one or two of them and I'd say, "This is what I'm thinking

author: A
sentence: What do you reckon?" Before I might take [inaudible] 00:33:36, depending on the skill

author: A
sentence: But your job is to - it's like an orchestra

author: A
sentence: You know, part of the job is to make sure everybody gets heard because you can get quiet people, people who - particularly in government boards who just want to play to their strengths and think that the only thing they have to do is concentrate on one [inaudible] 00:33:58 of the business

author: A
sentence: [Inaudible] 00:34:00, "No, no, no

author: A
sentence: Your job is also to hold the business

author: A
sentence: " So you might, as chair, be encouraging them to learn more

author: A
sentence: I would - I would allocate the roles on various committees

author: A
sentence: Partly on the basis that I've got the skill set that that community is supposed to have, but partly to educate other people

author: A
sentence: So, "Can you go on that committee? Because you don't know about that part of the business

author: A
sentence: " Yep, [overtalk] 00:34:27 -

author: Q
sentence: Is this your mentoring?

author: A
sentence: -@ comfort thing

author: Q
sentence: Is this your mentoring?

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: "You'll learn a lot more about the business if you sit on that committee

author: A
sentence: I know you don't -" like an audit committee

author: A
sentence: Somebody said, "Oh, I've never been to one of those

author: A
sentence: " Well, go and you'll learn

author: A
sentence: You know, no one expects you to have all the answers when you go up there, but you'll bring a different perspective, you'll ask different questions

author: A
sentence: Then you will have voices that are too loud

author: A
sentence: So part of your job is to turn them down

author: A
sentence: Part of it is to protect your board

author: Q
sentence: So what would you do to protect your board?

author: A
sentence: Well, sometimes you'll step out and be the - if there is a difficulty, it will be put on your shoulders

author: A
sentence: Of course

author: A
sentence: Or if it's a hot political item, you will try and keep them in the background so that they're protected

author: A
sentence: If we've got [background noise] 00:36:19 problems with management which and they're not getting on well with management, you'll try and foster a better relationship

author: A
sentence: Sometimes you have to stand up for them

author: A
sentence: They might have questions - management will say, "That's got nothing to do with the board

author: A
sentence: " "Yes, it does

author: A
sentence: " Or sometimes you have to say to your board members, "Actually, that's management's job

author: A
sentence: I know it's really interesting and it's in your field and you've got a lot of knowledge, but you know what? You're not the manager anymore

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: It a different role

author: Q
sentence: You keep the scope

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: It's a fascinating role

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

sentence: I'm thinking, of course, of the NAB chair and CEO are both, at the same time, after the Hayne's report, being very much in the media and -

author: A
sentence: That's okay

author: Q
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well, you know, if you lose your chair and your CEO at the same time, it's a big disruption

author: A

author: A

sentence: Of course

author: A
sentence: The government ones, absolutely

sentence: Also on superannuation

author: A
sentence: So on my super board -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

sentence: Tell me

author: A
sentence: - we're a bit unusual

sentence: So we have 50% independents and 50% appointed by the unions and the employer groups

author: A
sentence: So there are not many

author: A
sentence: I think we're probably the only one that's got 50-50

author: A
sentence: Others are a third-a third-a third

author: A
sentence: So yes, there external parties that are nominate - have the right to nominate directors for our board

author: A
sentence: So the unions have a right to nominate their incentive and the employer does, as well

author: A
sentence: But we work with them

author: A
sentence: Again, we come back to - here's the skill set that we're looking for

author: A
sentence: It used to be, in the old days, you just got whomever - [inaudible] 00:39:49 and to be honest, in the industry funds, it hasn't done too much harm

author: A
sentence: Because actually, the industry funds have been very well governed

author: A
sentence: But now in WA we say, "Look, we really want these skills, so can you find somebody - even if they don't work for you, you could just get - nominate this person

author: A
sentence: But these are the skills we want

author: A
sentence: " So that's quite different

author: A
sentence: When I used to run the Holden superfund, we had 50% employer, 50% employee

author: A
sentence: But you know, in those super funds, despite those when you didn't do skills matrixes, got a good result

author: A
sentence: You know, one of the smartest people on my Holden superfund was a guy from the shop floor

author: A
sentence: Loved the subject, incredibly well informed about it

author: A
sentence: Pain in the arse to deal with, however, in terms of knowing his stuff, he was fantastic

author: Q
sentence: So great contributor to decision-making

sentence: Yeah

sentence: So the concept that the nominees don't necessarily bring the skills, I'd argue with that

sentence: So how do you think - what created this groundswell of women being able to get there? How did they make that work?

author: A
sentence: They absolutely have voting rights

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so they've got - right, okay

author: Q
sentence: You don't have any choice about whether they're selected or not? You can just -

sentence: Well, they're entitled under the constitution

author: A
sentence: So basically, you have to work - you have to have a good relationship with the nominating bodies so that you do get what you want

author: Q
sentence: So there's an important share role?

sentence: Yeah
