sentence: I mean, if you couldn't reach agreement, they're entitled to nominate who they like

author: A
sentence: But in super, you have what's called fit and proper

author: A
sentence: So people have to fast - pass the fit and proper test

author: A
sentence: Our fund, say, in WA, we said - well, we say, "What makes you fit and proper?" That will include having done the AICD course and certain skills

author: A
sentence: But you know, you try not to have a conflict about it

author: A
sentence: Conflict doesn't help there

author: A
sentence: It needs to be a collective agreement

author: A
sentence: Government boards, you don't get a say

author: A
sentence: As the chair, you don't get a say

author: A
sentence: You just get told, "Here are your two new directors

author: A
sentence: It's very irritating

sentence: Yes, I can imagine

sentence: I'm - now we're on the super - because I'm just trying to think of the - we've had the Global Financial Crisis

sentence: So we've got national policy which is really putting a lot of weight on superannuation funds, in terms of public interest

author: A
sentence: Yes

sentence: So there's a lot of political and personal interest in there

sentence: So it's a hot - I would call it -

author: A
sentence: Topic

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: I just think - part of it was led by the Institute of Company Directors, AICD, who pushed hard for a quota and pushed very hard

author: A
sentence: So they had the 30% club and started to really agitate

author: A
sentence: Then they also did things like they had - so they created a company director's course

author: A
sentence: So a course of study to understand what the role is, as a basic

author: A
sentence: Then they created another level called Mastering the Boardroom, which was a higher level, and they handed out scholarships for this

author: A

author: A
sentence: So they got many of them the chairs of big ASX listed companies to mentor women

author: A
sentence: Well, some industry funds have got 50/50

author: A
sentence: Others have moved to 30/30/30

author: A
sentence: We went a bit further

author: A
sentence: We went 50/50

sentence: How do you do - this is a Constitution? Every board has its own constitution, does it? Who writes that?

sentence: The shareholders

author: A
sentence: Well, for instance, when I chaired the Holden superfund, which was for all the Holden employees, I introduced two independents to the board

sentence: Because we really needed some extra skills

author: A
sentence: So -

author: A
sentence: Well, I just spoke to the employer group and the union group and said, "I think it would be a good idea if we had some independents

author: A
sentence: " "Oh, good

sentence: We'll deal and you tell us what you need and we'll see what we can find for you

author: A
sentence: " Anyway, if you think of the African community, first, it's not their culture to want to be on a board - yet

author: A
sentence: But it's a big - it's a big gap

author: Q
sentence: Because we're second generation Africans, wouldn't we be now?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, but you still - there's still confidence, networks

author: A
sentence: You know, where is the network? That's the sort of thing that holds people back, too, is the lack of networks

author: A
sentence: That's why - that's why they've - the female representation has got much better because there is a big network

author: A
sentence: It's quite a big network

author: Q
sentence: It's interesting

author: Q
sentence: So networks are important -

author: A
sentence: Yep

author: A
sentence: - [overtalk] 00:02:08 they're paid roles

author: A
sentence: They're paid roles

author: Q
sentence: - whereas another interview I said, "Well, what about networks?" "Well, I see that as counter to diversity

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: A
sentence: You've got to have the networks because you have to hear about things

author: A
sentence: You have to have bodies, you have to have people on call, you have to hear about things

author: A
sentence: Without a network, how do you hear what's happening?

author: Q
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So you're - yeah, so this is how the supply chain works, only through a network

author: A
sentence: Not only, but it's a big contributor

author: Q
sentence: With a - let's say an invisible group or a disadvantaged group -

author: A
sentence: They don't have that network -

author: Q
sentence: It's fairly important

author: A
sentence: So two things, they don't have a network that the other networks can go to

author: A
sentence: That's a - when you say - well, they don't know where to look

author: A
sentence: Now there may well be a big network of Indian community or Muslim community in the western suburbs, what have you

author: A
sentence: But if I'm sitting on the rem committee of a listed company, how do I even approach them? The headhunters are not good at that

author: Q
sentence: I think what I really like about the research is that we’re talking to people on boards and people who influence boards to develop a model, so it’s like the ground up

author: A1
sentence: Bachelor of Economics and Master of Finance

sentence: Was it in the US?

sentence: It is written by the US, but it’s a review of all the literature

author: A1
sentence: Yep

sentence: I think you’ve already done that, you’ve already explained how you do it

sentence: So what does board diversity mean to you? Now we’re going to get to the crunch

author: A1
sentence: Board diversity, to me -Secondary participant might have seen - it’s what we were talking about before

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

sentence: Yep, beautiful

sentence: Social networks?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, in the literature there’s some talk about networks, because board members can use their networks to - so diverse networks is not -

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so finance and economics, and -

author: A1
sentence: I mean, I take networks to be a block to diversity

author: Q
sentence: Ah, good

author: Q
sentence: That’s how I think of networks

author: Q
sentence: If I’m using my network, I’m probably using people who I went through uni together with, or through school together with, or live near, or have the same interests outside of working, which could indeed involve some diversity, but not typically proper diversity

author: Q
sentence: Lovely

author: Q
sentence: I like that

sentence: I’ll pull that out later when we - so is that similar with your research, have you looked into that?

author: A2
sentence: I don’t think we’ve looked into that that much, no

author: Q
sentence: So gender diversity has been debated for a while

author: Q
sentence: How do you feel about the recent inclusion of ethnicity, sexual orientation - good, it’s not there?

author: A2
sentence: Ethnicity is -

author: Q
sentence: Ethnicity’s there, but sexual orientation is also sort of being included

author: A1
sentence: Yep, rightly so

author: Q
sentence: Does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others, do you think? And if so, why?

author: A2
sentence: Commerce and law

author: A1
sentence: Well, again, I’m probably influenced by my organisation’s approach to this question, but the gender diversity seemed to be the highest level issue of concern five years ago, and now we’ve evolved where we realise it’s - and we always realised this, but we now think it’s greater than gender diversity

author: A1
sentence: But if you’re asking me to pick the different points of diversity and what’s the most important, I’d still say it’s gender

author: Q
sentence: Why is that?

author: A1
sentence: Because we’re not quite where we need to be

author: A1
sentence: When we are, then we can say that something is of greater importance of that

author: A1
sentence: But I don’t think -it’s not a pick one question for me either

author: A1
sentence: You can work on gender diversity, and ethnicity, and age, and skills, and sexual orientation

author: Q
sentence: And I guess gender diversity because of the data, you’ve got data, so it’s easier for you, as an organisation, to use it in terms of your -

author: A1
sentence: I don’t know if it’s even that

author: A1
sentence: It’s in your everyday experience

author: A1
sentence: Any time you go to a meeting, and I’ve had numerous meetings in this room with seven people from a client and their advisors, and including me, there’s seven males and one female

author: A1
sentence: Now, 15 years ago, I probably would have thought there’s nothing unusual about that

author: A1
sentence: But now, I think this is weird

author: A1
sentence: How is it that this room ends up having seven males and one female talking about this thing

author: A1
sentence: So it went from - I mean, I’m of a certain generation, Secondary participant’s of a different generation, but it went from your experience in a workplace in the 1990s were a particular type of experience

author: A1
sentence: And they’re a different type of experience now

author: A1
sentence: But I think anyone of my generation - I’m not saying that we’re the first generation, but of any generation, over time, it’s just - you’re struck more by what you see, even as a male, that seems to be circumstances, like gender diversity

author: A1
sentence: I’ve had other experiences

author: A1
sentence: Secondary participant beat out three other males for his position

author: A1
sentence: I’ll let you know, Secondary participant, I wanted females in my candidate pool, but I didn’t get any

author: A1
sentence: And I was, ‘Where are the females for this role?’ They just didn’t step forward

author: A1
sentence: I could have delayed the whole hiring process until I got - and sometimes that would happen

author: A1
sentence: I’d say to my boss, ‘Look, I can’t go forward with the hire at this point because I don’t have any female candidates

author: A1
sentence: I have to go and get me a recruiter to go and get me some female candidates to look at

author: A1
sentence: ’ But I didn’t do it with Secondary participant’s appointment, because it was more urgent, and I wasn’t using a recruiter in the first place, I was using the university job board

author: A1
sentence: Which is pretty democratic

author: A1
sentence: You’re allowed to see it and apply

author: A1
sentence: Did it say something about females attitude to what they think I might have been as a boss? I don’t know

author: Q
sentence: ASX?

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, it sounded like a boy’s club to me

author: Q
sentence: <Laughs> You need to change the image of ASX

author: A1
sentence: We’ve never had a female chief executive either

author: Q
sentence: Commerce and law

author: Q
sentence: You’re both males, and you’re both with ASX

author: Q
sentence: ASX, it influences the for profit and has nothing to do with the not-for-profit, is that correct?

author: Q
sentence: <Laughs> We’ve already said that

author: Q
sentence: Now I want to talk about board functioning, which really goes back to one female in the room

author: Q
sentence: We want to understand how diversity influences board functioning

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that there are particular board functions that diversity can really help with? And can you give me an example?

author: A1
sentence: Sorry, can you repeat the question?

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that there are particular board functions that diversity can really help with, whether it’s gender or others, and can you give me an example?

author: A1
sentence: I haven’t really attended too many board meetings in my life, and I’ve sat on one not-for-profit board for a number of years, so I’m going to say what I’ve heard others say rather than what has truly been my experience

author: A1
sentence: But I’ve heard more than one male who’s been on numerous different boards say that when they are on boards that are all male, the dynamic is completely different than if there are females represented on the board, and the dynamic is more productive and collaborative when there are females on the board

author: A1
sentence: Because the testosterone is obviously reduced, there is more careful regard to proper manners

author: A1
sentence: But there’s also, sometimes - and you can probably generalise here, but this is what people have said - is that the females on the board bring a different perspective

author: A1
sentence: They maybe have sometimes better ways of communicating than the men, diffusing disagreement

author: A1
sentence: Not to say, ‘Let’s all find a way to agree and not have the right debate about a subject’, but it’s just done in a more productive way

author: A1
sentence: I’ve thought that’s of interest, because I’ve heard that a number of times

author: A1
sentence: I don’t know if that’s come through in your interviewing of others, but -

author: A2
sentence: I think as a specific example as well, I remember reading in the Ansell Annual Report, Ansell Limited, the latex rubber provider, they do specifically focus on age diversity, and also getting directors to serve limited sentences just to bring new insights into the company and innovations

author: A2
sentence: Like that’s another example of how diversity adds or improves the functions of the board

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: This question really came out of the pilot

author: Q
sentence: It wasn’t in the pilot of five, so you’re my first post pilot

author: Q
sentence: Because some different things people said, so I thought we need to drill down on this

author: A1
sentence: Sure

author: A1
sentence: It’s a good question

author: Q
sentence: And then conversely, do you think - there might be some board functions that this kind of decision process is actually bad for

author: Q
sentence: It limits or undermines, do you think? Have you heard that, that sort of problem solving -

author: A1
sentence: Limits or undermines?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: That is very correct

author: A1
sentence: Quick observation there, the history of these corporate governance principles, when we first produced them in 2003, immediately an area of interest that we attracted with that, which was a little unexpected, was the not-for-profits -

author: A1
sentence: I suppose it could in some ways

author: A1
sentence: In what ways is not occurring to me

author: Q
sentence: And you haven’t heard this - because you’re drawing from what you’ve heard

author: A1
sentence: Well, if I can again just borrow from other people and their views, I suppose over time, there have been a fewer number, but they’re there

author: A1
sentence: There will be people who say, ‘This is all a load of boloney

author: A1
sentence: It’s not going to help me sell widgets, or make a profit, or do anything that’s going to add real value

author: A1
sentence: If I can have a board that looks great with all the right diversity and stuff, it won’t make any difference to anything

author: A1
sentence: In fact, it’s just a waste of my time

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so it’s like, it’s irrelevant

author: A1
sentence: It’s irrelevant, yep

author: Q
sentence: It’s not going to undermine, it’s just irrelevant

author: A1
sentence: It might undermine to the extent that I have to go off and have board evaluation meetings, or do different things that is just time taken away from making widgets and that’s -

author: Q
sentence: We all hear that when we work in the area of quality or whatever, anything to do with being accountable and transparent about your processes

author: Q
sentence: That’s great

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: There’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and board functioning

author: Q
sentence: I’d like to drill down a bit on that

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that cognitive diversity influences a board functioning, and is there a positive or negative influence? Perhaps it depends

author: A1
sentence: Secondary participant, you’ll know what cognitive diversity is

author: A1
sentence: What is it?

author: A2
sentence: I wouldn’t know

author: Q
sentence: Really?

author: Q
sentence: The way I’m using it here, draws from some people who talk about it as different approaches to problem solving, which you’ve talked about, different perspectives, different information processing styles, which you’ve referred to

author: Q
sentence: So swish term is cognitive diversity

author: A1
sentence: Okay, yep

author: A1
sentence: So cognitive diversity is - sorry, the question you asked again?

author: Q
sentence: Does it influence board functioning, which you’ve sort of already indicated it does, in a positive, negative, or it depends sort of way?

author: A1
sentence: I think, again, it would be great to have all of the evidence in on this question, but maybe to think about our organisation, and in my team, and other teams

author: A1
sentence: We’re a company that’s been in business for 150 years probably, but we’re using technology more and more in our business, and there’s more and more opportunities for us to develop more technology, and it’s all very exciting

author: A1
sentence: But it means that we’ve got people with finance backgrounds, and legal backgrounds, and management backgrounds, and technology background, and marketing backgrounds and other backgrounds that we haven’t actually had people from those backgrounds before

author: A1
sentence: And we suspect that when we get them all into a room, they’re all going to have different perspectives, and we’re going to produce some great things

author: A1
sentence: Other times, we’re going to have a complete failure to communicate and it will all not work out as well as we’d hoped

author: A1
sentence: But senior management’s absolute belief is that if we have more diversity in our teams, we’re going to get new products, exciting developments, we just need to be mindful that we have a licence to operate a stock exchange that needs us to absolutely mission critical on all the systems, get everything right, have a really attuned risk culture around risk management

author: A1
sentence: And sometimes those things are just about boring people like me who know that’s the process and we stick to that process

author: A1
sentence: So maybe don’t take me to a creative meeting and come up with lots of great new products, but our managing director he knows he needs people like me, he needs people like Secondary participant, and he needs other people with other things

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: I’m thinking also then, you’ve alluded to how to avoid miscommunication

author: Q
sentence: The role of the chair, or someone in facilitating the conversation so as the things that have to be absolutely right, this has to be risk assured, so we can’t try too much innovation here, this is compromise -

author: A1
sentence: Yes, correct

author: Q
sentence: So how the chair - in the board, it’s the chair - might manage this

author: Q
sentence: What kind of processes or skills do you think they need to manage this diversity?

author: A1
sentence: Well, they’d probably, I suppose, if I think about chairman, they need to have terrific wisdom, a lot of experience, and be good at a lot of things

author: A1
sentence: But also, give over some of their control to others that they know are going to be better at doing so

author: A1
sentence: Our company’s got new business developments, that would involve people who are taking control, and they report back to the board, ‘This is our progress along the path of this business

author: A1
sentence: ’ And the board will say, ‘That’s great

author: A1
sentence: Keep doing that’, or, ‘We don’t like where that’s going

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good way of managing - like having subcommittees, so then the whole meeting’s not overcome by this creative - so you have subcommittee formation, and they feedback to the board

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, because as long ago as back then, if we were to do a public seminar for our stakeholders, being our listed companies in investors, from the back of the room there would be, ‘Well, this is all great, but how am I going to adopt this for my charity organisation’ or ‘How is this going to work?’ And I would say, ‘Well, with due respect, I don’t know

author: A1
sentence: It wasn’t intended to -

author: A1
sentence: I’m not saying anything you couldn’t read in our reports that we put out publicly, but it’s no secret that we’ve got some new business initiatives

author: A1
sentence: If we had a culture at the top of our organisation that said it wanted to do new business initiatives but actually, when it started to do them, completely caused an inability for those people to actually do the things that are needed to create new business, they would walk away and they’d say, ‘It’s just all too hard

author: A1
sentence: ’ And no one’s doing that, so we’re making progress

author: A1
sentence: And in deep, we’re replacing a legacy system which is very important infrastructure with a new technology blockchain, which is quite interesting

author: A1
sentence: So we’re feeling that we want to use a technology that no other stock exchange has used, and we think it can work for us

author: A1
sentence: And it’s not just a new business initiative, it’s actually replacing the Chet system, which is a key part of our infrastructure for our business

author: A1
sentence: We probably demonstrate some of those attitudes to being open to change

author: A1
sentence: To produce that new technology we need to hire a lot of new people

author: Q
sentence: And that’s similar to the ABC, moving to a digital platform, it needed a whole lot of new people, and possibly contributed to some of the -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: As I said, I think I said in my opening remark, the world, business wise, there’s so much disruption, so much change, speed of change, technology

author: A1
sentence: You couldn’t possibly just stay the way you are and think that your business will go on as it has in the past

author: Q
sentence: Your organisation doesn’t do anything to cultivate new board members, that’s relevant to other institutions, isn’t it? Except for your standards -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, I think there would be something in there that talks about -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, there are

author: Q
sentence: Sorry

author: Q
sentence: Can you think of any ways that your organisation helps candidates from minority groups? We’ll look at this

author: Q
sentence: Because I want to move to the regulating, which is the last three questions

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, sure

author: Q
sentence: What do you see is the main barriers to building diverse boards in Australia? And how do they work, these barriers?

author: A1
sentence: The barriers, yeah

author: A1
sentence: Well, I think one of the barriers would be that it’s all fine to think that boards can become more diverse, but any appointment of any board person to a board is based around the needs of that business and what the shareholders want from their investment in that business

author: A1
sentence: It gets down to those simple considerations

author: A1
sentence: So it would be preferable, or else equal, to hire the younger female, who doesn’t have an Anglo-Saxon background, and has some really good experience in technology and marketing onto the board of my staid old company

author: A1
sentence: But I’ve got another candidate who’s not those things but is other things, and he’s male, and he’s older, and I evaluate that

author: A1
sentence: And I think well, what will my shareholders make of it if they find out that I had the opportunity to hire that person onto my board, but I hired the other person, who doesn’t have any experience, who I think could be great, but it feels like a bit of a risk to me

author: A1
sentence: It’s not just a risk that I’m allowed to take on my own behalf, I’ve got shareholders

author: A1
sentence: So I would think that’s probably something that would weigh -

author: Q
sentence: So is that like shareholder’s perception of risk -

author: Q
sentence: That’s interesting

author: Q
sentence: There’s a question later about how you actually influence your stakeholders, who are the for profits, you influence the not-for-profits

author: A1
sentence: I think so, yeah -

author: Q
sentence: Which you might be willing to take the risk -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: But to sell it to your shareholders is difficult?

author: A1
sentence: Not even to sell it to them, just to know that your obligations are to them

author: A1
sentence: They may never even know, but - if I’m the theoretical or hypothetical chairman of the board of this company, it’s not my plaything, I’ve got these responsibilities

author: A1
sentence: It’s not just up to me

author: Q
sentence: What do your guidelines do to help manage that barrier?

author: A1
sentence: Well, I don’t think they talk specifically to that

author: A1
sentence: They do -  I mean, I used that as one example, there’s probably ten others you can think of

author: A1
sentence: It’s just the people will recognise these barriers or they won’t recognise them, I guess

author: A1
sentence: They’re just there as barriers

author: Q
sentence: Were they there five years ago?

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, I would imagine so

author: Q
sentence: And it still hasn’t changed?

author: A1
sentence: Like it or not, anything put out in a public forum like this, which gathers the views of a lot of different people, it attracts great interest, great buy-in, included by people that it wasn’t even intended for, which said to me one thing, which was there was clearly a void there, that they were looking for anything to fashion into what they needed it to be fashioned in to

author: A1
sentence: But if you look on the ASX website, the submissions on the most recent revisions - and I haven’t done this myself - but you’re likely to see amongst all the submitters, you’re probably going to see some not-for-profits and some people maybe with just their particular agenda item that they want to progress through our consideration

author: A1
sentence: Well, the numbers are changing

author: A1
sentence: And what I think has changed is this document is pretty impactful

author: A1
sentence: People don’t ignore much in this

author: A1
sentence: Some will do it better than others, but it won’t be ignored

author: A1
sentence: So the new words that talk about wider diversity, the new words in the fourth edition, will have an impact

author: A1
sentence: People will ask questions this year, and the year after, and the year after that about -because the council reconvenes, so they will have another meeting sometime next year, they’ll have another meeting later next year, they’ll have further meetings, there’ll be a fifth edition

author: A1
sentence: And what would be particularly considered is those things that we changed for the fourth edition, how did that work out? So I think it will become absolutely an area of greater focus

author: A1
sentence: But as I’ve said before, I think most people are inclined to the view that greater diversity on boards is going to produce better outcomes

author: Q
sentence: And this attitude of concern about risk and duty, that conservative view, that is being perhaps brought into question, or you’re allowed to set it aside somewhat because these standards are saying, ‘Diversity’s good

author: A1
sentence: I don’t even know that you set them aside

author: A1
sentence: Your question earlier was what would be a barrier? I think that would be a barrier

author: A1
sentence: I mean, each of these principles has some interconnectedness

author: A1
sentence: But you could argue, I suppose, that if you were to jump in too enthusiastically into board diversity per this principle, that you could affect your risk management under one of the other principles, especially if you’re operating a bank and you decided that you wanted to appoint four new persons to your bank board who didn’t have any banking experience

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

author: Q
sentence: I’m just trying to see how I can move this here

author: Q
sentence: You’re showing data, I guess, you’re publishing data that shows that more people have women on boards -

author: A1
sentence: Just to be clear, Secondary participant’s looked at the numbers, AICD is publishing data -

author: Q
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: Women on Boards do, and AICD, yep -

author: A1
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So the institutions that influence boards are publishing data -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And you’re requiring that it’s reported so it’s able to then be captured and made public

author: Q
sentence: I think it’s an interesting question

author: Q
sentence: Can we just leave this as we talk through the questionnaire -

author: A1
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So there’s a general, then, awareness of diversity and the world hasn’t collapsed

author: A1
sentence: Hmm

author: Q
sentence: And shareholders haven’t walked away

author: A1
sentence: Hmm

author: Q
sentence: So being the lonely person out there, taking risk on their own, is scary, but when everyone’s, ‘Well, this is the norm now

author: Q
sentence: ’ So this starts to lose power, this barrier

author: A1
sentence: Hmm

author: Q
sentence: I guess what I’m trying to - you have labelled, like a barrier of thinking, and how this is being influenced or shaped is through, in part, your regulations, which say people have to document this

author: Q
sentence: And then other organisations that influence boards, which will say publicise it, and it becomes hard to sustain that when someone on the board can say, ‘Well, hang on, 40% of the people in ASX200 are female, so how can you say it’s a high risk

author: Q
sentence: We’ve only got two

author: A1
sentence: It would become a high risk if you maintained an all-male board, I would have thought

author: Q
sentence: Turn it around, yeah

author: A1
sentence: Yep

author: A1
sentence: Sure

author: A1
sentence: I didn’t want to distract, I just thought an interesting-

author: A1
sentence: You could turn it around, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So do you feel that new board member selection is an issue, or not, in terms of managing diversity?

author: A1
sentence: Well, an issue inasmuch as -

author: Q
sentence: It’s preventing it, like it’s a barrier to building diversity?

author: A1
sentence: I’m not sure

author: Q
sentence: You don’t have to think so

author: Q
sentence: We can leave it

author: Q
sentence: I’m thinking it’s better for a board member anyway, probably

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: From a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about the way diversity of Australian boards is currently being promoted? How do you feel about the use of gender targets, for example, and quotas to influence board diversity?

author: A1
sentence: Well, I think that the principles are saying, ‘for those of you not using numerical targets, you need to really explain why that is

author: A1
sentence: ’ I think some people use numerical targets for executive - in some ways, it’s probably a bit easier to my way of thinking, to set your targets for board diversity than it is senior management

author: A1
sentence: That’s where it gets difficult, because you won’t necessarily have roles within your company that succession planning, or any kind of planning made it possible that meeting whatever benchmark whatever you wanted to set could actually be achieved

author: A1
sentence: Especially if it’s in an organisation like us, where there’s some specialised roles where you’re unlikely to get people from outside who can do the role as well as two or three people from within the organisation

author: A1
sentence: And if those three people are each male, then that’s probably going to be a senior appointment of a male, or it could be females

author: A1
sentence: Not always

author: A1
sentence: We’re relatively diverse within our organisation

author: A1
sentence: So I think it wouldn’t just be our company, but I think a lot of companies would - I mean, if you were just trying to meet the targets, if you just wanted to be able to meet the targets, make those appointments, you’d probably - you could appoint a director from outside to fill a non-executive role relatively easily

author: A1
sentence: It’s the internal appointments, or the appointments to fill management roles that sometimes -

author: Q
sentence: No, no

author: Q
sentence: A question’s come to me, how these interact, like how your guidelines, written for the for-profits, not for the not-for-profits, how that might, now that you’re consciously aware you can’t ignore it, how you think, if you know, if you think it would have influence, and why you think they might be influenced or be interested

sentence: Okay, finally, ten years into the future, how would you like to see the diversity of Australian boards?

author: A1
sentence: Well, I suppose what I wouldn’t want to see is every board sitting on 30% female representation, because it might suggest that everyone ticked boxes and nobody actually engaged with it

author: A1
sentence: I would probably expect and hope to see diversity of diversity, so we will see eight person boards with six females, and eight person boards who are six males, and every other possibility, including a small oil and gas company with four males, it might be difficult to change that

sentence: And that would be understood and accepted by me, if not others

author: A1
sentence: I go back to my point, which is in some ways it’s relatively easy to fix gender diversity on boards, and the numbers have improved

author: A1
sentence: The greater challenges are within management, and their tomorrow’s directors, and they’ll be arguably good directors, especially if they have that management experience

author: A1
sentence: Because - and I didn’t read Graeme Samuel’s comments last week, and I know he’s tried to clarify his comments, but they probably were a bit wide of the mark, but I don’t think Graeme Samuel said this, but others have observed that with some directors, their experience - if they’re female directors, sometimes they’re male, but sometimes they’re female, is that their experience is being a lawyer or an accountant or a consultant, not experienced within the industry on the board that they sit

author: A1
sentence: And there’s a perception that there’s some potential weakness in that skill that brought to the board

author: A1
sentence: It’s all fine to have a lawyer or an accountant and their background experience, that’s great

author: A1
sentence: But it would be, to some people’s way of thinking, better if boards were comprised of people with experience, especially in the industry that that business operates, or in other industries that don’t typically attract people onto boards

author: A1
sentence: And so that might be helped by having more diversity at the management level, for those people to then move through and become directors in the future, in ten years’ time, when they’ve had great experience within that particular business or businesses rather than having that broad experience but not deep experience necessarily if they’re a lawyer or accountant by background

sentence: In 2003, the first principles were produced, and they were produced because the council was convened in 2002

author: A1
sentence: And the reason it was convened in 2002 was there was some corporate scandals -

author: Q
sentence: HIH

author: A1
sentence: There  was HIH

author: A1
sentence: And in the US there was Enron, and there was a very, by most peoples’ points of view, a relatively extreme legislative response to corporate governance failings in the US with Sarbanes Oxley, and ASX was in a position where it was maybe called upon to do something, and we thought it was right to do something, to set out some principles

author: A1
sentence: Because there was nothing, there was absolutely nothing

author: A1
sentence: And we recognised with our companies, large and small, that a set of principles that’s disclosure based was going to be preferable to sitting back doing nothing and having the government of the day say, ‘Why don’t we have some legislation applied to this

author: A1
sentence: ’ And we thought that may not have been a very good thing

author: A1
sentence: So we thought, we’ve got to fill the breach here, we’ve got to step up

author: A1

What’s your skills diversity like?’ People are reporting on their board skills matrixes, so we’re going to have better understanding of what skills there are on boards

author: A2

author: Q
sentence: Sure, so it’s still focused on that

author: A1
sentence: And the fourth edition actually, called out this weaker disclosure against objectives, where it said, ‘Non numericalobjectives are great, and by all means report them, but don’t use them in place of numerical objectives

author: A1
sentence: ’ So the fourth edition has been a bit clearer on that

author: Q
sentence: How did your organisation seek to influence Australian boards?

author: A1
sentence: Bluntly - but only in a couple of areas

author: A1
sentence: So going back to how the principles began at all, there were corporate scandals, in the US particularly, involved financial misreporting, and we’ve had some problems -isolated- but problems with financial reporting in Australia too

author: A1
sentence: There was a big case involving Centro

author: A1
sentence: So what we say is that you must have an audit committee that’s made up on non-executive directors, the majority of whom are independent

author: A1
sentence: So you can’t have executives on your auditory committee

author: A1
sentence: But we say that about our top 300 companies

author: A1
sentence: We don’t say that about every company, because - going back to my earlier point, our market of 2200 listed entities includes very small entities with three person boards, mining explorers, bio techs, quite small companies that wouldn’t be listed on exchanges overseas

author: A1
sentence: So we’ve got a very broad section of companies, and so we think at the top end - and we know that investors think this too - there should be some more strict rules around board composition for remuneration committees and audit committees

author: A1
sentence: And we say, ‘You just have to have that

author: A1
sentence: ’ So if a company fell out of compliance, if it had an audit committee that had the right composition but a director resigned from that board and we became aware of it, we would go to that company and say, ‘You must appoint a director who’s independent, non-executive, and have them on the audit committee

author: A1
sentence: You must go do that

author: A1
sentence: ’ So that’s our role, and that’s what we say

author: A1
sentence: That’s built into the listing rule

author: A1
sentence: So it’s not just about a disclosure based principle, which is a good thing to do but not a must do

author: A1
sentence: This entire document, for a smaller company, it’s all good things to do but not must dos

author: Q
sentence: But for the larger company, there are some musts in there?

author: A1
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Great

sentence: Thanks, now the transcriber will be able to put your initials by what you say and I don’t have to keep indicting who’s who

sentence: I saw you on LinkedIn, and I think it’s law and commerce

sentence: If they break a must, what can you do? What do you do?

author: A1
sentence: It might be the case that the company that’s not in compliance might say, ‘We need some time to organise this

author: A1
sentence: How about we get back to you in three months’ time when we’ve shortlisted a candidate pool

author: A1
sentence: And by within six months, we’ll have it all rearranged to your satisfaction

author: A1
sentence: ’ We would say, ‘That’s not quick enough for our liking

author: A1
sentence: You need to move much more quickly than that

author: A1
sentence: ’ And our powers are only to suspect a company’s shares from trading, and then to delist the company if we thought that was necessary

author: A1
sentence: That’s never come up with companies of the size that we’re talking about, obviously

author: A1
sentence: I don’t think we’ve ever had to suspend a company for not having compliant committees within its board structure for our requirements

author: A1
sentence: But that is clearly after naming and shaming, so we might be moved to write to the company and say, ‘You’re not actually in compliance with this rule

author: A1
sentence: Please advise when you will be

author: A1
sentence: ’ And there might be a response back

author: A1
sentence: So that in itself would be something the company would not welcome, an ASX query that’s publicly disclosed

author: A1
sentence: ASX identified a breach of a rule that is yet to be rectified, and the company have to explain a timeframe in which it will rectify that

sentence: Okay, and as a shareholder, I would see that if I went on your site?

author: A1
sentence: Yep

author: Q
sentence: So it is public shaming

author: A1
sentence: But I wouldn’t suggest that that would be - that query process might have happened only a couple of times

author: A1
sentence: Because companies are responsive to all of this at the larger end, and any company can lose a director and fall out of compliance with that rule

author: A1
sentence: That’s understood

author: A1
sentence: It’s just they need to get back into compliance in a prompt way

author: A1
sentence: Responsibly, not employing the next director off the street

author: A1
sentence: Go through the proper process, but we think that proper process ought to take only so much time

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so you have - the clout really comes from that, you have this potential risk or threat, so then it helps people to be proactive in using your guidelines

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A1
sentence: And these expectations are now understood

author: A1
sentence: I mean, they were originally 17 years ago now, and over time, people have begun to realise that not only is it an ASX rules, their own investors, shareholders and others are totally expecting it as well

author: Q
sentence: So how do you know that? How do you know shareholders expect this?

author: A2
sentence: And commerce

author: A1
sentence: Because we know that all of our companies - not all of them, but the majority of them at the larger end - have these engagements with shareholders and groups prior to their AGM

author: A1
sentence: So when they come up to have elections for directors at the forthcoming AGM, they’ll sit down with shareholders, and sometimes with proxy advisors, so these proxy advisors will provide advice to whomever asks for it

author: A1
sentence: Often they might be industry superfunds, or they might be offshore investors, and they’ll say, ‘I’ve got this enormous portfolio of investments

author: A1
sentence: I can’t follow everything

author: Q
sentence: How important do you think it is to have a diverse board? If I was to give you a scale of 110, where 10 is extremely important, and 1 is not at all

author: Q
sentence: Where would you put it?

author: A1
sentence: A diverse board, it would have to be 7 or higher, wouldn’t it? Probably for me it’s an 8

author: Q
sentence: Do you want to have a voice?

author: A2
sentence: I think I’ll leave that to Main participant

author: A2
sentence: <Laughs>

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that it’s always been important, and if this has always been the case?

author: A1
sentence: Well, I’ve given it an 8, so I rate it as important

author: A1
sentence: I think some might say, ‘What are you saying, the only correct answer can be 10

author: A1
sentence: ’ I only ever give marks of 8 on most things, or lower

author: A1
sentence: Well, it’s important these days - I mean, if we think about our company or we think about any company, the world’s never been an easy place to conduct business, but it’s an even more difficult place to conduct business with industry facing disruption in all these different areas, customers, different customer groups, different regulations, different skills that directors need

author: A1
sentence: You can’t possibly have five white males aged between 45 and 60 who have all the answers

author: A1
sentence: In fact, they’re going to have mostly the same answers to a lot of the questions

author: A1
sentence: And so it would make sense that there’d be ethnic diversity, skill diversity, age diversity, and, of course, gender diversity

author: A1
sentence: I think you could almost take that as a given

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: It’s that complexity -

author: A1
sentence: Yeah

author: A2
sentence: Also on that point is that with smaller boards, it’s a little bit more difficult to achieve the gender diversity ratios than in larger boards as well

author: A2
sentence: So there are some companies on the smaller end that do acknowledge the fact that they haven’t set any objectives just because of their size at the time

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: And -

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it varies with industries, are there some industries that are -

author: A1
sentence: Sure

author: A1
sentence: You take oil and gas

author: A1
sentence: I don’t know

author: A1
sentence: I’m aware that there are a reasonable number of females going through the university studying geology, but becoming geologists and being miners, these are reasonable numbers, but they’re not big numbers

author: A1
sentence: And if it’s oil and gas, it’s probably a lower representation of females again

author: A1
sentence: So if I’m a small oil and gas company, I might find it actually really difficult to even find a suitable candidate to join my board

author: A1
sentence: I might have a four person board, all male, all over 50, because try as I might, I couldn’t get great gender diversity, and maybe even diversity on the other measures within my world

author: A1
sentence: It does depend on industry

author: A1
sentence: You’ll see in other industries, they lend themselves more easily to female

author: A1
sentence: If we’re talking retail, or we’re talking health businesses - and the interesting thing for them is that sometimes they can tell a very good story around gender diversity, and these principles are kind of written to presume that everyone needs to improve their gender diversity, so what are your targets? And yet, if you’re kind of sitting at level where you like your diversity, you’re 50/50 on your board, or you might even be 60/40  to the female, you wouldn’t want to be improving that more, you might just want to maintain that

author: A1
sentence: So what do you say in your objectives? You’re going to try and maintain it

author: A1
sentence: It might be perfectly valid

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, sometimes change is not good

author: Q
sentence: <Laughter> Do you think that there is any situation or context that might cause you to change your importance rating? So not now that you have your 60/40 or your 50/50, but the importance that diversity has

author: Q
sentence: Is there anything uncertainty, high risk, uncertainty, anything?

author: A1
sentence: I was at a breakfast just last week, and we were chatting about this at another university actually, MacquarieUniversity, where I was a graduate in finance, and I actually was talking about this point

author: A1
sentence: Because I must have been - I wasn’t specifically thinking about forthcoming interview, but it was probably in my head

author: A1
sentence: And I said, ‘It would be great to get information, actual data that proves that better governed companies per these principles are actually definitely delivering, as can be seen from the data, definitely delivering better outcomes for shareholders in their returns

author: A1
sentence: Because I’m not aware that there’s been that work done

author: A1
sentence: And if the work was done and it proved it beyond doubt, then everyone would have to - and part of that was the diversity on boards- then what shareholder would stand against that, what person would stand against that? If it was - I mean, a lot of people think that socially it’s the right thing to do, or there’s other reasons to do it over and above or outside of shareholder returns, but if the shareholder returns are being produced by it, then the argument is largely done, I would have thought

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Well, the evidence won’t be clear, I’m telling you that

author: Q
sentence: <Laughter> That’s us, we’re looking for perceptions

author: Q
sentence: There is no situation that you would change, except, like you’re saying, if there was evidence, evidence of financial gain for shareholders, that would be a mover

author: A1
sentence: I think so

author: A1
sentence: But I think you’re right, it’s going to be very difficult to find the evidence, because you can’t have an experiment where you have ANZ wanting to have a completely male board and we’ll see how that goes

author: A1
sentence: Westpac, why don’t you have 50/50 and let’s see how that goes

author: A1
sentence: If you’re prepared to be in the experiment, we want to see how it goes

author: Q
sentence: <Laughs>Exactly

sentence: I can send you a really good review I found, if you want

author: Q
sentence: Not on that, but would you be interested? Do you have time to read such things?

author: A1
sentence: Yeah, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, it’s a review of a literature on performance

author: Q
sentence: But it says there is no clear answer

author: A
sentence: I particularly enjoy working with senior people

author: A
sentence: Not because of hierarchy or status, but because they have the most impact for good and for bad

author: A
sentence: That's definitely where my focus is

author: A
sentence: Let me just - and we're all set

author: Q
sentence: You have a psychology background?

author: Q
sentence: The individual leader

author: A
sentence: - why not me? By the way, I do a lot of work with young leaders and I love them

author: A
sentence: They are the hope of the world!

author: Q
sentence: Uh-oh

author: A
sentence: No, they really are!

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, I love my nieces and nephews!

author: A
sentence: Yeah and so I think that that's really important

author: A
sentence: So, when you talk about age diversity, I think having them at the table - some of the best groups that I've run for example, back in YPO, where we have everyone from grandparents to these young adults where I had the whole gamut in the group

author: A
sentence: It's extraordinary because this group up here certainly understand that the world has changed so much, I can really, really learn from you; and if you have respect in the group that the millennials recognise that if you have role models in the group, gosh I can learn from you and your experience! So, that's a wonderful mix

author: Q
sentence: So, respect in the group is really key then?

author: A
sentence: Totally

author: A
sentence: Respect and trust

author: Q
sentence: How is that built?

author: A
sentence: Well -

author: A
sentence: I do

author: A
sentence: But I kind of an eclectic - I'm not a registered psychologist, I'm qualified to be but I'm not

author: A
sentence: I just didn't go down that path, so how I think about my background is that it's quite eclectic in that originally it was philosophy and politics, then I went on and did post-grad in psych in the States and then in Queensland, at a post-graduate level

author: A
sentence: But I think my career has always been in that space of education and growth and human potentially really, and I've got a business background as well

author: Q
sentence: This is board functioning

author: A
sentence: Yeah, board functioning

author: A
sentence: Having explicit rules of engagement is really important in that; why are we here?  What are we all signing up for? So if we focus on the process rather than - see, most board meetings are like 95% content and task, whereas I think the most important focus is to just to remind everyone about how we engage, everyone comes prepared, so it's about commitment, it's about respect for each other, it's about confidentiality, trust

author: A
sentence: All those elements, the rules of engagement have to be agreed to, they have to be explicit, we have to remind each other of them and call each other out; so, values and action

author: A
sentence: Very few boards pay attention to that

author: A
sentence: One rule of engagement could be; we're open to challenge

author: A
sentence: It's really about having a conversation all committed to why are we here

author: A
sentence: Having a positive impact

author: A
sentence: So, there's that

author: A
sentence: That's major important but even more important is who's at that table

author: A
sentence: Now, if you have people that are driven by their ego and their ambition, you might have a narcissist - and I think it's fair to say they are over represented at senior levels - that's tricky, but that can be managed by strong leadership

author: A
sentence: By a chair for example who is setting boundaries, who is holding the space, creating the safe space where people are able to contribute; so, it's all that stuff

author: Q
sentence: Oh, this is wonderful because -

author: A
sentence: It's all there!

author: Q
sentence: -@ yeah exactly

author: A
sentence: No, I'm not saying it for that reason

author: Q
sentence: No, but -

author: A
sentence: But that's what I really believe in

author: A
sentence: It's about that, basically what we're talking about is that emotional maturity and that detachment from people's own egos and drives

author: Q
sentence: In your experience, how many boards in Australia - let me focus on that one - actually have values, let's call them values, and are rules and whatever values -

author: A
sentence: Function optimally? Along those lines?

author: Q
sentence: Oh? That didn't come -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that they actually make it explicit what their values are, so that the chair can then set boundaries

author: A
sentence: I think very few

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, that's what I feared

author: A
sentence: Very few, it's crazy though

author: A
sentence: I can guarantee you that I could go into any board and not I, being I, Participant, but anyone that could in this space, could go in and draw most board's attention to this challenge of, are you just focussed on getting the work done or are you actually focussed on being optimal? And how do we really increase our impact and be of significance? It's the same with organisations

author: A
sentence: I get so excited when I find them, they do exist! And they -

author: Q
sentence: [Inaudible] 00:29:36 where is it, who creates it?

author: A
sentence: Well, always! Definitely and sometimes it can be a momentous task

author: A
sentence: But it's about the leadership

author: Q
sentence: What has come up in other interviews is that - when we talk about conflict or anything because that comes up in the board one, the director one - the chair does it, but there's nothing underneath that, nothing to -

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: - this is really what you're pointing out

author: Q
sentence: You're saying this is what the Chair does

author: A
sentence: Yeah, but at the same time we have to have everyone - a distributed leadership as well -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well I've had my own businesses

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, but set up a distributed model rather than a top down model

author: A
sentence: Yeah exactly, it is [unclear] 00:30:26 authoritative though and getting that buy-in and getting that engagement, and getting the vibrancy and making the meetings interesting and stimulating

author: A
sentence: But I think too, the other thing that we haven't mentioned is there's such a focus on just risk management now, rather than if you think about boards being focussed equally on perhaps strategy and risk management, I think it's unfortunately - I think we can tip - and that's once again that's because of the personalities sometimes of the board, lean very much into the risk management of it; which is absolutely vital

author: A
sentence: But not being strategic enough in terms of what are we seeing here? What is the - in terms of looking at the operations of the organisation and looking at the bigger picture, I don't mean going into the operations, but asking those strategic questions; what's happening here? And what path are we on?

author: Q
sentence: Rather than compliance, [unclear] 00:31:34 like legal -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, auditing -

author: Q
sentence: -@ financial?

author: A
sentence: - which should be an absolute given in terms that they're foundational, of course

author: Q
sentence: With diversity, do you think it can be seen to undermine that focus on risk or make it more complex?

author: A
sentence: No! You just have to make sure that - when you're looking at board composition you have to have those fundamentals covered, but it's - absolutely

author: Q
sentence: So, it has the capacity

author: A
sentence: It has to have the capacity

author: A
sentence: You need a lawyer; you need an accountant

author: Q
sentence: Oh, of course

author: Q
sentence: Oh, and you were the Chair of -

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there's anything where diversity has little bearing on a particular board function? Is a board function that diversity has no bearing on it at all?

author: A
sentence: No, I don't

author: A
sentence: Because when you think of risks and what blindsides boards or organisations is tunnel-vision, so you can be looking at the numbers but without someone asking a question from left field - that'll come from the edges rather than being right in the problem or the task

author: A
sentence: It's someone from over here that will say, "Well, hang on, that doesn't quite sit comfortably with me because of my background that was in firefighting

author: Q
sentence: Exactly!

author: A
sentence: No absolutely

author: A
sentence: If it's important enough and complex enough, I don't mean complicated but it's -

author: Q
sentence: Socially and political

author: A
sentence: - yeah then diversity can only be an asset, not a distraction

author: A
sentence: But that's where it's not chaotic

author: A
sentence: Diversity is about how do we really access this rich resource in a way that's purposeful? It's not chaotic or we're not lurching all over the place because diversity is a resource

sentence: Okay, beautiful

author: A
sentence: No, that's the thing

author: A
sentence: That's the thing in that we're witnessing signatures, do we need 10 different types of writing styles? Probably not, but it's - I think the work of the board with risk management and the focus on the - it's not just governance, it's also strategy

author: A
sentence: So, I think it's really important

author: A
sentence: It can only add value

author: A
sentence: Senhoa, yes

sentence: You've explained it beautifully, don't worry, that'll be fantastic

author: A
sentence: I was on a board where the CEO and it was a not-for-profit, it was the most ambitious individual, total narcissist and what he was doing was, he had built this team around him of 'yes' people, he was a very charismatic individual and he held all the power in his executive team and on the board

author: A
sentence: I won't go into the history, but he had what he considered - or who he considered to be quite a weak chair

author: A
sentence: He invited me to join the board for a particular reason and I was accepted on to the board, and I think he made the mistake that I was just going to be kind of his 'yes man'

author: A
sentence: Because that was the deal, right! That was the actual unconscious deal that he made with everyone that he surrounded himself with

author: A
sentence: What he did though, he was actually developing this IP - or someone in the business was - and he wanted to take that out to be a separate company

author: Q
sentence: And IP is?

author: A
sentence: Intellectual Property

author: Q
sentence: Oh! right

author: A
sentence: Yeah sorry! Software that could be used for their client base, but he wanted take it out to a separate company

author: A
sentence: Okay, that's interesting and he wanted to be CEO as well of that separate company and a shareholder because it was going to be a private company; and that he felt he was deserving of the shares because of what a wonderful job he'd done over here

author: A
sentence: So, myself and the chair and two other people on this board - there was about a dozen people on this board - had a different view! He went into a kind of narcissistic rage

author: A
sentence: We had a six hour board meeting which was terrible

author: A
sentence: It was just - and I have to say I think I participated as badly as everyone else! But the upshot of it all was that he actually found a way - a legal loophole - he'd found a lawyer that actually declared our board not legitimate because of some - and it was just - and he held all the money! This is a true story, it's phenomenal

author: A
sentence: I mean it's an extreme story, but when I was talking to the AICD and - the course, you'd be amazed at the stories that we hear, and it comes down to what lengths do you go to as a board member

author: A
sentence: Speaking up can obviously come at -

author: Q
sentence: A great price

author: A
sentence: - and I know of many people who have been shunted off boards for speaking up

author: A
sentence: What was the question? Sorry, my fault!

author: A
sentence: Cambodia, that's right yes

author: Q
sentence: A story of how the chair can facilitate these power games

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well that one was one where the chair clearly lost control and that was extremely toxic, but I think in that kind of situation, it's very, very difficult

author: A
sentence: That's an extreme -

author: Q
sentence: Not a bad example

author: A
sentence: - but not as extreme

author: A
sentence: I think that it's a matter of trying to - well as I said before, "Setting up

author: A
sentence: These are our rules of engagement

author: A
sentence: " Being very clear and consistent, it's like parenting! These are the boundaries and the consequences for everyone

author: A
sentence: We all sign up to them as adults

author: A
sentence: But I think it's about ensuring that you're fostering relationships with everyone

author: A
sentence: That's about inclusivity

author: A
sentence: What tends to happen naturally is that people can lean closer to other people, so then all the sibling rivalry starts to emerge

author: A
sentence: So, it's really making sure that - but also that people are accountable to contribute

author: A
sentence: That's the other thing, if you think about human history, the problem has always come up is when people feel that things are unequal

author: A
sentence: So, if I feel like you're king of being a passenger here and you're being paid or whatever and you're -

author: Q
sentence: Freeloading

author: A
sentence: - just showing up, so I think it's about holding people to account

author: A
sentence: Having the rules of engagement, making them explicit, calling out the behaviour in that classic chair role, firmly and fairly

author: A
sentence: Having your conversations outside with your one-on-ones to try and like whisper the people -

author: Q
sentence: Into the group

author: A
sentence: - yeah, into the group

author: Q
sentence: Good

author: Q
sentence: That's a good example, it illustrated your point which was made earlier

author: Q
sentence: There's a lot of talk about diversity of understanding, beliefs, problem solving; do you think that's really important?

author: A
sentence: Diversity of?

author: Q
sentence: - to prevent - well, hopefully limit their -

author: Q
sentence: Understandings, beliefs - it's called cognitive diversity

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely! Because things like - whether it's our conscious vibes or cognitive vibes, there's about a hundred of them, I think - yeah, totally

author: Q
sentence: Do you think everything reduces to that?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: What doesn't and can you -

author: A
sentence: What doesn't reduce to cognitive diversity?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, because you talked a lot about the decision making and that which could come as cognitive diversity, it could be seen as cognitive diversity

author: A
sentence: Well, cognitive is only one element

author: A
sentence: And I think that's the problem, is when there's a bias just towards what seems - what can we make look like common-sense here? Or, a good business case for this? Human beings can rationalise anything

author: A
sentence: Particularly their own behaviour! That's why it's limiting

author: A
sentence: Things like integrity are incredibly important

author: A
sentence: Are we actually acting with integrity? The capacity to think systemically

author: A
sentence: Are we actually seeing the whole picture here? Can we refrain? Innovation plays a part, too

author: A
sentence: Can we think about this differently? Are we asking the right question? So that's another important thing

author: A
sentence: Are we all tapping into our own experience to bring to bear here? Or am I being unduly influenced by your story? Your experience bases? Are we really holding up the mirror here and seeing what our patterns are? Do we tend to just rubber-stamp, for example? There's a culture

author: A
sentence: What's the dance in the board? Is it just to kind of all agree or maybe we have someone who is a black-hat and we hound them down? What are the patterns? Do we actually hold the mirror up? Are we actually showing - tapping into our humanity?

author: A
sentence: We are a group of human-beings and no matter what sector you're in or what board you're on; it involves people

author: A
sentence: It's going to impact on people so have we brought enough expertise into the room? Who do we need to collaborate and connect with? Are we positioned to make an important decision? I could go on and on!

author: Q
sentence: Perfect

author: Q
sentence: That's excellent

author: A
sentence: That's yours, hope I've done that right

author: A
sentence: Have I signed it for you? Yeah, I have

author: A
sentence: And does it actually connect with what the organisations purpose is, as well? That's more the culture

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that's great

author: Q
sentence: You've really situated it - shown the other things that matter

author: A
sentence: Decision making is far more complex than -

author: Q
sentence: Cognitive

author: A
sentence: - cognitive

author: A
sentence: That's the easy part

author: Q
sentence: Then the challenge is when you're selecting new board members

author: Q
sentence: How might you go about that if you're interested in building diversity?

author: A
sentence: Well, I think you have that front and centre that we are building a diverse board and having quite a broad definition of diversity

author: A
sentence: Diversity is more than just gender and race, I think

author: A
sentence: It is about what is the range of experiences for example, that this person brings

author: A
sentence: The grittier someone's experience base is better, for example

author: A
sentence: I think setting that as front and centre and really looking hard to find people that - we're not cloning

author: A
sentence: We know what happens when we clone, yeah?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Have you seen this work well through - are there particular strategies that really help to select a board that is diverse like that? Because it's hard to measure some of these things, I mean, backgrounds you can

author: A
sentence: I think in practice and there'd be other people better qualified - I imagine - the technical capacities to do this exist, you get the experts in; recruitment et cetera

author: A
sentence: But I think that generally speaking, it is about who knows who, who's turn it is, who's in the right place at the right time, quite often, do we need a female? All these other drivers that also can come into place

author: A
sentence: It is hard - very rarely do you start with a blank slate anyway

author: A
sentence: No, I can't think of examples where it's happened beautifully!

author: Q
sentence: I see your organisation as doing - really being about cultivating board candidates - leadership ultimately, if you want to have impact not just senior management and executive management but being on a board

author: Q
sentence: That's really your -

author: Q
sentence: Well thank you, Participant, for agreeing to participate, that's wonderful

author: Q
sentence: It's good

author: A
sentence: Being a worth board member

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, exactly

sentence: That's definitely what my - my core business and focus and passion

author: Q
sentence: Given that, do you do anything to help people from minority groups, they might be financially - you would charge, so there could be financial barriers for some people? So, do you have any strategies to cultivate people perhaps from a lower socio-economic group?

author: A
sentence: I do, yes

author: A
sentence: I just don't charge them corporate rates

author: A
sentence: It's often less than half of what my normal would be

author: A
sentence: Years ago, I use to charge - and sometimes I charge nothing - if I mentoring and I actually call it mentoring, so I'm seeing a young person and she's on the board of her own not-for-profit

author: A
sentence: It's extraordinary, I find them so inspiring but for people whose organisation's not funding them, yeah, I do

author: A
sentence: I always have

author: Q
sentence: Okay, oh good

author: Q
sentence: That's [unclear] 00:47:49

author: A
sentence: I want to do more in that - and I don't quite know what it is - in that I feel like there's something in me still that - I am very passionate about the world actually needs worthy leaders

author: A
sentence: I don't quite know what that looks like yet and I'm not overstating my own - I'm not being grandiose here but I feel like I would like to contribute

author: A
sentence: I'm not quite sure what that platform looks like at this point - sort of a niggle!

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, okay

author: Q
sentence: I will ask of other people; I'm intrigued how it might be solved

author: Q
sentence: From a regulatory perspective, how do you feel about the way diversity of boards is currently being promoted in Australia? For example, through gender targets and quotas?

author: A
sentence: I wonder whether - I think targets are great

author: A
sentence: In a way in terms of it's a bit like the TAC saying, "Let's go towards zero

author: A
sentence: " I think it's an aspiration

author: A
sentence: I think an aspiration is important, that we're 50% of the population that boards need to reflect that

author: A
sentence: I do worry about the compliance part of it; it's like force feeding

author: Q
sentence: How do you think it effects - because you're very much into the confidence, the self-perception of the leader - do you think it might affect the self-perception?

author: A
sentence: Excellent, yeah so that's good and I've been on other boards and things as well

author: A
sentence: So, hopefully I can be of some assistance

author: A
sentence: Absolutely! I always say to people, "Even if you're being offered a job, let alone the top job, it's far better if you go through a merit selection; you'll own it, rather than, “I got parachuted in

author: A
sentence: " It's the worst feeling for people in terms of sense of worthiness

author: A
sentence: That's what I mean, I have mixed feelings around that - and there are great women!

author: Q
sentence: Of course!

author: A
sentence: That's the thing, look a bit harder!

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, you haven't even looked!

author: A
sentence: Encourage, foster

author: Q
sentence: We have women on boards here that are focussed on that strategy

author: Q
sentence: Another kind of diversity that you feel cannot be reliably measured and reported on, were you - like targets you think, can be useful -

author: A
sentence: Aspirations, yeah

author: A
sentence: Targets, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So, there are somethings that can't be measured and put up there as a graph -

author: A
sentence: Well, I think -

author: Q
sentence: How might?

author: Q
sentence: Yes, I am sure you will

author: Q
sentence: So, let's get going, okay

author: Q
sentence: There's a lot of talk about board diversity, but we're interested to hear from people on the ground and particularly from the Australian point of view, because there's not much research from the Australian point of view

author: Q
sentence: So, there's a lot of theory from other countries, but we're looking to develop a model that is informed by people - and I know you work in the US, you're quite a global citizen - but I also notice that you do work here in Australia

author: A
sentence: Oh, sorry, I've interrupted

author: Q
sentence: No, no go for it, please

author: A
sentence: One of the things that strikes me - and I've enjoyed the AICD course - but I think that not enough - or I might be wrong, but I think in my experience and just looking at the end result - is done to really educate, to train boards in Vivo almost - how can we be effective? In the same way that you might do for an executive team

author: A
sentence: But I think that it's too much experience and seen as the transacting, the getting through the board papers

author: A
sentence: I find board roles actually really quite unappealing and uninteresting

author: Q
sentence: Yeah?

author: A
sentence: I do!

author: Q
sentence: Defined roles, it goes with it! Anyway, the final question because I'm aware of the time

author: A
sentence: Yes, that's fine

author: Q
sentence: Finally, looking 10 years into the future, Participant, how would you like to see the diversity of the Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: Oh I would - look, walk around Melbourne, we are a multi-cultural society and so I would love to see us - it's a bit like that picture behind you, it's just reflecting the colours and the vibrancy - look at that! the dynamism that comes from race, cultures, gender, age variation

author: A
sentence: Have the warrior youth and the elders of the tribe all on the board! In terms of contributing in their own ways and learning from each other

author: Q
sentence: Oh, that's fantastic

author: Q
sentence: You've been a consistent focus on this process which is so key to the board's functioning

author: A
sentence: Yeah, in the main

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: I think it comes through in how you define diversity and I love the way you finish with it! It's beautiful

author: A
sentence: Well, I'm hope I've been able to give you something!

author: Q
sentence: Oh, absolutely

author: Q
sentence: Really good, seriously

author: Q
sentence: Any final comments?

author: A
sentence: Well, no it's interesting

author: A
sentence: No, not on - but it's actually interesting -

author: Q
sentence: Do I take this off?

author: A
sentence: Yes, sure

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, so you're familiar with our corporate landscape -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: - and how that feeds into boards

author: Q
sentence: So, I chose to use the questions from institutions

author: Q
sentence: They're institutions and people that influence Australian boards, rather than the questions directed at a director to talk about their particular board experience

author: A
sentence: Okay!

author: Q
sentence: Because that's what I really want, I thought you'd be able to bring

author: A
sentence: Sure

author: A
sentence: Are we being taped?

author: Q
sentence: So first, how have the composition of boards, that you're familiar with, changed over time in terms of diversity? Has it increased? Decreased?

author: A
sentence: Well if I think about over time and reporting into a board at quite a young age, in my late 20s in my first leadership role, and we do have females on boards and obviously not enough! But that's been one change

author: Q
sentence: We're getting more, you mean?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Was that a for-profit or a not-for-profit?

author: A
sentence: It was in the higher-ed sector, so yeah, not-for-profit, I guess

author: A
sentence: And actually, being on a board also in my 30s myself for-profit and I was the only female

author: A
sentence: Look, I don’t think that's changed a lot to be honest, in terms of diversity

author: Q
sentence: You're thinking specifically gender diversity?

author: A
sentence: Well that's the obvious one

author: A
sentence: But I think probably the less visible and more impactful element is personalities

author: A
sentence: For example, if you think about who actually ends up on boards, it's people who are achievement oriented which is good, and outcomes oriented which is also good, but that kind of classic split between the focus on task and people that - so that's one thing that you get a lot more people with more of an engineer type brain, rather than an innovative artist type personality; that would be one thing

author: A
sentence: So, logic over possibilities, sometimes

author: A
sentence: Brain over heart

author: A
sentence: I think also, the other obvious - which is more obvious too - is just social stratum

author: A
sentence: I think it's just the kind of middle class; educated of course, I've got my MBA in my briefcase!

author: Q
sentence: How does your organisation - I'll call you an organisation - how does your organisation influence that kind of diversity? Or seek to influence that kind of diversity of boards?

author: A
sentence: Well, that's why I wrote my book! In that for me, it's all about helping people, good people and what I mean by good people; people who are motivated to make a contribution, whatever sector they're in, a positive contribution to ask the question of, ‘Well why not me?’ The reason I called my book 'The Worthy Leader' is that so many people can - it's quite extraordinary how many people - even when they are at the table, are still asking 'am I doing a good enough job? could someone else do a better job?'

author: Q
sentence: And I'll just turn this on -

author: A
sentence: So, addressing that particular question, but also helping people really focus on that question of, how can I expand my worth and impact? And the way that most organisations are structured now, whether it's at the executive general board level, it's about being at the table

author: A
sentence: It's about participating

author: A
sentence: So, if I'm at the table, I have a voice and I can influence, which is really everything that speaks to leadership

author: Q
sentence: This is what you - for the sake of the context - how do you influence? How does your organisation seek to influence? You've got a book -

author: A
sentence: Via coaching and facilitation and it's really helping people to see - through those processes they're the two key processes - helping people to see themselves more accurately, clearly and their context

author: A
sentence: And to ask those questions; well, why not me? How do I get a seat at that table? Then if I'm there, what kind of impact can I make?

author: Q
