sentence: Do you work around people's networks? Do you use your own networks to help people that you're coaching or whatever? Or, do you work through the individual that you're working with only?

author: A
sentence: In the main, it's working with the individual; however, when I'm working in a mentoring role, I also meld - work as a mentor which is usually pro bono, it pretty well is - and so then I will tap into my own networks, bringing people together

author: A
sentence: In fact, I've got a meeting with a mentee this afternoon and in a form of when I'm in a coaching environment, occasionally I do

author: A
sentence: But it's more about helping people access their own wisdom, for want of a better word, in terms of their self-belief and to look at what they need to optimise within themselves, and also to activate their own networks

author: Q
sentence: Part of the empowerment?

author: A
sentence: Exactly

author: Q
sentence: Okay, great thanks

author: Q
sentence: Do you see this influence works across all industry sectors or do you think it works - your approach, your organisation - is it really specific industries?

author: A
sentence: Without question, across all sectors for every leader

author: A
sentence: Whether they're an aspirant leader, whether they're already at the table

author: A
sentence: I do a lot of work with CEOs for example through YPO which is the world's largest CEO network

author: A
sentence: What I do with them is group coaching, where they're from different organisations and they come together

author: A
sentence: Of course, many of them are chairs of their own boards as well

author: A
sentence: Without question, helping busy people stop and reflect and ask strategic questions about their leadership impact

author: A
sentence: It's important for everyone

author: A
sentence: I wish I'd had it!

author: Q
sentence: Yeah exactly

author: Q
sentence: So, how important do you think it is to have a diverse board? If I gave you a scale of one to 10; one not at all, 10 extremely?

author: A
sentence: Yeah great

author: A
sentence: Extremely

author: A
sentence: I mean for me, diversity is about inclusion, it's about tolerance and acceptance and that of course is about openness to learning

author: A
sentence: Which of course allows us to tap into the richness of other people's stories, whether their life experience or their practical technical experience; and I see this happen all the time in the groups of CEOs that I'm working with

author: A
sentence: Someone will come from the construction industry and then you'll have someone from retail or you'll have someone come from a very affluent background, you'll have someone who's come from struggle street as part of their story

author: A
sentence: Well, I'd never thought of it like that

author: A
sentence: You see people literally expand their perspective and so if you think about all that feeding into the decision making, the discerning process which leaders have to make which is how do we make the right decision here in these complex circumstances? It's so helpful, it's absolutely imperative and it's the survival of the species, right? Diversity!

author: Q
sentence: You're the first person to describe it that way

author: Q
sentence: It's wonderful! You're number 12

author: A
sentence: Oh!

author: Q
sentence: Yes, this is great

author: A
sentence: It's what I see

author: Q
sentence: It's beautiful

author: A
sentence: It actually works

author: A
sentence: It's about how we do activate and tap into - whether it's your story or expertise, it's phenomenal the stories and backgrounds that people have

author: A
sentence: It's about unlocking and allowing -

author: Q
sentence: Unlocking?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, unlocking that diversity and allowing - appropriately, of course - be accessible to others

author: Q
sentence: So, this group, where you have the CEs from different places, do you select it to be a diverse group?

author: Q
sentence: - and here's a consent form for it

author: A
sentence: No, the organisation - it's one of their values, diversity, the reality - and there's something like 27,000 members from across the world, so it's massive; quite USA eccentric

author: A
sentence: But the reality is we get these little groups together, they're called forums, eight to 10 people

author: A
sentence: Except for countries like Indonesia where - in the main, they're quite male dominant, of course

author: A
sentence: They're not diverse in that they've ended up - they may not have started - but they've ended up being the wealthy people

author: A
sentence: Because the selection criteria to belong to the organisation is pretty high, very high

author: A
sentence: So, there's that, but we certainly have diversity of race - it's a global organisation - definitely; religions, personalities and they're actively trying to get more females

author: A
sentence: The other thing we do is we have younger - the CEOs kids are active in the organisation as are their partners

author: A
sentence: But they're not in the actual particular little groups, but they have their own separate - so that's inclusive

author: Q
sentence: It spreads out the network through the family

author: A
sentence: Mm-hm, it's family friendly

author: Q
sentence: So, in Australia, what's the story here with that organisation? I know that isn't easy

author: A
sentence: Well the story here in Australia is - oh and the other diverse element that they have is, totally diverse sectors people come from

author: A
sentence: It could be engineering or it could be advertising agencies whatever, so there's definitely the different sectors

author: A
sentence: There's also the difference between corporate and entrepreneurs so that provides diversity

author: A
sentence: And there's also what I call MFBs, my father's business! Then the ones that have been the founders of their own business

author: A
sentence: So, there is that, yeah

author: Q
sentence: How it came to be

author: Q
sentence: So, in Australia, the situation?

author: A
sentence: That's the situation

author: Q
sentence: That's the situation here?

author: A
sentence: Yeah!

author: Q
sentence: That's out here too?  Because I notice you're a facilitator with these organisations -

author: A
sentence: Great, okay

author: A
sentence: Yes, that's right

author: Q
sentence: -@ So you do that out here in Australia

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Okay, perfect that's good

author: Q
sentence: You think it's really important - diversity here in Australia, has it always been important, do you think?

author: A
sentence: Oh, as I said, "It's the survival of the species

author: A
sentence: " In that if I'm not able to access a range of possibilities from within a board or from within an executive team, then the chances of us being vibrant and flourishing - that's why organisations get blindsided, because we think of all the cognitive biases and decision making, for example - in that we need someone, not just through a skill base but because they're coming from a diverse background

author: Q
sentence: It's raw

author: A
sentence: How about this? Or what I know is something different?

author: Q
sentence: Do you think such diversity has always been valued by others? By other boards? Seen as a good thing to have?

author: A
sentence: No! [unclear] 00:18:49 no, not at all, look at the history of the human race!

author: Q
sentence: Do you think it's become more important, recently?

author: Q
sentence: You've probably read it

author: Q
sentence: I'm very keen to hear your views, as I mentioned in the lift, of how you can influence Australian boards and in particular looking up-stream, because of your work in leadership and coaching

author: A
sentence: I think we are in transition and it seems like the transition has been taking a long time and I think that's totally understandable, particularly when you think about gender, which I think has been the biggest shift

author: A
sentence: What we've got at the moment is probably compliance around that and it's what people say when they're not in their formal roles, which I think is most telling

author: A
sentence: Still the boy’s club, for example; yesterday I was invited to a meeting of the boys and they forgot that I was on the invitation and it was about confirming, and one of them says, "Yeah, I'll be there you c-u-n-t!" and I've heard it before, nothing will shock me but I'm thinking - so it's that kind - because they were thinking they were just in their club and that's fine

author: A
sentence: I guess what that speaks to is that there's a lot being suppressed I think, and they thought that was private, that discussion

author: A
sentence: Rather than - generalisations are so - the trend is; we're not there

author: Q
sentence: Because there's still that language

author: A
sentence: Yeah and there's still, I think, resentment which is very politically incorrect to express on behalf of males; for them to be able to say, "We're forced to have females, there's pressure on us and we have to be seen to be doing the right thing

author: A
sentence: " Look at what happened with the board directors of that bank, I think that's a classic example where with the Royal Commission

author: A
sentence: They were the ones - the two - I can't remember who they were with, was it - look I'm just saying, I think it's still - women are judged more harshly and there is a sense of - I think the whole merit versus quota thing is still very muddy

author: A
sentence: We're not there yet

author: Q
sentence: Good, because they're these questions

author: Q
sentence: I might switch to that and make sure that we don't miss a point

author: Q
sentence: We're talking now about barriers

author: Q
sentence: Five years ago, the situation was very clubby and now you don't see any difference?

author: A
sentence: At the deepest level, not

author: A
sentence: It's what's running under the surface

author: A
sentence: At the surface, absolutely

author: A
sentence: People are forced to resign if they say something inappropriate or we have to have the quotas at the table and I am generalising

author: A
sentence: Of course, some organisations have made that shift -

author: Q
sentence: At the deepest level, we're talking?

author: A
sentence: It's cultural I think, both at a broader level and at an organisational level in that - and it's a real transition, almost like a changing-of-the-guard in that - and there's also another force that's rising, which is through the younger people too, which is the next generation coming up, which is the - what's the word? Which is the - they're not conditioned like I was for example and you might have been too, that it was normal to have just white middle-aged men around the table in this country and that you didn't give it a second thought

author: A
sentence: Whereas now, I think we're all noticing and thinking, hang on a second, that picture doesn't look quite right

author: A
sentence: So, I think things are shifting but not in reality at the table, if that makes sense

author: A
sentence: Yes, social mores and - definitely I think there's a shift but it's still - we're not there

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the social mores that can help to drive organisational or cultural change?

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: I'm all about - it's the journey to leadership wisdom

author: A
sentence: My focus is on leadership maturity

author: A
sentence: I've had a lot of years and I had businesses in leadership competence, 360-Degree Feedback et cetera and I just became increasingly interested in leadership maturity

author: Q
sentence: And then that in turn can help to reshape the table or board -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: - and the decision makers -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: - but it's slow

author: A
sentence: It's slow and it's generational

author: A
sentence: If you look at, for example, the role of the male parent - think back to my father for example - so of course, but it's a transition and it's painful for some people

author: Q
sentence: This is now the making sense of why age diversity might be important because it will help to bring in the newer social mores -

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: Q
sentence: - in selection, for selection

author: Q
sentence: So, your role then in mentoring and facilitation, do you work with the social mores to try and influence organisational culture?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I've done a lot of that but I think at the moment as well probably more frequently, it's working with the individual and their own self-limiting beliefs; which begs that question of before -

author: A
sentence: No, it’s actually two months short of 22 years, but as I pointed out to you it’s only been one board so I haven't had a cross section experience of other boards

author: Q
sentence: And it was 22 years?

author: A
sentence: Yes, it’s market evidence

author: Q
sentence: - for resolving it, yeah

author: Q
sentence: the conflict that arose around this, did it divide the board?

author: A
sentence: No because if a board was tending to divide on something then we got an independent evaluation of the circumstance, of the issue and we’d generally then settle for whatever they came up with, albeit it might’ve been tweaked a bit or something like that

author: A
sentence: But I can recall that the Fund Manager Entity did take a bigger chunk of equity in the fund eventually, and so the fact that you’ve got skin in the game meant that they had to look after both their longer term interests the same as they had investors

author: A
sentence: So they were on board in that way, but day to day fee structures, well yeah you’ll pinch a bit of money here and there

author: Q
sentence: So there’s another thing now, there’s the long term interest and the independent advice helping to alleviate the conflict?

author: A
sentence: Mm hm

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful, okay

author: Q
sentence: And yes, the conflict or diversity, was it influenced by institutions such as your big investors, super investors and stuff like that?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: We used to meet at least once a year with investors, and sometimes depending on the circumstances if there was a big buyout of another company or something like that sometimes the investors wanted to meet to talk about that because it was quite a big chunk of money or something like that

author: A
sentence: But we met with investors on an investor tour once a year

author: A
sentence: That’s the chairman and myself, I did that with the Victorian and another director did New South Wales

author: A
sentence: It was just depending on the circumstances

author: A
sentence: The GFC obviously raised a lot of issues there, and the investors were calling for more feedback on issues that were going on overseas and things like that

author: A
sentence: So in those circumstances yeah investors heightened their feedback, but in good times, well in the last few years I recall at annual board meetings where the investors turned up we would be lucky to have 10 people, whereas after the GFC we would’ve had 200

author: Q
sentence: Wow

author: A
sentence: So you can see how it reflects on the day to day and how it’s all travelling

author: A
sentence: If it’s smooth going you never hear from them

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: So the GFC was a major marker in board -

author: A
sentence: Yes because of the losses that were there, the share prices dropped dramatically and we had a lot of overseas investment in America and that sort of thing too so -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, so you were exposed

author: A
sentence: Yeah, currency fluctuations really exposes you all from GFC

author: A
sentence: So yes, in times of trouble you really get the feedback

author: Q
sentence: And going back to diversity, diversity helps there?

author: A
sentence: Most definitely

author: A
sentence: In handling those issues, yeah absolutely because you only have one of those GFCs once in your business lifetime -

author: Q
sentence: Hopefully

author: A
sentence: Generally, yeah, and coping with that takes a lot more time and involvement in what you’re doing

author: Q
sentence: So how did diversity of the board help with that situation, that adjustment?

author: A
sentence: I think someone who’s had experience in overseas investments, with the financial transactions between two countries, having a knowledge of that

author: A
sentence: Having a knowledge of the respective governances in another country as well as our country

author: A
sentence: They differ in some aspects and you have to compromise through a point on some of those or at least have to be aware of them

author: A
sentence: The reporting systems are different and all that

author: A
sentence: So in terms of diversity someone who’s had experience in overseas investments is important

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so first how has the composition of the board that you’re familiar with changed over those 22 years?  How has it changed?

author: Q
sentence: Before the global financial crisis that really wasn’t considered?

author: A
sentence: It probably was yeah, but then again that’s my only experience in overseas investments and it really hit home then

author: A
sentence: On other boards, well there’s a lot of Australian companies that invest overseas, huge some companies, so they would require that sort of experience from that board diversity in terms of that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: So that’s not just skills now, that’s experience background

author: Q
sentence: Like someone who’s been to the States and worked in that industry over there is valuable on the board here?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, and all the governance would surround businesses over there as well

author: A
sentence: So that’s probably key for that rather than just a designated Australian company, specifically Australian investment

author: Q
sentence: With your board it was really the global financial crisis that brought that need to the surface

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: Probably for a number of other Australian boards that was a real wakeup call to this is a global community and diversity will help us

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: At all times you can go and outsource it with the Australian legal system who are fairly up with all those latest things, and you can always get their opinions, which we did in a lot of cases

author: A
sentence: But even again the final decisions, and if you have a diverse board and they’re on top of that and are familiar with it, then it’s easier to make a decision

author: Q
sentence: You can anticipate

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well originally when I was asked to go on this board it was a newly formed trust back in ’95

author: A
sentence: My understanding in those days having not been on a board before was that I was interviewed by the directors of a major Bank and they wanted to have someone of experience because they were putting together a shopping centre retail trust

author: A
sentence: So with my background and -

author: Q
sentence: Good, okay

author: Q
sentence: This is a question about the role of the chair

author: Q
sentence: We’ve talked about outsourcing the decision to an independent about finances, about fees, was there anything else that the chair did perhaps in the situation where the global financial crisis happened and the impacts were being felt, and your board was let’s say struggling to respond to this incredible overnight almost uncertainty and risk exposure and loss, so how did the board respond, did it create conflict and if so what role did the chair play?

author: A
sentence: We certainly visited America a few more times to meet – we had joint venture partners over there

author: A
sentence: So we met with them face to face rather than accepting what management tell us

author: A
sentence: So we had a firsthand view of who we’re dealing with

author: A
sentence: Now I’ve forgotten the question

author: Q
sentence: In this crisis situation what did the chair and the board do to manage that conflict?

author: A
sentence: There’s probably a lot more outsourcing required into how we managed these circumstances

author: A
sentence: Market trending on where the market was going and making decisions at the right time and for the right reason

author: A
sentence: Our chair, he was very experienced

author: A
sentence: He came from an accounting background and a number of boards

author: A
sentence: What else?

author: Q
sentence: So it sounds as though it was a reliance on outsourcing to get independent expert advice, and trending and analysis did management do that or was that once again outsourced?

author: A
sentence: Management instructed them on the feedback we needed, then of course they run with it, and then they come and present it back to the board after that

author: A
sentence: So you just rely on the management and how they present it to them

author: A
sentence: But it’s normally documented stuff in any case so it’s nothing they can invent if you like

author: A
sentence: So they prepared all that and it came back in a final draft and then we went through that

author: Q
sentence: So I would call this like a rational decision making process, was there anything around the social soft stuff?  So were people anxious and did the chair do anything, did the board do anything to manage anxieties within the board?  Was insurance around -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, things like insurances and things like that were checked

author: A
sentence: The grievances were expressed at annual general meetings when the shareholders came along, and you got the drift of what they were looking at and what they wanted you to achieve or avoid or whatever

author: A
sentence: As is aid the difference between when there’s an urgent situation on and things are going smoothly, in terms of people harassing you or investors harassing you, it’s just one extreme to another, and as long as they’re getting their return, reasonable and that, everybody goes quiet

author: A
sentence: With the bigger investors you go and talk it through with them, and generally they’re aware of what’s going on in the market in any case and they might just have some questions on, “Is so and so doing his job properly?”, the CEO or something like that

author: A
sentence: Because the investors also meet with CEOs and that sort of thing, and if they had any grievances with the key executive staff they would air those at our meetings

author: A
sentence: If it was something extremely crucial they’d just pick up the phone and ring the chair

author: A
sentence: So from that point of view you’ve got an open door to all investors at any time, and as long as you maintain that then there’s no need for panic

author: Q
sentence: So really the chair had to work with, it’s not just the board, it’s about the relations between management and investors and the board

author: Q
sentence: Your background’s in?

author: A
sentence: That’s right, yeah

author: Q
sentence: So that really became the focus then, not just are we being nice and open to each and respectful

author: A
sentence: No, and you’ve got to be completely honest in what you portray to the investors as well

author: A
sentence: Everybody gets found out eventually if you twist something which isn't quite true

author: A
sentence: There’s always stuff on the table that someone can find and research it and say, “Hey, that wasn’t said on this date, it was said on another date and this is what you said and no you didn’t do it

author: Q
sentence: Yeah because they’re big stakes aren't they?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: I talked about cognitive diversity, you’ve already answered that question, so now it’s the last few questions, managing diversity

author: Q
sentence: This is about board selection, did the board consider ways to increase diversity as you understood it the skills I think it’s your background skills when they were selecting?

author: A
sentence: Yes, and again today as distinct from years gone by around the mid 90’s, back in the Macquarie days when the fund was managed by Macquarie in those early days from what as far as I was aware, a lot of new directors were just recommendations from inside directors, whereas now the directors use companies to outsource and present people who match what your criteria is

author: A
sentence: So you’re relying on them because again there’s platforms for that, for people who put their names on these sort of things as experience and that, so should it come up you can pick them off and say well these are the groups that do the initial investigation, do the basic research of what you’re trying to achieve in terms of the board, and then they might put up half a dozen people for the board to review them face to face independently

author: A
sentence: So that was probably one of the biggest transitions I saw over the time is that became more professional and selective about who they chose rather than maybe than just, “I’ve got a friend that wants to go on the board

author: A
sentence: ”  I suspect a lot of that used to happen

author: Q
sentence: So when did this change happen?

author: A
sentence: It’s hard to pick of the time

author: A
sentence: In shopping centre management, development, leasing and all that sort of thing, I attained that background working with Westfield combined with a retail background with Woolworths supermarkets

author: A
sentence: So I was doing some consulting work for a major bank and they asked me, “Would you mind having a position on this new Retail REIT board we are creating?  I knew nothing about board positions back then and it would appear you didn’t have to have any sort of set criteria for it, but obviously my retail and associated property background suited their requirements

author: A
sentence: But as time went on and you’ll appreciate that governments became more involved with the regulatory process and the deeper responsibilities representing investor’s interests

author: A
sentence: So it was the responsibility of the company forming these Trusts etc

author: A
sentence: , to drill down a bit more to ensure appropriate business backgrounds of Board members which adequately represented the investor and regulatory requirements

author: Q
sentence: Five, 10 years ago?

author: A
sentence: I’d say probably more so after the GFC I think, yeah you were expected to get out there

author: A
sentence: With the gender diversity too, that has brought that in as well because there’s been a push for that in the last 10 years as well

author: A
sentence: So in that last five years or even the last three to five years we had the first woman ever introduced to our board who came on, and then one of the other directors who represented the Property Trust for the management, she was a director too

author: A
sentence: So that was changing as my term was coming to an end

author: A
sentence: Again it’s very unusual I think to have a board with the amount of men that we had on it to go for such a long term each one

author: A
sentence: But again I think that just shows that the board work well together so they kept it, and the investors saw that the board was working well together and the results were there so there was no need to change it

author: A
sentence: So again it’s only something disruptive in the market sometimes that it gets ripples back up and they want to have a look at change

author: Q
sentence: The tenure was quite long -

author: A
sentence: Well mine was and the chairman when I was there, he was there for at least 18 years and he’s just retired last year and there was another chap there who was there  for about 12 to 14 years as well

author: Q
sentence: So now is it a limited period you’re on the board for?

author: A
sentence: I think it always had a limitation, but in the transition from when the original management platform was sold from one banking entity to the new specialist Property Trust REIT, we existing Independent Directors had a further “grandfathering” extension period of two three year terms by default, when it transitioned over to the new entity

author: A
sentence: The new entity wanted to retain the Trusts historic knowledge through the sitting Independent Directors, as it was important to show their investors that Board stability prevailed at least into the near future

author: A
sentence: If the success of the group was there since the REIT’s inception, why would you push them out?

author: Q
sentence: So this could be a barrier to diversity, if the current board was not diverse but it was performing well then -

author: A
sentence: Yes, there’s no need to change it

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, if it ain’t broke don’t change it

author: A
sentence: Being there for so long and over all those years I’ve learnt a lot, but much of the actual Board member roll process I learnt as I was going

author: A
sentence: What’s transpired over that time is the market has become more regulated and more specific on what they expect board members experience to cover

author: A
sentence: Anyway, I remained on the board as I said 22 years, but it’s a continual ongoing process to stay abreast of all the new evolving regulatory requirements and investor expectations

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: There’s a lot to be said for that

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, and from an investor point of view and they’re so influential, there’s uncertainty that we can’t manage but we can manage the certainty, the stability of the board

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So long as, and I’ve said this before, you have to be – the appointment of what’s her name from the TV personality who’s gone on the ABC?

author: Q
sentence: Ita Buttrose

author: A
sentence: Ita Buttrose

author: A
sentence: I mean she looks good and everything like that, but at 75 I would be very sceptical of putting someone at 75 years of age

author: A
sentence: Someone could be bright and smart but - just to give you an example one of our board members who was getting up to 72, he was a very knowledgeable man and a very nice gentleman, but he got to the point where he forgot the AGM or he missed it somehow and there was another occasion when he missed meetings

author: A
sentence: You start to wonder when the drop off point is at an age, and I think you’ve got to be very conscience of age and related ongoing cognitive skills

author: Q
sentence: Do you recognise that through skills, like forgetting meetings and things like that, or do you make an age where we can cut off?  What do you feel?

author: A
sentence: Well generally the term’s three years and you can change in that period I think when you get to that age point

author: A
sentence: The older you become you realise, that for some, yeah you lose the plot –

author: Q
sentence: More vulnerable

author: A
sentence: Yeah, you’re more vulnerable to things

author: A
sentence: I think you’ve got to be very careful, and not only that, with the way things are now with – sorry

author: A
sentence: [Phone call interruption]

author: Q
sentence: So you said it became more regulated, was there an event like the HIH crash or something that triggered it?

author: A
sentence: [End part one] [Start part two]

author: A
sentence: What was I saying? I’ve lost my track now

author: Q
sentence: Oh age

author: Q
sentence: Forgetting where we are, you know

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: I just think boards have got to be very careful about that, and whilst someone may have had a lot of experience in that field you’ve got to be very conscious of yeah, you can lose it a bit

author: A
sentence: And not only that, with cyber activity, with all the technical data stuff that comes on, it just changes so quickly

author: A
sentence: We know from our phones and all that sort of thing, and you don’t necessarily as you get older keep up with that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: I think if you’re acting on behalf of younger investors you’ve got to have someone in there who’s fairly astute or up with it or be able to absorb that sort of stuff

author: A
sentence: The dynamics of business is just changing so quickly that you can’t afford to have someone who’s just on the fringe

author: Q
sentence: A balance perhaps

author: Q
sentence: It’s a mix

author: A
sentence: Oh yes, I’m not saying you wipe them off

author: A
sentence: You have to assess them

author: A
sentence: And how young do you go on a board?  What was I, 48 or something?  Generally I think independent directors are at least are over 50 any rate I think most

author: A
sentence: I don’t know, you’d know more than me

author: Q
sentence: I’ve been interviewing people in their early 40s, and someone said she was on a board, her first board when in her 30s, she’s 32

author: Q
sentence: So it depends doesn’t it?

author: A
sentence: Well yeah it depends on how big your company is and all that sort of thing –

author: Q
sentence: Of course, yeah

author: Q
sentence: A lot of these young people are getting on boards, they’re not paid positions and it’s to get board experience so they can get on the sort of board you’re talking about

author: A
sentence: Yes I know, a friend of mine is doing that too

author: A
sentence: Look I can’t remember specifically back then whether there was or there wasn’t, I just think there’s more expectations by investors, I think there was a lot more super funds coming out of the woodwork that wanted investment on behalf of clients and things like that

author: A
sentence: So potentially the backwash from some of those investors, they asked more questions and their expectations were a bit higher on regulation and all that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So maybe that was relevant

author: A
sentence: Certainly after the GFC things tightened up a bit more as well

author: Q
sentence: Do you feel that tensions can arise in board selection between on the one hand trying to obtain a collegiate fit, so to manage the culture of your board, and on the other hand trying to avoid groupthink or everyone thinking the same way?  Do you think that tension can arise in who you select between those two?  “This one will get on really well with our culture, respect, openness, whatever else, but there’s a risk of groupthink

author: A
sentence: And you’re saying should you –

author: Q
sentence: Would you feel that there can be tension?  When you’re instructing the head hunters, “This is the sort of person we want” how do you manage that tension?

author: A
sentence: Well I think first off the head hunters have got to have a good round conference with the directors or the people who are wanting to form the group of people, the chairman, to ensure that they have on board exactly what you’re looking for

author: A
sentence: Then after that really if they’re bringing say half a dozen people to you, it’s up to the board to say, “Well really there’s no one there that really fits” or, “Yeah that one fits perfectly

author: A
sentence: ”  I don’t see how you can do it any other way really

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but the fit in terms of culture and the fit in terms of having different ways of looking at things, different backgrounds, different understandings, different skill mix, so getting on, fitting in and bringing all those different understandings including the digital, global, all these different things that come up

author: Q
sentence: So getting that – because you’ve got one person, so you might have someone who’s really good on digital but they are so disrespectful, they don’t listen, and you might find gee, that seems to be what this group are like

author: A
sentence: Well I think I would prioritise someone who’s open and listens to everybody, takes on board and has a firm opinion on what they think, I think I’d prioritise them over someone who had the specific detailed knowledge of the criteria you’re looking for in the business you’re looking for

author: A
sentence: I think discussion opens up everything in any case, it opens it up more, and the more abilities you have within your board to ensure that happens then I think you get more from it, a better result from it rather than someone that might be absolutely a genius in their field but not be able to converse and interact with people and get the right combined result around it

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think I’d tend towards that one

author: Q
sentence: That sounds really sensible

author: Q
sentence: And then with outsource, get your independent expert opinion from that?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, because you always have that as an option outside to go externally and investigate there

author: A
sentence: They’re a little bit more costly and all that sort of thing, but if you get the result that doesn’t matter

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and if it’s important

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: The board that you’re on, do you feel there are any barriers to managing or building diversity?  Let’s say pre global financial crisis and post there’s a lot more regulation now, before it was a different culture really so –

author: A
sentence: With government regulation they’re bringing in more and more refinement of what you can – well reporting systems and all that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: So what sort of expectations do the institutions like the super funds, what did they bring that was new?

author: Q
sentence: On the board itself?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: So you have to be familiar with that

author: A
sentence: Sorry, what was the –

author: Q
sentence: So barriers

author: Q
sentence: Compared to say pre global financial crisis or post, so barriers to diversity, has it changed?

author: A
sentence: No, I don’t think so

author: A
sentence: What I think has changed is the broader and subsequent higher investment knowledge of investors combined with the related associated governances

author: A
sentence: This higher knowledge has subsequently raised investor expectations and progressively necessitated Board makeup to be more diverse to better accommodate the more astute investor sensitivities

author: Q
sentence: You talked about earlier, one thing I picked up was you mentioned, it’s too strong to say cronyism but networks were really important in recruiting people before the financial crisis, but after the culture shifted and the rules shifted, and the influence of your major investors shifted

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: And that put pressure on you to be more focused on –

author: A
sentence: Yes, on people who apply to today’s current market and also governance’s gender diversity, those sorts of things

author: A
sentence: I think you’ve just got to review each one in their own respective fields

author: A
sentence: I don’t think it necessarily has restricted anybody

author: A
sentence: It also depends on the availability of people at the time you’re looking for someone, the availability of that specific type of person you’re looking for

author: A
sentence: Sometimes when there’s a booming market in something they drill down on the people who’ve got that experience and you don’t necessarily have a lot of experience in the field you’re looking for because they’ve all been employed somewhere else

author: A
sentence: So there’s that aspect of it as well

author: Q
sentence: So supply -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So you’ve got a good idea of the history of development of that board for that period –

author: A
sentence: I’m trying to think back that far

author: Q
sentence: - more than regulation

author: Q
sentence: That’s a good point yeah, supply

author: A
sentence: I always used to think geographically you’d want your directors to be in Australia and preferably in Melbourne or Sydney, but that shouldn’t override their experience in bringing to the board

author: A
sentence: I used to fly to Sydney all the time

author: A
sentence: In my mind I don’t think you’d want a board member overseas

author: Q
sentence: At uni what we do now more and more is rely on technology to bring people into meetings, do they use that in boards?

author: A
sentence: We used to use that for our American joint venture partners over there, but there again there’s nothing like a one on meeting

author: Q
sentence: I know –

author: A
sentence: You and I had a meeting today to find out the real personality

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, yeah I know

author: Q
sentence: So even at board level decision making that matters?

author: A
sentence: I think so

author: A
sentence: You do get a better feel, and again it’s only my personal experience

author: A
sentence: I just know from sitting around the table with all those people you get to know their personalities better, what they react to and what they don’t, who’s on their phone in a board meeting and what’s relevant and what’s not to them sort of thing

author: A
sentence: You can see that physically

author: A
sentence: But technology, yeah for the odd meeting here and there that’s fine

author: Q
sentence: You wouldn’t want every meeting to be over Zoom with that person or something?

author: A
sentence: No

author: Q
sentence: Yes, it was history

author: Q
sentence: I get that

author: Q
sentence: We’re nearly finished

author: Q
sentence: From a regulatory perspective how do you feel about the way diversity of boards is currently being promoted?  You mentioned gender targets and quotas to influence board diversity, what do you think about that? Targets I think

author: A
sentence: Absolutely

author: A
sentence: Our REIT Fund Manager, I think their total employment was roughly 50/50, overall in, the company itself

author: A
sentence: Don’t quote me on it but it’s roughly around 50-60%, and I could see it’s just brought a different dimension to a board and a management structure as well

author: A
sentence: I was amazed having worked – I worked for Westfield for many years, and the women were the secretaries in those days, whereas here they’re sitting opposite me in a board meeting today

author: A
sentence: And I think it gives a broader levelling point for a lot of discussion and how it’s conducted and all that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think a different type of female mindset to men sometimes, and if the circumstances is good –

author: Q
sentence: Can I challenge you to give me an example?

author: A
sentence: I’m just trying to think of one

author: A
sentence: Where I found it in my experience was that we managed shopping centres and the most dominant people or gender to shop at shopping centres are female

author: A
sentence: So they generally brought far more personal experiences than the men, and I know the board, without mentioning any names, none of them shopped weekly

author: A
sentence: Well I can’t say none of them, but it appeared from conversation that the majority of shopping was done by their wives and I was the only person on the board who did my own weekly shopping because I live on my own

author: A
sentence: I was familiar with the latest retail trends through my consulting business and you just had to know it from the floor space right up to the Management level about what was going on in retail generally

author: A
sentence: But generally the female Board members had a far better grasp of all aspects of shopping experience than the men

author: A
sentence: They generally confirmed my own thoughts!

author: A
sentence: So from that perspective, in my specific board experience, the female perspective was very much appreciated and valued, the men generally had a different mindset

author: A
sentence: The men think - well she must do it and knows it, she’s been there, but for other company type boards, apart from their specific qualifications / work experience, I’m not sure what the specific female gender inclusion generally adds to an overall Board experience – perhaps some dignity, common sense and communication skills! I have limited broader knowledge in this area

author: Q
sentence: So it’s the different experience that people of different genders can have

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: That then comes in and shapes how they might problem solve with the board

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: They’ll look at it differently, understand it differently

author: Q
sentence: So even though they might be an accountant or a lawyer they have that knowledge, and then it’s this experience which also comes in which is really dependent on gender, ethnicity –

author: A
sentence: Look, it was probably primarily instigated by their financial planners and that who had a greater depth of knowledge in that

author: A
sentence: Maybe there were questions that came up from the clients and then the super funds had to ask more questions

author: A
sentence: I’m really not sure exactly how it evolved

author: A
sentence: Yes, they’re probably more – I shouldn’t say this but females are probably more generally family focused so they’re more familiar with getting the message across

author: A
sentence: I don’t know, I might be wrong in saying that

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so communication style

author: A
sentence: Yeah, they might be better at that, I don’t know

author: A
sentence: They’ve certainly got their place and I have certainly seen a difference since bringing females on a board and more into management

author: Q
sentence: Do you think women have to really - gender equality needs to be at the level of management before it can get to board level?  Do you think one feeds the other?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: You can’t expect to have gender diverse boards if management is skewed toward males for example?

author: A
sentence: Yeah I agree

author: A
sentence: I think the larger companies promote from within, and if there’s structure correctly and the gender is a good 50/50 mix roughly or whatever or they’re promoting that, then I think they have a better, broader choice of who they pick for the better jobs

author: A
sentence: As I said from Trusts Managers perspective I couldn’t believe just how many females they had there and they all just worked together so well

author: Q
sentence: And was this because of targets do you think?

author: A
sentence: I think initially targets were the instigator, but in the finish – there again I don’t know directly, but I would’ve thought that they saw the results so they kept doing it

author: Q
sentence: So it was a good stimulus?

author: Q
sentence: And were the questions around financial accountability or -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: As a regulation it’s a good stimulus and then the proof was in the pudding, it was successful

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: I think they just saw that gee, this is all right, so they kept on promoting that type of diverse gender employment because they saw the results were there

author: A
sentence: And the blokes who promote your Executives to potential clients, gradually saw that females were just as good in these positions as the men

author: A
sentence: I haven't been on the office floor space to experience it first hand, but I just got that feeling when I walk up into the Head Office that everybody worked well together

author: Q
sentence: Excellent

author: Q
sentence: Did that take long do you think?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: From what I could see it – when the Property Management brought it out about five or six years ago and they then moved to a new open plan office, walking in there for meetings I can just see there was more and more women in the last three to five years

author: Q
sentence: So five years you’ve really got an effect and you’ll see it at the board level?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think so

author: A
sentence: In the last 3 years of my term, we included our first female Independent Director as well as a Deputy Fund Manager who is an obvious pick for a future Director

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: Do you think there’s a kind of diversity that matters which can’t be measured, like you can’t regulate it in terms of targets or voters?

author: A
sentence: Which can’t be measured, not sure what -

author: Q
sentence: So we’re looking at regulation of boards in terms of diversity, I know you use your head hunters to get people for a cultural fit for example, it would be very hard to set targets to support that wouldn’t it, like the government pass regulation?

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Yeah, absolutely

author: A
sentence: I think the targets come from a company experience, just like I said, that they naturally bring on board more women

author: A
sentence: I think that’s also come about through the generations there’s more and more women who have got that education experience as well

author: A
sentence: So it’s been a natural progression in any case underlying with education

author: A
sentence: So there’s just been more and more women come through which have been given those opportunities, whereas before the mum stayed at home and they didn’t have that sort of thing

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s a transition of something which is happening in the education sector in any case, and it’s to necessarily forced upon them, it’s just a natural progression

author: Q
sentence: That’s right

author: Q
sentence: So it would be unfair in fact if we didn’t have equality

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: If you were a firm that 70-80% are all men there’d be something wrong I would –

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, but it might be wrong at the education system rather than – it might be that no women go into engineering

author: A
sentence: Yeah well that could be right too, they may not be in that field

author: A
sentence: I’m just trying to think – plumbers

author: Q
sentence: Yeah plumbers and engineering and mining and stuff there’s fewer women

author: Q
sentence: Coming along

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so the final question is looking 10 years into the future now how would you like to see diversity of Australian boards?

author: A
sentence: In 10 years?  Well I don’t see it changing much from what it currently is, and when I say currently I think in the last three or four years it’s really got into that perspective where boards are balancing more on the gender through what we just discussed

author: A
sentence: It’s just a natural progression of women in fields that men are in now and come in

author: A
sentence: So I can’t see it changing that much because we’re already there

author: Q
sentence: What about going back to the global financial crisis and the conversation we had around crisis, wake up, we don’t know enough about America and their systems, we don’t know enough about whatever else contributed to that crisis where we were caught on our back feet and we lost a lot

author: Q
sentence: So what about that kind of diversity that you said well now you’d have people who are experienced with the American financial system on board

author: Q
sentence: So not just gender, now we’re talking all the other sorts of diversity; the skills and backgrounds and experience

author: Q
sentence: - responsible investment, socially responsible -

author: A
sentence: What else could change?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, in 10 years time what do you think with that sort of broadened understanding where are we heading?

author: A
sentence: I think it’s more of a world market, so you’ve got to be more familiar with world markets

author: A
sentence: But I’m talking in the larger companies, not necessarily a local company

author: A
sentence: But even so, even if it’s local it certainly is a world market and you’ve got to be more familiar with what’s going on in economies and things like that, and you’ve got to be conscious of all that and how it affects your business

author: A
sentence: So I think you’ve probably just got to become more worldly as to the economics and what’s transitioning in the world in terms of trends because it’s going to affect you in some way or another

author: A
sentence: How do you get that?  Well you can research it online these days and become aware, you can go and see it firsthand in a country somewhere, but certainly the world is one and we’re affected on a daily basis by what’s happening over the other side of the world somewhere and you’ve got to be up with it and more familiar with it

author: A
sentence: So someone who’s into that and someone who experiences that on a day to day would be more likely to be promoted I suppose, someone who shows experience in that field

author: Q
sentence: We talked about Zoom technology and things like that, that boards might actually have members from different countries and they meet using technology so you don’t have to all fly

author: Q
sentence: So that would be a very different looking board –

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Look, no doubt there are big large international companies that are Australian based that you must have someone from overseas where they have investments represented, because if you don’t have that then you don’t have the firsthand knowledge of the economy and the firsthand experience of what your investors are thinking

author: A
sentence: So certainly for big companies - I think I said before you shouldn’t have an overseas director but with those big companies most definitely you have to because they bring that perspective of their local market to the board level

author: A
sentence: From that perspective you’ve got to be more worldly I think in your attitude and your knowledge as a board member

author: Q
sentence: Do you think government, it might be law, institutions like the law and banking needs to do something to facilitate this future?

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily

author: A
sentence: I think the world is so small how everybody travels I think they do it on their own accord

author: Q
sentence: It’s done anyway, yeah

author: A
sentence: From what I can see is that the younger executives of the world, many of them work overseas when they’re younger while they’re travelling and they go and work somewhere and then come back after a few years

author: A
sentence: So I think it’s something that’s done in their own time and you don’t necessarily have to promote it

author: A
sentence: I think the younger ones see that in any case

author: A
sentence: Just about everybody travels these days and they travel when they’re young so they become familiar with more worldly affairs than they used to be

author: A
sentence: So I think that’s naturally occurring in any case

author: A
sentence: All those sorts of things, yeah

author: A
sentence: With IT coming in and cyber security and all that sort of thing and sustainability, these sorts of things going round the woodwork as well

author: A
sentence: The odd thing to do with climate change and what does your company do with refuse removal in my case and how does that get recycled and things like that

author: A
sentence: So I think that’s how it evolved, but I think it was a slow process

author: Q
sentence: And there are no Australian laws that interfere with this global engaged board?  Not that you’re aware of?

author: A
sentence: Not that I’m aware of but it could’ve changed in the last two years for all I know but it’s just I’ve been retired

author: A
sentence: I think generally speaking most Australian companies only invest in companies where they know they can identify with their own local laws there which is similar to ours, I’m not saying all of them

author: A
sentence: There was a lot of scepticism about going into China initially, but they’ve recently become more westernised in their approach, but there’s still companies that wouldn’t invest in China just yet

author: A
sentence: The more westernised and aligned that overseas countries are in the same mentality around governances and things like that, I think that’s just a worldly thing and people would become accustomed to it in any case, be more lenient about it

author: Q
sentence: This is so interesting

author: Q
sentence: This is the last question, I promise I’m going to let you go

author: Q
sentence: From an Australian board perspective, let’s say going to China major investment opportunities happening there probably well into the future, the expectation is that they adopt a western type governance framework so that we can engage as Australian –

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: Q
sentence: So diversity doesn’t extend to, “Okay, we will learn to play the rules of Confuciun whatever” –

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: “You really have to fit in with our governance frameworks

author: A
sentence: Well yeah, it’s got to work both ways obviously, and if you’re a publically listed company you’ve still got to be compliant with all the regulations here which take into consideration what interaction you do overseas

author: A
sentence: It’s still got to be aligned with Australia –

author: Q
sentence: With our laws, yeah

author: A
sentence: With our laws

author: A
sentence: As I said there’s a lot of companies that wouldn’t go to China but a lot more do now because – that’s the same with Japan once upon a time, after the war no one would go there but now you do

author: A
sentence: So I think things are changing in that way and it’s just becoming a more worldly market overall and you’ve got to be aware of what’s going on around you everywhere, not just in your home country

author: Q
sentence: So how important do you think it is to have a diverse board?  Let’s say 10 is extremely important and one is not important at all where would you put it?

author: Q
sentence: I think globalisation is a very nice line to finish on which you just finished on, that’s so good

author: Q
sentence: So unless you have any final comments you’d like to make on board diversity?

author: A
sentence: No

author: A
sentence: What I did bring, and I don’t know whether you’re aware of these things –

author: Q
sentence: Probably not

author: A
sentence: Have you seen these skills metrics reports?

author: Q
sentence: No I haven't but I’ve heard about them

author: A
sentence: This is the last one that I did and I just wanted to show you the types of questions that you – yes, no and a score and all that

author: Q
sentence: Brilliant

author: Q
sentence: Would I be able to have that or is that private?

author: A
sentence: It’s not private, no it was up – let me just double check

author: A
sentence: I think it’s –

author: Q
sentence: No names on it?

author: A
sentence: No I’m pretty sure they said it was up on the website so they could see because this is the final summary of it

author: A
sentence: But that’s the type of question we had

author: A
sentence: I’d have to say nine

author: A
sentence: I mean if you can describe to me what you mean by diversity that would help me a bit

author: Q
sentence: This is what you’re talking about, the head hunters used to screen people and then you guys –

author: A
sentence: No, no, this is what we as an existing board – about every two years you go through and see whether the board’s up to scratch or not –

author: Q
sentence: To analyse your capacity, your skills

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Is that how it’s used?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Well if I could – do you want me to check if it’s on the web and if it’s not on the web I can’t use it?

author: A
sentence: Yes if you could do that because I’m pretty sure it’s up on the website but that’s 2017 or something isn't it?

author: Q
sentence: I’ll look for it on the web and if it’s not there then I know I can’t use it

author: Q
sentence: I’ll say only use if available on web

author: Q
sentence: Otherwise I can have it as my understanding, so when they say it I know right, that’s what they’re using

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Board evaluations – yeah, that was brought in around about 2014 I think that boards had to do some formal metrics like that on board skills

author: A
sentence: Yeah, I think it was 2014

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to ask you what you think because it’s really how you perceive it, not how I do

author: Q
sentence: Brought in 2014 to evaluate

author: Q
sentence: So it’s to evaluate your own capacity

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well that’s something that’s changed because in the early days we were never interviewed on a regular basis by anybody, but then every two years our chairman sat down with us and would say, “Where are we going her? How do you feel about everything?”and you had a meeting, and then this has been up-scaled now to be more formalised for me independently like that

author: A
sentence: So that’s the sort of thing that’s changed

author: Q
sentence: I imagine the big investors you talked about, looking at this they think that’s appropriate, this is good

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: Q
sentence: Do they also say the gender mix now?

author: A
sentence: They probably do, well they can see it on the annual reports

author: Q
sentence: Yeah right, the annual reports say it

author: A
sentence: Well they’ve got all the pictures they have to provide in the annual report

author: A
sentence: All the pictures and that are in there

author: Q
sentence: And that’s on the web?

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Yeah

author: A
sentence: Well I just think it’s a broad knowledge of all aspects to do with whatever the investment type is

author: A
sentence: So in my case it was shopping centres, so my aspect of the board’s specific influence was around shopping centre management and development and all that sort of thing, but of course you have to have people who are good with finance, people who are good with governance issues and all that sort of thing, and they’ve become more specific now on those types of people being on boards

author: A
sentence: Finance issues, governance issues, that’s what I said

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s brilliant, thank you, I’ve taken more of your time than –

author: A
sentence: No that’s all right

author: A
sentence: After not being in a board meeting in two years you really have to think about it

author: Q
sentence: Don’t worry

author: Q
sentence: I’m going to turn this off so you can -

author: Q
sentence: So different skills?

author: A
sentence: Yes, there are a number of different skills that you have to bring in, and if those specific skills relate to the type of investment you’re doing it’s even better

author: Q
sentence: The type of investment?

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s important that they have some form of knowledge of the type of investment or what the company is investing in, some sort of knowledge in that

author: A
sentence: But that’s not always possible, but eventually progressively you bring people into that

author: A
sentence: For instance nobody was a specialist in cyber security once upon a time, and now you’ll find there’s more people who have a knowledge and background of that, and that’s in their accounting and economics and things like that they get that

author: Q
sentence: Please have your coffee, I notice you like it very hot

author: Q
sentence: Okay, that’s good

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that there is any situational context that might cause you to change that importance rating you gave?  So maybe high uncertainty, high risk you think oh well diversity is not as important in that situation

author: A
sentence: I can’t think of any but as I said to you had I been involved on a number of boards that may raise a few issues but -

author: Q
sentence: We’re getting across a number of people, so from your experience in this board no

author: Q
sentence: That’s good

author: Q
sentence: So what does board diversity mean to you?  So skills, what about there’s a lot of talk about cognitive diversity and that’s like different approaches to problem solving, ways of thinking, so it’s not so much the skills

author: Q
sentence: Does that matter?

author: A
sentence: It’s thinking outside the box a bit, is that what you mean?

author: Q
sentence: Exactly, that sort of thing yeah so as everyone’s not on the -

author: Q
sentence: So that’s really a unique perspective which won’t show up as an identifier, but you have a good historical perspective so that’s really useful

author: Q
sentence: So thank you very much

author: Q
sentence: My understanding is that you recently -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well that generally forms part of your management team under the board to initiate those sorts of things, but it’s certainly helpful if you can find someone who has that capacity to think outside the square, and I’m not saying that they’re not, it’s just generally I’ve noted in my experience that the board members that I associated with, they’re generally over 60 at least and because cyber and because of digitalisation and things like that are a new form of control and that sort of thing in businesses, they’re not fully aware of the updating and all that and they rely on management to bring that through  to them

author: A
sentence: To a large degree, I’m not saying all

author: A
sentence: But it’s just evolving so fast that it’s hard to find people who have all that experience of a younger person who’s just learning all that type of thing and being involved with it on a day to day basis

author: Q
sentence: Do you think having a mix of age on the board is good then, diversity in terms of age?

author: A
sentence: Yes, most definitely

author: Q
sentence: What about gender?

author: A
sentence: Whatever, if the person fits the bill whatever gender

author: Q
sentence: It’s more irrelevant than -

author: A
sentence: Yes, it’s more important to have the people who are experienced so if the gender, male or female fits that bit you go with that

author: Q
sentence: Now there’s been a recent inclusion of ethnicity, sexual orientation, do you think those kinds of diversity matter or once again back to the depends on the skills?

author: A
sentence: Not necessarily

author: A
sentence: I think first and foremost its skills, then if someone with whatever background then fits that bill well - in my experience when I retired from the board, I know the person who replaced me, he was a gay man, but a very well experienced person

author: A
sentence: Retired

author: Q
sentence: It wasn’t because he was gay, it’s because of his -

author: A
sentence: No, very experienced

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: We’ve talked about different kinds of diversity, skills - you’ve really come down to skills, that’s the most important, so I’m going to say does a particular kind of diversity matter more than others?

author: A
sentence: Skills and knowledge of the investment that you’re in

author: Q
sentence: Skills and knowledge, okay beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Now we want to understand a bit about the board functioning and how diversity works there

author: Q
sentence: Are there particular board functions that you think diversity can really help with, so having the diverse skills and knowledge, and also can you give me an example, a story?

author: A
sentence: Let me think

author: A
sentence: Again I can only refer to my position -

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, do

author: A
sentence: In my experience in management of real estate and development of real estate I’m thinking ask more direct questions to the management of any company, and you can drill down on them and make them more accountable for what they present to you at board  meetings

author: A
sentence: So again from my experience I could go right down to the finer points of management, leasing and development, and they were aware that if they came to our board meetings, the management side of things, then they would be asked questions and sometimes that’ll be out of leftfield

author: A
sentence: So they had to be properly prepared for all sorts of circumstances and questions

author: A
sentence: Does that answer your question?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah it does

author: Q
sentence: So the particular skill that you brought, that skill and knowledge, that enabled the board to make potential investors much more accountable or the board’s decisions more accountable because you could really understand the offering, is that how you’d sort of -

author: A
sentence: Yes

author: A
sentence: Well the investors relied upon you as an independent director to ask those questions on their behalf essentially

author: A
sentence: So they had to see, and there are new platforms being set up more recently whereby investors can convey their thoughts to these specific external platforms who question the knowledge and the broad spectrum of what their experience is and what their board runs and manages

author: A
sentence: So these platforms directly ask the questions on behalf of the investors why is this done, why isn't that being done, boom, boom, boom

author: A
sentence: And more particularly when a board member has come up for re-election they put their two bob’s worth in, so what their investors should think of him or whatever, take your vote this way or that way

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, you recently retired from the board, but we’ll consider it - was it a not for profit or for profit?

author: A
sentence: So there’s more and more of that, but we found also that for overseas investors they were using people who just asked the question from far away, these sorts of things, and weren’t very familiar with the actual person who was on the board who was an independent director, whereas the Australian people could actually link with them and have a chat to them and become more familiar with what they were all about

author: A
sentence: So they weren’t necessarily a good representation for their investors to take on board their opinions, and we found there were some issues with that, that they were really pushing the wrong barrel

author: A
sentence: I mean they were trying to get rid of some directors whose turn was up but they were really very, very good and even the local investors thought they were very, very good, but because of the isolation of the people doing the enquiries they got it wrong in a lot of things

author: Q
sentence: Okay

author: Q
sentence: So is this like a social media platform?

author: A
sentence: No, it’s a -

author: Q
sentence: What’s it called?

author: A
sentence: I’m just trying to think of the description, what they do there

author: A
sentence: It’s a body that sort of investigates companies and their boards and their structures and all that sort of thing, and gives independent opinions on where it’s going and what’s currently relevant

author: A
sentence: I’ve forgotten the actual name that they use for it

author: A
sentence: Proxy Advisors, that’s it

author: A
sentence: It’s a more recent thing

author: Q
sentence: Okay, so we’re onto here

author: Q
sentence: So conversely are there board functions that diversity can limit or undermine? So having people from different background and skills on your board, do you think that can undermine or reduce the function of your board decision making et cetera?

author: A
sentence: I haven't experienced that

author: A
sentence: I think a lot of it is to do with also who the chairman is and his willingness to create an environment with the board that encourages questions and openness

author: A
sentence: I think if you’ve got a good chairman and he does that then you find that everything comes to the surface, whatever the issue whether personal issues with particular people/management, or the way it’s run, anything like that

author: A
sentence: I think the chairman has a key role and if you have a person that does that and encourages that sort of thing then I think it’s a smoother board and there’s more openness in it

author: A
sentence: Does that answer the question?

author: Q
sentence: Yeah that’s really good

author: Q
sentence: So the chair really creates an open culture so that everyone – and that marries with -

author: A
sentence: Yeah, it’s an inclusion of everybody’s thoughts and -

author: A
sentence: For profit, yeah

author: Q
sentence: Beautiful

author: Q
sentence: Do you think that sort of inclusive culture on the board is essential for diversity to work?

author: A
sentence: Yes, I think it’s good to have people who assimilate with that and also have an openness towards that

author: A
sentence: In general they are

author: A
sentence: Just to get to that position those people have that sort of culture in them in any case that they’re, aggressive is the wrong word, but you don’t get to that position if you’re a quiet person sitting on the board

author: A
sentence: They generally have that in their day to day mindset in any case to do that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: Their DNA is to get involved, but what about to be respectful of other people’s points of view?

author: A
sentence: Yes I think that’s inbuilt into them

author: A
sentence: They may not agree with them but they do respect them, yeah

author: A
sentence: I think at that level generally people deliver that type of thing, they’re quite respectful of each other

author: A
sentence: And again that’s a chairman to run the meeting so it is respectful I think, that’s his job

author: Q
sentence: Do you have rules of how to be, how to listen to each other, is there an explicit value statement or anything to guide this on a board or -

author: A
sentence: No, I’ve never heard of one

author: Q
sentence: I’m hoping it’s not needed but anyway

author: A
sentence: I think that’s all in your initial selection of a new board member and the culture that you’re trying to create within a board, and you only take on people who maybe fit with that culture to a certain degree

author: Q
sentence: And that culture is not people of the same ilk, it’s -

author: A
sentence: Yes, it’s a culture of being expressive and air your viewpoints and listen to others and take on board everybody’s opinions

author: A
sentence: Well that’s how our board used to work, we only took on people that had that sort of expression within them, and when you interviewed them you hinted at that to see if they had that sort of culture in them

author: A
sentence: But I think that’s really how it works, yeah

author: Q
sentence: And was it in finance industry?

author: Q
sentence: We’ve got a section we’re coming to on selection so I think we’ll hold that point and just look at is there – some people think that diversity can contribute to conflict on the board, I’m just wondering if you’ve seen that, I mean there must be disagreement, and if so how was that conflict managed?  Can you recall a situation where -

author: A
sentence: I think the more issues that arise between directors whether you’d call it conflict or debate I think the better

author: A
sentence: There’s a process that you have a vote at the end of the day to put issues through, so ultimately it ends up it’s all done in the correct manner in any case, in an organised manner

author: Q
sentence: I’m really keen to know because in theory they use words like conflict not debate, and I’m really interested because I intuitively understand there’s a difference, can you describe the difference on the board, this is a debate, this is conflict? Can you give me a -

author: A
sentence: I’m trying to think of whether that ever arose

author: Q
sentence: Even make it up, what would it be? Conflict’s like this -

author: A
sentence: Yes well again the conflict would be between the independent directors and the directors, and in my case we had a trust of properties and it was managed externally

author: A
sentence: So the other board, the other directors representing the management company, the conflict that we had if any was fee structure, that we had to pay them a fee and it was based on this

author: A
sentence: But when that occurred we went out to independent advisors to research the day to day market on fee structures to come up with, “Is it right, is it on par or what is it with the rest of the market?” and generally speaking it was

author: A
sentence: As I say they were independent advisors who did that for us on behalf of the directors

author: A
sentence: So that’s probably the only real conflict that we had was always assessing fee structures

author: A
sentence: The management company also had 16% equity in the fund in any case, so they did have money to be lost if that was the case, if there was any incorrect decision or something which swayed their way and not investor’s ways

author: A
sentence: But as I said there’s always independent advisors that you can call in if there was a conflict and we could resolve it with, “Well this is what the outcome was, do you accept it or don’t you accept it?” basically

author: A
sentence: And any type of conflict you can do that, you can have independent advisors on that sort of thing

author: Q
sentence: So probably conflict would be linked to resourcing decisions, money in the end?

author: A
sentence: Well I don’t know what other companies would say but that was the difference between our board and -

author: Q
sentence: That is so good

author: Q
sentence: I’m hoping that in future interviews I’ll see if I can find other examples because that is really good

author: A
sentence: No it was in the property sector; shopping centre

author: A
sentence: Yeah, well that was always a key issue, and investors when we met with them they always raised that issue, “What about the fees?  Are they correct, are they market fees?” and I’d say, “Yeah, here’s the report, we have done boom, boom, boom, this is how they assessed it

author: Q
sentence: So it’s a conflict basically between the investor interest and the management interest?

author: A
sentence: Mm

author: Q
sentence: And you’re the meat in the sandwich really

author: A
sentence: We’re the meat in the sandwich and that’s what we’re there for, we’re there to represent them

author: Q
sentence: Yeah, and you help to resolve it by having an external independent advisor

author: A
sentence: Yeah -

author: Q
sentence: That is a really neat idea

author: A
sentence: And that happened on quite a number of occasions with different types of issues

author: A
sentence: I’m just trying to think of another one

author: Q
sentence: That’s good because it’s an evidence based independent rational process -
